DIV1.HEAD: HISTORY OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.

Q.L: OF THE RIVER TYNE.
"O ye dales
Of Tyne, and ye most ancient woodlands; where
Oft as the giant flood obliquely strides,
And his banks open and his lawns extend,
Stops short the pleased traveller to view
Presiding o'er the scene some rustic tow'r,
Founded by Norman or by Saxon hands."
Q.BIBL: AKENSIDE, Pleasures of Imagin. 4to edit. book iv. line 2.
Q.L: "Or rocky Avon, or of sedgy Lee,

Or coaly Tyne,
Draiton, in his Polyolbion, p. 381, last edition, thus introduces the Tyne, making it, by a well-known poetical figure, describe itself as follows:
"I could, if I did please,
Of my two fountains tell, which of their sundry ways
The south and north are nam'd, entitled both of Tyne,
As how the prosp'rous springs of these two floods of mine
Are distant thirty miles: how that the South-Tyne nam'd
From Stanmore takes her spring, for mines of brass that fam'd;
How that nam'd of the North is out of Wheel Fell sprung,
Amongst these English Alps, which as they run along
England and Scotland here impartially divide;
How South-Tyne, setting out from Cumberland, is ply'd
With Hartley, which her hastes, and Tippall that doth strive,
By her more sturdy stream, the Tyne along to drive;
How th' Allans, th' East and West their bounties to her bring,
Two fair and full-brimm'd floods; how also from her spring
My other North-nam'd Tyne thro' Tyndall maketh in,
Which Shele her handmaid hath, and as she hastes to twin
With th' other from the South, her sister, how clear Rhead
With Perop comes prepar'd, and Chertop me to lead,
Through Ridsdale on my way, as far as Exham, then
Dowell me homage doth, with blood of Englishmen,
Whose stream was deeply dy'd in that most cruel war
Of Lancaster and York. Now having gone so far,
Their strengths me their dear Tyne do wond'rously enrich,
As how clear Darwent draws down to Newcastle, which
The honour hath alone to entertain me there,
As of those mighty ships that in my mouth I bear,
Fraught with my country coal, of this Newcastle nam'd,
For which, both far and near, that place is no less fam'd
Than India for her mines.—" or ancient hallow'd Dee." MILTON.
"The harvest of the river is her revenue." ISAIAH, xxiii. 3.

DIV1.P:
THE different and almost directly opposite derivations of the name of this river, that have been offered by the learned, afford ano∣ther striking proof of the general uncertainty of etymology. It has
been derived by Baxter from a British word, signifying "the extended riverVide Glossarium Antiq. Brit. I. Baxter in verbo.;" while Skinner, on the other hand, deduces it from a Cambro-British epithet rendered by "pent inSee Skinner in verbo.." Though the improbability of this last conjecture is evident, on the first sight of its wide and extensive bed, yet has it the sanction also of Cambden's authority, whom Somner suspects to have mistaken the sense of the British word,
to which he refers it, and to have confounded it with a Saxon one, which greatly resembles it in sound
Tine, fluvius, hodièque sic dictus in Agro Northumbrensi:—So called, saith Cambden, if we may believe the Britons, for that by reason of his narrow banks he is strait pent in; for so signifieth tin, as they say, in the British tongue, so be.— For Britons and British, he should haply have rather said Saxons and Saxonic, the word being of that signification with these (as may be seen in Tinan), but not in those."—Somner, Saxon Dict. in verbo.
Bullet, in his Memoires sur la Langue Celtique, tom. i, p. 346, derives the name of our river from a Celtic word, signifying double, i. e. a river formed of two rivers. "La Tine, rivière formèe de deux rivieres. Ty, deux; Tyn, double. On a étendu par abus le nom de Tine à chacue des rivieres qui la forment.".

The opinion that the names of our rivers are of Saxon origin, has been lately controverted by the author of the History of Manchester, who asserts, with great plausibility of argument, that most of them are British, and the same now as when first imposed"Few of the British names," says he, "have descended to us—The appellations of our places have been all lost, but those of our rivers are generally preserved; the former are confined to a small extent of region, and known only to a few; but rivers flow through a length of country, and communicate their names and waters to different districts and various associations of men; while those, therefore, are easily lost, these are pretty faithfully retained;— such are the Avons, the Cams, the Tynes, &c." He adds, "I have previously shewn the word Avon to have been frequently contracted into An, An, or Un, and as D'Avon and T'Avon are both the same with it, so are they contracted in the same manner; the latter is reduced into Tayne, the name of a frith in Scotland; into Taune or Tone, that of a river in Somersetshire; and into Teyne, that of a current in Staffordshire, &c.".
No literary monuments have been transmitted to inform us with certainty by what name this river was distinguished while the Roman legions were stationed on its banks.

It occurs not as a river of Northumberland in Ptolomy's ancient map of Britain; if it was not then called the Vedra, which is the name of a river marked in it, about the place where that of Tyne ought to be found
Ptolomy is generally thought to have written under Trojan, who began his reign A. D. 99; Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius, who ended his in the year 162. His numerous and manifest errors are very discouraging; the learned and candid Baron Clerk said he always considered Ptolomy amongst the most incorrect of all ancient authors. Several things, however, as Horsley has observed, might justly be pleaded to excuse his inac∣curacies, and great allowances must be made for the time in which he wrote. This must apologize for his omission of the Tine, and of Newcastle under any name, "for," adds the same ingenious writer "unless Vedra mean the Tine, and Ostia Vedrae, the Roman station and town at the mouth of this river, near South-Sheilds, they are nameless in this Geographer."
See Bourne's History of Newcastle, p. 157..

The present appellation of this river is implied in the first accounts of a religious house at Tinmouth, evidently so called from its vicinity to the mouth of the Tyne, which was first erected a little after the beginning of the seventh centuryA little after the year of Christ 617. See account of that monastery..

This river occurs, with its present name, in Bede's Church History, under the year 685Bede is speaking of John, Bishop of Hexham, who had a hermitage opposite to that place, on the north side of the river: "Est mansio quaedam secretior nemore rara et vallo circumdata non longe ab Hagustaldensi Ecclesia, id est, unius fermè millarii et dimidii spatio, interfluente Tino amne separata, &c." Bede, lib. v. cap. 2., and in an ancient record belonging to the church of Durham, sub anno 863A. D. 863, et regni Aellae Regis Northumbror' 5o. Et Fardulphi Episcopi Lindis∣sernensis 14o. Haldena Danorum Dux crudelis multa cum classe Tinam ingrediens circa Tinemouth, &c." (Excerpta e Libro Ecclesiae Cathedralis Dunelm' cui Titulus Liber Ruber, cap. 1. Grey's Collection of MSS.).
The same appellation occurs, in the Saxon Chronicle, under the year 875The Saxon Chronicle is speaking of Healsden's wintering with some part of his army in Northumberland. "be Tinan.".

From records cited by Spearman, in his Inquiry into the State of Durham, it appears that, in the time of William the Conqueror, the boundaries of this river were described, at which early period the bishop of that see had the south part of it boundering upon this county palatine"Turris London ss. Record' Marchiar'; whereby the meets and bounds of the river Tyne are described as then enjoyed; and the Bishop of Durham had then the south part thereof next his county palatine. Vide Recorda tempore Willielmi Conquest' Regis." (Spearman's Durham, p. 7.).

Records of the dates of William Rufus', Henry I.'s and Henry II.'s reigns, ascertain the river Tyne to have been the ancient boundary
between the county of Northumberland, and the bishoprick of Dur∣ham; and that from Stanley-Burn to Tinmouth, a moiety of the water thereof, on the south, belonged to St. Cuthbert, and the see of Durham; that another moiety thereof, on the north, appertained to the county of Northumberland; and that the third and middle division was common and free: the whole is to be measured at high tide
The following is copied from the Tinmouth Chartulary remaining at Northumber∣land-house, fol. 184.
"De aqua Tyne.
"Quia comitatus Northumbrie dudum fuit jus et hereditas cujusdam Roberti de Mowbraye & successorum suorum. Qui quidem Robertus fuit comes comitatus predicti tempore Willielmi Regis filii Willielmi Conquestoris et eorundem tempore fuit Randulphus Episcopus Dunelm' Qui quidem Randulphus et predecessores sui et comes et antecessores sui fuerunt de episcopatu et comitatu predict' comitivè Inter quos episcopatum et co∣mitatum aqua erat marchia ab omni tempore Ita videlicet quod una medietas aque predicte versus Austrum semper remansit predicto episcopo et predecessoribus suis ut jus ecclesie sue Sancti Cuthberti Dunelmen' et altera medietas versus Boream semper re∣mansit predicto comiti & successoribus suis ut jus comitatus predicti. Ita tamen quod tercia pars tocius aque predicte versus Austrum semper erat seperabilis predicto episcopo et predecessoribus suis et tertia pars totius aque predicte versus Boream semper erat seperabilis predicto comiti & successoribus suis. Et tertia pars totius aque predicte in medio ejusdem aque semper erat libera & communis omnibus navibus et batellis ibidem ementibus pro proficuo et aisiamento dominorum possess' tam in episcopatu quam in comitatu predictis inhabitancium.
Tempore Regis Henrici primi filii Regis Willielmi facta est concordia (de) Piscaria de Tyna secundum quod antiquiores tocius Halywersolke et Northumberlande juraverunt tempore Ranulphi Episcopi in presencia Walteri Specke et Eustacii filii Johannis Justic' quod a Stanburnemouth usque Tynemouth, videlicet usque in mare mdietas aque de Tyna pertinet ad Sanctum Cuthbertum et episcopatum Dunelmensem et alia medietas ad comitatum Northumbr' Ita tamen quod trtia pars utriusque erit communis et libera in medio. Eadem aqua debet monstari (mensurari) ad mainslode quando eadem aqua fluit ut sit plena banck et banck. Et omnes piscarie habent nomina et loca, &c.
C'est record first trove en le Rouge Liver en le Tresory a Lunders par Sir Robert de Willower en temps Anton Evecke de Durame, et le dit Mons. Robert prist le copi hors de liver et la livera a Sir Nicholl Gatgang, et les parcels precedentz, et le debat ue del Ewe de Tyne en temps le Roy Henri primer entre Lesveke Randolf et les Gentz de Northumberlande. i. e. This record was found in the Red Book in the Treasury (Exchequer) at London, by Sir Robert de Willower, in the time of Anthony, Bishop of Durham; and the said Sir Robert took a copy out of the book, and delivered it, and the parcels aforesaid, to Sir Nicholas Gatgang. And this controversy was con∣cerning the water of Tyne, in the time of Henry I. between the Bishop Randolph and the people of Northumberland.
The Murray MS. p. 205, has the same: after the above "nomina et loca," it goes on, "hec recordatio facta est a senioribus de Aleworkefolke et Northumbr' tempore Regis Henrici secundi coram justic' Angliae scilicet Rogero Archiepiscopo Ebor' Roberto Episcopo Lincoln' et Hugone Episcopo Dunelm' et Ricardo de Lucy apud Novum Castellum," with the subsequent attestation: "Vera copia, Rob. Daile, dep. cler. cancellar. Dunelm.".

The Tyne, at those very early periods, abounded with fisheries, con∣cerning which it is not improbable that a competition of interests might have first occasioned the above division
From an ancient MS. in the library of Thomas Astle, Esq fol. 114.
"Nota de aqua de Tyne. Memorandum quod tempore Henrici primi filii Regis Willielmi facta est recordacio de piscariis de Tyna secundum quod antiquiores totius Haliwerisfolk et Northumbrie juraverunt tempore Ranulfi Episcopi in presencia Walteri de Speck et Eustachii filii Johannis justiciariorum quod scilicet a Stanleyburne usque ad Tynemuthe videlicet usque in mari medictas aque de Tyna pertinet ad Sanctum Cuthbertum et ad episcopatum Dunelmen' et alia medictas ad comitatum de Northum∣bria Tertia pars in medio aque erit communis et libera Et eadem aqua mensurari debet al' Maienflodh quando eadem aqua ita fluit ut sit plena de banck en banck Et omnes piscarie habent loca et nomina. Hec piscarie incipiunt ad Stanleyburne et pertin∣gunt usque ad mare. Prima piscaria Sancte Hildeyare et Ebbeyare que pertinent ad Wynestowe Ad Jarue pertinent iste piscarie Ful-Yare in Pul Ebbe-Yare Aches-Yare th-Yare Hutrede's-Yare Stanre-Yare. Ad Munchestum pertinent iste piscarie Fule-Yare Hungre-Yare Ad Heberine Peth-Yare Sywyne-Yare Uthward-Yare Ad Hewrithe mor' Uthward-Yare Uth-Yare Londe-Yare Hoochemunges-Yare Bondene-Yare Fid∣dene-Yare.
Hec sunt piscarie de terra monachorum quas antiquitus habuerunt. Alie vero que subscripte sunt pertinent ad terram Dunelm' Episcopi Ad Gateshaved Goureth Cuiper Hit-Yare Bosi-Hongri-Yare Dike-Yare Olfletes-Yare Chirche-Yare et alia Chirche-Yae Lether-Hose Grene-Yare Deaphe-Yare Offulnes-Yare Malde-Yare Littell-Yare Bonde-Yare Duo Comuthe-Yares Ad Quickam Tinnmuthes-Yare Hul∣omes-Yare Grip Rote Vornerk Deape-Yare Alcherles-Yare Heh-Werestein Ad Derewente-Mouth una Sagena Seth-Brannet Ad Wynlanton Berde-Yare Bladene-Yare Due Sagene que vocantur Toletpula Quatuor Stelentes Duo Rednettes ad Ritonam Crumbwell Wythes-pole Stampul-Pul Quatuor Stelentes ad Cranecruc Buresfordes-Pull.
Hec recordacio facta est a senioribus de Haliwerisfolk et Northumbrie tempore Regis entici secundi coram justiciariis Anglie videlicet Rogero Archiepiscopo Ebor' et Ro∣berto Episcopo Lincolniens' et Hugone Episcopo Dunelm' et Ricardo de Lice apud Novum Castellum Et ex illa parte Tyne habent monachi Dunelm' octo piscarias scilicet ad Gateshende Bondewe-Yare Wales-Yare Utwardis-Yare Holmes-Yare Ad Wynelyngton Teotting-Yare Simpes-Yare Rahgere Utwardis-Yare.".

King Henry I. granted a confirmation of customs, of St. Cuthbert's division of the water of this river, to the then Bishop of Durham, which Ranulph, a former bishop of that see, had made good before the said king and his barons, against the inhabitants of Northumber∣land
"Charta Henrici primi regis Angliae Ranulpho Flambard Episcopo Dunelm' de consuetudinibus in aquis Sancti Cuthberti de Tyna quas Ranulphus Episcopus dira∣cionavit adversus Northumbrenses in sua et baronum suorum presentia." Spearman's Durham, p. 7. Also, Record read at the Jarrow-Slake trial..

Which customs were also confirmed to St. Cuthbert, and the above see, by King Henry the SecondMurray MS. p. 206. "Ego Henricus Dei gratia Rex Angl' &c. Sanct' Cuthbert et Ranulph Episcop' tempore Regis Henrici avi mei—Calumpniabantur consuetudines in aqua Sancti Cuthberti in Tyna quas omnes consuetudines et earum calumnias di∣racionavit adversus eos Ranulphus Episcopus in presentia Henrici Regis avi mei et baronum fuorum sicut carta predict' Regis Henrici avi mei testatur. Et ego Deo et Sancto Cuthberto et ecclesiae Dunelm' et Hugoni Episcopo & omnibus successori∣bus suis omnes libertates impertuum concedo et confirmo. Teste Roberto Linc' Episcopo, &c. apud Eboracum." Vera copia et ex' per Rob. Daile, cler' canc' Dun∣elm'.,

King Henry II. granted, or confirmed, to the then Bishop of Dur∣ham, that ships should be allowed to moor on his side of the river, as was done on the opposite shore of the Tyne
"Charta Henrici secundi Regis Episcopo Dunelm' de applicatione navium ex parte sua in Tyna tam libere honorificè et quietè sicut rex habet ex altera parte." Spearman's Durham, p 7, et seq.
King Henry IId.'s grant or confirmation. Quod episcopus haberet libere honorifice et quietè applicationes navium ex parte sua in Tyna sicut habent ex altera p. Record read at Jarrow-Stake trial..

In a charter of King John, to the prior and monks of Durham, of the date of 1204, he granted them (inter alia) Gerwy, and the fisheries of Tyne; confirming to them, at the same time, a fishery in that
river, which had been given to St. Cuthbert by Nicholas de Grene∣vill
Murray MS. p. 222. "Ex rotulo chartar' de anno regni Regis Johannis quinto, m. 13, charta monachor' Dunelm' apud Newport 2 die Februarii anno &c. quinto. Johannes Dei gratia, &c. sciatis nos concessisse & confirmasse in puram et perpetuam elemosinam Deo & Sancto Cuthberto & priori et monachis ibidem Deo servientibus omnes terras et decimas et ecclesias, &c. viz. Gerwen cum ecclesia sua et piscarias de Tyna—in Tyno flumine unam piscariam quam Nicholaus de Grenevill dedit Sancto Cuthberto, &c."
In a MS. copy of Matthew Paris' History, preserved in the king's library, and supposed to be an autograph of that historian, and written about the middle of the thirteenth century, is a map, one of the oldest extant of Great Britain, in which the river "Thine" is marked between those of "Wer" and "Koket." See last edition of Gough's Topography, vol. i. p. 61, 62, where an engraving is given of this singular cu∣riosity..

By an agreement, made A. D. 1259, between the town of Newcastle and the prior and convent of Durham, among other things, it was stipulated, that the tenants of the latter, at South-Sheilds, should have liberty to bake and brew for themselves only, but not for the use of strangersAubone MS. Also Murray MS. p. 234..

A. D. 1292, there was the following judgment in a cause between King Edward the First, the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the prior of Tinmouth, viz. "that the port within the water of Tyne, from the sea to Hedwin-Streams, is the free port of the king and his heirsBourne's History of Newcastle, p. 161. Also Aubone MS. which last says "that the record thereof is in the Ro. and Treasury at Westminster; and the same is among the plea rolls in the Tower, but the other is more perfect."."

The year following an inquisition was taken at Newcastle upon Tyne, concerning a moiety of the water of Tyne, belonging to the Bishop of Durham
"Inquisitio—capt' ad Novum Castrum super Tinam in com' Northumbriae Cra. Sancti Hillarii anno regni Ed. Regis, ilii Regis Henrici 21, d' medietate aque d' Tyne Episc' Dunelm, spectant." Spearman's Durham, p. 7, et seq.
Another occurs ibid. taken in the year 1317, for a moiety of the water of Tyne for the Bishop of Durham. "Inquisitio d' medietate aquae d' Tyne pro Episcopo Dunelm' anno 10 Ed. II." Ibid. p. 7..

A. D. 1306, judgment was given in parliament, that the prior of Tinmouth, who had built a shore at North-Sheilds within the flood-mark of this river, should remove it at his own costBourne's Newcastle, p. 161..

In the year 1319, King Edward the Second, having granted a depu∣tation of the conservatorship of the river Tyne to John Hamsted, re∣called that power on the claim of the mayor and burgesses of New∣castle upon Tyne
Ibid. p. 163.—Also Aubone MS. See also Wallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 204. "Tyne aqua concessa Johanni de Hamsted, pat. 12 R. Ed. II. p. 1, m. 27. De custodia aquae de Tine, concessa pridem Johanni de Hampsted, revocata quia Rex intelli∣git quod commissarius predictus agit in prejudicium libertatis burgensium Novi Castri. Claus. 12 R. Ed. II. m. 26.
A grant of Edward the Second of the conservatorship of the river to the town of New∣castle, was produced at the Jarrow-Slake trial 1697..

About this time John Pebrim occurs, as admiral of a fleet of ships stationed on the northern coasts of England, and taking in provisions at Tinmouth
Wardrobe account of 15th, 16th, and 17th of Edward II. penes Th. Astle, armig. p. 91. "Johannes ebrim admirall slote navium versus partes boreales reddit compotum de 250 quarter' frumenti recep' de Henric' de Shirokes apud Tynemuth quinto die Aug' anno 16o, per preceptum Domini Regis ad participand' inter diversas nautas ejusdem slote —de quibus idem Johannes computat liberasse Willielmo Snowe, magistro navis vocate la Grande Mariote de Jernemuth et 35 magistris aliarum de Jernemuth Lenn Herewyco Donewyco Ozeford Gippewico Blakeney Goseford et Waynestete per preceptum Domini Regis in subsidium sustentacionis sue et nautarum navium earundem morando in obsequitum Domini Regis supra mare versus partes boreales inter 27 diem Junii anno 15 et secundum diem Septembr' proxim' sequen' 48 quarteria que allocantur eidem Johanni hic per mandatum Domini Regis sub privato sigillo in gardoba, una cum quodam rotulo nomina magistrorum et navium ac summas quarterior' eisdem magistris particulatim liberatorum continente per dictum Johannem liberatum mense Januarii anno 19 London. Et vendun∣tur eidem Johanni super compotum istum 2 quarter' d quorum preio gard' oneratur in recepta denar' anno 16o."
The subsequent entries occur p. 143 et 144. "Johanni Barry magistro navis vo' la Godeyere de Novo Castro carianti in navi predicta per mae inter loca predicta (i. e. de Novo Castro super Tynam usque Leth in Scot') 5300 allec' sorr' 27 xx. pisc' sals' 3 quarter' salis minuti 2 barill' sturgon' unum barill' vini actis et 1 barill' viridis suci pro expen' hospic' Domini Regis pro fretto navis predicte per predictas quatuor Sept' per∣cip' perseptimanam 20s. per convencionem secum factam per dictum Henricum 4l.— Gilberto Stanpot magistro navis voc' la Bartelmeu de Novo Castro carianti in dicta navi 200 quarter' frumenti per mare inter loca predicta pro negotio memorato pro fretagio ejusdem navis et sustentacione nautarum per quinque septiman' dicto 28 die Julii &c. 100s.
Willielmo fil' Ede de Alnemuth magistro navis voc' la Weltfare de Novo Castro carcate cum 56 doliis vini ad partes predictas ut supra pro frettag' dicte navis per 8 septiman' per quas fuit in obsequio Domini Regis prec' pro qualibet septiman' 2 marc' per convenc' &c. 10l. 13s. 4d.".

Upon an inquisition taken at Gateshead before the sheriff of Dur∣ham, on the Friday before the feast of Pentecost, 1323, the before-mentioned ancient division of the river Tyne was ascertained, i. e. that a moiety of the water thereof from Stanley-Burn to Tinmouth be∣longed to Saint Cuthbert and the church of Durham, and another moiety to the county of Northumberland, and that the third part of the same water in the middle of the stream was common and freeMr. Astle's Durham MS. p. 115. "Tine." "Inquis' sacta coram Simone de Essh vicecomiti Dunelm' in pleno comit' Dunelm' die Lune prox' post festum Sancte Margaret virginis anno pontific' domini Ricardi Dunelm' Episcopi 3o ad inquirend' de dampnis oppressionibus & illesionibus atque transgressionibus & injuriis contra ecclesiam et libertatem ecclesie Dunelmen' factis per quoscumque per sacramentum Johannis Breton Johannis de Gildsorth Johannis de Bronnynghill Willielmi de Gillesworth Johannis Bille Johannis de Almsheles Willielmi Ochespen' Willielmi Lardener Ricardi de Ravenssforth Rog' de Wermouth Willielmi de Helton de Wilkestone et Roberti de Lambtin. Qui dicunt super sacramentum suum quod Episcopus Dunelmensis & homines libertatis ejusdem solebant habere passagium liberum per medium aque de Tyne cum navibus et batellis et carcag' et discarcag' ubicunque voluerint durante costera episcopatus Dunelm' usque filum aque predicte et rivagium commune cum omnimodis mercimoniis et quibuscunque aliis neces∣sariis ad voluntatem omnium quorumcumque emencium vel vendencium. Item dicunt quod burgus de Gateshead habebat sorum per duas dies in qualibet septimana videlicet per diem Martis et diem Veneris usque ad medium pontis et nundinas videlicet in festo Sancti Petri ad vincula. Item dicunt quod dominus episcopus & prior ecclesie Dunelmen' habent piscarias suas liberas super costeram aque de Tyne ubi libere solebant vendere pisces suos ubicumque voluerint Dicunt eiam quod piscatores domini episcopi et dicti domini prioris tam in Pipewelgat quam in le Scheles et alibi sunt omnino perturbati vendere pisces quo prendiderunt tam in aqua de Tyne quam in mare et vi et armis abstrahuntur et coguntur ad forum Novi Castri et si alibi vendant redimuntur seu graviter amerciantur Dicunt eciam quod non permittitur alicui habere rivagium ad carcand' vel discarcand' qui redi∣muntur: et ubi prior Dunelm' habuit lanas suas proprias venientes de Halieland in quadam navi in aqua de Tyne super solum domini prioris apud le Scheles liberatas propter illam liberacionem navis attach' fuit et ducta apud Novum Castrum. Et si piscatores de Scheles vendant episcopo vel priori Dunelm' vel alicui alii apud le Scheles super solum dicti domini episcopi extra forum Novi Castri ballivi Novi Castri capiunt dictos piscatores et ducunt eos usque villam Novi Castri et ibi imprisonantur donec redimantur & nichilominus ca∣piunt custumam de eisdem, preterea predicti ballivi perturbant omnes cariantes boscum carbones & meremium cum aliis necessariis descendere ad terram episcopatus sine redemp∣tione Et dicunt quod burgus Novi Castri super Tynam edificavit ad finem pontis super solum Episcopi Dunelm' appropriand' eis solum et liberum tenementum Item dicunt quod quidam Willielmus de Ullesam operabatur super pontem Novi Castri et cecidit in aquam ex parte ville de Gateshead et ibi submersit et statim venit Ricardus Mekilmuk & Thomas Parry et invenerunt predict' Willielmum infra filum aque de Tyne ex parte episcopatus Dunelmen' et traxerunt corpus ab eo loco usque villam Novi Castri & postea reduxerunt corpus predicti Willielmi usque cemeterium beate Marie de Gateshead et ibi sepelierunt corpus predicti Willielmi &c. Et super hac inquisitione supplicavit dominus Ricardus Dunelm' Episcopus Domino suo Regi pro remedio contra injurias predict' obtinend' qui Dominus Rex breve suum majori et ballivis ville Novi Castri direxit." See account of Gateshead under this year..

King Edward III. by his writ in the year 1334, forbade the mayor and bailiffs of Newcastle upon Tyne to hinder the mooring of ships on the south side of this river"Edwardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie Dominus Hibernie & Dux Aquitaniae majori & ballivis suis ville Novi Castri super Tinam salutem. Ex parte venerabilis patris Richardi Dunelm' Episcopi nobis est ostensum quod licet ipse et predecessores sui episc' loci predicti et eorum homines infra aquas de Tyne et Tese per filum aque de Tyne pred' ascendende & descendendo per totam costeram episc' predict' pisces carnes boscum carbones et alias res quascunque tam venales quam non venales cum navibus et batellis suis carcar' discar∣rator' et piscator' ejusdem episc' in aqua pred' et in mari piscari et pisces capere et omnia bona pred' pro voluntate sua ducere & reducere ac commodum suum inde facere possent ut deberent impedit' minus juste ipsos abducend' naves & batellas suas usque dictam villam Novi Castri et eas ibidem discarcandas indebite compelland' in ipsius episcopi et hominum suorum pd' grave prejudicium et libertatis sue Dunelm' lesionem manifestam Et quia eidem episcopo aut hominibus suis pred' injurias fieri nolumus in hac parte vobis manda∣mus quod ab hujusmodi impedimentis eidem episc' seu hominibus suis pred' de ctero inferendis penitus desistentes ipsas naves & batellas suis cum bonis et rebus suis pred' per costeram pred' carcare et discarcare. Et piscatores pisces capere ac omnia bona sua pred' tam venalia quam non venalia per filum aque pred' ducere et reducere ad commodum suum inde faciend' libere et absque impedimento de cetero pretermittatis prout hactenus facere consueverunt. Et si qua bona eorund' occasione pred' capta fuerint & arrestata ea eisdem sine dilacione restitui faciatis. Teste meipso apud Ebor. 20 die mensis Augusti anno regni nostri 8vo.—Gray's MSS. quarto, p. 319. See also Spearman's Durham, p. 9..

In the year 1343, there was a commission of Richard Bury, Bishop of Durham, concerning the hindrance of ships in the water of Tyne.Spearman's Durham, p. 27. Commissio Richardi Bury Episc' ad inquirend' d' impe∣dimentis navium in aqua de Tyne. Rot. A. Ricardi Bury Episc. Sched. 16. Ed. III. Regis.—See Appendix.

In the year 1345, the Bishop of Durham obtained a verdict against the King's commissioners, for trespasses done by them, in intermed∣dling in the conservatorship of the south side of the river Tyne
Record read at the Jarrow-Slake trial. Also Spearman's Durham, p. 9. Also claus. 18 Ed. III. p. 2. m. 15. dorso. De inquis. de gurgit.' &c. in aqua de Tyne levat' in retardac' battellor et nocumentum piscar' reg' &c."—Notes of records in the Tower of London, &c. communicated by Thomas Astle, esq
"March 7th, 1352. On complaint against the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle for molesting the tenants of the prior of Durham at South Sheilds, in seizing their boats with fish, and carrying them up to Newcastle before the church of Jarrow had got its tythes, &c. and causing the owners to swear that in future they would sell their fish at Newcastle market only—the said mayor and burgesses engaged not to molest them for the time to come." Grey's MSS. quarto, p 315..
A. D. 1372, a commission of conservatorship of the river Tyne was granted to the mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne and othersAs appears by a record read at the Jarrow-Slake trial..

In the year 1384, King Richard II. granted a charter to the Bishop of Durham for the mooring of ships, the loading and unloading of , &c. in the river Tyne, without molestation from the men of NewcastleSpearman's Durham, p. 10. "Charta Ricardi II. Regis Episc' Dunelm' pro applica∣tione navium, onratione et exoneatione carbonum mercandisarum et aliarum rerum quarumcunque absque impedimento hom' villae Novi Castri super Tynam anno 7 Ric. II. Regis 1384. Johan. Fordam Episc'—includes ballast inter alia.".

A. D. 1385, there was a plea between the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne and the Bishop of Durham concerning the right of the river
Tyne, from the sea upwards to Hedwin-Streams, and scire facias and supersedeas to the said bishopAubone MSS. "Novum Castrum super Tynam. De placito inter burgenses ibidem et Episcopum Dunelm' de jure aquae de Tyne, viz. a mari usque ad locum vocat' Hedwin-Stremes." Claus. anno 8vo. Ric. II. m. 43. dorso, in the Tower of London..

A. D. 1393, the King confirmed to the Bishop of Durham his moie∣ties of the waters of Tyne and Tees, with power to unload and load coals, merchandize, &c. without hindrance or molestation from the men of Newcastle upon Tyne
Spearman's Durham, p. 10. Inspeximus &c. Confirmation charter of Richard II. to the Bishop of Durham. Dugdale's Monasticon, p. 47.
"Una cum medietatibus dictarum aquarum de Tyne et Tese versus episcopatum, A. D. 1393."
Charta Richardi II. Regis Episc' Dunelm' d' libertatibus regal' com' palatin' infra Tynam et Tesam (usque medium aquarum illarum) cum applicatione oneratione & exoneratione navium batellorum & aliorum vasorum in eisdem aquis. Nov. 10, anno 15 Ric II. Regis, 1393. Vide Dugdale, fol. 46..

Froissart, who wrote his chronicle during the reign of Richard II. says, by a mistake, which ought not to invalidate his authority as to historical facts, and which will easily be pardoned, when we consider in how uncultivated a state our country was at that time, that the city of Carlisle, as well as the town of Newcastle, was seated upon the banks of the river Tyne
Cap. 18. "Si court parmi une riviere pleine de cailloux & de grosses pirres qu'on nomme Thin. Sur celle riviere fied la ville et le chastel qu'on nomme Cardoel en Gales— Et devant est assise la ville appelee Neuf Chastel sur Thin."
The following is a just and accurate description of the river Tyne:
"The river Tyne rises from different sources; some of them about sixty miles to the north-west, and others about fifty to the west and south-west from Newcastle, and from thence to its entrance into the sea at Tynemouth is about ten miles; but if we measure by the windings of the river, it will be more in both cases.—The channel betwixt New∣castle and Tynemouth is of a very different width and depth, so that the tide is more rapid in some places than in others. The entrance into the harbour at the low lights is very narrow; but the channel forms into a fine large bason for the whole length of Sheilds, capable of holdin above two thousand sail of large ships. Above which, the tide spread over the extensive slats of Jarrow-Slake; and then, for a great length some a remarkably fine broad and deep pool called the Long-Reach, all which contain an immense quantity of water. After this the tide is obstructed by several windings and narrow places in the channel, till it comes within about a mile of Newcastle, where it runs in an open and wider pool, till it flows about two miles above the town, when it is a good deal intercepted in its course by a large island, consisting of many acres, called the King's Meadows; after flowing round this island by two narrow channels, and through several beautiful windings, it rises a little above the village of Newburn; in all about seven or eight miles above New∣castle.
"The tides commonly flow about four hours and a half, and ebb about seven hours and a half at Newcastle bridge: and the perpendicular rise of the river here in a spring tide will sometimes be about eleven or twelve feet, and at Tynemouth bar about eighteen feet: but both these circumstances vary greatly from the different winds, and the different quan∣tities of fresh water in the river: in a north-westerly wind they will sometimes rise three feet higher than is mentioned above; and in a south-westerly one, sometimes scarcely half so high: and in some of our great land floods, the tide has not sufficient forces to stem and turn the current, which will set downwards during the whole swell of the tide." Rotheram's Philosophical Inquiry into the Nature and Property of Water, p. 114..

About the year 1414, a third part of the river Tyne, and of the bridge at Newcastle, was ascertained to belong to the Bishop of Dur∣hamSpearman's Durham, p. 10. "A record of the trial and judgment from Thomas Langley, then bishop of Durham, against the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, for the south part of the river Tyne, and of the bridge with the tower thereupon: up a a solemn trial at the King's-Bench bar, by a jury of the counties of Westmoreland and Cumberland, of an issue joined before my lord chancellor, and transmitted to the King's Bench to be tryed by order of parliament, anno 2 Hen V. 1415, vel anno 4 Hen. V.".

A. D. 1416, there appears to have been a cause depending between the church of Durham and the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, concerning the holding of markets at South-Sheilds for fish, bread, and beer, and concerning the right of wrecks and fishery in the Tyne
In a MS. in the Cotton library, sub effigie Vitellii A. 9. occur: "Responsiones prioris Dunelm' ad querelas majoris & burgensium ville Novi Castri super Tin"—which is in the nature of a breviat, or instruction drawn up by Prior Wossington of Durham, for counsel to plead in a cause that was then depending between the church and town, about holding markets at South-Sheilds, for fish, bread, and beer, and the right of wrecks and fishery in the river."—Dr. Ellison's MSS.
It appears, by an inquisition taken at Newcastle upon Tyne on the Tuesday in Easter week, 1417, that anciently all those fishermen that went out to fish at sea from that port, were accustomed to live in a street assigned to them in that town, called Fisher-Gate, to prevent the regrating of the fish before they were brought up to that town, and had paid the king his customs and prizes.—Murray MS. p. 235.
By another inquisition taken at the same town on the Thursday following, it appears that complaints had been exhibited against the priors of Durham and Tinmouth; as also against the abbot of Newminster, for making wears in the river Tyne, which en∣croached on the deep course of the water, that is the king's stream, called the channel and middleway, and for having nets of such small size as to destroy the brood of salmon and other fishes.—Ibid. p. 211..

In the year 1423, King Henry VI. made a grant to the mayor, sheriff, and commonalty of Newcastle upon Tyne, of certain customs to be received of every ship in that port
Aubone MS. "At a common-council held June 21st, 1676. Table of the townes duties: The committee appointed March 23d, 1676, reported that they had made exami∣nation, in the town chamber, of the duties received of freemen and unfreemen upon their clearing, which they find to be as followeth:
Free towns alphabetically. Ships clearing. s. d.
Aldbrough Free ship of Newcastle. For entering 0 1
Beaverley For his ballast at 10d. per tun pays 0 6
Brickley For his ballast at 9d. per tun pays 0 5
Colchester
Cambridge A freeman's ship of the free towns. For his ballast some 9d. others 10d. per tun
Dunnesh For his 1st shovel full 1s. buoyage 4d. en∣tering 1d. in all 1s. 5d.
Dover
Feversham For his coals per chalder 3d. and stone likewise.
Grinsby
Hastings
Hull To clear an unfreeman's ship For ship and boat 20d. besides the 1s. 5d. paid by freemen, in all 3s. 1d.
Headon
Hide
Ipswich For coles 5d. per chalder, or stones likewise.
London
Maldon For his ballast 9d. or 10d. a the shore requires.
Orphord
Portsmouth
Rey A Dutch or French ship For ship and boat 3s. 3d.
Southampton For coles or stones per chalder, 1s. 4d.
Sandwich For their ballast as Englishmen.
Scarbrough
Winchelsey For goods and merchandizes as in the card is specified."
Wanderswerke
Common council Books▪
York
Yarmouth.
.

By a charter dated July 11th, 1443, the above king exempted the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne from the warrants and jurisdiction of the admirals, constables, and marshals, and of the warden of the marches towards Scotland
See Prynne on the 4th institute, p. 342. "That the admirals of England," says he, "had ancient jurisdiction in marine causes and contracts made in the ports within the realm, may be collected by this patent of exemption of the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne.—Cart. 21 Hen. VI. m. 41. per breve de privato figillo."
In 1442, the commons in parliament stating the necessity of having an armed force upon the sea, pointed out at the same time where such ships as were wanted might be obtained: among those of other places occurs "at Newcastle a great ship called the George
In the rolls of parliament, vol. v. p 70, A. D. 1444, 23 Hen VI. there occurs, "A shipp called Cristofore of Newe Castell, of which shipp was master Alebrande Derykson."
Ibid. p. 59. "Item atte the Newe Castell a grete shippe called the George atte Newcastell with the grete ship there one Balinger."."
Topham's Historical Description of a Second Picture at Windsor Castle, p. 21..

Upon an inquisition taken in the year 1447, it was found that the river Tyne and the soil thereof, from the place called Spar-HawkThe Sparhawk is at present a sand, though it is said to be a rock, at the depth of four feet. September 29th, 1780, I went off to sea in a boat, to found and make observations on this ancient boundary. It is about a quarter of a mile from the Spanish fort, near Tin∣mouth castle. It is nearly of the shape of a crescent, one point of which is directed to∣wards Prior's Haven, and the other towards the Bar. It had then four feet of water upon it, but the tide was risen considerably. N. B. The direction for being past the Bar into the sea is when a full view is gained of the village of Cullercoats. in the sea to Hedwin-Streams, belonged, under the crown, to the corpo∣ration of Newcastle upon TyneBourne, p. 163. "By an inquisition 4 January, 25 Henry VI. the jury upon their oaths found that time beyond the memory of man the town of Newcastle upon Tyne had and hold of ou sovereign Lord the King and all his predecessors, as burgesses of the said town (when there was no mayor), and as mayor and burgesses of the said town (when there was a mayor), the said town and water of Tyne, and the soil of the said water of Tyne, wherever it was covered from a place called Sparrow-Hawk in the sea, unto a place called Hdwin-Stream and that the same, with the appurtenances, were parcel of the liberties and free customs of the said town, and were hold under a farm, saving the king's ents, pse and assesments in the port of the said town. Then they find and set forth King John's charter and confirmation; and dse other customs and privileges belonging to the said town are there mentioned, expressed, and set forth.".

In the year 1454, the King granted the conservatorship of this river, from Sparhawk to Hedwin-Streams, to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne
A commission anno 32 Hen. VI. directed to the mayor and others for conservator∣ship between Sparhawk and Hedwin-Streams.—Record read at the Jarrow-Slake trial.
Gardiner, in his England's Grievance, &c. p. 15, pretends that the right granted as above was extinguished by Queen Elizabeth's grant of February 5th, 1522, to Charles, Lord Howard, of the office of high admiral for life.—See afterwards under 1589..

June 30th, 1528, Arthur Plantagenet, vice admiral under Henry, Earl of Nottingham, lord high admiral, made an acknowledgment of admiral jurisdiction granted by King John, and confirmed by succeed∣ing princes, to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne
A. D. 1523, King Henry VIII. granted his commission under the great seal to Wil∣liam Franklyn, clerk, Sir William Bulmer, and Sir William Ewre, knights, to inquire of and seize a prize ship driven into Tinmouth Haven in the river Tyne at South-Sheilds, within the bishop's royal liberty, and to deliver the ship, with the goods and habiliments of war in her, to the said bishop, as of right belonging to him (in right of his see of Dur∣ham) allowed by ancient grants and confirmations from the crown, produced and ap∣proved.— Rotul 'A. Tho. Woolsey, cardinal. episc' No. 8. anno 15 Hen. VIII. Regis. Spearman's Inquiry—Durham, p. 23., on the view and inspection of their several grants and privilegesGrey's MSS..

In the year 1530, the conservatorship of the river Tyne was con∣firmed to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, by an act of parlia∣ment prohibiting the shipping loading or unloading of any goods to be sold into or from any ship at any place within the limits of Sparhawk
"Tynemouth Barr," says an account in Dr. Ellison's collections, given by Mr. Robert Reed, one of the trinity masters, after the year 1700," is a ridge of sand, which lyes at the mouth of the river Tyne: the depthe of water is different as to spring and neape tides; on which there is at highest or spring tides 21, 22 and 23 foote at hyghe water, and upon low or neape 16, 17 and 18 foote at hyghe water. I set these depthes, they beinge the usualle depthes unless freshe and fludes of rain or change of windes will make a foote or two more or lesse. The tydes rise upon a spring 16 or 17 foote, and upon a neape tide 8 or 9 foote."
The subsequent is extracted from Warburton's MS. collections remaining at Northum∣berland-house.
"To sail into Tinmouth Haven—Run along the shore till you come open of the river's mouth, then bring the light houses one into the other and so saile in, which will carry you cleare of a sand called the Hurd, lying on the larboard side, and a rock called the "Ass∣midden," which lieth on the north side until you are shot in, then you may open the light to the southward."—"When the moon comes to N. E. and S. W. it is full sea at Tin∣mouth Barr—The tides set when flowing to the south east and ebb to the north west."
and Hedwin-Streams, but only at the town aforesaid, and impower∣ing the mayor, burgesses, and commonalty of that town, and their successors, to pluck down all wears, gores, and engines, that should be made in the river, to the great obstruction of the navigation thereof, between the places aforesaidAubone MS.—See also printed act, 21 Hen. VIII. cap. 18..

In the year 1547, all the sands, called shores, of the river Tyne were settled
The subsequent extract is from a MS. collection of the abstracts of deeds, to prove that the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne have enjoyed the soil from the high water mark to the low, and granted leases, &c.
"42 Eliz. A. D. 1600, Decr. 13. A lease from the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne to Henry Anderson, alderman, for 21 years, of St. Lawrence, with the ballast-shores on the east and west sides of Ouseburn, &c.
"18 Ja. I. A. D. 1620, June 22. Lease from the same to Thomas Riddell, merchan, for 31 years—Rent 1s. of a piece of ground called Salt-Grasses to the low water mark along the north side of Tyne adjoining on Byker Manor—400 yards—stretching eastward from the grounds of St. Lawrence—to build a ballast-wharf.
"2 Car. I. A. D. 1626, April 18. A lease from the same to Sir William Fenwick, knt. and bart. and John Fenwick, esq for 99 years —Rent 1s.—The soil from high to low water mark from a place called the Scottes...up the river Tyne boundering St. Anthony's and Walker ground, to erect a ballast-wharf.
"4 Car. I. A. D. 1629, June 9. Lease from the same to Matthew Chapman, merchant, for 30 years—Rent 1s.—Ground from low to high water mark 500 yards in length, boun∣dering on the west side of the grounds of Felling, and upon the east on the grounds of Hayning on the south side of the Tyne, to erect a ballast-wharf.
"22 Car. I. A. D. 1647, June 28. A lease from the same to Ann Dudley, widow, for 10 years—Rent 1s. of five score and eleven yards of ballast-shore at the south ballast shore in the parish of Gateshead.
"A. D. 1651, February 8th. Lease from the same to Thomas —, shipwright, for 9 years—Rent 1d. Their ballast-shore on the south side of Tyne, except that already let out for coal staiths, commonly called the Town's Ballast-Shores in the Salt Meadows in the parish of Gateshead.
"A. D. 1653, November 14. Lease from the same to Benjamin Ellison, merchant, for 31 years.—Rent 1s. Their key or wharf then built and called Jarrow-Key, in length 1000 yards from the said key to the Black Point westward up the river, for a ballast-shore.
"12 Car. II. A. D. 1660, July 31. A lease from the same to Thomas Blunt, shipwright, for 8 years, at the rent of 1s.—Their ballast-shore on the south side of Tyne, except that let for coal staiths, called the Town's Ballast-Shore in the Salt Meadows, in the parish of Gateshead."—Archives of the corporation of Newcastle. on the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, for the maintenance of that town and preservation of the port of Newcastle
From a MS. intitled "The Right and Title of the Corporation of Newcastle to the Soile and Ground in the River between the high and low water marks, and to the Con∣servatorship of the river of Tyne"—referring to a statute 2 Ed. VI. not printed.
The proper disposal of the gravel, &c. brought for the purpose of ballasting the empty ships that traded hither for coal, appears at this early period to have been an object of con∣cern to the corporation of Newcastle, without whose intervention it is not improbable but that the bed of the Tyne had been choked up long ago with this adventitious matter and one of the most important of our rivers by that means rendered unnavigable. The mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, it should seem, were at this time first invested with the power of depositing this ballast where there would be the least danger of its falling into and damaging their river, although in several contests concerning this power they have been desirous of claiming it by prescription as conservators of the Tyne, strengthened by an ad∣ditional authority derived to them from the statute 34 Hen. VIII. cap. 9.
From the circumstance of this being the first mention that occurs of ballast-shores, it seems probable that the coal trade was now first beginning to be of considerable conse∣quence. In a course of years and great increase of commerce, these ballast-shores have crowded the banks of the Tyne on both sides with artificial mountains.
Bourne tells us that a place below Sand-Gate, where there is at present a great ropery, was the first ballast-shore out of the town, the site of which, as also of the burying-ground, which still retains the name of Ballast-Hills, a little lower down the river, had been pur∣chased by the corporation of Newcastle of the Lords of Biker, for that and other purposes..

A. D. 1553, a third part of the river Tyne, and of the bridge over it at Newcastle, was restored by act of parliament to the Bishop of Durham.
Spearman's Durham, p. 11. "By act of parliament the county palatine, with a third part of the river Tyne, and of the bridge there, and all the bishop's royal franchises and jurisdictions, were restored to the Bishop of Durham—then Cuthbert Tunstal—and also by Queen Mary's charter under the great seal: and the two acts of 7 Ed. VI. whereby it was dissolved and Gateside annexed to Newcastle, were repealed. Stat' anno. 1 Mariae Reginae, parliam' 2, c. 3, stat. 7. Ed. VI. c. 10."

Queen Elizabeth having been petitioned by the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, to grant them a charter of liberties concern∣ing
sea jurisdiction and admiralty in that port, by her letters patent, dated 30th August, 1589 (the 31st year of her reign), granted the reversion of the office of the high admiralty of the river Tyne, and port of Newcastle, to the above mayor and burgesses of that town: the said office having before, February 5th 1522, been granted to Charles, Lord Howard, of Effingham (inter alia), in his patent of the office of lord high admiral of England, during his life, which terminated January 26th, 1618See charters.—Also Aubone MS. "An exemption from the jurisdiction of the ad∣miralty, and grant of a court admiral, to be held in the town every Monday, before the recorder and aldermen (or any three of them, whereof the mayor or recorder to be one) inhabiting within the port.— Also they are made justices of peace for the ad∣miralty, and for conservation of the river, within the port there. The serjeants of mace to execute the process. Also the mayor hath power to make a judge of admiralty, and other officers. Also cognizance of admiral pleas granted, and all that belongs to the admiralty.".
A. D. 1603, a commission of conservatorship of the river Tyne ap∣pears to have been sent to the mayor and burgesses of NewcastleRecord read at the Jarrow-Slake trial..

February 27, 1605, the above lord high admiral made an assign∣ment to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, of the admiral jurisdiction, within the port of that town, extending from Sparhawk to Hedwin-Streams, with power to hold a court of ad∣miralty
From a copy in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne:
The oar that has been carried or placed before the mayor, as an ensign of authority in this court of admiralty, and which, by the date it bears, evidently appears to have been made in consequence of the above grant, is still preserved in the archives of New∣castle upon Tyne.—On one side are painted the royal arms, with "Ao. R. R. Ja. 4." On the other, those of the town, with "Ao. Dni. 1606."
I have seen an old MS▪ book, communicated by Mr. Jasper Harrison, attorney at law, containing orders and rules for the proctors, made at a court of admiralty of record, in Newcastle upon Tyne, September 16, 1666, with an account of fees to be received there by the judge, register, marshal, and proctors; as also a trial.
October 5, 1674, William Lilburn, Esq was chosen in the place of Mr. Richard Matthews, for the admiralty—Common-council books.
September 20, 1687, Mr. Robert Medley of York, having pretended to have a grant, as judge of the admiralty court, Newcastle, there was an order of common council, that the office should be defended against him by the town.—Common-council books.
April 13, 1702, Sir Robert Shafto was appointed "judge of the admiralty court, on the death of John Blackiston, Esq"—Ibid.
September 25, 1705, John Ogle, Esq was appointed to the same.—Ibid. He was father of Sir Chaloner Ogle.
I collected the subsequent notices concerning the river-court.—Ibid.
March 7, 1649, application to be made to one of the members of parliament for New∣castle, "for the farther impoweringe of the river-court, &c."
September 27, 1692, Gerard Robson, on the death of Henry Shaw, chosen "summoner of the river-court."
August 6, 1659, all fines in the river-court ordered in future to be estreated.
There is preserved in the old books of the river-court, the form of the oath of the river-jurors.
April 30, 1722, a barge with six oars was ordered for the use of the river-jury.
September 24, 1764, an order was made, "at a court, held for the conservation of the river Tyne, by custom, time out of mind, in the Guild-Hall of the said town" (af∣terwards printed), concerning the proper mooring of ships at North-Sheilds. This, on being found deficient, was repealed May 27, 1765, and a new one made and published instead of the former.
By letters patent, under the great seal of his Majesty's High Court of Admiralty, dated May 6, 1761, 1 Geo. III. Hugh, Earl of Northumberland, was constituted, during the king's pleasure only, vice-admiral, commissary, and deputy, in the office of vice ad∣miralty, in the county of Northumberland, and town of Newcastle upon Tyne. He had been first constituted in March, 1753. By a grant, dated Nov. 11th, 1776, the Duke of Northumberland appointed Thomas Davidson, Esq his deputy, in the above office.
By like letters patent, dated October, 1786, Hugh, the present Duke of Northumberland, was constituted vice-admiral, during the king's pleasure, of the county of Northumber∣land, and town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne; who appointed John Davidson, Esq son of the above Thomas Davidson, his deputy in the said office., &c.

King James I. by order of council, dated January 29, 1613, granted the conservatorship of the river Tyne to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, jointly with the Bishop of Durham, and other justices of the peace for the counties of Durham and Nor∣thumberland
From a paper communicated by Mr. Thomas Aubone. Dorso: "Conservatorship of the river Tyne, 1616."
The subsequent notices concerning the salt-trade upon the river Tyne, about A. D. 1605, I extracted from original letters to the then Earl of Northumberland, and now remaining in the archives of that illustrious family.
"In the two counties of Durham and Northumberland, there were then 153 salt-panns which, casting at the rate of fifty weighs a piece, made in the year 7653 weighs of salt: 430 salters were employed in them, besides 120 keel-men, for the carriage of coals, and besides "the cadgers and wayne-men, where coals are not carried by water."
A weigh of salt sold at that time for twenty and twenty-two shillings; and a salt pann would burn sixteen tens of coals per annum, every ten worth 53s. 4d..

Charles, Earl of Nottingham, Baron Howard, of Essingham, &c. and Lord Admiral, by authority of the royal commission granted to him, by writ of privy seal, April 4, 1610, granted to the mayor and aldermen of Newcastle upon Tyne, a commission, July 7, 1614, con∣cerning pirates, who, at that time, in great numbers infested the seas, impowering them to fit out against them "on shipp or more war∣likelie appointed with men, ordnaunce, and victual sufficient for the enterprizeFrom a copy in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.."
There is also a letter to the mayor of Newcastle, from the privy council, for the suppressing of pirates, dated February 7, 1618From the papers of the Trinity-House of Newcastle..

In the year 1616, the mayor, aldermen, and jury of the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, exhibited a grievous complaint to the king and council, at Whitehall, of the great decay of that river, through neglect, or breach of trust, in the commissioners appointed in 1613
From the paper, dorso, "Conservatorship, &c." communicated by Mr. T. Aubone.
Gardiner, in his England's Grievance, p. 15 and 47, tells us, that King James, on the 28th of January, 1618 (two days after the death of Charles, Earl of Nottingham), granted the admiralty of all England to the Duke of Buckingham, on which account, he (Gardiner) conceived that the title of (the town of) Newcastle, by virtue of the charter of 31 Elizabeth, is of little force. Vide supra in 1589. It would have been more candid in that angry declaimer to have accused King James of acting unlawfully, which either with design or inadvertently, he certainly did, in granting to his favourite Buckingham the admiralty of all England, when Queen Elizabeth, as shewn before, had granted the reversion of that of the port of Tyne, on the death of the then lord ad∣miral, to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle..

February 4, 1616, seventeen new commissioners, among whom was the mayor of Newcastle, were appointed, with thirteen new articles added to the former nine, for the better conservation of the river Tyne, which was strictly enjoined them to provide for, under pain of forfeiting all the liberties of the town of Newcastle into the hands of the king. Four additional articles were made the year fol∣lowing, by the commissioners themselves, who had a further power to add more articles if requiredFrom a paper communicated by Mr. Thomas Aubone, dorso, "Conservatorship of the river Tyne, 1616.".

In the years 1625, 1626, and 1627, there were great arrearages, on whatever account, due from government, for freight of merchants and Newcastle ships, employed in his majesty's serviceRushworth's Collections, vol. i. p. 466.—"60,000l. in the years 1625 and 1626." And for "the freight of sundry merchants and Newcastle ships, employed in his ma∣jesty's service to the Isle of Rhee, and other places, in the year 1627, 19,560l. 12s. 4d.".

A. D. 1630, the prescription for conservation of the river Tyne, by the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, was allowed in the Court of King's Bench
In the year 1631, an order occurs from the king and council, to the sheriff of Durham, for the apprehension of persons doing damage to the river Tyne, with power to carry them before the mayor and aldermen of Newcastle, who are styled therein, "the conservators of the said river."—Bourne, p. 164.
About the year 1632, Sir Robert Heath began to build a ballast-shore at Sheilds, adjoining to the Tyne, though his right to lay ballast thereon was warmly disputed by the corporation of Newcastle; yet was it, by several orders of the king and council, permit∣ted to be carried on, and completed. —Gardiner, ut supra, p. 48, 49, 5.
June 5th, 1633, a petition was presented to King Charles, on his passage by water from Newcastle to Tinmouth, against "Kayes and Staiths," erected between Newcastle bridge and the s, and represented therein as nuisances to the river Tyne. Trinity-House books..

The same year, as also in 1637, the same prescription from Spar∣hawk
to Hedwin-Streams
Several years before 1641, the great increase of the coal trade in this river had induced the corporation of Newcastle to appoint an additional officer to their water-serjeant, whose province it was to cess the ballast, make out bills concerning it, &c. with the title of "ballast assessor."
Henry Eden, "assisting water-serjeant," and, on his death, Robert Urwen, occur in the common-council books, before March 7th, 1641, when the latter is ordered to be con∣tinued.
William Cutter, sworn June 23d, 1657.
Francis Anderson, merchant, on the resignation of R. Urwen, October 31st, 1661.
Francis Anderson, junior, on the resignation of his father, August 31st, 1669.
Patrick Kelley, merchant, on the death of F. Anderson, October 1st, 1719.
John Higgins, merchant, May 23d, 1720.
Joseph Kelley, September 8th, 1720, on the surrender of the above.
Peter Ports, junior, April 29th, 1729, on the surrender of J. Kelley.
Peter Russell, July 15th, 1734, on the surrender of P. Potts.
Christopher Wilkinson, September 25th, 1777, on the death of P. Russell.
on the death of C. Wilkinson.
The ballast assessor is sworn on admission to his office., was acknowledged in decrees of the Ex∣chequerBourne's History, p. 163, 164..

In the year 1636, the king sending writs for ship-money into the different shires of England and Wales, Newcastle upon Tyne was rated, on that unhappy occasion, at seven hundred poundsRushworth, ut supra. Northumberland to furnish one ship of 210 tuns, and 84 men, at the charge of 2,100l. Newcastle was charged 700l. and Berwick and Morpeth 20l. each..
In the year 1646, there were several orders of common-council made for the preservation of the river TyneCommon-council books..

This year a ballast-wharf was erected at South-Sheilds, and a tem∣porary leave given by the committee of the admiralty, on the petition of several masters of ships, to unload at it
Hostmen's books.
The subsequent account is extracted from the books of the Trinity-House, shewing the number of ships cleared from the river Tyne, in the memorable year, in which, after a most gallant defence, Newcastle was taken by the Scots.
"January, 1644, 7 coasters, and 12 English cross sea.
February — 7 cross sea, and two strangers.
March — 2 English cross sea, and one stranger.
April — 5 strangers.
May — no ships of any kind.
June — 1 stranger.
July, August, September, October, and November, no vessels whatever.
In December 1644, 145 coasters, 1 English cross sea, and 5 strangers.".

April 12, 1647, there was a petition, signed by several of the companies, to the committee of the admiralty, from the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, against loading the ships at SheildsCommon-council books..

In the year 1653, the corporation of Newcastle, for the conveniency of trade, granted that a ballast-shore should be erected on the south side of the river Tyne, from a place called the Black-Points, to Jarrow-Pans, capable of receiving ballast for more than sixty years to comeAnswer to Gardiner's Charge against the corporation. It appears by the hostmen's books, that in the year 164, the saltmakers of South and North Sheilds petitioned the lord protector, and the above fraternity, against the Scots bringing in salt into England, which they were able to able lower than the English could..

September 9, 1665, a lease, for a thousand years, was granted by the mayor and corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne to Sir Francis Anderson, of a large parcel of ground at Winlington, between high and low water-mark, with liberty to build quays, and cast ballast, on payment of two-pence for every tunIn the archives of the corporation of Newcastle..
The subsequent is taken from a curious printed paper, subjoined to an engraved map of the river Tyne, remaining in All Saints vestry:

"About 28 years since, Sir Charles Adderley, and one Mr. Crook, tenants to the dean and chapter of Durham, attempted to build a ballast-shoar upon Jarrow-Slike, but were obstructed by the corporation of Newcastle; which occasioned several petitions to his majesty King Charles II. in council; and, after divers hearings of both parties, it
was ordered by his majesty in council, that the town's right should be determined by a trial at the Exchequer bar; which accordingly was had in Easter term, 1669, on a feigned issue, in the name of Wil∣liam Blacket, Esq on behalf of the mayor and burgesses of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, plaintiff, and John Cooke, Esq lessee and assignce of the dean and chapter of Durham, was defendant, by a Buckinghamshire jury, where the issue is, whether the dean and chapter of Durham could lawfully erect and use ballast-keys and wharfs at Jarrow-Slike, without the licence of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle: and the jurors gave a verdict, after six hours evidence, that the dean and chapter could not erect a shoar or wharf there, without the licence of the mayor and burgesses. But Sir Charles Adderly, and Mr. Crook, with others, shortly after did petition the king in council, setting forth several advantages the public might receive from such a shoar, if built, praying the matter of the said petition might be referred to the lord mayor and court of aldermen, and Trinity-House, to report their opinion, whether a shoar at Jarrow-Slike would be of such advantage as was alleged in the said petition: and, after hearing of diverse witnesses, the following report was made: To the king's most excellent majesty: We, the lord mayor and alder∣men of the city of London, in pursuance of an order of your majesty in council, of the 5th of August last past, made upon the petition of Sir Charles Adderly, Knt. and John Crooke, Esq touching a ballast-shoar, intended by them to be erected at Jarrow-Slike, near South-Sheilds, in the county palatine of Durham; whereby we and the masters of the Trinity-House are required severally to consider of the petitioners allegations, and to report to your majesty in council, what advantage and conveniency may accrue to the public by erecting the said ballast-shoar, doe humbly certifie, that we have taken into serious consideration the said several allegations mentioned in your majesties said order: which are (that this intended ballast-shoar tends greatly to the advance of trade, security of shipping, preservation of the river Tyne, and men's lives, and that Newcastle itself, by the
increase of trade, will be much advantaged thereby), and have heard, as well what was thought fit to be offered by those gentlemen con∣cerned, who appeared for it, as by divers gentlemen of Newcastle, and their counsel learned, who appeared against it: And upon the whole matter, nothing was made out before us in proof or evidence of the said allegations; but on the contrary, it appeared to us by what was offered and demonstrated by those of Newcastle, and by the testimony of divers able and ancient ship-masters, and other persons unconcerned, that the erecting a ballast-shoar, as is designed, at Jarrow-Slike, would prove destructive to trade in general, dangerous both to shipping and men's lives, to the inhancinge of the price of sea coales, to the obstruction and choaking of the river Tyne, exceedingly mis∣chievous to the bar of Tinmouth-Haven, and manifestly to the de∣crease of trade, and damage of the town of Newcastle: the better judgment and consideration whereof is humbly submitted to your majesties great wisdom, by your majesty's most humble and most obe∣dient subjects and servants, Samuel Starling, mayor, Richard Cheverton, John Lawrence, William Peake, William Hooker, Joseph Sheldon, Thomas Davis, Fran. Chaplin, James Edwards, Dan. Forth, I. Ward, Jonathan Dawes. October 27th, 1670It is framed and glazed, and hung up in the vestry.."

The map prefixed to the foregoing account is intitled, "The survey of the river of Tyne, leading from the sea on the east to Newcastle on the west." With this addition: "This is a true coppy of the mapp, taken upon oathe."

The execution of the engraving is in the manner of Hollar or Gaywood. The following names of places are marked on it: on the north side of the river, "Newcastle, Ropery, Glashouses, Dents-Hole, St. Antoney, Billwood, Walker-Shoar, Stots-Powe, Mr. Cou∣zen's House, Walls-End-Dean, Willington-Key, a ballast-shoar, How∣den-Pans, a ballast-shoare, Whitehill-Point, North-Sheels, High-Light, Low Light-House, Black-Middens, Tynmouth-Castle, Sparrow-Hawk."
The subsequent occur on the south side.

(Above bridge) "Trunk-Stath." (Below-Bridge) "Ropery, Towne-Shore, Fryer-Goose, Feling-Slats, Feling-Shore, Heworth-Shore, Lden-Heugh, Cdden-Shore, Bell-Shore, Haining-Shore, Ballast-Shoar, Molina-Key, Hebborne-Steath, a ballast-shore, Half-Way-Trees, Black-Steath, Jarrow-Key, a ballast-shoare, Jarrow-Church, Jarrow-Slyke, the intended shoare, Westoe, West-Pans, South-Sheeld
There are the following references: "Bicker-Sand, St. Anton's-Sand, Frenchman-Sand, Bill-Sand, Elbow-Sand, Jarrow-Sand, Flatworth-Sand, Dirtwich-Sand, Westoe the lower part of Jarrow, Hird-Sand, West-Panns, Prier-Haven (the Spanish fort is marked as near it), Boye-in-the-river, Coble-Dean." I never saw another copy.
It appears from the books of the Trinity House, A. D. 1672, that great storms and land floods had occasioned, about this time, so many ships to be wrecked in the port of Tyne, that, notwithstanding the light-houses, the bar of that haven was unnavigable by night, some of the wrecks lying in the very middle of the channel.."

There was an order of common-council, made in the year 1675, for a map of the river Tyne to be drawn, from above Newcastle-Bridge to Hedwin-Streams
Common council books, December 16th.— September 30th, 1690, there is an order of that body, to refer to a committee the consideration of what means are necessary to ! "for preventing the great growth of trade at Sheilds."
The following passage occurs in North's Life of Lord-Keeper North, written in the time of Charles II. p. 121. "Ever since ships have been built larger, partly for better roads, and partly for better pilotage, the port towns have crept nearer the main; as they say would happen upon the Tyne: and Sheilds would become the port-town, if Newcastle had not a privilege, that no common baker or brewer should set up between them and the sea.".

It appears from the monumental inscription on the tomb of Charles Howard, Earl of Carlisle, &c. who died February 24th, 1684, that he was vice-admiral of the coasts of Northumberland, Cumberland, bishopric of Durham, town and county of Newcastle, and maritime parts adjacent.

In the year 1691, a scheme was proposed by — Howes, Esq to lay chains in the river Tyne, in Sheilds harbour, for ships to ride Drake's Eborum.
at; but having been deemed impracticable by the Trinity-House of Newcastle, it was never put in executionBooks of the Trinity-House.—They say it cannot be done, "our river being so verry narrow at Sheilds, where most ships take in their lading, that there is not roome for them to wind up and downe every tide, without heavinge and vereing, as the wind blowes, which cannot be done by ships rydeing at chaines; neither can ships lying at chaines have both sides at liberty to take in their lading, &c.".

In the years 1694, 1697, and 1698, the great cause was in agi∣tation, between the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, plaintiffs, and the dean and chapter of Durham, and Samuel Shep∣herd, defendants, concerning a ballast-key, or wharf, at Westoe, or Jarrow-Slake. In this trial upon a decree, confirming the conservator∣ship of the river Tyne in the said mayor and burgesses, there was a perpetual injunction, which, on an appeal, was afterwards confirmed in the House of Lords
Bourne's History, p. 164. This cause was tried at the Exchequer-bar, at West∣minster, in or about the year 1697, concerning the above defendant's erecting a ballast-shore, key, or wharf, at Westoe, or Jarrow-Slake, within the river Tyne: on which trial there was a verdict for the plaintiffs, and a decree thereupon; and a perpetual injunction awarded, to quiet the plaintiffs in possession of their franchises, liberties, and privileges; and to stop the defendants' erecting any ballast-shore, or wharf, in Westoe, or Jarrow-Slake, aforesaid. From which decree they appaled to the House of Lords, and on 7th May, 1698, the said appeal was dismissed, and the decree affirmed by the lords.—See Lords' Journals, vol xvi. p. 239.
About this time was published "A Draught or Map of the River Tyne," by Capt. G. Collins, II. Moll, sculpsit, dedicated to the Trinity-House of Newcastle. The following names of places occur in it, on the north side of the river: "St. Anne's, Glass-House-Bridge, Glass-House, Red-House, Peter-Shoare, Dents-Hole, St. Tantlius, Billpoint, Winckhamlee-Key, Cosen-House, Stotspow, North-Roade, Woolington-Ballas-Key, Key, Howdon-Ponds, High-Hole, Flatworth-Neste, Durtwich, North-Sheelds, Salt-panns, Sheels-Church, High-Light, Low-Light (no mark of Clifford's-Fort), Tin∣mouth-Castle, Light-House, Pryer, Sparrowhawk." And on the suth side, the follow¦ing: "St. Maryes, Keyes, South-Shoare, Cole-Key, Pryer-Goose, Fallen-Shoare, Fallen-Creeck, Curton-Mill, Bill-Key, Haburn Key, Halfway-Tree, Buoy-of-the passe, Jarro, Jarro-Slike, Jarro-Lake, Salt-Pans, South-Shields, Salt Pans, Hard End.".

During the years 1695, 1697, and 1698, the great cause was de∣pending between Vinkeston, shipmaster, plaintiff, and Ebdon, under
water-bailiff to the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, defendant. This suit commenced on the following occasion: Vinkeston, after loading his ship at Newcastle, refused to pay the toll of five-pence for every chaldron of coals shipped in that harbour, and due to the above corporation, for their charge in maintaining the port of that town; for which the defendant seized her anchor, cable, and sails. Upon this trial, by a special verdict, judgment was given for the defendant
From a MS. communicated by Mr. Josiah Robinson, of the town-clerk's office. See 5 Modern. 359. 1 Salkeld, 248. Carthew's Reports, 357.
It appears from the votes of the House of Commons, June 6th, 1701, that a petition from the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne was presented, and referred to a committee of the whole house, in favour of the numerous body employed in the salt-works upon the river Tyne; who, from the great decay of that trade, were reduced to the lowest indigence, and became a burden to the said town, and places adjacent. See Journals of Commons, vol. xiii..

A. D. 1705, there was an attempt made to procure an act of parliament to make the river Were navigable, and to build a pier or piers at Sunderland by the sea: upon which occasion the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne requested their members to oppose the in∣tended bill, and prevent its passing into a lawCommon-council books. 22d June, 1717, the royal assent was given to this bill..

In the year 1706, it appears to have been in agitation to remove the rocks, called "the Black-Middens," near the entrance of the river Tyne into the sea, which had long been complained of as great nuisances to the navigation of that river. This design was, however, never carried into execution: the scheme was revived at two different times afterwards, but to no better purpose than at firstIbid..

About the year 1711, when an order of parliament passed for leave to bring in a bill, for making the river Tyne navigable from New∣burn to Hexham, the corporation of Newcastle opposed this scheme, as a project, that, if proceeded in, would be of great damage to the river and port of NewcastleIbid. Also Journals of the House of Commons, vol. xvi..

It appears that between February 28th, 1719, and the same day
1721, no less a quantity than 106,874 tuns of ballast were laid upon the several ballast-keys upon the river TyneAffidavit of Henry Peareth, chamber-clerk, in the report of Sir Robert Raymond, attorney-general, relating to Walker estate, 1723. In this he affirms, that, in about 20 years last past, the town had expended, in and about the said river, the sum of 10,000l. and upwards, as appeared by the books belonging to his office, and in his custody..

About the year 1726, the Trinity-House of Newcastle petitioned the mayor and aldermen of that town, concerning several sands in the river Tyne; setting forth, that the channel was much straitened and choaked up; a circumstance occasioned, in their opinion, by the building of Willington-Quay, and the custom of taking ballast out of ships into keels. They expressed, at the same time, their appre∣hensions that the great weight of ballast upon Jarrow-Quay would bring it down, to the immense prejudice of the river
Trinity-House papers.
It appears, January 12th, 1740, that the Tyne was frozen so hard, that all manner of diversions were daily pursued thereon, as sliding, jumping, running, foot-ball; dressing of meat, and selling all kinds of liquors in tents. The continual concourse of persons of both sexes made it resemble a fair. Upwards of 800 keels were laid off work. Newcastle Courant.
It appears by the primage book of the Trinity-House of Newcastle, that so late as A. D. 1750, great quantities of onions, figs, cabbages, &c. were imported from Hol∣land, and other places, into the port of Tyne; which shews, that, about that period, few vegetables were produced in that town and its environs..

A. D. 1755, the fraternity of hostmen, of Newcastle, petitioned the House of Commons against Mr. Richard Liddell's patent for machines for conveying ballast out of ships in the river Tyne, and unloading them at seaHostmen's books..

August 6th, 1761, no less than 260 salmon were taken at one draught, in the river Tyne, at Newburn
Newcastle Courant. The subsequent occur, ibid. "August 28th, 1762: This week a large stone, computed to be upwards of 20 tuns, commonly called "the Grey-Mare," was taken out of the river, opposite the glass-houses, below bridge. It was weighed up with keels, under the direction of Captain Errington, town's-surveyor."
"October 19th, 1765. Tuesday a new machine, of a particular construction, built under the direction of Mr. Robson, a very able and experienced engineer, for clearing this river, was launched off the key."
In the Newcastle Courant, November 1st, 1751, mention occurs of the opening of a subscription, for carrying on a Greenland fishery, from the port of Tyne. The Swallw, Capt. Elliot, returned with four whales, July 7th, 1752.—Ibid.
June 12th, 1755, upwards of 2,400 salmon were taken in the river Tyne, and sla in Newcastle market at one penny, and a penny farthing, per pound.—Ibid.
In the year 175, or 1758, during the mayoralty of Ralph Sowerby, there was printed an account of ballast-dues, dues of the river, and owners' wages..

February 4th, 1765. A petition of masters of ships in the coal trade occurs in the votes of the House of Commons, setting forth, that, from the present method of unloading ballast from ships in the Tyne, that river had, in many places, become shallow, and was apparently filling up so fast as to be greatly alarming, and to demand the con∣sideration of that House: but the fraternity of hostmen of Newcastle set forth, by a counter-petition to parliament, that to permit any bal∣last to be unloaded from ships in that river, otherwise than to be thrown and deposited upon the dry land, where the tide never flows, would be productive of the most dangerous consequences to the na∣vigation thereof
See Hostmen's books.
In the Newcastle Courant, August 23d, 1755, mention occurs of notes being first issued from the Newcastle-Bank, opened December 1st, 1755, in Pilgrim-Street. This is now (1787) called the Old-Bank. There are besides in Newcastle, Surtos' and Burdon's Bank, the Tyne-Bank, and the New-Bank. A filth was established in 1783..

About May, 1768, there was a dangerous insurrection of the sailors, in the port of Tyne, which was made under pretence of raising and regulating their wages
As appears by a printed hand-bill, now lym before msned "Gm."
It appears by the Newcastle Courant, January 22d, 1774, that the river then frozen over, four miles below Newcastle bridge, so that many hundreds of people were skarting, sliding, and walking upon it..

A plan of the low part of the river Tyne, shewing the rocks, sands, high and low water-marks, and depth at low water: also, the towns,
forts, lighthouses, docks, &c. adjacent, from an accurate survey, finished in 1772, by John Fryer, mathematician in Newcastle, was engraved by T. Kitchen, hydrographer to his majesty, in the year 1773. It is on three sheets of paper, dedicated to the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne.

In Hutton's Plan of Newcastle, dated January 10th, 1772, it is related, that the number of ships entered inwards every year in the port of Tyne is nearly as follows:
Ships.
810 77,880 tons, from the coast with goods.
140 18,650 tons, from foreign parts.
950 96,530 In all.

"The trade and shipping of this place," continues that authority, "are very considerable, and have always made it of the utmost con∣sequence.
