Besides its necessary services in supplying a great part of the nation with coals, &c. and the very great revenues arising from thence, it is of the greatest consequence as a nursery for brave and hardy seamen, who have always struck such a terror into the hearts of all the enemies of Great-Britain, that, whenever a rupture hap∣pened with any foreign power, attacks upon this branch of commerce, and body of men, were always studiously avoided"Beside the home and coast trade," adds this account, "the foreign trade of Newcastle, in general, is with Spain, Portugal, France, Holland, Germany, Russia, Sweden, Norway, Denmark, and Poland; besides occasional ships to and from Ame∣rica, the West-Indies, &c. and four or five fitted out every season for the Greenland fishery. The manufactures of steel, and both cast and wrought iron in this neighbour∣hood, are very considerable; that for wrought iron, at Swallwell, about three miles from Newcastle, up the river, commonly called Crowley's-Works, being the greatest in England. Here is also a considerable manufactory of broad and narrow woollen cloth (in Gateshead), and two sugar-house, which have been established here for some time. Likewise two public offices of insurances upon ships, and merchandise, and three printing-offices, whose weekly newspapers circulate several hundred miles."." In the month of June, 1775, no less than 265 salmon were caught at one draught,
at the low lights in the river Tyne.Newcastle-Courant. There had been great commo∣tions among the sailors of Sheilds and Sunderland in the month of March precedingIbid. It was occasioned by a determination of the masters and owners of ships, not to load coals at the late advanced price of one shilling per chaldron.—John Erasmus Blackett, Esq alderman of Newcastle, distinguished himself by his spirited exertions on this alarming occasion..
The subsequent account of the lead exported from the port of Tyne, on an average of six years to Christmas, 1776, was communicated by Mr. Page, deputy comptroller of the port of Newcastle.

ROW.CELL: "To London and other ports of Great-Britain
Weight, at 1 cwt. 2 qrs. per piece, 7072 tons and an half."

DIV1.P:
There was an act of the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, dated October 13th, 1777, ordering ten warrants to be sealed with the common seal of the corporation of that town, impowering the water-bailiff
The water-bailiff's office is of great credit and trust—He is to prevent all defaults against the haven and river of Tyne; to seize to the use of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, all such merchandises as are conveyed on shore in suspected places; and to look after, preserve, and maintain the royalties, privileges, and liberties of the port of Tyne, and is allowed a deputy to assist him in the execution of his very extensive duty. His title was anciently "The Serjeant of the Water."—He is sworn at his admission to his office.
Charles Mitford occurs May 9th, 1623, in St. Nicholas' Register.
Michael Bonner, February 20th, 1646, on the removal of the above.—Common-council books. May 24th, 1703, Nicholas Fenwick, (ibid.) July 20th, 1721, Thomas Fenwick, (ibid.) 1737, Joseph Gamul, (ibid.) 1738, William Aynsley, (ibid.) January 19th, 1745, John Kelly—Newcastle Courant. November 10th, 1758, William Watson was chosen water-bailiff. This officer bears the mace before the mayor and corporation in their solemn processions. The last has lately resigned in favour of his son Stephen Watson.
July 20th, 1721, the common-council ordered a payment of 20l. out of the revenue of the corporation to the water-bailiff, in lieu of samples for deals imported by freemen on their own account, and that no demand of them should be made by any future water-bailiff.—Common-council books.
The corporation of Newcastle appoint an officer called the Key-Master, whose duty it is to attend on the Key or Wharf there—He is to prevent any damage being done to the Key—to appoint the births or stations of ships—to assess or rate by the ton such ballast as shall be cast by warrant directed to him into any keel or boat upon the New Key, out of ships stationed there—to indorse on the said warrant the number of tons and due casting of them without damage to the river, after which the said warrant to be returned into the ballast-office.
While that part of the town-wall that ran along this key was standing, he had the charge of its numerous water-gates. Several fees are paid to this officer for what is called the groundage of ships, besides a stated salary from the corporation.
Robert Carr occurs before 1653, in the common-council books.
October 14th, 1653, John Huntley.—Ibid.
December 14th, 1655, Bertram Anderson.—Ibid.
May 6th, 1704, Baptist Johnson, on the surrender of his father Francis Johnson.—Ibid.
February 26th, 1711, Daniel Soulsby.—Ibid.
September 30th, 1736, John Green occurs.—Ibid.
March 19th, 1740, William Harrison.—Ibid.
January 15th, 1749, George Stephenson.—Ibid. Henry Shadforth, junr. is the present. to seize all goods shipped or unloaded, to be sold in this realm, or elsewhere, at any other place within the port of Tyne, between
Sparhawk and Hedwin Streams, than at the town of Newcastle afore∣said
Common-council books.
August 1777. In consequence of a petition from the masters and owners of ships of the port of Tyne to his majesty, an order of privy council was sent down to permit the ships in the coal trade to take on board guns and stores for defence in case of an attack from an enemy, on giving security that the same be not sold or otherwise disposed of.—A similar permission was granted to the other ports on this coast.—Newcastle Courant.
August 5th, 1778, a deed was executed for the incorporation of a society styled the Union Society, at North-Sheilds, for the insurance of ships belonging to the port of Tyne, to continue for 21 years.
October 28th, 1778, a society for the insurance of ships belonging to Newcastle upon Tyne had their first meeting, and became a body corporate. From printed accounts circulated by the societies..
A. D. 1780, a privateer, called "The Heart of Oak," was fitted out in the port of Tyne, as was also another the year following, called "The Antigallican." Both these proved unsuccessful.

It appears by the Newcastle Courant, August 1st, 1781, that one Ralph Harrison was convicted of causing a quantity of rubbish to be thrown into the river, and fined fifty shillings for the said offence.
The subsequent account of the exports from and imports into the port of Tyne, was communicated A. D. 1782, by Mr. Thomas Aubone, secretary to the Trinity-House.

"Exports are
Of the exports from the river Tyne, Hutton, in his Plan, gives the following account: "Tallow, of which there is shipped annually 40,000 cwt. butter, of which there is ship∣ped annually 30,000 firkins, and salmon, for which there are a great many fisheries on the river, which produce immense quantities. But the greatest quantity of salmon is shipped from Berwick, with the title of Newcastle salmon—for anciently they were brought to Newcastle by land carriage, and being shipped from this port, were called, with the fish really caught in this river, by the common name of Newcastle salmon in London."
"Our imports are most kinds of merchandise," he adds, "as corn and flower, wines, spirits, timber, tar, deals, flax, iron, fruits, smalts, ashes, &c."
Campbell, in his Political Survey, compares the Tyne with the Rhone in France.

Coals, lead, glass, salt, though this trade is now almost lost,It is said to be owing to the loss of the salt trade, that fewer foreign vessels trade hither at present than in the time of Henry VIII. &c. The decline in this branch of trade is said by some to have been occasioned by the avarice of former salt owners, who deceived their foreign dealers, by sending the salt when it was too green; but others ascribe it to some recent discoveries in the art of preparing fossile salt. grind∣stones, cinders, coastways.

FIGURE.P: To George Stephenson Esq This View of the PORT of TYNE with CLIFFORD'S FORT and the Light Houses belonging to the Trinity House of Newcastle upon Tyne. Engraved at his Expence is most respectfully inscribed by his very obliged & most deroled faithful-humble Servt.

DIV1.P:
March 5th, 1787. From a general state of the Greenland whale-fishery (from the accounts of the vessels at that time fitting out at the different ports of the kingdom), it appeared that, at Newcastle upon Tyne, there were then preparing seven ships for that trade; burthen, in all 2,300 tons
Publick Advertiser, London.
The following comparative view of the numbers of ships that came into the port of Tyne in the subsequent years, is extracted from the books of the Trinity-House.

N. B. The number of coasters must be divided by 8, to give the number of vessels, which, one with another and communibus annis, are said to make each 8 voyages in a year—so that for the year 1777, 547 may be thought to be the true number of our vessels in the London and coast trade..

The mayor and burgesses of Newcastle are accustomed every year, on Ascension day, to survey the boundaries of the river Tyne, going down in their barges from the Mansion-House to or near the place, in the sea, called Sparhawk, and returning in the same manner up the river to their utmost limits at Hedwin-Streams. They are always attended on this annual festive expedition by the river jury.

DIV2.HEAD: CUSTOMS AND CUSTOM-HOUSE AT NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.
DIV2.P:
IN the year 1281, Bonricini Giudiconi, for himself and his com∣panions, the merchants of Luca, in the account of moneys received for the new custom of wools, skins, and leathers, in England for that year, appear to have accounted for 323l. 3s. 9d. the custom of 771 sacks, 7½ stone of wool; 11,182 woolled skins, and 80 lasts and 12 dackers of leathers, at the port of Newcastle upon Tyne, at the rate
of half a mark for every sack of wool, a mark for a last of leather, and half a mark for 300 woolled skinsMadox's History of the Exchequer, folio, p. 634..

A. D. 1295, "a Cockettum," or Custom-House, of which Roland Trentacost was the keeper, occurs at Newcastle upon Tyne"Rolandus Trentacost ad custodiam coketti ad Novum Castrum super Tynam per Societatem Lucanicam deputatur, postquam lanae et pelles per preceptum Regis suerunt arrestatae et transfretatio earum inhibita."— Mem. in Scaccar' 23 Ed. I. by Sir John Maynard.—See Cowell's Interpreter in verbo..

In the year 1298, Henry le Escot and Peter Graper were appointed customers, or keepers of the king's customs at Newcastle upon TyneIn process of time, says Madox, p. 535, ut supra, the King's customs came to be more generally called "Custuma"—"Northumbria—de custodia custumae apud Novum Castrum super Tynam per consimiles literas assignantur Henricus le Escot et Petrus Graper ad custodiendum predictam custumam apud Novum Castrum super Tynam. T. Thes. apud Westmon' 5o die Maii anno vicesimo sexto.".
March 26th, 1343, Robert Shilvyngton and Ric' de Galeway occur as collectors of the king's customs, in the port of Newcastle upon TyneRolls of Bishop Bury, Sch. 15. anno episcopatus 11o..

In the year 1347, John de Copeland had 100l. per annum assigned him out of the customs, in the port of Newcastle upon TyneRymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 543. "20 Ed. III. Johanni de Copeland centum libras de exitibus custumarum nostratum in portu Berewici et centum libras singulis annis de exitibus custumarum in portu villae Novi Castri per manus collectorum habueritis, &c.".

July 10th, 1351, Robert Bertram had an hundred marks assigned him out of the customs in the port of Newcastle upon TyneIbid. p. 723. "Rob. Bertram centum marcas de exitibus custumarum in portu Novi Castri super Tinam per manus collector' percipiend' &c. decimo die Julii 1351.".
A. D. 1388, John de Refham and Robert de Rypon are mentioned as searchers in the port of Newcastle upon TyneRymer's Foedera, tom. vii. p. 589..
July 16th, 1440, Robert Rodes was appointed by King Henry the Sixth to the office of comptroller of the port of Newcastle upon TyneBourne's History, sub anno..

In the year 1454, there was an order of parliament to levy 20l. of the inhabitants of Newcastle upon Tyne, and also that that sum should be repaid them out of the first money that should arise out of a subsidy on merchandises exported from, and imported into, the port of that townRot. Parliament. vol. v. p. 245..
November 22d, 1509, King Henry VIII. appointed John Dalton collector, and customer of wools, skins, and woolfells, in the port of the town of Newcastle upon TyneBourne's History, sub anno..
A. D. 1527, Leonard Musgrave, Esq was collector of the customs in the port of NewcastleIbid. sub anno..
The following account of the establishment of the custom-house at Newcastle upon Tyne, in the time of Queen Elizabeth, is preserved in Peck's Desiderata Curiosa.
February 17th, 1578, Robert Dudley, gent. occurs as one of the Queen's customers of the port of Newcastle.In a deed preserved in the vestry of All Saints in Newcastle upon Tyne.

In September that year, Mr. Henry Mitford occurs as comptroller.
Register of St. Nicholas, ibid. Mention occurs, ibid. February, 1584, of Mr. Sher∣wood, a former customer.
Ibid. November 1588, there is mention of "Mr. Henrie Sanderson, customer."
Ibid. August 1592, of "Mr. Johnson, customer."
Ibid. July, 1598, of "Mr. Henrye Ryvers, controller," and August, 1600, of "Mr. Richard Pittes, customer."
Ibid. October, 27th, 1616, of "Mr. Bakar, customer."
Ibid. September 7th, 1609, "Philip Norton, one of the king's customers," buried.
Ibid. December, 1619, "Mr. Kellio, customar," occurs.
The following entry is in All Saints Register: "Nov. 15th, 1613, Mr. Christopher Ridley, clarke of the custome-house, buried."
January 6th, 1604, mention occurs of a house upon the Sand-Hill, called the Custom-House—See account of Nunmoor.
Guthrie, in his Memoirs, p. 133, tells us that on the taking of New∣castle upon Tyne by the Scots, October 19th, 1644, "James Sword, burgess of St. Andrews, was made collector of the customs."

December 5th, 1644, Mr. George Dawson was appointed to that office; as at the same time was Mr. Henry Dawson to that of custo∣mer in the town of Newcastle, in the place of Richard Wynne, and Mr. George FenwickIn a letter preserved in the Lords' Journals, vol. vii. p. 43, from the committee at Newcastle, to William Lenthall, Esq speaker of the commons, October 22d, 1644, this Mr. George Fenwick is recommended as one "who hath suffered very much and been long banished from his house in the towne of Newcastle." to that of customer also, in the room of Mr. John Mettam; to manage and collect the customs for the advantage of the common-wealthJournals of Commons, vol. iii..
December 9th, 1644, the new appointed officers of this Custom-House were directed to make a new seal for cocketts, and other things belonging to the said houseIbid..

July 15th, 1734, a salary of 20 guineas per annum was ordered by the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be paid to Alfred
Lawson, Esq of the Custom-House of that town, during their pleasure, for his services in inforcing the payment of the dues of the corporation, usually paid before that time at the town's house by all masters of ships, when they cleared their respective vessels at the Custom-HouseCommon-council books..
Before Nov. 1st, 1746, Anthony Isaacson, Esq was collector of the customs in the port of NewcastleNewcastle Courant..

May 20th, 1765, the workmen began to clear the ground on a spot on the Key side of Newcastle upon Tyne, near the Low-Crane, for the erection of a new custom-houseIbid.. This has since been finished on a neat and elegant plan. The old custom-house stood near the corner of the Sand-Hill.

A. D. 1772, the revenue of the Custom-House was estimated at 41,000l. per annum, exclusive of the Duke of Richmond's shilling per chaldron on all coals sent coastways, amounting to about 15,000l. moreHutton's Plan of Newcastle upon Tyne, dated January 10th, 1772. He adds, that "the excise raised in Newcastle and Gateshead is about 80,000l. Besides these, the land tax and window cess for both produce about 5,000l. so that the whole revenue raised from Newcastle and Gateshead, will be about 140,000l. per annum.".

February 15th, 1772, Sir Blackeston Conyers, Bart. occurs as lately appointed to be collector of the customs in the port of Newcastle, on the resignation of Langdale Sunderland, Esq
Newcastle Courant.
Ibid. Dec. 23d, 1775, a patent is mentioned to have passed the seal containing a grant to Sir Samuel Gordon, Bart. Jennison William Gordon, and Thomas Shaftoe, Esqrs. or the longest liver of them, of the office of customer in the port of Newcastle upon Tyne. April 1th, 1782, a patent passed the great seal, appointing Sir Jennison William Gordon, Bart. and William Charleton, Esq jointly customer of the port of Newcastle upon Tyne. Ibid.
April 6th, 1782, mention occurs ibid. of the appointment of Chistopher Nesham, Esq customer of the port of Newcastle, on the death of Thomas Shaftoe, Esq
April 24th, 1782, died Mr. Thomas Richardson, land-surveyor of the port of New∣castle. Ibid.
In a list of useless offices in the customs to be abolished by publick authority, but in compenstion for which an annual value is to be paid to the grantees during their lives, occur those of "two customers of Newcastle:" and in another of employments in the said customs, which have been converted into sinecures, the holders of whom having coe no duty, and proved themselves of no use, are therefore laid aside with annuities their lives, occur those of the "Newcastle comptroller and searcher."—New∣castle-Journal, March 15th, 1783..
In the year 1785, there were cleared at the Custom-House of New∣castle upon Tyne 4339 vessels coastwise, 491 over sea; in all 4830Newcastle Courant..

At a general meeting of the merchants residing in the port of New∣castle, held Sept. 15th, 1787, pursuant to publick advertisement, Mr. Mayor in the chair, a letter from Mr. Rose, one of the secretaries of the treasury, to the mayor, being read, it was, after some deliberation, resolved, That the abolition of the sees of the officers of the customs, if followed by a tonnage duty, is inexpedient, and will be highly dis∣tressing to the merchants and ship-owners of this port, from the par∣ticular nature of their trade. That if the sees now paid in this port remain as they are, it will not be necessary that parliament should interpose in the regulation of themIbid..

DIV2.HEAD: GLASS-WORKS ON THE RIVER TYNE.
DIV2.P: GLASS-MAKERS are said to have been first brought out of France into England A. D. 674, on the building of the new abbey of Were∣mouth, at a few miles distance from the mouth of the river TyneAnderson's Dictionary of Commence, vol. i. p. 6..

Glasses, the siner sort of which were first manufactured at Grutched-Friars in London, first began to be made in England A. D. 1557. The fine flint glass, little inferior to that of Venice, was first made in the Savoy-House in the Strand, London, as were the first glass-plates for looking-glasses and coach-windows at Lambeth, by the encourage∣ment of the Duke of Buckingham, in the year 1673Ibid. p. ..

We may venture to fix the beginning of the glass-works upon the
river Tyne about A. D. 1619
In the book of inrollments in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, liber primus, p. 2, there is a copy of a lease to "Sir Robert Mansell, knt. vice admiral of England," on consideration of the surrender of a former lease made for diverse years yet unexpired, "of certaine grounds, being the greatest part of the east-ballast shoares and the glasse-houses, and other several tenements erected upon the same, and boundreth upon Useburne on the west, and extendeth itselfe to a runnell betwixt the said shoares and the grounds of St. Lawrence on the east, upon the river of Tyne upon the south, unto a place called Slatiford on the north part." Date, 5th of February, 1637-8, 13 Charles I. —Term from Michaelmas last for 21 years, at the yearly rent of 20 shillings.—The same covenant, were in the former lease.
Howeil, who appears by the Biographia Britannica, vol. iv. p. 2684, to have been steward to Sir Robert Mansell's glass-house, in Broad-Street in London, previous to which he had been sent over to Venice to learn the art of glass-making, tells us, in one of his letter dated March 5th, 1618, that King James is reported to have said, "that he wondered Robin Mansell, being a seaman, whereby he had got so much honour, should I fall from water to temper with fie, which are two contrary elements."—In a letter to Dr. Franis Mansell, at All Souls in Oxford, the same Howell has the following wor: "Your honourable uncle, Sir Robert Mansell, hath melted vast sums of money in this glass business."
In St. Nicholas' Register, Newcastle, November 22d, 1619, is the subsequent entry: "John Teswicke, sonne of Tymothie Teswicke, glasse-maker, a Frenhman, bap."— "Alm Felwick" is the name of one of the godfather.
In All Saints' Register, M 15th, 1619, "Isaack Hensey, glas maker," occurs. "De∣cember 1619, Jacob Hen, glass-maker."—"October 162, Samuel Trk, glass-maker"—"October 162, David Tyttre, alias Rusher, glass-maker"—"March, 165, Daniel Henzey, broad glass-maker"—"1626 Perigreene Henzey, broad glass-maker" —"September 1631, Tubal Crissom, workeman at the glass-house." "September 1647, Robert Tazzick, broad glass-maker"—"January 5th, 1644, Peregreene, sonne of Benja∣min Hanzey, glass-maker."—It is observable that the Henzells and Tizacks still con∣tain to prside over these glass-works—indeed they will admit none of any other name to work with them. The Titorys are now extinct., where they were established by Sir Robert Mansell, knt. vice admiral of England. The cheapness of sea coal was no doubt his chief inducement for erecting them at so great a distance from London.

In the year 1635, King Charles, by his proclamation, prohibited the importation of any sort of glass from foreign parts, during the term granted by King James to Sir Robert Mansell, for the sole making of that commodity: In this proclamation it is set forth that "Sir Robert Mansell had by his industry and great expence perfected that manufac∣ture, with sea-coal or pit coal, whereby not only the woods and timber of this kingdom are greatly preserved, but the making of all kinds of
glass is established here, to the saving of much treasure at home, and the employment of great numbers of our people"Rymer's Foedera, tom. xix. fol. 693. It appears that King James, in the 13th year of his reign, had prohibited the making of glass with wood firing, for the better preserving of timber, and also had prohibited the importation of foreign glass. King Charles's proclamation tells us "our subjects now are furnished with glass at far more moderate prices than they were when it was brought from foreign parts." Yet Sir Robert Mansell is permitted to import such glasses from Venice, Morana, and other parts of Italy, as he should think fit for special uses and services.—Anderson, in his Dictionary of Commerce, vol. ii. p. 54, understands this permission as relating to the fine Venetian flint glasses for drinking, the making of which in England was not brought to perfection till the reign of King William the Third..

February 20th, 1646, there is an order of common-council for a parcel of ground, at St. Lawrence Shore, to be let upon lease for the term of 21 years, to Edmund Harris, of London, gentleman, to erect certain glass works on, and for which the tenant was to pay the yearly rent of ten pounds
Common-council Order-Book: This "parcell of ground at St. Lawrence Shoare, conteigning in length 15 yards or thereabouts, and 90 yards in breadth o thereabouts, and in breadth at the east end 40 yards and halfe the docke, att the yearely rent of tenn pounds, and that the toll of the two glasse-houses now built on the said shoare bee also lett unto him for the said terme—(21 years)—at the yearely rent of 15l. for each glasse-house, &c."
Some variance arising between this Mr. Harris and a "Richard Haynes of this towne," (i. e. Newcastle) there is an order of the above common-council, Sept. 10th, 1647, that the above be leased to these two person outh.
In the Lords' Journal, vol. vii. p. 38, 21 April, 1645—we read that "upon hearing the cause by counsel on both sides, between Sir Robert Mansell and Mr. Harris—Re∣solved, that Mr. Harris shall restore the possession of the houses, pots and stones, to Sir Robert Mansell, with 100l. for damages."
Ibid. Die Martis 23 Sept. 1645, Edward Harris refusing to pay the 10l. "Ordered that the gentlemam usher attach the said Harris for his contempt."
July 17th, 1652, Sir Robert Mansell petitioned the common-council of Newcastle for a new lease of the east ballast-shores and glass-houses thereupon, six years and upwards of his former lease being unexpired; but his request was not complied with.
In the common-council books, April 1st, 1653, "new glass-houses and ould glass-houses" occur.
April 10th, 1653, ibid. Mr. Haines occurs as owner, or lessee of the new works, and acknowledging "at present he is not in a capacity to pay ars of rent and toll."
Ibid. August 12th, 1653, mention occurs of "thed ath of Sir Robert Mansell, and that the remainder of his lease, about 6 years, had devolved to one Mr. Moyer.".

March 18th, 1656, John Hatteril and Robert Tainton, on behalf of themselves and others, citizens and glaziers of London, requested a lease of the common-council of Newcastle, "of the old glass-houses," to expire with that of the new glass-houses yet in being, or else to have them renewed for 21 years. They represented themselves as
interested by two assignments in both the said glass-works.—This was granted on the 24th of March followingCommon-council books..

June 4th, 1658, the common-council granted a lease to Robert Tainton, and William Pollicot, called "The glass-men from London," for 21 years, of the old glass-house, at the rent of 70l. per annum, and to pay 10l. per annum, should they build the house which was at that time in ruins. John Hatteril, John Oliver, and Alice Kaine were the other lessees.Ibid..
June 20th, 1678, there was an order of common-council, for a new lease of the western glass-houses to Robert Tainton, John Oliver, and Benjamin TaintonIbid..

September 21st, 1679, there was an order of common-council to grant a lease to Jacob Henzey, William Tizacke, and Daniel Tittery of the western glass-houses, to commence at Michaelmas following. The clauses, term, rent, and covenants, to be duly considered by the mayor and aldermen, and in case the glaziers of Newcastle have the glass at a certain rate, and on condition also that the burgesses inhabit∣ing that town should have the glass, as well as the glaziers, for their own private use within the town, at a certain rate, at which the pro∣prietors and lessees should be obliged to sell itIbid..
April 7th, 1684, the common-council ordered a new lease to John Henzell, Peregrine Tizack, and other partners in the eastern glass-houses, for 21 yearsCommon-council books..
Dec. 20th, 1692, a glass-house occurs at Howdon-pansIbid..
July 23d, 1694, a glass-house appears to have been erected at Haining-Shore, now called the Bill-KeyIbid..

Dec. 3d. 1696, the glass-makers in and about Newcastle are men∣tioned as petitioning parliament against a late act, by which a perpetual duty had been laid upon all glass wares made in England, to their great loss and discouragement, and praying the relief of the house, to have the said duty taken off
Journals of the Common, vol. xii.
21 May, 1698—Joshua Middleton is mentioned as the owner of a glas-house at Newcastle..

March 9th, 1699, the house having taken off half the duty upon glass, the same petitioners occur as praying that the remaining half may also be taken off. Their petition was referred to a committee, but they obtained no farther reliefJournals of Common, vol. 11..

April 24th, 1710, mention occurs of a glass-house at Close-GateCommon-council books At the same time leave was granted to the glass-makers to erected gallery at their own charge, at the west end of St. Ann's Chapel..

April 5th, 1737, the following glass-works are mentioned in the com∣mon-council books: "Broad glass-houses called Howden and South-Sheilds glass-houses.—The bottle houses, called Close-Gate bottle-house —Western bottle-house—St. Lawrence bottle-house—Bill-Key bottle-house, and the flint glass-house at Close-Gate."

There appear to have been constantly and fully employed on the river Tyne, A. D. 1772, sixteen large glass works, viz. one for plate glass; three crown glass-houses; five for broad or common window-glass— two for white or flint glass, and five bottle-houses. The glass manu∣factured in these is sent to most parts of the worldHutton's Plan of Newcastle, dated January th, 1772..

In 1777, the parliament having laid an additional duty on glass, the several glass-makers in the river Tyne were under the necessity of advancing the prices of that commodityFrom a printed bill distributed by the owners and proprietors of the glass-houses.

DIV2.HEAD: MONASTERY OF JARROW.
DIV2.P: THIS house, which was of the Benedictine orderSee Bede's Lives of the Abbots of Weremouth and Jarrow, edited by Ware, p. 230, 235., was originally annexed to the neighbouring monastery of Weremouth; so that they stand inseparably connected in the earlier parts of their common history.

Both were founded towards the end of the seventh century, chiefly under the auspices of Benedict Biscop
Bede styles him "Biscopus cognomento Benedictus." He was a native of North∣umberland, and descended from a noble family of the Angles: having been rewarded with lands for his military services, by Oswy, king of Northumberland, he betook him∣self to a religious life, and went to Rome, according to the prevailing practice among the new and zealous converts to Christianity, of visiting the holy see. Unsatisfied with the first, he appears to have made a second voyage thither, soon after his return to Britain, and was to have been accompanied in it by Alchfrid, the king's son, if that pious prince had not been prevented by his father's express injunctions to the contrary. Afterwards having taken the tonsure, he was two years a monk in the isle of St. Honorat, in France, and going a third time to Rome, was deputed from thence, by Pope Vitalian, in company with Theodore and Adrian, two distinguished ecclesiasties, emi∣nent for both sacred and profane learning, as a missionary into Britain.
Settling in Kent, where Theodore was appointed archbishop of Canterbury, and Benedict, abbot of the monastery of St. Peter and St. Paul in that city, after two year, Benedict went a fourth time to Rome, to purchase sacred books, &c. purposing on his return to have put himself under the protection of Coynwalh, king of the West ; but finding that king dead on his arrival, he returned to Northumberland, and, with the assistance of King Ecfrid, founded the above monasteries of Weremouth and Jarrow. Leland, on I know not what authority, has asserted, that Theodore, Archbishop of Canterbury, founded the monastery of St. Peter, at the mouth of the Were, and also this at Jarrow, in honour of St. Paul.—Collectanea, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 70., a Saxon monk, of great eminence in his time, who having been a soldier in his earlier youth,
devoted himself to religion at the age of twenty-five; and, having taken the tonsure, became a zealous teacher, and, as it were, missionary of the monastic life.

Under the protection of Egfrid, King of Northumberland, who gave the site
Egfrid, who had four years before succeeded his father Oswy, in the kingdom of Northumberland, gave Benedict 70 families of land, on the above occasion. Sir James Ware supposes that hides, or carrneates, are here intended by the expression "families of land."
The same king gave afterwards 40 families of land more, in augmentation of the first endowment.—Bede Vit. Abbat. ut supra, 224., together with an ample endowment of land; and, assisted by the skill of an able and zealous coadjutor, named CeolfridIbid. p. 239., A. D. 674, this Benedict began to lay the foundations of a monastery, near the mouth, and on the northern bank of the river Were, in ho∣nour of St. Peter, the prince of the apostles. Benedict made a voyage into France the year following, and brought back with him skilful masons to build the church of that abbey
He constructed the church of stone, after the manner of the Roman architecture, and adorned its walls and roofs with pictures which he had purchased at Rome, representing, among other sacred subjects, the Virgin Mary, the twelve apostles, the evangelical history, and the visions of the Apocalypse. The windows were glazed by artists brought from France. He added to his monastery an ample library, which he stored with Greek and Latin volumes, imported by himself from Italy. Ceolfrid, his successor, augmented this collection with three volumes of pandects, and a book of cosmography, wonderfully enriched with curious workmanship, and bought at Rome. See Bede's Hist. Abbat. Wiremuth. p. 295, 297, edit. Cantab.
In one of his expeditions to Rome, he brought over John, Arch-chanter of St. Peter's in that city, who introduced the Roman method of singing mass.—Bede, ibid. p. 295.
He taught the monks of Benedict's Abbey, and all the singers of the monasteries of that province came from various parts to hear him sing.—Bede's Hist. Eccles. iv. 18. He likewise brought over from Rome two silken pall, of exquisite workmanship, with which he afterwards purchased of King Aldfrid, successor of Elfrid, two pieces of land for his monastery.—Bede, Vit. Abbat. ut supra, p. 297. Bale censures Benedict for being the full who introduced into England, painter, ziers, "et id genus alios ad voluptatem artifices" Cent. 1. 82. This is the language of a puritan in life, as well as in religion. —Warton's 2d Dissrtation. History of Poetry, vol. 1., after the manner of the
Roman architecture, which rose under their hands with such rapidity, that, within a year after it began to be built, it was covered in, and divine service performed in it
A bell hangs at present in the belfry of Jarrow church, which is doubtless the one that was placed at the first in the church of the monastery. It has two fleurs de lis on it, which sufficiently intimate in what country it was cast. Bede tells us, "Cuncta quae ad altaris et ecclesiae ministerium competebant, vasa sancta, vel vesti∣menta, quia domi invenire non potuit, de transmarinis regionibus advectare religiosus emptor curabat." He is speaking of Benedict, and just before the above passage men∣tions his sending to France for masons and glass-makers. This is certainly one of the first bells used for religious purposes in England.
It is observable in the inscription on this bell (see plate of Miscellaneous Antiquities, No 8.), which is plainly to be understood "SANCTE PAULE ORA PRO NOBIS," that the A in ORA, the R in PRO, and the N in NOBIS, have, probably through the ignorance of the founder, been turned upside down in the mould. To the same cause may be attributed the transposition of some of the letters; the V after the L in PALUS, ought to precede it; and the S that follows, be taken to the end of the word NOBIS, where, instead of that letter, there is an E turned upside down, which ought to follow the L, and make the word "Paule," in the vocative case, to agree with "Sancte." That the fleurs de lis were then in the arms of France, see Edmondson's Complete Body of Heraldry. vol. i. p. 3, where he cites several ancient authors, for the fabulous account that a banner, whereon were depicted three lilies, or, on a field azure, was sent from heaven to Clovis, the first Christian monarch of France, who began his reign A. D. 486. The diameter of this bell is nearly 29 inches, and its greatest circumference 78 inches..
About the year 680, Benedict obtained from Agatho, Pope of Rome, a grant of privileges and immunities for the above mo∣nasteryBede's Vit. Abbat. ut supra, p. 221..

In the year of Christ 681
I have dated the foundation of Jarrow in 681; and the dedication of the church of that monastery according to the inscription still preserved in the present parish church of Jarrow, on the kalends of May, four years afterwards, i. e. 685, which was indeed the 15th year of the reign of King Ecfrid, and the fourth year of the abbacy of Ceolfrid, the founder. This makes an intire correspondence between the dates on the first and last pages of Bede's History of the Lives of the Abbots of this place: Ceolfrid, he says, died on the 7th of the kalends of October, A. D. 716, after having been abbot of Jar∣row 7 years, and of the joint monasteries 28 years.
Lambarde says, that Jarrow was founded in the year 673.
The date of the foundation thereof, in the Biographia Britannica, is A. D. 682., the monastery of Jarrow
Jarrow, Girvum, Gyrpa, Saxon, a Fenne or Marishe. Lambarde's Topogr. Dictionary in verbo.
"Gyrwii vocantur qui juxta paludem, vel infra paludem, habitant. Gyr, Anglicè profunda palus."—Dr. Ellison's MSS.
"What is now the of Ely was anciently called Suth-Girwa." Bentham's Ely, p. 47.
"It is to be remarked," says Dr. Pettingal, on the gule of August, Archaeolog. vol. ii. p 63, "that in the old English or British language, the Y, W, and G, are used interchangeably for each other, as in Yule, Wyl, and Gwyl, all three being but one and the same word, signifying the same thing, though differently written.", founded by
CeolfridBede Vit Abbat. ut supra, p. 231., in honour of St. Paul, the teacher of the Gentiles, began to be built, under the auspices of Benedict, and with the approbation, or rather at the command of King Ecgfrid.

This was intended to be rather a part of, than a distinct institution from, the former house at Weremouth, under the general name of the one monastery of St. Peter and St. Paul, situated in different placesIbid. "In ditobus locis posito uni monasterio beatorum Apostolorum Petri et Pauli 28 annos praesuit.".
A. D. 683, Benedict, accompanied by Ceolfrid, for the fifth time, set out for Rome; Eosterwin having, before their departure, been ap∣pointed co-abbot of both housesIbid..

The famous ecclesiastical writer Bede, who was born of obscure parents in the vicinity of Jarrow, was, in the year 684, being then seven years of age, sent for hi education to the monastery of that place.

During the absence of Benedict and Ceolfrid, on their visit to the holy see, the church of Jarrow monastery appears to have been com∣pleted. It was dedicated, on the 9th of the kalends of May, 685, as we learn from a very observable inscription, in large Roman letters, on a square stone, still preserved in the parish church of that place
The subsequent copy of this inscription I took m the original stone, November 16th, 1782, which had them been newly built upon the wall over the entrance to the chancel of Jarrow church; it had before been built up in the north wall of that edifice:
The stone is of two pieces, joined in the middle. Mr. Allison, the mason and master builder, informed me, that they had been wrought so originally. The piece se∣parated by a crack running through the L C and D, was found cramped on with an iron cramp when taken out. The most minute particulars are interesting concerning a stone, which bears one of the most curious inscriptions now remaining in the island.
There is a copy of the above in Leland's Collectanea, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 42, taken by him from a chronicle of an uncertain author and date, preserved at Whitby. In that copy an M is put by mistake instead of the second Q.
Grose, in his account of Jarrow, tells us, that, "in the space between the third and fourth line, there is a roughness on the surface of the stone, seemingly as if a line had been erased." On taking it out of the north wall, A. D. 1782, when Jarrow-church was altered and repaired, it was discovered to be of two pieces, at the juncture of which this roughness appeared.
Bourne's reading is erroneous, and so is that of Sir James Ware.
Grose's reading wants the— above the D O.
I translate it as follows, taking in the two QQ's.
"The dedication of the church of St. Paul on the 9th of the kalends of May in the 15th year of King Egfrid, and the fourth of Ceolfrid, abbot, and, under God, the founder of the said church."
The basilicae of gentile Rome, the buildings where the magistrates held the courts of justice, were converted into churches on their conversion to Christianity; and thus came the word basilica to signify a church. The 9th of the kalends of May is the 23d of April..

A. D. 687, March 6th, Eosterwin diedBede, ut supra. He died in the 47th year of his age. He was cousin german by the father's side to Benedict, and so humble, that he thought it not beneath his dignity to accompany the brethren at the plough, work at the anvil, winnow corn, milk the cow, and shep, and partake of other labours with them in the garden, bake-house, and kitchen. Such was the ancient simplicity of manners in the monastic life, and so far were the dignitaries of the infant church here from affecting pomp or state. of the plague, and Sig∣frid was elected co-abbot of the two monasteries in his stead. In
this situation Benedict and Ceolfrid, after a long absence, found him on their return. The devout travellers purchased on this occasion, and brought home with them ornaments of images and pictures for the new church of Jarrow monasteryIbid. p. 229. "Imagines quoque ad ornandum monasterium ecclesiamque Beati Pauli Apostoli de concordia Veteris et Novi Testamenti summa ratione compositas exhibuit, verbi gratia Isaac Ligna quibus immolaretur portantem et Dominum crucem in qua pateretur aeque portantem: proxima super invicem regione pictura conjunxit. Item serpenti in heremo a Moyse exaltato, Filium hominis in cruce exaltatum comparavit.".
January 12th, 690, Benedict, worn out with labours and travels, died of a palsy, and was buried in the church of St. Peter, at Were∣mouth.
Sigfrid died, of a disorder in his lungs, four months afterwards: two months before his death Ceolfrid was a second time appointed abbot of both monasteriesBede's Lives of the Abbots, ut supra..

A. D. 696, Bede was ordained a deacon, by John, Bishop of Hex∣ham; to which see the monasteries of Jarrow and Weremouth be∣longed before the erection of the bishoprick of DurhamSee Smith's Bede, p. 797, l. 30..

In the year 700, certain privileges were granted to the joint mo∣nastery of St. Peter and St. Paul, at Weremouth and Jarrow, by Sergius, Pope of Rome. These were afterwards confirmed by King Alfred
Wilkinsii Concilia, tom. i. p. 63, de privelegio monasterii S. S. Petri et Pauli, concesso a Sergio papa, &c. A. D. 700. Ex MS. Usserii.—Tanner's Notitia Monasti∣ca. See Simeon of Durham de Gest. Reg. Angl. apud decem Scriptores, col. 95.
"Privelegium monasterio (Petri et Pauli) a papa Sergio accepit, quod perlatum & coram synodo patefactum magnifici Regis Alfridi subscriptione est confirmatum.".
A. D. 707, Bede was ordained a priest, by the above John, Bishop of HexhamSmith's Bede..

September 25th, 716, CeolfridThis Ceolfrid obtained from the learned and pious King Aldfrid eight hides of land, near the river Fresca (now unknown), the grant of which Benedict had undertaken before his death, and gave them to the monastery of Jarrow: which eight hides of land were afterwards exchanged, in the reign of Ofred, for other eight hides in a village called Sambuce, which lay nearer to the monastery.—Leland's Collectan. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 160., then 74 years of age, and on a
second journey to Rome, died at Langres, a bishop's see, in the pro∣vince of Champaigne, in France. He had left Weremouth on the 4th of the preceding June. There were at this time near 600 monks in the two monasteries. Ceolfrid, who had been in priest's orders 47 years, and abbot 35 years, or rather, as he was the constant com∣panion and coadjutor of Benedict from the first foundation of Were∣mouth, he may be said to have been abbot 43 years
Egfrid, the sixth king of the Northumbrians, began his reign A. D. 670, and was killed in the year 685, the fortieth of his age, and fifteenth year of his reign. Ealdfirth, or Alcfrid, natural son of Oswy, succeeded his half-brother Egfrid, and dying 705, was succeeded by Ofred.—Strut's Chronicle, vol. i. p. 142, 143, 144.
In the year 710, Naiton, king of the Picts, sent ambassadors to Ceolfrid, abbot of this house, desiring his advice concerning the observation of Easter, and the mode of the tonsure; requesting of him also to send architects into Scotland, to build a church of stone there, after the manner of the Romans, which he promised to dedicate to the Prince of the Apostles. Ceolfrid sent him in return a very long letter of advice, and also architects for the above purpose, according to his desire. Bede's Church History, lib. v. cap. 21., was buried with great funeral pomp, in the church of St. Gemini, near Lan∣gresBede's Lives of the Abbots, ut supra, p. 240, &c.

Before Ceolfrid left England, Huetbert was chosen abbot of both monasteries, in whose favour the former carried with him a recom∣mendatory epistle to Gregory II. who had just then been appointed to the papal chair.

This Huetbert was confirmed in the co-abbacy of Weremouth and Jarrow, by Acca, Bishop of Hexham. He had been placed here at a very early period of his life, and, in the time of Pope Sergius, had visited Rome: he was very expert at writing, singing, reading, and teach∣ing, and had been twelve years in priest's orders before his last pro∣motion.

He removed the body of his predecessor Eosterwin, from the porch of the church of St. Peter, at Weremouth; as also the bones of Sigfrid, his former master, which had been buried on the outside of the vestry towards the south, and, putting them in one coffin, se∣parated only by a thin partition, deposited them near the remains of BenedictBede Vit. Abbat. ut supra..

May 26th, 735, Bede, the great boast of the monastery of St. Paul, died, and was buried, first at Jarrow, but his body was afterwards removed to Durham
Vita Bedae—Smith's edition, p. 804, &c. He had become a great Latin scholar, and made no small proficiency in the Greek tongue. His fame had reached the ears of Pope Sergius, who wrote to the above Ceolfrid to send him to Rome: perhaps he de∣clined the invitation through modesty; for he is said never to have been out of his native island. The pope's epistle is preserved by Malmsbury.
A porch (or chantry perhaps) was consecrated in honour of Bede, on the north side of the church of St. Paul's, at Jarrow; and in the eleventh century, a little mansion built of stone, to which he was wont to retire to his studies and devotions, was pointed out to all that came then to visit the ruins of this place.
About a mile to the west of Jarrow there is a well, still called Bede's Well, to which, as late as the year 1740, it was a prevailing custom to bring children troubled with any disease or infirmity, a crooked pin was put in, and the well laved dry between each dipping. My informant has seen twenty children brought together on a Sunday, to be dipped in this well; at which also, on Midsummer-eve, there was a great resort of neigh∣bouring people, with bonfires, musick, &c.
The picture of Bede, in a fine blue habit, in coloured glass, is preserved in the church a Durham.—Antiquities of Durham Abbey, p. 109.
Pale, in his British Writers, century 2d. p. 10, gives us an account of one Cuthbert, monk of Jarrow, the friend of Bede, and who wrote and dedicated to his contemporary Cuthruinus, a book on the Life and Death of Bede, and another volume of familiar Epistles. He flourished A. D. 74..

A. D. 788, the general of a party of Danes, who had entered King Egfrid's haven, was killed, whilst the barbarians were pillaging this monastery
Leland's Collectanea, vol. ii. p. 321. "Anno Higbaldi 7 (viz. 788.) dum pa∣gani portum Ecfridi Regis, hoc est Girwi vastantes, monasterium ad ossium Tini amnis depraedarentur, dux eorum ibidem crudeli nece interiit."
Bourne's History, an explanatory note adds, that Ecfrid's Haven is a gulf which pene∣trates from the Tyne to Girwi, or Jarrow. It penetrated also more inward, as far as Ellton, almost 3,000 paces above Girwy, where also little ships formerly came. A ri∣vulet enters this gulf..

In the year 870, this monastery of Jarrow was plundered and de∣stroyed during an incursion of the Danish barbariansMatthew Westminster' Flores Histor. p. 314. "Anno 870 destructa referuntur nobilishma monasteria in margine maris fita—Coenobium Girwiense monachorum et Witethense in quibus Beda presbyter legitur educatus.".

About the year 1070, Jarrow is said to have been burnt by William the Conqueror, who came down to the north at this time to revenge the death of Earl Cumin
"Jarrow tune combusta per Conquestorem." Liber Ruber Ecclesiae Dunelm. Grey's MSS.
See Leland's Collectan. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 197, where, speaking of the flight of Bishop Eglwinus with the body of St. Cuthbert, he says, "Fugam ineunt 3 Id. De∣cemb. Feria sexta—primam mansionem habuerunt in Girwi, secundam in Bethling∣tune." See ibid. vol. ii. tom. i. pars 2. p. 380. "Interea regis exercitus etiam per loca quaeque inter Teisam et Tyne diffusus, vacuis ubique domibus solam invenit solitudinem—Tunc etiam ecclesia S. Pauli Apostoli in Girwi flammis con∣sumpta." See ibid. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 229. "Cirester 4 annum Gul. Mag. Bedae monasterium violentia Gul. Mag. conflavit.".

A. D. 1074, this place is mentioned as being then in ruins, re∣taining nothing of its primitive grandeur, without any thing left but the naked walls: about this time Aldwin, who had come down as a missionary from the southern parts of the kingdom to revive the monastic institution in Northumberland, was advised by Walcher, then bishop of Durham, to remove from Monkchester (now Newcastle), his first residence after his arrival, to Jarrow, which that prelate ap∣pears to have re-endowed on the occasion.

At the same time Waltheof, Earl of Northumberland, gave to this Aldwin and his brethren the church of Tinmouth
Monast. Angl. p. 42.
Insuper Walthe Core Northumbriae donavit dictis morins in Girvum Tyne∣muth sub na forma: "In me Patris & Filii & Spiritus Sancti Amen. Ego Wal∣theol Comes totius Northumbriae do concedo & presenti scripto confirmo Aldwino priori et fratribus cum eo apud Girwe in Dei servicio congregandis—in puram & per∣petuam elemosinam, ecclesiam S. Marie in Tynemuth unà cum corpore S. Oswini Regis et Martyris, qui in eadem ecclesia requiescit, una cum omnibus terris & locis &c. imperpetuum et cum prescripta elemosina offero puerum istum Morkarum no∣mine sub monachica disciplina in Dei servitio instituendum. Et quia locus ille nimis videtur religiosis horridus & incultus et Dominus Episcopus Walcherus & nos caeteri quique probi hujus episcopatus viri competentionem quietis sedis circa sanctum Beati Cuthberti corpus Deo annuente eis preparare proposuimus, prescriptam ecclesiam cum omnibus quae modo Deo et Sancte Marie et Sancto Oswino data sunt vel imposte∣rum donanda sunt, Deo & Sancto Cuthberto glorioso confessori, cui fratres predicti deservituri sunt dono & concedo & scripto presenti signo sancte crucis in nomine S. Trinitatis confirmo. Signed also by Walcher Bishop of Durham, Alred Earl, Utred the brother of Morkar, Liulfus the father of Morkar, Leofwinus Dean of Dur∣ham, &c. &c.", deserted also of
its monks, with all the lands and possessions thereof, together with the body of St. Oswin
Anglia Sacra, vol. i. p. 785-6. Leland's Collect. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 198. Dug∣dale's Monasticon, p. 41.
The body of St. Oswin was afterwards removed back again to Tinmouth.—Leland's Collect. vol. ii. tom. i. pars 2, p. 333..

Aldwin and his brethren, on their first settling there, covered the naked walls of the monastery of Jarrow with a roof composed of un∣hewn timber, and thatched with hay or straw; but the bishop af∣terwards gave them possessions, to enable them to rebuild their church
"Igitur episcopus cum cos ecclesiam ipsam reaedificare et destructa monachorum habitacula videret velle restaurare, dedit eis ipsam villam Girvum cum suis appendiciis, scilicet Preston Munecoctum Heuworth Heabern, Wyneston, Heorcedun, et ut opera perficere et sine indigentia ipsi possent vivere."—Dugdale, ut supra, p. 41.
See Simeon Dunelm' de Gestis Reg. Angl. apud decem Scriptores, col. 210, et 243.
Grose say, that this monastery "was certainly re-edified after the coming of the Danes, as is evident from the style of some part of the remains; but when, or by whom, does not occur in any of the writers who treat of it."
Does not the above account in the Monasticon, p. 42, both tell us when and by whom it was rebuilt?.

On the barbarous murder of Walcher, Bishop of Durham, at Gates∣head, on the 14th of May, 1079, the monks of Jarrow, in grateful
remembrance of his former munificence to their house, sailed up to that place, and, taking on board their vessel his naked body, hardly distinguishable for the number of wounds, returned with it to their monastery, from whence it was afterwards removed to Durham, and there interredStowe's Chronicle, edition 1632, p. 118..

In the year 1083, William de Karilepho, Bishop of Durham, having expelled the canons, or secular priests, from his church, ob∣tained permission to remove the monks from Jarrow and Weremouth, into the convent of Durham, to which he annexed them as cells for ever.

King William confirmed the above by his charter
Dugdale's Monasticon, p. 42.
Stowe's Chronicle, edit. 1632, p 119.
Leland's Collectanea, vol. ii tom. i. pars 2. p. 385.
Lambarde's Dictionary, in voce Jharrow..

King John, by a charter dated at Newport, February 2d, 1204, confirmed, among their other possessions, to the prior and monks of Durham, Jarrow, and the church thereof, in pure and perpetual almsEx Rotulo Cartarum de anno regni Regis Johannis quinto, m. 13, Chart. Monack. Dunelm — Murray MS. p. 222..
In the year 1291, Jarrow church appears to have been valued at 40l. per annum"Taxatio, &c. facta apud Novum Castrum, 13 Kal. Januar. A. D. 1291, Ec∣clesia de Jaru 40l."—MSS. in the Exchequer..

A. D. 1313, William, prior of Durham, resigned his priory, and had conferred upon him the cell of Jarrow, with the manor of Wardle, &c.
Roberti de Graystanes Hist. Dunelm. Anglia Sacra, vol. i. p. 756.
"A. D. 1313, circa festum S. Barnabae senectutis et impotentiae sentiens incom∣moda Willielmus prior cessit prioratui: cellam de Jarow cum manerio de Wardle, &c. recipiens."
In the year 1318, Jarrow church appears to have been valued at 26l. 13s. 4d. per annumFrom a MS. in the Exchequer..

March 5th, 1323, after a controversy for the archdeacon's juris∣diction in the churches appropriated to the prior and chapter of Dur∣ham, between the rivers Tyne and Tees, it was agreed upon be∣tween the said prior and chapter and Thomas de Goldesburgh, that the prior should have common archidiaconal jurisdiction in the churches of Jarrow and Weremouth, and the said archdeacon in all the rest, during his lifeAnglia Sacra, vol. i. p. 759..
About this time, Robert de Durham occurs, as master of JarrowWardrobe account of 15th, 16th, and 17th of Ed. II penes Th. Astle Armig. p. 275. "Robertus de Dunelm. magister domus de Jarrowe.".
A. D. 1333, Alexander de Lamely, master of Jarrow, was present at the election of Robert de Graystanes to the bishoprick of Dur∣hamAnglia Sacra, vol. i. p. 762..
Joh. de Norton occurs as master of the cell of Jarrow, A. D. 1353Hutchinson's Durham, vol. ii. p. 477..

Walter de Skyrlawe, who was elected to the see of Durham in 1389, built or repaired the bridge of Jarrow
Ibid. p. 774. "Pontem de Yarrow construxit pro quo de quibusdam terras emebat, quas postea pro reparatione ejusdem pontis dedit."
In Grose's View of Jarrow is represented the column of what it should seem has once been a cross, on the south end of Jarrow bridge, on the west side..

About the year 1424, the prior and monks of Durham com∣plained to their diocesan of their inability to sustain the grievous burthens imposed upon them in supporting their cells, but especially those of Weremouth and Jarrow
"Latera duecta Episcopo Dunelm. pro consilio suo pro relevamine cellarum de rrow & Weremouth. Reg. 3. Ecclesie Dunelm. p. 82.—(Randall's MSS.)
Reverendissime in Christo Pater & Domine singularissime premissa recommendatione votivà cum omni reverentia et obedientia tam debita quam devota. Scire dignetur vestra paternitas reverenda nos gravia onera in sustentatione cellarum nostrarum et maxime Weremouthe et Jarrow hactenus sustinuisse et graviora in posterum sustinere debere nisi citius apponatur remedium opportunum, ad que, una cum aliis oneribus & sumpribus quotidianis debite supportandis nostri monasterii his diebus non suppetunt facultates. Unde ad vestram dominationem confidentissimam semper in nostris arduis precipuam adjutricem Willielmum Ebchester confratrem nostrum super statu cellarum nostrarum plenius informatum transmittimus pro presenti, devotissimè deprecantes quate∣nus vestrum sanum consilium et auxilium in premissis generosissime dignemini impartiri sibi in dicendis ex parte nostra, si placent adhibere firmam fidem. Vestram dominationem reverendam conservet altissimus in prosperis juxta votum. Scriptum Dunelm' 2o die mensis Novembris." There is a marginal note informing us, that William Ebchester occurs in 1424.
Leland, who travelled round England between the years 1536 and 1542, tells us, that he gathered from an old chronicle of an unknown author, preserved at Whitby, that at the time that was written, there were but three monks at Jarrow, who still shewed the oratory of Bede, with a little altar, in the middle of which, instead of a gem, there was a little piece of serpentine, or green marble. Leland's Collect. vol. iv. tom. 3, p. 42..
John Durham occurs as master, Jan. 4th, 1437Hutchinson, ut supra..

At the dissolution
I copied the following from a curious MS. in the Cotton library. Cleopatra, E. iv. p. 144. Plut. v. c. (Dorso) "Comperta, i. e. crimina in variis monasteriis. Gerro cella. Sodom. Alexander Durham per voluntar' polluc' Fundator Episcopus Dunelmen' Reditus annuus xl. lib."
Ibid. under the title of religious houses under the value of 200l. per annum, in Henry VIIIth's time,—"Cella de Jerrowe—38l. 14s. 4d."
The following notices concerning this place are extracted from the minister's or bailiff's accounts of the property of the late monastery of Durham, dated February 4th, 32 Henry VIII. remaining in the Augmentation Office: "Parcell' decimarum grani rectoris de Jarrow (memorandum residuum rectorie de Jaro reservatur in manibus Domini Regis) valet in firma sive exit' garbarum decimarum diversarum villat' viz. pro Walle∣send 73s. 4d. Wyllyngton 73s. 4d. Wardeley 10s. Nether HeworthAt Nether-Heworth Capella destructa, Curates. Rob. Abell, 1395; Joh. Walker, 1633.—(Randall's MSS.) 30s. Follynge 10s. Monketon 50s. Harton 9l. 10s. Westhowe 6l. 18s. 6d. Sheldshugh 21s. 6d. In toto per ann. 29l. 16s. 8d." of religious houses, Jarrow was valued at 38l. 14s. 4d. per annum, according to Dugdale's account, but after that of Speed at 40l. 7s. 8dTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 111..

By the endowment of the cathedral church of Durham, by King Henry the Eighth, dated May 16th, 1541, the corn tythes of the
villages of Wallsend, Willington, Wardley, Nether-Heiworth, Felling, Monkton, Harton, Westow, Sheldheugh, parcels of the rectory of Jarrow, are granted to the dean and chapter of that churchAllan's printed collections..

A. D. 1545, on the authority of Tanner, in his Notitia Monastica, both Jarrow and Weremouth are said to have been granted to Lord Eure
Tanner, ut supra.—He makes a query in a note, whether Jarrow were not granted afterwards in 1553, to Simon Welbury and Christopher Moreland?
The subsequent entry occurs in Grey's MSS. "King's rent pro Jarrow 2l. 13s. 0d".

By an act of the chapter of Durham, July 20th, 1567, the tythes of Harton in the parish of Jarrow, worth 9l. 10s. per annum; as also those of Walls-End in the same parish, worth 3l. 13s. 4d. a year, with those of Wardley and Felling in the same parish, of the annual value of 1l. were assigned to the seventh prebendary of that church. Those of Nether-Heworth in the said parish, worth 1l. 10s. a year, to the tenth prebendary. At which time also the tythes of Westho, worth 6l. 18s. 6d. per annum; those of Willington, worth 3l. 13s. 4d. a year; those of Monkton, worth 2l. 10s. per annum; and those of Sheile∣hughe, worth 1l. 1s. 6d. a year; all in the above parish of Jarrow, were assigned to the twelfth prebendaryDr. Ellison's MSS.—In an account of the rents, &c. of the cathedral of Durham, mention occur ibid. under A. D. 1618, of a collicry at Jarrow—"Minera carbon' de Jarroe—lib.—1l. 13s. 4d.".
John Hutchinson occurs as curate here, 27th June, 1566.
In the year 1573, Jasper Hoppringle occurs as curate of Jarrow.
Thomas Maslet in 1578.
John Biers about 1612. John Walker 3d October, 1633.

A. D. 1657, Francis Battie occursSigus himself in an address from the ministers of Durham and Northumberland to the protector, "Fran. Battle, at Jarrow"—July or August.—Thurloe's State Papers, vol. vi. p. 431., an intruder, ejected for non∣conformity.
1697, George Howie.
1703, Richard Roberts.

1722, Mordecai CaryM. Carey was scholar of Trinity-College, Cambridge, master of Morpeth School. 1724; appointed 22d March, 1731, Bishop of Clonfert and Kilmach-Drugh in Ire∣land, in the room of Dr. And. Synge, promoted to the see of Cloyne, and afterwards translated, 20th Dec. 1735, to the bishoprick of Killala and Achonry, in the room of Rob. Clayton, translated to Corke and Ross. Ob. 1751..
1724, Robert Wilson, per Res. Carey.

1727, Henry Williamson
Randall's MSS. I copied the following from an old pew in Jarrow church, Nov. 16th, 1782: "Hec sedes Joannis Biers facta Marcii 26, anno 1612."
There is an engraving of Jarrow in Buck's Views—Grose's collection contains a view of the monastery of Jarrow, or Gyrwi, engraved by Sparrow—with the following ac∣count of the place: "The site is an eminence on the south side of the river Tyne, about five miles east of, or below, Newcastle. Its bounds do not seem to have been very ex∣tensive; neither was the place judiciously chosen with respect to healthfulness, there being a large marshy spot bordering it on the south: and when the tide is out, scarce any thing but stinking ouse remains in the bed of the creek that runs close under it, over which is the bridge seen in the view.
The remains consist of the chapel, now converted into a parish church, and several walls and fragments of the offices of the abbey. In some are circular arches, but the greatest number are pointed. Some cottages have been patched up here, partly with the standing walls of the old building, and partly with the materials pulled down. Several pieces of short columns with Saxon capitals lie scattered amongst the rubbish.
The church, which seems to have been lately repaired, has now only one isle, but the marks of other buildings are very apparent on its north wall The west door has a plain circular arch, and on its north jamb is an ancient cross ornamented in the Saxon style.The taken out on the alteration of the church in , and is now in my possession. Per∣ the arms of Jarrow monastery great variety of compose the arms of —Eliose of Gl Tanner's Notitia Monastica. No. 149. most nearly resemble in soon. —Here likewise are two very ancient carved oaken reading desks, having each seats for four persons. But what is esteemed the greatest curiosity, and as such is carefully kept under lock and key in the vestry, is the chair of venerable Bede, a great two armed chair said to have been deposited here ever since the dissolution of the monastery. It is of oak, and appears to have been hewn out with an axe, except that at the top of the back the cross piece is mortised to the standards, or upright parts, which serve both for legs and its support; these, with the seat and sides, are very ancient; but the back, according to the person who shews it, has been since added. Various are the superstitions and ridicu∣lous stories told of this place, among which are these: "That it was never dark in Jarrow church; and that the windows were of horn instead of glass." The latter perhaps re∣lates to some almost forgotten tradition, concerning the introduction of glass by Benedict." Grose's Antiquities. Jarrow or Gyrwi. Durham.
In the Antiquarian Repertory, vol. ii. p. 163, is given a plate of Bede's chair, which was shewn (by a mistake, pardonable in an inhabitant of the sea coast) under the denomi∣nation of Admiral Bede's great chair.
You are told as a common piece of water-wit in passing Jarrow church, "that it was as light at twelve o'clock at night as at mid-day." This riddle is solved when the wretch∣ed aenigmatist informs you, that at each time it would weigh the same, could you find a pair of scales large enough for that operation..
John Mills, A. B. 1751, obiit November 12th, 1775: he was suc∣ceeded by Mr. William Glover, the present perpetual curate, appointed by William Hargrave, Esq

A. D. 1782, Jarrow church was altered and repaired. Some curious inscriptions were discovered on this occasion
There was found a mutilated sculptured stone—subject—an archer shooting at a stag; I suspect this to be Roman workmanship.
Also a Roman stone inscribed in bold Roman capitals:
And another with the following:
These stones may have been brought to Jarrow at the first building of the monastery, from the adjoining Roman station near South Shields.—See Appendix.
An oblong grave stone, with a crosier and a key upon it, is supposed with great proba∣bility to have covered the grave of some abbot or cellarer of this monastery.
On a stone, built up at present with the letters inwards, at the bottom of the east jamb of that south window which is next to the west door of the lately erected body of Jarrow church, copied December 10th, 1782, when at my most earnest request the master builder was prevailed upon to open it out from within, I read: "In hoc singulari anno vita reditur mundo"
This inscription is undoubtedly christian, and appears to me to allude to the founding of this religious house, or rather has been made on its refoundation by the Normans.
The subsequent fragment of an inscription is on a stone found here December 10th, 1782.
—BERCHTI
EDVERI
C CRVCE
The first letters are evidently part of the name of one of the abbots—the whole is spelled in Smith's Bede, p. 293, "Huaetberct."
I saw two stones near a chimney-piece amongst the ruins of Jarrow, the chequer work designs on which very much resemble a specimen of Saxon ornaments given in Grose's work, preface, p. 76—There is another very observable stone built up in a wall near Mr. Railstone's house (not far from Jarrow), which was brought from the ruins of this mona∣stery..

The present lay impropriators of Jarrow parish, who have in some parts thereof the great and small tythes, in others the small tythes only, are Mrs. Elizabeth Mountagu, Sir Thomas Clavering, Bart. General Ellison, Thomas Lewen of Kibblesworth, and William Hargrave of Shawdon, Esqrs.From the information of Mr. Railstone. Yet the following occurs in Hutchinson's Durham, vol. ii. p. 474. "One half belongs to William Hargrave of Shawdon, Esq one quarter to General Cuthbert Ellison (the representative of); one eighth to Sir Tho. Clavering, Bart. and one eighth to Mrs. Elizabeth Montague; and the impropriated lands are possessed in the same proportion."
They present by turns—Mr. Mills was nominated by Sir Thomas ClaveringJarrow is a peculiar belonging to the Dean and Chapter of Durham, in the deanery of Chester, and is not in charge..

FIGURE.HEAD: To the most Noble & Puisiant Prince Hugh Duke & Earl of Northumberland Earl & Baron Percy, Baron Lucy Poynings Fitzpayne Bryan Latimer, and ak worth and Baronet Lord Lieutenant and Custos Rotulorum of the Country of Northumberland and of the Town & County of the Town of Newcastle upon Tyne, Vice. Admiral of the County of Northumberland Lieutenant General of his Majesty's — Forces, Colonel of the second Treep of Horse Grenadier Guards, &c. &c. &c. — This View of the Remains of the CASTLE and MONASTRY of TINMOUTH in the County of Northumberland taken from the North. Is most gratefully inscribed by his Graces very obliged & most devoted faithful humble Servant John Brand.

DIV2.HEAD: MONASTERY AND CASTLE OF TINMOUTH.
DIV2.P:
NOTWITHSTANDING what has been advanced to the contrary by the learned Horsley, some recent discoveries seem clearly to prove to us, that the Romans had a station in this place during their resi∣dence in Britain
See Miscellaneous Antiquities (plate of) No. 11, 12, 13, 14.—No. 11 is an exact representation of the front of a Roman altar found in Tinmouth Castle in Northumber∣land, by Major Durnford, at the depth of six feet in the earth, where it had been laid as a foundation stone, probably of the ancient Christian church, which is said to have been erected there soon after the introduction of that faith into Britain. The lower part of it, by whatever accident, is much defaced, and it is at present quite flat at the top, though we may suppose it to have had originally a focus there, which the workmen, in order to make it square and bed properly, may have been obliged to take off. The inscription is plainly to be read: "Jovi optimo maximo Aelius Rufus Praefectus Cohortis quartae Lin∣gonum." The Lingones were a people of Champagne in France, and are well known to have been among the Roman auxiliary troops of infantry, but this is our first informa∣tion where the fourth cohort of them was stationed in Britain.
No. 12, represents a stone nearly square, one foot nine inches by one foot ten, which was found also in the same place, June 12, 1783, where it had been laid in the foundation of some of the ancient buildings.
The first letter of what I call the first line of the inscription, is confessedly faint and doubtful: the second letter appears plainly to be a Y, as does the third to be an R, though at first sight it resembles a P. There can be no doubt concerning any of the others. Whether or not the stone, which I take to have been a tablet on a temple erected there to some god of the winds, has undergone any alterations, when it was wrought up in the Christian structure, I am not able to ascertain. As there are none but the most usual contractions in the other lines, I was induced to think there was none in the first, and therefore read the whole:
Gyrum, Cumbas, et Templum secit Caius Julius Verus
Maximinus Legionis sextae victricis ex voto. I suppose Gyrum to mean here "a circular harbour for the shipping," and, in favour of this hypothesis, have to observe that there is still a recess of that form, called Prior's Haven, adjoining on the south to Tinmouth Castle, which has every appearance of hav∣ing been one of the artificial harbours of that great people, and is, I presume, the place alluded to in the inscription.
Scheffer, in his Book de Militia Navali Veterum, p. 212, cites Columella, lib. ix. as describing the ancient mode of making harbours in the following words: "praejaciuntur in Gyrum moles."
This word seems to have been corrupted afterwards into "Gyrrus," in the base Latinity: see Dufresne in verbo, where he gives us a quotation from an authority of the date of A. D. 1064, in which the following passage occurs: "Eant et redeant piscatores Gyr∣rum." If this does not mean that "The fishermen shall have ingress and regress to and from the harbour," I fear it will be difficult to point out its signification.
Scheffer abovecited, p. 71, speaking of the word "Cumba" being frequently used for "Cymba" tells us: "Cumbam nominat quam supra Cymbam diximus, usitata Latinis scribendi consuetudine, qua U Graecorum in U suum vertunt."
"Fecit" is with the strictest propriety used here to signify "making" a harbour, "building" ships or barges, and "erecting" a temple.
If this Maximinus be the person who was afterwards made emperor, this inscription may be dated some little time before A. D. 235.
No. 13 and 14 give side views of the altar: on one of which the presericulum, securis, secespita and bullock's head, all of rude design and execution, are common ornaments; but the snakes, one on each side of the patera, on the other, appear singular..

A religious house, doubtless of rude and simple architecture, is said to have been erected here in the very earliest ages of Christianity, and soon after the introduction of the monastic institution into our island.

Edwin, King of the Northumbrians, some time between the years of Christ 617 and 633, erected here of wood a place of residence for nuns only, as some writers inform us, but more probably for religious persons of both sexes, and in which his own daughter Rosella after∣wards took the veil"Edwinus, Rex Northumbrorum, sacellum erexit Tinemutae ex ligno in quo Ro∣sella ejus filia postea velum sacrum accepit."—Leland's Collectanea, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 42, on the authority of a chronicle written by a monk of St. Albans, whose name was not certainly known: "Tinemuthe Chronicon autore monacho Albanensi sed incerto nomine.".

Oswald, a succeeding king of the same people, and who began his reign A. D. 634, soon afterwards caused this house of wood to be taken down, and raised upon the site thereof a new structure of stone:"S. Oswaldus monasterium de Tinemuthe ex ligneo lapideum fecit. Ibid. a circumstance which no doubt gave rise to the opinion of those writers who assert that this Oswald was the original founder of Tinmouth monastery"Tinmouth, olim Dunemuth or Donemade, founded by St. Oswald, the first Chris∣tian king of Northumberland, according to some; though others ascribe its foundation to Ecgfrid."—Tanner's Notitia Monastica..

Mention occurs of an oratory dedicated to St. Mary at this place, soon after it had been rebuilt of stone, where a great number of per∣sons of distinction assembled under a regular order for the performance of divine service: the monastery had by this time acquired such a repu∣tation of local sanctity, that persons dying in the neighbourhood were brought to be interred in it according to a superstitious custom that prevailed in that age
"In quo loco virorum illustrium mag. multitudo congregata erat, qui sub ordine regulari divino cultui serviebant. Qui quidem in tantam excreverat honoris eminentiam, ut si quis per infrajacentem provinc' in fata concessisset, ad eundem locum pro reverentia et honore religiosae gentis tumulandus deferretur."—From Leland's Collectanea, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 113. "Ex libro cujusdam monachi S. Albani de Vita S. Oswini: autor operis suit aliquanto tempore, ut ipsemet testatur, prior de Wimundesham."
At Tinmouth, says Leland, were buried Edred, King of the Deiri; and also Henry, Hermit of Coket Island..

Hither was conveyed for that purpose the murdered body of Oswin,
This King Oswin was born at a town that had been a Roman station, opposite to Tinmouth, on the south side of the river Tyne, called Urfa: it was afterwards laid waste by the Danish pirates.
Tinmouth was called by the Britons, Pen Ball Cragg, i. e. the Head of the Rampire upon the Rock: from whence it has been asserted, that if the Roman wall did not reach as far as this place, the foss certainly did.
Mr. Camden says, that he will not gainsay this opinion, but he dares confidently affirm that this place in the time of the Romans was called Tunacellum, which signifies as much as the promontory of Tuna, or Tina, where the first cohort called Aelia Classica, be∣cause it was first raised by the Emperor Hadrian, whose family name was Aelius, was in pay for sea service; for the Romans had their naves lusoriae, or light frigates, in their border rivers, both for the suppressing of the excursions of the neighbouring enemy, and the making of incursions upon them, as may be seen in the Codex Theodosii, under the title "De Lusoriis Danubii," i. e. light vessels on the Danube.
Under the Saxon Heptarchy this place was called Tunacester, not, as Bede affirms, from the Abbot Tunna, a mere romantic story, which if we recommend to the reader, it must be only for his diversion, and not for any truth in it, but from its situation on the mouth of the river Tine. Baxter, in his Glossary, gives it that etymon. "Vernaculum nomen Tinmouth, quod os est tenti fluminis sive Tinnae."
Leland, in his Collectanea, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 32, has the following account of both places:—"E regione Tinemuthae fuit urbs vastata a Danis Urfa nomine ubi natus erat Oswinus Rex."—"Locus ubi nunc coenobium Tinemuthense est antiquitus a Saxonibus dicebatur Penbalcrag—i. e. caput valli in rupe, nam circa hunc locum finis erat valli Severiani."
King
"Oswinus a latere perfossus lanceâ obiit anno regni ejus nono 13 kal' Septembris in loco qui dicitur Gethlingum A. D. 651.
Regina Eanfleda, propinqua Oswini, postulavit a Rege Oswi, ut donaret ibi locum monaster' construendo. Quo concesso constructum est in Gethlingo monasterium cui praesuit Trumhere jure abbatis.—Corpus Oswini ab eis qui truncaverunt delatum est ad ostium Tinae fl' ibique in oratorio S. Mariae sepulturae traditum. Leland's Collectan. vol. iv. tom iii. p. 113. Ex libro monachi S. Albani de Vita Oswini. of Deira, one of the provinces of the then divided kingdom of Northumberland, who, through the treachery of the ungrateful Hun∣weld, fell a sacrifice to the ambition of Oswy, King of Bernicia, the other province, on the 13th of the kalends of September, A. D. 651, at a place called Chillingham
I find this place occur under the following names: "Gethling."—"Chivelyngham." 5 Ric. II. "Gillingham." Leland's Collectan. vol. ii. pars 2. tom. i. p. 515.
"Jugethlingum"—Flores Hist. p. 228-9, by Matthew of Westminster., where Queen Eanfleda, a relation of the deceased King, is said to have erected a monastery for his soul. Harding, the writer of an old English chronicle in metre, has errone∣ously supposed her to have founded that of Tinmouth on this mourn∣ful occasionHardyng's Chronicle (London 1543.) fol. 90, 91. There is preserved among the Harleian MSS. 1499. 25, a copy of an heraldric visitation of Northumberland in 1530, wherein it is said that "Sainct Oswyn Kyng of Daire—founded furst the monasteri of Tynmouth of black monks.".

The division of the kingdom of Northumberland is reported, and with great probability, to have been the cause of the quarrel between the kings Oswy and Oswin"Divisio reg' Northumbr' caussa odii inter Oswi et Oswinum."—Leland's Collec∣tan. vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 113. Ex libro cujusdam monachi S. Albani de Vita S. Oswini: autor operis suit aliquanto tempore, ut ipsemet testatur, prior de Wimundesham..

Egfrid, made king of Northumberland, A. D. 671, and who was slain May 20th, 685, was the founder of this monastery, if we will give credit to an old account, that Leland has preserved, of the ravages
committed by the Pagans in Northumberland, during the reign of that king, and which cannot be reconciled with the former history of this place, unless we suppose it to have been destroyed, with other religious houses, in the time of that king, by the barbarous Danes, and to have been restored by his pious munificence: a conjecture which seems by no means to want probability
Leland's Collectanea, vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 297. "Gens vero pagana praedaverunt North∣umbre et monasterium Ecgfridi spoliaverunt apud Dunemuth."
See Tanner's account of this monastery, where, after ascribing the foundation of it to St. Oswald, he adds, "though others ascribe its foundation to Ecgfrid."
