In Hegge's Legend of St. Cuthbert, mention occurs between A. D. 646 and 687, of one "Verca or Veria, abbatess of Tinmouth." Though this is thought by some to re∣fer to the monastery of Tynningham on the Tyne, in East Lothian, in Scotland, and not to this place—sed quaere; for Ridpath, in his Border History, p. 28, notes, tells us, speaking of St. Cuthbert, "that in the course of an episcopal visitation, not long before his death, having gone through the higher places of his diocese, he came to a monastery of virgins, situated not far from the mouth of the Tyne, of which a woman of noble ex∣traction, called Veria, who made him a present of sine linen, which he kept for his wind∣ing-sheet, was abbess; and there, miraculously by his blessing, changed water into wine. Cudb. Vita, c. 35. He had while a boy performed a great miracle at the same monastery, which was then inhabited by monks, some of whom being carried out to sea on certain floats, on which they were bringing wood to the monastery, he saved, by his prayers, from the imminent hazard of being drowned."— C. 3.
"Smith," he adds, "understands the Tyne spoken of in these two miracles to mean the Tyne of East Lothian, on which was situated the famous monastery of Tynningham; but both stories being vouched at first or second hand, by brethren in Bede's monastery, makes it probable that he means the Tyne in Northumberland.".

St. Herebald, the companion of St. John of Beverley, archbishop of York, who died A. D. 721, appears to have been a monk, and af∣terwards abbot of Tinmouth
Leland's Collectanea, vol. iii. p. 104. "Herebaldus, qui est postea monachus Tyne∣mutensis servus Johannis Episcopi.
"Herebaldus clericus Johannis postea abbas Tinemutensis.
"Idem Johannes archiepiscopus Ebor. obiit A. D. 721."—Ex Vita D. Johannis archiepisc. Ebor. Autore Folchardo Durovernensi..

Osred, the banished king of the Northumbrians, who was appre∣hended and slain on the 18th of the kalends of October, A. D. 792,
on his return from exile, was afterwards interred in this mona∣sterySaxon Chronicle, p. 65—thus latinized; "Osredus qui fuerat Northymbrorum Rex post exilium domum reversus, prehensus est et interfectus 18 kal. Octobris ejusque corpus jacet ad Tinanmutha." Also Leland's Collectanea, tom. ii. vol. iii. p. 172. Also Sy∣meon Dunelm. Hist. de Gestis Regum Anglorum..
In the year of Christ 800, the monastery of Tinmouth was plun∣dered by the Danes"Anno 800 ecclesiae de Hertenes et de Tinemuth spoliatae sunt a Danis." Leland's Collectan. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 388..

A. D. 832, an army of pirates from the same barbarous nation made an attempt to land at this place, but were routed and driven back to their ships
"Anno gratiae 832, exercitus Danorum infidelium piratarum, postquam apud Dunemutham victi et fugati fuerunt, Seapeium id est Ovium insulam depredati sunt." Flores Historiarum, p. 300.
Hutchins, in his History of Dorsetshire, vol. i. p. 314, supposes the above to relate to Tinmouth in the county of Devon..

In the year 866, during the ravages of Hungar and Hubba, the monastery of Tinmouth is said to have been utterly destroyedDugdale's Monasticon, p. 334. "Hinguar et Hubba hoc monasterium destruxe∣runt: monachi metu persecutionis fugerunt ad quandam ecclesiolam in fundo suo quam Sanctus Cuthbertus dedicaverat. Quo comperto Dani ipsam ecclesiam et omnes qui in eo erant igni succenderunt et omne loci nobilis aedificium in campi planitiem redegerunt.".

A. D. 870, a monastery of nuns occurs at this place as having been plundered by the same infidels, who, three years before, had subjugated the whole province of NorthumberlandFlores Historiarum, p. 314. "Coenobium etiam Tynemuense Sanctimonial', &c.".
In the year 876, Tinmouth was again ravaged by Halfden, the Danish kingLamba de's Topographical Dictionary, p. 360, in verbo..

During the reign of Athelstan, king of the West Saxons, which began A. D. 924, and ended in 940, this monastery, then hardly recovered from its former desolation, was again ravaged by the DanesLeland's Collectan. vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 42, on the authority of the "Chronicon authore monacho Albanensi, sed incerto nomine:— monasterium—iterum destructum per Danos tempore Ethelstani Regis.".

It is no wonder that, after having been so often plundered and de∣stroyed, this place should have lain so long in ruins, that the re∣membrance of King Oswin, the sainted patron thereof, was utterly lost.

After some respite from the invasions of the Danish pirates, to whom its exposed situation on the sea coast rendered it an easy and defenceless prey; and who, by their repeated depredations, appear to have left nothing that could induce them to return, the then bishop of the diocese obtained it of the Earls of Northumberland; and, after filling it anew with religious, restored therein the celebration of di∣vine service.
It was not, however, till the latter end of the reign of Edward the Confessor that the bones of the royal martyr St. Oswin were dis∣coveredLambarde's Topographical Dictionary, ut supra..

About the conclusion of this reign, which ended in 1066, the royal saint and martyr Oswin, in one of those dreams common to the times, is said to have appeared to Edmund, the sexton of this place, and pointed out to him the place of his own interment. Judith, wife of Tosti, Earl of Northumberland, gave credit to the sexton's vision, and ceased not to exert her influence with Egelwine, then bishop of Durham, till he had ordered a search to be made for the royal bones, which are said to have been discovered in an oratory, according to the saint's directions in the vision, on the 5th of the ides of March, A. D. 1065, and 415 years after his death. The royal remains, after having been inclosed in a coffin, and honoured with every kind of funeral pomp, were recommitted to the sacred earthMatthew of Westminster, Flores Historiar. p. 428. Leland's Collectan, vol. iv. tom. iii. p. 113. Ibid. vol. iii. tom. ii. p. 195..

Tosti, Earl of Northumberland, according to some writers, rebuilt this monastery from the foundation
Leland's Comment. vol. ... p. 103.
"Tinmouth Monasterium Northumbr. Robertus Moubray, co. Northumbriae, primus fundator temp. Conquest. Tostius co. Eboraci frater Haraldi, primus fundator per alios.".

About the year 1074, Waltheof, Earl of Northumberland, gave the church of Tinmouth, with all the lands and possessions thereof, to∣gether with the body of St. Oswin, to the monks of the neighbouring monastery of Jarrow, to which place they removed the sacred remains of the royal saintLeland's Collectan. vol. i. pars ii. p. 383..

Albrey, appointed Earl of Northumberland, on the murder of Walcher, Bishop of Durham, A. D. 1079, confirmed the above grant of Tinmouth, made by his predecessor Waltheof, to the monks of Jarrow, who, by this time, as related in the account of that mo∣nastery, had been removed to the church of DurhamIbid. p. 385..

A. D. 1090, Robert de Mowbray, Earl of Northumberland, having endowed the monastery of Tinmouth, and filled it with black monks, whom he had brought from St. Albans, in Hertfordshire, on account of some displeasure which he had conceived against the then Bishop of Durham, took it from that church, and made it a cell to the said monastery of St. Albans for ever
"A. D. 1090, circa hos denique dies Robertus de Molbraio Northumbrensis comes, divina inspiratione tactus, volens ecclesiam beati Oswini de Tinemutha jam∣dudum desolatum restaurare, atque ibi Deo & Sancto Martyri Oswino monachos ser∣vituros constituere, consilio amicorum suorum, Paulum, ecclesiae Sancti Albani ab∣batem convenit, petens obnixiùs et devote ut ex monachis suis aliquos illuc transmit∣tere dignaretur; promittens omnia quae ad victum et vestitum necessaria sunt, se eis affatim suppediturum. Petitioni quidem abbas predictus non defuit; nam quosdam illuc ex Sancti Albani monachis mitti procuravit; quos cum comes praefatus ma∣neriis, ecclesiis, redditibus, piscariis, molendinis et rebus omnibus locupletasset et literis praedicta omnia ab omni saeculari servitio exempta et penitus libera confirmas∣set, dedit praedicto abbati Paulo ejusque successoribus et ecclesiae beati Albani An∣glorum protomartyris, ecclesiam Tinemuthanam cum omnibus appendicibus suis, pro salute propria in perpetuum possidendam. Ita quidem ut abbates Sancti Albani (qui pro tempore fuerint) cum consilio ejusdem loci conventus, liberam habeant dispo∣sitionem priorum et monachorum tam in illis constituendis quam removendis prout viderint expedire."—Matt. Paris. p. 16.
See also Symeon Dunelm. Hist. de Gest. Regum Anglie, col. 243.
Matt. Paris Additamenta, p. 199.
Dugdale's Monasticon Angl. p. 45.
Stevens' Continuation of Dugdale, vol. i. p. 242..
In the year 1092, Remigius was prior of TinmouthBrowne Willis..

The bodies of Malcolm, King of Scotland, and his son, Prince Ed∣ward, both slain on St. Brice's day, A. D. 1094, were interred in this monastery
Leland's Collectan. tom. ii. vol. iii. p. 200.
Lambarde Dict. Topograph. in verbo.
Also Matth. Paris Hist. p. 950..

About the year 1097, the priory of Tinmouth appears to have been in possession of the villages of Seaton, Whitley, Seghill, Stanton, Bewick, and Lilburn; also of the manor of Eglingham, Chirton, Earsdon, and Coquet-Island, with their several churches, tythes, and whatever else belonged to them
Matthew Paris. Mention occurs ibid. of a decree of Richard, who was made ab∣bot of St. Albans, in the year 1097, and died A. D. 1119, with the unanimous consent of the convent of that place, that the church of Tinmouth should annually pay to the monastery of St. Albans, thirty shillings, on the festival of that church, on condition that no other demand should be made. The abbot of St. Albans was to keep in his own hands Anebell, and Coquet-Island, with the churches of Bywell and Woodhorne; and when he chose to come down to Tinmouth with twenty attendants, they were to be supported by that house fifteen days; but if the abbot's journey was on business par∣ticularly concerning Tinmouth, then he and his retinue should be supported solely at the expence of that monastery.
Some time in the reign of William the Conqueror, Gospatrie, a nobleman of New∣castle, who had come over into England at the conquest, gave the church of Connys∣clife, whereof he was patron, to the monastery of Tinmouth. MS. Cotton Library. Vitellius, B. 20. 8..

A. D. 1095, Earl Mowbray, having entered into a conspiracy to dethrone William Rufus, is said to have converted this place into a castle, to defend his treason on that occasion
Leland's Collectan. tom. i. pars ii. p. 332, has the following passage: "Robertus Mowbray Comes Northumbrie offensum Gul. magn. timens, Tinemuthe loco cas∣telli occupat, postea tamen ibidem captus."
"I finde no mention of this castle before the tyme of the conquest" (says Lam∣barde, in his Topographical Dictionary in verbo), "and therefore I suspect that this Robert Mowbray was the first author thereof, the rather for that Matthew of West∣minster callethe it the New Castle.". The King marched
with an army against him, and, after a siege of two monthsRoger de Hoveden Annal. p. 267. See also the Saxon Chronicle, where, under A. D. 1095, occurs a passage in Latin as follows: "Castellum etiam apud Tine∣mutham obsedit donec illud cepistet et comitis fratrem in illo, omnesque qui cum eo una fuerunt."—p. 202., took Tinmouth-Castle by storm: he found the earl's brother therein, and made him his prisoner; but Mowbray himself had escaped by stealth, and taken refuge in Bamborough-Castle. The King besieged that also, but finding it impregnable, erected a castle over against it, in which he placed a garrison to continue the blockade, and returned himself towards the south. The besieged earl having been invited out by some of his partizans, who were the guards of Newcastle upon Tyne, escaped and made towards that place, but being pursued, he retired a second time, and took sanctuary in the church of this monastery, from whence, however, he was soon dragged out by violence, and made a prisonerSee under Annals and Historical Events..

After this, King William Rufus confirmed the grant of this church, with all its property and possessions north and south of Tyne, with which Robert Mowbray, late Earl of Northumberland had endowed it, before his attainder, to the monastery of St. Albans. His charter on this occasion is dated at NewcastleDugdale's Monasticon, vol. i. fol. 334. He ascribes it by mistake to William the Conqueror, for it contains internal evidence to prove it a grant of William the Second, and made after the attainder of Robert Mowbray, in 1095: the following passage evinces this assertion; "Quae Robertus Comes de Northumberland et sui homines dederant Sancto Oswino antequam mihi forisfactus eslet.".

On the 13th of the kalends of September, 1110, the body of St.
Oswin was removed from Jarrow to the monastery of Tinmouth, which had been newly rebuilt
Leland's Collectanea, vol. iii. p. 114, 115.
"Corpus Oswini translatum in novum monasterium de Tinemuth A. D. 1110, 13 al. Sept".

King Henry I. by a charter dated at Branton, confirmed to the priory of Tinmouth all the tythes in Northumberland, which Earl Mowbray had given them, i. e. those of Corbridge, Ovington, Wylam, Newburn, Dissington, Callerton, Elswick, Bothall, Warkworth, Ane∣bell, Rothbury, and WoolerDugdale's Monasticon, vol. i. p. 335. By another charter, ibid. dated at West∣minster, he granted to this house of Tinmouth, the court and customs which Earl Mowbray held in the time of his brother, and before he had forfeited them by treason..

A. D. 1121, the monks of Durham made an attempt to recover the monastery of Tinmouth from the church of St. Albans; on which occasion they urged the repentance of Earl Mowbray for having taken it out of their hands, as an argument to prove the injustice of not restoring it; but powerful as such reasoning might appear at that period, it proved ineffectualSimeon Dunelm. Hist. de Gest. Reg. Angl. col. 243, 244..
In the year 1124, William de Bedford was prior of TinmouthBrowne Willes..

David, King of Scots, by a charter dated in the month of June, 1138, at Norham, with the consent of his son, for the souls of his father and mother, for the soul of Alexander his brother, the soul of Matilda, Queen of England, his sister, and for those of his an∣cestors and successors, granted peace and protection to the monastery of Tinmouth, and to all persons who were in the peace of St. Mary, and the saint of this place, on Barnabas-day that yearDugdale's Monasticon, vol. i. p. 335, from a register of St. Albans, in the Cotton library, fol. 18. Richard Prior, of Hexham, informs us (apod decem Scriptores, p. 316) that on the 4th of the id of January, 1138, William, son of Duncan, nephew of King David, invaded England—after him, that King David himself, with his son Henry, ravaged Northumberland, and committed the most horrid barbarities Tinmouth bought ostts destruction on this occasion with the sum of 27 mark of silver which the prior and convent thereof paid to the King of Scotland..

Robert, abbot of St. Albans, elected A. D. 1151, and who died in 1166, visited his cell of Tinmouth, which he presented with a cloak or pall, of the value of ten marksStevens' Continuation of Dugdale, vol. i. p. 247. He stayed fifteen days at Tin∣mouth..

A. D. 1152, John, the Pope's legate, on his way to Ireland, land∣ed at Tinmouth
Johan' prior Hagulstaden' apud decem Scriptores, p. 279.
"Anno 1152. His diebus appulit apud Tynamutha in Northymbria Johannes presbyter ordinalis directus apostolicae sdis legatus cum palliis Hyberniensibus directis. Excepit cum Willielmus Episcopus Dunelmi cum reverentia, scripsit autem David Regi Scotiae significatis de f et de causa adventus sui, expetens conductum ejus in Hyberniam.".

King Henry the Second, by a charter dated after A. D. 1175, re∣stored and confirmed to the monastery of Tinmouth, the lands which he had seized on account of the flight of Adgar into Scotland, and the war of the Scottish King, viz. Eglingham, Bewicke, and Lil∣burne, which the above Adgar had farmed of this house, and which, by an inquisition taken by the King's command, appeared to be their escheat and demesne. He confirmed also at the same time what the abbot and convent of St. Albans had provided and appointed con∣cerning their churches of Eglingham and Apelton, appropriated to hospitable purposes for ever, as appeared by their charter on that be∣halfDugdale's Monasticon, p. 335. Selden, in his History of Tythes, in quarto, p. 25, is us, that Henry II. confirmed to the monks of Tinmouth all their churches ap∣propriated, and decimas de Corebriga et Newburna et de Wertewurtha, et de Calvr∣dina et de Alswicha et de Anibella et decimas de dominio de Herth et de Stna et de Tunestal et de Daltona et de Mideltona et de Ovingthuna. All which were without churches formerly, and in perpetual right consecrated by the owner's devotion. The like often occurs in confirmations made to them by the successing kings.".

November 4th, 1189, King Richard I. made a grant of privileges to the church of Tinmouth, by a charter dated at Canterbury
"Ricardus Rex, &c. notum facimus vobis nos concessisse Deo & Sancto Albano ecclesiae suae Sancti Oswini de Tynemuth, cellae Sancti Albani et monachis ibidem Deo servntimus omnes terras suas et omnes homines suos cum scha, seba, over strond et streme, on wode et felde, toll, them, & grithburge hamsocne murdrum et forestall, dangeld, infangenethef et utfangenethef flemnene fremeth, blodwit, wreck, &c." Dated at Canterbury, 4 November, 1 Ric. I.
Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 350. See an exposition of the above bar∣barous terms in blount's Law Dictionary, voce Strond. This charter of King Richard his uncle is mentioned in King Henry the Third's letter to the Bishop of Durham, A. D. 1248.—Matthew Paris, p. 744..

By a grant remaining in the Augmentation-Office, about the date of 1190, it appears that Henry de Bulemer gave, in frankalmoigne, and confirmed to St. Oswin of Tynmouth, and the monks serving God in that place, for the health of his soul and the souls of his ancestors, twenty-eight acres and an half of land, in his demesne in the fields Jesemuth, near Newcastle upon Tyne"Universis sancte matris ecclesie filiis ad quos presentes litere pervenerint Henricus de Bulemer salutem. Sciatis me caritatis inturtu concessisse et dedisse et hac mea presenti carta confirmasse Deo et beato Oswino de Tynemu et monachis ibidem Deo servienti∣bus pro salute anime mee & pro salute animarum antecessorum meorum viginti et octo acras et dimidiam terre de meo dominico in campis de Jesemu unde octo acre sunt in illa cultura que vocatur Weneslat et quatuor acre in illa cultura que vocatur Magna Milneside sicut ipsa est longa et lata usque in Thesam et due acre & dimidia in illa cultura que vocatur Parva Milneside sicut ipsa est longa et lata usque in Thesam et due acre et dimidia in illa cultura que vocatur Huwchalen et tres acre in illa cultura que vocatur Sandirig et sex acre in illa cultura que est proxima illi domui que fuit Radulfi Baard versus Austrum et due acre & dimidra in una alia cultura in australi parte rivuli de Litteldene in occidentali parte chimini sicut itur ad Bentun et jacent ter culturas Radulfi Baard Et preterea totum herbagium quod habui in occidentali parte de Litteldene sicut via le extendit a chimmo Novi Castelli usque ad chiminum de Bentun et ita deorsum sicut rivulus currit ab occidentali parte ejusdem rivuli et ita deorsum per rivulum donce perveniat ad capudSic illius culture versus orientem que vo∣catur Welleflat habend' & tenend' in putam & liberam & perpetuam clemosinam &c His testibus Gilberto de la Wal, Patricio filio Edgari Waltero Gratherd Milone filio Huberti Radulfo de Witclithe Waltero serviente Petro de Mulsham Nigello de Dichington Jordano de Bacworth Ada de Herford Radulfo capellano Simone filio Milonis Daniele filio Nicola Johann cum Barba Johanne filio Ivere de Novo Castello et multis aliis." (Seal lost off.).

The same Henry de Bulemer gave also in frankalmoigne to the
prior and convent of Tinmouth, the moiety of a fishery, called Ac∣cusyare, in the water of TyneCopy on parchment remaining in the Augmentation-Office. "Omnibus videntibus vel authentibus has literas tam futuris quam presentibus Radulfus dictus prior de Tynemouth & ejusdem loci conventus salutem. Noverit universitas vestra nos conces∣sisse et dedisse et hac mea presenti carta confirmasse Willielmo Sellario de Novo Castello & lredibus suis medietatem illius piscarie cum pertinen' in Tyna que voca∣tur Accusyare quam Henricus de Bulmer nobis in pura elemosina dedit & carta sua confirmavit habendam & tenendam in feodo et hereditate fibi et her' suis de nobis & successoribus nostris libere solute honorince et quiete reddendo annuatim unam libram cere ad festum Sancti Oswini in Augusto pro omnibus serviciis & consuetudinibus & pro omnibus exaceronibus et querelis Hiis testibus Radulfo de Gawgi Jordano Hayrn Ger∣vasio de Boutrer Willielmo de Bre. Waltero Grafhard Gilberto de la Vale Radulfo de Witclithe Gilberto de Hoghill Daniele filio Nicolai Regin' fil' Lenwini Malgero Suano apte Grunter Thoma de Carleolo Arnaldo de Horneby Roberto Aurifabro Johanne cum Barba Nicolao Scot Ricardo Nigro Hug. Clerico Thoraldo Widone et altis .".
In the year 1196, Hugh Pudsey, Bishop of Durham, confirmed to the monks of Tinmouth all their tythes in Northumberland, and the bishoprick of Durhamden's History of Tthes, quarto, p. 325..

The learned Madox, in his History of the Exchequer, p. 275, in∣forms us that many towns and persons, at various times, in the reigns of King Richard and King John, were fined in various sums, for grants and confirmations of divers sorts of liberties, franchises, and exemptions, according to the tenor of the respective records; and instances the abbot and monks of St. Albans, who, in the year 1204, were fined 25 marks and a palfrey, for the monks of Tinmouth, for the confirmation of a charter granted to the latter, by King John; and that the monks of Tinmouth paid 50 marks on the same account.

The above charter of King John, dated 1204, confirmed to the church of Tinmouth all their lands and possessions, i. e. the villages of Tinmouth, Seaton, Preston, both the Chirtons, Millington, Whit∣ley, Erdesdon, the two Backworths, Seghill, Morton, Bebside, the two Dissingtons, Ulsington, Bewick, Eglingham, Lillburne, Anibell, Hawkeslaw, Elswick, Wylam, Weltedon, and half of Copun, Carle∣berry,
and Morton in bishoprick, Helleshaw, and the land of Royley and Denum, with the churches of Tinmouth, Woodhorn, Whalton, Bolum, Bewick, and Eglingham, and of Hertburn and Connyscliff; also Hereford on Blyth, and the tythes of Hertnes, with those of Mid∣dleton on Tees, of Corbridge, Rothbury, Warkworth, Wooler, and Newburn, with the liberties granted them by a former charter of King Richard, his uncleSee Dugdale's Monasticon..

In the year 1205, King John granted to the monks of Tinmouth an exemption from the payment of cornage"Claus. 6 Joan. m. 5. Quod monachi (de Tynemuth) sint quieti de cornagio. Tanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391.. It appears from the records of this house, that several villages in Northumberland paid cornage both to the abbot of St. Albans, and to the prior of this house
Tinmouth Chartulary, at Northumberland-House, fol. 67.
"Cornag' domini abbatis de termino apostolorum Petri et Pauli & Abbotstuth.
De Erdesden 6s.
De Seton 41d.
De Whitelei 40d.
De Preston 40d.
De Est-Chirton 40d.
De Middel Chirton 40d.
De Milneton 4d.
De Sighal 40d.
De Bacworth 4s. 6d. quadr.
De Copun 16d.
De elemosinar' pro Herford 5d. ob.
De Anbell et Hawkeslawe 40d.
De Elstewyk 14d.
De Wylom 20d.
De Dissinton 5s.
Cornag' prioris in festo Sancti Michaelis.
De Sighal 13d. ob.
De Bacworth 8d. ob. quadr.
De Dissinton 13d. ob.
De Wissington 13d. ob.
De Whitelei 13d. ob.
De Flatford & Wylom 13d. ob.
De West-Chirton 15d." .

The honest but credulous Matthew Paris relates, that a wicked monk of St Albans, who had been banished, as their manner was with de∣linquents of that monastery, for the crime of forgery and for having stolen the seal of the house, to their cell at Tinmouth, in the time of John, elected abbot in the year 1195, and who died in 1214, instead of profiting by his punishment, still continued to lead a debauched and impenitent life, and made here a truly horrid and lamentable end"There was at that time in the monastery, one who wore the habit, but was not a monk, but like Lucifer among the angels, or Judas among the apostles, a most wicked hypocrite among the religious men. This man, whose name was William Pigun, be∣ing corrupted by Robert our adversary, thrust himself busily, as it were, to assist them, among those appointed to search the writings of the house; and, observing that the common-seal was not so strictly watched as it ought to have been, being kept among these writings, he artfully found an opportunity, whilst the others were busy, to put the seal to a counterfeit deed prepared for that purpose, and delivered the same to the afore∣said Robert, our adversary; who, having got it into his hands, began to boast that he had not yet produced that which would confound all his opposers. This being told to the abbot, he soon concluded that there must needs have been some treachery in his own house, and, sifting into the matter, the fraud was detected, and the manager of the same convicted; whereupon he was sent away to the cell of Thinemue, there to do perpetual penance for his crime. Being implacable, he often bitterly cursed the abbot, who had sent him to Thinemue: but all his curses fell upon his own head; for, falling asleep in the necessary-house, when he had over-eaten and drank, he never waked again; and the monks who were in the dortor distinctly heard a voice crying in the privy, Take him, Satan—take him, Satan." Matthew Paris, and Stevens' Contin. of Dugdale, vol. i. p. 253.
About this time, two-thirds of the tythes of Bothal were given by Richard Bertram to Tinmouth monasteryDugdale's Monasticon, p. 336..

Soon after A. D. 1214
Matthew Paris, p. 118, also Stevens' Continuation of Dugdale, vol. i. p. 256.
"On the death of John, abbot of St. Albans, A. D. 1214, William Trumpinton was elected to that abbacy. After the death of King John, he visited Thynemue, and other cells. When the abbot goes to Thynemue, he is to be attended by six esquires, who to this effect have extraordinary feofs of the land of the church. These six are at the abbot's charge, both going and coming; but upon their own horses, the which to be sightly and strong enough to carry, according to custom, if need be, the habits of a monk behind each squire. If any horse belonging to any of these squires shall happen to die by the way, the abbot is to give him ten shillings for his loss. It is to be observed that the abbot is to ask the king's licence to go to such remote parts of the kingdom, and so near to Scotland, whensoever he designs to repair to Thynmue. When arrived there, he is to behave himself modestly, correcting the family, not to be a tyrant, not squandering the provisions and stores of the house; but considering he is come thither to reform all that requires it, and to visit his flock with fatherly affection. This abbot pro∣ceeded to Thynemue, attended by such a multitude as looked like an army. There he reformed what was amiss, and was desired by the prior to discharge him of that office, because he was grown old. The old prior of Thynemue with much difficulty obtained leave to quit that dignity, and was all the rest of his life kept by the abbot as his coun∣sellor, and at his table." This abbot had before banished his prior Reimund to the cell of Thinemue, "which is a place of banishment for our monks.", William Trumpinton, abbot of St. Albans,
visited Tinmouth, and the other cells of that monastery. The mode of his visitation of this place was as follows: he had six esquires to ac∣company him, who were on that account well enfeoffed with lands of that church. These esquires travelled on their own horses, but were supported at the abbot's expencc; these horses were to be good ones, each able to carry an esquire, and, if need required, a monk's clothes behind him; and for every one of them that should happen to die on the journey, the abbot was to allow ten shillings. It appears on this occasion that the abbot was not permitted to visit these remote parts, bordering on the kingdom of Scotland, without a special licence from the King.

In the year 1216, Ralph GubiumThe cause of his resignation is thus related by Matthew Paris: he had been very much harassed by one Simon, of Tinmouth, who claimed two corrodies, which he as∣serted had been given by a former abbot of St. Albans to the church of Tinmouth; and, when William, abbot of St. Albans, came down to visit Tinmouth, he met him with a great concourse of the neighbouring gentry, and begged leave to resign, but was refused for the present: afterwards he followed the abbot on his return to St. Albans, bringing up a boxer with him; for the contending parties had agreed that the affair should be decided by duel. Gubium's champion, on the day of the battle, got the worse, and Simon gained his cause; at which the old prior was so much grieved that he instantly resigned his office. resigned his office of prior of Tinmouth, and was succeeded by Germanus of the North
This Germanus appears to have granted eight quarters of wheat to be received yearly out of the granary of Tinmouth, by the nuns of Newcastle upon Tyne.
"Omnibus sancte matris ecclesie filiis hoc scriptum visuris vel audituris Germanus prior et conventus de Tynemouth salutem in salutis Auctore Noverit universitas vestra nos caritatis intuitu concessisse monialibus de Novo Castro octo summas Lundonar' de frumento ad earundem sustentationem recipiendas singulis annis in perpetuum de gra∣nario nostro de Tynemouth ad quatuor terminos, viz. ad festum Sancti Michaelis duas summas et ad Natal' Domini duas summas et ad Pascha duas summas et ad festum beati Johannis duas summas. Et in hujus rei testimonium huic scripto sigillum nos∣trum apposuimus." From a copy on parchment remaining in the Augmentation-Office. The confirmation following is annexed to it: "Omnibus Christi fidelibus, &c. Johannes Dei gratia abbas ecclesiae Sancti Albani et ejusdem loci conventus salutem in Domino sempiternam Noverit universitas vestra nos divine caritatis intuitu concessisse ac presenti pagina confirmasse dilectis in Christo priorisse & monialibus ecclesie Sancti Bartholomei Apostoli in Novo Castello super Tyne flumine octo quarterias bladi annuas in perpe∣tuum ad mensuram quarteriarum London' quas perceperint de granario prioris et con∣ventus de Tynemouth prout carta earundem monialium quam habent de cella nostra de Tynemouthe evidenter testatur. Ut igitur hec nostra confirmatio robur firmitatis ob tineat presenti pagine sigillum nostrum commune duximus apponend' Valeat universitas vestra in Domino in eternum. Dat' apud Sanctum Albanum die Sancti Birini Episcopi anno 1250."
See Matthew Paris Vit. 23 Abbat. Sancti Albani, p. 119. "Loco vero Radulphi Gubum prioris de Thynema appositus est Germanus de ipsis partibus borealibus oriun∣dus." This Germanus was afterwards made abbot of Selbye.—Ibid. p. 69.

A. D. 1223, William de Barton occurs as prior of this house
Tinmouth Chartulary at Northumberland-House, fol. 210.
In the year 1227, this house appears to have had some dispute concerning the manor of Cherinton, I suppose by a typographical error put for Chirton.—Tanner's Notit. Mon. p. 391.
"Plac' de banco 10 Hen. III. Hill. Rot. 18. pro maner. de Cherinton.".

In the time of John, abbot of St. Albans, who was elected in 1235, and died during the reign of Edward I. the church of Norton appears to have been given to the monastery of Tinmouth, for the purpose of mending their ale, and for extraordinary acts of hospitality. The church of Eglingham, which had been given to this house by R. de Marisco, Bishop of Durham, to mend their ale, was at the same time made their private property. At this time also Walter, Bishop of Durham, gave them two-thirds of the church of Hertburne, worth 153 marks, to enable them to increase their hospitality. The abbot of
St. Albans kept the church of Norton in his own hands, and the prior of Tinmouth paid him yearly 240 marks for the churches of Egling∣ham and HartburnMatthew Paris, ut supra, p. 144..

October 4th, 1224, William de Bedeford occurs as prior of Tin∣mouth. He died October 29th, 1242I conjecture that William de Bedeford was succeeded by Ralph de Dunham, of whom I find mention as follows in the Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 73, b. "Memo∣randum quod Dominus Radulphus de Dunham prior de Tynemuth dedit & concessit cum consensu ejusdem loci (conventus) dudum I. de Sutherax tunc sacriste de Tyne∣muth et ejus successori qui pro tempore fuerit imperpetuum unam dimidiam acre terre in campo de Moreton—pro qua dabit sacrista qui pro tempore fuerit singulis annis tres denarios die Cene ad inveniend' unum pauperem ad mandatum prioris— item pro duabus acris, &c. inveniet sacrista qui pro tempore fuerit duos cereos ad majus altare scilicet unum ante ymaginem beate Virginis et alium ante ymaginem Sancti Oswini cum aliis cereis in omnibus principalibus festis ardentes et in anniversar' Domini Johannis abbatis & Domini Radulphi de Dunham, prioris de Tynmuth.".
In the year 1243, the prior of Tinmouth contributed five marks to the aid which was levied by King Henry the Third, to marry his eldest daughterMadox's History of the Exchequer, p. 414, fol. edit..

A. D. 1244, a peace was concluded between the King of England, and the Scottish King, by the mediation of the prior of Tinmouth, who acquitted himself to the satisfaction of both parties, by his great attention and fidelity on the occasionMatthew Paris, p. 646..

In the year 1247, an agreement was made between the church of Durham and that of St. Albans, concerning the visitation of the parish church within the monastery of Tinmouth
Ibid. p. 725, 726. Alwoldus occurs preost of this church, A. D. 1085.—Randall's MSS.
In the Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 207, is the following entry: "A. D. 1227 preceptum fuit per commune consil' regni quod abbas de Sancto Albano habeat amercia∣menta hominum suorum de Tynemuth et quod de cetero ea recipiat ad scaccariam." As is the subsequent, fol. 205. "Prior de Tynmuth habet retornum brevium et tenet placita de namio vetito & habet wreckum maris & alia que ad coronam pertinent per cart' Regum Anglie predecessor' Regis nunc et habet sure' & assisam panis et cerevisie a tempore Re∣gis II. filii Willielmi Regis Conquestoris.".

A. D. 1248, the Bishop of Durham, in violation of the above agree∣ment, appears to have renewed his vexatious claims. The King was appealed to on this occasion, who commanded the bishop to desist, on pain of his displeasure. The bishop's attempt on this occasion was to extort money from the church of Tinmouth, either to repair or raise some new fabrick in the church of DurhamMatthew Paris, p. 744..

On the day of St. Birinus the bishop, A. D. 1250, the abbot and convent of St. Albans confirmed a charter of Germanus, prior, and the convent of Tynmouth, to the nuns of St. Bartholomew, in Newcastle upon Tyne, of eight quarters of wheat, to be received annually from the granary of TinmouthSee before note under 1216..

A. D. 1255, an agreement was made between the prior of Tin∣mouth, and Sir John Baliol, Knight, who had exercised great rapacity and injustice towards this monastery"A. D. 1255, facta est concordia inter Episcopum Dunelmen' Walterum & Jo∣hannem de Baillol, militem, super pluribus controversiis inter ipsos motis. Similiter est pax reformata inter priorem de Thinemua & dictum Johannem: Ipse enim Johannes supra quod deceret et animae suae expediret avarus, rapax et tenax: tam ecclesiam de Thi∣nemua quam ecclesiam Dunelmensem diu et multum injustè vexaverat & enormiter damni∣caverat.".

In the year 1269, King Henry III. granted a charter of the mo∣nastery of Tinmouth, for a market to be held at BewickTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391. "Cart. 53 Hen. III. m. 2, pro mercat. apud Bewyke.".

A. D. 1271, the same king granted a charter of liberties to Tin∣mouth monastery
Ibid. p. 391. "Cart. 55 Hen. III. m. 4 & 7, de Libertatibus."
In an account of the privileges belonging to the church of St. Albans, as they were settled by William Hortune, monk of the same house, and Master William St. Edwand, A. D. 1257, in Stevens' Continuat. of the Monasticon, vol. i. p. 234, the following occurs: "Item, it is granted that the obligations of our cells of Thinemue & Belver, made to the Bishop of Hereford by Master Rusland, be recalled, and the merchants other∣wise satisfied.".

In the year 1279, judgment was given in the King's Bench against the prior of this house, who claimed a market at Tinmouth
Aubone MS.
In the Tinmouth Chartulary under the year 1279, is recorded the ancient mode of asking their liberties of the justices itinerant, by the King of Scotland, the Archbishop of York, the Prior of Tinmouth, the Bishop of Durham, and Gilbert de Umframvyll, or by their several bailiffs, on the coming of the said justices to the pleas at Newcastle— if they came from York, at a fountain at the head of Gateshead, called "Chille"—if from Cumberland, at Faurstanes, or any place near their entrance into the county. Fol. 205..
A. D. 1280, Friar William de Norton occurs as cellarer of this monasteryIbid. fol. 206..

In the year 1292, there appear to have been great disputes between the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne and the prior of Tinmouth, concerning which, judgment was given in parliament, A. D. 1306
See history of the River Tyne — Also Tanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391.
By an inquisition dated at Newcastle A. D. 1291, "William Bernard" appears to have been the immediate predecessor of the then prior of Tinmouth—and that "Ada de Meperdeshalle" had been the predecessor of William Bernard in that office, as one Ralph had been of the said Ada de Meperdeshalle. In the same inquisition "William de Horton" is mentioned as having been prior of this house some time during the reign of King Henry III..

A. D. 1292, the monastery of Tinmouth was in the possession of ten manors, viz. Tinmouth, Preston, Seton, Backworth, Flatford, Bebeset, Elstwick, Wylom, Anebel and Bewyk, producing in all a yearly revenue of 200l. which with 214l. 2s. 11d. per annum, made a sum total of 414l. 2s. 11d. a very large income, if we consider the value of money at that periodTinmouth Chartulary, fol. 54, et seq..

May 2d, 1293, King Edward I. who had claimed the advowson of the priory of Tinmouth, made a grant of it for ever to the abbot and convent of St. Albans
"Paten' de anno regni Regis Edwardi primi vicesimo primo, m. 19, pro abbate de Sancto Albano de advocatione prioratus de Tynemuth.
R. omnibus ad quos &c. salutem. Sciatis quod cum advocationem prioratus de Tyne∣muth in comitatu Northumbr' nuper in cur' nostra coram dilectis & fidelibus nostris Hugone de Cressingham et fociis suis justie' nostris itinerant' in eodem comitatu per breve nostrum de recto versus abbatem de Sancto Albano petivissemus ut jus nostrum. Nos caritatis intuitu et ob reverenciam beati Albani prothomartir' Angl' necnon et pro salute anime nostre ac eciam clare memorie Alianore quondam Regine Anglie consortis nostre et animarum omnium antecessorum & successorum nostrorum remisi∣mus pro nobis & heredibus nostris prefato abbati de Sancto Albano omnem accionem quam ergo eundem abbatem habuimus in advocatione prioratus predicti seu ejus pertinen' quibuscunque volentes & concedentes pro nobis et heredibus nostris quod predictus abbas de Sancto Albano et ejusdem loci conventus habeant et teneant advo∣cationem predictam cum pertinentiis ut jus ecclesie sue predicte de Sancto Albano sibi et successoribus suis sine occone vel impedimento nostri vel heredum nostrorum in perpetuum. In cujus &c. Teste Rege apud Westm' secundo die Maii."—From an attested copy of the original record remaining in the Tower of London. See also Chro∣nicon sive Annales Prioratus de Dunstable, p. 603-4, vol ii.
Pleas at the assizes for Northumberland, 1293, occur concerning Tinmouth monastery, the last of which related to the manor of West-Chirton.—Tanner, Not. Monast. p. 391..

In the year 1295, Ada de Tewyng was prior of Tinmouth
Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 35, b.—There are mentioned at the same time "W. de Bolum et W. de Lose, capellanis et Nichola Vigrus Seniore ejusdem domus."
Ibid. fol. 203, b. "Simon" occurs as prior of Tinmouth A. D. 1293.
A. D. 1291, the prior of Tinmouth is mentioned as having a portion in the church of St. Nicholas, in Newcastle upon Tyne, of eight pounds per annum.—MS. in the Ex∣chequer, copied May 10, 1781.
And in the year 1318, mention occurs of that portion as reduced to 40s.—Ibid..

By a grant from John Lord Greystock and Sir Robert Somervill, made in the year 1296, the monks of Tinmouth monastery had car∣riage roads for themselves and their tenants through Benton Moors, with liberty of pasture for twenty-four beasts of any kind: The above grant was confirmed by Ralph Lord Greystock, A. D. 1391. 14 Ric. II.Carta penes h. v. Ducem Northumbriae, printed in Wallis' History of Northumber∣land, vol. ii. p. 260.
King Edward I. after his victory over the Scots in the year 1298, visited and remained for some time in Tinmouth monastery.Ibid. vol. ii. p. 265, citing Hollingshead's Chronicle, vol. ii. p. 308.

King Edward I. by a charter dated at Westminster, February 20th, 1299, confirmed to the prior of Tinmouth, a cell of the abbacy of St. Albans, to have all pleas within his liberty of Tinmouth, as well those of the crown as others, concerning his men, lands and tenements, to be pleaded and determined by his own justices, the King's justices not being permitted to enter the said liberty; restoring at the same time
other liberties and free customs which had been seized into the King's handsFrom an authenticated copy of the original charter preserved in the Tower of Lon∣don.—See also Tanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391, cart. 27 Ed. I. n 31..
In this charter the body of St. Oswin is mentioned as resting in a certain shrine within the church of Tinmouth.

December 8th, 1299, King Edward the First offered a clasp of gold, of the value of six marks, at the shrine of St. Oswin of TinmouthWardrobe account of the 28th of Edward I. published by the Society of Antiqua∣ries of London, p. 333. "Firmaculum auri, precii 6 marc'—offertur per Regem ad feretrum Sancti Oswini apud Tinemuth 8 die Decembris."—The following occurs ibid. p. 39, under the same year: "20 die Junii in oblacionibus missis per Johannem de Langele usque Tinemuth ad offerend' nomine Regis ad feretrum Sancti Oswini in ec∣clesia prioratus ibid. 7 solid.".

In the year 1301, Simon, mentioned before, in a note, as prior of Tinmouth, A. D. 1293, occurs as holding the same office
Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 168, b. Quaere, was this the "Simon de Walden" who is mentioned in F. Peck. Menast. Angl. Supplem. tom. iii. Mus. Brit.—De prioribus hujus monasterii?
King Edward I. dates from Tinmouth 23 June, 1301. See Rot. Parliam. vol. i. p. 155..

A. D. 1303, the Queen of Edward I. resided at Tinmouth monastery while the King was on his last march to Scotland
Wallis's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 265, citing Hollingsh. Chron. vol. ii. p. 312.
Among other charges exhibited against Hugh Spencer, occurs the following very sin∣gular one: "En retornant (from Scotland) vous Hugh, votre pere & Robart de Baldoc faucement et traytrousement consallatez nostre Seignour le Roy a lesser Madame la Royne en grant peryl de corps en la priore de Tynmuth en la marche de guerre."—Knyghton de Event. Angl. col. 2548..

In the year 1303, also, a charter was granted to this monastery for an annual fair at Tinmouth, but the year following, on a petition of the town of Newcastle, the grant for the fair was revoked
Rot. Parliam. vol. i. p. 165. Notitia Monastica, p. 391. "Cart. 32 Ed. I. n. 14, pro feria apud Tinmouth."
See also Aubone MS. where we read, "In the 33d of Ed. I. after inquisition for∣merly had, judgment was given against the prior of Tinmouth, who claimed a market there by the grant of Richard I. and the grant was revoked, and the market annulled.
By the Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 190, b. it appears that this fair was to have lasted 15 days—i. e. to be on the vigil and day of St. Oswin, in autumn and for the 13 follow∣ing days..—About
this time a Quo Warranto occurs to the abbot of St. Albans and the prior of this house, to shew on what authority they claimed the re∣ception of all felons coming within the grith of Tinmouth
Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 193.—The following occurs, ibid. fol. 193, b.
"Jur' presentant quod Mich' de Flandr' occidit de die Galfri le Messer de Tynem' cum quadam hach in campo de Tynem' et statim post factum captus fuit et imprisonat' et in prisona prior' de Tynem' et in eadem custoditus fuit per villam de Tynemuthe. Et postea a prisona illa evas' et posuit se in ecclesiam monachale et ibidem coram Adam de Pykering coronatore abjur' regnum."
In the above very curious record are mentioned the subsequent imposts and services "Abbotstuth—Hertnespenies—Radmal—Hedepenyse—Byllingmalle—Warda Castri— Lonynge—Magnum Hittrip in Autumpno—Mercheta—Hornyeld—Merdesfenpenies— Hethpenies—Conewais Silver—Inlad—Anthrep—Conevaisates—Boenere—Milnesilver— Nsumlade—Boonharowe—Leirwyta—Magnum Bonum—Yevel Penies—Fin' Cur'— Coventhespenies—Welcom Abbatis."—A species of tenant, are called "Selfodes"—Can this mean "Ridge or Butteholders"—i. e. tenants for a ridge of ploughed land—from "Selio"—See Kennet's Glossary to his Parochial Antiquities—"Quatuor seliones terrae quae vocantur Buttes."—"Sull," he says, "in the north is still the name of a plough. See extracts at full length in the Appendix..

March 15th, 1307, King Edward I. for a certain fine pardoned the prior of Tinmouth, for acquiring possessions in Herford, Bebbeset on Blythe, Coppon, East-Backworth and West-Backworth, Tynemuth and Preston, without a licence of mortmainFrom an authenticated copy of the original preserved in the Tower of London..

This year also, on the morrow of the feast of the apostles Peter and Paul, Simon, the prior of this monastery, caused a pillory to be erected in the village of TinmouthTinmouth Chartulary, fol. 191, b.—"Memorandum quod in crastino apostolorum Petri et Pach anno Domini millsimo ecc. septimo et anno regni Regis Edwardi tricesi mo qino S. prior de Tynemouth per consilium amicorum levati fecit in villa de Tynemuth collistrigium hoc est pillori, eo quod tale judicium pertinet ad assisam panis & cerevisie quam dictus prior & predecessores sui habuerunt sicut communiter dicitur a tempore quo non extat memotia per libertates contentas in cartis regum Anglie sed ta judicio hoc est pillori per suam negligentiam usi non fuerunt usque ad crastinum apostolo∣rum Petri & Pauli supradictum, item die translationis Sancti Thome martiris anno Domim supradicto & anno regni Regis similiter supradicto idem Rex apud Burgum super Saund non procul a Karliol diem clausit extremum.".

On Ascension Day, 1312, King Edward the Second, and his favou∣rite
Gaveston, appear to have been at Tinmouth, from whence they took shipping for ScarboroughRymer's Foedera, tom. iii. p. 328..
In the year 1313, the King granted a patent to the monastery of Tinmouth for the return of briefsTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391, "Pat. 6 Ed. II. p. 1, m. 10, dorso, pro re∣turn' brev.".

A. D. 1315, a chantry was founded at Tinmouth for the soul of John Lord Greystok, who died in the year 1306
Wallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 262. It was founded by Ralph, son of William Fitz Ralph, lord of Grimethorp in the county of York, a kinsman of the deceased.
The following names of the chaplains of this chantry are preserved ibid. Thomas de Bulmer "before the first pestilence." Gilbert Willynson de Tynemouth, Rob. de Ambell, John de Walsyngham, John de Whalton..

In the year 1315, Tinmouth is mentioned among the castles of NorthumberlandJohannes de Trokelowe Annales Ed. II. p. 32. "Circiter 1315. Et sciendum quod non remansit in partibus illis aliquis locus ubi Anglici tute latere poterant, praeter∣quam in civitate Carleolensi et Burgo Novi Castri super Tinam et prioratu de Tyne∣mutha, ceterisque castris per Northumbriam.".

A. D. 1316, as before in 1311, John de Howickes, or de Hou∣worthe, occurs as priest of Tinmouth
Randall's MSS.
In the Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 168, a is the following memorandum:
"A. D. 1316, prior de Tynemuth remisit Roberto de Slikeburn 41. de carbonar' de Merden pro destruccione facta per Scotos.".
In the year 1316, King Edward the Second granted a charter to the monastery of TinmouthTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391. "Cart. 9 Ed. II. n. 39.".

The year following, certain infatuated persons of Northumberland, called Shavaldores, at the head of whom occur Sir William de Mid∣dleton,
Knt. and Walter de Seleby, committed great depredations on the priory of Tinmouth, but having been taken prisoners and sent up to London, they were there tried and condemned, and suffered death on the gallows
Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 212. Also Johannes de Trokelowe Annales Edwardi II. p. 40, 1, 2, 3. "Quidam fatui de Northumbria qui dicebantur Savaldores"—After recit∣ing the robberies they committed, and the taking of Sir William Middleton, he adds, "Vinctus apud Nevm Castellum—deducitur et post paucos dies in quadam navi in portu de Tyne positus, ventum congruum expectans, pro dampnis et injuriis Sancto Oswino et suis per ipsum frequenter irrogatis, veniam invitus postulavit. Vento tandem boreali sortiter flante et mari horribiliter intumescente, Grimmesby, vix vita comite per∣ducitur, ubi, pedibus sub equino ventre copulatis Londonias mercedem pro meritis sus∣cepturu, de lucitur et judicio in eum lato caudis equorum funibus innexus, Furcas usque distrahitur, et totum jus cum dominio quod ipse vel fratres sui in comitatu Northum∣brie habere clamitbnt suspendio eorundem terminatur."
In the above Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 11, mention occurs of certain out-houses which had ben pulled down by the order of the prior, "ne Shavaldores et alii latrones ." should find shelter in them..

In the year 1320
"Carta Henrici Faukes de quadam via ad quareram de Bacworth et quieta claman∣ ejusdem pud Rodestan More.
Sciant prntes et futuri quod ego Henricus Faukes de West-Bacworth propter affec∣ti am quam habeo de persona fratris Ricardi de Tewyng prioris de Tynemuth concessi mea confirmavi Deo & ecclesie Sancte Marie & Sancti Oswyni de , ventui ejusdem loci & eorum successoribus monachis de Sancto Zbario apud Tynemuth Deo servientibus viata largam & sufficientem imperpetuum pro et cart qui vocantur Solates pro coopertura domorum suarum de quare suis in West wrth cariand' omnibus anni temporibus, viz. sub gardino meo ultra tertam meam liered' meorum & omnium aliorum ad quorumcunque manus dicta terra mea imposterum devenerit a porta mea boreali usque orientem sicut terra mea ibidem jacet. Remitto insuper pro me et hered' meis ac quietum clamo dictis priori & conventui omne jus si quod habui in quadam parte More de Rodestane More ex occi∣dentali parte de Preston, que quidem pars continet in se sexaginta acras et extendit se in longitudine de via que ducit molendino de Billing usque Moreton usque ad culturam que vocatur Blake Chestres in campo de Est Chirton usque ad Northstrete que ducit de Tyne∣muth usque Furcas de Rodestane. Hiis testibus Dominis Johanne de Fenwyk tunc Vic' Northumbr' Roberto de la Val Johanne de Vallibus Willielmo de Swyneburne militibus Willielmo de Schafthow Johanne fil' Johannis de Horsley Simone de Welteden, Johanne de Bacworth Alano de Castro & aliis Dat' apud Tynem' die Dominica proxime post festum Sancti Jacobi Apostoli anno regni Regis E. fil' Regis E. quarto decimo."— Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 81, b.
In a plan now remaining at Northumberland-House, intitled the "Plan of the Manour of Tinmouth and Tinmouthshire, &c. as surveyed by I. Thompson, 1757," the field in which this monkstone stands is called in the reference "Cross-Close Pasture," con∣taining 9 acres, 3 roods and 10 perches., a place occurs in the field of East-Chirton, near Tinmouth, under the name of "Blake-Chestres," indicating plainly, it should seem, that there were on the spot at that time some remains of a Roman station.

In the same deed "the gallows of Rodestane" is mentioned in a situation answering to that of the present monkstone, which I have several reasons for thinking is no more than the shaft of an ancient cross or rood stone, the inscription upon which is clearly of a modern date. See a description and print thereof in Grose's Antiquities.

St. Leonard's Hospital
In the ministers or bailiffs account of certain religious houses in Northumberland, from Michaelmas, 30 Hen. VIII. to the same term, 31 Hen. VIII. remaining in the Aug∣mentation-Office, the following occurs: "Ac eciam 10s. de firm' unius domus voc' le Spittell-Howse cum 1 claus' voc' Spittell-Close."—As do the subsequent: "Over Spittell-Deane et Spittell Deane—Spittell Brugge—12 shorte butts jac' in le Weste Spittell"—in that of the possessions of Tinmouth monastery.
In the above plan, dated 1757, the place where St. Leonard's Hospital has stood, still dis∣tinguishable by the inequalities of the ground, like the ruins of buildings on the left hand side, after passing the bridge on the road from Tinmouth to Chirton, is called "Spittle-Yards," containing 5 acres, 2 roods and 37 perches.
In the Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 166, mention occurs of "2 acras terrae de domi∣nicis apud Gunnildeserosse." occurs as existing at this time, the ruins of which are still to be traced a little to the west of Tinmouth, on the road to Newcastle. Richard de Tewyng is mentioned in the above deed as the then prior of Tinmouth.

In the year 1322, the Queen of King Edward the Second resided for some time at Tinmouth monasteryVahole account of Edward II. from May 15th, 12, to 19th ober, 1324, in the library of Thomas Astle, Esq p. 45—"Thome de Holm suttero horprei Domini Regis moranti in prioratu de Tynemuth una cum aliis scutifetis de hospicio Domini Regis in municione ejusdem prioratus racione more Domine Regine ibidem pro expens' oris sui per 16 dies 26 die Septembris pro primo computato, percipiendo 4d. ob. per diem 6s." (The part of the account from whence this is extracted is from 1st May, 15 Ed. II. to 7th July, 16 Ed. II.).

On the last day of September, 1323, the body of Ada, a bastard son of the above King Edward the Second, was buried in the conven∣tual church at TinmouthFratribus ordinum predicator', minorum, Sancti Augustini et monte Carmeli ville Novi Castri super Tynam exist' apud Tynemouth die sepulture Ade filii Regis defuncti et ibidem sepulti de elemosina Domini Regis cuilibet ordini 5s. per manus fratris Johan∣nis de Leck de ordine predicator' ibidem eodem die 20s." "Ultimo die Septembris pone∣bantur per preceptum Regis super corpus Ade dicti filii Regis bastardi defuncti die sepul∣ture ejusdem in ecclesia conventuali de Tynemuth—duo panni ad aurum in servicio de Leck."—Wardrobe account of Ed. II. ut supra, p. 32 and 215..

A. D. 1326, King Edward the Second granted licences of mortmain to the church of Tinmouth, for messuages and lands in Backworth, Moreton, Whitley and Milnton"Carta predicti Regis Ed. II. de licentia impetrandi de Thoma de Raynton 4 messuag' xaginta decem acras et tres rodas terre cum pertinen' in Bacworth Moreton White∣et Milneton—Dat' apud Westm. 12 Julii anno regni nostri 19o.": as also in Newcastle upon Tyne, the last of which are said to be situated "super les stathes" in that town
Tanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391, "Pat. 19 Ed. II. p. 1, m. 35, pro mess. et tertis Bokeworth, Moreton, Whitley and Milneton, et p. 2, pro mess. in Novo Castro.
The second of these licences is dated at Sturrye, June 10th, 1326, and is granted to John Felton, chaplain, to assign to this house a messuage with its appurtenances in New∣castle upon Tyne, of the annual value of four marks—mentioning a former licence of mortmain granted to this house, to acquire lands and rents to the value of ten pounds per annum, their goods and possessions having been destroyed by the Scots.—This last men∣tioned appears by the Tinmouth Chartulary to have been dated June 26, 1323.—Fol. 77..

A. D. 1328, King Edward III. granted a licence of mortmain to the church of Tinmouth, for two tofts and places in the villages of Seton and WoodhornTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391—also Tinmouth Chartulary.—It appears by a charter in Dugdale's Monasticon, p. 336 (de anno 2 Ed. III. n. 3) that some of the re∣puted liberties of this house had been adjudged to King Edward III. in the beginning of his reign, which he then regranted to them in as large a manner as ever, out of the especial devotion which he bore to the glorious martyrs St. Alban & St. Oswin..

A. D. 1332, a ship called the James, of which one Cantis, of Sand∣wich, was master, on Friday after the feast of the Annunciation, was
cast away at Tinmouth. On this occasion the prior and convent there purchased of the master the timber of the wreck, with the anchors, sail and ropes, and all other utensils of the said vessel"Pateat universis per presentes quod ego Cantis de Sandwyco, magister & dominus navis vocat' James fract' tempestate maris in mari apud Tynemuth die Veneris proxime post fest' Annunciationis beate Marie anno regni Regis E. tercii a conquestu sexto vendidi priori et convent' de Tynemuth pro quadam summa pecunie mihi pre manibus soluta om∣nimodum maeremium proveniens de predicta navi cum anchoris et velo & omnibus cordis et omnibus aliis utensilibus appendiciis et omnibus aliis rebus quocunque nomine cen∣seantur mihi & predicte navi pertinentibus seu inde aliquo modo provenientibus ad quo∣rumcunque manus devenerint et ubicunque inveniantur &c—Dat' apud Tynemuth statim post fractionem predicte navis die & anno supradictis."—Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 163, b. —Two others of the like kind occur ibid.—The master's name of one, "Henric' Clerson magister navis vocat' Rikeharing de Axil"—Of the other: "Petrus Triff de Whitsand, dominus navis de Whitsand vocat' Navis Sancti Johannis.".
Friar Richard de Tewyng, who occurs in the year 1320 as prior of Tinmouth, appears to have filled the same office A. D. 1339Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 169 & 120..

June 18th, 1336, King Edward III. granted a licence of mortmain to John Gros, of Berwick upon Tweed, to assign to the prior and convent of Tinmouth, a messuage in a street there called Uddyn-Gate; as also a rent of 13s. 4d. out of a messuage in St. Mary-Gate in the same town. The above charter is dated at DarlingtonTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 9 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 7, vel 8." Also from an au∣thenticated copy of the original preserved in the Tower of London..

A. D. 1336, mention occurs in the Tinmouth Chartulary of the new chapel of St. Mary at Tinmouth
Fol. 18, b.—"Quam prior assignavit nove capelle Sancte Marie."
On a large oval in the ceiling just above the altar place in this oratory, is the figure of our Saviour with a cross in his hand, and one kneeling before him The inscription de∣faced.—The roof of this chapel is composed of several arches intersecting each other. Twelve of the principal intersections are adorned each with an oval piece of sculpture, representing an apostle, with the name, and Ora pro nobis in an inscription. The lesser intersections are joined by less rounds representing knots, initial letters, and the Northum∣berland badge. In the center of the roof on a large oval, is the representation of our Saviour sitting in judgment, and the angels sounding the trumpets, inscribed "In die judicii libera nos Domine." In the roof is also a round with intersecting hands extend∣ed, and a heart emblematical of the willing mind, and endeavours of the benefactor to∣wards good works.—See Miscellaneous Antiquities, plate of, No. I.
In the "Supplementum Historiae Aureae I. de Tinmouth," preserved in Bennet-College library, Cambridge, among the benefactors to St. Albans occurs the following: "Henricus Percye, Comes Northumbrie hujus domus protector efficax et defensor sepius pro nostris commodis insudavit et pro nobis sepius intercessit, nostraque negotia promvoit. Celle nstre de Tynemutha plurima dona dedit ac inter cetera contulit ad fabricam ejusdem loci porte centum marcas: contulit etiam prioratui nostre de Tynemutha mille & amplius arbres in subsidium reparacionis domorum prioris & conventus erutorum per Scotos."
In a Chartulary of St. Albans monastery preserved among the Rawlinson MSS. in the Bodleram library at Oxford, there is mentioned a grant of the Earl of Northumberland tempore Edwardi IV. of 10l. per annum to this house, charged upon his manor of New∣burn in Northumberland. I saw this MS. January 1786..

A receipt dated August 23d, 1337, occurs in that Chartulary, as given to the prior of Tinmouth by the Bishop of Carlisle, for an an∣nual pension of 6s. 8d. paid by this convent to that see"Acquietancia Episcopi Karl' de annua pensione 6s. 8d. Pat at universis per presentes quod n Johannes permissione divina Episcopus Karleolensis recepimus de domino priori de Tynemuth solidos & 8 denar' argenti de una pensione annum nobis per cun∣ ita pro termino supradicto &c. Dat' apud Karliol' 23 die mensis Augusti 1337, &c."—Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 173..

Under the year 1338, there is mentioned in the same Chartulary, a windmill belonging to the convent of Tinmouth, at Cupon, a village in NorthumberlandIbid. l. 175. "Memorandum de molendino ad ventum de Copon dimisso Roberto Mau de eadem villa in festo passionis Sancti Oswini 1338.".
A. D. 1340, Thomas de la More occurs as prior of TinmouthBrowne Willi..

May 16th, 1340, the King granted a licence of mortmain to Richard de Dalton, of Newcastle upon Tyne, to assign a messuage and 60 acres of land in Moreton, to the prior and convent of Tinmouth
Tanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 13 Ed. III. p. 1, m ....
Also from an authenticated copy of the original preserved in the Tower of London..

December 13th, 1346, the King granted a licence of mortmain to Henry Barnetoft, &c. to assign lands and tenements in Tinmouth, Preston, Bacworth, Moreton, Seton, Bewyk, Copon, Erdestone and Middle-Chirton, to the prior and convent of this house
Tanner, ut supra —"Pat. 19 Ed. III. p. 3, m. 4, vel 5.
Also from an authenticated copy of the original preserved in the Tower of London..
A. D. 1347, the prior of Tinmouth lent the King twenty marks towards defraying the expences of the siege of CalaisRot. Parliam. vol. ii. p. 454..

June 26th, 1349, the King granted a licence of mortmain to Henry de Burnetost, chaplain, &c. to assign to the prior and convent of Tin∣mouth, lands and tenements in East-Moreton, Milnton and Back∣worth, Tinmouth, Preston and East-Chirton: as also to Richard Scot, of Newcastle upon Tyne, to assign to them 66 acres of land and pasture for 12 oxen in Elstewyk, worth 26s. 8d. per annumTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 22 Ed. III. p. 2, m. 28, vel 29." Also from an authenticated copy of the original preserved in the Tower of London..

A. D. 1350, John de Weceley occurs as priest of Tinmouth church. This year also Thomas de la More, prior, was chosen abbot of St. AlbansRandall's MSS.Stevens' Continuation, vol. i. p. 261. He occurs as abbot of that place, 6 Ric. II. in Harleian MSS. No. 602, p. 2, a.—There is mention ibid. p. 1, b. "Johannis Moot, priotis"—Is this a mistake of the transcriber for "More," and does it mean the prior of Tinmouth?.

May 24th, 1355, the King granted a licence of mortmain to this convent for tenements in West-Morton, East-Backworth, West-Back∣worth, Preston, &cTinmouth Chartulary, fol. 105.—Also Tanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 28 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 2, pro ten' in West-Morton, East Backworth, West-Backworth, Preston, &c.".

In the year 1357, an inquest was taken at the suit of the prior of Tinmouth, who claimed Fenham as part of his manor of Elswick. By this inquest, which is of record in chancery by return of the justices of record, and was taken before the chief people of Northumberland, it was found that that village had been all along parcel of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and was held by farm of the crownSee Rolls of Parliament, vol. ii. p. 348..
A. D. 1360, on the Wednesday before the feast of St. Barnabas, John de Whetele occurs as vicar of the church of Tinmouth, and Alan Whiteheved as chaplainTinmouth Chartulary, fol. 3, b..

May 6th, 1361, the King granted a licence of mortmain for tene∣ments in Wolsington, Morton, and Middle-Chirton, to the prior and convent of this house
Ibid. fol. 105. "Teste Thoma filio nostro carissimo custode Anglie apud Redyng 6 Maii A. R. nostri Anglie 34, Francie 21."
See also Tanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 34 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 18, pro ten' in Wol∣sington, Morton et Middle-Chirton.".

About the year 1366, flourished John de Tynmouth, a writer of great eminence, who was born in the town of Tinmouth, and was afterwards vicar of the church in this monastery
See Pitts, p. 499.—Tanner's Biblioth. p. 433—Nicholson's Historical Library, vol. i. p. 179.
Nicholson tells us that his Golden History in 20 books is in the library at Lambeth.— John of Tinmouth wrote also a supplement to the Legend, extant amongst the MS. col∣lections of Dr. James, collected in the Bodleian library, No. 18.
He wrote also the Sanctilogium majus et minus, &c.
The following occurs at the end, p. 920, of Pitt's Lives—"Index alphabeticus quorun∣dam librorum ab Anglis editorum quorum auctores plerique non cognoscuntur. Chro∣nica de Tinmouth.".

February 20th, 1379, King Richard the Second granted a licence of mortmain to the prior and monks of Tinmouth, to hold possessions to the value of 20l. per annum, to enable them to repair the walls of their fortifications, which had been damaged by incroachments of the sea. The priory is described in this curious grant as having been, and being to the then King and his progenitors, "a certain fortified and walled place for defence against the enemies of the kingdom"
"Ricardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Franc. et Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quo presentes litere pervenerint salutem. Sciatis quod nos considerantes qualiter prioratus de Tynemuth super rivolum de Tyne ad ingressum maris in com' Northumbrie situatas quedam placea fortificata et murata ad resistendum maliciem inimicorum progenitorum nostrotum et nostrorum ac regni nostri Anglie fuerat & existit et jam tarde per erecio∣nem & superinundaciones maris muri ejusdem prioratus sunt debilitati et in periculo ruine. Ita quod ultra sustentacionem prioris & monachorum ibidem possessiones eidem prioratui spectantes, quarum una magna pars jacet tam prope ad marchiam Scotie quod de longo tempore dicti prior et monachi proficuum suum inde prout debent habere non potuerunt per magnum tempus, ad reparacionem murorum predictorum non sufficiebant. De gratia nostra speciali et in auxilium et relevacionem status dicti prioratus, qui occasione predicta in multo est deteriorata ut accepimus, concessimus & licenciam dedimus pro nobis & heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est dilectis nobis in Christo priori et conven∣tui prioratus predicti quod ipsi terras tenuras & redditus cum pertinentiis usque valorem vi∣ginti librarum per annum juxta verum valorem eorundem tam de feodo suo proprio quam alieno exceptis terris ten' & redditibus que de nobis tenentur in capite adquirere & recipere possint ab ipsis qui eadem terras, ten' & redditus ex devotione vel per aliam causam ipsi priori & conventui dare, assignare vel legare voluerint et eadem terras ten' & redditus cum pertinenciis habendum & tenendum eisdem priori & conventui & suc∣cessoribus suis imperpetuum, statuto de terris & ten' ad manum mortuam non ponend' edito non obstante, &c. In cujus rei, &c. Teste meipso apud Westmonast' vicesimo die Februarii anno regni nostri tercio."—Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 114.
There is an extract from this curious record in the Cotton library, thus mentioned by Tanner, in his Notitia Monastica, p. 391. "Excerpta ex antiquo registro prioratus de Tinmouth remanente apud Comitem Northumbriae. MSS. in Bibl. Cotton. Vitellius. E. V. 9.".

May 4th, 1380, the King granted a licence of mortmain to Ada de Fenrother, clerk, William de Meryngton, chaplain, Hugh de Brandon, William de Chevyngton, and William de Seton, to assign to the prior and convent of Tinmouth the manor of Denton and Rede∣wode near Mewburn, excepting out of the said manor an annual rent of ten marks, and another of one mark. As also to Alan Whitheved, vicar of Tinmouth, and Robert Fenrother, to assign to the said prior and convent 8 messuages, 8 tofts, and 362 acres and an half of land in Tynemouth, Monkseaton, Est-Chirton, Middle-Chirton, Preston, East-Mureton, Backworth, Coupon, Wylom, and Eglyngham, worth 4l. 16s. and an halfpenny per annumTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 4 Ric. l. p. 2, m. 3, pro ten' in Seton mo∣nachorum, Est-Chirton, Eglingham, Denton, &c."—Also Tynmouth Chartulary, fol. 113..

In the year 1381, some of the monks of St. Albans, who had been concerned in the insurrection of Wat Tyler, made their escape from thence, and fled for their lives to Tinmouth priory, which proved an asylum to them on this occasion, though it was wont to be considered before as a place of banishment
"He bids those pointed at and named by Greyndeob to Tyler, shift for themselves; which they were not long in resolving of.—The prior, four monks, and some of the ser∣vants, one part horsed, another on foot, fly for their lives, not assuring themselves till they got to Tynmouth, a priory of this monastery of St. Albans, in Northumberland."—Idol of the Clownes, p. 75.
Adamar de Athol, and Ralph de Eure, were elected knights of the shire for Northumber∣land, for the parliament held at Westminster, 5 Ric. II. A. D. 1381. Each was allowed four shillings a day for his expences, to be raised by the different villages in the county; but the following ones, which were said to be in the liberty of the prior of Tinmouth, paid nothing: "In libertate prioris de Tynemouth.
De villa de Tynemouth, Milnton cum Sheeles, Chirton East, Preston, Munkston, Whitley, Mureton, Eresdon, Backworth, Seghall, Wolsington, Dissyngton, Elswyke, Wylom, Herford, Cowpon, Bebside, Weltden, Hauxlawe, Ambell, Eglynham, Bewyke, Lilburne, Flatworth, Middle-Chirton, West-Chirton." Wallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. Appendix, p. 4..
A. D. 1382, the King granted a charter to the prior and convent of TinmouthTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 5 Ric. II. m. 1, vel 2.".

The following legendary miracle relating to this place affords a curious instance of the credulity of ancient times. In the year 1384, on the 20th of August, i. e. on the feast of the passion of St. Oswin, king and martyr, as a sailor was cutting a piece of wood on board his ship, at Newcastle upon Tyne, he saw blood gush out of it in great abundance; when, recollecting the festival, he gave over work; but a companion of his, regardless of the miracle, persisted in the profane business; but upon striking the wood, the blood gushed out again in still greater abundance. Both clergy and laity were informed of, and approved the miracle, and the wood was carried to Tinmouth, where the saint's body was interred, to be there preserved in testimony thereof
Ypodigma Neustriae per T. de Walsingham, p. 536.
"A. D. 1384, vicesimo die mensis Augusti, id est, in festo passionis Sancti Oswini regis et martyris, dum apud Novum Castrum super Tynam, quidam nauta lignum dolaret ad opus suae naviculae repente vidit de dicto ligno ubertim sanguinem emanare, recordatusque dicti festi continuit manus ab opere. Sed ejus socius parvi pendens mira∣culum accedit et lignum ferit, ebullitque sanguis illico quacunque parte percutitur, velut cum pecus ferro transfigitur. Res desertur in coetum clericorum, qui omnes cum laicis miraculum approbant. Lignum defertur Tynemutham ubi predicti Sancti corpus quiescit in testimonium miraculi praemonstrati.".

In the year 1385, Alan Whitehead, chaplain of Tinmouth church, did homage at the Lord's Court, at Long-Benton, for lands in that
village, which had been given him by John, son of Henry de Har∣rington, KnightWallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 262..

The same year the King granted a charter to the prior and convent of Tinmouth, for appropriating the church of Haltwhistle in TyndallTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 8 Ric. II. p. 1, m. 2, pro ecclesia de Haut∣wyssell in Tyndall approprianda.".

In the year 1389, a party of Scots, after having plundered and laid waste the adjacent country, came to Tinmouth, desiring to have a peaceable conference with the cellarer of that monastery: while the cellarer, who had been let out of the castle, was treating with them for the ransom of the town from being destroyed by fire, some of the houses appeared in flames; which being perceived by one of the guards of the castle, he let fly an arrow from his cross-bow, which nearly killed a servant of the Earl of Murray. Upon this there was a great outcry of the Scots, who, suspecting treachery, were for putting the cellarer to death; nor would they suffer him to return back into the castle, but upon condition that he should take the wounded servant in with him, and after he was cured send him back to his lord at the expence of the convent: after this had been agreed upon, the Scots quitted the place
Hearnii Hist. Vitae Ricardi II. a monacho de Evesham, p. 109, 110.
"Eo tempore (seil. circa festum Sancti Laurencii 1389) Scoti intraverunt et pene totum comitatum de Tinemunethia vastati fuerant, praedati & succenderant nemine resistente. Et cum ad villam de Tinemunthia venissent, petierunt loqui pacificè cum celario et hiis qui in castello erant. Egressus celarius cum coepisset cum eis pacificè agere de redimenda villa cum appendiciis ab incendio, subito vespiliones latenter ingressi domos, imposue∣runt ignem in tectis et repente incendium per totam villam coluxit. Quod cernens quidam de castelianis sagittam emisit de balaustre et percussit quendam garcionem Comitis de Murriz ita ut mortuus crederetur. Fit ergo clamor Scotorum ingens & celerarium perfidiae arguunt, cum perimere statuentes. SetSic. interventu quorundam Scotorum eum diligentrum vix ereptus est et domum redire permissus ea conditione ut laesum Scotum secum duceret, ad curam ipsum haberet et sanum in Scotiam ad dominum suum domus suae sumptibus destinaret, sicque Scoti ab illo loco recesserunt."
Tanner, in his Notitia Monastica, preface, p. 29, 30, tells us, that it was the office of the cellarer to procure provisions for the monks, and all strangers resorting to the convent: viz. all sorts of flesh, fowls, wine, bread, corn, malt for their ale and beer, oatmeal, salt, &c. as likewise wood for firing, and all utensils for the kitchen. — The cellarer of Peterborough is said to have been "pater secundus in monasterio, and to have had great privileges."
The subsequent inscription in old characters remains on a stone, now used for a seat near the Light-House, in the north-east corner of Tinmouth-Castle, but which has once covered the grave of one of the cellarers of this convent: it is broken through in the middle. "✚ WALTERUS CELRARIUS.".

In the year 1391, Thomas of Woodstock, Duke of Gloucester, and youngest son of King Edward III. resided a few days at Tinmouth-CastleHakluyt, vol. i. p. 123, after telling us that the prince made a voyage to Prassia, adds, "at length having, not without danger of death, sailed along the coasts of Den∣mark, Norway, and Scotland, he returned into Northumberland, and went to the castle of Tinmouth, as unto a place of refuge knowen of old unto him; where after he had refreshed himself a fewe dayes, he tooke his journey towards his mannour of Plashy, bringing great joy into the whole kingdom, as well in regard of his safety as of his re∣turne.".

November 15th 1392, King Richard II. for a fine of 20 marks, granted a licence of mortmain to Alan Whitheved, vicar of Tinmouth, John de Dalton, chaplain, Robert de Anbell, chaplain, &c. to as∣sign to the prior and convent of Tynmouth 8 messuages, &c. in the town of Newcastle upon TyneTanner's Notitia Monastica, "Pat. 15 Ric. II. p, 1. m. 7, pro mess. in Novo Castro. Ibid. m. 12, pro aliis messuagiis ibidem.— Ibid. p. 2, m. 6, vel 7."— Also from an authenticated copy of the original record preserved in the Tower of London..

A similar licence was granted, in the year following, to the prior and convent of this house, for tenements in Elswick, Newbigging, Widdrington, Cuppon, &c.
Tanner ut supra—"Pat. 16 Ric. II. p. 1, m. 6, pro ten' in Elstwick, Newbigging, Wodrington, Cuppon, &c." About this time William de Bellingham occurs as chaplain. Wallis' North. vol. ii. p. 262.
In an original deed preserved in All-Saints vestry, in Newcastle upon Tyne, dated on Palm Sunday, 1392, a tenement on the key side in that town is described as boundering on "a tenement of the prior and convent of Tinmouth on the east, &c. and in length from the stone-house of the said prior and convent to the ground ebbe of Tyne."—"The great stone-house of the said prior" occurs in another deed preserved ibid. dated St. Matthew's day, 1397.

A. D. 1396
Hearne's Preface to Otterbourne and Whethamstede, p. 58. "Tynemuthae in agro Northumbriensi monachorum benedictinorum prioratus—quem cellam S. Albani fuisse constat. Hujus cellae (castro Tynemuthensi, operi magnifico et munito adjunctae) priorem quendam extitisse Johannem Whethamstedium e MS. quodam collegii Corporis Christi Cantabr' colligimus.
"Constat ipsum eo titulo gaudentem interfuisse electioni Johannis Moor in abbatem Sancti Albani mense Octobr' A. D. 1396, uti etiam electioni Willielmi Heyworth in ejusdem loci abbatem mense Novembr' 1401."
Memorand. I saw, in the month of July, 1783, by permission of Dr. Coleman, the above MS. in Bennet-College library, Cambridge, and made the following extracts.
"15 die Septembris, A. D. 1396, Thomas de la Mare abbas Sancti Albani diem clausit extremum."
"9 Octobris, 1396, Johannes Wathenstede, prior of Tynemuth, Robertus Stikford, tercius prior, Rogerus Hevered, sacrista, Willielmus Westwyk, camerarius, &c.—A. D. 1401, Johannes Wathamstede prior de Tynemutha.
He was the 33d abbot of St. Albans, and was so called from the place of his birth, a village near St. Albans. The name of his family was Bostock., John Whethamstede occurs as prior of Tinmouth: he was afterwards elected abbot of St. AlbansSee his epitaph in Stevens' Continuation of the Monasticon.. He wrote a chronicle of English affairs. On his election to the abbacy aforesaid, he pre∣sented the priory of Tinmouth with a very massy chalice of pure gold.
In the year 1401, there was a charter from King Henry IV. to the prior and convent of TinmouthTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391. "Cart. 2 Hen. IV. p. 1, n. 4.".
As there was another charter of the same King, A. D. 1405, to the above prior and convent, for the manor of WhitleyIbid. "Pat. 6 Hen. IV. p. 1, m. 35, pro maner' de Whitley.".

Robert de Rhodes is said to have been prior of Tinmouth in the time of King Henry VI.See Grey's Chorographia, p. 10. Dr. Ellison's MSS. note that R. Rodes' coat of arms was within the gate of the castle at Tinmouth, adding that it was taken down from thence, and sent to him by Col. Valliers, the governor, A. D. 1705..

Roger Thornton, by his will, dated the Thursday before Christ∣mas,
A. D. 1429, bequeathed a noble to every monk in the convent of TinmouthBourne's History of Newcastle, sub anno.
