The descendant of this Roger Thorn∣ton appears to have farmed the great tithes of Hartburn rectory, of the abbot and con∣vent of St. Albans.—Harleian MSS. p. 64, b. "Pateat universis &c. nos Johannem misratione divina abbatem monast' Sancti Albani et ejus loci conventum recipisse et habuisse die confectionis presencium de Rogero Thornton de Witton in com. Northum∣brie Armigerum novem libras bone et legalis monete Anglie quas nobis debet de firma decimarum rectorie nostre de Hertburn"—for one year—Dated at St. Albans on the penult' of May, 34 Hen. VI..

A. D. 1438, John Bambourgh occurs as sub-prior of the conven∣tual church of TinmouthTanner's Bibliotheque.—In the year 1458, Brother John Bambourgh, sub-prior of the conventual church of Tinmouth, published a Life of St. John Wethamstede, formerly prior there, and which he addressed to the then abbot of St. Albans, who was nephew by his sister to the above prior St. John.—Hearne's Wethamstede, &c. vol. ii. p. 428..
January 4th, 1447, John Thornton appears to have been cellarer of this monasteryIn an inquisition of that date taken at Newcastle, "Johannes Thornton, monachus et celerarius ejusdem domus," occurs..

In the year 1451, John Langton was prior of this monastery. He was afterwards suspended for contumacy and disobedience
Under "A. D. 1451, Johannes Langton, prior de Tynemutha, Ricardus Waltham subrefector us: Rotholandus Breton, Willielmus Blakeney, Thomas Luton, praecentor. Johannes yton, Thomas Blakenale, Thomas Albon, custos novae ordinacionis t Thomas Walyngford, subelemonlin," all of this monastery, are mentioned together in the Ap∣pendix, p. 165, vol i. Walter Hemingford, edited by Hearne.
The following occurs in the Harleian MSS 602, p. 54, b.—"Patent universis per presentes nos Johannem miseratione divina abbatem monaster' Sancti Albani et ejusdem loci conventum ordinasse constituisse ac in loco nostro posuisse dilectos nobis in Christo Radulphum Percy militem, Johannem Langton, priorem de Tinmutha & Willielmum Colt, vicar' ecclesie de Eglingham nostros veros & legitimos attornatos conjunctim et divisim ad petend' recipiend' et levandi' omnes et omnimodas decimas a retro et proven tus nobis et monast' nostro debit' ratione rector' nostre de Eglingham, &c."
In the Chartulary of St. Albans, Rawlinson's MSS. Bodleian library, Oxford, a mentioned, "Literae suspensionis, citacionis & exoneracionis Domini Johannis Langton nuper prioris de Tynemuth a regimine prioratus predict' propter contumacias & disobe∣dientias.".
A. D. 1463, King Edward IV. granted a charter to this conventTanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 391, "Pat. 3 Ed. IV. p. 3, m. 12.".

May 2d, 1481, King Edward IV. granted by charter to William Wallingford, then abbot of St. Albans, and his successors, the advowson of the priory of TinmouthStevens' Continuation of Dugdale, vol. i. p. 264..

November 19th, 1483, Nicholas Boston occurs as prior of Tin∣mouth
Chartulary of St. Albans. Rawlinson's Collection of MSS. Bodleian library, Oxford "Perpetuitas concessa Domino Nicholao Boston, priori de Tynemuth mensis Novembris die decimo nono anno Domini millmo. cccclxxxiiio."
The following notices concerning this monastery occur ibid.
"Concordia sacta per dominum abbatem inter priorem de Tynemuth & priorem de Bynham 1485.
"Promissum priotis de Bynham factum coram domino abbate ad solvend' omnia debita prioratus de Tynemuth pro tempore quo ipse stetit prii ibidem. Perpetuitas cosa priori de Tynemutha 8vo. die Marcii anno 1482. Visitatio apud Tynemuth mensis Decembris die 10, A. D. 1480—facta suit commissio Domino Joh. Hatfeld, priori de Belvero ad visitand' prioratum de Tynemuth, &c. &c.
"Literae missae prioribus de Tinmouth &c. &c. &c. ad interessend' electionem. Perpe∣tuitas concessa Domino Nicolao Boston archid. Sancti Arbam in priorata de Tin∣mutha.".

John Hebborne, L. L. B. is mentioned as vicar of Tinmouth, A. D. 1492
Bishop Fox's Register, p. 31—Also A. D. 1501, there occurs ibid. p. 23, "Monicio contra vicarium de Tynemouthe (J. Hebborne) ad residend'—Nov. 4, 1449, absentavit se per menses plutimos continuo a vicaria et adhuc absentat."
Ibid. p. 31. "Pluralitas magistro Johanni Hebborne perpetuo vicario de Tinmouthe Bac'm legibus concessa est ab Innocentio Papa 1492, 5 idus Junii pontificat' anno 8vo.".

In the year 1504, mention occurs of John, prior of Tinmouth
Ridpath's Bord History, p. 478, notes.
Tanner, in his Notitia Monastica, cites the receipts of the Exchequer, A. D. 1520, as containing some memorials of that date which related to the convent..

A. D. 1523, Robert Lambert and others having murdered Chris∣topher Radcliff at Shereston, in the diocese of Durham, and the for∣mer having taken sanctuary in the priory of Tinmouth, Cardinal Wolsey, then Archbishop of York, being struck with the heinousness
of the crime, and offended at so shameful an evasion of justice, wrote to Lord Dacres, warden of the marches, to use every exertion to get him out from thence, in order to his suffering condign punishment
Hearne's Orterbourne and Wethamstede, vol. ii. p. 579.—From "divers letters re∣lating to the affairs of the north"—A. D. 1523, 15 Hen. VIII. an original with the seal.
"To my lovyng friend my Lord Dacre of the north wardeyn of the Kynges west marchis forst Scotland My Lord, I commaunde me herteley unto you. And wher of late on heynous murdre was committed at Shereston within my bishopricke of Dursine by one Robert Lambert, Richard Littlefare, William Turnour, Robert Johnson and other, which (as I am infourmed) murdred one Cristofer Radcliff, and after the same murdre committed the said R. Lambert fledd unto the priorie of Tynmouthe for re∣fuge and sainctuarie and ther as yet remaynithe (as it is saied) I wille and desire you that by all means and politique wayes, which ye can devise, ye endevour yourself with dili∣gence for thapprehending and taking as welle of the said Robert Lambert as of thother shal factours, whiche (as I am infourmed) gos abrode within that my bishopricke as yet unpunished And after that ye have taken theim or ony of theim to be delyvered into the handes of Sir William Boulmer Knight my sheref there, in his keaping to remayn, untill such tyme as they may be ordred by the Kinges lawes and receyve punishement according to their dmerites And in so dooing ye shall ministre unto the king, our soveraigne lord right accptable service in the furtherance of his lawes to the terrible example of other like offendours Thus I committ you to God. From my place at Westminstre the 12th aye of June. Your lovyng frende T. Car. Eborum.".

In the year 1526, Edward Felde, S. T. P. was appointed vicar of Tinmouth on the death of J. Hebborne
Randall's MSS.
"Magister F. Felde, S. . P. resig. Jul. 10, 1533, per procuratorem suum magistrum lorum Thwat, publicum sacra auctoritate apostolica notarium." E Registro Tunstal. p. 13..

A. D. 1528, Thomas Gardiner occurs as prior of the convent of Tinmouth
There are the following particulars in the Harleian MSS. No. 1499, 25, concerning this prior, in the account of a visitation of Northumberland by notroy king of arms, in the year 1530.
"ble, a chevron argent between three bugle horns argent stringed or. These be the armes of my lord the prior of Tynmouth, whose name ys Gardener. And the said prior sndyd of the noble Que ateryn wy to Kyng Henry the 5th, and dauhr to Charles Kyng of Prince, for the said Qune was after marryed to Oweyn Todur, by whom he had yssue hronde of Rihmond and Jasper Due of Bedord, which Jasper begate a bastard doughter called Ellen, maryed Willyam Gardener who was father to my said lord prior. Be yt noted that the said prior of Tynmouth had geven unto me norrey kyng of armes of the north parties this pedigree and armes of his awre re∣porte, which he woll afferme before the kyng and his counsaile that this pedigre is true and the armes also."—See also Willis' Mitred Abbies, vol. ii. p. 165.
It appears by Bishop Tunstal's Register, p. 16, that Friar Clement Westminster, Friar Robert London, and Friar William Facet, monks of Tinmouth, were ordained priests Dec. 20th, 1533.
In the same register, p. 23, are mentioned Thomas Duresme, Robert Charite, George Faythe and Edward Hope, "prima tonsura," i. e. shavelings, monks of Tinmouth, Dec. 18, 1535.
There occurs ibid. as ordained priest on the title of the monks of Tinmouth "Cuthbert Baleye of the dioces of Durham.".

July 10th, 1533, William Hobson, A. M. was appointed vicar of Tinmouth, on the resignation of E. Felde
Bishop Tunstall's Register, p. 13.
"Tho. prior de Tynemouthe et ejusdem loci conventus patroni",

By an inquisition taken at Whalton, Nov. 20th, 1535, it appears that the church there paid yearly to the monastery of Tinmouth 8s. 4d. that the prior and convent of Tinmouth had presented last to it, but that William Blythman was patron for that turn (it being then vacant) by right of advowson granted to him by the prior and convent of Tin∣mouth, under the common seal of their houseIbid. p. 23..

In 1535 Dugdale informs us, that the separate yearly revenue of Tinmouth priory, subordinate to St. Albans, amounted to 397l. 10s. 5½d. —Speed makes it 511l. 4s. 1½.
Stevens, in his Continuation of Dugdale, says that 397l. 10s. 51/d. was the clear value.
I made the following very singular extract from a MS. in the Cotton library. Cleo∣patra, E. iv. p. 144. Plut. v. c. (dorso) under the head of "Crimina comperta in variis monasteriis.
Tynemouth.
Robertus Halle per voluntar' polluc."
Robertus Gathed per voluntar' polluc."
Stephanus Hexham per voluntar' polluc."
Willielmus Facet per voluntar' polluc."
Sodom. Georgius Gasper per voluntar' polluc."
Thomas Hayton per voluntar' polluc."
Willielmus Heresden per voluntar' polluc."
Thomas Gardener, prior. voluntar' polluc."
"Superstitio. Hic habent feretrum sive monumentum Sancti Oswini regis et mart" in veneracione, et calicem Sancti Cuthberti, digitum Sancti Bartholomei ac zona beate Margarete parturientibus ut putatur salutiferam.
Fundator Dux Norfolchie.
Relitus annuus Vo. IX. lib."
The subsequent entry occurs in the same MS. p. 324:
"Prioratus de Tynmouth.
Summa inde 511l. 4s. 1½d.
Summa clara—7 score and 17l. 10s. 5d. ob."
As the following does ibid. p. 384: "Priotatus de Tynmouth 397l. 10s. 5d. ob."

A. D. 1539, Robert Blaickney occurs as prior of Tinmouth. The
house, in distress for want of money at this time, borrowed an hundred marks of Sir Thomas Clifford, KnightFrom a bond in Madox's Formulare Anglicanum, p. 367..

January 12th, 1539, 30. Hen. VIII. Robert Blakeney, prior, with fifteen monks and three novices, surrendered the monastery of Tin∣mouth
From the original surrender remaining ut supra. "Omnibus Christi fidelibus ad quos prseus scriptum pervenent Robertus Blaykney alias dictus Robertus Blaykney prior monasterii sive domus de Tynmouth ordinis Sancti Benedicti Dunelm' diocesis et ejusdem loci conventus salutem in Domino sempiternam. Noveritis nos prefatum priorem & con∣ventum unaina assensu et consensu nostris animis deliberatis corta scientia et mero motu nostri ex quibusdam causis justis et rationabilibus animas et conscientias nostras specia∣liter moventibus ultro et sponte dedisse concessisse ac per presentes dare & concedere red∣dere deliberare et confirmare illustrissimo in Christo principi et domino nostro Henrico octavo Dei gratia Anglie & Francie Regis fidei desensori Domino Hibernie et in terra supremo capiti Anglicane ecclesie totum dictum monasterium nostrum de Tynemouth predict' et totum scitum fundum circuitum et precinctum ejusdem monasterii nostri de Tynmouth predict' nec non omnia et singula maneria dominica messuagia gardina curti∣lagia toft' &c. &c.
"In quorum testimonium nos prefati prior et conventus sigillum nostrum commune presentibus apponi fecimus.
"Dat' in domo nostra capitulari duodecimo die mensis Januarii anno regni Reg Henrici octavi tricesimo.
Per me Robertum Blakeney priorem
Per me Thomam Castell presbyterum
Per me Robertum Bowland presbyterum
Per me Robertum Forman presbyterum
Per me Robertum Hawle presbyterum
Per me Thomam Bennet presbyterum
Per me Willielmum Carlell presbyterum
Per me Robertum Gatshede presbyterum
Per me Willielmum Erisden presbyterum
Per me Dominum Stephan' Hexam presbyt'
Per me Antonium Gardener presbyterum
Per me Georgium Jasper presbyterum
Per me Clementem Westmynster presbyterum
Per me Robertum London presbyterum
Per me Willielmum Facet presbyterum
Per me Thomam Dorram Novicii."
Per me Robertum Charyte Novicii."
Per me Georgrum Faithe Novicii.". A beautiful impression of the common seal of the priory on green wax, is still affixed to the original surrender, remaining in the Augmentation-Office: it represents the Virgin-Mary and child and St. Oswin, in two niches—over them a head of a larger size, unknown—
Inscription, "Sigill. commune prioratus Sancte Marie & beati Oswini de Tinmutha."In a deed remaining in the Augmentation-Office, dated January 28th, 1490, a writ∣ing of a still older date is described as having been sealed with a double seal: Unum scriptum sigillatum per priorem & conventum de Tynemouth sigillo capituli sui, videlicet, in cera viridi cum ymagine Sancti Oswyni et in dorso ejusdem cum ymagine Sancte Marie Virginis.. See plate I. of Seals, No. 3.

On the suppression of this priory, an annual pension of 80l.
The subsequent account extracted from "a brefe certificate made upon the dissolucions of diverse monaster' & priores ther surrendrid in the moneths of Decembre Januar' & Februar' in the 30 yere of the regne of oure soverane lord King Henry theght as insuyth." Harlton MSS. 6 4, makes the prior's pension only 50l. "Tynemouth priorat. Richard Belleses keeper.
The numbre of the prior and brethern with their pencions: prior 50l. 18 confrat. 8l. 13. 4d.
money remanyng of the yerely possessions 399l. 2s. 7d. ob.
The stk, store & domesticall stuff sold, with dotts receyvyd 185l. 13s. 4d.
with porcions payd unto the priors: confr. cum 53l. 6s. 8d.—97l. 10s. 12l. s. 8d.
Th maner of the price of goods and catalls sold 76l. 2s. 8d.
dwells remanyng—lead reservatur—bells 6—woods and underwoods 40 acres, wll —aur'. 62 unc'. argent' 1827 unc.' dimid.
girdells per ent.'
Dettwyng unto the houses &c. 105l. 19s. 7d.
Dettwyng by the houses, 180l. 3s. 6d.
Clere value of the possessions over and above the annual reprisez 537l. 10s. 11d. ob." was assigned to Robert Bakeney, the prior, and smaller ones to each of the above monks and novices
Book of pensions remaining in the Augmentation-Office.—The prior's pension is not insted there. "Rex ad quos &c. salutem. Cum nuper prioratus de Tin∣mouthe in com' nostro Northumbrie jam dissolut' unde quidam Thomas Castell tempore dissolu illius et dum atea monachus ibidem fuit Nos rationabilem annualem pen∣m sive promo conlignam eidem Thorne ad vitum exhibitionem & sustentaci∣em suum melius susi' Sciatis igitur quod nos in consideratione premissorum de gratia nostra speciali ceta screntia & mero motu nostris et per advisiamentum & consensum cancellar' & consilii curie augmentationum revenconum corone nostre de∣dimus & concessimus ac per presentes damus et concedimus eidem Thome quandam annuitatem sive annualem pencionem sex librarum tresdecim solid' & quatuor derios ster um habend' gauderd' et annuatim percipiend' easdem 6l. 13s. 4d. ad tem et pro termino vite ipsus Thome vel quousque idem Thomas ad unum vel plura &c. annon valoris 6l. 1s. 4d. promotus suerit &c. In cujus &c. Teste— Pye milite apud Westmon' 1 March 30 Hen. VIII."
Of the same date there occur similar grants of pensions as follow to the several monks of this house:
To Henry Woddall 6l.
To Robert Bllande 6l.
To Robert Forman 5l. 6s. 8d.
To Robert Hall 6l.
To Thomas Benette 6l.
To William Carliell 5l.
To Robert Gateshed 5l. 6s. 8d.
To William Erisden 6l.
To Stephen Hexham 5l.
To Anthony Gardener 5l.
To George Jasper 5l.
To Clemens Westmynster 5l.
To Robert London 5l.
To William Facette 5l. 6s. 8d.
To Thomas Durhame 4s.
To Robert Charite 4s.
To George ithe 4. .

Sir Oliver Selby was appointed to the church of Tinmouth, Sept. 15th, 1540, on the death of W. HobsonTunstall's Register, p. 29. "Thomas Lewson, arms , ptns vice ratione advocationis sibi per priorem et conventum nuper dissoluti monastem fa' &c.".

March 9th, 30 Hen. VIII. the King demised to Sir Thomas Hilton, Knight, the scite of the late monastery of Tinmouth, with all the houses, edifices, barns, stables, &c. for 21 years, at the annual rent of 163l. 17sCited in the minister's or bailiff's accounts of divers religions houses in the county of Northumberland, from Michaelmas 30 Hen. VIII. to the same m 31st of that king, remaining in the Augmentation-Office. The following occurs, ibid. "De aliquo pro∣ sive firma castri de Tinmouth una cum fostat' et lez bulle warks intra et circa castrum predictum existen' hic non respondit eo quod omnia et singula hujusmodi edificia castro∣ram et fossat' rem' in manibus Domini Regis sub custod' constabulator ibidem ad usum regie majestatis.".

The priory of Tinmouth had great possessions: the twenty-seven following villas in the county of Northumberland, with their royalties belonged to it, viz. Tinmouth, Milnton, Shields, East-Chirton, East-Preston, Monkton, Whitley, Murton, Ersden, Backworth, Seghill, Wolsington, Dissington"Willielmus Delaval d dilie ecclesie villam que Ducentima appellatur in regione Northanhumbrorum."—Supplement. Historiae Aureae I. de Tinmouth, remaining in the college library of Bennet-College, Cambridge.—Incipit prologus super librum de Bene∣factoribus Monasterii Sancti Albani compendiose consect'.). Elswick, Wylam, Hertford, Cowpon, Beb∣side,
Welden, HauxleyIn the minister's or bailiff's account above cited, the following occurs in the account of "Ax "—"Et de 26s. 8d. de precio 8 piscium sals' provenien' de custum' pro quatuor cobulls piscant' ibidem ex antiquo usu.", Ambell, Eglingham, Bewick"Matilis Regina dedit nobis Bewyk et Lilleburne", Lilburn"Matilis Regina dedit nobis Bewyk et Lilleburne", Flatworth, Middle-Chirton, West-Chirton. They had a manor-house in the village of Benwell
Robert Blakeney, the prior, seems to have retired to this house after the dissolution.
Et de 23. 4d. de firma manerii (Benwell) cum turre et aliis edificiis eidem annex' nec non gdini eidem pertinen' cum uno clauso vocat' South-Close continent' 3 acras prati et uno clauso voc' Northe-Close continent' 3 acras prati que omnia et singula nuper fuerunt in manibus & occupatione dti nuper prioris, nunc in tenura et occupatione Roberti Blakeney nuper prioris ibidem solvend' ad term' S. Martini & Pent' equaliter.. They returned the King's writsIn Fitzherbert's Natura Brevium, p. 514, is preserved a copy of an ancient roll in the Exchequer, of what abbies or priories the King ought to have a corrody and pension either or both: by which it appears that in the abbey of Tinmouth was one pension. within these respective lordships, and were exempt from cornage.
They had the lands of Royeley and Denum.

They had the tithes of Corbridge, Ovington, Wylam, Newburn, Dissington, Callerton, Elswick, Bothall, Warkworth, Ambell, Roth∣bury and Wooler in Northumberland; with those of Hertnes and Middleton upon Tees in the bishoprick of Durham.

They had also the impropriations and advowsons of Tinmouth, Wood∣horn, Whalton, Bolam, Bewick, Eglingham"Ricardus de Marisco Dunelmens Episcopus compaciens debilitatem potus con∣ventualis contulit insuitu pictatis ad nostrae cerevifiat melioracionem ecclesiam de Egling¦ham, ob quam meruit memoriam sempiternam."—MS. in Bennet-College library, Cambridge, ut supra—intitled Supplen tum Historiae Aureae L de Tinmouth., Hartburn
"Walterus Dunelmensis Episcopus ad incrementum hospitalitatis hujus domus con∣lit nobis ecclesiam de Hertburne."
In the minister's or bailiff's account of divers religious houses in the county of North∣umberland, from Michaelmas 3 Hen. VIII. to the same term 31st of that king remain¦ing in the Augmentation-Office, under the head of "penciones & porciones Tynmouth" occur 13s. 4d. paid annually from the rectory of Hartborne by the possessors of the late monastery of Newminster—4l. 13s. 4d. from the vicarage of Hartbourne—4l. 13s. 4d. from the vicarage of Woodhorne—13s. 4d. annual pension from the rectory of Whalton, and 13s. 4d. a certain portion of tithes from the parish of Wooler.—Under the head of "penciones cum senodal" occur 13s. 4d. annually paid from the rectory of Haltwyesell to the bishop of Durham—also 6s. 8d. ibid. to the prior of Durham—lastly forty marks per annum to the vicar of Tinmouth.
In the above minister's or bailiff's accounts, &c. their revenue is stated to arise from the demesne lands of Tinmouth,—from Tinmouth villa—from Preston villa—from East-Chirton—from Middle-Chirton—from Whitley—from Monk-Seton—from Morton— from Earesden—from Backworth—from Sighell—from Hallewell—from Hartley—from North-Shells—from Elstewick—from Benwell—from Deaton, with Dissington and Wolsington—from Wylome—from Cowpone—from Bebside—from West-Hareford— from Ambell villa—from Axeleye villa—from Bewyke—Bewyke Magna and New-Bewyke —Whipperdon—Crawceter—Newcastle upon Tyne—Gatesyde near Newcastle—Coket Island—Tinmouth rectory—Haltwysell rectory—Woddern rectory—with pensions and porcions amounting in all to 706l. 10s. 8d. per annum., Shilbottle and Haltwesel, in Northumberland, and those of Conscliff, in the bishoprick of Durham.

Several messuages in Newcastle upon Tyne were also their propertyThe following account of their property in Newcastle upon Tyne occurs ibid. "Novum Castrum super Tynam—Computus Anthon' Heryoton ballivi & collectoris reddit' ibidem per tempus predictum—sed reddit de 3s. de reddit' & firmis octo burgag' in tenura 8 tenentium &c. in le Kayesyde—Et de 6s. de firma 1 burgag' in Hallowebanke &c.—Et de 10s. de firma 4 burgagiorum in Pilgramstrete—Et de 3s. 8d. de firma unius burgag' in vico voc' le Sydegate in tenura Thome Langton, capellani—Et de 8s. de sum' 1 tenemen' in vico voc' le Gallogate—Et de 13s. 8d. de firma 3 burgag' in vico voc' Westgate—Et de 18s. 4d. de firma 3 burgag' in vico voc' le Middelrete—Et de 20s. de firma 2 burgag' in vico voc' Cloithe-Market &c.—Summa 9l. 1s. 8d..

In the year 1550 or 1551, Coket Island, on which had been, till the dissolution, a small house of benedictine monks, which was a cell to Tinmouth, appears to have been granted as parcel of that priory to John, Earl of Warwick, afterwards Duke of Northumberland
In the minister's or bailiff's accounts, ut supra, occur the following notices concerning Cokett Island. "Insula de Cokett &c.—Computus Thomae Bennett capellani et collec∣toris reddit' & firmar' ibidem per tempus predictum.—Sed reddit de 20s. de firma ejusdem insule voc' Cokett Island scituat' infra mare ex opt' castrum Domini Regis de Wark∣worthe cont' in se 4 acras pasture una cum edificiis et una capella infra eandem insulam. N non cum tenemento uno orreo & 3 felion' ter' arabilium jacen' in villa & campis de Ax ley eiem insule pertinen' sic dimiss' Thome Bennett capellno. Ia quod dictus tenens reparabit nia edificia predict' sumptibus suis propriis et expens' Nec non ibidem in∣habitabit ac divina ibidem de die in diem cla bit ad laudem Dei omnipotentis recipient' tntummodo pencionem sive annuitt' eidem per Dominum Pegem per literas patentes durante n capellai concess' in eisdem literi paten' plenius continetur. Solvend' ad term' Sancti Martini & Pent' per eql' porciones et de 10l. de quodam an∣nuali reu recept' de hered' Domini Percy comitis Northumbrie exeunt' de castro de Warkewothe ad sustentacionem unius capellani insule predicte ex antiqua concessione solvend' per recept tis terr' que fuere dicti nuper comitis nunc autem in manibus Domini Regis, videlicet pro uno anno."
See Tanner's Notitia Monastica, p. 390.
In an ancient MS. account of Castles and Towers in Northumberland, preserved in the Cotton library, Juliu, fol. x. p. 155, Tinmouth castle, the tower of Whitley near it, and that of Coquet-Island, are said to belong to the prior of this house.
"Castrum de Tynmouth, prioris de Tynmouth—Turris de Whitle juxta Tinmouth, prioris de Tinmouth — Coketelande, prioris de Tynemouthe.".

For in the fifth year of the reign of Edward VI. a grant had been made to John Dudley, Earl of Warwick, afterwards Duke of Northum∣berland, in fee of "all that the monastery of Tynemouth, and all the demesne lands of the same, with the appurtenances, and all and sin∣gular
messuages, mills, lands, tenements, meadows, feedings, pastures, tythes, pensions, portions, advowsons, donations, presentations and rights of patronage
Notitia Monastica, p. 390. This record is preserved in the Rolls-Chapel.
In Haynes' Burleigh's State-Papers, p. 180, the following occurs in the Journals of Proceedings in the Privy-Council:
"At Richmount the 5th Septembre 1553. A lettre to the capten of Tinmouth castle to cause one Nicholas Musmer, a man, whome he had apprehended to b st with his companie, shippe and goods in sure custodye, so as he may be forth coming to answer to that is laid to his charge by John Handrie and other the Quene's Highnes' subjects."
In 1553 (according to Willis' Mitred Abbies, vol. ii. p. 165) there remained in charge the annuities and pensions of T. Castell—R. Bellarde— R. Forman—W. Facette—W. Carliell—S. Hexham—Clemen Westminster— Anthony Gardiner— Robert London— and Robert Charity, formerly monks of Tinmouth.
A. D. 157, Queen Mar, in the 5th year of her reign, August 16, for a fine of 100 marks let to Thomas, Earl of Northumberland, the house and scite of the late monastery of Tynemouth for 21 years, from the feast of the Annunciation, A. D. 1560, at the annual rent of 5l. 3s. 4d. Harleian MSS. No. 24. Rentale Regine Marie, p. 63, b. "North∣umbr' —Regina 16 Augusti anno quinto pro fine 100 marc' ad firmam dimisit Thome Comit' Northumbr' domum et scitum nuper monaster' de Tynemouth cum pertinen' pro 21 ann' a festo Annunc' beate Mariae Virginis quod erit in anno Domini 1560, pro annuo redditu 53l. 3s. 4d."—Rot. 77.."

A. D. 1558, Sir Thomas Hilton, Knight, occurs as captain of Tinmouth Castle
Haynes' Burleigh's State Papers, p. 220.
In Peck's Desiderata Curiosa, lib. ii. p. 15, about this time is the following account of the garrison of Tinmouth Castle:
"Tinmouth Castle, Northumberland—Master gunner, fee per diem 8d.
Inferior gunners 6— fee per diem a piece 6d.".

A. D. 1559, Sir Henry Percy, Knight, was appointed by Queen Elizabeth captain of Tinmouth Castle, on the death of Sir Thomas Hilton
Haynes' Burleigh's State Papers, p. 220, where, in a letter of the Queen's Majesty to the Duke of Norfolk, dated January 10th, 1559-60, is the following:
"Whereas we did the last sommer appoint Sir Henry Percy, Knight, upon the death of Sir — Hilton, to take the charge of Tynmouth, being a place necessary to be well garded and sene to; which he hath according to our commandment doone, having no fee nor interteynment for the same: our pleasure is that ye shall cause the same his charges to be considred and discharged, and shall assigne to hym a convenient nombre for the saffe keping therof, with such convenient interteynment, as shall be mete for the same, until furder order may be taken for the establishing thereof, in what sorte it may be kept in peace, and in what sort in warr: wherin we praye yow to confeir with such as have experience therof. And for the tithes, which in tymes past have belonged therto our meaning is, that now, when the less shall expyre at our Ladye Daye next, the same shall be letten to the kepar only of the howse from tyme to tyme and not to be dissevered from the house as it now is. The lyke also shall be with the demaynes, the less wherof we meane to have redemed for the use of the howse."
The subsequent extracts were taken from an ancient pedigree of the Percy family, pre∣served at Northumberland-House: "Henry nowe Lord Percy borne at Tynemouth 21st April 1564." (N. B. He was afterwards the 9th earl of Northumberland. See Collins's Peerage, vol. ii. p. 408, edit. 1779. He died November 5th, 1632.) "Tho∣mas son of 8th Earl Henry borne at Tynemouthe 19th March, 1505."—(He died un∣married in April, 1587. Ibid. p. 407.) "Lucye (loughter of ditto), borne at Tyne¦mouthe 18th of October 1567."—(Lady Lucy Percy married first to Sir John Wotton. Knt. and secondly to Sir Hugh Owen, of Anglesey, Knt. but died without issue.—Ibid. p. 408)..

In the year 1563, the garrison of Tinmouth Castle consisted (besides the captain) of a master-gunner, eight gunners, and eleven houshold servants
Haynes' Burleigh's State Papers, p. 397, in the establishment and charges of the east, west, and middle marches, 1563. "Tynmowthe—Henry Percye, Knt. captain there for his
Fee per annum 66l. 13s. 4d.
One annuytie for the same per ann. 33l. 6s. 8d.
One master gonner at 12d. per diem 18l. 5s. 0d.
Eight gonners at 6d. per diem each 73l. 0s. 0d.
Eleven howshold servaunts, every of them at 6l. 8s. 4d. per annum 73l. 6s. 8d.
Graunted by the Quene's Majestie that now is." Sum 264l. 11s. 8d.
The following occurs in Randall's MSS. "Louck Akome wills December 18th 1563 to be buried in the church of Tinmouth—gives to the mending of the south window of the church 20d.—To the Spettel Brig 12d.—Witness, Sir Thomas Jackson, curat."— Lib. Test. Dunelm. p. 114..

Tinmouth, which, on the attainder of the Duke of Northumberland in the reign of Queen Mary, had reverted to the crown, appears to have remained ungranted, till the tenth year of the reign of Queen Elizabeth, A. D. 1568Domina Regina fuit seisita de et in castro et manerio de Tynemouth nuper monaster. Sheles, East-Chirton, Preston, Monkseton, Whitley, Murton, Eresdon, Backworth, Wolsington, South-Dissington, Elswick, Benwell, Denton' Wylam, Hertford, Cowpon, Hauxley, Ambell, Eglingham, Bewick, Lilburn, Flatworth, Middle-Chirton, West-Chirton, Billimill, Whittingham, et Framlington." Escaet. de anno 10 Eliz. Wallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 263..

In the year 1577, Anthony Hudson occurs as vicar of Tinmouth church
Randal's MSS.
"Edw. Torotbecke, cur. not licensed Feb. 1, 1577. B. Visitation.—Ibid..
John Knightley, clerk, was appointed June 26th, 1578, on the re∣signation of A. Hudson; Queen Elizabeth patronessBarnes' Register, p. 3..
Gilbert Spence was appointed vicar in 1588, on the death of J. KnightleyLib. Testam. at Durham, p. 77..

William Robinson, A. B. succeeded, on the death of G. Spence, December 31st, 1607
Bp. James' Regist.
"November 2d, 1609. Offic' Domini contra gardianos Rob. Fife, James Rawling, Cuthbert Tailour, et Hen. Bowe—their church is in greate decaie—they want a table of the ten commandments, a register-booke in parchment, and a chieft or coffer with three locks."—Randall's MSS..

August 8th, 1628, John Heslop, A. B. minister of Tinmouth church, on the death of W. Robinson: patrons, Henry, Earl of Northumber∣land, and Sir Ralph Delavalle, KnightBp. Neil's Register, p. 56. He was ordained priest Sept. 22, 1622.—Ibid. p. 50..
June 5th, 1633, King Charles I. visited Tinmouth CastleAn entry in the Parish Register..
William Alder, A. M. occurs as minister of this church, July 24th, 1633Bishop Morton's Register..

James Hume, A. M. occurs as minister of Tinmouth, January 11th, 1637
See Walker's Sufferings of the Clergy.
Ra. Delavale, Knight, and Robert Delavale, Esq his son, hold (inter alia) in capite, a moiety of the rectory of Tinmouth.—E Rotulis Turr. Lond. 14 Car. I..

In the year 1642, Tinmouth Castle was put into a posture of de∣fence by the Earl of Newcastle, then governor of the town of New∣castle upon Tyne, who furnished 300 soldiers with arms from thence, and sent them down also six great guns. Trenches were cast up, and a fort was made at the mouth of the haven on this occasion
Parliam. History, vol. xi. p. 261. June 2d and 28th, 1642.
"Three hundred soldiers are sent down to Tinmouth Castle to guard it, and they have all arms given them out of the magazine here in this town: there is great guns going down to them, six pieces—they are casting up trenches as fast as may be: there i a fort making at the haven mouth that no ships can go in or out without their leave. The Earl of Newcastle is making sorts at Sheeles, one of each side. There is diverse of the great ordnance removed to the key-side to be sent down."—Letters from Newcastle, dated June 22d and 23d, 1642, in Lords' Journals, vol. v. p. 170..

October 27th, 1644, Tinmouth Castle, after having been besieged
for some time, surrendered to General Leven and the Scots army, when thirty-eight pieces of ordnance, and great store of arms, ammuni∣tion, and provisions, fell into the hands of the enemy. The garrison were allowed to march out with their baggage on this occasion; but they had bound themselves by the articles of capitulation, to submit to the instructions of parliament. On the preceding 19th of that month it is mentioned, that the garrison of this place had suffered so much by the plague, that the chief commanders had fled out of itParliament. History, vol. xiii. p. 326. Letter dated October 27th, 1644. It sur∣rendered late in the evening of that day.—See Grose's account..
February 3d, 1646, there was a garrison of the Scottish army in Tinmouth CastleRymer's Foedera, tom. xx. p. 553..

December 11th, 1646, Major-General Skippon was approved of by a resolution of the House of Commons, to be governor of Tinmouth Castle
Journals of Commons, vol. v. December 21st, 1644, the following proviso was desired by the Lords to be added to the order of both houses, for making Major-General Skippon governor of Newcastle, Gateside, and Tynmouth Castle, and agreed to: "Pro∣vided that this ordinance, nor any thing therein contained, shall no way prejudice the Earl of Northumberland's right, title, or interest unto the castle of Tynmouth."
He appears to have been at the same time governor of the city of Bristol..

On the 30th of January, 1647, the Scots delivered up this castle
Lords' Journals, vol. viii. p. 699.
In a letter from Major-General Skippon to the Speaker of the Peers, dated Newcastle, the 31st of January, 1647, in the morning, the following passage occurs: "I have re∣ceived an express from him whom I commanded to receive the castle of Tynmouth, that the same was fairly and quietly delivered into our possession, about six of the clock last night."
In the Journals of the Commons, vol. v. March 29th, 1647, Serjeant-Major-General Skippon is mentioned, as having been called up to the army, and ordered to depute one to take the charge of Newcastle and Tinmouth.
Ibid. vol. v. "Resolved, That the governors of Tinmouth Castle, &c. shall have for their pay 7s. as governor, and 8s. as captain.".

A. D. 1648, Sir Arthur Haslerigg occurs as governor of Tinmouth CastleJournals of the Commons, vol. viii. 11th July, 1661.. He was, at the same time, governor of Newcastle upon Tyne.
Colonel Lilburn, his deputy in the government of Tinmouth Castle, having revolted, and declared for the King, he stormed the said castle, and put all that were in arms therein to the sword. Lilburn's own head was cut off on this occasion, and set upon a pole. This event of regaining Tinmouth Castle by the parliament happened August 11th, 1648
See Rushworth's Collections, p. 4, vol. ii. p. 1226. "An express came this day to the house from Sir Arthur Haslerigg, at Newcastle, dated August 11th, 1648, giving the house an account of the revolt and storming of Tinmouth Castle, in brief thus: Wednes∣day last Lieutenant-Colonel Henry Lilburne commands most of his officers and soldiers out of the castle upon service; reserves a few, most of which of his own mind; afterwards discharges the prisoners, and calling all the soldiers together, declares for himself and King Charles; and such as did not yield hereunto were dead men. Hereupon many of the honest soldiers got over the wall; a corporal refused to yield hereunto, forthwith the lieutenant-colonel run him through. After this he sends down to Sheilds, and towns ad∣jacent, desiring such as love King Charles, to join with him for his assistance: which many did accordingly. This said news being brought presently to Newcastle, Sir Arthur Haslerigg draws out a considerable brigade of foot, and an hundred dragoons, and gives them in command to Lieutenant-Colonel Ashfield, and Major Cobham, with orders to storm the castle with expedition. They advance all night, ladders are sent after them by sea; about two in the morning they fall to work, the ladders prove too short; the lieu∣tenant colonel fires four pieces of ordnance upon the stormers; they, not discouraged, force in at the port-holes, and, after a short dispute, become possessors of the castle, and masters of the soldiers, who cry out for quarter, and then yield. Many of these within were slain; amongst the rest the perfidious governor's body was found: three of the stormers were wounded, but one slain."
In a pamphlet entitled, A Particular of the several Victories, &c. London, 4to, 1648, among the particular occasions of the thanksgiving 7th September, 1648, occurs, "the wonderful timely regaining of Tinmouth Castle, on the eleventh of this instant Au∣gust, &c."
The six prisoners mentioned in Captain Grose's account of this place, made their escape from thence about the beginning of August, 1648. They had been lately taken in Northumberland.—See Rushworth, p. 4, vol. ii. p. 1219. They escaped "through a privy built on the north side of the castle; and though the rock is very high, yet with sheets sewed together, let themselves down.".

February 5th, 1654, John Topping occurs as deputy-governor of Tinmouth Castle
Thurloe's State Papers, vol. iii. p. 138. In a letter of this Topping to Secretary Thurloe, March 17th, 1655, ibid. he says, "We have two companies in this garrison, consisting of 70 men in a company." He complains of the coldness of the situation of the castle, of the sickness of his soldiers, and requests a greater number of men.
In the same work, vol. v. p. 572, occurs the following article concerning the informa∣tion of the Lady Hall, November 7th, 1656.—"She saith that Tinmouth Castle was to be betrayed to the use of Charles Stewart, and that Major Towlehurst had had conference with one Marley, an agent from Charles Stewart, for that purpose: and that Mr. Cla∣vering, and Adam Shipperdson was to contrive a way from the colepitts, about two miles from the castle, under ground, into the castle of Tinmouth, for to relieve the enemy with provisions, if need required: and for that purpose there was great store of provisions laid in, and to be laid into Hebburn-House: and that there was 80 firelocks, and a great num∣ber of stilttoes laid into Fellon-House; but now both the provisions and the arms are removed she knows not whither."
The following inscription is barely legible on a flat stone, in the burial-ground within Tinmouth Castle: "Here lieth the body of Prudence, late wife of John Topping, some years governor of this castle, who departed this life in child-bearing, February 19th, 1658; also four of their children, Ellinor, Richard, and a sonne still-borne, with a child who was interred with her, February 21st, 1658.".
A. D, 1657, Thomas Lupton was pastor at SheildsSions himself so in an address of the ministers of Durham and Northumberland, to the protector, of that date.—Thurloe's State Papers, vol. vi. p. 431..
Before the restoration one Gordon was minister of the church at TinmouthRandall's MSS..

About the beginning of December, 1659, the soldiers of the garrison at Tinmouth Castle having been drawn into a chapel, there to sign an engagement to stand by the Lord Lambert, and his party, a part thereof fell in and killed five or six of themMercinius Britannicus, No. 5, p. 46, by an officer of the parliament's army in Scot∣lands this number, "from Friday, December 23d, to Tuesday, January 3d, 1660." The writer adds: "Certainly the villainy and inforcement of such treacheries as these, not only upon the liberties and privileges of a freeborn people, but likewise upon their estates and conferences, did never go far or continue long, without being overtaken by the certain hand of divine judgment. It hath sadly begun in the North unto them, &c.".
This account breathes the true spirit of those superstitious times.
In the year 1660, Sir Arthur Haslerigg surrendered his government of Tinmouth Castle to General MonkLords' Journals, vol. ii. p. 293..

Henry Ashburnham, clerk, was instituted to the vicarage of Tin∣mouth, October 29th, 1662: Algernon, Earl of Northumberland, patronNeil's Register, p. 107. Ordained deacon August 17th, and priest September 21st, 1662..

The common-council of Newcastle voted 200l. towards the repara∣tion of the works of Tinmouth Castle, in consequence of a letter they received from King Charles II. dated 1665, May 25th, informing them, that Colonel Edward Villiers, governor of Tinmouth Castle, had been directed to repair the said castle, on account of the Dutch war, and to protect the trade and port of Tyne; promising them sufficient convoys for the coal trade, notwithstanding the necessities of war, and recommending it to them at the same time to lend their as∣sistance on this occasion
Common-council books, June 28th, 1665. The King's letter is there copied at full length. In the governor's house remain the Villiers' arms—they are over the gateway, though now almost defaced—"argent on a cross gules 5 escallops of the field, crest a lion rampant—the date of 1676 is on the spouts."
An escutcheon, of the date of 1646, is still preserved in this house—" or, a chevron gules between three sheaves gules, crest a boar's head, helmet facing the spectator, like that of a baronet.".

The old church within the castle of Tinmouth was used for divine service by the inhabitants of that parish, till the year 1668Ecarta penes P. Boulby., when a new church then but just completed, though it had been begun A. D. 1659In the common-council books of Newcastle, August, 1659, a petition from Tin∣mouth parish, for a collection to help them to build their church, is mentioned., was consecratedThis new church and church-yard were consecrated on Sunday, July 5th, 1668, by the name of Christ-Church:" In longitudine ab orientali plaga ad occidental' 71 pedes & 6 pollices et a boreali plaga ad australem totidem et in latitudine 24 pedes."—Dr. E∣lison's MSS. by John, Bishop of Durham. The style of the architecture of this building (which stands near the flexure of the road to North-Sheilds) resembling that of a Presbyterian meeting-house,
sufficiently marks it to have been undertaken before the resto∣ration
Mention occurs that the old church in the castle was at this time so ruinous, especially at the east end, and in such danger of falling, that without extraordinary cost it could not be repaired for the use of the garrison; so that the said bishop was petitioned to grant his licence to pull down the east end of the old church, that a less chapel at the west end might be fitted up for their service. This appears to have been done: several tombstones still remain in this place, which at present has no roof.
On the above occasion cross stones appear to have been put in, intersecting the ancient windows, as at Brinkburn-Abbey. It is observable too, that the fine ornaments of the great western door-way have been filled up with lime, and plaistered over. On two altar tombs of blue marble, in the part that has been the chancel, are the two following in∣scriptions:
"Here lieth the body of Henry Reay, Esq merchant, alderman, and twice mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne, who died October 18th, 1734, aged 63. He was a magistrate able, generous, and of a truly public spirit of religion; A zealous advocate and defender of the Church of England, and those that wait at its altar: a sincere friend and understanding patron. In the various institutions of public charity a prudent director, and munificent benefactor. Of exact integrity in commerce, humanity to strangers, civility to acquaintance, and generosity to all."
"Here lieth interred the body of Utrick Reay, son and heir of Henry Reay, Esq alderman of Newcastle upon Tyne. He was endowed with all those amiable and social qualities which cause men to be beloved when living, lamented when dead. By his wife Bridget, daughter of Henry Blencow, of Blencow-Hall, in the county of Cumberland, Esq he had issue three children, Philadelphia, who died before him, April 4th, 1736, in the 1st year of her age; Hannah and Utrick, who survived him: He died April 10th, 1742, in the 31st year of his age. Here also lieth buried Utrick Reay, his son, who died March 4th, 1744, in the 7th year of his age. To whose memory this monument was erected, by the forenamed Bridget Reay.".
Thomas Dockwray occurs as vicar of Tinmouth, 1671Randall's MSS..

Stephen Dockwray, A. M. was presented, July 20th, 1672, on the death of Thomas Dockwray, S. T. P.
Ibid. He was instituted February 10th, 1673. A mandate the same day to induct. Patrons, the Earl of Essex and William Peirrepoint, Esq
A. D. 1673, Hollar engraved a view of Tinmouth Castle, town, and shipping, with the wrecks of Captains Vicars and Grey, &c.
There is a small engraving of Tinmouth Castle, among Fairfax's Views, done about the time of the great rebellion.
Thoresby, in his Ducatus Leodensis, mentions a view of the Castle and Light-house of Tinmouth, from the north, by F. Place.

A. D. 1674, arms were borrowed from Tinmouth Castle, for the use of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne"Common-council books. "August 8th, 1674, armes borrowed of Tinemouth Castle, for which the towne lately gave a note for redelivery. Ordered, That a letter be writ to his Grace the Duke of Newcastle, for getting in the said note, and freeing the towne of and from the same.".
Thomas Dockwray was appointed to the vicarage of Tinmouth, on the death of S. DockwrayRandall's MSS..
"James Fitz James, natural son of King James II. was by him created Earl of Tinmouth at the same time (viz. in 1688) that he made him Duke of BerwickMoll's England and Wales, folio, page 336.."

A. D. 1691, the establishment of the King's garrison at Tinmouth Castle appears to have been rated at 474l. 10s. per annum
Journals of Commons, vol. x. p. 565. 28th November, 1691.
The following occurs, ibid in the particular payments charged by the Earl of Ranelagh, as paid to the garrisons, in the abstract of his receipts and payments, from the 5th of November, 1688, to 29th of September, 1690.
"To Tinmouth and Clifford's Fort, 720l. 8s.".

August 18th, 1707, died Henry Villiers, Esq only brother of the
Earl of Jersey, and Governor of Tinmouth Castle. He was ap∣pointed to this command about the year 1687
Epitaph on a stone in the priory church-yard:
Hìc sitae sunt mortales reliquiae
Henrici Villiers, armigeri,
Stirpe antiqua prognati,
unici
Honoratissimi Comitis de Jersey
fratris,
Nec non hujus presidii
circiter 20 annos
Fidelis et perquam dilecti
Praefecti.
Vixit annos 49. Obiit 18 Aug.
Anno Domini 1707.".

February 8th, 1715, Algernon, Earl Hertford, who had been ap∣pointed governor of Tinmouth Castle and Clifford's Fort, by Queen Anne, for his signal services, was continued in those governments by King George I.
Collins' Peerage, ed. 1779, vol ii. p. 472.
December 2d, 1748, on the death of his father he succeeded to the titles of Duke of Somerset, &c. &c. &c.

In the year 1717, the establishment of the garrison at Tinmouth Castle was rated at 573l. 15s. per annum
Journals of Commons, vol. xviii. 2 Decembris, 1717.
s. d.
l. s.
"Tynmouth Castle The governor 16 5¼ per diem 300 0 per ann.
Lieutenant-governor 10 0 182 10
One master gunner 2
36 10
Three other gunners, each 12d 3
54 15
£ 1 11 5
£573 15
Regulation of fire and candle Tynmouth Castle, 18l."
The expences of Clifford's Fort near Tinmouth occur ibid.
s. d.
l. s.
"One master-gunner 2 0 per diem. 36 10 for 365 days.
Four other gunners, each 12d 4 0 73
6 0
£. 109 10."
.
A. D. 1722, John Potter occurs as vicar of Tinmouth; he resigned the same year—succeeded by Leonard DarantRandall's MSS..

December, 1722, Henry Villiers, Esq was appointed lieutenant-governor of Tinmouth Castle, in the room of Colonel Sabene, de∣ceased
He died in May, 1753.
October 11th, 1727, Mr. William Raper occurs as his majesty's store-keeper at Tin∣mouth Castle and Clifford's Fort.—Newcastle Courant..

A. D. 1740, Charles Ward occurs as vicar of TinmouthRandall's MSS. March, 9th, 1740, the church of Tinmouth was robbed of three surplices, a pulpit cushion of crimson velvet with gold tassels, a black silk hood, &c..

January 13th, 1746, a vessel arrived in the port of Tyne from Dover, with nine brass and three iron guns, and also a great quantity of stores for the garrison of Tinmouth Castle
Newcastle Courant.
A view of this castle and haven, drawn by T. Smith, was engraved by Vivares, 1747.— Gough's British Topography, vol. ii. p. 66.
There was a "north view of the monastery and castle by Buck." Ibid..
Emanuel Potter, A. B. was inducted to the vicarage of TinmouthRandall's MSS., June 6th, 1749.

A. D. 1758, new batteries appear to have been erected at Tin∣mouth Castle
Newcastle Courant.
"A view of the castle-gate, by Grose and Godfrey, 1773.
"The priory and castle, two views by Grose—1773—Also one of the Munkstone, an ancient cross, by Grose and Drawensa, 1774." Gough, ut supra, vol. ii. p. 66..

July 20th, 1774, Hugh Brown occurs as afternoon lecturer of Tinmouth parish
Bishop's Visitation.—He died Dec. 2d, 1775, aged 64.
Succeeded by — Thompson.
— Haswell about January, 1778..

July 15th, 1775, a temporary light-house is mentioned to have been begun in Tinmouth Castle, in order to rebuild the old one in a more commodious manner. This has been since completed
Newcastle Courant.
In Hutchinson's View of Northumberland, vol. ii. 1776, is a north-west view of Tin∣mouth. W. Hutchinson del. I. Bailey, sculp..

In the year 1778, Lord Adam Gordon was appointed governor of Tinmouth Castle
London Papers, April, 9, 1778.
The following occurs in the London Gazette: "War-Office, February 27th, 1779. Colonel Spencer Cowper, lieutenant-governor of Tinmouth Castle."
I made the subsequent observations on a visit to the remains of this place, June 20th, 1780.
In the ruins of Tinmouth monastery there are still observable three recesses in the south wall, near the entrance to the oratory of St. Mary; one is said to have been the confessional chair, divided by a stone partition, where there has been anciently a grate.—Another of them has evidently been the cavity for containing the holy water, and the third the closet for the consecrated host.—It is remarkable that the capitals of the columns have each of them a different kind of ornament.
The oratory of St. Mary has been cleaned out by order of the governor, and shut up to preserve it from future desecrations.
On the outside of this oratory, are cut in a sort of blue stone, different from the rest, now almost defaced by time and the fret of the sea, the arms of Tinmouth priory, viz. gules, three crowns or: those of the abbey of St. Albans, i. e. azure, a cross saltire or, as used at present by the borough of St. Albans; and in the middle the common Greek abbreviation of the name of Jesus, erroneously interpreted Jesus hominum salvator— for it consists of a Greek ota, epsilon and sigma.—The arms of Tinmouth priory were originally those of Oswin, King of Northumberland.—See Miscellaneous Antiquities, (plate of,) No. 1.
Among the ruins in the west part of the church, is a pillar of the very rudest Saxon architecture, which has probably been a part of the original building. On the south side of the grand entrance to the church is a Saxon arch with a Gothic capital.
I observed a whimsical anachronism in sculpture on an upright stone in the priory church∣yard, where in the crest of the shipwright's arms Noah's ark is pierced for guns, and has a quarter-deck. "The 30th of February" occurs on a grave-stone. In an inscription on a stone covering the remains of a child of five years of age, the infant (for want of proper pointing) is plainly made to have a wife and child. A person of the same name with Baronet Liddell has taken the arms of that family upon his tomb-stone, forgetting to omit the hand, gules, of Ulster.—The following quaint inscription occurs, ibid.
"John Grant died April, 1779.
God did call and he is gone
When Death doth come he spareth noe
To his wife and children was good and just
And to his family was one of the best
And to his kindred kind withal
Which makes them to lament his call."
I read also the following: "In memory of Robert Smith, Esq late captain-lieutenant in the Royal South Lincoln militia, who departed this life January 11th, 1781, aged 46 years"—"In memory of Sarah, daughter of the Rev. Mr. Potter, vicar of Tynemouth, who departed this life January 1st, 1769, aged 15 years. "O happy probationer, accepted without being exercised!"
—"Here lieth the body of the Rev. Hugh Browne, lecturer of Tynemouth, who de∣parted this life Decr. 2d, 1775, aged 64.—Hugh, son of the above, died March 13th, 1763, aged 11.".

About the year 1783, Government resumed the possession of Tin∣mouth castle for a place of arms and depository of stores, for the better protection of the port of Tyne, and of the adjacent coasts of Durham and Northumberland
Newcastle Courant, Sept. 28, 1782.—Ibid. October 19th, 1782, is the following: "Saturday last a company of the Royal Artillery, with ten fine brass field pieces, four howit∣zers, and twenty-three ammunition waggons, arrived here from Woolwich."—"Last week were begun the intended works for the defence of this harbour at Tinmouth, which will be completed with all possible expedition: and as soon as a proper arsenal can be prepared, the above cannon, stores, &c. are to proceed thither to be in readiness in case of any emergency to act on any part of the coast."
It was on this occasion that Major Durnford discovered the stones with Roman inscrip∣tions, buried here in the foundation of the ancient church, the beautiful ruins of which, it is probable, the alterations of half a century more will entirely remove.
The subsequent notes occur in Randall's MSS. concerning the vicarage of Tinmouth. "Church dedicated to St. Mary and St. Oswine:
"Vicarius solvit archidiacono Northumbriae ad annual' fest' Paschae summam 10 solid. et ad annuale fest' Sancti Michael' archangel' summam 11 solid. nomine et loco procura∣num et synodalium pro dicta ecclesia de Tynmouth.
Clear yearly value 41l. 18s. d.—yearly tenths 2l. 9s. 11¼d—Bishop's procuration money 14s.—Archdeacon's procuration 12s. Pri' Tinmouth. propi'.
Tinmouth vicarage
Earsden chapel
Plth chapel
Seaton Delaval chapl.— N. B▪ In the Tinmouth Chartelary is a presentation of Wil∣liam de Whitby, chaplain to the chapel of Seaton Delaval, by Robert Lord of the vill of Seaton Dlval—dated at that place the nones of May, 1352 —It begi, "Reverend religionis viis dominis priori & conventi de Tynemouth, &c." fol. 175, b. Ibid. fol. 16, there is a presentation o Richard de Burndon by the same to the same, dated "12 alend Junii 1333." Leonard Hall occurs as curate 1 Feb. 1577 Bishop's Visitation—Diding¦ton chapel—John Syn, son occurs as curate, Feb. 1, 1577.—Ibid. Patrons, Hugh Duke of Northumberland 1 turn Sir Francis (John) Delaval 2 turns."
Among the fee-farm rents received, 1783, by John Widdrington, Esq for an alms-house in the city of Bristol, occur the following:
"9l. 0s. 8d. for the mill called Tinmouth-Mill received of the Duke of Northumber∣land: 5l. 15s. for the rectory and church of Tinmouth received of (late) Francis Blake Delavall, Esq"
The village of Tinmouth is at present a place of genteel resort for sea-bathing during the summer season, for which purpose the recess called Priors-Haven, on the south side of the castle, is exceedingly well adapted. The usual morning walk of the company is among the extensive and venerable remains of this castle and monastery, where visitants of taste will not forbear to exclaim, in the language of Shakespear,
— "O, it pities us
To see these antique towers and hallow'd walls
Split with the winter's frost or mouldering down,
Their very ruins ruin'd: the crush'd pavement,
Time's marble register, deep o'ergrown
With hemlock or rank fumitory, hides,
Together with their perishable mould,
The brave man's trophies and the good man's praise,
Envying the worth of buried ancestry!"
See in the plate of Miscellaneous Antiquities, No. 1, a sketch which I made on an ad∣jacent grave-stone of the east-end of the ruins of Tinmouth monastery, with the oratory of St. Mary, and below some of the inside ornaments..
January 18th, 1788, the new peal of bells in the lately erected steeple of Tinmouth church, were rung for the first time in honour of the Queen's birth-day. The steeple was built by subscription.

DIV2.HEAD:
HISTORY OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE AS A CORPORATE TOWN, OR BOROUGH
For the etymology of the word borough, consult Junii Etymon Anglic. in verbo, Brady on Boroughs, p. 1. Also Menage's French Dictionary, in verbo.
Brady tells us that Isaac Casaubon, in his Commentaries on Strabo and others, will have the Greek and the Latin Burgus to be the same, and the latter derived from the former, and so to signify a tower, a castle, or city. He adds, that the Thracians and Macedonians pronounced the word instead of ..
DIV2.P:
THE site of the modern Newcastle upon TyneOr, more strictly speaking, the site of part of it, for, as the adage tells us of Rome, our town in its present extent was certainly not erected all at one time, but has been the work of different periods., covered by a station, town or fortress, and noted by whatever name, for it seems frequently to have changed its title"Ad Murum—Pons Alii—Moncaster—or Mountcaster," previous to its present ap∣pellation., had probably, as I have shewn elsewhere in this work, been distinguished from the common banks of our river long before the year of Christ 653, when it occurs in history as that of a royal villa, with the appellation of "Ad Murum
See Bede's Church History, where it is styled "Ad Murum, regia villa industris."
Bishop Kenne, in the Glossary to his Parochial Antiquities, tells us that "villa regia" was a title given to those country villages where the ings of England had a royal seat and held the manor in their own demesne."—See Historical Events.," and one of the residences of our Northumbrian kings.

It appears to have been held afterwards under the royal commission as parcel of Northumberland, by the earls of the countySee ibid. an extract from a MS. in the Exchequer of Durham, shewing that New∣castle, whe called Monhester, belonged to the earls of Northumberland., from the time that great district ceased to be a separate kingdom, till on the erection of a new fort, or rather on the enlargement of its old one, soon after the Norman conquest, it gave foundation to a borough of
very early importance, and which has successively, by the charters of our several princes, been favoured in common with other incorporated towns, with various privileges and immunities.

It occurs as the property of the crown"Of such places styled interchangeably cities, towns, and burghs, the King possessed some as by ancient right, as part of the original inheritance of his crown; others by ancient escheat, in contradistinction to which the former were called the ancient demesne of the crown."—Madox's Firma Burgi, p. 5., and with the name it still retains, in the time of William Rufus, who after he had finished the castle (a stupendous pile, probably begun by his father, and intended to be both a check to, and an asylum against, the Scottish incursions), gave the circumjacent ground
Our authentic and laborious annalist Hardyng (in his Chronicle, written in metre about the time of Edward the Fourth, at a very early period of our language, and where, as we need hardly look for poetry, if we find not truth we find nothing) tells us with a circumstantial minuteness that must have been founded on authorities, which time or ac∣cident has since destroyed, speaking of William the Second,
"He buylded the Newcastell upon Tyne
The Scottes to gaynstande and to defende
And dwell therin, the people to enclyne
The towne to builde and walle as did append
He gave them ground and golde ful great to spend
To buylde it well and walle it all aboute
And fraunchised theim y to paye a free rente out z." Adding that, out of the Archbishop's rents and fruits; as also those of the bishops of Win∣chester and Sarum, and out of the revenues of nine abbies, he built "Westminster-Hall And the castel of Newcastell withall."
A strong presumptive argument to prove the truth of the above account is, that in a charter to the town of Newcastle, dated in the beginning of the reign of King John, the rent payable from that town to the crown is styled an "ancient fee-farm." See after∣wards A. D. 1200-1201.
Hardyng was brought up in the family of the Earl of Northumberland.
"It wants not probability, though it manifestly appears not," says Brady, "that Wil∣liam Rufus, Henry I. and King Stephen, being all usurpers, granted large immunities to burghs to secure them to their party."—Treatise on Boroughs, p. 18, folio. to the neighbouring inhabitants, whom he is said to have invited to settle here, and build and fortify a new and more extensive town.

In those barbarous times, and its then hostile situation, the fear of danger and hope of security would equally contribute to the speedy enlargement of this place, which that monarch is said to have first converted into a borough, and demised to its own burgesses y at a certain annual
"By fee-farm is meant perpetual ferm or rent. In ancient time, both in England and France, ferm signified rent;—for ever since feodum, fee, was by usage in England applied to signify a perpetual estate, or inheritance in land, it hath been also used to sig∣nify perpetuity in an office, and in a rent or ferm: thus perpetual ferms are fee-farms."— Madox's Firma Burgi, p. 3.
"When a town was put to fee-farm, the tenure of it was burgage; as well particular burgage tenements lying in the town, as also the town itself, were said to be so holden." Ibid. p. 21.
"This scheme of forming a new power and revenue out of towns or cities, produced a double advantage to both prince and people; for whilst it tended to weaken feudal tenures, it gave at the same time, as it were, a beginning to the commerce of these towns, the inhabitants whereof agreed to pay an annual rent or fine to the crown, in considera∣tion of their being endowed with sundry privileges which protected them from the most arbitrary power of the feudal lords or barons." Anderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 90. fee-farm z.

At this period commences what may be properly called the history of Newcastle upon Tyne, as a borough or incorporated town
"The word town is now become a generical term, comprehending under it the several species of cities, boroughs, and common towns.—A city is a town incorporated, which is, or hath been, the see of a bishop: and though the bishoprick be dissolved, as at Westminster, yet still it remaineth a city. A borough is now understood to be a town, either corporate or not, that sendeth burgesses to parliament. Other towns there are which are neither cities nor boroughs, some of which have the privilege of markets, and others not."—Blackstone's Comment. vol. i. p. 114. 8vo.
"In England cities have been styled in records either civitas, or villa, or villata,indiffer∣ently; towns and boroughs, either burgum and burgus, or villa, or villata, indifferently; the citizens of a city, either cives, homines, or burgenses; and the men of a borough, either homines or burgenses."—"The terms citizens and burgesses were in effect syno∣nimous, as well in England as likewise in many parts of France."—Madox's Firma Burgi, p. 2, 3. He proves his assertions by several quotations from ancient books of un∣questionable authority..

King Henry the First appears to have granted laws
Du , that the chief things which constituted a community, were a maior, of dermen, a holy, society, fraternity, or common-counsell, out of which they w e chose. A belfry and bell to call them together at publick meetings, common sed jurisdiction —See Brady on Burghs, p. 18, folio.
From the entries in the common-council books of Newcastle upon Tyne, the orporation of that town appear to have repaired the steeple of St. Nicholas' church, which contains the common ll, that convenes the burgesses to their courts of guild, &c. to which mtings there are no other summons.—See account of that church., customs and privileges to this infant community
" sui et contuetudines quas Henricus Rex concessit burgensibus suis de . cet naniare rusticos et rure habitantes infra suum forum et extra, infra extra sine licentia prepositi, nisi ad com' venerint et nisi sint in exercitu vel in custodia castell' sed non licet alicui burgensi namiare alium sine licentia data a pre∣posito. Si burgensis villano vel alio aliquid adereditaverit infra burgum loquele que in burgo moventur ibidem tractentur preter illas que corone Regis sunt. Si burgensis calumpniatus fuerit non extra burgum placitabitur nisi pro defectu curie nec debet re∣spondere de appellaione sine die & termino nisi prius incidat in stultam responsionem et nisi de ill' que corone Regis sunt et nisi coram justic' itinerantibus. Si navis appli∣cuerit apud Tynemouth que non abire voluerit consilio burgens' potest quilibet emere mercem de illa nave. Si placitum motum fuerit inter burgenses et mercatorem itine∣rantem infra terciam maris fluxionem rectum inter se faciant. Mercandise que per mare burgo adportantur ad terram portari debent preter salem et allec' que in nave debent vendi. Quicunque in rgo terram tenuerit uno anno et una die juste et sine calumpnia et calumpniator infra regnum fuerit, non debet calumpnianti respondere. Si vero calump∣niator puer sit non habens aetatem placitandi ei respondeat. Si burgensis habeat filium i domo sua ad mensam suam silius ejus eandem habeat libertatem quam et pater suus.
Si villanus veniat ad burgum manere et uno anno et una die terram in burgo tenuerit sine prolocutione domini sui vel propria ad aliquem terminum remaneat in burgo sicut burgensis. Nullus forinsecus debet emere panum ad tingendum nisi sit de consuetudine burgi. Quilibet burgensis terram suam vendat et ire quo voluerit nisi terra illa fuerit in calumpnia. Si quis burgensis de loquela unde bellum debet surgere appelltur ab aliquo villano vel e habitante per legem quam habet in sua consuetudine se defendat, nisi de scelere tali appelletur pro quo recte debeat pugnae, nec burgensis debet contra villanum pugnare nisi ante calumpnia de burgagio exiit. Item mercatori forinseco non licet emere nec in foo nec apud us, nec lanam, nec coia nec cetera. Item fotisfactum burgens' erga prepositum debet ese commune. Item in burgo non debet dai nec mer∣cht, nec heriet, nec blodwyt, nec stensvit. Item quisque burgensis potest habere fur∣num et molendinum. Item si quis de parte vel cerevis' vendit in sori factum ceedre erga prepositum: prepositus sic se intromittat si bis forisfecerit det forisfactum, si ter foris∣fecerit communi consilio burgensium puniatur. Nullus forinsecus potest findere piscem ad vendendum. Item burgensis potest bladum suum ducere ex patria sine licentia quo volu∣erit."— From an ancient register, on parchment, of the possessions of the Percy family, preserved at Northumberland-House, fol. 125, b.—See a translation of the above in a note on the free customs of the corporation of Newcastle..

In this reign also, we have a curious account of the receipt of tolls at Newcastle upon Tyne
"De tallio dando et accipiendo apud Novum Castrum tempore Henrici Regis. Hec suit consuetudo. De quadrig' cum bobus 4d. De quadriga caballaria 2d. De trussel in fella 1d. De trussel retro sellam ob. De tymbr' de gupill' vel martinis vel sab∣lin' vel beverin' 4d. De dacre pell' caprinar' 1d. De tymbr' de scurell' ob. De sulcitra 1d. De sussino ob. De vitlo ¼. De vacca ob. De equo vend' 1d. De equo transeunt' ob. De celdra bladi vel farine vel salis 1d. De dimid' celdr' ob. De lasto coriorum 8d. Si vendatur per dacres de unaquaque dacre 1d. De decem porcis vel ovibus vel capris 1d. De quinque singulorum ob. De trussl cordelato 4d. De trussl brocato 1d. De nave culata 4d. si vend' infra villam vel veniat in villam. De nave non culata 1d. De quolibet mercante piscem et super equum portante 1d. Persone ec∣clesiarum, barones et milites sint quieti de tollonio sue monse et nullu alius. De qua∣drig' plumbi 4d. De millear' alle' 1d. De quolibet cum burgensi cue et redeute cum catall' suis 4d."
This follows: "Hec consuetudo suit tempore Rand' Episcopi et Galfrid' Episcopi et Will' Episcopi. De pisa sepi vel uncti 1d. De wayda supra equum 1d. De bundo pel∣um 1d. De unguibus super equum 1d. De carca de alum vel de pipee vel gingib' vel similibus 4d."—Ut supra, register on parchment preserved at Northumberland-House..

Newcastle upon Tyne appears to have been the residence of David, King of ScotsSee Historical Events under A. D. 1201., during a great part, if not the whole, of the reign of Stephen. He is proved to have given away lands, and is said to have founded religious houses at this place, where also he fabricated his code of borough lawsSee the Regiam Majestatem..

Henry II. granted a charter to the burgesses of Newcastle
See charter of King John, dated 9th February, in the second year of his reign. I find the subsequent entry in a book of inolments of charters, &. in the archives of the cor∣poration of Newcastle.
Han primus vel secundus incertum Concessit burgensibus suis de Novo Castello qui taniam de the∣olonio, &c." Fol. 33., the first of which mention occurs in our public records, exempting them
from the payment of toll, passagePassage signifies the hire that a man pays for being transported over sea, or over any river.—Blount in verbo., pontagePontage is a contribution towards the maintenance or re-edifying of bridges, and may also signify toll taken to this purpose of those that pass over them., hanse-duty
Hansa vel ansa, pensitatio pro mercibus exsolvi solita.—Dufresne's Glossary.
In the year 1168, the burgesses of Newcastle were fined an hundred marks for compel∣ling a knight to swear, which was an infringement of the then laws of honour: but the sum was remitted them for their services in the King's castle, or other fortifications of the town.—Madox's History of the Exchequer, p. 388, folio edit. "De Placitis Ricardi de Luci: Burgenses Novi Castelli reddunt compotum de 20 marcis quia coegerunt mili∣tem jurare: in operatione eadem (viz. Novi Castelli) liberaverunt et Q S."—Mag. Rot. 14 Hen. II. Rot. 11, a, Northumbr'., and of every other impost for goods, which they could ascertain to be their own in any part of his dominions. I find no account of any charter of Richard I. to Newcastle upon Tyne
The following is an extract from the Chartulary of Tinmouth monastery at North∣umberland-House, fol. 147. "Inquisitio infra burgum Novi Castelli.
"Burgenses Novi Castelli dicunt quod infra burgum nullum est tenementum sic datum vel alienatum a Domino Rege a servicio excepto redditu 4 marc' de quadam terra quam Dominus Rex Ricardus dedit Sewallo fil' Henrici et post obitum ipsius Sewalli dictus Rex Ricardus eandem terram commisit Philippo de Ulecotes quamdiu placuerit Domino Regi.".

King John, by his charter dated February 7th, 1201
"Carta de anno secundo Johannis Regis, No. 14.
"Johannes Dei gratia &c. Scratis nos liberasse ad sirmam burgensibus nostris de Novo Castello super Tynam villam de Novo Castello super Tynam cum pertinen' pro sexagint' libi' numero que reddere solebant antiquitus o quinquagint' libi' numeroLibra ad numerum (I suppose 'numero' here must mean the same) says Kennet, in the Glossary to his Parochial Antiquities, signifies a pound in ready money opposed to libra ursa et pnsitata, a pound weight in solid metal."—"Sterling money," says the same learned writer, "seems to be that sort of com which for metal and value was to be a common standard of all current money." habenda et tenenda quamdiu nobis bene servierint et firmam suam bene reddiderint Hanc autem fir∣mam reddent per manumMadox, in his History of the Exchequer, tells us, "the town, burghs & villares of England, which were in the hands of the King, were commonly let to form, and the form of them were answered to the crown either by the sheriff of the county, wherein the town , a included in the is comitan, o as superadded to it; or else by the townsmen themselves p manun sm, either by the name of homine, cves, o burgenses of such a town, burgh or villate, under the name of the provost, or other particular ustos or erm." Page 226, folio edition." suam ad duoIn the King's Exchequer there still continued the distinctions of the two notable terms of the year, called the 'duo scaccaa'.—Madox's History of the Exchequer, p. 54, folio edit. from the end of King John's reign to that of Edward the Second. scacc' nostra, scilicet ad scacc' Sancti Michaelis triginta libr' et ad scacc' Pasch' triginta libr' Et preterea reddent ad scaccarium nostrum per manum suam ad eosdem terminos de escaet' ejusdem ville subscriptis centum et decem solid' et sex denar' scilicet ad scaccarium Sancti Michaelis quinquaginta quinque solid' et tres denar' scilicet quinquaginta et unum solid' et obol' de terra quam moniales de eadem villa habent de dono David Regis, et triginta et novem solid' et quinque denar' de terra quam hospitalarii habent de dono ejusdem David et viginti solid' et obol' de terra que fuit Gervasii Medici quam habuit de dono ejusdem Regis. T. Hug' Barde apud Alnewic 7 die Feb. Convenit cum recordo Johannes Boroughe."— Murray MS.
The above eschaets had probably fallen into the crown, as having been the donations of an usurper, on whose removal they had reverted to their true owner the King., raised the fee-farm of Newcastle from the sum of 50l. to that of 60l. sterling, and charged the burgesses of that town with the payment of certain eschaets there, to the yearly value of an hundred and ten shillings and six-pence. It is observable that 50l. is called in this charter the ancient o fee-farm of Newcastle.

By a charter dated at Newcastle 9th of February, 1201Johannes Dei gratia, &c. Sciatis nos concessisse et presenti carta confirmasse burgen∣sibus nostris de Novo Castello super Tinam et omnibus eorum rebus quas ipsi poterint assecurare suas esse dominicas, quietanciam de theolonio et passagio et pontagio et de ansa et de omnibus aliis consuetudinibus per totam terram nostram et prohibemus ne quis eos inde vexet vel disturbet super forisfactra nostra sicut carta Henrici Regis patris nostri rationabiliter testatur. Testibus Ricardo Sancti Andree Episcopo Willielmo de Statovil Hugone Bart. Roberto filio Rogeri Willielmo Bruer &c. Datum per manum Henrici Wellin' archidiaconi apud Novum Castellum super Tinam nono die Februar' anno regni nostro secundo."—From a copy remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle collated with the original in the Tower of London, by N. Punshon, Esq under sheriff of Newcastle., King John confirmed to the burgesses of that town, the before-mentioned charter of his father, King Henry the Second.

There is another charter of the same king preserved in the Tower of London, dated at Newcastle, February 9th, 1201
Chart' de anno regni Regis Johannis secundo, m. 12, n. 16.
"Carta burgensium Novi Castelli super Tinam. Johannes Dei gratia &c. Sciatis nos liberasse ad firmam burgensibus nostris de Novo Castello super Tinam villam de Novo Castello super Tynam cum pertinen' pro LX. libr' sterling numero quam solebat reddere antiquitus quinquagint libr' numero habend' et tenend' quamdiu nobis bene servierint et firmam suam bene reddiderint. Hanc autem firmam sexagint' librar' reddent ad duo scacc' nostra scilicet ad scacc' Sancti Michaelis 30 lib. et ad scacc' Pasch' 30 lib'. T. Willielmo Briwer apud Novum Castel super Tinam 9 die Febr'." (This is a true copy from the original record remaining in the Tower of London, having been examined. Robert Lemon, clerk in the Record-Office.), to the same pur∣port
with that of the 7th of that month, only we read here sixty pounds sterling in number.

In the year 1201, the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne were sined an hundred marks and two palfreys, for the privilege of holding the town in their own hands by ancient farm, and for the confirma∣tion of the liberties granted them by the charter of King Henry the Second: the King afterwards ordered by writ, that without the bur∣gesses answering in person, the sheriff of Northumberland should ac∣count for their farm as he had done before it was augmented from 50l. to 60l.
"Homines de Novo Castello super Tinam (debent) 100 marcas et 2 palefridos pro h∣benda villa de Novo Castello super Tinam in manu sua per veterem sirmam scilicet 50 lbt 10 libras de cremento: et pro habenda confirmatione de libertatibus suis quas habent per cartam H. Regis patis. Sed postea mandatum est per breve Regis quod estn sorulo Marcalli quod nec predicta firma neque crementum ab eis exigatur: quia Rex concessit vicecomiti ut respondeat de firma ejusdem ville sicut consuevit antequam cre∣mentum esset positum."—Mag. Rot. 3 Johannis. Rot. 18. a, Northumbr'.
"Many towns and persons," says Madox, History of Exchequer, p. 275, folio, "at ratione times in the reigns of King Richard I. and King John, were fined in various sum for grants and confirmations of divers sorts of liberties, franchises and exemptions."

This year also the said burgesses gave forty marks and two palfreys for the King's welcome, probably as a present on his arrival at New∣castle"Homines de Novo Castello super Tinam reddunt compotum de 40 marcis et 2 pale∣sridis pro bono adventu Regis."—Mag. Rot. 3. l. Rot. 18. a, Northumbr. Tit. Nova Oblata.—Ibid p. 35..

In the year 1202, the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, in com∣mon with several other towns in the kingdom, amerced in different sums according to their respective abilities, paid a sine of twenty marks for the liberty of buying and selling dyed cloth
"Homines de Novo Castello super Tinam reddunt compotum de 25 marcis ut possint liberè emere et vendere pannos, sicut solebant tempore Regis Henrici; in Th. l. et Q. S."—Mag. Rot. 4 Johann. Rot. 14, b.
Ibid. p. 324, he translates "pannos" dyed cloth., a privilege they had
enjoyed in the reign of one or other of the preceding HenriesHenry I. See before.. This was not for foreign but British clothSee an ordinance of Edward I. A. D. 1284.. The art of manufacturing woollen cloth, which had arrived to a great height during the reigns of Henry II. and Richard I. was, during the wars in the reigns of John, Henry III. and Edward I. and II. almost entirely lost.

King John granted a charter
Chart. Antiq. G. N. 22, dorso, Tower of London. "Carta burgensium de Novo Castello.
"Johannes Dei gratia &c. Sciatis nos concessisse et dimisisse et hac carta nostra confir∣masse probis"Probi homine," say Brady, in his Glossary, " famous, stout o noted ma prelaty napl activity, understanding, ability, and virtuon action." hominibus nostris de Novo Castello super Tynam et heredibusThe word "hered," heirs, occurs in no former charter, but is constantly continued in the subse∣quent ons.—See a clause in the customs confirmed by Henry I. to . corum villam nostram de Novo Castello cum omnibus pertinentiis suis ad feodi firmam pro 100 lib. nobis et heredibus nostris annuatim inde reddendis ad scaccarium nostrum per manum suam ad duos terminos scilicet ad Pasch' 50 lib. et ad festum Sancti Michaelis 50 lib. salvis redditibusBy "ents" here, it should seem, we are to understand the custom of the port of Tyne let out to fan. et prisis
Ps, say Mado, Excheq. , fol. edit. was the duty the King for wine.
