P, s Blount, in h L D taken the King subject is. Also accustom due to the . et assisisAh—intedum su pro in dem. Du in verbo. nostris in portu ejusdem ville. Preterea concessi∣mus eis et dedimus 110 solidat' et 6 denerat' redditus quas habemus in eadem villa de escaetisH following account "De Dus Re in villa de usdem pro terris suis qua ann ad dividendum et assignand' illis qui redditus suos amiserunt occasione fos∣sati et nove operationis facte subtus castrum versus aquam, ita quod inde plus habeant qui plus amiserunt et qui minus minus. Concessimus eciam eis quod in nullo sint respon∣dentes vic' vel constabulario de hiis que ad ipsos pertinent. Quare volumus et firmiter precipimus quod predicti homines nostri & heredes eorum habeant et teneant predictam villam cum omnibus pertinenciis suis per predictam firmam, sicut predictum est, bene et in pace, libere & quiete et integre cum omnibus libertatibus et liberis consuetudinibus quas habere consueverunt tempore Regis H. patris nostri salva libertat' civitatis nostre Lond'.The liberties of the Londoners make an express article of Magna Charta. See chap. 10. Dat' per manum R. de Marisco archd. Richemundie et Northumbrie apud Stocton 5 die Februar' anno regni nostri 14o."—From a copy communicated by Thomas Astle, Esq keeper of the records in the Tower of London., dated at Stockton, February 5th,
1214, to the burgesses by the title of the good men of Newcastle upon Tyne and their heirs: by which he raised the fee-farm of that town to 100l. per annum, remitting to them the payment of the eschaet rents of 110 shillings and six-pence, to be divided proportionably amongst those who had lost their property by the enlargement of the fortifications, and sinking the foss of the castle. He exempted them at the same time from being answerable for any of their property to the sheriff of Northumberland, or the constable of the castle, empow∣ering them as before to pay their rent by their own hand: and reserved to himself the rents, prizes and assizes of the port of the town and the liberty of the city of London.

King John, by a charter dated at Durham, January 28th, 1217
Johannes Dei gratia Rex Anglie Dominus Hibernie Dux Normannie, Aquitan' et Comes Andeg' archiepiscopis, episcopis, abbatibus, prioribus, ducibus, comitibus, baroni∣bus, justiciatiis, vicecomitibus, prepositis, ministris et omnibus ballivis et fidelibus suis salutem. Sciatis nos concessisse et hac carta nostra confirmasse burgensibus nostris de Novo Castro super Tynam pro fideli servicio suo et heredibus corum in perpetuum quod nullus eorum per aliquem distringatur extra eundem burgum ad reddend' alicui debitum aliquod unde non sit capitalis debitor vel plegius—Concessimus etiam eis quod nullus eorum faciat duellum—Et quod de placitis ad coronam nostram pertinentibus se possint disraci∣onare secundum antiquam consuetudinem civitatis nostre Winton'—Et quod nullus de mise∣ricordia pecunie judetur nisi secundum antiquam legem ejusdem civitatis Winton' quam aburunt temporibus antecessorum nostrorum. Et quod terras & tenuras suas et va∣monia et omnia debita sua juste habeant quicunque ea eis debeat et de terris suis et tenurs que infra burgum predictum sunt rectum eis teneatur secundum consuetudinem civitate. Witon'. Et quod de omnibus debitis suis que accomodata fuerunt apud Novum Castrum super Tynam et vadimonia ibidem facta placita ibidem teneantur.—Concessimus insuper eisdem ad emendationem ejusdem burgi quod omnes sint quieti de yeresgyne et scotall. Ita quod nullus vicecomes noster vel aliquis alius ballivus scotallian faciat infra eundem burgum. Si vero consuetudines injuste levate suerint tempore guerre omnino sint cassat' et quicunque petierint burgum Novi Castri super Tynam cum mercandisa sua de quo∣cunque loco sint sive extranei sive alii, veniant, morontur et recedant in salva pace nostra reddend' certas et debitas consuetudines. Et prohibemus ne quis super hoc faciat impe∣dimentum. Has vero consuetudines eisdem burgensibus nostris Novi Castri super Tynam & eorum heredibus concessimus & presenti carta confirmavimus et omnes alias liber∣tates et liberas consuctudines quas habuerunt temporibus antecessorum nostrorum quando eas meliores et liberiores habue unt habendum & tenendum de nobis et heredibus nostis sibi & heredibus suis imperpetuum bene et in pace, libere, quiete plenarie integre et hono∣rificè in omnibus locis & rebus sicut predictum est Quare volumus & firmiter precipimus quod prefati burgenses nostri Novi Castri super Tynam & heredes eorum habeant omnes libertates et liberas consuetudines predict' sicut predictum est Testibus R. Comite Cestrie W. Comite de Ferr' Phil' de Albin' Rogero de Monte Regon' Hugone de Bayll Hugone de Bolbeck W. de Cantill' Philip' de Ulecot' Gerard' de Furnival' Dat' p manum Magistri Roberti de Marisc' cancellarii nostri apud Dunolm' vicesimo octavo die Januarii anno regni nostri septimo decimo."
(From a charter of inspeximus, dated 13th May, 3d of Elizabeth, remaining in the a¦chives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.—See under "Merchant-Adventurers" the several clauses omitted in the above copy, which particularly relate to the foundation of that ancient fraternity.), granted and confirmed, for their faithful services, to his burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, and to their heirs for ever, the privilege that none of them should be distrained out of that town for the payment
of any debt for which he was not chief debtor or surety—that none of them should be tried by duelDul was a single combat between two persons, to prove the truth of any contro∣very which he who overcame was thought to prove. (Fleta) See Barrington on the an∣cient Statutes.—that they should be allowed to tra∣verse in pleas of the crown, according to the ancient custom of the city of Winchester—that none of them should be judged of misericordia moneyMisericordia money means an arbitrary amerciament or punishment imposed on any person for any offence.—Blount in verbo., but according to the old law of Winchester—that they should hold justly their lands, tenures, recognizancesRecognizance is a bond or obligation testifying the recognizer to owe the recognizee a sum of money, and is acknowledged in some court of record, &c.—Blount in verbo. and debts from whom∣soever owing—that their lands and tenures within that town should be held rightly to them according to the custom of Winchester, and that pleas should be held in Newcastle concerning debts and recognizances
lent and made there. The King farther granted, for the improvement of the town, that all the burgesses should be exempt from the pay∣ment of yeresgyne
Yeresgyne.—This word occurs in a great variety of spellings: "Jeresgiene, jeresceue, gersuma, jeresumma, gyeresgyver, gressume, zeresgen, &c." all signifying the same thing.— Brady says it means a bribe or reward given to the King's or other officers for connivance, and being favourable in their office, but properly an income, or fine paid for the entrance upon some place, office or estate.
According to Blount, who derives it from the Saxon gaersuma, sumptus, premium, it signifies first an income, secondly, a fine for a fault, and lastly is taken for a exaction or demand. and scotale"Scotale," from st, a gathering or shot, and ale in the known signification. Sco∣tales were abuses put upon the King's people by his officers, who invited them to drink ale, and then made a collection, to the end they should not vex or inform against them for the crimes they had committed, or should commit."—Brady on Boroughs, Appendix, p. 13, folio edition.—that no sheriff or bailiff should make any scotale in that place—that those customs which had been unjustly levied in the time of war, should be altogether annulled—that every person from whatever place, whether foreigners or others, that resorted to Newcastle upon Tyne with merchandise, should be permitted to stay there, and depart from thence in the King's peace, after payment of such established customs as had become due. This charter confirm∣ed also all other liberties and free customs granted before by the King's ancestors.

King John, in what year of his reign it is left uncertain, granted a yearly fair to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, to last for two days, that is, the vigil and day of St. Peter ad vincula, commonly called Lammas-daySee afterwards a charter granted to Newcastle, dated 12 November, 12 Ed. II. in which express mention of t occurs..

In the year 1223 there was a talliage of an hundred and twenty marks raised upon the town of Newcastle upon Tyne
Carte's History, Henry III. 24. Note 4. "In 1223, Feb. 27, King Henry III. issued out commissions for assessing a talliage he had laid on all cities, towns, and manors of his demesne, perhaps with a view of being in a readiness to oppose the progress of Lewellin, Prince of Wales.—The talliage raised upon the town of Newcastle was 120 marks"
"Talliage, or tallage, from the French taillie, which originally signifies a piece cut out of the whole, and metaphorically a share of a man's substance paid by way of tribute, toll, or tax, is, according to Sir Edward Coke, a general word, and includes all taxes." —Blount in verbo..
This year mention first occurs of a seal belonging to the corporation of that town, and described as a round one, two inches large, with the device of a castleMadox's Formulate Anglicanum. p. 375..

By a charter dated July 2d, 1235
In Astle's MS. notes and charters in the Tower of London, relating to Newcastle upon Tyne, there is said to be preserved in that great repository:
"Pat. 1 Ric. II. p. 5. m. 1, in qua sunt duae chartae de annis 18o & 22o Hen. III. quorum nullum extat recordum." i. e. A. D. 1235 & 1239., King Henry III. granted and confirmed to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne that town, with all its appurtenances, at the annual fee-farm, of 100l. reserving to himself the rents, prises, and assises of the port of Tyne, as had been done bv King John in his charter of February 5th, 1214. By this charter the rent of the town was ordered to be paid in future at Michaelmas only, and not, as before, at two half yearly payments. It included also a confirmation of King John's grant of the eschaets, to be divided amongst those who had lost their property by the new works of the castle"Henricus Dei gratia &c. omnibus &c. salutem. Noveritis nos concessisse & dimi∣fusse et hac carta nostra confirmasse pro nobis et heredibus nostris probis hominibus nostris de Novo Castello super Tynam et heredibus corum villam nostram de Novo Castello cum omnibus pertinentiis ad seodi fu mam pro centum libris nobis & heredibus nostris reddendis per manus suas ad scaccanium Sancti Michaelis quas prius reddere solebant ad scaecarium nostrum per cartam Domini Johannis Regis patris nostri ad duos terminos viz. ad Pasch. 50 libr' et ad sellum Sancti Michaelis 50 libr' salvis nobis redditibus & prisis et assisis nostris in portu ejusdem ville. Pretera concessimus ess et carta noia confirmavimus pro nobis & heredibus nost is centum et decem solid & sex deuam' redditu quos habent ex dono ipsius patris nostri is centum et decem solid' & sex denan' red litas quos habent ex dono ipsius patris nostri in eadem villa de esche ad divident' & ag∣nand' illis qui redditus suos amiserunt occatione soffati et mae operators fache fulitas versus etiam eis pro nobis et heredibus nostris quod in nullo sint respondentes vice-niti nec constabular' de hiis que ad ipsos pertinent leiut caa predici patris nostri quam inde habent rationabiliter testatut. Quare volumus et precipimus peo nobis et heredibus nostris quod predicti homines nostri et heredes eorum habeant et teneane predictam villiam cum omnibus pertinentiis suis ad feodi firmam pro predictis centum Chris nobis et heredibus nostris inde annuatim reddendis per manus suas ad scarcarium Sancti Michaelis ficet predictum est bene et in pace libere er quiete & integra cum om∣nibus libertatibus et liberis consuetudinibus quas habere consueverunt tempore Regis Henrici avi nostri salva libertate civitatis nostre London. Hiis testibus R. Dunelm' & W. Kal' Epise pis W. Com' Warren' (et aliis contentis in carta) Dar' per manus vene∣iis patiis R. Cicestter' Episcopi cancellarii nostri apud Westmon' secundo die Julii anno regtii decimo octavo"—From a copy in the Harleian MSS. No. 6598, fol. 8..

This year a special liberty was granted to the men of New∣castle upon Tyne, that no Jew should reside amongst them"The Jews seem to have behaved ill in Northumberland. For the King, upon peti∣tion of the inhabitants of Newcastle, granted them the following privilege, that no Jew should ever reside amongst them. Rex vicecomiti Northumberland salutem. Sciatis quod concessimus et carta nostra confirmavimus probis hominibus nostris de villa Novi Castri super Tynam & heredibus eorum quod habeant hanc libertatem quod nullus Judaeus de cetero tempore nostro vel heredum nostrorum maneat vel residentiam aliquam faciat in eadem villa: sicut plenius continetur in charta Regis &c.—Claus. 18 Hen. III. m. 16." Tovey's Anglia Judaica, p. 102. : they appear to have paid the King an hundred marks for this privilege
Harleian MSS. 624, p. 172, b. Commun' memor' scaccar penes rememor' domini thesauraii de anno 19 Hen. III. Rot. 3.
Pro hominibus de Novo Castello super Tynam. Rex baronibus. Sciatis quod prob▪ homines de Novo Castello nostro super Tynam finem fecerunt nobiscum pro centum marcis pro habenda libertate quod nullus Judaeus de cetero tempore nostro vel heredum nostrorum maneat vel residenciam faciat in villa Novi Castelli nostri super Tynam &c. Teste meipso apud Kenynton 5 die Jul' anno 19 regni nostri.".

Henry III. by letters patent, dated December 1st, 1239, is said toi have granted licence to the burgesses of Newcaste upon Tyne, on their petition, to dig coals and stones in the castle-field and sirth adjoining to that town.

In order to enable them the better to pay their fee-farm rent, the King gave them, on their second petition, by his grant, dated May 11th, 1248, all the stones and coals in the firth abovenamedSee Gardiner's England's Grievance, discovered in relation to the Coad-Trade. Lon∣don, 1655. quarto, p. 8, 9.—See under History of Coal and Coal-Trade..

By a charter dated 1251, King Henry III. is mentionedBrowne Willis, cited by Wallis, in his History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 187.—Also Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 405. to have made the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, which had been governed before by bailiffs, a mayor town
Bourne says, "The word mayor was anciently called meyr, from the British word miret, i.e. custodire, tokeep or protect."
Cleland, in his Specimen, & p. 170, derives it from the Celsie, where maer, or mawr, signifies the head ruler.
For seals of the mayoralty of Newcastle upon Tyne, see Plate II. No. 2—Plate 1. No. 7 and 9.: yet see afterwards under 1290, when the town appears to have been seized into the King's hands, because the burgesses had chosen a mayor without warrant from the crown.

The above King, by his charter, dated October 18th, 1253, granted for ever to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne the liberty of choos∣ing coroners, who were to be sworn in full court in that town, and to be proper persons for so important an office"Henricus Dei gratia Rex Anglie Dominus Hibernie Dux Normannie Aquitan' et Comes Andeg' omnibus ballivis et fidelibus suis ad quos presentes litere pervenci int salutem. Sciatis quod concessimus pro nobis et here libus nostris quod burgenses ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam imperpetuum habeant hanc libertatene, viz. quod de supsis de cetero successive eligere et habere possint coronatores in villa predicta qui prestito sacra∣mento fidelitatis in plena curia coram majore et ballivis ejusdem ville facient et confer∣vent et quae ad coronam nostram pertinent in villa predicta Ita tamen quod tales ad hoc eligent et assignent qui melius sciant et possint ad hoc intendere. In cujus rei testimo∣nium h iis literis nostris patentibus sigillum nostrum secimus apponi. Teste meipso apud Westmon' decimo octavo die Octobris anno regni nostri tricesimo sexto." (From a char∣ter of inspeximus, dated May 13th, in the 3d year of the reign of Queen Elizabeth, re∣maining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.).

Prynne, speaking of restraining bishops by writs from citing persons out of the counties or corporations wherein they lived, though within their dioceses, for fornication and adultery, instances in a prohibition issued by King Henry III. in the year 1260, to the Bishop of Durham, forbidding him or his officers to cite the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne on such occasions out of their own boroughOn the 4th institute, p. 240. "It had grown into a practice in the ecclesiastical jurisdiction of this see, to cite certain persons residing in Newcastle, to attend the bishop's officials and archdeacons at their courts and visitations, in places distant from that bo∣rough, contrary, as it was alleged, to the liberties of the burgesses. This practice grow∣ing into a great grievance from the expences attending, or the loss of time of the mer∣chants and artificers, insomuch that some of them were reduced to the miserable neces∣sity of begging, application was made to the crown for redress, and the King issued his writ of prohibition for relief thereof, and his mandate to the bishop, commanding him and his officers to forbear such proceedings in future."—Hutchinson's Durham, vol. i. p. 213..

A. D. 1262, Adam de Gesemuc, sheriff of Northumberland, re∣ceived of the burgesses their fee-farm of an hundred pounds for certain uses of government, to which the King had enjoined him to apply that sum
Harleian MSS. 624. Plut. 2/v F. dorso. pag. 198. Commun' ex parte rememo∣ratoris domini thesaurarii de anno 47 Hen. III. Rot. 13.
"Baronibus pro Ada de Gesemue. Rex baronibus quod 100 li. quas Adam de Gesemue vicecomes Northumbr' recepit a burgensibus Novi Castri super Tynam de firma ville de termino Sancti Michael' anno 46 ad quedam negotia Regis que ei injunxit inde expedi∣enda quas eisdem ballivis allocari fecit et de quibus idem Adam reddere tenebatur compo∣tum ad scaccarium et similiter 25 li. et 18s. quos recepit de exitibus comitatus Northumbr' ad expedicionem negociorum predictorum, posuit idem Adam in vadiis suis duorum mili∣tum et 12 armigerorum per septies 20 et undecim dies, videlicet a vigil' Exaltationis sancte Crucis anno 45, usque ad diem Jovis prox' ante Purific' beate Marie anno 46, circa con∣servasionem ville Novi Castri et partium illarum prout Regi constat per computationem inde coram consilio Regis factam. Et de predictis 100 li. ipsum Adam quietem esse faciant & predictas 25l. et 18s. eidem Ade in exitibus comitat' predict' allocent' Breve est in forulo Marescalli."
In the year 1265, mention occurs of an impression of the seal of the corporation of New∣castle upon Tyne upon green wax, with the following inscription: "Commune sigillum Novi Castri super Tynam." (Bourne's History, p. 187, from MSS. of Mr. Smith.)—See seals in this work, Plate I. No. 13. There is the representation of a still older seal pre∣served in the vetusta monumenta of the society of Antiquaries of London.—See a copy, Seals, Plate I. No. 1.
For other common seals of that town, see Plate I. No. 8 and 15..

A patent, dated in 1265, for levying and collecting murage
Pat. 49 Hen. III. de muragio pro villa, i. e. Novi Castri super Tynam.
(MS. note of records in the Tower of London concerning Newcastle upon Tyne, communicated by Thomas Astle, Esq) for the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, is preserved in the Tower of London.

In the year 1275, there was a commission to inquire into the custom
of Newcastle, by which every burgess might bequeath his tenements, which he had of purchase in his own hands as chattels.Aubone MS. See more under the 9th year of that king's reign.—Also there occurs, of the same date, an inquisition concerning divers trespasses and articles touching the state of that townEscaet. 3 Ed. I. m. 85. Inquis' de divers' transgress' et articul' stat' vill' predict' tangen'.—Astle's MS. note, ut supra..

A. D. 1276, King Edward I. granted by patent, that the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne might bequeath their lands and tenements to whom they pleasedBurgenses Novi Castri super Tynam possint legare terras et tenementa sua tanquam catalla cui voluerint &c. (Pat. 4 Ed. I. m. 24, tom. iv. Rot. Turri Londinensi.— Wallis' History of Northumberland. vol. ii. p. 189.).
This year also the liberty of the burgesses of that place, that none should be impleaded out of the town, was twice allowedAubone MS..

In the year 1281 there was an inquiry upon divers trespasses and other articles concerning the state of Newcastle upon Tyne
Aubone MS.—See before 1275. "It was found on this occasion that the town was worth 200l. per annum, if it were in the King's hands, but that King John had granted it for 100l. in fee-farm, when it was not worth so much, but that it was then so increased by coals as to be sometimes, though not always, worth 200l. per annum." And, "that the comonalty of that town had removed Hugh de Merchinleigh the bailiff there, who acted for the King's profit, in contempt of the King, but they said he was none of the comonalty,Bdy, in his Treatise of English Burghs, p. 24, fol. edit. cites a clause in a private act of parliament, which clearly proves that the mayor and commonalty of a borough were a select number, and distinct from all the other burgesses, on other persons resident and dwelling within the same. So that mayor and commonalty means the mayor, aldermen, and common-council, or the mayor and chief burgesses which composed the governing part of the town. whereupon he was removed, because he procured murage against them." See before A. D. 1265.
"Forestalling," adds the same authority, "was also presented.".

It appears that in Michaelmas term, 1284, there was an allowance, in the Court of Common Pleas, of the liberty of the burgesses of New∣castle upon Tyne to hold plea for land in that townIbid. The same authority informs us, that in Hilary term 1287, cognizance of pleas was allowed in the Court of Common Pleas, of the liberty of the above burgesses to hold plea for lands there"—"that the like was done again the same year, and that in 1289 there was the like allowance.".

In the year 1290 a quo warranto was issued out against the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, by which eight of the wiser and more wealthy townsmen were ordered to attend in the Exchequer, and shew by what warrant they had chosen themselves a mayorMemoranda in scace' 18 Ed. I. Mandat' est vic' Northumbrie quod non omittat propter libertatem ville Novi Castri super Tynam quin eam ingrediatur et venire fc' coram baronibus de scaccario octo de discretioribus et ditioribus hominibus ejusdem ville ad ostend' pro se et tota communitate &c. in le ensuant roll quo warranto elegerunt sibi majorem de scipsis in eadem villa.—Mich. 18. finien' incip' 19 Ed. I. (Sir John Maynard's Reports, p. 16, folio 1678).

It appears that the town was seized into the King's hands on this occasion
A. D. 1292 and 1293. In Michaelmas term he who then had the custody of New∣castle, was commanded to supersede, or forbear from unlawful distresses taken of the bur∣gesses of Lynn.—Aubone MS.
"In Easter term 1292," adds the same authority, "the liberty of the said town of New∣castle upon Tyne was allowed in the Court of King's Bench, that none of the burgesses should be elsewhere impleaded.".

In 1293, a quo warranto was brought against the bailiffs and com∣munity of Newcastle upon Tyne, to shew what claim they had to the return of all the King's writs—to hold pleas "de vetito namio"—to have a guild merchant—that none of them should be impleaded with∣out the said town concerning his tenements, nor be fined for any offence above eight shillings—that without the King's writ they should hold pleas there "de libero tenemento."—That they should be quit of toll, lastage, passage, pontage, yeresgeve, and scottale in all sea ports, and throughout the whole kingdom of England, and that they should have custody of prison, and coroners of their own within the town, without the King's licence, &c. Nothing was done upon the appear∣ance of the bailiff and community, it having been alleged that "the whole town is the mannor of King John." They were ordered, but
did not appear afterwards at York, when it was adjudged that the liber∣ties aforesaid should be taken into the King's hands
"Placita de quo warranto et de Rageman' coram H. de Cressingham et sociis justici∣ariis Domini Regis itinerantibus apud Novum Castrum super Tynam in comitatu Nor∣thumbr' in crastino Sancti Hillarii anno regni Regis Edwardi fil' Regis Henrici 21o. Rot. 8.
"Ballivi et communitas de Novo Castro super Tynam summoniti fuere quod essent hic &c. ostendentes quo warranto clamant habere in burgo predicto return' omnium bre∣vium Regis et tenere placita de vetito namioNamium veritum is an unjust taking the cattle of another, and driving them to an unlawful place, pretending some damage done by them. In which case the owner of the cattle may demand satisfaction the injury, which is called "placitum de namio vetito."—Blount's Law Dictionary in verbo. et habere gildam mercatoriam et quod nullus ipsorum extra burgum predictum de ten' is implacitet' neque quocunque delicto ultro octo solid' amercietur et sine brevi Regis placita de libero tenemento ibidem placitare et esse quieti de theolon' lastag' passag' pontag' yeresyene et scottale per omnes portus maris et totum regnum Anglie et habere custod' prison' et coronatores proprios infra burgum predictum quod ad coronam & dignitatem Domini Regis pertinet sine licentia et voluntate Regis et progen' &c.
"Et ballivi & communitas venerunt et quia tota villa est in manerio Domini Regis Johannis nichil inde ad presens. Dies datus est eis apud Ebor' a die Sancti Johannis Baptiste in quindecem dies &c. postea ad diem illum non venerunt. Judicium—Predict' libertat' capiantur in manus Domini Regis nomine distric' et ipsi summoniti quod sint hic apud Ebor' a die Sancti Michaelis in quindecim dies audituri judicium suum."—Browne Willis' MSS. in the Bodleian library..

A. D. 1294, a writ was directed to the sheriff of Northumberland, to restore the town of Newcastle upon Tyne into the hands of the burgesses thereof to be held as before: the King also pardoned the said burgesses for deceiving him concerning the sum of sixteen hundred pounds, which they had alleged the King owed them upon his bond, but which it afterwards appeared, as they themselves acknowledged, he was under no obligation to repay
"Memorandum in scace' Hil. 22 Ed. I. A. D. 1294. Vil seisi quia esly maior sans garr. Roy dec' son garr' void. Novum Castrum super Tynam seisi in maines le Roy quia les burgesses de ce ont eslew un maior sans garrant et puis petition al Roy in parle∣ment pur restitution offerant a reles 1600l. quas Rex eis debet per literas suas obliga∣torias ex causa mutui et Rex mandat baron' quod acceptis prius ab eis literis predictis re∣stituer' &c. Et les burgesses veigne al Exchequer et redes le dett sed ont jour usques o pur liver les breves obligatory &c. quia sunt in Northumbr.' Et surce baron men vic' quod restituat villam &c. salvis exitibus medio tempore perceptis. Postea ils n icy les letters quibus inspectis compertum quod Rex non tenetur eis reddere debitum pre∣dictum nisi ad voluntatem suam et iidem burgenses dederunt Regi intelligi quod tenebitur eis merè ex mutuo et per ipsos non stetit quin Dominum Regem decepissent in ho. Id considerat' est quod villa predicta recapiatur. Postea le Roy eux pardon' et restituitor villam predictam."—Sir John Maynard's Reports, p. 24.
Ibid. Mich. 22 Ed. I.
"Restitution pur maioralty occupy sans licens.
"Vic' Northumbr' Edw. vic' ss. &c. Quia homines ville Novi Castri super Tynam nobis satisfecerunt pro transgressione quam fecerunt occupando officium majorita Regem sine warranto propter quod villam illam capi fecimus in manum nostram &c. precipimus quod villam predictam predictis hominibus liberes tenend' sicut antea, nobis exitibus medio tempore perceptis."—Rot 10. v. Mich. 19 Ed. I. Rot. 2, 3. ibid p. 30..

December 8th, 1294, King Edward I. granted an exemplification and confirmation of the charters granted to Newcastle upon Tyne, in the 18th and 36th years of the reign of King Henry the Third"Nos autem concessiones confirmationes & dimissiones predictas ratas haber gratas eas pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est, predictis hominibus burgensibus et corum heredibus imperpetuum concedimus et confirmamus sicut carta et liter predicte rationabiliter testantur et prout iidem homines & burgenses et antecessores su libertate predicta halenus usi sunt rationabiliter & gavisi. Hiis testibus venerabi patribus A. Dunelm' W. Flien' J. Karl' et W. Bathon' & Wellen' episcopis Willielmo de Valencia avunculo mo Hemico de Lacy Comite Lincoln' Gilberto de Thornton Johanne de Mthyng Roberto de Hertford Rogero Brabasim Roberto Malett Ricardd Posco et alus. Dat' per manum nostram apud Westmon' 8vo die Decembris anno nostri vicesuno secundo." (From a charter of Inspeximus 13 May, 3 Elizabeth, ining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.).

King Edward I. by his charter, dated December 20th, 1299, granted to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, the lands and tenement it Pampeden
Edwardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie Dominus Hibernae & Dux Aquitanie arches, copies &c. salutem. Sciatis quod dedimus et concessimus et hac carta nostra conta∣vimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris delectis burgensibus & probis hominibus nostris vile Novi Castri super Tynam omnes terras & tenementa cum pertinentiis in Pampeden in Pyker juxta predictam villam Novi Castri cum redditibus & serviciis omnium tenentium nostrum et heredum suorum cum suis pertinen' que habuimus ex concessione & reddi∣cione Roberti de Byker et Ladararie uxoris ejus et que iidem Robertus et Ladararia dbis prius tenuerunt de hereditate ipsius Ladararie habendum et tenendum eisdem burgensibus et probis hominibus & heredibus suis de nobis & heredibus nostris per eandem sumam quam nobis reddunt de villa Novi Castri supradicti imperpetuum cum omnibus ad terras & tenemen' reddit' et servic' predict' spectan' ad uniend' & includend' dicte ville Novi Castri in augmentum emendationem & securitatem ejusdem ville Volumus etiam et dimus pro nobi et heredibus nostris quod predicti burgenses & probi homines ejus∣deri ville Novi Castri et eorum hredes habeant in predictis terris & tenementis de peden liberum burgam siut in predicta villa Novi Castri cum omnibus liber∣tbus & liberis consuetudinibus ad liberum burgum pertinen' et quod terre et tenementa predict' de cetero sint libera burgagia & teneantur in liberum burgagium adeo libere et qte sicut predicti burgenses & probi homines burgagia sua in predicta villa Novi Castri & liberius tenent. Et quod predicti burgenses & probi homines et eorum heredes eorum heredes qui terras et tenementa predicta in Pampeden modo tenent et in habeant in omni' as et per omnia libertates & liberas consuetudin predicti burgens & probi in predicta villa Novi Castri ex conces∣ pregeniterum & nostra et quod predicta villa Novi Castri et terre & tenementa predicta in Pampeden unica villa detero sint et unus burgus. Ita quod nullu , aut alius ballivus seu minister noster serinficus in pre∣dictis & tenementis in Pampeden in aliquibus ad dictam libertatum pertinen' de cetero nisi in nsium & proberum hominum predict' vel ballivorum quod nullum sive ragium de rebus per naves et tenementis in Pampeden predict' & vol burgensium ex prebrum hominum predict' Novi Castri tenementorum predict' in & probis homnibus ville Novi Castri deit et intendnt omnibus qe contignat libertatem Quare et nter precipimus pro nobis & heredibus nostris quod predicti burgensis et probi homines predicti ville Novi Castri & heredes sui habeant et teneant omnes terras & tene∣menta predicta cum pertinen' in Pampeden in Byker una cum redditibus & serviciis om∣nium tenentium nostrorum & heredum suorum cum suis pertinentiis de nobis et heredibus nostris per eandem firmam quam nobis reddunt de villa Novi Castri supradicta imperpe∣tuum cum omnibus ad terras tenementa reddit' et servicia predict' spectan' ad uniend' et concludend' dicte ville Novi Castri in augmentum emendacionem & securitatem ejusdem ville et quod habeant in predictis terris et tenementis in Pampeden liberum burgum sicut habent in predicta villa Novi Castri cum omnibus libertatibus et liberis consuetudinibu ad liberum burgum pertinen' et quod terr' et tenementa predicta de cetero sint libera burgagia et teneantur in liberum burgagiumBurgagium liberum was, when the tenants had paid their yearly rent to the superior lord, they were free from all other services.—Blount in verbo. adeo libere & quiete sicut predicti bur∣genses et probi homines burgagia sua in predicta villa Novi Castri medius & liberius tenent Et quod predicti burgenses et probi homines et eorum heredes & illi & eorum heredes qui terras & tenementa predict' in Pampeden modo tenent et in posterum tenebunt habe∣ant in omnibus & per omnia omnes libertates & liberas consuetudines quas predicti bur∣genses & probi homines habent in predicta villa Novi Castri ex concessione progenitorum nostrorum regum Anglie & nostra et quod predicta villa Novi Castri & terr' & tene∣menta predict' in Pampeden unica villa de cetero sint et unus burgus ita quod nullus vice∣comes coronator &c. (ut supra) Hiis testibus venerabili patre W. Covent' et Lich' Epis∣copo Joh' Tregon Will' de Cantelupo, Will' de Rither, Waltero de Teye Joh' de Insula Hugone de Sancto de Phileberto Edw' Charles Will' de Felton & aliis. Dat' per manum nostram apud Ebor' 20 die Decembr' anno regni nostri vicesimo septimo."
(From an Inspeximus charter, dated May 13th, in the 3d year of the reign of Queen Elizabeth, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.) in the manor of Byker, adjoining to that town, and which had been granted to the crown by Robert de Byker, and Ladararia his
wifeBourne supposes that Robert de Byker, and Laderar' his wife, were people of great figure, probably lord and lady of the manor of Byker, and had their town's house in or near that part of Pandon called Byker-Chare., and was the inheritance of the latter, to be united to New∣castle for the increase, improvement, and security of that town: the lands and tenements of Pampeden to be held in free burgage, in the same manner as those of Newcastle, with all customs and liberties there, as elsewhere in the town, by the same fee-farm, and the two places to constitute henceforth one town and borough.

Madox, in his History of the Exchequer, on the subject of dormant writs of allocate and computate, instances one of the former dated August 1st, 1311, in which discount was ordered to be made by King Edward the Second, out of the fee-farm of Newcastle upon Tyne, till the burgesses of that town should be reimbursed the sum of 633l. 6s. 8d. which they had lent himPage 676, folio edition..

In the year 1312 mention first occurs, in Bourne's History of New∣castle,
of the ancient custom of acknowledging fines in the Guild-hall of that town between the four benches of the court
"It appears," says he, "by several records, that there has been an ancient custom within the said town of Newcastle upon Tyne, of acknowledging fines in the Guild-hall of the said town between the four benches therein; and that the same has been con∣tinued and usually practised, and is now frequently done.
"A fine so acknowledged for lands or tenements within the said town, being by that custom of the same force and validity as a fine acknowledged in any other manner, and it is done so publickly, and before so many persons, that the cognizors must be known to some of them, which allows no opportunity for a fraud.
"And when a fine is to be acknowledged by a wife, she is not only particularly examined in open court, but also makes oath that she does it freely, and voluntarily, without any force or compulsion of her husband."
He mentions under 1315, another "quatuor bancos," in the manner aforesaid..

A letter of thanks, dated December 18th, 1315, to the mayor, bailiffs, and good men of Newcastle upon Tyne, from King Edward II. occurs in Rymer's Foedera. From the circumstance of their vicinity to Scotland and by their loyalty and valiant opposition to their hostile neighbours, they had been exposed to various calamities, and suffered the most griev∣ous oppressions. He wrote also at the same time to the King of France, and to the Duke of Britanny, on their behalf, to allow them to purchase in their respective dominions, corn and other provisions necessary for the defence of the town, and their own support, without the exaction of any other but the old and accustomed prises
Tom. iii. p. 544.
It appears that King Edward II. granted the office of tronage, and clerk of the market of Newcastle upon Tyne, to Gilbert Haukyn, during his royal pleasure. See Madox's History of the Exchequer, p. 535, folio edit. where he tells us, "Officium tronatoris & clerici novae custumae apud Novum Castrum super Tynam," was committed to Gilbert Hakyn, quamdiu Regi placuerit. Hill. Commiss. 2 Ed. II. Rot. 11, a.
In the merchants' books are the following entries: "A. D. 1563, an act to restrain "the tronne and skail" from strangers, &c. When also they appear to have "paid for amending of the weights in the Quenes Maj waye house 9s. 4d."
"A. D. 1567, paid to Henry Brandelyng for his fee in keping the weyhouse from strangers this yere, 40 shillings.
March 6th, 1666, an order that no brother shall sell any lead to any stranger, "before he shall bring the same to the Kinges Majesties beame in the weigh-house of this towne, &c." The office of trenor and poisr of Newcastle upon Tyne appears to have been granted by King William III. by letters patent for three lives, to the mayor and burgesses of the town. (Common-council book, 23d, 1734.)
July 4th, 1717, Isabel Wetwa, widow, occurs ibid. as tronor and poison.
June 1th, 177, John Marei, and Isabella his wife, occur as resigning that offi which the corporation of Newcastle appointed Thomas Valentine..
In the year 1316 King Edward II. granted, that no purveyances should be made in the town of Newcastle upon Tyne.

The same king, by a charter, dated at York, November 12th, 1318
"Nos autem concessiones et confirmationes predictas ratas habentes et nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est concedimus et confirmanus predicta nationabuiter teslatur. Preteres volentes eisdem burgensibus gratiam parte an plim corcessimus eis pro nois & heredibus nostris quod licet ipsi predecessores burgenses burgi illius aliquibus libertat' in dicta carta contenc' emergent' htenur plene usi non fuerunt, ipsi tamen burgenses et eorum hered cessores bur enses ejusdem bui libertatibus illis et earum qualibet absque impe nostri vel heredum nostorum justiciar' tor' vicecrnitum aut aliorum bllis seu ministrorum nostrorum cumque de cetero plene gaudeant et utentur. cessimus etiam dictis burgenibus, pro nobis et liredibus nostris et hac carta cons quod ipsi et heredes et successores sui burgenses burgi predicti imperpet icti de theolnio, munglo et pannio de omnibus rbus et merchandisis potestatem nostram et per omnes portas maris tam infra quinq quam ald et quod de aliquibus placitis infra burum predict' per sed nimodo per comburgenses nisi res ipsa vel heredes nostors ministrus nostros aut communitatem ville predict Et quod bsprerum infra muros burgi predicti per assisam vel liberationes voluntatem burgensium predict' nisi in presentia nostra vel advntri exercitus nostri vl heredum nostrorum aut hominum des nostros ad partes illius missiorum seu in present justic' nostrorum nostrorum itinerancium ad communis placita in com' Northumbrie vel justic' assign' et tum per nostres vel herd' nostrorum seu dict' hominum ad justic' marescall' et per visum mayoris & bellivorum burgi predicti in illis quo hospi ex liberacion debent hospicia predict' Johannis habeant in per duos dic duratutum, pro nobis & nostirs et hac carta nostra confirmavium tero habeant in codem burgo unam duratrum, viz. per predictos dies, & de merch illud sit ad nos vnarum rarum..
"Qe volumus et firmiter precipimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris quod predicti bur∣gensis et eorum successores et heredes imperpetuum habeant liberates predict' in forma predicta ac etiam predictam setiam in burgo predicto per viinti et octo dies amodo duratur cum omnibus libertatibus et liberis consuuditibus ad hujusmodi scrum pertinen' nisi mentum predictum sit ad nocumentum vicinarum seriarum sicut predictam est. H. tibus venerabilibus patbusN. B (for ) the 12th of II.—S . Wl ber' Archiepscopus Anglie Primer rvices Episcopo et J. Episcopo cancellar' nostro Thoam Come baneastrie Johanne de Pritum' Comit' Ademar de Valencia Comite V." imo Marte de et aliis. Dt'
Novembris anno regni nostri duodecimo." (From a charter of , dated , 3d of of Elizabeth, in the archives of the corporation of Next upon Tyne.),
confirmed the former one, of the 17th year of the reign of King John, to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, with all its customs, notwith∣standing the non-use of them. He granted also, that the burgesses of that town should be free of toll, murage, and pannage, for all their mer∣chandises, as well in the cinque-ports, as in every other sea-port of his dominions: that they should have trials amongst themselves by their fellow burgesses, unless in matters that concerned the King, or the com∣munity of the town;—that none should take lodging, or be quartered within the walls of that town by assize or livery of the marshal
is an oier of the corporation of Newcastle, called the town marshal.
August 2d, 168—also April 6th, 1655, Robert Sharpe occurs in the common-council boo as such.
March 27th, 175, John Harrison.
March 26th, 171 Joseph Lngstaffe, on the removal of J. Harrison.
September 30th, 1745, Wilcocks Wall, on the resignation of J. Langstaffe.
December 15th, 1766, William Trotter, on the removal of W. Wall, who had re∣turned to him 142l. 10s. three-fourths of the stipulated value of the place.
March 21st, 1776, Richard Owen on the death of W. Trotter.
Mr. Manners, the present, 1786., against the will of the burgesses, unless when the King should be there, on the coming of his army, or of soldiers sent to those parts, or of the justices itinerant to the Common Pleas of the county of Northumber∣land, when, by the King's marshal, or the marshal of the armies or jus∣tices, and under the inspection of the mayor and bailiffs, inns were to
be provided for the free quartering of those persons to whom such al∣lowance was due. By this charter also, the King extended the duration of the fair at Lammas, granted by King John for two days only, i. e. the vigil and day of St. Peter ad vincula, to twenty-eight days, if such in∣crease of duration should not be found prejudicial to the neighbouring fairs.

In the year 1325 the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, by a pe∣tition to the King in parliament, obtained a remission of the payment of their fee-farm for two years, in consequence of their heavy charges, both in defending and guarding that town, as well since the late truce with Scotland as beforeRot. Parliam. vol. i. p. 438, A. D. 1325..

A. D. 1327 King Edward III. granted the custom of things sold at Newcastle upon Tyne for seven years, towards the building or repara∣tion of the walls and fortifications of that townAubone MS.—also Murray MS. "Novum Castrum super Tynam. De consuetad' de rebus venalibus ibidem capiend' pro termino 7 annorum in auxilium predict' vill' claudend' &c."—Pat. 1 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 39. Astle's MS. notes say "m. 37.".

In the year following, that monarch pardoned and remitted to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne all debts and arrears that were owing to him or his progenitors: as a recompense for the great losses they had sustained by the frequent incursions of the Scots, all debts, as well of greenGreen wax seems to be used for estreats delivered to the sheriff of the Exchequer, under the seal of that court (made in green wax) to be levied in the counties.—Blount n verbo. wax as arrears of ferms, or those otherwise due by the summons of Exchequer, were forgiven them: as also forfeited rents and chattels of felons, with every thing which they owed to the crown,
except debts for victuals which they had purchased of the King's fatherMadox's Firma Burgi, p. 98..

In the year 1330 the King granted a charter of confirmation to the burgesses of Newcastle
Confirmationes cartarum, cart. 5 Ed. III. n. 81. Astle's MS. note of charters in the Tower of London concerning Newcastle upon Tyne.
Another authority dates this at Waltham, 26th of January. (Note of charters in the town-clerk's office in Newcastle.). He is said to have granted them a like charter the year followingConfirmationes cartarum 6 Ed. III. n. 81. Astle's MS. note, ut supra..

The same King, by a charter dated at York, January 28th, 1332, with the assent of his prelates, barons, and others assembled in par∣liament, granted
"Edwardus D. g. Rex Angl' Dom' Hib' & Dux Aquitan' &c. Sciatis nos pro bono & laudabili servicio nobis et progenitoribus nostris per dilectum nobis Ri∣cardam de Emelden nunc majorem ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam et alios bur∣genses ejusdem ville multipliciter impens' de assensu prelatorum, comitum, baronum et aliorum in presenti parliamento nostro existen' concessisse et hac carta nostra con∣firmasse eisdem burgensibus et eorum heredibus et successoribus quod major ville predicte, qui pro tempore fuerit, sit escaetor noster et heredum nostrorum in eadem villa & libertate ejusdem et quod officium escaetor' in eisdem faciat et exerceat, absque eo quod escaetor noster seu subeschaetores nostri qui pro tempore fuerint aut alius minister noster vel heredum nostrorum seu aliorum se de hujusmodi officio escaetric in villa et libertate predict' intromittant quoquomodo, ita quod de exitibus et proficuis inde provenien' nobis re∣spondeat ut debebit. Quare volumus et firmiter precipimus pro nobis & heredibus nostris quod major ville predicte qui pro tempore fuerit sit eschaetor noster & heredum nostrorum in eadem villa et libertate ejusdem et quod officicum escaetrie in eisdem faciat & exercear absque eo quod eschaetor noster seu subeschaetores sui qui pro tempore fuerint aut alius minister noster vel hered' nostrorum aut aliorum se de officio escaetrie in villa & libertate predictis intromittant quoquomodo, ita quod de exitibus & proficuis inde provenientibus nobis respondeat ut debebit sicut predictum est. Hiis testibus venerabilibus patribus W. Archiepiscopo Ebor' Anglie Primate J. Winton' et W. Norwicen' Episcopus Thoma Comite Norf' Mariscallo Anglie Joh' de Warrena Comite Surr' Willielmo de Roos Willielmo de Mountague Rado de Nevill senescallo Hospicii nostri et aliis. Dat' per manum nostrum apud Ebor' 28o die Januarii anno regni nostri septimo."
(From an Inspeximus charter dated 13th May in the 3d of Elizabeth, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.) and confirmed to the burgesses of Newcastle upon
Tyne, their heirs and successors, as a reward for their good services, that the mayor of that town for the time being should be eschaetor within that place, and the liberties thereof, and account to the King for the rents and profits arising from that office, appointing Richard de Emelden, the then mayor, to be the first. This year also he appears to have granted the said burgesses a charter of confirmation.

The year following the same King granted them another charter of confirmationAstle MS. note of charters, 8 Ed. III. n. 35., and, being in person at that town, caused the walls thereof to be repaired, established the mayor with authority, granted stallage, and confirmed the election of magistrates, merchants, freemen, and of the commonalty of that place"Rex Edwardus tercius anno regni sui octavo ad partes aquilonares descendens pervenit ad Novum Castrum super Tynam ubi comicium sive concialabulum vel par∣liamentum suum servavit et omnes culpas & transgressiones suorum legalium hominum castigavit, correxit et emendavit. Fidelitates, feoda & homagia Regis Scotiae, dominorum ... et baronum illius suscipiens, diu ibidem permansit, muros illius restauravit, libertates novas ordinavit, privilegia concessit, consuetudines confirmavit, presectum regium sive majorem cum auctoritate instituit, burgagia, stallagiaStallge means money paid for the liberty or right of pitching or erecting stalls in fairs or markets.— Blount n verbo, passagia, electiones senatorum, mer∣cantium, liberorum hominum & communitatis ejusdem roboravit et donavit."—Bernard's Catalog. MSS. Bodleian library, "Newcastell.".

There was a patent granted in the year 1342, for inclosing and for∣tifying the town of Newcastle upon TynePat. 15 Ed. III. p. 2, m. 19, de villa claudend' (the fortification of the town)—Astle's MS. note of charters in the Tower of London, concerning Newcastle upon Tyne..

May 6th, 1342, the King having lately taken the town of Newcastle upon Tyne into his own hands for certain misdemeanors, and given the custody thereof to William de Felton; in consideration of the former good services of the townsmen, and their great expence in sur∣rounding the town with a wall, at their earnest request, and on their undertaking to repair the said wall at their own cost, and defend the
place against the Scots, restored it to them to be held as before at their accustomed fee-farm
"Fines 16 Ed. III. m. 22. Restitucio ville Novi Castri super Tynam.
"Rex omnibus ad quos &c. salutem. Sciatis quod cum nos nuper villam nostram Novi Castri super Tynam que in manibus burgensium ejusdem ville ex concessione progeni∣torum nostrorum quondam Regum Anglie pro certa firma nobis inde annuatim reddend' existit pro quibusdam transgressionibus & excessibus per ipsos burgenses jam de novo in villa predicta factis ceperimus in manum nostram et custodiam ejusdem dilecto & fideli nostro Willielmo de Felton commiserimus habend' quamdiu nostre placuerit voluntati, ita quod nobis de exitibus inde provenientibus responderet ad scaccarium nostrum; nos confiderantes fidelem gestum predictorum burgensium erga nos & progenitores nostros et graves labores quos ipsi & eorum antecessores burgenses burgi illius pro salvatione & defensione ville istius contra Scotos inimicos nostros pluries ante hec tempora subierunt et sumptus et expensus onerosos quos ea de causa et circa clausuram ejusdem ville fecerunt ad instantem requisitionem eorundem burgensium, et pro eo quod ipsi assumpserunt coram nobis & consilio nostro, quod ipsi defectus in muris predicte ville jam imminentes ad sump∣tus suos proprios reparari et dictam villam contra dictos inimicos nostros juxta vires suas salvo et secure in pacem nostram illesam mihi custodiri et delinquentes in eadem villa juxta eorum demerita et secundum legem & consuetudinem regni nostri puniri facient con∣cessimus et restituimus eisdem burgensibus villam predictam cum pertinentiis, habendum et tenendum sibi & successoribus suis cum omnibus libertatibus & liberis consuetudinibus ad eandem villam pertinentibus eodem modo et adeo libere & integre sicut iidem bur∣genses et antecessores sui predicti villam illam ex concessione progenitorum nostrorum predictorum et nostra ante capcionem ejusdem in manum nostram ut premittitur tenuerunt imperpetuum reddendo nobis et heredibus nostris ad scaccarium nostrum firmam ejusdem ville quam iidem burgenses ante capcionem supradictam nobis reddiderunt pro eadem. In cujus rei &c. Teste Rege apud Westmonast' 6 die Maii. Per ipsum Regem et consilium.
"Et mandatum est presato Willielmo quod villam predictam cum pertinentiis prefatis burgensibus liberet habendum juxta tenorem literatum Regis predictarum, vult enim Rex prefatum Willielmum de custodia predicti erga Regem exonerati. Teste ut supra."— (From a MS. copy communicated by Thomas Davidson, Esq) The above is confirmed by the Aubone MS..

October 20th, 1342, the King confirmed the subsequent articles con∣cerning the government of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, which had been agreed upon in full guild, held at the hospital of St. Mary, in Westgate, in that town, on the Friday before Valentine day in that year, and had been sealed under the common seal
"Edwardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie et Francie & Dominus Hibernie ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Inspeximus quasdam litteras per communitatem ville nostre de Novo Castro super Tynam nuper confectas et sigillo communi ejusdem ville signatas in hec verba: Hoc instrumentum testatur quod die Veneris proximo ante festum Sancti Valentini episcopi anno regni Regis Edwardi tertii a conquestu sexto decimo convocata communitate ville Novi Castri super Tynam apud hospital' beate Marie Virginis in le Westgate in plena gilda ejusdem ville tunc ibidem tenta pro bono pacis dilectionis & unitatis confovendo & habendo et pro lege firmius conservanda et manutenenda et ad utilitatem & melioracionem ville predicte de communi assensu & voluntate tocius com∣munitatis predicte assensum est et ordinatum quod de cetero in antea articuli subscripti in predicta villa firmiter teneantur, utantur et conserventur: videlicet,
1. Quod si quis in terrorem pacis in predicta villa per diem vel per noctem aliquam suscitet contumeliam vel dissentionem et se custodibus pacis obedire noluerit nec per illos ut decet secundum legem justiciari quod omnes predicte communitatis in auxilium dictorum pacis custodum cum hutesio et clamore surgant et malefactores capiant et illos secundum legis exigenciam puniant Quod si forte recusaverint aut legitimis impedimentis non prepediti id facere neglexerint, tunc per majorem ville illius qui pro tempore fuerit & viginti et quatuor de duodecim misteriis infrascriptis habito respectu ad statum cujuslibet se reusentis vel negligentis graviter puniantur & amercientur. Quorum quidem amer∣ciamentorum una medietas ad opus Domini nostri Regis levetur et altera medietas in communem utilitatem ville predicte convertatur.
2. Item quod omnes burgenses ville predicte tam pauperes quam divites cujuscunque con∣ditionis existant de omnibus navibus tam forinsecis quam intrinsecis portum ville predicte ingredientibus quibuscunque merchandisis venalibus oneratis possint liberè emere quod eis necesse fuerit Et si quis dictas mercandisas emat in grostum de mercantoribus predictis quod quilibet burgensis dicte ville si voluerit habeat de emptore illo partem mercandisarum illarum prout sibi necesse fuerit pro sustentatione sua et familie sue ad idem precium pro quo dictus emptor de dicto mercatore dictas mercandisas prius emerit solvendo et satis∣faciendo dicto emptori precium partis sue quam emerit infra bordam navis. Et quod per dictos mercatores mehil vendatur de mercandisis illis antequam planckum navi apportur sub poena forisfacture mercandisarum.
3. Item quia plures dissensiones et pericula ante hec tempora evenerunt super elec∣tionibus majoris & ballivorum ville predicte per confederaciones et procurationes, et villa predicta & majoratus ac libertas ejusdem ville in manum Domini Regis ea de causa capti extiterunt, ordinatum est et assensum quod de cetero viginti quatuor de duodecim misteriis honorabilioribus decentioribus & honestoribus ville predicte, viz. de merca∣toribus panni lanei, de mercinariis, de pellipariis, de cissoribus, de celariis, de mercato∣ribus bladi, i. e. bothemen, de pistoribus, de tannatoribus, de allutariis, de carnifi∣cibus, de fabris, & de fullonibus, eligantur quatuor tam de ipsis quam de aliis probiori∣bus melioribus et fidelioribus tocius communitatis ville predicte qui quatuor eligant sibi octo et illi duodecim eligant alios duodecim qui viginti quatuor eligent ma∣jorem ville predicte pro anno tunc proximo futuro et ille major sic electus et juratus cum predictis viginti quatuor electoribus suis eligent ballivos et omnes alios officiarios pro eodem anno.
4. Item ordinatum et concordatum quod quilibet maior, cum ballivis & camerariis suis in fine cujuslibet septimano videant & computent omnes exitus & omnia proficua in villa predicta provenientia & scribuntur in quodam rotelo indentato cujus una pars remaneat versus predictos majorem, ballivos & camerarios et altera pars liberetur pre∣dictis duodecim misteriis ita quod communitus ville predicte scire possunt valorem ejusdem ville in fine cujuslibet anni & qualiter et quomodo exitus et prosicua predicta expen∣duntur, per quod non oporteat vendere exitus nec prosicua ville predicte in detertora∣cionem & depauperacionem communitatis predicte. Et quod nullum scriptum sive munimentum sigilletur cum communi sigillo ville predicte sine consensu consideracione ac inspectione predictorum duodecim misteriorum.
5. Item quod maior & camerarius ville predicte qui pro tempore fuerint de cetero reddant certis auditoribus per predictam communitatem & duodecim misteria predict' electis et juratis computum suum singulis annis infra proximos quindecim dies ante festum Sancti Michaelis Archangeli de omnibus exitibus & proficuis ville predicte.
6. Item concordatum est quod omnes assessores taxarum de cetero eligantur per viginti quatuor misteriorum predictorum cum aliis probis hominibus dicte communitatis qui melius sciant & cognoscant status, conditiones, et facultates communitatis & misteriorum ville predicte Et quod ipsi viginti quatuor habeant contrarotulum taxarum contra assessores, ita quod communitas videre possit quod dicte taxe fideliter fuerint assesse et levate.
7. Item concordatum est quod omnes taxatores & collectores denariorum Domini Regis majores eciam et omnes alii officiarii qui levaverunt taxas et alias collectas de commu∣nitate predicta, reddant compotum certis auditoribus per dictam communitatem et per viginti quatuor de misteriis predictis deputatis & assignatis de taxis & collectis predictis ita quod omnes de communitate possint videre quomodo taxe predicte fuerint lvate et Domino Regi levate ex quo ipsa communitas inde oneratur Intentio tamen dicte commu∣nitatis non existat quin Dominus noster Rex assessores taxatores & collectores ad denarios taxas seu alia bona eidem Domino Regi per communitatem ville predicte concessa vel ex nunc concedend' assidend' levand' et colligend' per alios fideles suos quam per homines communitatis predicte deputare et assignare poterit cum sibi viderit expedire Qui quidem sic deputati et assignati ad compotum inde coram prefatis viginti quatuor hominibus reddend' artari non poterunt nec debeant nisi de mandato ipsius Domini nostri Regis speciali.
8. Item assensum est quod boni usus & consuetudines predicte ville in scriptis redigantur et ponantur et quod copia de eisdem liberetur predictis viginti quatuor misteriorum pre∣dictorum et omnibus aliis burgensibus ville predicte copiam inde habere petentibus ita quod predicti usus & consuetudines ville predicte per ballivos voluntarios non mittentur.
9. Item quod quolibet anno die electionis majoris omnes carte & omnia munimenta libertatem ville predicte tangencia ostendantur et legantur coram communitate ita quod si aliqua carta seu aliquod munimentum elongetur vel perdatur, quod ille vel illi qui in custodia sua illa habuerunt inde respondeant & satisfaciant.
10. Item pro eo quod placita terre per breve sunt placitabilia in curia predicte ville Novi Castri virtute libertatis ejusdem ville pro exheredacione hominum ejusdem ville evitanda assensum est quod rotuli curie predicte ville salvo et bene custodiantur et in thesauro tanquam ea que sunt de recordo ponantur. Et quod capitalis clericus ville pre∣dicte liberet sursum quolibet anno rotulos curie ville predicte dicto die quo major fuerit electus in presencia communitatis. Et si aliquis rotulorum predictorum perdatur vel elongetur respondeat & satisfaciat communitati habito respectu tam ad exheredacionem et perdicionem que parcibus que placitabunt vel placitaverint quam ad dedecus et per∣dicionem curie fuerint facta.
11. See Tyne Bridge.
12. Item quod equa lex fiat et manuteneatur in curia sine mutacione legum et con∣suetudinum scilicet faciendo unam legem pro divite & unam aliam pro paupere et quod judicia in curia predicta reddita secundum legem proficiscantur absque eo quod exe∣cuciones inficiantur seu prorogentur favore dono seu magisterio alicujus ballivi vel alicujus alterius officiarii. Et qui de infectione seu prorogatione executionum predict' convictus fuerit officio suo deleatur.
13. Item quod assisa panis & cerevisie teneatur et manuteneatur secundum legem et quod magistri pistores & non eorum servientes habeant et ferant penitentiam per statutum ordinatam Et quod probacio omnium mensurarum, ulnarum et ponderum bis fiat vel semel per annum ad minus.
14. Item quod catalla felonum liberentur et ponantur in salva custodia illorum qui po∣tentes sunt et terras habent et tenementa et illi qui custodiam inde habuerunt obligentur et heredes sui terras & tenementa sua ad quorumcunque manus devenerint ad respondend' de catallis pred' aut de eorum valore in itinere justiciar' ad salvand' pred' communitatem indempnem ex quo dicta communitas inde onerabitur.
15. Item quod fines illorum qui de aliqua transgressione contra pacem et libertatem ville predicte perpetrata convicti fuerint non relaxentur savore prec' aut procuratione cujusdam nec condomentur.
In cujus rei testimonium sigillum commune ville predicte Novi Castri super Tynam presentibus est appensum Dat' apud dictam villam Novi Castri super Tynam die & anno supradictis Nos autem literas illas et omnia contenta in eisdem ad requisitionem communitatis predicte acceptantes eas quantum in nobis est approbamus & tenore pre∣sencium confirmamus sicut litere predicte rationabiliter testantur. In cujus rei testimo∣nium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste Edward' Duce Cornubie & Comite Cestr' filio nostro carissimo Custode Anglie apud Kenyngton vicesimo die Octobris anno regni nostri Anglie 16o. regni vero nostri Francie 3o."
(From the original charter of Inspeximus, dated 26th February, 6th Ed. IV. remain∣ing in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, to which is affixed an impression on green wax of the great seal of England.).

1. Hue and Cry to be raised against obstinate offenders against the peace of the town, who are to be punished by extremity of law; one half of the fines, imposed on such persons by the mayor and twenty-four of the town, to go to the King, and the other half to the cor∣poration.

2. Every burgess, whether poor or rich, to have the liberty of going on board the ships, either of foreigners or fellow subjects, and of buying merchandize necessary for himself and family at prime cost.
Nor were any goods to be sold in such ships till a plank was laid on board, on pain of forfeiture.

3. Many quarrels and dissensions having arisen concerning the election of mayors and bailiffs of the town, so that the said town, with its mayoralty and liberties, had fallen into the King's hands: it was ordered that, in future, twenty-four of the most respectable brethren of the twelve misteries, i. e. merchants of woollen cloth, mercers, skinners, taylors, sadlers, merchants of corn or boothmen, bakers, tanners, cord∣wainers, butchers, smiths, and fullers, should be chosen in manner fol∣lowing; i. e. each mistery should present two, out of which twenty-four so presented four should be chosen, which four should elect other eight, in all twelve persons, which twelve should choose other twelve, by which twenty-four so chosen as above, the mayor for the year ensuing should be elected: which mayor so chosen and sworn, with his twenty-four electors, was to proceed to the election of bailiffs, and other officers of the corporation.

4. The mayor, with the bailiffs and their chamberlains, was to cast
up the accounts of the corporation every week, and ingross them upon a roll indented; one part whereof was to be kept in the hands of the mayor, bailiffs, and chamberlains, and the other by the twelve mis∣teries; and no writing or muniment was to be sealed with the common seal of the town, without the consent and inspection of the misteries aforesaid.
5. Certain auditors were to be chosen, and sworn to make account yearly, within fifteen days before Michaelmas, of the issues and profits of the town.

6. All assessors of taxes were to be chosen by the twenty-four of the misteries aforesaid, who were to be in possession of the counter part of the taxation roll against the assessors, to satisfy the community that taxes were faithfully levied.

7. All taxors and collectors were to give account to certain auditors
assigned by the above twenty-four, except the King's assessors, who were not to account to such auditors without the royal command.
8. The uses and customs of the town were to be committed to writing, whereof a copy was to be delivered to the twenty-four of the misteries aforesaid, and to such other burgesses as should desire it.

9. On the day of electing the mayor in every year, all the charters and muniments that respected the liberties of the town were to be produced and read before the commonalty thereof, and the keeper of them was to be answerable for any that should be purloined or lost.

10. Pleas of land by writ being pleadable in the courts of the town by virtue of the liberties thereof, it was ordered, to prevent the disin∣heriting of the townsmen, that the rolls of these courts should be kept safely in the treasury as matters of record, and be produced yearly on the day of choosing the mayor, by the chief clerk of the town, who also was to be accountable to the commonalty for any of them that might be purloined or lost.
11. See under account of Tyne Bridge.

12. An equal law was to be kept in that court for poor and rich; the plaints brought in it were to go forward according to law. Exe∣cutions were not to be corrupted by favour, reward or interest, on pain of removal from office.

13. The assizes of bread and beer were to be held according to law, and the master bakers, and not their servants, to suffer the penalties ordered by statute. Measures, ells, and weights to be proved twice, or at least once a year.

14. The chattels of such felons as were of ability, and had lands and tenements, were to be delivered, and put into safe custody: the keepers of such chattels, and their heirs, were to answer for them to the jus∣tices itinerant, so as to keep the commonalty indemnified.
15. The fines of such persons as had been convicted of any trans∣gression against the peace and interest of the said town, were not to be remitted or forgiven them, on any account whatsoever.

October 24th, 1345,
"Edwardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie et Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Licet nuper pro quibusdam contemptibus et transgres∣sionibus nobis per quosdam homines de communitate ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam factis dictam villam cum libertatibus & omnibus aliis ad villam illam pertinentibus capi fece∣rimus in manum nostram. Volentes tamen pretextu boni gestus quondam burgensium tam in eadem villa commorantium qui de hujusmodi contemptibus & transgressionibus ut accepi∣mus sunt immunes et ut ipsi de cetero majorem diligenciam de pace nostra in eadem villa conservanda et malefactoribus puniend' apponant cum eisdem agere generose restituimus burgensibus ejusdem ville villam predictam cum pertinentiis habend' et tenend' sibi heredibus & successoribus suis cum omnibus libertatibus per cartas progenitorum nostrorum quondam regum Anglie seu nostras prefatis burgensibus vel eorum anteces∣soribus concessis ac omnibus aliis liberis consuetudinibus ad eandem villam priusquam capta extitit in manum nostram tenuerunt imperpetuum, reddendo inde nobis, et heredi∣bus nostris ad scaccarium nostrum antiquam firmam ville supradicte salva nobis accione nostra versus ipsos de dicta villa Novi Castri qui transgressiones & contemptus predictos perpetrarunt de transgressionibus et contemptibus illis cum voluerimus versus eos inde loqui Et quia ante hec tempora plures dissenciones & discordie super electione majoris ville predicte oriebantur volumus et de consilio nostro ordinavimus quod electio majoris pre dicti de cetero fiat in forma que sequitur, viz. quod major ville predicte et quatuor ballivi sui singulis annis die Lune proxime post festum Sancti Michaelis Archangeli in Gild-halla ville conveniant & ibidem septem de probioribus & melioribus hominibus jusdem ville eligi faciant et illi duodes im eligant quatuor homines de communitate pre∣dicta tam de seipsis quam de aliis et ipsi quatuor jurati eligant octo de melioribus & discretioribus hominibus ville predicte et illi duodecim jurati eligant alios duodes im de melioribus & discretioribus post ipsos. Qui viginti et quatuor sic electi et jurati eligant unum majorem pro anno tunc futuro et ille major sic electus et juratus cum predictis viginti & quatuor electoribus eligat ballivos & omnes alios ministros & officiar' ville predicte pro eodem anno et quilibet electorum predict' juret super sancta Dei Evangelia quod sine consideratione vel affectione alicui persone habenda, illos qui magis idonei et sufficientes pro nobis et regimine populi nostri ac conservatione pacis nostre in villa pre∣dicta fiant, eligent pro officiis supradictis et quascumque alias ordinaciones de majore ville predicte per homines de misteriis dicte ville eligendo ante hec tempora factis etiamsi per nos confirmate fuerint duximus revocand' et omnino evacuand' In cujus rei testimo∣nium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud Westmon' vicesimo quarto die Octobris anno regni nostri Anglie decimo nono regni vero nostri Francie sexto. Per breve de privato sigillo. Woll."
(From the original remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.) the King regranted the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, which had been again seized into his hands, to the bur∣gesses
thereof, and ordered that the future election of mayors, &c. should be in the following manner, i. e. that in every year on the Monday next after Michaelmas, the mayor and four bailiffs should meet in the Guild-hall of that town, and cause seven reputable and discreet burgesses to be elected to themselves, which twelve should choose four men of the commonalty, who, being sworn, should elect eight others; which twelve should elect other twelve, and they, being twenty-four in number, should, after having been sworn, elect a mayor for the ensuing year; which mayor so elected and sworn, with his twenty-four electors, should proceed to the election of bailiffs and other officers, and that each elector should swear that, without favour or affection, he would choose the fittest and ablest persons for the peace and good government of the town. The former order, dated October 20th, 1342, was revoked on this oc∣casion.

November 4th, 1345, the town of Newcastle upon Tyne was again seized into the King's hands for new transgressions, and by him com∣mitted to the charge of Henry de Percy, Ralph de Nevill, John de Fenwyk, Walter de Creyk, and Robert de Fenwyk, sheriff of North∣umberland
"Fines 18 Ed. III. m. 11. de libertatibus ville Novi Castri super Tynam in manum Regis capiend'. Rex dilectis & fidelibus suis Henrico de Percy, Ranulpho de Nevill, Johanni de Fenwyk, Waltero de Creyk & Roberto de Fenwyke vicecomiti Northum∣brie salutem Quia pro quibusdam contemptibus & inobedientiis notoriis nobis per majorem et communitatem ville Novi Castri super Tynam noviter factis, de assensu consilii nostri ordinavimus quod libertates ville predicte in manum nostram capiantur et de secura cus∣todia ville illius provideatur.
"Nos de fidelitate & circumspectione vestris plenius confidentes assignavimus vos quatuor tres & duos vestrum quorum alterum vestrum vos prefati Henrice & Radulphe unum esse volumus ad libertates predict' in manum nostram capiend' et ad dictam villam cum omnibus ad eam spectantibus salvo et secure custodiend' quousque aliud inde duxerimus ordinand' et ideo vobis mandamus firmiter injungentes quod premissa faciatis et exequamini effectualiter in forma antedicta volentes semper quod probi homines ville predicte benigne pertractentur & rationabiliter educantur. Damus autem uni∣versis et singulis ville predicte tenore presencium in mandatis quod vobis quatuor tribus & duobus vestrum quorum alterum vestrum vos prefati Henrice & Radulphe unum esse volumus in premissis omnibus & singulis intendentes sicut obedientes et respondentes prout eis scire feceritis ex parte nostra. In cujus rei &c. Teste Rege apud Melford quarto die Novembris.—Per breve de privato sigillo.
(From a MS. copy communicated by Thomas Davidson, Esq clerk of the peace for Northumberland).

By a patent letter of the great seal, dated January 26th, 1346, the King committed the custody of Newcastle upon Tyne to Robert de Tughale, whom the former committee of five had appointed their deputy, with a salary of forty pounds per annum for that service: he was to answer for the issues of the town and liberties at the King's Exchequer, and to see the town safely keptMadox's Firma Burgi, p. 258..
Some time this year the town was again restored into the hands of the burgesses thereofAubone MS. "But in the 19th year they were restored.".

In the year 1348 the King granted a patent for a custom to be levied for the purpose of repairing and securing the walls and fortifica∣tions of Newcastle upon Tyne"Pat. 21 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 1, de consuetud' pro vill' ibidem claudend." (Astle's MS. Note of Charters relating to Newcastle upon Tyne.).

The year following there was a patent granted for an aqueduct to convey water to that townAubone MS.—Also Murray's MS. "Novum Castrum super Tynam. Confirm' pro fabric' pipor' ducentium aquam ibidem. Pat. 22 Ed. III. p. 3, m. 16.".

A. D. 1351 licence was granted to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne to dig stones and coals in a place called Castle-FieldAubone MS.—Also Murray MS.—"Novum Castrum super Tynam. Licen' sodiendi carbon' et petr' extra mures civitat' in locis vocatis le Castle Feld. Pat. 24 Ed. III. p. ... m. 6.".

May 10th, 1358, the King granted the royalty of Castle-Field and Castle-Moor, an
"Et quia ex parte dilectorum nobis burgensium ejusdem ville nobis est supplicatum ut cum mora et terra vocat' Castel-Feld et Castell-More ex parte boreali dicte ville Novi Castri de quadam placea vocata Ingler-Dike per metas positas usque ad quandam placeam vocatam le Thornbusk juxta crucem et deinde per certas divisas et metas positas versus dictam villam Novi Castri usque furcas et sic inter postes furcarum ita quod una postis stat in marchia inter terram prioris de Tynemuth et terram dicte ville Novi Castri et sic usque le Quarel-Dyk et deinde per viam regiam usque ad candem villam Novi Castri, sunt terra et solum dicte ville Novi Castri pertinentia ad candem a tempore quo non extat me∣moria cum omnibus proficuis de eisdem terra, mora & solo provenientibus prout per inqui∣sitionem inde per certos fideles nostros de mandato nostro captam et in cancellaria nostra retornatam (In the Murray MS. occurs the following entry: "Novum Castrum super Tynam. Inquisicio de metis et bundis in terr' ibidem vocat' Castel-Feld & terr' prioris de Tynemuth anno 31 Ed. III. No. 56.") est compertum. Et licet ipsi burgenses et corum predecessores a tempore quo dictam villam cum pertinentiis sic ad firmam habuerunt dictas moram & terram vocat' Castle-Feld et Castel-More tanquam pertinentia ad villam pre∣dictam tenuerunt et omnia proficua de eisdem mora et terra provenientia habuerint et per∣ceperint semper hactenus pacifice & quiete: dicti tamen burgenses pro eo quod de dictis mora & terris licet de pertinentiis dicte ville existant, in carta predicta mentio facta non existat, metuunt se posse imposterum impetiri dictaque villa tam propter ultimam pestilen∣ciam quam propter guerrarum discrimina et alias varias adversitates adeo sit depaupertata et hominibus destituta, quod proficua ejusdem ville ad solucionem firme predicte non sufficiunt, velimus eorum indempnitati in hac parte providere. Nos ad bona et utilia ob∣sequia per burgenses ville predicte nobis et progenitoribus impensa et ad labores sumptus et onera gravia que ipsi circa salvacionem & defensionem dicte ville a longo tempore sus∣tinuerunt et indies sustinent considerationem habentes ac volentes proinde graciose agere cum eisdem, concessimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris quod predicti burgenses et eorum heredes habeant et teneant moram et terram predictas per metas & divisas predictas tan∣quam pertinentes ad villam predictam cum omnibus proficuis de eisdem mora et terra infra metas et divisas predict' fodere et minera carbonum et petrarum ibidem habere et car∣bones et petras inde extrahere et commodum suum de eisdem carbonibus & petris ac aliis proficuis de eisdem mora et terra provenientibus in auxilium solucionis firme sue predicte facere possint, prout eis melius & utilius videbitur expedire absque impedimento nostri vel heredum nostrorum justiciariorum, escaetorum, vicecomitum & aliorum ballivorum seu ministrorum nostrorum quorumeunque Hiis testibus venerabilibus patribus S. Archie∣piscopo Cantuarie tocius Anglie Primate, W. Wynton' Episcopo cancellario nostro et J. Roff' Episcopo thesaurario nostro Willielmo de Bohun Northampton Ricardo Arundell Rogero de Mortuo Mari March et Radulpho Stafford Comitibus Henrico de Percy Radulpho de Nevill Johanne de Grey & Rotherfold senescallo hospicii nostri et aliis. Dat' per manum nostram apud Westmonasterium decimo Die Maii anno regni nostri Anglie tricesimo primo regni vero nostri Francie decimo octavo" (From a charter of Inspeximus dated February 26th, 6 Ed. IV. in which the above follows King Edward the Third's confirmation of the charter of 17th of John, and that of the 12th of Edward the Second.) See also Murray MS.—"Novum Castrum super Tynam. Licen' fodiendi car bon' et petr' extra muros civitatis in loco vocato le Castel-Feld."
"Pat. 3t Ed. III. p. 1, m. 5, dorso.—Vid commiss' tangent' eandem materiam, m. 25." extensive track of land to the north of that town, to the burgesses thereof, who had before the property of the land and soil. In their petition to the crown for this privilege, which empower∣ed them to dig mines of coals and work stones there, they set forth that these places were the soil of that town, which, although they had been held from time immemorial with their appurtenances, by them and their predecessors by a fee-farm, yet they apprehended that as no express mention was made of them in any charter, their right to them might be called in question; pleading at the same time their distresses by former wars and the late very grievous pestilence. Castle-Field and Castle-Moor are limited in this charter from a place called then Ingler-Hedge, towards the east, by boundaries extending to a thorn-bush near the cross, and from thence by certain divisions and boundaries set up towards the town of Newcastle as far as the gallows (one part of which stood upon the land of the prior of Tinmouth, and the other on that of Newcastle) to the hedge of the Quarry, and then by the King's highway to the said town of Newcastle.

In the year 1363 the King granted an exemplification of the above charter, dated May 10th, 1358Aubone MS. This authority adds a clause, of which it is difficult to guess the mean∣ing. "And a grant made to the mayor for years.".

A. D. 1364 the royal licence for the acquisition of certain lands was granted to the town of NewcastlePro statuitate Novo Castro super Tynam facta ad terrae acquirenda Pat. 37 Ed. III p. 1, m. 2, tom. iv. Rot.' Turr' London.—Wallis's History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 190..
