The year following there was an ordinance made concerning the manner of choosing the mayor and other officers of that townMurray MS.—"Novum Castrum super Tynam. Ordinacio fact' de modo major' et aliorum officiar' ibidem eligend.' (Pat. 38 Ed. III. p. 2, m. 34.).
A. D. 1368 a patent occurs concerning the measuring of sea coals at NewcastleIbid. "Novum Castrum super Tynam. De carbon' marit' mensurand' Pat. 41 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 11, 12 & 19, & m. 16, dorso.".

May 1st, 1371, the King, at the request of the burgesses of New∣castle upon Tyne, reconfirmed the ordinances made at that place on the Friday before Valentine-day, and confirmed by the King October 20th following, but which had been set aside October 24th, 1345"Nos autem tenorem literarum nostrarum predictarum ad requisitionem proborum hominum ville predicte duximus exemplificand' per presentes. In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud Westmonasterium primo die Maii anno regni nostri Anglie quadragesimo quinto regni nostri vero Francie tricesimo secundo." (The above immediately follows the confirmation dated 20th of October, 1342.).

July 28th, 1375, a charter of exemplification of several charters to the town of Newcastle was granted by the King at the request of Robert Hales, prior of the hospital of St. John of JerusalemFrom the original remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne; the seal is lost..
A. D. 1377 an inquisition concerning the bounds of Castle-Field before-mentioned, and the right to the soil there, appears to have been exemplifiedAubone MS..

June 10th, 1378, King Richard II. confirmed the ordinances made by the commonalty of Newcastle upon Tyne, on the Friday before Va∣lentine-day, 1342, with their former charters and privileges"Nos autem Rex Ricardus supradictus assensum et concordiam et omnes & singulos articulos supradictos in dictis literis contentos ratos habentes et gratos, eos pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est prefate communitati & successoribus suis tenore presencium ratificamus concedimus et confirmamus prout litere predicte supradicte plemus testantur preterea volentes pro bono pacis dilectionis & unitatis consovendo & pro lege firmius conservando & manutenendo ac pro utilitate & melioracione ville predicte que in tot adversis & periculis consistit eidem communitati de assensu consilii predicti et hac curia nostra confirmavimus pro nobis & heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est eidem communitati & successoribus suis quod licet ipsi aliquo vel aliquibus assensus concordie seu articulorum supradictorum aliquo casu emergente hactenus plenè usi non fuerint, eadem tamen communitas & successores sui assensu concordia & articulis supradictis et eorum quolibet de cetero plene gaudeant et utantur ac eos plene exerceant imper∣petuum sine occasione vel impedimento nostri vel heredum nostrorum justiciariorum escaetorum vicecomitum aut aliorum ballivorum seu ministrorum nostrorum quorum∣cunque Hiis testibus venerabilibus patribus W. London' A. Meneven' cancellario nostro Tho. Exon' thesaurario nostro et Ricardo Sar' Episcop' Johanne Rege Castelle & Le∣gionis Duce Lancastrie avunculo nostro carissimo Willielmo de Ufford Comite Suff. Johanne Domino de Nevell et Henrico Lescrop et Ricardo de Stafford Bancrettis & Jo∣hanne de Fordham custode privati sigilli nostri & aliis. Dat' per manum nostram apud Westmonast' decimo die Junii anno regni nostri primo."—From the original charter of Inspeximus remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, dated Feb. 26th, in the sixth of Edward IV..

In the year 1385, a decisive decree was obtained against the Bishop of Durham, who had invaded the liberties and privileges of the mayor and community of Newcastle upon TyneQuod gaudeant major et communitas Novi Castri super Tynam libertatibus et pri∣vilegiis concessis preceptum est Episc' Dunelm' claus. 8 Ric. II. In initio rotuli et in dorso in 51 intus inter Episc' p. 100, et in 42 dorso."—Wallis' History of Northumber∣land, vol. ii. p. 204..

A. D. 1387 there was an assignment to the mayor and bailiffs of Newcastle to take workmen to repair the walls, the defects whereof they had petitioned to have surveyed in the year 1379
Aubone MS.
In a book of inrolments preserved in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle, fol. 33, the following occurs: "Anno 3 Ric. II. ut videtur supplicarunt homines et burgenses ville predicte ad supervidend' in mur' ville predicte.".

The King by his letters patent, dated January 25th, 1391, granted to William Bishopdale, then mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne, and to all his successors in that office, to have a sword borneRicardus Dei gracia Rex Anglie & Francie & Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Sciatis quod nos considerantes honorem ville Novi Castri super Tynam de gratia nostra speciali concessimus dilecto nostro Willielmo Bishop∣dale nunc majori ejusdem ville quamdiu ipse maior fuerit et omnibus aliis qui pro tem∣pore futur' majores erunt ville predicte quod ipsi unum gladium ante eos portatum habere possint. Quem quidem gladium dare concessimus ex causa supradicta In cujus rei testi∣monium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westmonasterium vicesimo quinto die Januarii anno regni nostri quarto decimo." before them in honour of the town
Sword-bearers of Newcastle.
John Lasseles buried Julie 1582.—St. Nicholas' Register.
Francis Comynge occurs ibid. 1582.
Ralph Rawe, buried October 3d, 1596. (Ibid.)
Robert Wynter occurs ibid. May 31, 1601.
Matthew Randell occurs ibid. January 1619.
Charles Metcalf occurs in the Common-council books, July 9th, 1660.
Gerard Robson, ibid. October 7th, 1700.
Timothy Tully, appointed July 9th, 1711, on the death of Robson.
Anthony Tully.
Sept. 7th, 1732, James Hall surrendered—had been appointed on the death of A. Tully.
October 6th, 1732, Robert Makepeace.
Sept. 10th, 1745, Nathaniel Bayles, on the resignation of R. Makepeace..

It appears that, in the year 1394, some pieces of ground within the town of Newcastle were granted, by the King, to the burgesses thereof, for the convenience of making highways and a bridge. This was pro∣bably for the building of the Low-Overdeen bridge in Newcastle"De quibusdam placeis terre in Novo Castro super Tynam burgensibus ibidem con∣cessis pro ponte & viis construend'. Pat. 18 Ric. II. p. 2, m. 27 & 40, tom. iv. Rot' Turr' London."—Wallis' History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 190..

April 27th, 1400, King Henry IV. confirmed all the former grants and customs that had been made to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, notwithstanding their non-use of themInspeximus eciam quasdam literas patentes presati Domini Ricardi nuper Regis Anglie &c. (The grant of the sword follows) Nos autem donaciones concessiones dimissi∣ones, libertates, confirmationes, assensum et concordiam predictam ac omnia & singula in cartis et literis predictis contenta rata habentes et grata ea pro nobis &c. confirmamus &c. Hiis testibus venerabilibus patribus Th. Cantuarie Aschiepiscopo tocius Anglie Pri∣mate R. London' J. Elien' W. Dunolm' Episcopis Edmundo Duce Ebori avunculo nostro carissimo Henrico Northumbrie constabular' Anglie Radulpho Westint mariscal' An he Johanne Somers cameratio nostro comitibus Johanne de Scarle cancellario Johanne de Norburi thesaurario nostris Johanne de Coffeham chivaler Thoma de Kempston senescallo hospicii nostri Magistro Ricardo de Clifford custode privati sigilli nostri et aliis. Data per manum nostram apud Westmonasterium vicesimo septimo die Aprilis anno regni nostri primo." (From a charter of Inspeximus, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, dated February 26th, in the 6th of Edward IV.).

By a charter dated May 23d, 1400"Henricus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie et Dominus Hibernie archiepiscopis &c. salutem. Sciatis quod de gratia nostra speciali in melioracionem succursum et relevamen ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam ac burgensium nostrorum ejusdem ville heredum & successorum suorum concessimus eisdem burgensibus ac eorum heredibus et successori∣bus imperpetuum quod dicta villa cum suburbiis suis et precinctu eorumdem juxta fines et bundas prout antiquitus debite limitabantur que modo infra corpus comitatus Northum∣brie existunt et continentur ab eodem comitatu exnunc separata sint et exempta tam per terram quam per aquam et quod dicta villa et suburbia ejusdem & eorum precinctus de cetero sint comitatus per se et comitatus ville Novi Castri super Tynam nuncupatus im∣perpetuum Et quod predicti burgenses et eorum heredes et successores imperpetuum habeant infra villam suburbia & precinctum predicta franchesias privilegia & liber∣tates subscripta et iis et eorum quolibet de cetero plene gaudeant & utantur. Vide∣licet quod dicti burgenses et eorum heredes & successores habeant imperpetuum loco bal∣livorum ejusdem ville unum vicecomitem in eisdem villa suburbiis & precinctu et vice-comitatum ejusdem ville Novi Castri Qui quidem vicecomes in forma subscripta annuatim eligatur et perficietur, videlicet quod dicti burgenses quolibet anno quando necesse fuerit per viginti et quatuor de magis idoneis discretioribus probioribus & honestioribus burgen∣sibus dicte ville tam de scriptis quam de aliis comburgensibus suis eligent unam personam idoneam in vicecomitem ville suburbiorum & precinctus predictorum. Qui quidem vice∣comes statim post electionem hujusmodi sacramentum suum coram majore ville predicte qui pro tempore fuerit in forma debita prestabit cujus nomen sub sigillo communi dicte ville in cancellariam nostram vel heredum nostrorum annuatim mittetur imperpetuum. Ita semper quod idem vicecomes de omnibus exitibus de officio illo provenientibus nobis & heredibus nostris respondeat ad scaccharium nostrum & heredum nostrotum predicto∣rum et quod aliquo tempore futuro aliquis alius vicecomes in dicta villa suburbris & pre∣dinctu nisi de scipsis ut predictum est non existat Et quod idem vicecomes ville Novi Castri tales habeat potestatem & jurisdiccionem ad quaecunque alia ad officium vicecomites perti∣nentia in eisdem villa suburbiis & precinctu faciend' prout ceteri vicecomites nostri alibi infra regnum nostrum Anglie habent et quod vicecomes ville Novi Castri teneat comita∣tum suum ibidem per diem Mercurii de mense in mensem eodem modo et prout alii vice∣comites nostri alibi in eodem regno comitatus suos tenent Et quod dictus vicecomes dicte ville Novi Castri qui pro tempore exist' quolibet anno prosicuum suum fac'et computare possit coram thesauratio & baronibus de scaccario nostro et heredum nostrorum per suffi∣cientes attornatos ipsius vicecomitis ejusdem ville ad hoc deputatos et deputandos per lite∣ras patentes sub communi sigillo dicte ville signatas et signandas de quibuscunque rebus unde computabilis fuerit officium vicecomitis tangentibus. Et quod attornati illi ad pro∣ficuum & computum hujusmodi faciend' et reddend' loco ipsius vicecomitis per thesaura∣rios & barones predictos juxta vim et effectum literarum predictarum admittantur. Con∣cessimus etiam et hac carta nostra confirmavimus pro nobis & heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est eisdem burgensibus et eorum heredibus & successoribus imperpetuum quod nullus eorum implicitet aut implicitetur extra villam predictam de aliquibus tenementis vel tenuris infra eandem villam ac suburbia & precinctum ejusdem existentibus seu de aliqui∣bus transgressionibus convencionibus vel aliis contractibus quibuscunque infra eandem villam suburbia & precinctum emergentibus sed quod major et vicecomes ville predicto pro tempore existen' habeant et uterque eorum per se habeat cogniciones omnium placi∣torum tam realium quam personalium sive mixtarum de omnibus terris terements et tenuris infra villam suburbia & precinctum ejusdem predicta existen' necnon de omni∣modis transgressionibus, convencionibus et aliis contractibus quibuscunque infra eandem villam suburbia & precinctum emergentibus sive facts coram eis vel utro eorum in Guy∣halda ville predicte tenend' et debite terminand' tam in presencia nostra et heredum nos∣trorum quam in absencia nostra et heredem nostrorum. Ita quod senescalli & marescalli de cognitionibus placitorum de hujusmodi transgressionibus convencionibus aut contracti∣bus infra villam suburbia & precinctum predicta emergentibus se nullatenus intromittant nisi duntaxat de transgressionibus convenionibus & contractibus in hospicio nostro ethere∣dum nostrorum et inter illos qui sunt de eodem hospicio factis. Et quod predicti bur∣genses aut eorum heredes seu successores non ponantur in assisis juratis seu aliis inquisitio∣nibus quibuscunque ratione terrarum aut ten' suorum infra villam suburbia et precinctum predicta existencium extra eandem villam. Et ulterius de uberiori gracia nostra concessi∣mus pro nobis et heredibus nostris predictis presatis burgensibus et eorum heredibus et successoribus imperpetuum quod ipsi singulis annis de se ipsis eligere possint sex alderman∣nes tociens quociens necesse fuerit. Et quod predicti major et aldermanni ac eorum heredes & successores major et aldermanni ville predicte qui pro tempore fuerint seu qu∣tuor, tres, vel duo eorum cum dicto majore habeant plenam potestatem & auctoritatem ad inquirend' audiend' et terminand' omnes materias querelas defectus causas et articulo qui ad officium justic' pacis servientum laboratorum et artificum debite' pertinent ad cor∣rectionem & punicionem inde adeo plenè et integre sicut justic' pacis servientum or∣torum et artificum in aliis comitatibus regni nostri Anglie ante hec tempore habuerunt vel excrenerunt absque eo quod justic' pacis servientum laboratorum & artificum nostri vel heredum nostrorum in comitatu Northumbrie se imposterum aliqualiter intromittant de aliquibus causis querelis materiis defectibus seu alus articulis quibuscunque ad justic' pacis servientum laboratorum et artificum spectantibus seu pertinentibus infra villam suburbia et precinctum predicta ex causa quacunque emergentibus seu contingentibus. Ita quod prefati major & aldermanni seu eorum successores ad determinationem alicujus lome absque aliquo speciali mandato nostro vel heredum nostrorum quoquomodo non precedant. Cencessimus insuper pro nobis & heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est eisdem burgensbus & eorum heredibus & successoribus imperpetuum quod major et vice∣comes ville predicte pro tempore existentes habeant et teneant et uterque eorum per se habeat et teneat curias suas ville predicte prout maior et ballivi ejusdem ville curias suas ibidem hec tempora virtute libertatum iis per cartam progenitorum nostrorum quon∣d, regm Anglie in hac parte concessar' racionabilitr habuerunt et tenuerunt ac pro∣sua inde provedencia habeant et prcipiant prout fidem major & ballivi ea ante presen∣tem concessionem nostram virtate libertatum predictarum eis sic prius concessarum racio∣biliter habea runt et perceperunt salvis semper nobis et heredibus nostris omnibus & singulis sinibus redencionibus aut reiamentis exitibus forisfactis, et alus profictris quibus tn de officio vicecomitatu preliei et de placiris unde cogniciones vigore pre∣sentis carte nostre novo habent & habebunt quam de justic' pacis servientum laborato∣rum & artificum predictoriam quireunque prevenentibus imprpetuum. Quare et firmiter pre pro nobis & nostri quatum in nobis est quod burgenses & heredes et spand predict' burgenses ville predict' habeant libertates & quian predict' imperpetuum sicut predictum est et eis et earum qualitet de cetero plene lnt et tur. Hiis testibus venerabiliti partribus Thoma Archiepascopo Carturam Anglie Primate R. London' W. Winton' H. Lancoln' . Exon' Episcopis Edmundo Duce Ebori avunculo nostro carissimo, Thoma War' Hco Northumbr' Radalphus Westmerland Conntibus Johanne de Sae Johanne Nostur' th menis nostris Willielmo de Roos de Hancl Willielmo de Willughl Johanne de Cobhara Thoma Renston suo allo hospi nostri militibus Ma∣gistro Ricardo de Clifford custods privati sigilli nostri et aliis. Dat' per manum nostrum apud Westmonasterum vicemo terero die Mari anno regni nostri primo." (From a char∣ter of Inspeximus, dated Febuarary th, 6 Ed. IV. remaining in the archive of the cor∣poration of Newcastle upon Tyne) For an old seal of the office of sheriff of New st, see Seals, Plate I. No. 6. Legend. "S. Ost. vic' Novi Castri sup Tinam.", the King granted that New∣castle upon Tyne, with the suburbs and precincts thereof, according
to the ancient limits then belonging to the county of Northumber∣land, should be separated from thence, and be a county of itself, with
the title of the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne; and that the burgesses thereof, instead of bailiffs as formerly, should have a sheriff to be chosen annually, by twenty-four of the most reputable of that number: this sheriff so chosen to be sworn before the mayor of the town for the time being, have his name sent up every year to chancery, and be answerable to the Exchequer for the annual profits of his office; to have the same power as other sheriffs of counties had, and the privilege of holding a county court on one Wednesday in every month; and to reckon before the Barons of the Exchequer, by
his sufficient attorneys deputed for that purpose by letters patent under the common seal of that town—that none of the burgesses should plead or be impleaded without that town concerning any tenements or tenures within the same, its suburbs, or the precinct thereof, or con∣cerning any offences, or other matters arising there, but that the mayor and sheriff should have cognizance of all pleas in the Guild-hall of the town. That the said burgesses and their heirs should be exempt from serving on juries without the town; that they should have power to choose six aldermen, who, with the mayor, should be justices of peace, and that the mayor and sheriff should continue to hold the annual courts heretofore held by the mayor and bailiffs.

July 7th, 1400, the King, at the request of his loyal burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, pardoned them their share of a subsidy of one fifteenth and one tenth, that just before had been granted by the parlia∣ment, to be payable at Martinmas and Easter following"Henricus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie et Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem. Sciatis quod cum communitates regni nostri Anglie in ultimo parliamento nostro apud Westmon' tento concesserint nobis unam quintam de∣cimam et unam decimam ad certos dies solvend' videlicet unam medietatem inde ad seslum Sancti Martini in yeme proxim' futur' et aliam medietatem ad festum Pasche exturae proxim' sequens. Nos de gratia nostra speciali et ad supplicationem dilectorum ligeorum nostrorum burgensium et communitatis ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam perdona∣vimus et relaxavimus eisdem burgensibus & communitati et eorum cuilibet quicquid ad nos pertinet de quinta decima et decima predictis pro villa predicta occasione concessionis supradicte. In cujus rei testimonium lias litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud Westmon' 7o die Julii anno regni nostri primo per ipsum Regem. Gaunstede." (From the original remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, inscribed dorso: "Henry the Fourth's release to the town of Newcastle of a subsidy of one 15th and one 10th, granted by act of parliament.".

August 16th, 1403, the King granted to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, all fines, redemptions, amerciaments, issues and forfeitures, and other profits in all pleas whereof cognizance had before been granted to the said mayor and burgesses, for the support, emendation, and reparation of the walls and bridge of that town"Henricus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie & Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem. Sciatis quod de gratia nostra speciali concessimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est dilectis nobis majori & burgensibus ville de Novo Castro super Tynam heredibus & successoribus suis imperpetuum omnia et singula fines redemptiones et amerciamenta ac exitus & forisfacturas et alia proficua quecunque tam de omnibus placitis quorum cognitionem eisdem majori & burgensibus nuper concessimus quam de justiciariis pacis, servientum laboratorum et artificum quali∣tercumque provenientia sive emergentia infra villam predictam per ministros ipsorum majoris & burgensium recipienda & habenda in supportationem emendacionem & repa∣rationem murorum et pontis ville supradicte. In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud castrum de Pontefracto sexto decimo die Au∣gusti anno regni nostri quarto." Pat. 4 Hen. IV. p. 2, m. 11. Murray MS.—Also Gyll's interleaved Bourne. Ex copia communicat' per Josh' Douglas, arm'.

The King, by a patent, dated Nov. 20th, 1403, on a petition in parliament, pardoned and released to the men of the counties of North∣umberland, Cumberland, and Newcastle upon Tyne, all escapes of felons, fines, issues and amerciaments, with all kinds of tenths, fif∣teenths, &c. on account of the grievous injuries they had sustained by the Scots, and their great losses by the falling of bridges, occasioned by sudden inundations of waters, and on account of the great expences of the men of Newcastle, in keeping several of their ships well victualled and armed at sea, and in supporting a nightly wateh by an hundred men on the walls, for the defence of the town and country adjacentRotuli Parliamentor. vol. iii. Appendix, p. 668, A. D. 1403..

A receipt occurs, dated November 12th, 1419, by which it appears that an annuity of 90l. 16s. 8d. payable to Ralph, Earl of Westmore∣land, Lord de Neville, was charged upon the fee-farm of Newcastle upon Tyne: it appears to have been granted to the Neville family for ever, by letters patent of Edward III. dated at Henley, July 16th, in the 26th year of his reign"Radulphus Comes Westmorland Dominus de Nevile et Marescallus Anglie notum facit recipisse de majore vic' & hominibus ville Novi Castri super Tynam quater vigint' et 10l. 16s. et 8d. nobis debit' ad festum Sancti Michaelis ult' preterit' de feoda firma ville pre∣dicte pro anno ultimo preterito in plenam solucionem arreragiorum &c. Dat' 12 die Novembris anno 8vo. Hen. V." (Seal).

It appears that, in the year 1423, King Henry VI. made a grant to
the mayor, sheriff, and commonalty of Newcastle upon Tyne, of cer∣tain customs to be taken of every ship in the port of that townAubone MS. Also in a book of inrolments remaining in the archives of the corpo∣ration of Newcastle upon Tyne, I found the following entry: "Anno 2 Hen. VI. cre major' vic' et tot' communiati ville predicte confiretudines &c. de qualibet ve &c."— See Tolls before tempore Hen. I..

May 27th, 1433, the King, in consideration of the great distresses and burthens that had long been undergone by his liege subjects, the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, the grievous losses in shipping and merchandises on the sea, the desolation of the adjacent country, the dearness of corn in those parts, an approaching war with the Scots, and the great scarcity of inhabitants occasioned by a pestilence in the preceding year, remitted to them all kinds of taxes, talliage, tenths and fifteenths, and moieties of tenths and fifteenths, which had been granted him by the last parliament"Henricus Dei gratia Rex Anglie et Francie & Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pvenerint salutem. Sciatis quod nos considerantes immersa li∣beres custus et one a que dilecti ligri nostri major & communitas ville nostre de Novo Castro super Tynam pro salva custodia et tuicione ejusdem ville nostre a longe tempe habuerunt et sustinuerunt ac dampa et deperdita quamplurima que eisdem ligis nostris de navibus et mercandisis suis super mate evenerunt nec non debilitatem & vastum et desolacionem patrie adjacentis caristiamque bladorum in partibus illis ac eciam guerrara ibidem per inimicos Scocie imminentem et non modicam multitudinem dictam villam in∣habitantium a pstilentia anno proxime prterito defuntorum; pro quibus quidem one∣ribus et causis premiss quam plure extra dictam villam nostram retrahuntur et ai commotantur. Ita quod dicta villa nostra multipliciter desolata et magna pus ejusdem ministre inhabitata dev nit prout int ximus. Nos in auxilium & consolarionem l∣orum nostrorum predictorum de gratia speciali perdonavimus et relaxaximus eis et eorum cuilibet omnimoda taxes tallagia decimas & quintas decimas ac medietates decimarum & quintrum decimarum nob in ultimo parliamento nostro apud Westmon' tento, qu cunquer emine censcantur infra ilam nostram predictam et saburbia ejusdem volent quod prefati legi nostri de taxis talliagis decimis quintis decimis & medictori∣bus decimarum quintarum decimarum predictis penitus exonerentur et quilibet corum exonetur per presentes. In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus pa∣. Teste meipso apud Westmon' 27 die Mair anno regni nostri undecimo per bre∣ve defigillo et de altensu constiti. Mapilton." (From the original remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.).

In the year 1441 the King granted a confirmation of the charters and liberties of the town of Newcastle upon TyneAubone MS. "Anno 19 Hen. VI. Dat' apud Westm' 16 die Februar'."—Note of charters in the office of the Town-Clerk of Newcastle upon Tyne..

July 11th, 1444, the King granted to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne and their heirs, that that town should be free from the jurisdiction of the constable, marshal and admiral of England, and from that of the warden of the marches; and that all processes should be served there by their own officers"Henricus Dei gratia &c. salutem. Sciatis quod nos de gratia nostra speciali & pro majore tranquilitate quiet' et utilit te ville nostre Novi Castri super Tynam, majoris & burgensium nostrorum ejusdem ville heredum et successorum suorum concessimus eisdem majori et burgensibus heredibus et successoribus suis pro nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris quantum in nobis est quod major et burgenses ville predicte & successores sui ad intendend' seu obediend' aliquibus preceptis sive mandatis constabularii marescalli seu ad∣miralli Anglie aut custodis marchiarum versus Scociam seu aliquorum officiariorum et ministrorum nostrorum aut successorum nostrorum exceptis mandatis nostris et dictorum successorum nostrorum sub nomimbus et titulis nostris sub magno vel privato sigilio sigil∣lat' exceptis eciam mandatis et preceptis justic' nostrorum juxta formam statutorum in ea parte editorum non teneantur sed inde sint quieti et exonerati imperpetuum sic quod dicti constabularius mariscallus admirallus seu custos marchiarum predictarum aut aliquis ministrorum suorum villam predictam seu libertatem ejusdem ad aliqua placita ibidem tenenda aut quicquam aliud quod d officium alicujus corundem pertinet seu pertinere poterit in summum faciens millatenus inrediatur nec aliquod placitum extra villam et li∣bertatem predictam de aliqua re infra eandem villam seu ejus libertatem factum tenent Et quod nulli summonicio attachiamentum seu executio fiat per aliquos ministros nostros vel heredian nostrorum quoscunque p breve vel fine brevi infra libertatem vill pr∣dicte nisi per ministros ejusdem ville. Hiis testibus ven' patribus Thoma Cantuarie Archipiscopo tocius Anglie Primate cancellario nostro, W. Lincoln' & W. Carl' Epis∣copis carissimo avuncasto nostro Humtrid Gloucestrie & carissimo consanguineo nostro Jo∣hanne Ducibus catissimo contanguineis nostris Humfr' Staffordie & Willielm ff' esallo hospici nostri comitibus dilectis & fidelibus nostri Radulpho de Cromwell & Radulpho Botiller thesauro nostro Anglie militibus dilecto clerico nostro Magistro Adam Molems custode privati si illi nostri & alii. Dat' per manum nostram apud manerium meum de Shene undcimo die Julii anno regni nostri vicesimo secundo." (From a charter of Inspeximus dated 26 Februar' 6 Ed. IV. entam in the archives of the cor∣poration of Newcastle upon Tyne) Murray MS. "C anno 22 Hen. VI. No. 39".

In the year 1446 there were two inquisitions held concerning
divers rights belonging to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne; the one found by a jury of Northumberland, and the other by a jury of that townAubone MS..

This year also a pardon was granted to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon TyneIbid. Hutchinson, in his Durham, vol. i. p. 332, tells us, that, "In 1433, a warm inqui∣sition was held under royal authority against the Cardinal's (Thomas Langley's, Bishop of Durham's) prerogatives & jurisdictions in his see. The earls of Northumberland and West∣moreland, the mayor of Newcastle, and seven others, being commissioners (of whom the two first were of the quorum), the proceedings, though violent, proved a remarkable support of the immunities and privileges of the county palatine, and the Bishop's regal authority and right.".

There was a grant of King Edward IV. that no burgess of New∣castle should answer at the marches, except by the King's especial commandmentGrey's MSS. say that this was preserved among the writings in the town's hutch, A. D. 1565..
The same King is said to have given to the men of that town, a charter for the election of a mayorGrey's MSS..

In the year 1463 there was a grant from the crown of the maner of Byker in fee to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne.—See after∣wards, A. D. 1489Murray MS. "Novum Castrum super Tynam pro M. de Byker concess' sibi & suc∣cessor' pat. A. 4 Ed. IV. p. 1, m. 4." Also Harleian MSS. No. 744. N. B. Henry Percy, fourth earl of Northumberland, being in his minority when his father was slain, A. D. 161, was kept in the tower of London, till October 27th, 1469, after which his father's at∣tainder was taken off, and he was restored to the honours and estates of his illustrious ancestors. (Collins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 374. Edition of 1779.).

February 12th, and 26th, 1466, the King granted to the burgesses of Newcastle exemplification and confirmation of their former charters and liberties"Edwardus D. gratia Rex Anglie, &c. Inspeximus litreras patentes Henrici quarti nuper de facto et non de jure Regis Anglie de confirmatione post conquestum factas in hec verba: Henricus &c.—Nos autem pro eo quod littere predicte casualiter sunt amisle sicut Robertus Fulbury recordator dicte ville Novi Castri super Tynam coram nobis in canceslaria nostra predicta personaliter constitutus sacramentum prestitit corporale et quod ipse literas illas si eas imposterum reperire contigerit nobis in eandem cancellariam nostram restituet ibidem cancelland' tenorem irrotulamenti litterarum predictarum ad requisicionem majoris & burgensium ville predicte duximus exemplificand' per presentes. In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud Westmonaster' duodecimo die Februarii anno regni nostri sexto. Nos autem cartas et litteras predictas ac omnia et singula in eisdem contenta rata habentes et grata ea pro nobis & heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est acceptamus & approbamus ac dilectis nobis nunc majori & burgensibus ville predicte heredibus & successoribus suis ratificamus et confirmamus prout carte et littere predicte rationabiliter testantur. In cujus rei &c. Teste meipso apud Westm' 26 die Febr' anno regni nostri sexto."—From the original remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..
In the year 1483 King Richard III. granted a confirmation of former charters to the burgesses of Newcastle, their heirs and successorsAubone MS..

In the year 1485 King Henry VII. granted also a confirmation of their liberties to the burgesses of that town"Henricus Dei gratia &c. Inspeximus litt' pat' Domini H. nuper Regis Anglie septimi patris nostri precharissimi de confirmatione factas in hec verba: Henricus &c. Nos autem cartas et litteras &c. Teste meipso apud Westm' 7 Decembr' anno regni nostri primo."—From an original Inspeximus dated 13th May, in the 3d of Queen Elizabeth, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the year 1489 the King granted the manor of Byker in Northum∣berland, during the minority of Henry, Earl of that county, to the mayor and commonalty of Newcastle upon TyneAubone MS. Henry Algernon Percy, fifth Earl of Northumberland, was only eleven years old at the death of his father, in 1489.—Collins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 382. Edition of 1779..

A. D. 1490 the said King made a grant of the fair called St. Luke's fair to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne
"Though a charter is recited to have been granted by King Henry the Seventh to the town of Newcastle, yet it is to be observed that there does not appear to be any con∣firmation of privileges (here the writer is certainly mistaken), save the grant of a fair in the sixth year of his reign, as is mentioned in the paper from the Rolls Chapel." (From a paper preserved in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, which appears to have been transmitted to them by their agent, or by some of the keepers of the records in London.)
Grey's MSS. mention "a grant for St Luke's fair in Newcastle."—Note of writings in the hutch of Newcastle, July 24th, 1505.
In a book of inrolments remaining in the archives of Newcastle upon Tyne, fol. 3, is the following: "Ann. 7 Hen. VI. ut videtur. Conceslit majori & burgensibus vill predicte quod ipsi heredes & successores sui habeant unam terram in feste Sancti Lace Evangeliste." The mistake in the above entry is by transposition of the figure..

Newcastle upon Tyne occurs in the list of those cities and towns directed by the 4th chapter of the statute 11 Hen. VII. A. D. 1495, to keep a standard for weights and measuresSee Statutes at Large, anno unde cimo Hen. VII. cap. 4to..

May 6th, 1510, King Henry VIII. granted an exemplification of divers charters to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne"Henricus, &c. Nos autem cartas et littera, &c. (See the form of prior confir∣mations.) Teste incipso apud Westmonast' 6o die Mari anno regni nostri secundo.".

May 2d, 1516, a decree was made in the Star-Chamber concern∣ing the government of Newcastle upon Tyne, in consequence of great dissensions there between the mercers, drapers, boothmen, and spicers, and merchants, and the craftsmen, and other burgesses: it was ordered by this decree, that none of the crafts of "coliers, shoomakers, boochers, weevers, smithes, dawbers, porters, keilmen, slaters, tylers, millers, cooks, spurriers, barbours, wrights, furbishers, boiers, fletchers, gloovers, cowpers, girdlers, challon wevers, masons, sadleres, shipwrights, and wallers," should be admitted into the crafts of mercers, drapers, or spicers, unless they first renounced their own crafts, and paid sines as follow: No person worth less than ten pounds to be admitted at all; those worth above ten pounds, and less than forty, to pay ten shillings; those worth to the value of forty pounds and above, and under an hundred marks, to pay twenty shillings; and those worth an hundred marks or above, to pay one pound six shillings and eight-pence. All which sines were to go to the use of the commonalty, and be valued by persons on their oaths before the mayor, aldermen, and recorder.

It was further ordered by this decree, that, on the ancient day of election, each of the twelve crafts should present two of their body,
which twenty-four, after having been sworn, were to elect four, who had been mayors, aldermen, or sheriffs of the town, who were to choose eight to themselves, which twelve were to elect other twelve; which twenty-four were to choose a mayor, six aldermen, a recorder, a sheriff, eight chamberlains, two coroners, a sword-bearer, a common clerk, and eight serjeants at mace.

This decree further ordered, that none should be admitted free bur∣gesses of Newcastle, who had lived less than a year in that town, nor any gentleman's or lord's servant, unless he had served seven years apprenticeship: and that every person admitted to his freedom, should be sworn not to be retained, or wear any livery, or token of, or with any lord, gentleman, or other person, who was not free of that town.

The decree further enjoined that twenty-four auditors should be chosen by the twelve crafts to inspect the yearly accounts of the town, without any reward; and that the above orders should be observed on pain of imprisonment without bail or mainprize, concluding with the King's pardon to that town for all former contempts and grievancesBook of inrolments remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, fol. 63..
July 10th, 1517, the King granted a pardon to John Brandling, mayor, and divers other burgesses of the town of Newcastle upon TyneFrom a deed remaining in the above archives..
In the year 1519 there was a grant of an annuity of twenty pounds per annum, made by the King to the mayor and burgesses of NewcastleAubone MS..
May 28th, 1538, there was an exemplification of the decree of the Star-Chamber, dated May 2d, 1516, granted by the King to the town of NewcastleSee book of inrolments ut supra, sol. 63..

April 10th, 1548, King Edward the Sixth granted a charter of exem∣plification and confirmation of divers former charters to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne"Edwardus sextus Dei gratia Anglie, Francie & Hibernie Rex sidei desensor et in terra ecclesie Anglicane & Hibernice supremum caput omnibus &c. Inspeximus &c. Nos autem (See the form of prior confirmations). Teste meipso apud Westmon' decimo die Aprilis anno regni nostri secundo."—From an Inspeximus, 13th May, in the 3d of Queen Elizabeth, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the third year of the reign of King Edward VI. there was a private act of parliament to annex the ballast-shores, and part of Byker, to the town and county of Newcastle upon TyneAubone MS. "There had been," adds this authority, "in the 1st of Edward VI. an award made by Sir William Pawlet, and Sir Anthony Brown, concerning Mr. Law∣son's ballast-shores, and a sale thereof made by Mr. Lawson accordingly.".
In the year 1550 a patent was granted during the King's pleasure, for the payment of twenty pounds per annum to the mayor and bur∣gesses of NewcastleIbid..

June 20th, 1554, Queen Mary granted a charter of Inspeximus, and confirmation of former charters to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne"Maria Dei gratia Anglie Francie & Hibernie Regina fidei defensor & in terra ecclesie Anglicane & Hibernice supremum caput omnibus &c. Inspeximus &c. Nos autem (See the form of prior confirmations). Teste meipsa apud Westmon' vicesimo die Junii anno regni nostri primo."—From an Inspeximus, dated 13th May, 3d Elizabeth, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the 3d and 4th years of the reign of Philip and Mary, there was a grant of divers liberties and privileges to the mayor and aldermen of Newcastle upon Tyne; as also of sundry liberties to the mayor and burgesses of that townAubone MS.—In the book of inrolments, fol. 33, there is the subsequent entry "Ann. 3 & 4 Phil. et Mar. concedunt majori & burgensibus ville predicte et eorum successor' quod sint alii quatuor aldermanni ultra et super sex allos aldermannos &c. Et ulterius concess' prefat' majori, aldermannis & burgensibus ville predicte et eorum suc∣cessor' quod predictus maior & decem aldermanni erunt justic' pacis ville predicte. Ita quod de determinatione felon' non intromittant." See also in the following decree of the 23d of June, 1557, where mention occurs of "The King and Queen's majesties letters patent.".

June 23d, 1557, there was an exemplification of a decree made by the privy council, upon a submission to them for the good govern∣ment of Newcastle upon Tyne. It was ordered by this decree that
none should be admitted into any different craft, after having been of another, without renouncing the former, and paying the same sines as before, according to the decree of the Star-Chamber, dated May 2d, 1516, and that no one should change his profession above once: the valuation of property to be made by four honest persons of the craft of the person who desired to change, who were to be sworn on the oc∣casion. This decree ordered also, that the election of officers should be as before: only, that the first four should be chosen out of those who had been mayors or aldermen, and, for want of such, out of those who had been aldermen or sheriffs. This decree appointed also ten alder∣men; vacancies in that number to be filled up within twenty days, and those who had been mayors without having been aldermen, were to have the preference before any other burgesses in being chosen aldermen: Also that the eight chamberlains should account yearly to the auditors in presence of the mayor, aldermen, and sheriff; that the twenty-four electors should be assistants to the mayor and alder∣men for the year ensuing, "and to be taken of the common council of the said town for the said year," and vacancies in their number were to be filled up.

This decree ordered also, that the common seal of the town should not be affixed without the assent of the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of the town, and that the twenty-four auditors should be appointed as before directed in the abovementioned Star-Chamber decree; enjoining the several orders to be enrolled in the chancery, and remain of record, and concluding with a pardon for the breach of the former decreeFrom the book of inrolments ut supra, fol. 79..

May 13th, 1561, Queen Elizabeth made an exemplification and confirmation of divers grants to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne"Elizabeth Dei gratia Anglie Francie & Hiberme Regma fidei defensor &c. In∣speximus &c. Nos autem (See before the form of prior confirmations). Teste meipsa apud Westm' 13 die Maii anno regni nostri tertio."—From the original Inspeximus remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

August 2d, 1561, there was a decree made and signed by Henry Earl of Rutland, lord president of the council of the North, for the better government of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, wherein it was ordered that no burgess should change his art or mistery above once, according to the sines in the preceding decree of the 3d and 4th of Philip and Mary, when he should be allowed to exercise both crafts at his pleasure; that ten aldermen should be continued, who, with the mayor and sheriff, should be the chief rulers and magistrates of the town; and that they should respectively continue in that office of aldermen, unless some of them should be mayor, and during that time the other nine should continue in that state, and after the mayoralty of the tenth, he was to be an alderman as before. This decree further enjoined, that, on the day of choosing the mayor, twenty-four should be elected out of the twelve crafts or misteries, of whom twelve must have been mayors, aldermen, or sheriffs, who, with the other twelve burgesses, should elect the mayor and other officers; and that the mayor so chosen, with the sheriff, aldermen, and twenty-four, were "to remayne the common-counsaill of the said towne, over and besides the ten aldermen:" As also, that all the above orders, with all that re∣mained unaltered of the abovementioned decree of the third and fourth of Philip and Mary, should be strictly observed and kept, upon great pains and penalties. And that both decrees should be openly read twice a year to the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common councilMurray MS. p. 55..

In the year 1564 the Queen granted an exemplification of an act of parliament made in the second and third years of King Edward VI. reciting a suit between the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne and James Lawson, to the mayor and burgesses of that townBook of inrolments, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the year 1575 d, August 16th, William Flower, Esq norroy king
"Omnibus & singulis tam regibus ad arma sive heroaldis quam nobilibus ceterisque hoc scriptum visuris vel audituris Gulielmus Flower, Armiger, aliter dictus Nostroy prin∣cipalis Heroaldus et Rex Armorum partium orientalium occidentalium et borealium regni Anglie ultra ripam fluvii de Trent saiutem in Domino sempiternam Quum venerabiles viri Johannes Watson maior comitatus ville Novi Castri super Tinam et Ricardus Hodshon Christopherus Metforde Robertus Ellison Willielmus Dent Robertus Anderson Henricus Brandlinge Willielmus Jenison Thomas Riddell Willielmus Selby & Henricus Anderson junior aldermanni ejusdem comitatus & ville, sicut et eorum predecessores multis et egre∣giis privilegiis a regibus Anglie sint indulti et per nomen majoris et burgensium comitatus ville Novi Castri super Tynam incorporati: virtute ejus incorporationis (sicut et alie regni ville) insigniorum five armorum longo usu et demonstratione comitatus ville pre∣dicte clarior, honoratior & spectabilior efficitur. At quoniam insigniis seu armis predictis antiquissimis (quod plerumque et aliis nonnullis accidit) nulla reperitur super arma galea exornata cum quodam auctuario quod timbrum sive cristam vocant, simul cum anima∣libus collateralibus quas vulgo supportatores expellamus: ego predictus norroy rex armorum non solum quod est officii mei exequi sed etiam ville tam preclare deque prin∣cipe et patria nostra tam bene merite gratificari cupiens, pro majori et ampliori orna∣mento comitatus ville Novi Castri predicte insigniis sive armis antiquis cristam hanc simul cum animalibus collateralibus sive assistentibus et ceteris phaleris & appendiciis adjunxi videlicet leonis gardantis aurei pars anterior medio tenus ex castro argenteo pro∣minens prioribus duabus tibiis regni vexillum tenens divo Georgio olim dicatum: Et in clypei sustentationem equos marinos duos propriis coloribus ex utroque latere unum destmavi. Quernadmodum in margine presentium pro pleniori noticia magis ad vivum illuminanda delinanda depingendaque curavi: que quidem insignia clypei antiqua una cum apice seu crista galce imposita et animalibus predictis collateralibus ceterisque appendicibus ornamentis ego prenominatus norroy rex armorum virtute et auctoritate functionis et officii mei a regia majestate mihi in hac parte concesse digna dignis ut prescriberem admissus, dicto majori & burgensibus comitatus ville Novi Castri predict' super Tynam posterisque & successoribus suis in majus honoris incrementum et decus ville predicte addixi tradidi et imperpetuum confirmavi per presentes, habenda utenda et ostendenda, honoris gratia quibuscumque loco et tempore pro eorum arbitrio, aliquo impedimento contradictione aut prohibitione id ut ne fieri possit non obstante. In quorum omnium & singulorum fidem et testimonium ego norroy rex armorum predictus hiis presentibus manu mea propria subscripsi et officii mei sigillo presens diploma corroboravi. Datum in villa Novi Castri predict' decimo sexto die Augusti anno salutis a Christo millesimo quin∣gentesimo septuagesimo quinto, regni vero Regine &c. anno decimo septimo."—From a copy on parchment remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne. Dorso "16 August, 1575. Grant from William Flower, Esq norroy principal king of arms on the north side of Trent, of the appendices of the arms of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne."
On a curious oar, that belonged to the admiralty court of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and which is still preserved in the archives of the corporation, the arms of that town are painted after the direction of the above grant, without a motto—The date, "Ao. DNI 1606."
On a stone, formerly built up over the gateway of the tower on the old bridge, facing the south, placed at present (1784) in the wall of a garden belonging to Hugh Hornby, Esq alderman, in Pilgrim-Street, there is inscribed under the arms of Newcastle:
"FFORTITER DEFENDIT TRIUMPHANS 1646."
Bourne tells us, in his History of Newcastle, p. 234, after having described the siege ofthat town in 1644, "Thus was the town taken from the King after an obstinate and gallant defence, and well may assume the motto bestowed upon it."
"Fortiter defendendo triumphans."
King Charles was in person at Newcastle in 1646, and perhaps, for the very gallant defence of that town in his service, may then first have bestowed this motto upon the arms of it, as Mr. Bourne's expression seems to imply.
ARMS of the CORPORATION of NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE, &c. To Nathaniel Clayton Esq Town Clerk of Newcastle upon This Plate of the Arms of that Town Engraved in his Expences respectful inscribed by his obliged & most obedt humble Servt John Bra
of arms, granted the additions of an helmet, crest, and supporters, to the ancient arms of Newcastle upon Tyne. No motto occurs in this grant.

August 30th, 1589, the Queen granted a charter to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, wherein she incorporated them by the name of the mayor and burgesses of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the same, confirming to them the said town, with all its members and appurtenances, and the liberties they formerly had, as well by charter as by prescription, at an hundred pounds fee-farm payable at Michaelmas in every year, with power to the said mayor and burgesses, or the greater part of them, to make ordinances and bye laws for their better government, enjoining the obedience of them under pain of sine and imprisonment: this charter also gave them power to make perambulation, set boundaries, and remove encroachments on the limits of the town, the extent of which by land and by water was to remain as before. It further comprised a pardon of purchase made without licence, and power to retain what had formerly been purchased; and gave them the same authority and liberty in the castle, which was still parcel of the county of Northumberland, as in the other parts of the town. This charter further granted an exemption from the jurisdiction of the admiralty, with an admiralty court of its ownSee Seals, Plate II. No. 12. 2d Plate of Seals, No 12, is from a drawing by Sir Wil∣liam Dugdale in a MS. preserved in the Herald's College, London, and lettered, "West. Cumb. Durh. North. 1665, 1666."—From drawings by the same, remaining ibid. are also No. 10, in the plate of Miscellancous Antiquities; No. 15, 1st plate of seals; and No 2, in the second plate of seals: of this last, I have a very sine impression in my possession., to be held in that town every Monday before the recorder and
aldermen, or three of them, whereof the mayor or recorder to be one, making them also justices of the peace for the admiralty, and for con∣servation of the river within the port, with a serjeant at mace to exe∣cute the process. It empowered the mayor also to make a judge, and other officers of the admiralty; granting also cognizance of admiral pleas, and concerning wrecks and the coroner with authority to take recognizances for admiral causes and fines and issues with the power to levy them. Also chattels waived, deodands, goods of felons de se, and all that belongs to the admiralty, prohibiting at the same time the lord of the admiralty from intermeddling with them. Lastly, this charter gave them authority to hold gaol delivery, and all that belongs to the coroner's office, with power to erect gallows, and to purchase, notwith∣standing the statute of mortmain
From a copy of this charter in Latin, in the Murray MS. p. 61.
For the clause in it concerning Castle-Garth, see account of the castle of Newcastle upon Tyne..

June 21st, 1594, the Queen granted an exemplification of the pre∣ceding charter, dated August 30th, 1589, wherein she confirmed all the former privileges of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and granted several new onesThe original is preserved in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the year 1599 Newcastle upon Tyne received the first sum of one hundred and four pounds, which had been devised by Sir Thomas White, lord mayor of London, in 1554, to be given annually at Mer∣chant-Taylors' Hall to twenty-three cities and towns in England by rotation. Of this sum, an hundred pounds were to be let out to four young men for ten years without interest, and the remaining four in∣tended to pay the charges and expences incurred in receiving it
Their second payment was in 1623.—The third, which was due in 1646, was not received till 1651.—Their fourth, said to have been due August 24th, 1668, was received in 1674.—Their fifth payment, though due at the feast of St. Bartholomew, 1695, came not till September 11th, 1699, the estates having been sequestered during the civil wars.— Their sixth payment, due in 1722, was not paid till 1725.—Their seventh payment was in 1746.—Their eighth was due on St. Bartholomew's day, 1770.
The cities and towns to which it was left, were 1. York, 2. Canterbury, 3. Reading, 4. Merchant-Taylors' Hall, London, 5. Gloucester, 6. Worcester, 7. Exeter, 8. Salisbury, 9. West-Chester, 10. Norwich, 11. Southampton, 12. Lincoln, 13. Winchester, 14. Oxford, 15. Hereford East, 16. Cambridge, 17. Shrewsbury, 18. Lynn, 19. Bath, 20. Derby, 21. Ipswich, 22. Colchester, 23. Newcastle upon Tyne.
Sir Thomas White, son of Thomas White, was born at Rixmansworth, in Hertford shire, and afterwards bred a merchant-taylor in London, of which city he became lord mayor. He first built Gloucester-hall, and afterwards built and endowed St. John' col∣lege in Oxford..

March 22d, 1600From a copy at full length in Latin, in Grey's MS. collections., the Queen, at the humble request of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, granted them a new charter, whereby she confirmed that town to them, with all their former liberties, at the ancient fee-farm of one hundred pounds per annum, notwithstand∣ing any non-use, abuse or forfeiture. This charter ordered that the mayor and sheriff and ten aldermen, with twenty-four burgesses then resident, elected within five days after the election of the mayor by the twenty-four electors, should be the common-council of the town, and that this common-council, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven, or the mayor, and the major part of the burgesses, should make laws for the government of the inhabitants, for the regulation of markets and fairs, and of those who should resort to them, and should grant leases, fine, imprison and amerce and levy, and retain the amercements.

That, on every Monday next after Michaelmas, two of each of the twelve misteries should choose four, i. e. the then mayor, and three that had been aldermen; that these four should elect seven other alder∣men, and the sheriff, in all twelve; which twelve should choose other twelve, and that these twenty-four should elect the mayor, sheriff, two coroners, a clerk of the chamber, eight chamberlains, a sword-bearer,
eight serjeants at mace, and a recorder. That, upon the death of any of these above annually elected officers, another should be elected within twenty-nine days; and that, on the removal of any of the ten aldermen, the said electors should choose another within twenty days. That all the officers should be sworn; that any one refusing the mayoralty, or office of alderman, should pay two hundred marks, and one hundred for refusing to serve the office of sheriff, and be com∣mitted if they refused to pay the fines. That, on the death, or removal of any person whose office is eligible, the electors should choose others within twenty days, and that the mayor should have the casting voice where the suffrages were equal. That, on the death or removal of a mayor or sheriff, the oldest alderman and sheriff peer should supply their places; and that, during the absence of those newly elected, the above old ones should supply their places. This charter further en∣joined, that the mayor should hold his court every Monday, and the sheriff his on every Wednesday and Friday, except at Christmas, Easter, Whitsuntide, and on holidays, with power to hold pleas, with cogni∣zance thereof, and to commit to Newgate as before, and to punish officers, or others, offending in the court.

By this charter, the mayor, aldermen, and recorder, were constituted justices of the peace and gaol delivery; it empowered the mayor and burgesses to tax for the public use, and levy as before, and granted a licence to the lessees to assign the grand lease to them.

This charter further granted pardon of forfeitures upon the statute 9 Hen. V.—the 21st Hen. VIII. and 1st of this Queen, giving power to the hostmen to load at any place within the port of Tyne, not∣withstanding the statute 21st Hen. VIII. with an injunction to load and unload as near to Newcastle as they might, on pain of forfeiting five pounds for every time they did to the contrary. It granted also that statuteSee plate of Miscellaneous Antiquities, No. 10, from a drawing of Sir William Dugdale.-merchant should be taken before the mayor and bur∣gesses, or mayor and common-council, or the major part of them,
whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven: and exempted the mayor and burgesses from payment of toll, confirming the grant of all toll and custom, &c. which they had before, to be levied by their officers; as also the forfeiture of goods foreign bought and foreign sold.

This charter ordered also, that burgesses might be admitted by the mayor and burgesses, or the common council, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven, and concluded with the incorporation of the grammar-schoolSee history of Grammar-School annexed to the account of St. Mary's Hospital., and of the fraternity of hostmenSee account of the fraternity of Free Hostmen (after that of the Merchant Adven∣turers), incorporated with the History of Coal, and the Coal Trade..

December 21st, 1603, a decree was made by the president and council in the North, upon submission to them for the government of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, which ordered, that on the ancient day of election, the twelve misteries should present twenty-four, who were to choose four, the then mayor, and three other burgesses, who had been mayors and aldermen; and for want of such, to choose sheriff peers, and for want of these last, common burgesses; which four were to elect seven aldermen, and one that had been sheriff, in all twelve persons; and that, as to the other twelve, called the twelve of the latter election, the twelve misteries should each send one to be presented to the former elec∣tors, who were to choose six out of the said twelve. And that the follow∣ing, called by-trades, viz. "maisters mariners, weavers, barbers chirur∣gions, with chandlers, cutlers, shipwrights, house-carpenters, masons, glovers, joyners, milners, curryers, with felt-makers, and armourers, col∣lyers, with carriage men, slaiters, glaziers, with plummers and painters," in all fourteen companies, should each send one: and that twelve should be chosen out of this fourteen; out of which twelve, the former eighteen should take six, making twenty-four in all, who were to elect the officers of the corporation. And also twenty-four others, with the mayor, aldermen and sheriff, to make the common-council, of whom the whole or the greater number, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven, should dispose of the revenues, leases and offices, and that nothing should pass the common seal without their consent. This
decree enjoined also, that the twenty-four auditors should be allowed 13s. 4d. per diem; that the mayor and recorder should be of the quorum in the gaol delivery; and that every free burgessFebruary 27th, 1604, there was an order for the exposition of the word "Freeman" in the above decree, that it should be extended only to those who should have attained to that franchise by patrimony or service. should be admitted an hostman, on payment of fifty-three shillings and four-pence, and a freeman's son or apprentice for paying thirty-three shil∣lings, and that the charters should be renewed accordinglyFrom a record remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

March 31st, 1604, King James I. granted a charter to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, which confirmed the mode of electing officers as by the decree dated at York, December 21st, 1603, with this difference, that the by-trades, now increased one in number, should send fifteen persons, who were to choose twelve burgesses as by that decree. This charter further enjoined, that every act, ordinance, or constitution, which had been made or agreed upon in guild, either by the mayor and burgesses, assembled to make up any writings, &c. concerning the possessions of the said mayor and burgesses, unless the same were by the assent and consent, and in the presence of the mayor and the rest of the common-council, or the greater part of them, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven; and that the mayor, recorder and aldermen, five or more of them, might hold gaol delive∣ries for the said town, and have full power to erect a gallows within the town and liberties to hang felons, murderers, and other malefac∣tors; and also to take and arrest malefactors within the town and county aforesaid, to be kept there till they should be delivered by due process of lawFrom a copy at full length in Latin, in Grey's MS. collections..

In the year 1629 a quo warranto was brought in the Court of King's BenchAubone MS., against the mayor and burgesses of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, to shew by what warrant they claimed to be incorporated by that name, to have a common-council, make ordinances, lay penalties, tax the burgesses inhabiting that town,
take money for admitting into their companies, disfranchise, hold a court of record
Mayor's or sheriff's court.—See before the charter of Henry IV. for making New∣castle upon Tyne a county by itself.—Under sheriffs, or sheriffs' and coroners' clerks.
August 10th, 1642, William Scourfield appointed.
October 1st, 1645, Thomas Milbourne.
August 20th, 1655, Richard Walker, on the death of the above.
Mr. William Astell.
September 23d, 1658, William Jackson.
September 28th, 1674, John Douglas.
April 14th, 1685, John Ord.
February, 1703, Peter Potts.
December, 1721, Charles Clark.
John Ord.
Richard Burdus, on the resignation of J. Ord, about 1766.
November 23d, 1772, Philip Gibson, on the resignation of R. Burdus.
December 15th, 1774, Nathanael Punshon, on the death of P. Gibson.
Mention occurs in the common-council books, January 20th, 1766, of the Barons of the Exchequer at Westminster having ordered that, for the future, the sheriffs clerk of Newcastle shall always attend for passing the sheriff's accounts.
I am indebted for the subsequent very interesting strictures on Mr. Wallis's most erro∣neous account (See his History of Northumberland) of the courts of Newcastle upon Tyne, to the above Nathanael Punshon, Esq under sheriff.
"Mr. Wallis has been misinformed in almost every instance respecting the civil government of Newcastle. Speaking of the mayor's court of record, he says, "No attor∣neys are allowed to plead in it, but such as are free of the corporation." By which, one would suppose he means free burgesses: if this be his meaning, he is mistaken; for if an attorney be regularly admitted at Westminster, having served his clerkship to an attorney of the mayor's court, he has a right to be admitted there, whether he be a free∣man or not.—He says, "It has six serjeants at mace to attend it."—Now there are eight, viz. The water-bailiff, who bears the great mace, the sheriff's serjeant, and six common serjeants, who are all serjeants at mace, and called so in the charter.—"An action com∣menced in it may be brought to trial for 30s. but will cost more money and time in the sheriff's court, out of which an action may be removed into the mayor's at any time before a jury is sworn; but not of the mayor's into the sheriff's." Here again he is wrong; in the first place, it is very seldom that either the mayor's or sheriff's court takes cogni∣zance of debts under 40 shillings, being restrained by a clause in the act of parliament (of William and Mary) establishing the Court of Requests, commonly called the Court of Conscience, from holding pleas of such small debts, except for rent reserved upon lease, and some other causes of action, which the Court of Conscience does not extend to. Then with respect to the removal of causes from the sheriff's court to the mayor's, there never was an instance of any such removal; for no cause can be removed either from the sheriff's court to the mayor's, or from the mayor's to the sheriff's. These two courts are coeval, being instituted by the same charter (more strictly speaking, they may be said to be con∣tinued by the same charter); they are of similar jurisdiction and practice, and only differ in this particular, viz. that actions are brought against free burgesses in the mayor's court, and against foreigners, or non-freemen in the sheriff's. "The juries of this and the sheriff's court are the same; they are returned every Christmas by the several wards of the corporation, at their wardmote inquest, where particular wards appoint persons to serve as jurymen for every month in the year."—There is no such court as that of a ward∣mote in Newcastle at present; nor do I believe there ever was, though the town is divided into wards, and constables appointed to each.
"Upon a cause being removed out of the sheriff's court into this (the mayor's), and it appearing to the mayor that a verdict hath been obtained against the plaintiff for more than his just debt, the mayor may remit the cause to judgment for the just debt only." After observing that causes are not removed, or removable, in this manner, it is needless to say that there is no such practice in Newcastle.
With regard to the sheriff's court, he says, "The attorneys who plead in it are ap∣pointed by the mayor and court of aldermen." There is no court of aldermen in New∣castle. The attorneys are admitted there in the same manner as in the mayor's court.
The fees mentioned by Mr. Wallis are very different from what are taken and al∣lowed. Indeed, they were not well known, and consequently different charges were often made till the 15th and 19th of June, 1767, one being the mayor's, and the other the sheriff's jury day, when the fees of the two courts were settled. "The defendant may (after the verdict is given, and before judgment is entered) stop judgment by taking the cause before the mayor, for time to pay the money recovered." There never was a such practice in Newcastle. "If either party cannot stay in town till the day of trial, his testimony in writing will be allowed for good evidence." By the word party, I sup∣pose he means the plaintiff or defendant; and if this were allowed, it would be such an inducement to perjury as never was known, or admitted in any court of law.
The court of guild is holden thrice a year, as Mr. Wallis observes, but not for the purposes he mentions; the principal business of the guild is for the apprentices and sons of freemen to petition for their freedom; they are called by the style of the company that their masters or fathers were of: this is what is termed "calling their guilds." And the wardens and stewards of each company attend there to put a stop to, or prevent any person from obtaining his freedom, who, they apprehend, is not entitled to it. An apprentice called thrice in guild, or rather at three different guilded ; the son of a only once. And if an objection be made, or a stop put to his guild, the person making the objection is summoned before the common-council, to give his reason for stopping the guild. And if he shew good cause for making the objection, then the person applying cannot be sworn a freeman till the objection be removed. But if no stop be put, or ob∣jection made at guild, then the person applying may at any time afterwards be sworn a free burgess before the mayor, or any other magistrate. This is the principal business of the court, and not for turning over apprentices, or hearing differences between them and their masters, as Mr. Wallis tells us. The oath taken by a freeman on his admission, is very different from that mentioned by Mr. Wallis. Hence it appears, that he has been strangely misinformed with respect to the different courts in Newcastle; and as he has men∣tioned some that neither do, nor ever did exist there; so also he has omitted to mention one, i. e. the county court, that still continues to be held."
In the time of the commonwealth, it appears that the magistrates of Newcastle upon Tyne punished scolds with the branks, and drunkards by making them carry a b, called the drunkard's cloak, through the streets of that town. We shall presume that there i no longer any occasion for the former, but why has the latter been laid aside?
For representations of both, see "Miscellaneous Antiquities" (plate of), No 2 and 3.
A part of branks are still preserved in the town court of Newcastle.—See an account , with a plate, in Plott's Staffordshire.—Vide Gardiner's England's Grievance of the Coal Trade. The representation in this work is a fac simile from his., have cognizance of pleas, a recorder, eight serjeants
at mace, fairs, markets—exclude foreigners from selling there, have a clerk of the market, view of frank pledge, and correction of the assize
of bread, wine, &c. examination of weights, and measures, tumbril, and pillory, with all that belongs to a view of frank pledge.

Also why they claimed to have two-pence for toll of every chalder of coals bought and shipped there, and to be conveyed from thence; one shilling and nine-pence for every ship and boat brought into the port; to take of every one bringing in any grain into the said port a boll out of every ten chaldron brought in; to have justices of peace within the town, and a clerk of the peace there; to hold pleas of action popular, and of several penal statutes of causes arising there, and belong∣ing to justices of peace, of Oyer and Terminer; to take the issues, fines, amercements, and other profits before justices of peace, and in other places aforesaid; to erect a gallows, have coroners, eschaetors, returns of writs in the town and liberties; to have felons goods there; to have and build ballast-shores within a mile of the town on each side of the river, and compel every one that imported or exported any merchandize in that port to cast their ballast on those shores, and not
elsewhere, upon certain pains and penalties; to imprison and detain the ships on the non-payment thereof; to take an oath touching the cast∣ing of ballast within a mile of the port; elect a mayor, and so forth— all which the mayor and burgesses claimed, and set forth their right at large, and the warrant by which they claimed them. And upon a view of the acts of parliament, letters patent, allowances, and other records, writings, and ancient books of the mayor and burgesses shewn to the King's attorney-general, and examined by him; and also upon testimony of witnesses in the court of King's Bench, who deposed that the said mayor and burgesses had held, used, and enjoyed all and singular the said liberties, privileges, and franchises which they claimed, the said attorney-general acknowledged and confessed the same.

And thereupon, after due and mature deliberation, the King's serjeant and the said attorney-general being called thereto and present, the Court of King's Bench adjudged that the said mayor and burgesses, and their successors, should use, have, and enjoy, by virtue of the premises, all and singular the said liberties, privileges, franchises, and free customs which they claimed and challenged, and that they should be allowed and adjudged to them.

February 3d, 1664, King Charles II. granted a charter of Inspexi∣mus, confirming the preceding ones of the 42d of Queen Elizabeth, and the 2d of James I. with their ancient privileges, &c. to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, at the former rent of one hundred pounds per annum. It was ordered by this charter, that the King should approve of the recorder and town-clerk, and that the mayor, recorder, aldermen, town-clerk, and burgesses, should take the oaths of obedience and supremacyFrom a copy in Latin in Grey's MSS..

It appears from an entry in the common-council books of Newcastle, dated December 23d, 1669, that the following sums were yearly due, and paid out of the revenue of the corporation of that town: "3l. 6s. 8d. to the prisoners at DurhamThis appears to have been the gift of a Mr. Frankland, and was payable to the mayor of Durham. (Common-council books, June 21st, 1676.) This was probably the same person mentioned in the subsequent note., due at St. Andrew day in every year."
“1l. 6s. 8d. due then also to the poor of Houghton
"A. D. 1582, it appears by the will of Barnard Gilpin, rector of Houghton le Spring, dated 17th of October, 1582, that there was given to his foundation of the school of Houghton, out of the town-chamber of Newcastle, by the gift and appointment of Mr. John Frankline of blessed memory, one pension of four nobles by the year, to be paid all at one payment, about St. Andrew's day before Christenmas, and to be bestowed upon the poor of Houghton parishe. For this, says he in the will, we have no evidence, but only a writing of Mr. John Franklyn, written all with his own hand, with his name subscribed, but no seal.
"N. B. This donation is now lost, as well as Mr. Frankleyn's writing."—MS. note in Gyll's interleaved Bourne, p. 226. (le Spring)"—4l. ”due at St. Andrew's day in every year to the poor of Highington"John March of Redworth, Durham, by his will, dated February 13th, 1590, devised one hundred pounds to be paid into the town-chamber of Newcastle."—Old account; also common-council books, June 21st, 1676..

In the beginning of the year 1684, it was signified to the corpora∣tion of Newcastle, that the King expected a surrender of their charter, which was to be renewed on condition that the mayor, recorder, sheriff, and town-clerk might be always in the King's power to ap∣point or confirmCommon-council books..

The charter of confirmation, granted by King Charles II. in conse∣quence of the above surrender, reached Newcastle on the 13th of Fe∣bruary, 1685Two days after the proclaiming King James II. as appears by the preface to a small poem, intitled, "A Jocoserious Discourse, in two Dialogues, between a Northumberland Gentleman, and his Tenant, a Scotchman, both old cavaliers." By George Stuart, licensed June 12th, 1686..

January 5th, 1686, the common-council of the town were removed, and new ones elected, in obedience to a mandate of King James II. dated at Whitehall, December 15th, 1685From the original mandate, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle..

June 30th, 1687, Sir William Creagh, Knight, a zealous papist, was
admitted to the freedom of the corporation of Newcastle, in conse∣quence of a mandate from the same King, dated May 31st, 1687From the original mandate, remaining in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle..

By another mandate of the same King, dated at Whitehall, Decem∣ber 24th, 1687, the mayor, six aldermen, the sheriff, deputy recorder, and fifteen of the common-council, were displaced, and others of the King's choice were appointed in their steadIbid..

A flattering address, intended to have been presented to King James II. by the corporation of Newcastle, and signed by Sir William Creagh, Knight, mayor, and other aldermen that were papists, and others that were dissenters, with some of the common-council, January 16th, 1688, was carried in the negative by a majority of that body, and not sentFrom a copy in Dr. Ellison's MS. collections..

February 11th, 1688, a writ of quo warranto was served upon the mayor of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books., and on the 8th of March following a surrender of the charter of that town was sealed under the common seal, and signed by Sir William Creagh, mayor, eight aldermen, the sheriff, and fourteen of the common-councilIbid..

King James II. some time after the 9th of June, and before the 22d of September, 1688, appears to have granted a new charterIbid. to the corporation of Newcastle, which, however, the subsequent order of council and proclamation of that King, dated October 17th follow∣ing, soon cancelled and made voidIbid. This order of council and proclamation declared that all charters made since the year 1679 were void..

Thus again the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, emancipated from the shackles of a government founded on principles of the most despotic tyranny, recovered its ancient liberty in the choice of its own officers and magistrates, and immediately exercised that liberty by appointing a new set of themCommon-council books..

In the year 1689Journals of Commons, vol. x. an act of parliament passed for erecting a court of conscience at Newcastle upon Tyne, and by 27th George II. cap. 16, sect. 2, it was ordered that, after the 1st of January 1755, it should be a publick actSee Statutes at Large.—See also Appendix..

April 20th, 1699, there was an order of the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, that in future there should be paid, out of the revenue of that town, the sum of forty shillings to all the sons of poor freemen who should claim it, to defray the expence of binding them apprenticesCommon-council books..

"Hutch, arca, pluteus, G. Hotte et Belgis Hotte est corbis dossuaria. Gallis est Huche, H. Hucha. Omnia petit Skinnerus ab A. S. hpaecca idem signante L."—Lye's Junii Etymolog. in verbo.
"The Latin huchia, in Picardy and Scotland huche, English hutch, was a long wooden box, from whence possibly a huckster, who carried about goods to sell in such a box".— White Kennett's Glossary to his Paroch. Antiq. in verbo Hoke., or common treasury of that town, 2,152l. 13s. 0¼d.
