DIV2.HEAD: BURGESSES, REPRESENTATIVES IN, OR MEMBERS OF, PARLIA∣MENT FOR THE TOWN OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.
DIV2.P: IT is uncertain whether or not Newcastle upon Tyne was among the boroughs summoned by the barons, who took arms against King Henry the Third, to send members to the great council of the nation in the year 1264See Robertson's History of Charles V. vol. i. p. 44. Also Anderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 124, sub anno 1266..

A. D. 1283, King Edward I. summoned to his parliament at Shrewsbury two knights for each county, and two representatives each for twenty-one
Ibid.—"London, Winchester, Newcastle upon Tyne, York, Bristol, Exeter, Lin∣coln, Canterbury, Carlisle, Norwich, Northampton, Nottingham, Scarborough, Grimsby, nn, Colchester, Yarmouth, Hereford, Chester, Shrewsbury, and Worcester.
This first, or at least early instance of a third estate in parliamen gave the first con∣siderable blow to feudal tenures in England, and did undoubtedly pave the way for the greater security of freedom and commerce in cities and towns, as well as in the open country." of the principal towns of England, among which occurs Newcastle upon Tyne
"Rex majori et ballivis ville Novi Castri super Tynam.
"(De tractatu habendo super David filio Griffini captivato)
"Quot fraudum et machinationum &c—Vobis mandamus quod duos de sapientioribus et aptioribus civibus predicte ville eligi faciatis et eos ad nos mittatis: ita quod sint ad nos apud Salopiam in crastino Sancti Michaelis proximo futuro, nobiscum super hoe et aliis locuturi: et hoc nullatenus omittatis. Teste Rege apud Rothelan 28 die Junii."—Rot. Wallie, 11 E. I. m. 2, d. Foedera, tom. ii. p. 249.. The form of the ancient writs clearly evinces that the two persons to be honoured by such representation, were originally intended to be chosen out of the number of the prin∣cipal burgesses of the respective towns.

The first of our burgesses, whose names I have been able to recover, were John Scot and Peter Graper
Prynne's fourth part of a Brief Register, &c. of Parliamentary Writs, p. 1076.
Brady, in his Treatise of English Burghs, p. 63, tells us, that, "in some the elections are said to be made by the bailiffs, with the assent of the community of the burghs." He instances amongst others: "Accordingly two burgesses were elected for the community of the burgh of Newcastle upon Tyne, with their names and manucaptators' (sureties') names in a schedule."
Retorn. Brev. Parl. 26 Ed. I. Nomina burgensium pro communitate burgi Novi Castri super Tynam sunt in cedula huic brevi annexa.", or Draper, who represented New∣castle
upon Tyne in the parliament held at York A. D. 1297, the 26th of Edward I.
In the parliament held at London in the year 1301, Newcastle upon Tyne was represented by Nicholas Carliol and Thomas de FrisinaPrynne ut supra, p. 1076..

In that held at Carlisle A. D. 1306, by Nicholas Scot
"Rex majori & ballivis ville sue Novi Castri super Tynam salutem. Precipimus vobis quod de communitate ville predicte habere faciatis dilecto nobis Nich. le Scot, burgens' ejusdem ville nuper ad nos de mandato nostro pro villa predict' usque Karliolum venienti ibidem nobiscum super diversis negotiis nos et statum regni nostri specialiter tangentibus tractatur' rationabiles expensas suas in veniendo ad nos, ibidem morando et exinde ad propria redeundo, prout alias in casu consimili fieri consuevit. Teste Rege apud Landrecost 20 die Januarii"—Prynne's 4th part, &c. p. 26.
In the above writ, it is observable that no particular sum is mentioned, the representa∣tive being only to be allowed reasonable expences.: the name of the other burgess has not been transmittedPrynne ut supra, p. 1076..

In that held at York A. D. 1314, by Nicholas Scott
The subsequent extract from Prynne, ut supra, vol. ii. p. 164 and 165, proves that there is either a mistake in my authority with regard to the two last parliaments, o that the persons above named had been chosen, but did not attend. "There are some reo for the county of Northumberland very memorable and rare, and not to be paralleled any other shire.
"Anno 6 Ed. II. a writ issuing to the sheriff of Northumberland in usual form, ad ligendum pro communitate comitat' ill' duos milites et qualibet civitate duos civ et quolibet burgo duos burgenses; he makes this return on the dorso thereof: Willielm de Tindale vic' Northumbrie sic respondit: Quia homines tam com' Northumb' quam ville Novi Castri super Tynam multum timent quod pax inter regna Anglie & Scot per quosdam Scotie infringeretur propter quod ipsi se elongare ad presens commode no potuerunt ideo predicti homines nullos milites seu burgenses pro instanti parliament curant mittere."
Ibid. vol. ii. p. 165, we read, "In the 8th year of Edward II. the King issued forth another writ to the sheriff of Northumberland, to elect two knights, citizens and bur∣gesses, for the commonalty of the county, and of every city and borough within the same, on which the sheriff indorsed this retorn: "I stud breve oftensum fuit in pleno comitatu; ubi responsum suit mihi quod omnes milites de balliva mea non sufficiunt ad defensionem marchiae. Et mandatum suit ballivis libertatis ville Novi Castri super Tynam qui sic responderunt quod omnes burgenses ville predict' vix sufficiunt ad defensionem ville ejus∣dem: et ideo quoad executionem istius brevis nihil actum est."
Hutchinson, in his History of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 405, notes, "The above table of burgesses not agreeing with the several retorns, implies that a peremptory writ had compelled an election." and Richard EmeldonPrynne ut supra, p. 1076..
In that held at Westminster A. D. 1321, by Michael Scott and Robert AngertonIbid..
In that held ibid. in the year 1325, by Richard Emelden and Adam GraperIbid..

In that held at York A. D. 1327, by Richard EmeldenHere appears to be another mistake, for Prynne, ut supra, says, "Anno 1 Ed. III. a writ to elect two knights for this county of Northumberland, and two citizens and burgesses for every borough within the same, was directed to the sheriff, who returned this answer to it much like the former: Communitas com' Northumbr' sic respondet: Quod ipsi per micos Scotiae adeo sunt destructi quod non habent unde solvere expens' duob mil∣bus proficiscuris ad tractatum & consilium apud Lincoln' tenend'. Ballivi libertatis Novi Castri super Tynam sic respondent. Quod ipsi tam onerantur circa salvam custo∣liam ville predicte quod nemine possunt de dicta villa carere. Ideo executio istius brevis ad presens fieri non potest." Prynne reasons from the three above memorable re∣turns (which were admitted good and reasonable for aught that appears to the contrary), that the just fear of an invasion by a known neighbouring foreign enemy (as the Scots were then to Northumberland and Newcastle), and the want of knights and burgesses to defend the county and borough in apparent danger to be invaded by the Scots, was a just legal ground to excuse this county and town (and by consequence any other in like con∣dition) to elect and send knights and burgesses to parliament, notwithstanding the King's writs to the contrary, that they should elect and cause them to resort thereto." and Th∣mas DaulinPrynne ut supra..

This return was made by the sheriff of Newcastle by indenture, being the first on record after the appointment of that officer.—Prynne ut supra, p. 282, part 3.
"The retorns for Newcastle upon Tyne anno 6 Ed. II. and 1 Ed. III. forecited, and the retorns for the county of Northumberland, are singular and rare, made by the sheriff of the county heretofore: but it being since a county, and having a sheriff of its own (to whom writs of election are immediately sent), the sheriff returned this indenture for it anno 25 Hen. VI. A. D. 1447.
"Hec indentura facta inter Johannem Ward vicecomitem ville Novi Castri super Tinam ex una parte & Rogerum Thornton armigerum, Willielmum Harding Johannem Musgrave Simonem Weldon Thomam Wardley, Rogerum Buthe Rogerum Harding Willielmum Medicroft Willielmum Barton Johannem Camer Thomam Castell Thomam Bees Robertum Baxter Johannem Baxter Alan Bird Johannem Bird Willielmum Rose Johannem Sampill Alan Cary Willielmum Furnes Willielmum Pray Robertum Lang∣wath Johannem Jay Roland Broughton, Johannem Penreth Willielmum Ferrour Johan∣nem Spencer Nicholaum Wythwam Johannem Kempe Willielmum Long Robertum Eltom Willielmum Reed Willielmum Ludworth Robertum Lidster et Johannem Well probos homines ville predicte qui proclamationi facte unde in brevi hinc indenture consut' fit mentio intersuerunt auctoritate ejusdem brevis eligerunt duos burgenses de discretioi∣bus et magis sufficientibus burgensibus ville predicte libere & indifferenter juxta formam statuti Domini Regis in eodem brevi specificat' viz. Willielmum Harding & Thomam Morislawe burgenses in eadem villa residentes ad interessendum ad parliamentum predict' pro communitate ejusdem ville ad faciend' et consentiend' eis que in eodem parliamento Deo savente, contigerit ordinari in omnibus et per omnia secundum formam et effectum predicti brevis. In cujus rei testimonium partibus hujus indenture tam predict' vic' quam prefat' electores sigilla sua apposuerunt. Dat' in pleno com' ville predicte primo die Februar' anno regni Regis Henrici sexti post conquestum Anglie vicesimo quinto." —Ibid.
It appears, from the above indenture, that the two members chosen were resident bur∣gesses of Newcastle. The electors were 35 in number., by William Hard∣ing and Thomas MorrislawPrynne ut supra, part 4..

In that which met ibid. April 2d, 1572, by William Carr and Wil∣liam Jennison, GentRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. May 8th, 1572, by William Selby and Wil∣liam Jennison, Gent.Randall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. November 23d, 1585, by Henry Anderson and William JennisonRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. October 29th, 1586, by Henry Anderson and Edward Lewen, aldermenRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. February 4th, 1588, by Henry Anderson and Henry Mitford, aldermenRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. November 19th 1592, by Henry Anderson and Edward Lewen, aldermenRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. October 24th, 1597, by Henry Mitford— sed quereRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408.?
In that which met ibid. October 7th, 1601, by William Jennison and George Selby, aldermenRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. March 19th, 1603, 1 Jac. I. by George Selby and Henry Chapman, Esqrs.Randall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408.
In that which met ibid. April 5th, 1614, by Henry Anderson, Knight, and—Randall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. January 30th, 1620, by Francis Anderson, Knight, and Thomas Riddell, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. February 19th, 1623, by Henry Anderson, Knight, and Peter Liddell, or Riddell, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that held ibid. June 21st, 1625, 1 Car. I. by Henry Anderson, Knight, and Thomas Liddell, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..

In that which met ibid. February 6th, 1626, by Henry Anderson, Knight, and Peter Riddell, Knight, by mistake, as it should seem, called Liddell, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. March 16th, 1628, by Thomas Riddell, Knight, and Peter Riddell, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..
In that which met ibid. April 13th, 1640, by Peter Riddell, Knight, and Thomas Liddell, EsqRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408.

In that which met ibid. November 3d, 1640, by Henry
Sir Henry Anderson, Knight, was disabled September 4th, 1643, for deserting the service of the house, and repairing to the army against the parliament. He subscribed the solemn league and covenant.—Parliamentary History, vol. xiii. p. 9.
Both these members took the protestation May 3d, 1641.—Nelson's Collections, vol. i. p. 811.
The writ for the election of another member for Newcastle, in the place of Sir Henry Anderson, appears not to have issued till September 3d, 1645.—Journals of Commons, vol. iv.
Robert Ellison, of Hebburn, and Henry Warmouth, Esqrs. were candidates on the above vacancy. Henry Warmouth, Esq was returned, but not suffered to keep his seat long after his election, and his election was declared void July 23d, 1647, and a writ issued eodem die.—Parliamentary History, vol. ix. p. 35.
May 29th, 1648, Mr. Blakiston and Mr. Ellison occur as members of Newcastle.— Common-council books. Anderson, Knight, and John Blackston, EsqRandall's MSS.

Oliver Cromwell, usurper, convened a parliament, called the Little Parliament, but no representatives for any cities or boroughs, except London, were returnedRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408..

By the instrument of government subscribed by Oliver Cromwell, December 16th, 1653, when he was inaugurated lord protector, in the regulation for the more equal representation of the kingdom, three members were assigned for the county of Northumberland, one for Newcastle upon Tyne, and one for BerwickPeck's Memoirs of Cromwell, p. 112.. In pursuance of the above plan, in the parliament that met September 3d, 1654, New∣castle upon Tyne was represented by Sir Arthur Hasilrig, BaronetRandall's MSS.—There is an order of the common-council of Newcastle, May 31st 1654, for allowing five shillings per day to such person as shall be elected member of par∣liament, ordered to be summoned to meet at Westminster, 3d September next..
In that which met September 17th, 1656, by Walter Strickland, EsqRandall's MSS.
In the parliament of Richard Cromwell, which met January 27th, 1658, Newcastle upon Tyne was represented by Mark Shaftoe and Thomas Lylburne, Esqrs.Ibid. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 408.

By a list of the names of those who served in the parliament begun at Westminster, April 25th, 1660, called the Healing Parliament, as they were returned into the Crown-Office, it appears that Robert Elli∣sonBy an entry in the common-council books of Newcastle, June 20th, 1660, it appear that Mr. Robert Ellison, merchant, who had served as one of the burgesses for Newcastle in the Long Parliament, begun in 1642, for a whole year, without any allowance from the town, received after the rate of ten shillings per diem, 182l. 10s. He died January 1th, 1677, aged 64 years. and William Calverley, Esqrs. were elected for Newcastle upon TyneParliamentary History, vol. xxii. p. 217..
In the parliament held in the 13th of Charles II. Francis Anderson, Knight, and John Marley, Knight, represented Newcastle upon TyneBooks of merchant-adventurers, September 25th, 1661..

In that which met January 12th, 1665, that town was represented by Sir Francis Anderson, Knight, and Sir John Marley, KnightFrom "The Names of all such, who were summoned to any parliament, or reputed parliament from the year 1640." London, octavo..

In the year 1674Sir John Marley died in October 1673, and I suppose Sir William Blackett to have been chosen in his stead. Sir William Blackett and Sir Francis Anderson were the representatives of that town in parliamentRandall's MSS..
In the parliament which met March 6th, 1678, that town was repre∣sented by Francis Anderson, Knight, and Sir William Blackett, Knight and BaronetIbid..

In that held A. D. 1679, by Ralph Carr, Knight, and Nathanael Johnson, Esq
Ibid. Sed quaere.—See a list of the House of Commons, which sat at Westminster from 21st of October, 1680, to the 10th of January, &c. London, 1681. Small octavo.
"Sir William Blackett, Baronet occur.
Sir Ralph Carr, Knight" occur.
In that which met at Oxford March 21st, 1680, by Ralph Carr and Nathanael Johnson, KnightsRandall's MSS..
In the parliament that met at Westminster May 19th, 1685, 1st James II. by Nathanael Johnson, Knight, and William Blackett, KnightRandall's MSS. Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 40..
In the Convention Parliament, which met January 22d, 1688, by Ralph Carr, Knight, and William Blackett, Knight and BaronetIbid..
In the parliament which met March 20th, 1689, 1st William and Mary, by Ralph Carr, Knight, and William Carr, EsqIbid.
In the parliament held 7th of King William, by William Blackett. Knight and Baronet, and William Carr, EsqIbid.
In that of the tenth of that king, by the sameIbid..
In that of the twelfth of the same king, by Henry Lyddell, Baronet, and William Carr, EsqIbid.
In the parliament held the year following, which met December 30th, 1701, by the sameRandall's MSS..
In that which met ibid. October 20th, 1702, by Henry Liddell, Baronet, and William Carr, Esq This was the first parliament of Queen AnnIbid..

In that which met October 25th, 1705, the first parliament of Great Britain, constituted by the Union, which commenced on May-day, 1707, by William Blackett, Knight and Baronet, and William Carr, EsqIbid.
Sir William Blackett died December 29th, 1705, and was succeeded by Sir Henry Liddell, Baronet.

In the second parliament of Great Britain, which was summoned for July 8th, 1708, and which met November 16th that year, by Henry Liddell, Baronet, and William Carr, EsqIbid. Sir Henry Liddell demanded a poll for priority, but Mr. Carr carried it.

In the third parliament of Great Britain, which met November 25th, 1710, by William Blackett, Baronet, and William Wrightson, EsqIbid. This was a contested election which lasted two days, and ended November 2d, 1710. There were three candidates.—Sir William Blackett had 1177 votes—Mr. Wrightson had 886; and William Carr, Esq alderman, the unsuccessful candidate, 609.
In the fourth parliament of Great Britain, summoned for November 12th, 1713, by William Blackett, Baronet, and William Wrightson, EsqIbid. They were chosen without any opposition.

In the first parliament of King George I. which met March 17th, 1715, by William Blackett, Baronet, and William Wrightson, EsqRandall's MSS. There were three candidates; Sir William Blackett polled 639, Mr. Wrightson 55, and Mr. Clavering 263. James Clavering, Esq the unsuccessful candi∣date, petitioned parliament on this occasion. See Journals of Commons, vol. xviii. March 30th, 1715.

In the sixth parliament of Great Britain, summoned for May 10th, and which met October 9th, 1722, by Sir William Blackett, Baronet, and William Carr, EsqIbid. April 4th, 1722, Sir William Blackett, Baronet, William Wrightson, Esq and William, son of Joseph Carr, Esq stood for burgesses for parliament:—Mr. Carr polled 1234, Sir William Blackett 1158, and Mr. Wrightson 831. The poll was printed by John White, Newcastle. Octavo, 40 pages.

In the first parliament of King George II, summoned for November 28th, 1727, by Sir William Blackett, Baronet, and Nicholas Fenwick, Esq
Ibid. The poll ended September 8th, 1727, when Sir William Blackett had 1202 votes, Mr. Fenwick 1189, and Mr. Carr 620. It began on the 6th of September.
Mr. Carr lodged his petition in 1727, but nothing was done therein till after Sir William Blackett's death, and then he was heard; and having disqualified above 600 of Sir Wil∣liam's voters for bribery, he was voted duly elected.
William Carr, Esq petitioner, came in afterwards on the death of Sir William Blackett, which happened September 29th, 1728, Aetatis 39.

In the eighth parliament of Great Britain, summoned to meet at Westminster, June 13th, 1734, by Walter Blackett, Esq and Nicholas Fenwick, EsqThis election, the poll-book of which was printed, lasted eight days, and ended on Thursday, May 9th, 1734. The candidates were Walter Blackett, Esq (originally Walter Calverley, Esq eldest son of Walter Calverley, of Calverley in the county of York, Baronet) who married the daughter and heiress of Sir William Blackett, Baronet, and took his firname, who had 1354. votes; Nicholas Fenwick, Esq and alderman, who had 1083; and William Carr, Esq and alderman, who had 716 votes. 1795 freemen voted on this occasion.

In the ninth parliament of Great Britain, summoned for June 25th, 1741, by Walter Blackett, Esq and Nicholas Fenwick, Esq
At this election, long known by the name of the great contest, which lasted six days, ending May 19th, 1741, the poll book of which was also printed, there were four candidates, all of them aldermen of the town: Walter Blackett, Esq who had 1453 votes; Nicholas Fenwick, Esq who had 1231; Matthew Ridley, Esq who had 1131; and Wil∣liam Carr, Esq who had 683 votes. 2391 freemen voted on this occasion.
William Carr and Matthew Ridley, Esqrs. were petitioners.
Mr. Carr died May 16th, 1742. Mr. Ridley renewed his petition in the second session.
Mr. Fenwick declined being a candidate in 1747, and died at Lemington A. D. 1752.

In the tenth parliament of Great Britain, summoned for August 13th, 1747, Walter Blackett, Esq and Matthew Ridley, were the repre∣sentatives of Newcastle upon TyneNewcastle Courant. Walter Blackett, Esq succeeded to the title of Baronet, October, 1749, on the death of his father. William Ord, Esq was a candidate at this election, but declined standing the poll..
In the eleventh parliament, A. D. 1754, Walter Blackett, Baronet, and Matthew Ridley, EsqNewcastle Courant

In the first parliament of George III. the town of Newcastle upon Tyne was represented by Walter Blackett, of Wallington, Baronet, and Matthew Ridley, of Heaton, Esq who were elected March 27th, 1761Ibid..
March 21st, 1768, the above were re-elected to represent that town in the 13th parliament of Great BritainIbid..

In the 14th parliament of Great Britain, Newcastle was represented by Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, and Sir Matthew White Ridley, of Blagdon, BaronetIbid. Newcastle, July 2d, 1774. Mr. Ridley resigned against the next general election. The contest on this occasion continued eight days, ending on Wednesday, October 19th, 1774. The poll book was printed. Sir Walter Blackett had 1432 votes; Sir Matthew White Ridley, 1411; the Hon. Constantine John Phipps, afterwards Lord Mulgrave, 795; and Thomas Delval, Esq 677. 2162 persons voted at this election; a smaller number by 229 than at the great contest in 1741, although 600 are said to have been ad∣mitted to their freedom on the occasion..

Sir John Trevelyan, Baronet, was chosen March 14th, 1777, on a va∣cancy occasioned by the death of his uncle,There was a hard contest on this occasion. It began Thursday, February 26th, 177, and lasted days.—John Trevelyan, Baronet, polled 1163; and Andrew Ro∣binson , Esq Mr Bowes lodged a petition, which accused Sir John bribery; but no proof that was thought sufficient having been produced, of the latter was dated valid by a committee of the House of Commons. Sir Walter Blackett, which happened at London, February 11th that year.

September 21st, 1780, Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, and Andrew Robinson Bowes, Esq were chosen representatives of that town in the fifteenth parliament of Great Britain
ended September 21st, 1780. Number of vo ; for Mr. Bowes, 1135; for Mr. Delaval, 183.
At the of which number it is remarkable, that 862 was Matthew White Ridley; 514 for Mr. Bowes; and 117 Mr. Delaval. Mr. petitioned against Mr. Bowes; as did some of the burgess Sir Matthew White Ridley, but nothing was done in either petition..

Newcastle upon Tyne was represented in the sixteenth parliament of Great Britain, A. D. 1784, by Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, and Charles Brandling, of Gosforth-house, EsqNewcastle Courant. Mr. Bowes was a candidate, but declined standing a poll on this occasion.

DIV2.HEAD:
RECORDERS OF NEWCASTLE
"The recorder is an officer of later institution than the mayor; for (as it seems by the course of the records) some one of the officers was of ability to direct the court, ac∣cording to the law of the land and customs of the city; but at length, matters in law in∣creasing, by good advice it was held expedient that a learned man should be chosen, to be always attendant upon the court and chamber of the city, to direct them in all matters of difficulty according to law."—Isaacke's History of Exeter, p. 50.
Town-clerks of Newcastle upon Tyne.
William Jackson, Gent. first town-clerk.
Robert Clavering.
Claudius Delavall.
Robert Delavall.
Thomas Riddle occurs October 6th, 1637, knighted by King Charles I. in May, 1639 he surrendered about 1645, and was succeeded by William Greene, Doctor of Civil Laws
Edward Man, merchant, was appointed by the Lords and Commons, May 26th, 1645, on the death of Greene. He died December 9th, 1654.
John Blakiston, Esq appointed February 14th, 1655. He surrendered.
Mention occurs of "Mr. Bowes, town-clerk," June 10th, 1661.
July 14th, 1662, Robert Marlay, Gent. son of Sir John Marlay, mayor, was appointed on the voluntary surrender of the patent of that office by J. Blakiston.
William Jennison, Gent. elected May 6th, 1675, on the resignation of Robert Marlay
John Douglas, Gent. elected September 27th, 1699, on the surrender of W. Jennison.
Joshua Douglas, Gent. son of the above, elected April 13th, 179, on the resignation of his father.—He died May 27th, 176.
George Cuthbertson, Gent. elected October 4th, 1742, on the surrender of the above.
George Cuthbertson, jun. Gent. elected December 17th, 1750, on the surrender of his father.
William Gibson, Gent. elected February 28th, 1756, on the death of the former, whose father, George Cuthbertson, senior, became a second time candidate for the office.
Nathanael Clayton, Gent. elected July, 1785, on the death of W. Gibson..
DIV2.P: ROBERT FULBURY occurs February 26th, 1466.
A. D. 1517, Thomas Tempest.—Sir Thomas Tempest occurs A. D. 1536.
March, 1588, "Mr. Caverley, Gent." occurs as such in St. Nicholas' Register.
March 22d, 1600, Sir John Savil, one of the Barons of the Ex∣chequer—named in Queen Elizabeth's charter.
Sir John Jackson, Knight, occurs A. D. 1609, and in 1621.
Sir Thomas Riddle, appointed between A. D. 1620 and 1624,— occurs July 28th, 1637.
Sir George Baker before September 8th, 1643; displaced by order of Lords and Commons May 26th, 1645.
Edward Wright, of Gray's Inn, Esq on the removal of the above.
Mark Shaftoe, Esq occurs August 29th, 1648. He died February 25th, 1659.
Sir Robert Shafto, Knight, occurs A. D. 1660; made serjeant at law in Easter-term, 1674.
In the town's books, September 23d, 1685, he is called "late re∣corder." He died 1705, May 21st, Aetatis 72.
Henry Lampton, Esq occurs as deputy recorder ibid. September 23d, 1685. He came in upon the renewing of the charter. He oc∣curs December 5th, 1687.
Joseph Barnes, Esq eldest son of alderman Ambrose Barnes, was ap∣pointed by King James II.'s letter mandatory to be "deputy recorder," December 24th, 1687, on the removal of Lampton.
Sir Robert Shafto, Knight, came in again at the Revolution.
William Davison, of Beamish, Esq was chosen on the death of Sir Robert Shafto, but he did not act, and soon resigned.
John Cuthbert, of Durham, Esq barrister at law, afterwards serjeant, was elected January 18th, 1706. He died April 5th, 1724.
John Isaacson, Esq was appointed January 21st, 1725. He died January 3d, 1737.
Edward Collingwood, Esq barrister at law, elected February 13th, 1737. He resigned in November, 1739.

William Cuthbert, Esq barrister at law, was elected November 12th,
To Matthew White Rudley Bar M. P. ALDERMAN and GOVERNOR of the Company of MERCHANT ADVENTURERS of NEWCASTLE upon TYNE, This ee of the Exchange of that Town engraved at his Expence is most respectfully inscribed by his very obliged & most devoted faithful humble Servant John Brnd
1739. He was the eldest son of the former recorder of that sirname. He died August 29th, 1746.
Christopher Fawcett, Esq barrister at law, elected September 3d, 1746.—Son of John Fawcett, Esq recorder of Durham.
Edward Collingwood, of Chirton, Esq who had been made an alder∣man, was re-chosen recorder July 23d, 1753, on the resignation of C. Fawcett.
Christopher Fawcett, Esq appointed a second time on the resignation of E. Collingwood, December 6th, 1769.

DIV2.HEAD: MERCHANT-ADVENTURERS OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.
DIV2.P: TO the assistances of commerce society will be found indebted for the greater part of whatever contributes to the use, convenience or ele∣gance of life. Every acknowledgment is due to it from the inhabi∣tants of islands; and we of Britain, with our very existence perhapsBritain is supposed, with great probability, to have been first peopled by Grecian Phoenician merchants.—See Bertram's Ricardus Corinensis, p. 50., owe it all that gives value to our present being; our progress in science; our improvement in every art; our personal security; our national opulence and grandeur, and, probably, what ought to be of the highest concern to us, our superior knowledge of religious truth.

The particulars of a subject, which is found of such moment in the general consideration, cannot be thought trivial, nor will that labour seem unimportant, which had collected the scattered memorials of those inhabitants of this place, who, devoting themselves to the pro∣fession of merchandize, have in a long and uninterrupted succession, with the gradual improvement of their town, aggrandized their re∣spective families, and contributed in no small degree to the common advancement of the state.

Mercantile societies, anciently called guilds
Anderson, in his Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 70, tells us, "that at first the word guild, in England, was only applied to the body or community of a city or town, or of religious body of community (for there were ecclesiastical guilds, as well as afterwards we find the aggregate body of merchants or traders of a city or town called the Gilda Mercatoria."
"In England," says Madox, in his Firma Burgi, p. 23, &c. "the word gild is of Anglo-Saxon birth; and signified a company, society, brotherhood; and sometimes the privileges or free customs belonging to such company. In former times there were many guilds in England; some of them religious, others secular. The religious gilds were founded chiefly for devotion and alms deeds; the secular, chiefly for trade and alms deeds.", or fraternities, are thought
to have been first founded in Europe, near the latter end of the eleventh century. Unknown to the Saxons while in this kingdom, they are supposed to have been brought into it first by the Normans, who in their turn are said to have borrowed them of the free cities of Italy; the very early residences of trade and manufactures, and the places where merchant guilds were probably first establishedAnderson ut supra, vol. i. p. 70, in anno 1090..

Our early commerce stood much indebted to the protection of the otherwise unfortunate monarch King John, for, by erecting such mer∣chant guilds in his free boroughs, he gradually paved the way for its first introduction into the kingdomIbid. vol. i. p. 97, 98..

The borough of Newcastle upon Tyne, distinguished by some pri∣vileges in former charters, was honoured very early in his reign with new franchises and more extensive immunities. It was not, how∣ever, till his seventeenth
In the sixth year of King John A. D. 1204, there appears to have been no very consi∣derable body of merchants at Newcastle upon Tyne. With those of other towns they paid a quinzime, or fifteenth, for their goods and merchandizes in the subsequent proportion.
£. s. d.
Lond' is rated at 836 12 10
Boston at 780 15 3
Southampton at 712 3 7
Lyn at 651 11 11
Newcastle upon Tyne at 158 5 9"
See Madox's History of the Exchequer, folio edition, p. 530. year that he constituted therein a society of free merchants
The subsequent clause in King John's charter to Newcastle, given in his 17th year, contains the foundation of our society: "Johannes Dei gratia &c.—Concessimus etiam eis (viz. burgensibus nostris de Novo Castro super Tinam) gildam mercatoriam; et quod nullus eorum qui fuerit infra gildam suam mercatoriam placitet extra muros burgi Novi Castri de ullo placito preter placitum de tenuris exterioribus—et quod omnes bur∣genses predicti burgi et heredes eorum de gilda mercatoria quieti sint de theolonia, lastagio, pondagio et passagio tam in feria quam extra, et per omnes portus maris omnium terrarum nostrarum tam citra mare quam ultra—si quis autem in tota terra nostra theolo∣nium vel consuetudines ab hominibus ville Novi Castri super Tynam de gilda mercatoria ceperit, postquam ipse a recto defecerit vic' Northumbr' vel prepositus Novi Castri namium apud Novum Castrum inde capiat—&c.—Apud Dunolm' 28o Januarii anno regni nostri septimo decimo."
In a petition of the governor, wardens, assistants and fellowship of merchant-adventurers of Newcastle upon Tyne to parliament, 1644, they set forth, "that they have beene an antient company of merchants ever since King John's tyme, and have been confirmed by several grants of his majesty's royal predecessors a distinct corporation of themselves"— adding, "That the merchants of Newcastle are an antient guild of merchants ever since the 17th yeare of King John, which is a year before the grant to the merchants of London." —From a copy entered in the books of this society—also an original deed, dated January 12th, 1535, remaining in their archives., the members of which he exempted from pleading
any where without its walls to any plea, but that concerning foreign tenures: he released them also from the duties of toll, lastage, pontage and passage, not only during the fair he had established there, but also at other times, and in all his sea ports, as well abroad as at home; impowering the chief magistrate of Newcastle, or the sheriff of North∣umberland, to give them reparation for every injury that should be done them, by distraining the moveable goods of those who should violate this privilege at Newcastle.

Henry the Third confirmed the above merchant guild to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, by a charter which was allowed to the bailiffs of that place in the King's Bench, in the 4th and the 15th years of Edward I. It is unknown in what particular year of his reign he granted this charter of confirmationAubone MS..

Anciently our English merchants appear to have been prohibited from carrying staple commodities out of the realmAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 117.: an Italian mer∣chant,
named Bonricini Guidiconi, occurs exporting goods to a very great amount from Newcastle, in the year 1281, and paying for him∣self and his associates, merchants of Luca, in his account for the then new custom of wool, skins, and leather, for one year, the sum of 323l. 35s. 9d. the custom of 771 sacks, seven stone and an half of wool; and of eighty lasts and twelve dakers of leather, at the port of that townMadox's History of the Exchequer, folio edition, p. 634..

Madox's Firma Burgi exhibits this society as distinct from the other burgesses of Newcastle, in the year 1308, when some disputes occa∣sioning a suit in the Exchequer, William Sadler, says that authority, "with ten others, for the rest of the poor burgesses of that town, re∣covered 50l. damages of Nicholas de Carliol, and other burgesses of the gild mart of Newcastle upon TyneP. 95.."

King Edward II. by a charter dated at York, November 12th, 1318, confirmed to this society, the original foundation charter of the 17th of King John before recited, with all its customs, notwithstanding the non-use of them, and with the addition of new privileges
See charters under that year.
A curious letter of King Edward III. dated April, 28th, 1329, to the keeper of the kingdom of Dacia; a second to Henry Swart, burgess of Wysmer, in Germany; and a third to the Earl of Holland, of the same date, in behalf of Robert Musgrave, merchant and burgess of Newcastle upon Tyne, against certain pirates who had plundered his ship, called "The Good Year," occurs in Rymer's Foedera, tom. iv. p. 382..

The quantity of wool imposed upon Newcastle upon Tyne, towards the payment of thirty thousand sacks, granted to King Edward the Third, by his parliament, A. D. 1341, was seventy-three sacks, one quarter, two stone, three pounds and three quartersRotuli Parliament. vol. ii. p. 131..

By a charter dated October 20th, 1343, liberty was granted to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne at large, to purchase at prime cost, out of all ships coming into that port, such merchandises as were ne∣cessary
for the private use of each; which was an infringement of the particular immunities of the merchant guild of that place
See charters under that year.
A. D. 1346, it was granted to the men of Newcastle upon Tyne, that they might trans∣port their merchandise to any part of the kingdom, without payment of subsidy.— Aubone MS.—also Murray MS. claus. anno 20 Ed. III. p. 1, m. 16."
A. D. 1347, the commons of Newcastle upon Tyne petitioned the King and his council in parliament against the payment of seventy-three sacks, one quarter, two stone, and two pounds of wool, imposed upon them by certain commissioners; setting forch their great impoverishment by various taxes and extortions, to the imminent danger of the entire desertion of that town, and destruction of the adjacent country.—Rot. Parl. vol ii. p. 178..

In the year 1353 King Edward III. on a slight put upon him by the Flemings, whose Earl, though affianced to one of his, had married a daughter of the Duke of Brabant, removed the staple of English wool into England, when Newcastle upon Tyne, in common with nine others, was first made a staple town
Rot. Parl. vol. ii. p. 246.—See Echard's and Rapin's Histories of England.—See also statute 27 Ed. III. In the ordinances of the fees of the mayors and constables of the staple in the above statute, the fee of the mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne is rated at ten pounds.
Blount, in his Law Dictionary in verbo, says, "Staple signifies this or that town or city, whither the merchants of England were by act of parliament to carry their wool, cloth, lead, tin, and such-like staple commodities of this land, for the utterance of them by the great—from the French estape, i. e. forum vinarium, a market for wines, the staple com∣modity of France; or rather from the German stapelen, to gather or heap any thing together."
It appears from Rymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 875, that a royal licence, dated Novem∣ber 25th, 1356, was granted to Thomas Grey, then a prisoner in Scotland, a circumstance to which, probably, he owed the indulgence to ship an hundred sacks of his wool at Ber∣wick upon Tweed for Flanders, without carrying them to the port of Newcastle upon Tyne, where of right they ought to have been shipped..

King Edward III. by his charter, dated May 10th, 1358, confirmed the former privileges granted to the merchants of Newcastle, in the twelfth of Edward II. and in the 17th year of King JohnSee under charters that year, in History of Newcastle as a corporate town..

In the year 1369 the staple of wool and other commodities at Calais was effectually set aside, and ordered to be confined in future
to ten English ports, in which number that of Newcastle upon Tyne was includedAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 197.—Also Statutes at Large..

Although King Edward the Third, in consideration of the declining state of his town of Calais, had, in the year 1376, made it again the only staple port for English merchandise beyond the seas, yet we find King Richard II. in 1397, granting leave to the merchants of Newcastle to carry woolfels, and other commodities, to any other foreign port besides Calais, on condition of their paying custom and subsidyAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 204. We collect from the same author that, in the year 1390, the staple of English goods was removed from Calais to Newcastle, &c. as in 1353. It had been removed from Middleburg to Calais A. D. 1388, but it is unknown when it had been brought from the former to the latter place, where, however, it could not have remained a long time, having, as shewn above, been fixed at Calais in 1376.. Cot∣ton, in his Posthuma, p. 186, speaking of this, calls it a shameful privilege.

About the year 1398 a great commercial correspondence appears to have subsisted between Newcastle, and other English ports, and Campen, Lubeck, Hamburgh, Bremen, Staden, Wismar, Rostock, Straelfund, Gripeswald, &c. the principal hanse towns; as also Dantzick, Elbing, Marienburg, Thorn, Koningsberg, &c. places more immediately under the master-general of Prussia, for English woollen cloth, herring, and other commoditiesIbid. vol. i. p. 23..

King Henry IV. A. D. 1400, on petition of the mayor and mer∣chants of the staple of Calais, revoked the licence granted in the year 1397, to the merchants of Newcastle, for transporting staple ware to other places besides CalaisPrynne's Cotton's Abridgment of Records in the Tower, p. 48..

In the year 1405Hackluyt's Voyages, vol. i. p. 166. William Esturmy, Knight, and John Kington, canon of Lincoln, were deputed by the King, to require satisfaction for injuries done by the commonalties of the cities of Wismar and Rostok, against the liege people of the crown of England. At the head
of these, they stand charged with seizing a ship of Newcastle, called "The Good YearThis appears to have happened about Easter, 1394. Two of her crew were killed in the attack, and the rest detained in prison three years.," on her voyage to Prussia, of the burthen of two hundred tuns, the property of Roger Thornton, Robert Gabiford, John Paulin, and Thomas de Chester, valued, with her tackling, at four hun∣dred pounds, and laden with woollen cloth, red wine, &c. to the amount of two hundred marks of English money. Amongst the griev∣ances stated against these by the merchants of the Hans of Almaine, is an injury charged as having been done at NewcastleThis Redewish sets forth, that, having brought several goods to Newcastle upon Tyne, and paid the usual custom of three-pence in the pound for all his wares, the bailiffs o that town exacted seven pounds sterling more than their due., by the bailiffs of that place, to Albert Redewish of Prussia.
Matters were adjusted for some time, and an agreement made between the King of England, and the common society of the Hans, given at Dordract, December 15th, 1405.
A. D. 1415, King Henry V. repealed all licences granted to the men of Newcastle and Berwick, to carry merchandise to other places than to CalaisAppendix to Ruffhead's Statutes, vol. ix. p. 63..

In the year 1426 King Henry VI. renewed a licence, granted in 1397 to the merchants of Newcastle, to transport their wool to other ports besides CalaisSir Robert Cotton, speaking of the unlawful ways by which the kings of England have supported themselves, tells us, they sold licences contrary to the Calais act, and in∣stances as follows: "Hen. VI. nis 5, 21, 30, reneweth to the town of Newcastle the same they had anno 20 Ric. II."—Cottoni Posthuma, p. 186..
A. D. 1429, the above licence was again repealed, and the staple of wool strictly enjoined to be kept at CalaisAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 257..

A petition of the commons of Northumberland, Cumberland, West∣moreland, and the bishoprick of Durham occurs A. D. 1431, that the merchants of Newcastle might be allowed at all times to buy and
transport such wools as were the produce of the above counties, but which the King refused to grantPrynne's Cotton's Records abridged, p. 60. The answer, "The King will be ad∣vised," which is generally known to be a flat refusal from the crown..

In the year 1442 King Henry VI. renewed the licence granted before in 1397; repealed afterwards, and then renewed again in 1426, and again repealed in 1429, and 1432, to the merchants of Newcastle, to transport their wool to other ports besides CalaisCottoni Posthuma, p. 186..

In the year 1448 a statute was made that no licence should be available to carry wools, fells or tin, to any place out of the kingdom, except to CalaisRthead's Appendix to Statutes, vol. ix. p. 77. Also Anderson ut supra, vol. i. p. 27.: and yet we find, in 1452, the King renewing a licence so often repealed, and renewed before to the merchants of Newcastle to transport their wool to other ports besides CalaisCottoni Posthuma, p. 18, confirmed by a clause in the statute, 4 Ed. IV. c. ..

An act passed A. D. 1464, 4 Edw. IV. that, after the feast of St. John Baptist next, no wools, woolfels, shorlyngs or morlyngs of the growth of Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmoreland, Durham, Richmondshire, or Allertonshire, should be shipped any where but at Newcastle upon Tyne, on pain of forfeitureRot. Parl. vol. v. p. 53..
A. D. 1475, King Edward IV. appointed, or rather confirmed, a staple for wools in the northern parts of the kingdom at Newcastle upon TyneIbid. vol. vi. p. 157..

In the year 1480 the society of merchants of Newcastle upon Tyne subscribed a written agreement, consisting of certain articles formed for the better government of that body, and which were to remain in force for six yearsBooks of the Society.—They bind themselves to meet and hold their courts at the Maison-Diu hall on the Sand-Hill, on the last Thursday of every month—their head meeting (called a guild) to be on the Thursday next after "Mid-fast" Sunday— to serve seven year.—The society are to go in procession on Corpus Christi day, when they are to appear in the Meal-market, by seven o'clock in the morning (by an after insertion, the time is altered till "after high mass be done.") Those persons of the society, who for the time being shall be mayor, sheriff, or aldermen, to attend with then officers and servants upon the Holy Sacrament, and according to seniority of office are to be principal in the said solemn procession, in which the latest made burgess is to walk foremost. The name of the play they acted was "Hogmagog."—Many entries occur in their books concerning the expences of the above procession and play. In these orders men∣tion occurs of ships above the burthen of two hundred tuns. Also, "with and without forecastle." The brethren of the society beyond the sea are also mentioned in them..

December 4th, 1504, a licence was granted by King Henry VII. to the governor and merchants of the merchant gild of Newcastle upon Tyne, impowering them, till the first of August next, to buy any wools or woolfels of the growth of Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmore∣land, Durham, Allerton, and Richmondshires (except those of the growth of those parts of Northumberland which were assigned to the town of Berwick), and ship them from Newcastle to any parts of Flanders, Brabant, Holland, Zeland, or any foreign parts, at two ship∣pings, paying for every sack of wool ten shillings, and the like sum for every two hundred and forty woolfelsFrom a copy in the archives of the society..
March 18th, 1506, the same king granted the said body a licence to the same purpose as the above, but without limitation of timeIbid..
December 11th, 1509, King Henry VIII. renewed the above grant, which had been made void by the death of his father, and without limi∣tation of timeIbid..
In the year 1517 King Henry VIII. made an exemplification of former grants to the merchants of NewcastleA memorial in their archives, dated January 12th, 1535..

A composition was made at Antwerp, in the year 1519, by which it was stipulated that this society, in lieu of all impositions, should pay the sum of eight pounds per annum to the merchants of London be∣yond seaMerchants books..

The exports of this society about the year 1520 appear to have
been canvass, sheepskins, lambfells, lead, grindstones, coals, and rough and tanned leather. From the circumstance of coal and grindstones being found in the above list ofBooks of the society. exports, and from many others, there is great reason to suppose that the hostmen were originally a branch of this fellowship, till incorporated as a distinct society by the charter of the 42d of Elizabeth
"Ostmen money" often occurs in their old books,—as do also almost all the names of the new hostmen in the charter of 42d Elizabeth, as brethren of this society.
It is observable in these books A. D. 1515, that stewards for the mercers and boothmen are chosen, but no mention occurs of the drapers.
By a by-law dated 1524, it was ordered that no brother of this society should carry any goods into the country, either by water or land carriage, but to free fairs, except such of them as travelled with a foot-pack, which last, however, were to be allowed neither horse, hamper, nor mail..

In the year 1528 this society occurs by their governor and two wardens recommending a brother, on the payment of the usual duties, to be admitted into the fellowship of merchant-adventurers of England: to which privilege it appears, by the tenor of their recommendation, that any merchant who had served seven years to one of the fraternity at Newcastle had a just and unquestionable claim
Bourne's History of Newcastle upon Tyne.
A. D. 1534, the exports of this society to Zealand appear to have been skins, wool, lead, tanned leather, cloth, woollen cloth, and kerseys.—Books of the society.
By a by law of this society this year, it was ordered that the corpse of every brother, who during his life-time had paid his month-pence, should be preceded to church at burial by the common lights of the fraternity; a funeral honour to be paid also on the like con∣ditions to that of his wife.
The merchants of the staple at Calais having, in 1540, contributed to the entertain∣ment of Ann of Cleves, then affianced to King Henry VIII. and at that place on her way to her royal husband at London, this society were required to contribute their share of the expence on the occasion.—Merchants books; also Hall's Chronicle, fol. 238..

September 1st, 1546, King Edward VI. granted a charter to the merchants of Newcastle, by the title of merchants venturers in the parts of Brabant beyond the seas, to consist of a governor, twelve assistants, and two wardens, to be elected and sworn on the 9th day of October
in every year; to have perpetual succession; power to sue and be sued, &c.See Seals, Plate I. No. 10, and 14. a seal, a clerk and beadle; power to purchase lands, to take recognizances, to make by-laws, to buy and ship to foreign parts wool and woolfels of the growth of Northumberland (except of such parts thereof as were assigned to Berwick upon Tweed), Cumberland, Westmoreland, and Durham, and the liberties of Richmond, and Aller∣ton, in Yorkshire; to pay a duty of ten shillings for every sack of wool to the crown, and the like sum for every two hundred and forty wool∣fels, with the accustomed duties for skins called shorlyng and morlyng, and lambskins, to the collectors at the port of Newcastle upon Tyne
From a copy at full length in Grey's MS. collections; and another included in the charter of Inspeximus, granted by Queen Mary, and which I found, by whatever accident, among the records of the corporation of Newcastle. See Appendix.
In a statute made 5 and 6 Ed. VI. c. 7, limiting the time for buying and selling wools, there is a proviso in favour of the merchants of Newcastle.
By a by-law of this fellowship, dated 1553, a weigh-master is ordered to be sent over to the "lordes of Barrowe and Cawes," with power to take in the weigh-house "three stovers" of every pack of wool.—This book was to be sent over annuall, presents were to be made him..

Queen Mary, by a charter of Inspeximus, dated 15th of November, 1553, confirmed to this society the above charter of her late royal brother, but without the addition of any new privileges
From a copy at full length in Grey's MS. collections; and another included in the charter of Inspeximus, granted by Queen Mary, and which I found, by whatever accident, among the records of the corporation of Newcastle. See Appendix.
In a statute made 5 and 6 Ed. VI. c. 7, limiting the time for buying and selling wools, there is a proviso in favour of the merchants of Newcastle.
By a by-law of this fellowship, dated 1553, a weigh-master is ordered to be sent over to the "lordes of Barrowe and Cawes," with power to take in the weigh-house "three stovers" of every pack of wool.—This book was to be sent over annuall, presents were to be made him..

A by-law of this society, dated 1554, concerning the apprentices of the fellowship, exhibits an interesting picture of the then dress and manners: in this, among other affectations of finery unbecoming their stations and years, our mercantile tyros are forbidden to wear beards; another act of the same date enjoins, that every apprentice shall serve ten years
Books of the society.—"An act for the apperell of the apytices, made ∣vember, 1554, Mr. Cuthber Ellyon then beyng governour." After inve follows against the vices and excesse of the times," "What dy, urmuyng, what typling, daunseng and bras of hlo what hose lned with silke and cutt shos! what of girtnes by nyght, what of berds! what daggers vs by them worne crosse overthwart their back, that the the dooings are more cumlye and decent than seemlie for ho I appren∣tizes!" the act proceeds to forbid apprentices "to daunse, dyse, carde, or mum, or use any gytternes; to wear any cut hose, cut shoes or pounced jerkens, or any berds; to weare none other hoses than sloppes of course clothe wherof the yarde do not excede 12d. —their shoes and cotes to be of course clothe, and housewifes makeing—they are to wear no straite hoose, but playn without cutts, pounsyng or gards."—The apprentices of mayors, sheriffs and aldermen are excepted in the dress articles of this very humili∣ating order.
In 1556 this society occurs as trading in wools, lead, and cloth to Flanders, "at the colde and Easter marte, as also at Danske, and to France."—The following year two ships of war are mentioned as convoying their fleet to Zealand..

On the capture of Calais by the French in 1558, an event highly prejudicial to the commerce, and derogatory to the honour of Eng∣land, the staple of wool, &c. was removed to Bruges. The loss of this well-situated staple-port, that in more early times had dispensed the wool, lead and tin, and in later, the woollen manufactures of Eng∣land, into the inland countries of the Netherlands, France and Ger∣many, is said to have made Queen Mary break her heartAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 392..

Queen Elizabeth granted a charter of Inspeximus to this society, dated May 10th, 1558, confirming the former ones of her late royal brother and sister, but without the addition of any new privileges
Original in the archives of the society.—In the year 1559, the fleet of this society was convoyed to Flanders by the Falcon, a Queen's ship of war.
This year too, among their expenditures, occurs the subsequent article: "Paid forty shillings for pressing of men to the Mary Flour."—In 1560 the society resident here con∣sisted of 79 brethren..

December 16th, 1561, a licence was granted to this society by Queen Elizabeth, in the same words with that of a former one dated December 11th, 1509, extending the privileges contained therein, from the time of Queen Mary's death, during pleasureIbid..

A remarkable order, originating, no doubt, in their hatred of the moss troopers, occurs in the books of this society in 1564, prohibiting any person born in Tyndale, Tiddesdale, or such like place, to be ad∣mitted apprentice. The reason assigned for this restriction will at this time appear no less strange: "The parties there brought up are
known either by education or nature not to be of honest conver∣sationBooks of the society.—They are said to "commit frequent thefts and other felonys"— so that no apprentices are to be taken, "proceeding from such lewde and wicked pro∣genitors."—This act was not repealed till A. D. 1771..

In the year 1566 the English Russia company obtained the sanc∣tion of an act of parliament, the last clause of which decreed, that every one of the Queen's subjects inhabiting York, Newcastle upon Tyne, Hull and Boston, who had followed merchandise for ten years, and before the 25th of December, 1567, should join stock with them, should be accounted free, and enjoy every privilege of that society.

This Russian company, or society of merchant-adventurers of England for the discovering of lands, islands, &c. unknown, had been incorporated by Queen Mary, February 26th, 1554. It had met with great losses, and was, in 1566, refounded by Queen Eliza∣beth, by the name of the Fellowship of English Merchants for the discovery of new trades
Hackluyt's Voyages, vol. i. p. 369.—Also Anderson's Commerce, vol. i. p. 44, 405. This clause in favour of the northern ports of England was owing to their hav∣ing been early contributors to the first attempt for a north-east passage. It is observable that this statute was the first that established an exclusive mercantile corporation.
In the year 1567, the brethren of this society resident here amounted to 113..

A special licence was granted by Queen Elizabeth to the merchants of Newcastle, 1574, to ship and transport from that town into the parts beyond the seas, wool and woolfels, on payment of certain duties for the same, to her officers in the custom-house of that portMerchants books.—It appears ibid, that on the 9th of October, 1604, they petitioned King a renewal of the above licence determined by the death of the Queen..

In the year 1579 Queen Elizabeth granted a charter to the East∣land company of merchants. Those of Newcastle had the privilege of taking up the freedom of this new society, whose province it was to enjoy the sole trade through the Sound into Norway, Sweden, Poland, Lithuania (excepting Narva, which was within the Russian company's charter), Prussia and Pomerania, from the river Oder east∣ward,
Dantzick, Elbing and Koningsberg; also to Copenhagen and Elsinore, and to Finland, Gothland, Bornholm and Oeland.

In this society every one traded on his separate bottomMerchants books.—The first books of Eastland courts belonging to the merchants of Newcastle are lst.—That which has been preserved begins A. D. 1662, and ends June 21st, 183. The East Country is a name used of old, and still given by mercantile per∣sons to the parts of the Balti sea, but more especially to those in Prussia and Livonia..

In the year 1591 Queen Elizabeth granted under her privy seal to the merchants of Newcastle, an allowance of two shillings in the pound, and every fist-cloth for a wrapper, in the custom of their cloth
See a following article under the year 1605.
A licence was granted 1595, by the Queen's patentee, to Mr. Francis Anderson, a brother of the merchant-adventurers of Newcastle upon Tyne, to have the sole brew of ale and beer, for making beer, vinegar, beeragar and alegar within that town and its liberties.
The original deed, dated December 11th, in the 38th of Queen Elizabeth, is remain∣ing in the archives of the society..

By a clause in the charter of the 42d of Elizabeth to the corporation of Newcastle, statute-merchant was ordered to be taken before the mayor and burgesses of that town, or mayor and common-council, or the major part of them, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven. Statute-merchant is defined to be a bond acknowledged before one of the clerks of the statute-merchant and mayor of the staple, or before the chief warden or mayor of other cities or good towns, sealed with the seal of the debtor and of the King, which is of two pieces, whereof the greater is kept by the said mayor, &c. and the less by the said clerkSee plate of Miscellaneous Antiquities, No. 10..

By another clause in the above-cited charter, the custom of foreign bought and foreign sold was confirmed in the subsequent words: "We have by these presents, for us, our heirs and successors, granted to the said mayor and burgesses of the aforesaid town, and their suc∣cessors, that no merchant being a foreigner or stranger, from the
liberty of the town of Newcastle, shall or may sell any of the merchandises or wares within the said town, except victuals, and ex∣cept in the markets and fairs to be kept within the aforesaid town and liberties and precincts of the same, unto any foreign merchants: neither may or shall any such foreign merchants buy any ware or merchandise, except as before excepted, and except in the fairs to be kept in the aforesaid town, the limits and liberties of the same as aforesaid, from any foreign merchant within the same town, the liber∣ties and precincts of the same, upon pain of forfeiture of those mer∣chandises, so as aforesaid bought and sold, to the public use of the said mayor and burgesses, by them or their officers to be levied or seized for ever in as ample manner and form as in the said town hath been heretofore lawfully usedSee under charters, History of Newcastle as a corporate town.."

The exports of this society, A. D. 1603, were wool, rough sheep-skins, lead, white leather, double dozens, single dozens, karseys, long cloths, Coventry cloths, cottons great and small, black lead, lead ore, lamb, fox and coney skinsBooks of the society..

King James I. granted a charter of Inspeximus to this society, April 14th, 1603, confirming those of his royal predecessors, Edward VI. Queen Mary, and Queen Elizabeth, but without the addition of any new privilegesFrom the original remaining in the archives of the society. See Appendix..

It was ordered by a by-law of this fraternity, November 10th, 1603, that their apprentices should be forbidden to "daunce, dice, carde, mum, or use any musick either by nyght or by day in the streetes." Their apparel of cloth to be under ten shillings a yard, or of fustian, of or under three shillings per yard.—They are not "to weare any velvat or lace on their apparell, neither any silke garters, silke or velvet girdles, silke pointes, worsted or Jersey stockings, shoe strings of sylk, pumpes, pantofles, or corke shoes, hats lyned with velvat, nor double cypress hat-bands, or silke strings, nor clokes and daggers,
neither any ruffled bands but falling bands, plaine without laice, stiche or any kind of sowen work, neither shall they weare their haire longe nor locks at their ears like ruffians." A special gaol or prison was provided, for the punishment of the refractory and disobedient, in the west-gate of the town, to which a gaoler was appointed with a salary of forty shillings per annum
Books of the society.
A. D. 1605, an act passed for the granting and establishing of certain former allow∣ances to the merchants of York, Hull, and Newcastle, in the custom of their cloths, ac∣cording to a privy seal in the 33d year of the reign of Queen Elizabeth.
A. D. 1618, the exports of this society were "sheepskins, short cloth, long cloth, kerseys, lead, &c."—Their imports, "rye, rough and yellow flax, tow, soap, wine, iron, wrought and drest hemp, honey, tar, pitch, wainscots, clap-board, oars, hops, madder, brasil, cordage, prunes, raisins, ditto of the sun, sugar, rosin, frying-pans and dripping-pans, battery, &c.".

April 4th, 1622, an order was made by this society to restrain the secret transportation of money, gold, plate or bullion, or any foreign gold or money, more than was barely requisite for necessary expences, tolls, &c. by the brethren of their fellowship, on pain of disfranchise∣mentMerchants books..

In the year 1636 the London merchants at Rotterdam laid a new imposition on the cloth of those of Newcastle, though a composition had been made at Antwerp, A. D. 1519, for the payment of 8l. by this society to those of London beyond sea, in lieu of all impositions, and which till this time had been constantly tendered and accepted. They petitioned the King on this occasion, who referred the matter to his privy council: the privy council referred it to the Lord Chief Justices and Lord Chief Baron, who reported in favour of the Newcastle merchantsIbid. Between 1642 and 1649 several letters were sent back unopened, that had been addressed by those of Rotterdam to this society, by the title of "Deputy Governor, &c. of the merchant-adventurers of Newcastle upon Tyne.".
It appears that, during the continuance of the Scottish army in New∣castle, A. D. 1641, no merchants courts were held thereIbid..

William Warmouth, Esq merchant-adventurer, thrice mayor of Newcastle, and who died July 22, 1642, aged 83, by his last will, dated the day of his death, gave an hundred pounds to the common-council of that town, to be lent for three years, without interest, to a young merchantMerchants books..

A. D. 1643, the merchants of Newcastle evinced their loyalty to King Charles I. by a loan of nearly five hundred pounds, collected amongst themselves, to be laid out in defence of the garrison of that townIbid. In the year 1645 they made an order for repairing, at their common cost, that part of the town wall of Newcastle which lies betwixt Sand-Gate and the Carpenter's Tower.—That reparation however was effected by other means. About this time also they presented Sir James Lumsden, governor of Newcastle, with a tun of wine..

In the year 1649 a by-law of this society ordered that every ap∣prentice should "cutt his haire from the crowne of his heade, keepe his foreheade bare, his lockes, if any, shall not reatch below the lap of his eare, and the same length to be observed behind: and if in caise any be sicke, he shall weare a linnen cap and no other, and that without lace. And they shall weare no beaver hatts, nor castors, if their hattes be blacke they shall have blacke bands, if gray hatts their bands suit∣able: but neither gold nor silver woorke in any of them; neither fancies nor ribbins at their hatbands: the cloth for their apparell shall not exceed 14 or 15 shillings the yerde: they shall weare no stuff of silke or cammell haire; their clothes shall be made plaine up without lace or any other trimminges except buttons; and them only in places needfull—and no better than of silke. Their bands shall be plaine without lace or scallopes. They shall weare no cutts, boot-hos-tops or culloured showes or showes of Spanish lether, long neb'd showes or bootes: noe silke garters at all nor show strings better then serret or cotton ribbin, no gloves but plaine, nor bootes but when they ride
Merchants books.—At a court 5th of October, 1649, nine of the apprentices refused to conform to the above order, and were allowed till the 7th of December next to consi∣der of it, when three of them "shewing themselves disobedient and very obstinate, were first in open court (where a dish is said to have been kept, by the edge of which their hair was cut round) made exemplary by shortninge their hayre, and taking from their clothes superfluous ribbining: and for their wilfull obstinacy were committed to prison, where each was allowed no more than two-pence in breade and one quarte of table beare per diem." After eleven days confinement they petitioned the governor and fellowship, and desire their worships "to passe by and be oblivious of all their misdemeanors," promising also to conform on their enlargement, which was granted them.
The formal appearance exhibited by these disfigured youths provoked even the satire of these very formal times, and we find accordingly a brother of the society complained of for mocking them, and calling them "the company's coued tupps," in the coarse and homely language of that age.."

November 28th, 1649, the merchants of Newcastle petitioned par∣liament for two frigates to protect the port and trade of that town, by the convoying and better securing of goods at seaMerchants books..
February 14th, 1650, this society lent the corporation of Newcastle 100l. towards maintaining the common privileges of that townIbid. Repaid A. D. 1672..

At a court of this society held 26th June, 1651, it was enacted, that at the burial of a brother or sister, the arms of the society should not be impaled in the same escutcheon with their own; and that in future no arms should be impaled with those of the merchants on grave stones, but severally, on a penalty of 5l. payable by every executor of the deceased, who should be a brother or sisterIbid. The arms of this society correspond in the field with those of the merchant-adventurers of London, or Hamborough merchants, blazoned in Edmondson's Complete Body of Heraldry, vol. i. as follows: "Barry nebulee of six argent and azure a chief quarterly gules and or: on the first and fourth quarters a lion passant gardant of the fourth; on the second and third two roses gules barbed vert:" but seem to differ in the crest, sup∣porters and motto. The crest of this society is a Pegasus issuing out of a crown with ban∣ners displayed on each side—the supporters two Pegasi.—The Pegasi (both of the cst and supporters) are charged with two roses on each wing. I have met with two mottos: "God be my adventurer," on a stone over the door of Stote's-Hall, an old mansion-house near Jesmond: and another, "Deus sit noster amicus," on the front of the late school gallery in St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle. The subsequent is the inscription on their seal—"S. Societatis mere' vent' habitan' infra vill' Novi Castri super Tinam †".

March 17th, 1652, this society petitioned parliament against the act for the encouragement of navigation, and solicited the continuance of their ancient liberties in their trade to the Low Countries and other placesMerchants books..

Henry Warmouth, Esq son of William Warmouth above-men∣tioned, by his last will, dated April 8th, 1654, left 100l. to the com∣mon-council of Newcastle, to be disposed of at their discretion, to an∣cient decayed merchantsIbid..

A. D. 1654, contentions arose again between the merchants of Lon∣don and Newcastle concerning the imposition of 8l. mentioned above. Those of Newcastle petitioned the Lord Protector, who referred the matter to the committee for trade and navigation. Those of London answered, and were replied to by this fraternity: and on the 5th of February, 1656, the committee for trade determined the matter a second time in favour of those of Newcastle upon TyneIbid. A. D. 1655, by a bye law of this fraternity, it was enacted, that every apprentice convicted of fornication, should pay a fine of one hundred pounds sterling.—The order before stood at one hundred marks; but that sum probably having been found insufficient, it was now altered to as many pounds..

January 26th, 1656, an order was made by this society concerning the religion of their apprentices, the curious preamble whereof runs as follows: "Whereas in these late tymes, wherein iniquity abounds, wee find by wooful experience a great apostacy and falling off from the truth to popery, quakerisme and all manner of heresy and unheard-of blasphemy and profaneness."—It then proceeds to enact "that no popish recusant, quaker, or any who shall not attend duely on his maister at the publicke ordinances, or any who is base begotten, crook∣ed or lame, or any other way deformed," be taken apprentice on pain of being fined an hundred marksMerchants books..

Mr. William Carr, merchant-adventurer and mercer, by his last will, dated April 11th, 1660, bequeathed to this society the sum of
200l. to be lent to four brethren (50l. to each) for five years, with out interestMerchants books. By a by-law of this society, made A. D. 1658, it was ordered, that if any brother should refuse to carry the corpse of any brother or sister to church, he should be fined 3s. 4d. for every such offence..

A. D. 1663, the exports and imports of this society were "double dosins, single ditto or half cloths, kerseys, single bases, cottons, stockins, lead, flax, tow or snute, hemp, candleweeke, sail-twine, iron, bat∣tery, frying-pans, dripping-pans, and iron pots, aqua vitae and brandy wine, distilled waters, French and Rhenish wine, vinegar, honey, cloves, cinamon, nutmegs, mace, lofe sugar, madders, shewmakers thread, grain of all sorts, powder blue, Hollans of all sorts, blacke and brown thread, hops, butterIbid.."

An agreement was made October 27th, 1671, between the mer∣chant-adventurers of Newcastle and the brethren of the Trinity-House of that place, concerning the duty of primage to be paid by the former to the latter for goods imported within the port of Tyne. The im∣ports mentioned on this occasion are as follows: "Wainscotts, great balks, small and middle ditto, cappravens, boome-sparrs, single ditto, great and small masts and keel-oars, clapboards, spruce deals, ordinary ditto, swales, corn, ling, cod, pantiles, apples, onions, cabbages, Holland bricks, tow, drest flax, snuyt, drest hemp, candleweake, twine, hops, madder, battery, frying-pans, iron pots, linen cloth, bales of cloth, canvass, tarr, pipe staves, &c.Ibid."

Mr. Thomas Davison, merchant-adventurer and boothman, by his last will, dated November 25th, 1675, devised to this society certain lands in the Leazes near Newcastle upon Tyne, of the yearly value of ten pounds ten shillings for ever. Three pounds, part of the said annual rent, to be paid to three churches of that town, and the rest to be distributed, in the month of December every year, to the widows and children of poor merchantsIbid..

August 10th, 1681, this society, on consideration of an annual rent of thirteen pounds, secured to be paid to them for ever out of the chamber of Newcastle upon Tyne, at Michaelmas, sold ninety-four ridges of land in the Castle-Field, bequeathed to them as above, in 1675, by Mr. Thomas Davison, to the mayor and corporation of that townMerchants books. It appears also ibid. that, in the year 1688, during the tyrannical and arbitrary measures of government, that were pursued on the eve of the ever glorious revolution, the merchants of this society distinguished themselves by a peremptory refusal to comply with the illegal mandate of the then mayor and magistrates..

Mr. John Rumney, merchant-adventurer and boothman, by his last will, dated February 3d, 1694, gave to the fraternity of merchants of Newcastle, the sum of one hundred pounds, to be lent to a young brother for three years, without interestMerchants books..

Mr. Timothy Davison, merchant-adventurer and boothman, by his last will, dated February 7th, 1694, gave the sum of three hundred pounds to this society, on condition that two-thirds of the interest thereof should be paid to the poor brethren and widows of the com∣pany, in the month of December every year, and the remaining third part to the four churches of Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

On a motion made March 3d, 1697, in this society, that it would be convenient and honourable for them to meet in the exchange of Newcastle at some set hour of the day, they appointed between the hours of eleven and twelve in the forenoon for such meeting.—It was altered, in 1753, from twelve to oneIbid..

November 24th, 1697, there is an order of this society, forbidding the apprentices to go to dancing or fencing schools, to musick houses, lotteries, or play-houses —to keep horses—dogs for hunting, or fighting cocks, till they had served seven of their ten years.—They are to use no gold or silver trimming in their apparel or hats, nor to line any garment with any sort of silk—to wear no point lace, nor any embroi∣dery at all —no ruffles at their breasts, necks or sleeves, and, lastly, no long wigs, nor any short ones above the value of fifteen shillingsIbid..

Joseph Atkinson, Esq merchant-adventurer and boothman, by his last will, dated March 13th, 1712, bequeathed to this society the sum of one hundred pounds to be lent to a young trading brother for five years, without interestMerchants books..
The merchants of this society addressed King George I. December 15th, 1715, on the success of his arms against the rebels in Northum∣berlandIbid..

A. D. 1733, a letter occurs from this society to the members of parliament for Newcastle, complaining of the grievances of the excise laws, and requesting them in their parliamentary capacities to oppose every new species of exciseIbid..

March 2d, 1744, this fraternity addressed King George the Second against the pretender, and assured his Majesty of every assistance in their power against the common enemy, to the hazard of their lives and fortunes.—This was followed by a second, dated Sept. 11th, 1745, on the King's arrival from the continent, and on the success of his arms in America, with zealous professions of their allegiance to his crown, the kingdom being at that time actually invaded by a popish pretender. A third succeeded May 31st, 1746, on the most important victory at Culloden, where the army of the rebels was utterly defeatedIbid. December 21st, 1752, ibid. it was ordered that the apprentices of this soci∣ety should in future serve no more than seven years..

Thomas Davison, Esq of Ferry-Hill, in the county of Drham, by his declaration of trust, dated August 19th, 1755, acknowledged his having sunk five hundred pounds in the corporation of Newcastle, upon trust that they should pay the yearly interest at four per cent. of the said sum, whenever it should amount to fifty pounds, to a son of a merchant of this society, or to any young man, who by servitude shall have obtained his franchise thereof, to assist him in beginning business for himself—deputing first Sir Walter Blackett, Bart. Morton and Thomas Davison, Esqrs. to appoint such young merchants, and
after the death of each of these, the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle, for the time being, in common-council assembledFrom an original instrument remaining in the archives of this society..
September 1st, 1758, this society addressed King George the Se∣cond on the regaining of the important island of Cape BretonBooks of the society..

June 4th, 1760, it having appeared that the certain yearly revenue of this society had been found inadequate to defray the necessary ex∣penditures thereof, it was ordered, by a by-law of the fraternity, that an annual contribution of five shillings should be collected from each member in futureMerchants books..
November 4th, 1760, this society addressed King George the Third on his accession to the crown, and afterwards, October 6th, 1761, on his happy marriage with her present Majesty Queen CharlotteIbid..

July 27th, 1769, a bond of arbitration was signed by this fellow∣ship to the Trinity-House of Newcastle, "to the award and determi∣nation of Edward Collingwood, Esq of Chirton, recorder," by which, dated December 19th, 1769, it was determined that a duty of three halfpence per last, and no more, was due and payable by free merchants of Newcastle to the Trinity-House there for all corn im∣ported by this society from beyond the seasIbid.."

DIV2.HEAD: GOVERNORS OF THE MERCHANTS COMPANY IN NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.

LIST.HEAD: (From the Books of the Society and Grey's MS. Collections.)
LIST.ITEM: March 23d, 1480, Thomas Penreth occurs as clerk

DIV2.HEAD: SOCIETY OF HOSTMEN: INCLUDED IN NOTICES CONCERNING COAL AND THE COAL-TRADE.

Q.L: "— The grim ore
Here useless, like the miser's brighter hoard,
Is from its prison brought and sent abroad,
The frozen hours to cheer, to minister
To needful sustenance and polish'd arts—
Hence are the hungry fed, the naked cloth'd,
The wintry damps dispell'd, and social mirth
Exults and glows before the blazing hearth."
"As for the earth—under it is turned up as it were fire."

DIV2.P:
SOME writers derive the name of coal from an Hebrew word
"Cymreis gloyn est carbo, quod J. Davies derivat , pruna, carbo, atque adeo postremâ Hebraei vocabuli commode desumi possit, Al. col. chol."—Lye's Junii Ety∣mol. Anglican.
" as a noun, a live coal. Lev. xvi. 12.
