Is. xliv. 19. et al. freq. derivat. coal." —Parkhurst's Hebrew Lexicon. of similar sound and signification: we find other etymologists, on the contrary, desirous of deducing it from the Greek or Latin tongue"Alludit Gr. , niger. Vossius autem deflectit a Gr. , rens, callidus, splendidus. Mallem coal, a calendo, , deducere, hoc sine à dicto ."—Skinner in verbo..

To whichsoever of the ancient languages it owes its origin, we cannot but remark with how little variation it has run through the several dialects of the north
In the Anglo-Saxon col. In the Tentome kol, kohl. In the Dutch kole. In the Danish kul. See Manning's Saxon Dictionary, Skinner, &c.
Whitaker, in his History of Manchester, tells us, "that the Britons in general were acquainted with this fuel is evident from its appellation among us at present, which is not Saxon but British; and subsists among the Irish in their Ogual, and among the Cor∣nish in their Kolan, to this day."
"It is certain," says Pennant, in his Tour in Wales, quarto, p. 17, "that the Britons had a primitive name for this fossil, that of "glo."
In the Islandic kol is carbo.—See Hickes' Thesaurus.

The word coal, in its present import, has the three subsequent sig∣nificationsSee Johnson's Dictionary in verbo. For the two last senses of the word (the first is every where known), he gives us the authorities of Lord Verulam and Shakespear.: the common fuel of that denomination—the cinder of charred wood, or charcoal—and, metaphorically, any thing ignited or inflamed.

Among chemists, coal signifies any substance containing oil, which has been exposed to the fire in close vessels, so that all its volatile prin∣ciples are expelled, and that it can sustain a red heat without further decomposition. Coal in this sense is commonly solid black, very dry, and considerably hardSee Encyclopaedia Britannica, vol. iii. Edinburgh..

Of coalCoals are thus defined by Hill: "Solid, dry, opake, inflammable substances, found in large strata, splitting horizontally more easily than in any other direction: of a glossy hue, soft and friable, not fusible, but easily inflammable, and leaving a large residuum of ashes.", that black sulphureous inflammatory matter dug out of the earth, and at present the common fuel of most of Europe, as well as of other parts of the globe
There are several countries in Europe which possess considerable coal-mines, as France, Liege, Germany and Sweden. Also on the other side of the Atlantic ocean, there has been coal discovered and wrought: in Newfoundland, Cape Breton, Canada, and some of the New England provinces: but in all these countries the coal is of a quality much inferior to the British.—Encyclopaedia Britan. Edinb. vol. iii. in verbo "Coalery."
China abounds with coal.—See the Missionary's Letters, vol. i. p. 22.—Also Purchas' Pilgrims, vol. iii. p. 88.
According to Munster, coal is found in Tartary.—See Martin Schoock's Treatise on Turves, in Latin. Groningae, 1658, 12mo. p. 223, &c.
Coal is known to be in the island of Madagascar.—See Anderson's Dictionary of Com∣merce, vol. i. p. 227., considered as a genus, there are vari∣ous species: the chief of which, according to Dr. Black, are common coal, fat, or blacksmith's coal, and the Kilkenny coal
"Common coal," says he, "burns with a bright hot flame.
Parrot, or kennel coal is distinguished by producing a more copious bright flame than common coal. It is distinguished too by having a much closer texture, admitting a polish, and is often turned into toy.
Common coal has a much looser texture, and is divided into masses by numerous cracks and flaws, so that it generally breaks into masses of cubical figures.
Blacksmith's coal gives out less flame, but undergoes a sort of fusion, and unites into masses, forming a cinder, which is afterwards capable of producing a violent heat. It is valued because it is perfectly free of sulphur.
Kilkenny coal burns like charcoal, with a bright transparent blue flame, like that of spirit of wine, and without any appearance of smoke, leaving only a very small quantity of ashes. There is however a volatile vapour, probably fixed air, which rises from it, and gives a disagreeable smell in the house where it is used. There are many strata of it in the west of Scotland. These several varieties, when examined by analysis in close ves∣sels, shew themselves as much distinguished in this way, as by their manner of burning and appearance."—Dr. Black's Lectures—a MS. copy communicated by one of his pupils, Mr. Anderson of Newcastle upon Tyne, surgeon..

Coal, of whatever kind, according to the hypothesis of the above-mentioned ingenious professor of chemistry, and many other respect∣able writers and philosophers, as well of our own as of foreign na∣tions, is of vegetable
"There are many extraneous substances," says he, "and marks in the coal itself, which incline us to think it is of a vegetable origin. There are manifest traces of wood converted into a sort of charcoal: I have not many specimens of these extraneous sub∣stances, but this structure like charcoal is sufficiently common. 'Tis also very common in all the different kinds of coal to meet with a substance which is composed of small fibres, and separable from each other like the softer kinds of charcoal." In proof of this hypo∣thesis he adds farther, "In different parts of the world we find very large quantities of trees, forming beds with other strata over them, crushed together, but not united and blended so much as beds of coal, so that the branches, &c. of the trees may be discover∣ed: of these some are found near Exeter in Devonshire (Bovey coal) in large masses, re∣sembling wood in structureSir Joseph Banks, Bart. president of the Royal Society, so eminent for his knowledge in natural his∣tory, favoured me with the inspection of a large specimen of fossil, found in Iceland, in strata, of consider∣able thickness, and at great depths, which seems to exhibit a substantial proof that coal originally was wood. He has preserved several trunks of it, each of which is flattened, possibly by the weight of super-incumbent strata, so that, instead of being cylindrical, as the body or root of a tree naturally is, it is that. Some of them are more and some less woody. One is a fan plank of wood. A the wood ones are the atest curiosities, they are sent in preference. The specimen I examined appears to have been the root of a small tree, with the bark still adhering and remaining on the greatest part of it in the lower part, however, the transformation has proceeded farther than at the top, so that it is while the top is actual wood., which prove inflammable, and give a strong bituminous smell, insupportable to the inhabitants, and are on that account only used in burning lime∣stone, &c. There are beds of this kind also in some parts of Germany, as we are informed in the Berlin Transactions.—The strata of coal are always found mixed with other strata, which are recent, or produced as it were by accident: they are always mixed with strata of free-stone; the constitution of which free-stone, with many phenomena relating to it, on examination, leave no room to doubt its being composed of beds of sand, fastened to∣gether in some particular manner, and which have been washed by the sea: often too it is marked by worms and other marine animals: coal, therefore, as being found intermixed with strata of this kind quite recent, may on this account be supposed to be a substance generated in the same manner, or that it is composed of matter, which, having been bu∣ried by a length of time, had been crushed into a solid form."—Black's Lectures MS. ut supra.
Dr. Moyse, in his lectures which I attended at Newcastle upon Tyne a few years ago, supposed coal to have been originally wood of the fir or pine sort, as it produce tar as those trees do. He shewed that the branches of trees, or their resemblances, were some∣times found in it: as were also reeds, the hollow part of which was full of clay—that split, as it were, in some directions, it shews its woody texture; and, lastly, that the wood part remains still at the top of the strata.
I have a specimen of coal in my possession, which very much illustrates this hypothesis: it was given to me by William Cramlington, Esq a coal owner at Newcastle upon Tyne.
Mr. Jasper Harrison, attorney at law, informed me that a piece of coal, half fir wood and half coal, was found several years ago, as one of the workmen informed him, in a pit on Lanchester Common, in the county of Durham. origin: all the strata of which are either great
collections of trees
"Some go so far as to advance, that, by distilling coal, the same products are had as from the true resin of trees: this induced the learned translator of Henckel to regard this fossil as a dissolution of a ligneous matter, which contains, beside a very great quan∣tity of earth, a fat matter of the nature of vegetable oils, or resinous bodies."—See Mo∣rnd's "Memoires sur le Charbon de Terre," translated in the Universal Magazine, 1769.
This writer observes also, "that besides the impressions of plants, that often occur in the roof of coal mines, we likewise meet with frequently in their vicinity, or in the pits made for working them, large portions of wood and even entire trees.
"Near Luxemburg, at a short distance from the coal mines, are found considerable quan∣tities of petrified wood. The Abbot de Sauvages makes mention, in the Memoirs of the French Academy for 1743, of some fragments of stony wood, strongly incrusted up in the bark, with one or two inches of coal, in which this petrifaction was performed. It is very common to find, lying over coal mines, wood which is not entirely dissolved; but according as it is buried to a greater depth, it is more sensibly altered.
"At Brull, near Cologn and Bonn, M. de Bury, a famous collier of Liege, by diging into a vlley, found a sort of earth coal, which was nothing else but wood, that had been covered by a mountain of earth. There are several mines wherein none can mistake the trunks and branches of trees, and other remains of wood; heaps of fossil wood are met with at a great depth, disposed by benches, and separated from one another by beds of earth, and all of them affording good reason to suspect a passing of the ligneous nature, or a true transmutation of wood into coal. At the bottom of that chain of mountains that runs from Lyons to Strasburgh, on the high road between these two cities, M. Fontaine, of the Academy of Sciences, discovered one of those subterraneous forests, and took with him to Paris several of the pieces, collected at hazard, which Mr. Macquer and the au∣thor of this treatise, Mr. Morand, were commissioned to examine. They found there∣in two substances different from each other; the first was real wood, which had been preserved in the earth in its natural state, some parts of a brownish colour, others entirely black: the second underwent no alteration in the assemblage of the fibres that compose the ligneous body, in the knots they produce, in their weight and in their colour. The bark that had been consumed with rottenness was replaced by a sandy matter that adhered strongly to the wood. These pieces, whose ligneous body was entire, burnt well and were converted by fire into a good and real vegetable coal.
"In several samples portions were found, whose ligneous fibres were interrupted in their continuity, and reduced into a coaly matter, which crumbled by the pressure of the fingers, and blacked them as charcoal of the willow tree.
"There was another piece which might be called very curious by reason of the changes it underwent. The ligneous fibres were therein very perceptible as to their disposition, but the whole of them had contracted a complete mineralization. All the extremities of the fibres were black, and retained the lustre of finely-polished jet: and the whole piece was heavy, as pieces of petrified wood are known to be. The second substance was purely earthy. In several parts of Germany mines of fossil wood have been discovered, known by the name of Holtz-kohlen. These coals are of different kind, and as much distinguished by their colour as their properties. Some authors think that those heaps of fossil wood may lead to the finding of real coal, and that, if the wood-coal be not such, it is because it does not lie deep enough in the earth, for the woods being resolved to the necessary degree, that constitutes the stone coal: but this pretension does not seem to have any good grounds, if it be considered that good and true coal is often met with at a very little depth in the earth, and sometimes pretty near the surface. It seems more natural to seek the cause that has hindered this coal of fossil wood from becoming true coal, in the different earthy, saline, or bituminous substances wherein it is found. Their nature perhaps is not fit for operating this mineralization, or even an impediment to it." Ibid. compacted together, or large forests
Whitehurst, in his Inquity into the original State and Formation of the Earth, 4io. London, 1778, Appendix, p. 169, tells us, "all the strata, meumbent on coal, whether argillaceous stone, or clay, contain figured stones representing a great variety of vegeta∣bles, or the impressions of them; as reeds of various kinds, striated and joined at different distances, the euphorbia of the East-Indies, the American ferns, corn, grass, and many other species of the vegetable kingdom. They are inclosed in the solid substance of the stone, &c.
"These vegetable forms, and the strata containing them, are the certain indication of coal, not only in Derbyshire, but in every part of the kingdom which I have visited; and I am informed that the same phenomenon holds equally true in every other part of the world yet explored. Sir Ashton Lever's incomparable Museum of natural curiosities contains the most perfect specimens, and the greatest variety of fossil vegetables, if I may be al∣lowed to call them so, I ever saw.
"Now since it appears that all strata accompanying coal universally abound with vege∣table forms, it seems to indicate that all coals were originally derived from the vegetables thus enveloped in the stone or clay."
"On coal, let it be observed, that from its always presenting itself in beds of stone, or clay, impressed with vegetable forms, and having been met with in various stages of its transmutation, from the vegetable substance to that of perfect coal, it has with reason been concluded to derive its origin from remains of vegetables."—Eternity of the World, by G. H. Toulmin, M. D. London, 1785, 8vo. p. 30.
"In some districts at a considerable depth below the surface of the earth, large quan∣tities of trees are met with, lying as close to each other as they do in a wood, the trunks, branches, and leaves in perfect preservation."—Ibid. p. 36.
"In stone too of a totally different nature from marble or limestone, vegetable impres∣sions, and the remains of land animals, are every where obvious; and what is equally singular, coal never occurs but in the beds of matter, that are thus impressed with such land ani∣mals and vegetables."—Ibid. p. 30.
"February 13th, 1787, the workmen digging in the free-stone quarry on the sea side, upon the Musselburgh road, came upon a pine tree completely petrified in the heart of the rock. The impression of the branches, leaves, and pine cones are beautifully indented in the rock."—Public Advertiser, February 17th, 1787.
The following query was sent by Sir John Clerk, from Edinburgh, December 8th, 1739, to Roger Gale, Esq "If you think the strata of coal were as ancient as the world, or if the strata of soft earth, by length of time, imbibed a sulphureous, bituminous, com∣bustible quality?
The subsequent answer was dated from Scruton, February, 26th, 1740:
"As the strata of coal lie generally bedded between two other strata of stone, and rise and dip in parallel lines with them, they seem to me coaeval to the toxture of our globe, and to have undergone the same concussions that it has suffered; it being hard to con∣ceive how soft earth, included between two such solid bodies should imbibe a sulphureous and bituminous matter from or through them: there is indeed such a sulphureous matter found in coal-pits, but to me it appears much more reasonable to think it was shut up at the same time with other substances that enter into the composition of coal."—MS. com∣municated by George Allan, Esq F. A. S. of Darlington, in the county of Durham.
Thoresby, in his Ducatus Leodensis, p. 470, asserts, "that coal is nothing but bitumen hardened, and concocted under ground."—Fossil-coal by distillation yields phlegm or water, a very acid liquor, a thin oil like naphtha—a thicker oil like petroleum, which falls to the bottom of the former, and which rises with a violent fire—an acid concrete salt—an uninflammable earth remains in the retort.—These constituent parts are very similar to those of amber, and other bitumens."—Encyclopaedia ut supra—in verbo Lithanthrax., thrown
down by decay of time, and afterwards buried by some of the more violent changes to which the globe is liable, or other inflammable sub∣stances,
charred perhaps by the subterraneous fires, and incorporated with sulphur and bitumen.

We find express mention of coals, used as a fuel by artificers about two thousand years ago, in the writings of Theophrastus, the scholar of Aristotle, who, in his book on stones, gives the subsequent very par∣ticular description of them: "Those fossile substances, that are called coals, and are broken for use, are earthy; they kindle, however, and burn like wood coals. These are found in Liguria, where there is also amber, and in Elis, in the way to Olympias over the mountains: they are used by the smiths
See Hill's Theophrastus on Stones:—p. 62, there is the following curious note:
"The substance here described, whatever mistakes there may have been among authors since about it, appears to me to be evidently no other than the common pit-coal; and I have made it appear as clearly so in the translation, only by having properly rendered the word , the carelessly misunderstanding of which word alone, has been the occasion of all the erroneous guesses about the substance here described. The authors of these seem all to have understood the word , as signifying fossile, or pit-coal; and there∣fore, as the author compares the burning of this substance to that, they were necessitated to think of some other substance that he might here mean, as it was impossible he should intend to compare a thing to itself. Wormius on this foundation imagined that he meant the cannel coal. Quod Galenus vocat ampeletidem, &c. Theophrastus vocat carbones, quod eorum colorem habeat et vices gerat. Thus is Theophrastus, according to custom, accused of saying things he never meant; because the people who quote him have not been at the pains to understand him: is evidently, they kindle and burn like wood-coals, or, as we call it, charcoal; for that is the genuine and determinate sense of the word in Greek, and carbo in Latin; as is evident from the other works of this author, Pliny, and all the other old naturalists. Even the more correct of the moderns, when they would express what we call pit-coal, the sub∣stance here described by the author, never use the words or carbo alone, but always carbo fossilis, and . See Woodward, Charlton, Merret, &c. The similar use of this bitumen got it the name of coal, but always with an addition that distinguished it from what was more commonly and properly so called, that expressed its not being of vegetable, but fossile origin."
See Schoockii de Turffis, p. 228, 229. Groningae, 1658, 12mo.."

Though some writersCampbell's Political Survey—Arnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 82. have not scrupled to affirm that coal was unknown to the ancient Britons, yet othersWhitaker, in his History of Manchester, is of opinion that the primaeval Britons used coal. He argues first from the probability of their discovering it: "Our currents," says he, "frequently bring down fragments of coal from the mountains, the extremities rising into day-light, and being washed away by the rains and rivulets,—the Britons would soon mark the shining stones in the channels, and by the aid of accident, or the force of reflection, find out the utility of them. But we can advance still nearer a certainty: several pieces of coal were discovered a few years ago in the sand under the Roman way to Ribchester, &c."—"That the Britons," he proceeds, "were acquainted with this fuel, is evident from its appellation amongst us at present, which is not Saxon, but British, and subsists among the Irish in their Guel, and among the Cornish in their Kolan to this day." have adduced proofs to the contrary, which seem to carry along with them little less than con∣viction.

The Britons, as shewn before, had a primitive name for this fossil;See before. but farther, a flint ax, the instrument, says PennantSee Pennant's Tour in Wales, p. 17., of the aborigines of our island, was discovered stuck in certain veins of coal, exposed to day in Craig y Parc in Monmouthshire, and in such a situation as to render it very accessible to the unexperienced natives, who in early times were incapable of pursuing the veins to any great depthsPhilosophical Transactions, No. 335, p. 500..

There are no beds of coal in the compass of Italy; yet the strongest argument in favour of their opinion,
Arnt's History of Edinburgh, p. 82. Campbell's Political Survey. The latter tells us, "It is certain that coals are not, as some have imagined, the lapis obsidianus of Pliny." Lib. xxxvi. cap. 26. (Zenocrates writes, says Pliny, that this obsidian stone is found naturally growing among the Indians; within Samnium, also in Italy, and in Spain along the coast of the ocean.)
"Great disputes," continues Campbell, "have been about this substance, of which Augustus placed the statues of four elephants in the Temple of Concord." who think that the Romans,
while they were here, were ignorant of it, is, that there is no name for it in their language, the genuine and determinate sense of carbo being charcoal. Caesar is silent concerning it in his description of our island
Martin Schoock, in his Treatise on Turves, p. 229, speaking of the silence of an∣cient writers on stones, on this subject, tells us that some have confounded coal with am∣pelites, but erroneously, according to Libavius. They come nearer, he adds, to the Thracian stone, with which Agricola does not hesitate to confound them, an opinion ap∣proved by the very learned Cambden, and not much dissented from by the very accurate Labavius.
"Calx aqua accenditur ut Thracius lapis, idemque oleo restinguitur." Pliny, Nat. Hist. book 33, chap. 5.
Thus translated by Holland: "Quicklime will catch an heat and burn, if water be cast upon it, and so doth the Thracian stone; but oil doth quench the same."
Dr. Plott, in his Natural History of Staffordshire, when speaking of the damps in coal-mines, cites this, and tells us, that "the Thracian stone" is by some translated pit-coal.
Dr. Philemon Holland, whose translation of Pliny was printed in 1635, has the fol∣lowing note in the margin: "Which (i. e. Thraian stone) some take for pit-cole, or sea-cole rather, such as cometh from Newcastle by sea; or rather a kind of jeat."
Dr. Jorden (of Mineral Waters, chap. 14, in fin) tells us, that whole heaps of coals, mixed with a sort of pyrites (called metal-coals), by having water accidentally put upon them, have taken fire, and burnt before their time:—he assures us, that this actually hap∣pened at Puddle-wharf in London, and at Newcastle..

It seems, however, to have been proved beyond all doubt, that, al∣though it escaped the notice of that great people at first, it was after∣wards in actual use amongst themWallis, in his History of Northumberland, p. 117, tells us, "Caesar has recorded, that there were metals in the maritime parts of the island, but, he adds, not plentifully. He was too great a stranger to it to be acquainted with all its productions, he but just shwed it to the Romans.".

"The Romans," says the learned Whitaker
"History of Manchester.
Dr. Richardson's Letter. Leland's Itinerary, vol. i. ad finem.
"That coals were known by the Romans here appears farther, by quantities of this fossil having been found under certain barrows, appointed as it should seem for ancient land-marks. Cambden, speaking of a place in Northamptonshire, where there was anciently a Roman station, tells us, that there was a little piked hill cast up, "which some dig of late days (this was written about 1607), in hopes of finding old hidden treasures; but instead of gold, they met with coals."—"From the digging up of the coals," continues he, "what if I should guess that this hill was thrown up for a mark, or boundary? Since Siculus Flaccus tells us, that either ashes, coals, potsherds, broken glasses, bones half burnt, lime or plaister, were wont to be put under such bounds or limits: and St. Augustine writes thus of coals: Is it not a wonderful thing, that though coals are so brittle, that with the least blow they break, with the least pressure they are crushed in pieces, yet no time can destroy them; insomuch that they who pitch land-marks are wont to throw them un∣derneath, to convince any litigious person, who shall affirm, though ever so long after, that no land-mark was there."—Lib. de Civitate Dei, 21. c. 4.
"And so much the rather I am inclined to this opinion, because they who have written of limits or bounds, inform us, that certain hillocks, which they termed botontines (whence, says he, perhaps, come our buttings), were placed in limits; so that I suppose that most of these mounts, and round hillocks, which are so commonly seen, were raised for this purpose; and that ashes, coals, potsherds, &c. might be found under them by digging deep into the ground."
Mr. Strutt, in his 1st vol. of Manners, &c. p. 60, tells us, that, in the year 1773, he saw one of these opened near Maldon, in Essex, wherein he found potsherds, cinders and char∣coal very perfect, together with bits of bones (not human) so very rotten, as to be crushed to pieces with the least pressure., "appear actually
using coal in Britain. In the west riding of Yorkshire, and neighbour∣hood of North Brierly are many beds of cinders, heaped up in the fields, in one of which a number of Roman coins was found some years ago."

Horseley, the learned and modest author of the Britannia Romana,Britannia Romana, p. 209.—See also Wallis's History of Northumberland, who tells us, vol. i. p. 119, that "The Romans were as well acquainted with our pit-coal, as with our ores and metals: in digging up some of the foundations of their walled city Magna or Caervorran, 1762, coal cinders, some very large, were turned up, glowed in the fire like other cinders, and not to be known from them when taken out." speaking in that work of the inscriptions found at Benwell, a village near Newcastle upon Tyne, and the Condercum of that people, re∣marks, "that there was a colliery not far from that place, which is judged by those who are best skilled in such affairs, to have been wrought by the Romans."

Whitaker, in his History of Manchester, mentions a grant of some
lands made by the abbey of Peterborough, dated A. D. 852, which proves, as it should seem, that this fuel was known, and in use amongst us, while the Saxons were masters of Britain. By this grant, certain boons and payments in kind were reserved to the monastery, as one night's entertainment. Ten vessels of Welch, and two of common ale; sixty cartloads of wood, and twelve of fossil, or pit coal
See Saxon Chronicle, edited by Gibson, Oxon. 1692, p. 75. The words in the original are tƿaelf foður graefan, and which the Bishop has translated "duodecim plaustra carbonum fossilium."
Morton, in his Natural History of Northamptonshire, p. 544, speaking of the ruins of a castle at Castle-dikes, a high entrenched hill, within the liberties of Farthingstone, in that county, says that, at the bottom of an adjoining trench, he "saw some huge lumps of cinder, of the midland," he thought "not of the Newcastle coal; the former usually burning to a lighter and more spungy cinder: one of these lumps seemed at least half an hundred weight, and had pebbles and earth adhering to and incorporated in it." He sup∣poses this castle was built about A. D. 913, by the renowned Ethelfleda, relict and successor of Aethelred, viceroy of Mercia, and that A. D. 1013 it was set on fire, and de∣molished by the Danes, under Suane, at which time he conjectures this castle had stores of coal in it, "which were reduced into huge masses of cinder, by the intenseness of so great a fire."
He adds, "By their being in such large masses, one would imagine they were the cin∣ders of an iron work; but who would be at the trouble of fetching ore so far as from the iron mines in Staffordshire (I mention these as being the nearest), to be wrought with coal in the upper part of Northamptonshire? for they must have fetched their coals al∣most as far.".

No mention of this fossil occurs under the Danish usurpation; that people, indeed, were too much perplexed, during their stay in this country, by civil commotions, to have leisure to attend to any thing but what was obvious, and to be purchased with little trouble. So that wood would naturally be the chief article of fuel, while immense forests and thickets presented themselves to yield a ready supply.

For a few reigns after the Norman conquest,
In the Leges Burgorum of Scotland, which were enacted about the year 1140, a particular privilege is granted to those who bring fuel into boroughs; wood, turf, and peat, are expressedly mentioned, but there is no account of coal. These laws were made at Newcastle upon Tyne.—Leg. Burg. c. 38. Arnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 82, et seq.
About the middle of the thirteenth century, a noble Venetian, in his description of China, observes, "that, throughout the whole province of Cathay, certain black stones are dug out of the mountains, which being put in the fire, burn like wood, and when kindled, they continue burning a long time; insomuch that, if they are lighted in the evening, the fire will keep alive during the whole night. Many use these stones, although they have plenty of wood, the consumption of fuel in stoves being very great."—Marcus Paulus Venetus. Purchas's Pilgrims, vol. iii. p. 88. Arnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 82, et seq. during all which time our unhappy country was perpetually as it were under fire and
sword, the same silence, which must be attributed to the same causes, prevailed concerning fossil coal
Writers have called in fable also to the discovery of this very useful kind of fuel. "This kind of coaly stone, says Schoock, after Guicciardin, was discovered in the district of Liege, A. D. 1189, by a certain pilgrim, who, when he had pointed them out by a di∣vining rod to a smith, suddenly disappeared; afterwards they began to be dug in great abundance."—See Schoock on Turves, p. 223.
Morand tells us, that the person who in the country of Liege first discovered them, is called "Prudhomme le Houilloux," or "le Veillard Charbonnier," "Hullosus Pleneval∣lium," that is literally, "The collier or blacksmith of Plenevaux," a village within two leagues and a half of Liege, above the Serein.—See his "Memoires sur le Charbon de Terre.".

December 1st, 1239, King Henry the Third is said to have granted a charter to the townsmen of Newcastle upon Tyne, for liberty to dig coals in the vicinity of that place
Gardiner's England's Grievance, &c. quoted by Bourne. "In the reign of King Henry the Third, a licence was granted to the townsmen of Newcastle, bearing date December, the 23d of his reign, to dig coals and stones, &c. in the place called the Forth; and here it was, some think, or rather, as others, in the Castle-Leazes, that the first Newcastle coals were wrought.
"The King, by his letters patent, under the great seal of England, dated at West∣minster, December 1st, upon the good men of the town of Newcastle's supplication, gave them licence to dig coals and stones in the common soil of that town in the place called Castle-Field, and the Frith.
"This King was petitioned again by the burgesses of this place, to grant them all the stones and coals belonging to the Frith, which was granted them."
Anderson, in his Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 111, tells us, very erroneously, that King Henry III. A. D. 1234, confirmed a charter of his father, King John, to Newcastle, wherein coal is first mentioned. There is certainly no mention of coal in that King's char∣ter, which is dated at Westminster the 2d of July, in the 18th year of his reign.—See under "History of Newcastle as a corporate town." Gardiner's book has evidently misled him; and yet Gardiner is not in this place fairly quoted; for he tells us, that that grant, which, however, on a search in the Tower of London, I could not find, was dated as aforesaid, on the 1st of December, in the 23d year of his reign..

The strongest and most unequivocal proof that this species of fuel was in use amongst us during the reign of King Henry the Third, is to be found in an inquisition preserved among the additions to Mat∣thew Paris' History, of the date of 1245.

Here we find it called sea-coalLeland, in his Itinerary, vol. viii. p. 19, has the following passage: "The vaynes of the se-coles ly sometyme upon clives of the se, as round about Coket Island, and other shores; and they, as some will, be properly called se coals; but they be not so good as the coles that are digged in the inner part of the lande."; with express mention of making pits to win it, and of the wages of the colliers that wrought in them
In the Capitula Forisfactorum, seu Inquisitiones de Forisfacturis diversis super Foresta Domini Regis, scil. Hen. III. A. D. 1245.
"Inquiratur etiam de carbone maris invento infra forestam et qui mercedem cepe∣rint pro fossatis faciendis de carbone illo et pro cheminagio."—"Inquiratur etiam de marleriis, mineriis, turbariis, fabricis et carbonariis factis et levatis infra predictum tempus, ad nocumentum forestae, sine warranto Domini Regis et qui commodum inde receperint et quantum valent per annum secundum communem estimationem."
He speaks afterwards of carbo de foresta, which is ranked with busca and maeremium, brushwood and timber, and must, undoubtedly, signify charcoal: the manner of making of it, as described by Pliny, continues nearly the same at this day.
Ducange, citing the very passage under consideration, supposes carbo matis to mean fossil-coal: his words are, "Carbones maris lapides combustibiles quibus fabri ferrarri utuntur, Anglis sea-coales. He renders the word "carbonaria" in the second clause by "Fornax in foresta ad conficiendum carbonem," and defines the carbones de foresla to be charcoal in the subsequent words: "Ex ligno foreste combusto in fornace confecti.".

In the year 1281 there had been so rapid an increase of the coal trade at Newcastle, that, had not that town been granted before by King John at a fee-farm of an hundred pounds per annum, payable to the crown, that sum would probably have at least been doubled to the then burgesses
"In the ninth of Edward I. there was an inquiry upon divers trespasses, and other articles concerning the state of the said town, i. e. Newcastle upon Tyne.
"They found the town was worth 200l. per annum, if it were in the King's hands, but that King John had granted it for 100l. in fee-farm, when it was not worth so much, but that it was than so increased by coals, that it was sometimes worth 200l. per annum, and sometimes less."—Aubone MS..

The first mention of coal that occurs in any charter in Scotland, is found in a grant, executed in the year 1291, in favour of the abbot and convent of Dumfermline, and the privilege of digging coal in the lands of Pittencrieff, in the county of FifeCartulary of Dumfermline, p. 80. Advocates Library, Edinburgh.—Vide Arnot's History of Edinburgh..

The use of sea-coal was prohibited at London, in the year 1306, by proclamation. Brewers, dyers, and other artificers, who had oc∣casion for great fires, had found their account in substituting our fossil for dry wood and charcoal; but so general was the prejudice against it at that time, that the nobles and commons assembled in parliament complained against the use thereof as a public nuisance, which was thought to corrupt the air with its stink and smoke.

A regard to private interest caused the first royal proclamation con∣cerning it to be little noticed; on a second complaint, the King issued a commission of Oyer and Terminer, with strict orders to punish the delinquents by fines, and the demolition of their furnaces and kilns
See Prynne on Coke's Fourth Institute, p. 182. Anderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 148.
Prynne gives at full length, "Pat. 35 Ed. I. m. 4. Dorso, De rogis in civitate London supervidendis." Teste Rege apud Calde Cotes 28 die Junii.. It were superfluous to observe here how very differently succeeding parliaments have thought on this subject.

A few years afterwards sea-coals appear to have been used in the royal palace at London
Petitiones in parliamento A. D. 1321, et 1322. Ten shillings worth of that fuel used at the King's coronation, which had been ordered of Richard del Hurst by the clerk of the palace, had been neglected to be paid for.
"A notre Seigneur le Roi et a son counseil prie Richard del Hurst de Loundres q'il luy voille comandez de payer Xs. pur carboun de meer q' Johan de Norton nazguers clerk du palleis, prist de li a Loundres al coronnement notre Seigneur le Roi: dont il ad bille del dit Johan & unke ne fut paye, E ceo fut pur carboun pris al paleys al dit coro∣nement.
Mandet' thes' et baron' de sccio quod vocato coram eis predicto Johanne si invene∣rint quod allocatio eidem Johanni inde fiat, tunc fiat prefato Ricardo justicia.".

A. D. 1325, a vessel, the property of one Thomas Rente, of Pon∣toise, a town in the ancient dominions of the kings of England in France, is mentioned as trading to Newcastle upon Tyne with corn, and returning withRotuli Parliament. vol. i. p. 433. Petitiones in Parliamento, A. D. 1325, 19 Ed. II. No. 9. A notre Seigneur le Roi et son counseil supplie Thomas Rente le soen homme lige de Pontise qe come il mena sa neef charge de blee a Novel Chastel fur Tyne et carca arere sa dite neef de charboun de meer en son revener &c." a freight of sea-coals.

In the year 1327 the measure of sea-coals having become an object of consideration, we may infer that this fuel had become an im∣portant article in the commerce of that timeBourne's History of Newcastle, p. 158..

The prior and convent of Tinmouth demised to Ada de Colewell, at the yearly rent of five pounds, a colliery at Elswick, a village in the vicinity of Newcastle
"Memorandum de carbonar' de Elstewyk que vocatur le Heygrove dimissa Ade de Colewell a festo Sancti Martini anno Domini 1330 usque ad idem festum anno revoluto pro 100s. ad festum Pentecost' et Sancti Martini, incipiente prima solutione ad festum Pent' proxime' sequent'.
"Mem' de alia carbonar' nova quam Hugo de Hecham quondam tenuit in campo occident' de Elstewyke dimissa eidem Ade de Colewell pro 6 marcis solvend' anno inci∣pien' cum ipsam effoderit.
"Item memorand' de carbonar' del Westfeld juxta viam dimissa Radulpho Bullock a festo Annunciationis beate Marie anno Domini 1331 incipien' usque ad festum ad vincula Sancti Petri proxime sequens reddend' inde pro qualibet septiman' 2 fol.
"Mem' quod Johannes le Carter, Ricardus de Colewell et Galfridus Lene de Elstewyk, ceperunt unam carbonariam de novo effodiend' super moram de Elstewyk juxta le Ga∣lowflat, habend' a festo Omnium Sanctorum anno Domini 1334 usque ad idem festum anno revoluto pro 40s. solvend' ad festa Pur' beate Marie & Sancti Petri ad vincula per equales porciones."—Original Chartulary of Tinmouth monastery, fol. 165.
A. D. 1338, mention occurs ibid. fol. 172, of Staiths.—"Hec indentura testatur quod Ricardus prior de Tynemuth dimisit ad firmam Ade de Bolton, burgense, ville Novi Castri super Tynam quandam placeam terre in villa predicta super quam carbones marini reponi consueverunt et que est ad australe caput domus quam predictus prior et suus conventus de Tynemuth habent in predicta villa Novi Castri super le Stathes a festo Pent' anno regni Regis E. tertii post conquest' undecimo usque ad finem duorum annorum proxime sequen' plenarie completor' pro 40s. per annum custodi capelle Sancte Marie de Tynemuth qui pro tempore fuerit ad festa Sancti Martini in hieme & Pent' per porciones equales proinde solvend."
The worth staith is plainly derived from the Anglo-Saxon staƿe, ripa, littus, statio navium. At Hithe in Kent, the landing place is called to this day The Stade.—"Where the pits," says the Encyclopaedia Edinburg. voce Coaleries, "are situated at some con∣siderable distance from the harbour, it becomes necessary to have a store-house near the shipping place, where the coals may be lodged until the lighters or ships are ready to take them in. The waggon-way should be made into the store-house, at such a height from the ground, as to permit the coals to run from the waggons down a spout into the vessels; or else to fall down into the store-house, as occasion may require. This kind of store-house is well adapted to dispatch, and saving expence; for a waggon-load of coals may be delivered either into the store-house or vessels instantly, with very little trouble; and if the coals were exposed to the effects of the sun and rain, they would be greatly injured in their quality, but being lodged under cover of the store-house, they are preserved."
When the waggons are emptied into a keel or vessel by a spout, it is called a trunk staith.—At Whitehaven, they are called steers. When a waggon lets fall its contents down one of these spouts, the noise at a distance very much resembles a clap of thunder. These waggons, after being emptied, are brought round into the road or waggon-way by a turn-frame, and each is drawn back by a single horse. upon Tyne, from Martinmas, 1330, to the same term in the year following.

A. D. 1351, King Edward III. granted a licence to the burgesses of Newcastle, to dig coals and stones in a place called the Castle-Field, without the walls of that townMurray MS.—"Novum Castrum super Tynam. Licen' fodiendi carbon' et petr' extra muros civit' in loc' vocat' le Castel-feld."—Pat 24 Ed. III. p. ... m. 6, in the Tower..

May 10th, 1358, King Edward III. confirmed to the burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, the possession of the Castle-Moor and Castle-Field, with liberty to dig coals, &c. in the same; it having appeared that these places had from time immemorial belonged to that town
See Bourne's History of Newcastle.
Wallis, in his History of Northumberland, tells us, that Edward III. confirmed the fran∣chises of Newcastle, and granted it the perpetuity of the moor and lands, called Castle-Moor and Castle-Fields, to hold of him and his heirs, by the payment of forty shillings annually into the Exchequer.
"Nov' Castr' super Tynam. Licentia sodiendi carbones et petras extra muros civitatis in loco vocato le Castle-feld. Pat. 24. R. Ed. III. p. 3, m. 6, et anno 31, p. 1, m. 5, do. so. Et commiss' tangen' candem mater' m. 25, tom. iv. Rot. Turr. Lond'.".

A. D. 1365, the King issued an order concerning the measure to be used by the venders of coalsIbid. "Nov' Castr' super Tynam de carbonibus maritimis mensurandis. Pat. 38 Ed. III. p. 2, m. 34, Rot. Tur. Lond..

May 25th, 1368, the King granted a licence to Roger de Fulthorp, John Plomer, John de Britley, and Walter de Hesildon, to bring their coals, dug out of their mines in Gateshead fields, across the river Tyne in boats to Newcastle, on paying the King's usual customs in that port
Murray MS. p. 204. "Ex rotulo patentium de anno regni Regis Edwardi tertii quadragesimo primo, m. 19.
"Edwardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie et Dominus Hibernie majori et ballivis ville Novi Castri super Tynam salutem. Supplicarunt nobis Rogerus de Fulthorp, Johannes Plomer, Johannes de Britley & Walterus de Hesildon ut eis licentiam con∣cedere velimus quod ipsi carbones maritimos quos ipsi in campis ville de Gateshead in episcopatu Dunelmen' prope aquam de Tyne in mineris ibidem soderint et exnunc fodient, ad dictam villam Novi Castri ultra aquam illam ducere possint ad commodum fuum inde ibidem faciend' Nos eorum supplicationi in hac parte annuentes licentiam hujusmodi eisdem Rogero Johanni Johanni et Waltero duximus concedend' et ideo vobis mandamus quod predictos R. J. J. & W. carbones predictos in aqua predicta ex parte dicte ville de Gateshead in batellis carcare et usque ad dictam villam Novi Castri ducere permittatis solvend' nobis apud eandem villam Novi Castri custum' inde debit' prout decet. Teste meipso apud Westmon' vicesimo quinto die Maii." Convenit cum recordo Georgius Robson..

The same day and year a licence was granted by the said King to two of the above merchants, to send their coals, so brought to New∣castle, and having paid the duty there, to any part of the kingdom,Murray MS. p. 206. Ex rotulo patentium de anno regni Regis Edwardi tertii qua∣dragesimo primo. either by land or by water, but no whither out of the kingdom, ex∣cept to Calais.

In the year 1379 a duty of sixpence per ton every quarter of a year was imposed upon ships coming from Newcastle upon Tyne with coals
See Rymer's Foedera, tom vit. p. 220. Super desensione costerarum et ville de Scarde∣burg contra inimicos Gallicos
"Item de quibuscumque aliis navibus et vasis mare transeuntibus infra dictum admi∣ralitatum carnonibus carcatis apud Novum Castrum super Tynam cujuscunque sit portagii in quarterio uinnius anni de quolibet tonnetight sex denarios."—See also Selden's Mare Clausum, p. 300.
Coal-mines appear to have been wrought at this time in the county of Durham, at a considerable distance from Newcastle upon Tyne: the Bishop of Durham occurs Novem∣ber 1th, 1384, as appointing Thomas Haunsard supervisor of his mines of coal and iron, within his royalty, and in the districts of Norhamshire and Bedlingtonshire. Ran∣dall's MSS. from Rot. Fordham, Sch. 4, No. 4, in dorso..

December 28th, 1384, the King informed the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, that, on account of his devotion to St. Cuth∣bert, and for other reasons, he had granted leave to the inhabitants of the county of Durham, to load or unload coals, or other merchandise, any where on the south side of the river Tyne, within the liberty of the bishoprick and royalty, without paying duty to Newcastle
Murray MS. p. 207. Ex rotulo clausarum de anno Regis Richardi secundi sup∣timo, m. 20. Rex dilectis sibi majori et ballivis ville Novi Castri super Tynam & commu∣nitati ejusdem ville qui nunc sunt vel qui pro tempore fuerint salutem. Cum per quod∣dam statutum in parliamento Domini Edwardi nuper Regis Anglie avi nostri apud L' anno regni sui nono tento editum, ordinatum sit et stabilitum quod omnes mercatores alienigene et indegene et omnes alii cujuscumque status seu conditionis suerint qui ali∣quas mercandisas seu alias res venales de quacunque parte merchandise et res ille per alienegenas sive indegenas ad quemcunque locum sive fuerint civitas burgus villa portu∣maris feria mercatum aut alius locus intra regnum predictum infra libertatem vel ex venerint omere vel vendere voluerint mercandisas et res illas cuicunque sibi placuerint libere et absque impedimento vendere possint et quod nullus aliegena sive indegena im∣pediatur quo minus ipse mercandisas predictas et alias res venales in locis predictis libere emere et quocunque sibi placuerint ad opus suum proprium seu ad proficuum regum et magnatum populi regni predicti carcare valeat, &c. Et nos ob devocionem et affectionem quas ad gloriosum confestorem Sanctum Cuthbertum ecclesie Dunelm' patronum ac etiam propter affectionem quam ad venerabilem patrem Johannem Episcopum Dunelm' eo quod ipse tam caridimo domino ac patri nostro dum vixit quam nobis post ipsius domini et patris nostri decessum diu laudabiliter deservierit cordialiter obtinemus de prat nostra speciali et ex corta scientia nostris pro nobis & heredibus ac successoribus nostris unperpetuum pro pace et qurete ecclesie et episcopatus predictorum quod mercatores et alii quicunque anrici regni nostri Anglie qui voluerint cum navibus et vasis suis quibus∣cunque ex parte dicte patrie que episcopatus et libertas regalis Dunelm' nuncupatur in quocunque loco in aqua de Tyne eis placuerint applicare et carbones mercandisas et alias res quascunque quas ibidem carcare seu discarcare ex eadem parte voluerint carcare et discarcare: Nec non carbones mercandisas et alias res quas sic carcaverint quo eis placuerint ducere valeant pacifice et quiete fine impedimento nostri vel aliorum quorum∣cunque et quod idem episcopus et successores sui vasa sua propria in tota aqua predicta quacunque parte eis placuerint habere possint imperpetuum ad deserviend' eis pro deli∣beracione carbonum suorum et carriari et mitti faciend' carbones suos quocunque eis placuerint seu ad eos, mercatoribus vel aliis carbones illos emere volentibus vendend' Et quod dicti mercatores et alii hujusmodi carbones eskippare et quo voluerint ducere valeant sine impedimento aliquali et absque impositione seu alio onere quocunque de carbonibus merchandisis vel aliis rebus antedictis per vos vel alios quoscunque in qua∣cunque parte dicte aque capiendo seu levando aliqua carta libertate usu consuetudine aut alia causa qua contra tenorem aut formam statuti predicti allegari poterit non obstante dum tamen nullus virtute concess' nostre predicte lanas coria seu pelles lanatas eskip∣pare possit ad transeund' extra regnum pred' preterquam in villis et locis que per nos et heredes nostros sunt et erunt ad hoc ordinata, et quod ordinationes & defensiones ex parte nostra seu heredum nostrorum factas et in futur' faciend' de aliquibus dictarum mercan∣disarum seu aliarum rerum extra regnum nostrum predictum seu ad inimicos nostros aut dicti regni nostri minime traducend' prefatus episcopatus et successores predicti sui et omnes alii qui ex parte dicti episcopatus aliquas res allo tempore futuro eskippare volue∣rint adeo et eodem modo tenere et observare teneantur prout alii subditi et amici dicti regni nostri hujusmodi ordinaciones et defensiones in aqua de Tyne et in ceteris partibus regni nostri predicti tenere et observare tenebuntur prout in carta nostra predicta plemus continetur Nos volentes cartam nostram predictam effectum debito mancipari vobis et cuilibet vestrum firmiter injungendo precipimus et mandamus quod mercatores et alios quoscunque amicos regni nostri predicti qui voluerint cum navibus aut vasis suis pre∣dictes ex parte dicte patrie que episcopatus et libertas reglis Dunelm' vocatur in quo∣cunque loco in aqua predicta cis placuerint appre et carbones ibidem mercandisas et alias res quascunque quod ibidem cares discarcare nec non carbones mercandisas et alias res quas sic carcaverint quo cis placuerint duc et insuper ipsum episcopum & successores suos vasa sua propria in to aqua prdict quacunque parte ipsis placuerit et deserviend' cis pro deliberacione carbonum suorum et ad carrian et tti saciend' carbones suos quocunque cis placuerit seu ad co, mercatoribus vel aliis carbones illos volentibus vendend' ac ipsos mercatore, hujusmodi carbones stippre et quo voluerint ducere permittatis libere pifice & quiete sine impedimento aliquali et absque impositione seu alio onere qque de carbonibus mercandisis vel alus rebus antedictis per vos vel aliquem ex parte vostra in quacunque parte dicte aque capiendo seu levando aliqua carta libertate usu consuetudine aut alia causa que contra tenorem aut so mam statuti predicti allegari poterit et permittitur non obstante, juxta tenorem carte nostre supra dicte. Teste meipso apud Westmon' vicesimo octavo die Decembr.'—Convenitcan. recordo Johannes Boroughes.". The
above caused a scire sacias to the bishop, directed by the King to the sheriff of Northumberland, dated August 5th, 1385, ordering him to
appear, and shew cause why the mayor, bailiffs, and commonalty of Newcastle should not, according to the tenor of their charters, have the whole water of Tyne, from the sea to Hedwin-StreamsSee account of the river Tyne under that year..

It appears by the rolls of Whitby Abbey, in Yorkshire, for the years 1394, 1395, and 1396, that coals brought thither by shipping from Newcastle, Sheilds and Sunderland, were sold to that house at the rate of three shillings and four-pence per chaldron
See Charlton's History of Whitby. York, 1779, quarto, p. 260.
"Excerpta quedam ex rotulis Caenobii Whitbiensis annis 1394-5-6.
s. d.

There is preserved in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, an original receipt, dated the 4th of March, 1404, from the prior of St. John of Jerusalem in England to the mayor, aldermen, and community of that town, for the rent of mines of sea-coal then working at Fenham, a village in the vicinity of that place, then the property of that once famous order of religious, who date the above discharge from their house in Clerkenwell, London"Noverint universi per presentes nos fratrem Hildebrand Wotton preceptorem de Clerkenwell & Henricum Grendon generales attornati domini fratris Walteri Grendon pri∣oris hospitalis Sancti Johannis Jerlem in Anglia recepisse & habuisse die confeccionis presen∣tium de majore aldermannis & communitate ville Novi Castri super Tynam duode libras & decem solidos sterlingorum in partem solucionis summe triginta septem libratum et decem solidorum de firma minerarum carbonum maris de Fenham de annio Sancti Michaelis Archangeli proxim' futur' post dat' present' de quibus quidem duodecim libris et decem solidis in parte solucionis summe predicte fatemur nos nomine dicti domini nostri fore solut' dictosque majorem aldermanos & communitatem inde esse quiet' per present' sigillis nostris signat' Dat' apud domum Sancti Johannis de Clerkenwell quarto die mensis Martii anno regni Regis Henrici quarti post conquestum quinto.".

The importance of the Newcastle coal-trade at so early a period as A. D. 1421, will appear, by an act made in consequence of a petitionSee Rot. Parl. vol. iv. p. 148, n. 35. of the commons presented to parliament, May 2d, that year; in which it is directed, "that whereas there is a custom payable to the King of two-pence per chaldron on all coals sold to persons not franchised, in the port of Newcastle, and whereas the keels
Keel is a very ancient name, of Saxon origin, for a ship or vessel. See Anglo-Saxon Vocabulary, Ceol, navis. On the first arrival of the Saxons in this island, they came over in three long ships, styled by themselves, as Verstegan informs us, keeles. In the Chartulary of Tinmouth monastery, the servants of the prior who wrought in the barges, are called, A. D. 1378, kelers, an appellation plainly synonimous with our present keelmen.
In the oldest books of the Hostmen's company, keelmen are mentioned, A. D. 1600. Their vessels are called keels or lightners. The chief person on board the keel is called the skipper. Vox composita ex scip, navis, et wer, vir; euphonice skipper, Gramm. Angl. Sax. c. 3, reg. 20. The cabin of the keel is called the huddock;—this is probably a diminutive from hutte, cabin, as paddock from padde, a toad, hillock from hill, &c. See Sewel's Dutch Dictionary in verbo.
They call the great oar, used as a kind of rudder at the stern of this vessel, the swape. Swappe, to strike or fling down with violence, occurs in Chaucer.
The poles with which the keelmen on certain occasions navigate their vessels, are called puys.—Poy, appoyo, Spanish. Appuy, of appuyer, French, to support, is a pole used by rope dancers to poise themselves with.
With these puys our keelmen push on their keels in shallow water in the following manner, when it is inconvenient to use sails or oars.
One on each side of the vessel going toward the prow puts down his pole to the bottom, in a position inclined towards the head of the keel; at the same time thrusting against it forcibly with his shoulder, and walking down on the ga was towards th stem, as the keel moves under him; by this means the keel gains a tolerably quick and even course on the water: having walked the whole length of the vessel, they pluck up the puys, re∣turn hastily to the prow, put them down again, and thrust before.
Keel-bullies is a term used for this species of waterme bullies is also a common appellation among the people concerned in the in the coal work for brothers:—it is probably derived from the obsolete adjective booe, beloved.—See Ash's Dictionary.
A pauper giving an account of himself and family before the officers of a parish in New∣castle, in order to obtain a settlement, told them (inter alia) that "his father had brought up six of them bullies,"— i. e. had brought up six sons.—Such a clause in a deposition in the office at Bow-street would have justly alarmed a London audience with the account of such a brood to be let loose upon the town.
The wives and daughters of this hardy race, who sweep the keels, and have the sweep∣ings for their pains, are called Keeldeeters. To deet, signifies to wipe or make clean. —See Glossary to the poem called Yorkshire Ale.
Dr. Stukeley thus describes the method of navigating keels, in his Itinerary, about the year 1725. "The manner of rowing their great barges (at Newcastle) is also very particular, and not unworthy of remark. Four men manage the whole; three to a great and long oar, that push it forward, and one to another such a-stern, that assists the other's motion, but at the same time steers the keel, and corrects the bias the other gives it."
"These boats," says Pennant," are strong, clumsy and oval, and carry twenty tons a∣piece, they are navigated with a sail, but generally by two very large oars, one on the side plied by a man and boy; the other at the stern, by a single man, serving both as oar and ruer."—Tour, vol. iii. p. 311. which carry the
coals from the land to the ships in that port, ought to be of the just portage of twenty chaldron, according to which burden the custom aforesaid is paid; yet many now making their keels to hold twenty-two, or twenty-three chaldrons, the King is thereby defrauded of his due: wherefore it is now enacted, that all keels be measured by commissioners to be appointed by the King, and to be marked of what portage they be, under pain of forfeiting all the said keels which shall be found not marked
S Statu , anno nono Henrici quinti, s. i. cap. 10.
It seems plain from the above, that this duty of two pence per chalder upon coals sold to non freemen of Newcastle due to the King, was not first imposed at this time, but been of some standing; and the spirit of this statute is to prevent the King from wronged of any part of the impost.
the duty was first imposd A. D. 136, the 41 Ed. III. when there was a sa-coal.—See under that year.
Aa, in his Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 248, speaking of this statute, says, "The portation or foreign consumption of Newcastle coals must have been very con∣siderable even at this time."."

In consequence of the above, September 14th that year, William Glym, clerk, then vicar of Newcastle, the mayor of that town, and
the King's customers there; with John Strother, and William Bed∣ford, were appointed by the King to be commissioners during his royal pleasure, for measuring and marking keels in the port of New∣castle aforesaidMurray MS. p. 285. Paten' de anno nono Henrici quinti, pars ii. m 19. De navi∣bus mensurand' et signand' Novi Castri super Tynam..

Aeneas SilviusAenei Silvii Opera, p. 443. Arnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 82, et seq., who afterwards assumed the purple under the name of Pius the Second, visited this island about the middle of the 15th century. He relates that he saw in Scotland poor people in rags beg∣ging at the churches, and receiving for alms, pieces of stone, with which they went away contented. This species of stone, says he, whether with sulphur, or whatever inflammable substance it may be impregnated, they burn in place of wood, of which their country is destitute.

In the household book of the fifth Earl of Northumberland, of the date of 1512, a record of singular curiosity, equally throwing light on our ancient manners
Edited by Dr. Percy, now Lord Bishop of Dromore. Sixty four loads of great wood were allowed in the year to make the coals burn. This last circumstance seems to prove that the coal owners had not yet discovered or found means to win the deep strata of this fossil, or what is styled in the language of the , "the main coal."
Eighty chaldron of sea coal were allowed for a year, whereof twenty chaldron after 4s. 2d. the chaldron, and the other sixty ( land no doubt) at 5s. the chaldron, —the whole sum 19l. 3s. 4d. It is most probable that this sea-coal came by shipping from Newcastle upon Tyne., and reflecting lustre on the great family, whose extensive plan of domestic oeconomy it so minutely displays, mention occurs of this fuel, which it seems they had not yet learnt to use by itself, for the subsequent extraordinary reason, "bicause," ob∣serves this authority, "colys will not byrne withowte wodd."
The best kind of coals appear to have been purchased at this time for five shillings per chaldron, and those of an inferior sort for four shillings and two-pence.

October 1st, 1529Bourne's History of Newcastle under that year., Cardinal Wolsey, then Bishop of Durham,
granted a patent, wherein he appointed William Thomlyngson, keeper of Gateside park, and his son Thomas, jointly to the office of clerk of all his mines, as well those of lead and iron, as of coals, within his demesne lands of Durham, to receive daily one chaldron of coals out of each coal-mine within the demesnes of Gateside, Whickham, and Lynn-Dean.

December 30th, 1530, the Rev. Father in God Thomas Gardiner, prior of the monastery of Tinmouth, and the convent of the same, granted a lease from Whitsunday next ensuing, to the end of 25 years, of all the coals and coal-mines in the fields and bounds of Elswick, in the county of Northumberland, to Christopher Mitford, of Newcastle upon Tyne, Gentleman, at the annual rent of twenty pounds, upon condition that not above twenty chalder (six bowls to the chalder) should be drawn in a dayMinisters' or bailiffs' accounts of religious houses in Northumberland, from Michael∣mas, 30 Hen. VIII. to the same term, 31 Hen. VIII. remaining in the Augmentation-Office..

In the year 1536 coals were sold at Newcastle upon Tyne for two shillings and sixpence the chaldron, and at London for about four shillings the chaldron
See Stripe's edition of Stowe's Survey of London; also Maitland's London, vol. i. p. 236.
I copied the subsequent entries concerning the price of coal, from the old books of the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne:
"1540, Item paid for 1 chaldr' of colls to make fyer agaynst Mydsomer 10d.
Item paid for 20 chalder of colls to the bed folk 17s. 4d.
1545, Item paid for one chader of colls aganst Midsomer 12d.
1541, Item paid for 20 chaldr' of colls to the bed folk 18s. 8d."
The above was probably an inferior kind of coal.
Grey's MSS. inform us, that in the time of Henry VIII. coals were bought at New∣castle upon Tyne, at 2s. 2d. per chaldron, and sold in France for 13 nobles per chaldron..

September 26th, 1538, the Reverend Father in God Robert Blake∣ney, prior, and the convent of Tinmouth, occur as granting a lease of two coal-pits in Elswick, to the above Christopher Mitford, for eight years, at the annual rent of fifty poundsMinisters' or bailiffs' account ut supra,—on condition they should not work above forty chalder by the day, sixteen bowls to the chalder, "with sufficient wayleve and statheleve.".

A. D. 1546, orders were sent from the King to the mayor of New∣castle, Robert Brandling and Henry Anderson, to forward with all possible dispatch, three thousand chaldron of coals to Bullein in FranceCollection of original letters to the Archbishop of York, president of the council of the North, p. 131, communicated by Messrs. Egerton, booksellers, Charing-cross..
Bishop Fleetwood tells us, in his Chronicon Pretiosum, that, in the year 1550, a load of coals sold for twelve shillings.

Queen Mary, on the 10th of May, in the first year of her reign, in consideration of a fine of 10l. 13s. 4d. let to farm to Bertram Ander∣son, all the coal-mines within the fields and bounds of Elstwick, for twenty-one years from Michaelmas next ensuing, at the annual rent of sixty-eight poundsHarleian MSS. No. 240. Rentale Regine Marie, p. 6. "De anno primo—Northumbr' —Regina decimo die Maii anno supradicto pro fine decem librarum ac tresdecim solid' et quatuor denar' ad firmam dimisit Bertramo Anderson omnes miner' carbon' infra campos et bundas de Elstwyck pro termino 21 annorum a festo Sancti Michael' Archang' prox' futur' pro annuo redditu 68l. Rot. 4. per Thes. Anglie.".

In the Journals of the House of Commons, February 1st, 1563, mention occurs of a bill to restrain the carriage of Newcastle coals over sea
Vol. i. See also Burleigh's State Papers, by Haynes, p. 404. "Memoryall ad Wyndsor contra Gallos 7 August, 1563, to prohibitt the carryeng of Newcastle coles to the French."—From a minute of Secretary Cecil.
See afterwards under January 1600, where mention occurs of a duty of five shillings pr chaldron on coals exported beyond the seas. Quaere, was it first laid on about this time?.

June 4th, 1563, an act passed in Scotland to prevent the exportation of coal, which had caused a great dearth of fuel in that countryLaws and Acts of (Scotland's) Parliament. Edinburgh, 1681, folio, p. 170..

James, Bishop of Durham, granted a lease, dated May 20th, 1570, of coal-mines within the ground called Cross-Moor, in Whickham, to Bertram Anderson, of Newcastle upon Tyne, merchant-adventurer, for twenty-one years, at the annual rent of thirty pounds"The confirmation of Mr. Whittingham, dean, and the chapter of Durham, of a lease from the Right Reverend Father in God James, Bishop of Durham, to Bertram Anderson, of Newcastle upon Tyne, merchant-venturer, dated 20 May, 1570, of cole∣mynes within the ground called the Crosse-Moor, sit' lying and being in Whickham in the county of Durham, within these bounds hereafter declared, (that is to say) in the said moor, lying and adjoining next to the Twhagges and Newfield on the north, and lying and adjoining on the south to a place called the Gells-field, and Grenley-field, and lying and adjoining on the west to a place called the Crosse-Moor, and on the south-cast to a loan∣ing leading from Newcastle to the Strait-Yate, to sink, work, and digg within the premisses from time to time pitt and pitts, so that they work not passing three pitts at any one time. Habend' for 21 years, reddend' 30l."—Dr. Ellison's MSS..

January 12th, 1575, James, Bishop of Durham, granted to Henry Smith, Gentleman, his servant, a lease of coal-mines, within the South∣field of Whickham aforesaid, with sufficient way-leave to the water of Tyne, where he was to have a staith to lay the coals on. This grant was for twenty-one years, at the annual rent of eighteen poundsDr. Ellison's MSS..

The subsequent extracts from Harrison's description of EnglandP. 115. In the year 1580, coals appear to have been sold at Newcastle for five shil∣lings a chaldron, by the subsequent entry in the Trinity-House books, of the above date: "Paid to Clamant Anderson for 10 chalder of coles, 2l. 10s." prefixed to Hollingshead's Chronicle, edited in the year 1577, con∣tain some very curious and interesting notices concerning the coal-trade:

"Of cole-mines we have such plenty in the north and western parts of our island, as may suffice for all the realme of Englande. And soe must they doe hereafter indeede, if woode be not better cherished then it is at this present: and to say the truth, notwithstanding that very many of them are carryed into other countryes of the maine, yet theyr greatest trade beginneth to growe from the forge into the kitchen and halle, as may appeare already in most cities and townes thay lye about the cost, where they have little other fewell, excepte it be turfe and hassocke. I marvayle not a little that there is no trade of these into Sussex and Southamptonshire, for want whereof the smiths doe worke their yron with charre-coal.
"I thinke that farre carriage be the only cause, which is but a slen∣der excuse to inforce us to carye them unto the mayne from hence."

This plain but sensible writer observes farther, p. 91, "I might here take occasion to speak of the great sales yerly made of wood, wherby infinite deale hath been destroyed within these few yeres, but I give over to deale in this behalfe, howbeit, this I dare affirm, that if woodes doe goe so fast to decay in the next hundred yeare of grace, as they have done, and are like to do in this (sometymes for increase of shepewalkes, and some mayntaynaunce of prodigalitie and pompe, for I have knowne a gentleman that hath borne three-score at once in one paire of galigascons, to shew his strength and bravery) it is to be feared that brome, turfe, gal, heth, brakes, whinnes, ling, dies, has∣socks, flaggs, straw, sedge, reede, rush, and sea-cole, will be good marchandize, even in the citie of London, wherunto some of them alreadie have gotten readie passage, and taken up their innes in the greatest marchaunt's parlersOur honest remarker was not aware that even this dearth of wood, concerning which he complains so bitterly, would be converted into an occasion of great wealth to many, enrich the state, and, in process of time, become one of the most important articles of our commerce.."

This quaint writer goes on to contrast the manners of former times with those of his own: "Now we have manye chimnyes, and yet our tenderlings complaine of rewmes, catarres and poses; then had we none but reredosses"Reredosse" is rendered by "raised back" in the Gentleman's Magazine for Febru∣ary, 1787, p. 112, Note., and our heades did never ake. For as the smoke in those days was supposed to be a sufficient hardning for the timber of the house, so it was reputed a far better medicine to keep the good man and his family from the quacke or pose, wherewith as then very few were acquainted."

Our historian proceeds: "There are old men yet dwelling in the village where I remain, which have noted the multitude of chimnies
"Chamber with a chimney" occurs in the Visions of Pierce Plowman, a satire writ∣ten in the time of Edward the Third.
The chimneys of cottages in the vicinity of Newcastle are vulgarly called lums, and chimney-sweepers "lum-sweepers."—May not this be derived from the lome or clay, wherewith the wattle work, of which they are composed, is daubed over inside and out? The fraternity of bricklayers at Newcastle were anciently styled "catters and daubers."— The cut was a piece of soft clay, moulded into the form of a mower's whetstone. This was thrust in between the laths, and afterwards daubed, &c.
lately erected, whereas in their yoong dayes there were not above two or three, if so many, in most uplandish townes of the realme (the re∣ligious houses and mannour places of their lordes alwayes excepted, and peradventure some great personages) but each one made his sire against a reredosse in the halle where he dined and dressed his meate:" and, in all the bitterness of Horace's Laudator preteriti Temporis, adds, "when oure houses were buylded of willowe then had we oken men, but nowe that our houses are come to be made of oke, our men are not only become willow, but a great many altogether of straw, which is a sore alteration."

April 26th, 1582Gardiner's England's Grievance, p. 12.—He says that the Earl of Leicester sold or gave the same to Sutton, of the Charter-House., Queen Elizabeth obtained a lease of the manors of Gateshead and Whickham, with the coal-mines, common wastes, and parks, in both, of the Bishop of Durham, for ninety-nine years, at the annual rent of ninety pounds.

This, commonly called the grand lease, occasioned an advance in the price of coalsGrey's MSS. No. 1, quarto. Wilford, in his Memorials, p. 617, tells us, that "Tho∣mas Sutton, Esq who was founder of the Charter-House, was born in 1531, was steward to the Earl of Warwick, and secretary to the Earl of Leicester; to both he approved himself so able and faithful, that they declared him fit for more publick employments, as after appeared by their helping him to farm the northern coal-mines, and that upon no other security than his own word.".
This lease appears to have been procured afterwards of the Queen by the Earl of Leicester.
It was afterwards assigned to the famous Sutton, who founded the Charter-House in London: and the price of coals raised to six shillings per chaldron.

Thomas Sutton, Esq for the sum of 12,000l.Gardiner ut supra. This writer, who must not always be credited, says, that this lease was worth at least 50,000l. per annum, as was attested by Dr. Cradock, Archdea∣con of Northumberland. made an assignment of the above grand lease to Sir William Riddell and others, for the use of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne: coals are said to have been advanced on this occasion to seven, and afterwards to eight shillings per chaldronGrey's MSS. ut supra..

A. D. 1590Grey's MSS. No. 1. quarto.—See Maitland's History of London, vol. i. p. 274, where also we are informed, that "in the ear 1591, a contest arose between the lord mayor and citizens of London, and the lord high admiral of England, in respect to the right of coal metage; but on the mayor and citizens' shewing their indubitable right to the same, the admiral receded from his pretensions, and acknowledged the property to be in them; and, to prevent all controversies for the future, the citizens had this right confirmed by the Queen at the intercession of Lord Treasurer Burleigh.", the price of coals appears to have been advanced to nine shillings per chaldron: upon which the lord mayor of London complained to Lord Treasurer Burleigh, against the town of New∣castle upon Tyne, setting forth that the society there called freehosts, to whom the grand lease was first assigned for the use of the town, consisted of about sixty persons, who had made over their right to about eighteen or twenty, who engrossed all other collieries, viz. Stella, the bishop's colliery, Ravensworth colliery, the mine of Mr. Gas∣coign, the colliery of Newburn, &c. requesting that all the collieries might be opened and wrought, and that the price should not exceed seven shillings a chaldron.

In the latter end of the reign of Queen ElizabethGrey's MSS. No. 1. quarto.—See Maitland's History of London, vol. i. p. 274, where also we are informed, that "in the ear 1591, a contest arose between the lord mayor and citizens of London, and the lord high admiral of England, in respect to the right of coal metage; but on the mayor and citizens' shewing their indubitable right to the same, the admiral receded from his pretensions, and acknowledged the property to be in them; and, to prevent all controversies for the future, the citizens had this right confirmed by the Queen at the intercession of Lord Treasurer Burleigh.", the duty of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne on coals, at four-pence per chaldron, appears to have brought in 10,000l. per annum to that corporation.

A society of ostmen or hostmen
The cause of their appointment seems to be confirmed in the subsequent statute: 5 Hen. IV. cap. 9. (A. D. 1404) marchants aliens.—"And also it is ordained and stablish∣ed that in everie citie towne and porte of the sea in England, where the saide marchants aliens or strangers be or shall be repairing, sufficient hostes shall be assigned to the same marchants by the maior, sheriffes or bailiffes of the said cities, townes and portes of the sea: and that the said marchauntes aliens & strangers shall dwell in none other plase, but with their saide hoostes so to be assigned and that the same hostes so to be assigned shall take for their travaile in the maner as was accustomed in olde time."—Statutes by Barker, 1587, vol. i. p. 228.
From the accounts of the merchants-adventurers of Newcastle, A. D. 1516, it should seem that the hostmen were a branch of that society. The master had expended for the fel∣lowship 23l. 2s. 9d. They had paid him 25l. 16s. which was 2l. 13s. 3d. more than was due, and which he is said to owe to the company of hostmen.
There occurs ibid. date July 28, 10 Hen. VIII. an act "that no hosteman nor non other man being free of this fellowship shall buy any goods of their hosts."
About the year 1520, among the impositions mentioned in these merchants books, "beyond the sea," occur "for every two chalder of coals ½.—for every chalder of grind∣stones ½." Yet in the same books in their lists of impositions for 1603 and 1618, no men∣tion occurs of coals or grindstones, after the hostmen had been incorporated by royal charter. It is lastly observable, that out of the 48 names that are found in that charter, 38 occur also about the same time in the merchants books.—See in the statute of Her∣ring, 31 Ed. III. cap. 1, hostelers in the port of Yarmouth, who seem greatly to have resembled the hostmen in the coal-trade at Newcastle, and were, like the latter, a kind of mediators between the buyers and sellers. Cambden, in his Britannia, vol. ii. fol. 1319, gives the following etymon:
"The word hostmen may not improperly be taken to be traders into the eastern parts of Europe, and may have their name from the Latin word oustmanni, i. e. the eastmen, a trading into those parts, as well as the oustmanni, i. e. the eastmen, who came from the sea coast of Germany into Ireland, where, under colour of trade and merchandise, being admitted into some of their cities, in a short time they began a very terrible war."
It appears from the earliest entries in the books of this society, that the stranger arriv∣ing at the port of Tyne to buy coals, is called "the oaste." had existed as a guild or fraternity
in the town of Newcastle upon Tyne from time immemorial, before their incorporation by royal charter, which is said to have been granted on the following occasion: About the year 1599 Queen Elizabeth requiring of the mayor and burgesses of that town the great arrears of a duty payable to the crown, of two-pence per chaldron on coals sold to unfreemen in the port of Tyne, the date of the origin of which can only be conjectured, but of which there is express mention in a printed statute A. D. 1420, it appeared that the payment of this impost had been so long neglected, that they found themselves unable to comply with
her request; on which they besought her majesty to remit them the sum, and to incorporate the old guild of hostmen; who, on their in∣corporation, should, by a grant to the Queen, her heirs and successors, oblige themselves and their successors for ever to pay one shilling for every chalder of coals exported from thence to the free people of England. So writes GardinerP. 13. "The Queen," he adds, "conceived that twelve-pence upon every chalder would be better for the future, and well paid, and would rise to greater revenue, than the two-pence so long in arrear could endamage."; but they themselves in their own grantSee Appendix. affirm that they were influenced by more generous motives, and that what they did, arose from their gratitude to her majesty for incorporating them by charter, as also to assist her, then labouring under excessive charges, in support of the realm against its foreign ene∣mies.
