The agreement between the Queen and this fraternity, concerning the impost of a shilling per chaldron, had been made, or at least agreed upon before January 1600, for in the royal patent, dated at Westmin∣ster, January 3d, 1600, for the appointing of commissioners to mea∣sure keels at Newcastle, she includes in that number, "the collector of the shilling per chaldron granted her by the hostmenQueen Elizabeth, by her patent, dated at Westminster, January 3d, in the 42d year of her reign, appointed the mayor of Newcastle for the time being, the collectors of her custom and subsidy in that part, the comptroller, the farmer of the imposition of 5 shil∣lings per chaldron on coals exported beyond the seas, the collector of the shilling per chaldron granted to her by the hoastmen, 8 merchants, 4 masters and mariners, and 5 yeomen, in all 23 persons, to be commissioners for measuring keels according to the act of parliament made on the second day of May, the 9th of Hen. V. A. D. 1420.—From a copy in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.."

Queen Elizabeth's great charter to the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, by a clause whereof this fraternity is incorporated, we find dated March 22d, 1600: forty-eight personsSee Appendix. are named therein for the better loading and disposing of pit coals and stones upon the Tyne, and for their own better support as a society, with the title of gover∣nor,
stewards, and brethren of the fraternity of hoastmen in the town of Newcastle upon Tyne—a common seal is granted themSee Seals, Plate I. No. 11.. The governor and stewards are to be annually elected on the 4th of Ja∣nuary. Power is given them to load and unload any where on the Tyne between Newcastle and Sparhauk, yet as near to Newcastle as they can, notwithstanding the statute of the 21st of Henry the Eighth, &c.

April 8th, 1600, the fraternity of hostmen
This society are also called Fitters. The subsequent extracts from their own books, with the perusal of which I was favoured in the most obliging manner by Alexander Adams, Esq steward, will best explain the meaning of this appellation:
"Acts 20 Januarie 1600.
"7th—none shall "fitt" any keell or keells of anie other brother without the consent of the owner thereof &c."—"Fitt Tyde" occurs ibid.—April 28, 1625, "to fitt and load coles abord of the keeles &c." occurs.
It is observable in the printed Journals of the House of Commons, that the title of this fraternity is often by mistake spelled "fillers:" of Newcastle upon Tyne, for themselves and successors, granted to Queen Elizabeth, her heirs and successors for ever, twelve-pence for every chaldron of sea-coal, stone-coal, or pit-coal, of the water measure of Newcastle, shipped in the port of Tyne, to be spent within the kingdom, and not sent be∣yond the seas (coals sold and carried from Newcastle to Hartlepool for the salt-pans at that place, belonging to Lord Lumley, his heirs and assigns, or to any of the burgesses of Newcastle excepted). This impost to be paid to such officer or collector as the Queen should ap∣point, and that before the clearing of the ship at the custom-houseSee Appendix.

It appears by the order of the hostmen's company, dated A. D. 1600, that waggons and waggon-ways had not then been invented, but that the coals were at that time brought down from the pits in wains (holding eight bowls each, all measured and marked), to the staiths by the side of the river Tyne
"At a courte holden the thirde day of February anno Regine Elizabethe &c. 43 annoque Domini 1600.
"11th Acte—Yt is further ordered by th'aucthorytye aforesaide the saide daye and yeare that no free brother of this felloship of hostmen shall henceforth either himself or his servants or any other for him goe or send to the sheeles or the ballist-shores or within any parte of the ryver of Tyne or any place without the walles of the saide towne to talke or speake with the owner, mr. or purser of any shipp, hoie, or other vessell whatsoever upon the water to learne whose oaste he is, therby to procure him to be his oaste or to with∣drawe him from his old oaste by any kind of meanes &c."
—From the 20th act it appears "that from tyme out of mynde yt hath been accustomed that all cole waynes did usuallie cary and bring eighte boulls of coles to all the staythes upon the ryver of Tyne," till of late several had brought only or scarce seven boulls—The wains are ordered to be all measured and marked—Four persons are appointed to measure, gauge and mark them. "Foothers" occur ibid.
In the 15th act are mentioned "two small maunds or pannyers holdinge two or three pecks a peece.".

About the year 1600 an engine for drawing water out of coal-mines was invented in Scotland, by a predecessor of the first Earl of Balcarras, who obtained from King James VI. a patent for the discovery, for 21 years. I find no account of this having been adopt∣ed in the collieries upon the river TyneArnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 66..

An interesting account of the state of the coal-trade at Newcastle upon Tyne, dated February 26th, 1602, is preserved in the books of the above fraternity: there appear to have been at that time 28 acting sitters, or hoastmen, who were to vend by the year 9080 tens of coals, and find 85 keels for that purpose: the prices ordered were, for the best sort not above ten shillings the chaldron; for the second best sort not above nine shillings; and for the kind called there "the meane coles," not above eight shillings for the like quantity
"February 26th, 1602, an order and agreemente of partnership for the vente of coalles proportioned by quarters.
For the first quarter. Tens of coals, and to find for vent thereof.
Mr. William Selbie 600 5 keels.
Mr. George Selbie 150 1
Mrs. Barbara Ryddell and Mr. Peter Ryddell 700 4 or 6
Tens Keels
Mr. William Hodgshon 450 5
Mr. Robert Anderson 300 2½
Isaack Anderson 150 1½
2350 19
For the second quarter.
Mr. Henry Chapman 900 9
Mr. Henry Anderson 200 1
Matthew Chapman 400 4
Mr. Nicholas and Rowland Tempest 250 1½
Mr. Francis Anderson 300 2
Bertram Anderson 100 1
John Strangwiche 150 2
2300 20½
For the third quarter.
Mr. Lyonel Maddison and Henrye Maddison 700 9
Mr. John Barker 550 5
Robert Shafto 260 2¼
Ralphe Atkinson 420 4
Thomas Hall 300 3
2230 23½
For the fourth quarter.
Mr. Thomas Lyddell and Francis Lyddell 500 5½
William Bonner 400 4
William Jenyson, junr. 400 5
Mr. Tymothie Draper 420 5
Margaret Gray, wedow 180 1½
Edward Crome and Thomas Crome 300 2
2200 23"
.

A. D. 1603, complaint was made to the King of great wrongs done
to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, by the hostmen of that town: this matter, which appears to have arisen from refusing to admit into that fraternity, such as were free of the twelve misteries of the town, was referred to the Lord President and Council of the North, at York, who made a decree December 21, 1603, in conse∣quence
of which, great numbers out of the misteries were admitted free hostsHostmen's books—also archives of the corporation of Newcastle..

May 30th, 1604, a bill for explanation of the statute enacted in the 21st year of the reign of King Henry VIII. concerning sea-coal, was on a second reading in the House of Commons rejected.Journals of the House of Commons, vol. i.

November 12th, 1604, the Privy-Council wrote to the hostmen of Newcastle, for the reformation of some abuses in loading ships by the bulk, and to enforce a true payment to the farmers, of the twelve-pence per chaldron on coals.
In consequence of the above, new orders appear to have been made February 5th, 1605, by the said hostmenFrom a copy entered in the hostmen's books..

Against these also complaints were made to the Privy-Council, who by a second letter commanded they should be set aside: they were dis∣solved accordingly by an order of the society, dated July 27th, 1605
Hostmen's books.
I have seen an original letter of thanks from the mayor, aldermen, and sheriff of New∣castle upon Tyne, dated August 20th, 1605, to the Earl of Northumberland, acknow∣ledging his lordship's "last kind respects and countenance towards their brethren Mr. Lid∣dell and Mr. Jennison, and their proceedings in their common cause touching the order of uttering and sale of their coles.".

A. D. 1609, on some disputes between the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, and those of Lynn Regis in Norfolk, concern∣ing some duties which the former had claimed of the latter, there was an award, dated November 20th in that year, by Sir Henry Hob∣bart, attorney-general, and Sir John Jackson, recorder of Newcastle. This was confirmed by a decree of the court of Chancery, dated the 20th of that month, whereby the inhabitants of Lynn aforesaid were enjoined the payment of two-pence for toll of every chalder of coals loaded at Newcastle upon Tyne
The following extract is from the Aubone MS.
"In the 5th of James I. a quo warranto was brought against the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, and also against the hostmen there, alleging that each of them claimed two-pence a chalder of coals, &c.
"The mayor and burgesses prescribe their two-pence, and the hostmen disclaim it. This was exemplified 7 James."
Papers with the following titles are preserved in the archives of the corporation of New∣castle upon Tyne:
"15 November, 1609, award made by Sir Henry Hobbart, attorney-general, and Sir John Jackson, recorder of Newcastle, between the mayor and burgesses of King's Lynn in Norfolk, about some duties demanded by each of them.
"This award confirmed by a decree of the court of Chancery, Michaelmas term, 20 November, 7 Jacobi primi.
"Two-pence on every chalder shipped for Lyn Regis to the use of the mayor and bur∣gesses of Newcastle taken off. The inhabitants of Lyn are henceforth to pay 2d. for toll of every chalder loaded at Newcastle."
"The exemplification of a decree upon an information against the hostmen and maior and burgesses upon a writt of quo warranto by those of Lynn Regis for takeing 2d. per chalder for coles and for other duties." (In another hand) "Allowed and judgment granted for the maior and burgesses for and towards their charge in repairing wharfes &c.".

In a petition of grievances presented by the House of Commons to King James, July 7th (or 10th), 1610, a complaint occurs of "a late imposition of one shilling the chalder on sea-coals, rising in Blyth and Sunderland, not by virtue of any contract or grant, as in the coals of Newcastle, but under the mere pretext of his Majesty's royal pre∣rogative." This impost appeared upon examination to have pro∣ceeded from a mistake, and was laid down in consequence of the above petition
See Morgan's Phoenix Britannicus, p. 502; also Parliamentary History of England, vol. v. p. 240, where the following occurs: "Memorandum quod die Martis 10 die Julii 1610, in the afternoon—attended his Majesty in the Banquetting-House at Whitehall— concerning greivances lately exhibited to him by the Commons—greivance—imposition of one shilling upon the chalder of sea coals.
"Answer—There never was any imposition laid upon the sea-coals of Blyth and Sunder∣land, by the King's authority; but it being conceived that they were members of New∣castle (and so within their composition), they were only mentioned, in some letters patent, with the town of Newcastle: but it appearing that they were things distinct, let the said pretended impositions be laid down and no more taken."
Grey's MSS. No. 1, quarto, say it was July 7, 1610.
About A. D. 1610, an answer was drawn up by the coal owners of Newcastle upon Tyne, in which they offered their reasons to the consideration of the Privy-Council, con∣cerning a late information exhibited against them by the lord mayor and aldermen of London, concerning the prices of sea-coal.
By the accounts of the stewards of the society of hostmen for the year 1610, it appears that about this time they had been fitting up some place for a meeting-house for the fra∣ternity.
By a charter of James I. to the citizens of London, dated 15th of September, 1614, the King granted them the measuring and weighing of coals in the port of London from Yenleet to Stayne's Bridge.—Maitland's London, vol. i. p. 295..

March 6th, 1615, mention occurs of certain letters patent sent to the mayor and hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne, purporting a grant made for the surveying of coals shipped at that town and other places: whereupon the mayor and common-council deputed two persons to London, instructed with reasons to lay before his Majesty and the Privy-Council, which proved not only that the above grant was pre∣judicial to the state, but that the suppositions contained therein were not true
Hostmen's books.
On a reference from the Privy-Council to the lord mayor, &c. of London, they re∣ported nothing favourable to the office abovesaid, and the whole matter in return was re∣ferred to their lordship's consideration.—From a letter signed John Leman, maior, &c. of London, to the Privy-Council, inrolled in the archives of Newcastle upon Tyne..

In the year 1615 there appear to have been employed in the coal-trade of Newcastle, four hundred sail of ships, one half of which sup∣plied London, as the other did the rest of England with that fuel.

The French are represented at this time, as trading to Newcastle for coal in fleets of fifty sail at once, serving the ports of Picardy, Nor∣mandy, Bretagne, &c. as far as Rochel and Bourdeaux, while the ships of Bremen, Embden, Holland and Zealand, were supplying the inhabitants of Flanders with the same commodityVide Anderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. i. p. 494, citing a small tract pub∣lished in 1615, and intitled "The Trade's Increase," which informs us that "besides our own ships, hither, even to the mine's mouth, come all our neighbouring nations with their ships continually, employing their own shipping and mariners." &c..
In the year 1616Hostmen's books., it appears that 13,675 tens of coals were ship∣ped from the port of Newcastle upon Tyne.

By this time the use of sea-coal had become general, occasioned, as it is asserted, by a great scarcity of wood, which of late years they had neglected to plant throughout the whole kingdom
"Such hath bene the plenty of wood in England for all uses, that within man's me∣mory it was held impossible to have any want of wood in England, but contrary to former imaginations such hath bene the great expence of timber for navigation; with infinite in∣crease of building of houses, with the great expence of wood to make houshold furniture, casks and other vessels not to be numbered, and of carts, waggons and coaches; besides the extreame wast of wood in making iron, burning of brick and tile: that whereas in the year of our Lord God 1306, King Edward I. by proclamation prohibyted the burne∣ing of sea coale in London and the suburbs, to avoid the sulferous smoke and favour of the firing, and in the same proclamation commanded all persons to make their fire of wood; which was performed by all (smiths only excepted); yet at this present, through the great consuming of wood as aforesaid and the neglect of planting of woods, there is so great scarcetie of wood throughoute the whole kingdome, that not only the city of Lon∣don, all haven townes and in very many parts within the land, the inhabitants in general are constrained to make their firs of sea coale or pit coale; even in the chambers of ho∣nourable personages and through necessitie, which is the mother of all arts, they have of very late years devised the making of iron, the making of all sorts of glasse and burning of bricke with sea coale or pit coale.—Within thirty yeares last the nice dams of London would not come into any house or roome where sea coales were burned, nor willingly at of the meat that was either sod or roasted with sea coal fire."—Stowe's Annals by Howes. London, 1632, folio, p. 1025.
See also the Northumberland household-book, p. 99..
May 6th, 1618, an information was made in the Star-Chamber against several hostmen and skippers of Newcastle upon Tyne, for adulterating coals.

Judgment was given on this occasion against R. Bewic, J. Cole, R. Hodgson, W. Jennison, T. Hall and H. Maddison, to be committed to the Fleet, and pay a fine of 20l. each, to his Majesty's use: the de∣cree to be read in the open market at Newcastle upon Tyne, two seve∣ral market days.
The skippers, as also Ralph Cole, were acquittedGrey's MSS..

An act for the free traffick of sea-coals, stone-coals, and pit-coals, in and out of the counties of Durham and Northumberland, was acquitted
and discharged on the first reading thereof, February 27th, 1620, in the House of CommonsVide Journals.—Mention occurs ibid. April 18th, 1621, of a monopoly at Newcastle upon Tyne. And ibid. December 3d, 1621, by a speech of Sir Thomas Riddall, it ap∣pears that 16,000l. per annum were already granted upon coals..
In the year 1622 there were vended by the society of hostmen of Newcastle 14,420 tens of coals.

April 20th, 1622, there was an order made by the above fraternity against the secret and disorderly loading of coals. They had received several letters from the King and Privy-Council concerning this abuse.

They were summoned to answer again by process from the Ex∣chequer chamber against the governor, stewards, and some of the company for the above defaults, returnable in the subsequent Easter termHostmen's books.—For an account of a patent of James I. dated 29 April, in the 20th year of his reign, concerning the exempting of the payment of the shilling per chal∣dron impost to the poor of London, for 4000 chalder of coals, se afterwards March 11th, 1645..

By a clause in an act of parliament made in the year 1623, the duty of two-pence per chaldron, mentioned A. D. 1421, was saved to the crown
Anno vicesimo primo Jacobi Regis.
Cap. 2, Sect. 5. "Provided always that this act nor any thing therein contained shall extend to debar his Majesty, his heirs or successors, of or from any such claim and demand as his Majesty hath made, or may rightfully make, of a certain duty or custom of two-pence upon a chaldron of sea-coal, to be paid in the port of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, with the members thereof, but that the same shall be nd remain in such sort and degree as if this act had never been had or made.".

February 16th, 1624, a proclamation was made for surveying sea-coals at Newcastle upon Tyne, Sunderland and Blyth: his Majesty, by letters patent made September 22d, 1623, to Messieurs Sharpy and Hedley, for 21 years, had erected an office for the surveying of coals to be brought to London and other places, with a grant of four-pence per chaldron for surveying them: by which they raised 3200l. per annum
Journals of the House of Commons.
In the Parliamentary History, vol. xxiii. Appendix, p. 47, we read, "whereas it pleased your majesty the 27d day of September, in the 21st year of your happy reign over us, to grant unto Sir Robert Sharpleigh, Knt. and Alexander Hetley, Esq a patent of sur∣veying ships of Newcastle coals, with a fee of 3d. upon the great chaldron." &c. among the complaints on grievances, wherein it is afterwards set forth, that this patent is not only in itself unlawful, as being grounded upon many untrue suggestions, and burthensome to the people, &c.
There was an order of the host men's company A. D. 1625, that no brother should give above sixpence portage to the ship-master upon every chalder of coals..

In the year 1625 King Charles I. gave his royal consent, that a contribution of six-pence should be laid on every chalder of coals that should be transported from Newcastle upon Tyne to any of his domi∣nions, or beyond the seas into foreign parts. Alexander Davison, mer∣chant of that town (afterwards knighted), was appointed to collect the same
See Rushworth's Collections, vol. i. fol. 414. It is called "the voluntary contribu∣tion of the owners, buyers and sellers of coals—to be employed towards the maintenance, provision, arming, manning, victualling and furnishing six able ships of war, for guarding and defending the coast of this realm, from the furthest north-east point of the sea unto the mouth of the river of Thames."
Anderson, in his Dictionary of Commerce, mentions this under the year 1627.. Coals appear to have sold this year at that place for seven shillings and six-pence per chaldronTrinity-House books..

November 13th, 1626, the hostmen of Newcastle deputed some of their brethren to London, to attend the lord chief justice and others of the judges appointed to make report to his Majesty concerning the patent of survey of coals, and state to them the objections of this so∣ciety against it.Hostmen's books..

There occurs among the projected monopolies of the year 1627, a charter to three persons for the sole practice of their new invention for the melting of iron ore, and making the same into cast works and bars, with sea-coal and pit-coal onlyRymer's Foedera, tom. xviii. p. 992..

In the year 1629 a quo warranto was brought against the governor, stewards, and brethren of the fraternity of hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne, to shew by what warrant they claimed to be incorporated by that name, to plead and be impleaded, purchase and dispose of, &c.
have a common seal, choose a governor, &c. have their common-council to make ordinances and lay penalties there, and take money for admitting into their society; all which they claimed, partly by prescription, and partly by a charter of the 42d of Queen Elizabeth, dispensing with the statute of the 21st of Henry VIII. for loading at Newcastle; and by another charter of the second of King James: whereupon, and upon view of their ancient books, Mr. Attorney Ge∣neral confessed their plea, and thereupon their said liberties were al∣lowed and adjudged unto themAubone MS.—also the archives of the hostmen's company..

In the year 1630 the King granted an exclusive patent to four per∣sons for a pretended new invention for melting, forging or sining iron, lead, tin and salt; as also for the burning of bricks, tiles, lime, &c. with the fuel of peat and turf, reduced to a coal, without the use of sea-coal, pit-coal, or wood.

The same year one David Ramsay, a great projector, obtained an exclusive grant, or charter, to raise water from low mines and coal-pits, by a way never before usedRymer's Foedera, tom. xix. fol. 189..

April 22d, 1630, the King let to farm, under the great seal of Eng∣land, to Sir Thomas Lake, Sir John Trevor, Sir Marmaduke Darell, and Sir Thomas Bludder, an impost on coals of sive shillings per chal∣dron, for those transported out of England, Wales, and Berwick upon Tweed, to any part beyond the seas, except Guernsey, Jersey, and the Isle of Man—of one shilling and eight-pence over and above the five shillings on those to be exported as above by any Englishman or denison; and also of three shillings and four-pence for every chalder to be exported, or shipped to be exported, except for Ireland or Scot∣land
From the upper part of an original indenture preserved among the papers and records of the company of shipwrights in Newcastle upon Tyne, on the back of which are en∣grossed some private orders of that society. It is dated 26th November, 14 Charles I. and is made between Sir Ralph Freman, Sir Thomas Bldder, Sir John Trevor, Knights, and Lancelot Lake, Esq on the one part, and John Tompkins and John Lake, of New∣castle upon Tyne, Gent. on the other, appointing the two last to be deputies for collect∣ing at the Custom-House at Newcastle, and the creeks and members thereof, an impost on coals as above demised, granted and let to farm by indenture, sealed with the great seal of England, &c. as above to the four persons before-named, whose right and property in that grant had devolved, by two deaths, to the said Sir Ralph Freman, Lancelot Lake, Esq &c.
Gardiner, p. 53, says that this Sir John Trevor, &c. paid yearly for their lease one thousand four hundred pounds..
In the year 1631 an information was made in the Star-Chamber by Heath, attorney-general, against the hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne, for mixing 40,000 chaldron of coalsGrey's MSS..
In the year 1633 coals appear to have been sold at Newcastle for nine shillings per chaldronTrinity-House books..

A. D. 1634, the King, solely by his own authority, imposed a duty of four shillings per chaldron on all sea-coal, stone-coal, or pit-coal, exported from England to foreign partsRymer's Foedera, tom. xix. fol. 547..
In the month of October, 1635, coals sold at Newcastle for ten shil∣lings the chaldronTrinity-House books..
They occur at the same price water measure as sold there in the same month, 1637Ibid..

A. D. 1637, one shilling per chaldron appears to have been paid on the foreign vent of coals to the mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne: letters were sent thereupon from the Lord Treasurer and Lord Cotting∣ton to the Bishop of Durham, requiring him to write to the said mayor, and order an immediate restoration of the above exaction. The bishop's letter is dated January 10th, 1638
From the old books of the Trinity-House, (dorso) "A copie of my Lord of Durham's lettre to Mr. Maior to repaie the 12d a chalder upon coles upon the forme vent of sea-coles. Mr. Maior, I have receaved this very day lettres from the Rt. Honourable the Lord Treasurer and Lord Cottington requiring me to lett you understand that the 12 pence by the marchants, owners and masters of ships payd unto you, or to the factors or clerks of the office upon the forraine vent of sea-cole, must be restored unto the foresaid marchants and the rest which hath made payment thereof: and that there may be noe delay herein I shall deseire you that you will looke upon their lettres of attorney for the re∣ceipt thereof and to satisfie them accordingly: and thus &c."
"Durham, January 10th, 1637-8.".

A. D. 1637, the King granted, as Gardiner
Grievances of the Coal-Trade, chap. 21.
It appears, by Rymer's Foedera, tom. xx. fol. 191, that in 1637 the King granted a patent to Thomas, Earl of Berkshire, for a newly invented kiln for drying malt and hops with sea-coal, turf, peat, or any other cheap fuel. informs us, to Sir Thomas TempestJanuary 22, 1638, the hostmen of Newcastle appointed Richard Tickell, Gent. for the seizure of all coals unlawfully laid aboard of any ship, by a grant under their seal. This was in consequence of a contract under the great seal of England, August 1st, 1637, between the King, the mayor of Newcastle, and this fraternity, whereby it was ordered that no coals should be shipped in the port of Newcastle, but by the hands of one of the six factors therein named, under pain of forfeiture during 21 years. The salary of this temporary officer was 30l. per annum, and part of the seizures. and others (notwithstanding the former exclusive and perpetual right by charter of the hostmen of Newcastle) the sole power of selling all coals exported out of the port of Tyne for twenty-one years.

In the year following, as the same authorityGrievances of the Coal-Trade, chap. 22. "Provided they had a free market and ajust measure at Newcastle, &c." observes, the King incorporated a company of coal monopolizers, Thomas Horth, and other masters of shipsBy a letter from Lord Conway, then at Newcastle, to Archbishop Laud, dated June 13th, 1640, it appears that the new corporation of ship-masters had imposed two-pence on every chalder of coals sent from Newcastle or Sunderland, amounting to 1300l. a year, and that they exacted a mark from every one they received into their society. It appear' by the same letter, that they had already been incorporated two years.—Prynne's Hidden Works of Darkness, p. 185., impowering them to buy all the coals that should be exported from Sunderland, Newcastle, Blithe and Berwick, paying to the King one shilling custom for every chalder. They were to sell these coals again to the city of London, at a price not exceeding seventeen shillings the chalder in summer, and nineteen in winter, &c.
The grant of the preceding year was probably revoked on account of the above.

The King, in the July following, adds the same authorityGardiner's England's Grievances of the Coal-Trade, chap. 23. Mention of this oc∣curs in the Journals of the House of Commons, vol. ii. "November 12, 1640, the doc∣quet of Mr. Sandys, his patent for receiving twelve-pence upon the chaldron more than the old tax that was set upon the coals, was read.", granted another patent to Mr. Sands, with others, for the farming of the above custom of one shilling on every chalder, at the yearly rent of ten thousand pounds.
Monopolies contributed greatly, among other grievances, to hurt the interest of the unfortunate Charles with the people of Great Britain.
The granting of these in the coal-trade, as stated above, appears to have composed no inconsiderable part of that unhappy monarch's po∣litical sins.

There was a letter, dated July 31st, 1640, from the lords of the Privy-Council to the mayor and aldermen of Newcastle upon Tyne, for the purpose of regulating the prices, and to prevent the scarcity of sea-coal. This was referred to the hostmen, who appointed four of their brethren to examine the several staiths, and certify the particulars to their lordships, according to their requestHostmen's books..

When Newcastle upon Tyne was taken by the covenanters in the year 1640, the coal-trade, which before that event is said to have em∣ployed ten thousand people, sustained an immense loss: every one fled, thinking the Scots would give no quarter, and more than an hundred vessels that arrived off Tinmouth-Bar the day after the fight, hearing that the Scots were in possession of the town, returned emptyRushworth's Collections..
January 14th, 1642, an ordinance both of Lords and Commons was published, prohibiting ships from bringing coals or salt from New∣castle, Sunderland, or BlythSee Journals of the House of Commons..

About this time there was an imposition of three-pence laid upon
every chaldron of coals, for maintaining the garrison of Newcastle upon TyneBourne's History of Newcastle..

The King, by a letter from Nottingham, September 13th, 1642, to the custom-house officers of Newcastle upon Tyne, and by another, dated at Darby, September 14th, 1642, to the mayor, aldermen and burgesses of that town, ordered that the custom of coals transported into foreign parts, should be taken according to the old and not the new book of ratesFrom copies thereof entred in the common-council books..

In the year 1643 the Commons passed several ordinances for raising monies out of delinquents' estates and Newcastle coals, to satisfy those who had lent money for the advance of the Scottish army into Eng∣land.

The same year, when the Scots besieged Newcastle, the Marquis of Newcastle ordered all the coal-mines to be fired. This was prevented by General Lesley's surprising all the boats and vesselsWhitelock's Memorials, p. 72, &c. There was published about this time "Sea-coale, char-coale, small-coal, a discourse concerning the prohibition of trade with Newcastle, 1643."—Dr. Ellison's MSS..
April 1st, 1643, about this time there appears to have been a very great scarcity of coal in the city of LondonJournals of Common..

April 15th, 1643, the Commons made an order to restrain the im∣positions of wharfingers, chandlers and coal-sellers, who appear to have added to the general calamity of London, in violently oppressing the poor by extortionable pricesIbid..
June 8th, 1643, the Commons made an order to restrain the prices of coals to twenty shillings, or not above twenty-three shillings the chalderIbid..

June 25th, 1643, the gun-makers of London petitioned the House
of Commons for sea-coal to carry on their trade, which had unfortu∣nately by this time become a very important oneJournals of Commons..
July 20th, 1643, it was earnestly recommended by the House of Lords to the Commons, to send ships to procure coal, at that time a very scarce commodity, from NewcastleIbid. vol. iii..

September 7th, 1643, the hostmen of Newcastle agreed, for the defence of that town, to pay three-pence per chaldron for every chal∣dron of coals over and above the former three-pence, for three years following from Lady-day nextHostmen's books..

October 2d, 1643, an ordinance was made by the Lords and Com∣mons to supply the poor and others with wood, in default of coal, as Newcastle was at that time surprised, as it is expressed, by the "papal and malignant forcesJournals of the Commons.."

There is preserved in Rushworth's very valuable collections, a cu∣rious letter from the King to the Marquis of Newcastle, written in figure cyphers from Oxford, and dated November 2d, 1643, concern∣ing the procuring of arms from Holland in exchange for our coalsRushworth's Collections, part iiid. vol. iii. p. 368..

January 8th, 1644, at a court of the hostmen of Newcastle, it was ordered that six brethren of that society should attend the mayor, to adjust such quantities of coals as should be lent to his Majesty to pro∣cure corn, powder and ammunition, for the King's service, and in de∣fence of the country, pursuant to a commission from the Marquis of NewcastleHostmen's books..

March 12th, 1644, there was an order made by the Lords and Commons, that all persons of their party should have leave to trade for coals to either Sunderland or Blyth; both which places had then fallen into their handsJournals of the House of Commons..

July 15th, 1644, there was an imposition of four shillings a chaldron, Sunderland measure, and after the rate of two shillings a chaldron, London measure, or thereabouts, to continue for six months, laid upon all coals to be shipped coastwaysJournals of the House of Commons..

July 20th, 1644, the parliament made an ordinance to provide peat and turf for the city of London; the Marquis of Newcastle, then in possession of that town, having, as Rushworth informs us, prohibited the exportation of coals to that city, on account of the citizens' dis∣obedience to his MajestyRushworth's Collections, part iii. vol. ii. p. 770..

August 20th, 1644, the hostmen of Newcastle made an order, that the three-pence per chaldron paid by them upon coals, should be con∣tinued for two years beyond the time mentioned in a former order of the 17th of July, 1643Hostmen's books..

After the town of Newcastle upon Tyne had been taken by the Scottish army, the House of Commons took the management of the coal-trade, as well as the government of that town, into their own handsWhitelock's Memorials..

The committee of the parliament at Newcastle sent up on this oc∣casion a great quantity of coals for the relief of the poor of London, of which the Commons gave notice to the Lord Mayor, with orders for the distribution of them. Coals had before this time been raised in London to the enormous price of four pounds per chaldronBourne's History of Newcastle..

November 14th, 1644, an ordinance was published by both houses of parliament, for opening the trade to Newcastle upon Tyne, and for annulling the former ordinance that prohibited the trade to that townJournals of the House of Commons..

On the 18th following, the commissioners of the parliament at
Newcastle, with the concurrence of the hostmen of that town, made many regulations concerning the coal-tradeHostmen's books..

On the 21st of December following, the Commons in parliament made an order, that it should be referred to the consideration of the committee at Goldsmith's Hall, whether any proportion might be raised out of the revenue of the coals, towards the monthly pay assigned to the Scottish army, without violating or weakening the en∣gagement already raised upon the credit of that commodity; as also how that fuel might be best managed to the publick advantageJournals of the Commons, vol. iii..

January 4th, 1645, there was an order of parliament, that the com∣mittee of Goldsmith's Hall should appoint agents at Newcastle, Sun∣derland, &c. to manage the coals and collieries of the delinquents, &c. and pay over such monies as should arise from thence to the treasurer of the Scottish army, for the space of four months or longer, if it should appear necessaryJournals of the House of Commons, vol. iv..

March 11th, 1645, it was ordered in parliament, that the com∣mittee of the revenue should take into consideration the patent granted to the city of London, for four thousand chalders of coals to be sold again for the use of the poor
Ibid. In the said Journals for 6th of September, 1648, there occurs an order, "That it be referred to the committee of the revenues to consider of the desires of the city of London, to have four thousand chaldrons of sea-coals shipped from Newcastle, and brought to London free of impost, for the poor of that city and Southwark."
The following is an extract from Whitelock's Memorials: "October 4th, 1648, order for a thousand pounds for coals for the poor of London and Southwark, according to a grant of King James.
The subsequent I copied from a London newspaper. "February 14th, 1778. Yester∣day a court of common-council was held at Guild-Hall, at which a motion was made, that the committee for prosecuting sheriffs elect refusing to serve, be desired to consider the most eligible means of restoring to the poor of the city of London their ancient right to the impost or duty of one shilling per chaldron on four thousand chaldron of coals, to be shipped from the port of Newcastle, by virtue of letters patent of James I. dated the 29th of April, in the 20th year of his reign."
Giles Alcock, Esq agent for the Duke of Richmond, at Newcastle upon Tyne, in∣formed me that the above charitable donation, which he had been instrumental in setting aside, had been very much abused. It caused a diminution of two hundred pounds per annum to the revenue of the Duke of Richmond, arising from the shilling per chaldron on coals..

March 20th, 1645, it was resolved in parliament, that the five shil∣lings imposed upon every chaldron of coals, by the commissioners of both kingdoms, at Newcastle upon Tyne and Sunderland, should be taken offJournals of the House of Commons, vol. iv..

April 3d, 1645, the hostmen of Newcastle petitioned the above commissioners to take off the three-pence paid by them out of every chaldron of coals they sold, as they had done the last-mentioned five shillingsHostmen's books. Whitelock, in his Memorials, April 15th, 1645, tell us, that the inhabitants of Newcastle were discontented at the imposition on coal..

June 9th, 1645, there was an order of parliament for the speedy grant∣ing of five hundred tens of the coals of delinquents to the mayor and town of Newcastle upon Tyne, for the use of the poor and infected of that place, and among other purposes to repair the walls thereofJournals of the House of Commons, vol. iv..

September 29th, 1645, it was ordered by the parliament, that Sir John Trevor, &c. should be put into the collection of the twelve-pence per chalder upon coals at Newcastle, payable to the King, ac∣cording to their lease from his majesty of that dutyIbid..
January 4th, 1646, the hostmen of Newcastle set aside their orders of the 7th of September, 1643, and the 20th of August, 1644, for the payment of three-pence per chalder on coalsHostmen's books..
Whitelock, under the date of February 8th, 1646, informs us, that four shillings per chaldron upon Newcastle coals were continued for the maintenance of that garrisonSee his Memorials..

November 4th, 1646, the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle had
an opportunity (and embraced it) of testifying their loyalty, as it were in kind, to their unfortunate sovereign, at that time a prisoner within their walls, by defraying one half of the expence of the coals used by his majesty, and his retinue
Common-council books.—The following occurs ibid. November 30th, 1646: "Mr. George Dawson, alderman, made report to the common-council, that he had byn with Sir Thomas Riddle, Knight, about the coles for his majestie; and that the answer of Sir Thomas was, that he could not afford them under 3d the bowle, water measure, 21 bowles to a chalder."—"The maior and burgesses are to paie three halfe-pence the chalder (plainly by mistake for bowle), and his majestie, his excellency and the governor, the other three half-pence."
Mention occurs ibid. November 6th following, of a colliery about to be wrought upon the Town-Moor.—This was not the first coal-mine that was opened on this extensive common. Leland speaks of coal-pits in his time at Cowhill, or Cowmore, half a mile out of Newcastle..

February 8th, 1647Journals of the Commons, vol. v. Whitelock, in his Memorials, calls this five shil∣lings per chaldron., there was an order of parliament to continue the imposition of four shillings per chaldron on coals shipped coast-ways, till the 25th of March following: this was entirely taken off on the 13th of April that same yearJournals of Commons, ut supra..

There was an order of the common-council of Newcastle, dated January 27th, 1648, that the coal custom of strangers should be so re∣duced, that they might be encouraged to trade thither as formerlyCommon-council books.—"May 21st, 1648," says Whitelock, "it was referred to the council of state, to prevent the ingrossing of coals from Newcastle.".

July 17th, 1648, the Commons in parliament confirmed an impost of four shillings per chaldron on coals and grindstones, and on every weigh of salt from Newcastle, Sunderland and Blyth
Common-council books.—See also Journals of the House of Commons.
There is the following account in Grey's MSS. "August 1st, 1648, by an extraor∣dinary storm of wind and rain, two of the best collieries in the Were were drowned."
See Rushworth's Coll. vii.—1219..

In the winter of 1648, coals were so excessively dear in London, that many of the poor died for want of firing. Sir Arthur Hasilrigge, the governor of Newcastle, was blamed on this occasion, for laying a tax
of four shillings per chaldron on the coals at that town, estimated, says Walker, at 50,000l. per annumWalker's History of Independancy, part ii. p. 151.. May 16th, 1649, the House of CommonsJournals of the House of Commons.—Mention occurs August 10th this year, in the common-council books of Newcastle, concerning a convoy to the ships in the coal trade, the northern coast being infested with Pickaroons.—Whitelock's Memorials. referred an inquiry into this matter to the Council of State; recommending it at the same time to a committee of the navy, to in∣quire into the twelve-pence per chaldron on coals, and how it might be taken off.
The imposition of four shillings per chaldron was entirely set aside by a resolution of the House of Commons, made on the 11th of Sep∣tember followingJournals of the Commons, vol. vi..
Grey's account, in his Chorographia, of the coal trade of Newcastle, about A. D. 1649, is well worth transcribing:
"There come sometimes into this river for coales, three hundred sayles of ships." P. 19.

"Many thousand people are imployed in this trade of coales: many live by working of them in the pits: many live by conveying them in waggons and waines to the river Tine: many men are employed in conveying the coales in keeles from the stathes aboard the ships: one coal merchant imployeth five hundred or a thousand in his works of coals: yet, for all of his labour, care, and cost, can scarce live of his trade: nay, many of them hath consumed and spent great estates, and dyed beggars. I can remember one of many that raysed his estate by coale trade: many I remember that hath wasted great estates." P. 24, 25.

—"Some South gentlemen have upon great hope of benefit come into this country to hazard their monies in coale-pits—Master Beau∣mont, a gentleman of great ingenuity and rare parts, adventured into our mines with his thirty thousand pounds; who brought with him many rare engines not known then in these parts; as the art to boore
with iron rodds, to try the deepnesse and thicknesse of the coale; rare engines to draw water out of the pits; waggons with one horse to carry down coales from the pits to the stathes to the river, &c. Within few years he consumed all his money, and rode home upon his light horse."

"The coale trade began not past four-score years since: coales in former times was only used by smiths, and for burning of lime: woods in the south parts of England decaying, and the city of London, and other cities and townes growing populous, made the trade for coale in∣crease yearely, and many great ships of burthen built, so that there was more coales vented in one yeare, then was in seven yeares, forty yeares by past: This great trade hath made this towne to flourish in all trades." P. 26.

February 12th, 1650, there was an order of the common-council of Newcastle, to enforce the payment of an impost of three-pence per chaldron received on all coals in the chamber of that townCommon-council books..

March 3d following, the Trinity-House of Newcastle made a reso∣lution to maintain their claim to three-pence per chaldron received by them from time immemorial, of the hostmen, for their free parts of ships; and which the mayor and common-council, by the above order, were for taking away from them, to add to the revenue of the cor∣porationTrinity-House books..

April 4th, 1650, an act for laying an imposition on coals towards the building of ships for guarding the seas, was first read in the House of Commons, but did not pass till March 28th, 1651Journals of the House of Commons..
In the year 1653, the coal-trade appears to have been greatly an∣noyed by the Dutch men of warWhitelock's Memorials..
March 25th, 1653, an ordinance was published for continuing the imposition upon coals for the building of ships; as was another for the like purpose on the 18th of April followingIbid..
November 14th, 1653, articles appear to have been exhibited against the town of Newcastle, concerning the coal-tradeHostmen's books..
August 25th, 1654, mention occurs of a mutiny among the keel∣men at Newcastle for the increase of wagesWhitelock's Memorials..
The port of Sunderland by the sea occurs at this time as beginning to be of great importanceAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. ii. p. 94..

In the year 1655 coals are said to have been sold at London for above twenty shillings per chaldron.—About three hundred and twenty keels appear to have been employed at this time in the coal-trade upon the river Tyne, each of which carried eight hundred chaldrons, New∣castle measure, on board the ships. To adjust the difference of mea∣sures, it must be noted, that one hundred and thirty-six chaldrons, Newcastle measure, are equal to two hundred and seventeen London measureIbid. p. 96..

March 17th, 1655Hostmen's books., the hostmen made an act for taking one shil∣ling lighterage for every chalder of coals put on board of any ship be∣low a place called the Javil-Tree, in the river Tyne; but on the 17th of April, 1656, the Lord Protector Oliver, and the council, ordered the hostmen of Newcastle to permit the ships that traded thither for coals, to lade at the usual ratesBourne's History of Newcastle upon Tyne..
At this time coals, which two years before had been vended on the river Tyne at ten shillings, were sold at twelve shillings the chalderHostmen's books..

FebruaryBooks of that society. 23d, 1658, occurs a petition of the merchants-adven∣turers of Newcastle to parliament, against the custom of all coals transported, having been let to Mr. Martin Nowel, whom they charged therein with great acts of injustice and dishonesty.

This appears to have been let to the above Nowel, at 22,000l. a year, of which sum, 19,783l. 14s. 8d. were for the coals of England, and 2,216l. 5s. 4d. for those of ScotlandJournals of the House of Commons..

In July, 1658, commissioners were appointed by the lord protector under the great seal of England, for the measuring of keels; which they appear to have done in a new and better manner than had been used before that timeHostmen's books..

August 17th, 1658, a project for charking sea-coals by Sir John Winter, appears to have been in agitation, but it came to nothingAnonymous authority.—"August 17th, 1658, Sir John Winter had a project of charking of sea-coal, whereby it became as sweet fuell as wood or charcoal, and he sent some of it with a new-fashioned grate to several great men for a tryal, but it came to nothing.".

June 21st, 1659, the hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne were called upon, by order of the committee for preventing abuses in monopolies, to answer the complaints exhibited against them by Ralph Gardiner, Esq
Hostmen's books.
February 11th, 1659, an original instrument of this date is in the possession of Thomas Davidson, Esq of Newcastle upon Tyne, intitled "An Exemplification of a Grant of Benwell Colliery to William Scriven, and Philip Eden, Esqrs.
The exemplification is dated 4th of Queen Ann.
July 18th, 1660, the House of Commons agreed to the alterations brought in of the rates for sea-coal exported by Englishmen in vessels of that nationJournals of the House of Commons, vol. viii..

December 20th, 1660, a warrant was granted from the lord trea∣surer, for the payment of the shilling per chaldron
March 12th, 1600-1 King Charles II. let to farm the twelve-pence per chaldron on coals, granted by the hostmen of Newcastle to Queen Elizabeth, to Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott, their executors, administrators and assigns, for 31 years from Christmas-Day 1660, under the yearly rent of 1836l. 12s. 6d.
November 26th, 1661, King Charles granted to Sir Thomas Clarges, Knight, and his heirs and successors for ever, an annuity of 500l. out of the above rent for the twelve-pence per chaldron. on coals that had
been granted to Queen Elizabeth by the hostmen, to Lord Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott, Baronets, or their deputies; and the next day a warrant was signed by the above Lord Mordaunt, &c. to William Johnson, Esq alderman of NewcastleHostmen's books..

January 4th, 1661, the hostmen of Newcastle appear to have had intentions of balancing the coal-trade of Newcastle with that of Sun∣derland, by procuring a shilling per chaldron, to be laid also upon coals exported from SunderlandIbid. In the Journals of the Commons, 11th March, 1662, the proviso for an im∣position of the same custom and rate upon Sunderland coals to his majesty that is paid for Newcastle coals is referred to a committee..

January 20th, 1662, an order was made by the hostmen of New∣castle, to oppose the laying on of three-pence per chaldron on coals, having received information that endeavours were using to confirm their payment thereof by act of parliament
Hostmen's books.
March 7th, 1662, the hostmen made an order, "That head-fitters, inhabitants of Sand-Gate, might take in oasts in their own houses between six o'clock at night, and six in the morning, and not elsewhere without the walls of the town."—Ibid..

April 7th, 1662, mention occurs of a petition then framing by the wood-mongers, ship-masters, and others, to be presented to the council against the hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne for vending coalsHostmen's books..

August 20th, 1662, a petition, signed by two thousand colliers, in order to be presented to his majesty, occurs; in this they complained of the wrongs done them by the coal owners and overmen; a redress of grievances however prevented it from being sentIbid..

It was provided by the act for trade, 1663, 15 Car. II. cap. 7. that "coals transported in English shipping and navigation for his ma∣jesty's plantations, in lieu of all custom, shall pay only for one chaldron of Newcastle measure one shilling and eight-pence; for one chaldron
of London measure one shilling, provided good security be given for landing the said coals accordinglyMolloy de Jure maritimo.."

In the Journals of the House of Commons, June 4th, 1663, New∣castle coals at twelve-pence per chaldron for the inland vent only, then at lease for 1836l. 12s. 6d. per annum, are reported to be worth 8000l. full valueVolume viii..

By an act made A. D. 1664, and 1665, the weight and measure of coals were adjusted in London, where justices of peace were impowered to set a price on themSee Index to Statutes, "Coals, 16 and 17 Car. II. c. 2.".

May 8th, 1666, the hostmen of Newcastle upon Tyne laid an impost of one penny a chaldron upon coals cleared at the Custom-House of that town, for the support of workmen laid off work; the collieries being all laid in, great quantities of coals being already wrought, and not sold by reason of the warHostmen's books..
January 15th, 1667, coals appear to have been sold at an excessive price, for want of convoys to LondonJournals of the House of Commons, vol. viii..

September 20th that year the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne made an order, that the custom of sending coals by way of presents to their friends in London should thenceforth be discon∣tinuedCommon-council books..

December 16th, 1667, the parliament made an order, that the price of coals, till the 25th of March following, should not exceed thirty shillings per chaldronJournals of the House of Commons, vol. ix..

By an act of parliament made that year after the great fire of Lon∣don, a duty of twelve-pence per chaldron was granted to the lord mayor, &c. of that city to enable them to rebuild it, and which was
to continue till A. D. 1677; but this not being found sufficient, it was made three shillings a chalder, and to continue till 1687
See Index to the Statutes at Large, "Coals." A duty of twelve-pence a chaldron given to the city of London, 19 Car. II. c. 3, sect. 36; 22 Car. II. c. 11, sect. 38.
For the building, finishing and adorning of St. Paul's church, there was given by par∣liament, an imposition charged on sea-coal imported at the port of London, viz. of two shillings per chaldron or tun, from the 1st of May, 1670, to the 24th of June, 1677, and three shillings per chaldron from the 24th of June, 1677, to the 29th of September, 1687: and three-fourths of the money raised by the former, and one half of the money raised by the latter act, was to be employed towards the rebuilding of fifty-two parish-churches; one-fourth of the sum appropriated for the parish-churches was to be applied towards the rebuilding of St. Paul's.
Again, by another act of parliament 1 James II. chap. 15, an imposition on coals of eighteen-pence per chaldron or tun, was granted, to continue from the 29th of September, 1687, to the 29th of September, 1700, two-thirds whereof was applied towards the carry∣ing on the building of this church.—New View of London, vol. ii. p. 456..

By an act of parliament of the 25 Car. II. c. 6, A. D. 1672, a wise regulation was made for the encouragement of the exportation of our own product and manufactures, viz. the taking off aliens duty upon all the native commodities, coals only excepted, and manufactures of England, exported by foreigners; thereby putting them on a level with English subjectsAnderson's Dictionary of Commerce, vol. ii. p. 150..

September 2d, 1674, the hostmen of Newcastle endeavoured to pro∣cure an act of parliament, to regulate the great abuses and exactions upon the collieries for their way-leaves and staith-roomsHostmen's books. Lord Keeper Guilford, who was down on the northern circuit A. D. 1676, tells us, in his Observations on the Collieries, &c. about Newcastle; "Another thing that is remarkable is their way-leaves; for when men have pieces of ground between the colliery and the river, they fell leave to lead coals over their ground; and so dear, that the owner of a rood of ground will expect 20l. per annum for this leave." —North's Life of Lord Keeper Guilford..

April 16th, 1675, the same body occur as proposing to Lord Wid∣drington, to furnish his majesty with twenty-seven thousand tens of coal upon good security, at the rate of eleven shillings per chaldronHostmen's books. September 15th, 1676, the keelmen petitioned the hostmen for increase of wages..

A. D. 1675, King Charles the Second let to farm to Viscountess Mordaunt, a third part of the shilling per chaldron upon coals, for thirty-one years, at the annual rent of 612l. 17s. 6d. to commence at the expiration of the term granted to Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah WhichcottCollected from an authenticated or office copy of the original grant, on stamped paper, in the possession of the hostmen's company. Communicated by Alexander Adams, Esq steward.—See Appendix..

December 18th, 1677, the King granted to his natural son, Charles, Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and failing him and his heirs, to Louise, Duchess of Portsmouth, and the heirs of her body, the rever∣sion of the twelve-pence per chaldron on coals, the said twelve-pence per chaldron, the rent of 1836l. 12s. 6d. as also the above rent of 612l. 17s. 6d. yet subject to an annuity of five hundred pounds, to Sir Thomas Clarges, his heirs and assigns, at a yearly reserved rent of 1l. 6s. 8d.
Ibid.
There is a private act of the 30 Geo. II. c. 10, for varying and postponing certain limitations, in a grant made by King Charles II. of a duty on coals shipped in the rivet Tyne, to Charles, late Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and for enabling the present Duke of Richmond, Lenox and Aubigny, to make a jointure on his intended marriage with Lady Mary Bruce, A. D. 1757.—See Appendix.
Sir William Petty, in his Political Arithmetick, remarking on the increase of com∣merce in England, from the year 1636, to 1676, has the following passage: "The (coal) shipping of Newcastle is now about eighty thousand tons, and could not then be above a quarter of that quantity; first, because London is doubled in people: secondly, because the use of coals is at least doubled; they being heretofore seldom used in cham∣bers, as now they are; nor were there so many bricks burnt with them as of late; nor did the country on both sides the Thames make use of them as now."

In the year 1679 there was a design in agitation to renew the hostmen's charter; but they were opposed by a petition to the King from the twelve mysteries of Newcastle, and nothing was effectedBooks of the taylors' company in Newcastle.—Also hostmen's books, ibid..

A. D. 1682, the hostmen of Newcastle made an order, that no one in future who was free of any of the mysteries of that town, otherwise
than by patrimony or servitude, should be admitted to the freedom of their society, unless by particular favourHostmen's books.—October 3d, 1682, the hostmen made an order to pay ten pounds per annum to the schoolmaster of St. Ann's chapel (in Sandgate, where most of the keel∣men reside), for the instruction of poor scholars and children.—Ibid..

January 4th, 1683, the said hostmen ordered a warrant to be pro∣cured from the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, to seize coals that came into that port for Color-Coats, or otherwise, contrary to the act 21 Hen. VIII. or upon the custom foreign bought or soldIbid. April 25th, 1684, great complaints occur, ibid. of ships loading at the Low Lights..

A. D. 1685, there were so many foreign-built ships used in the coal-trade, and ship-building was reduced to so low an ebb at Newcastle upon Tyne, and other ports of the kingdom, that it was thought ne∣cessary that a duty of five shillings per ton should be laid this year upon all foreign-built shipping
"For the encouragement of ship-building, greatly decayed in Newcastle, Hull, Yar∣mouth, Ipswich, and other ports of England on the eastern coasts, occasioned chiefly by the so much employing of foreign-built ships in the coal-trade (this is far from being so in our days), and other inland or coasting trades: there was a duty of five shillings per ton laid on all such shipping, in this first year of King James the Second, by act of par∣liament (chap 18), one-half thereof to be for the use of the chest of Chatham, and the other to the corporation of Trinity-House, towards the relief of wounded and decayed seamen, their widows and children."—Anderson on Commerce.
A. D. 1686, 1687, King James II. sent two letters to the hostmen of Newcastle, re∣quiring them, by the first, to enfranchise Sir William Creagh, Knight; and by the second, to make him free of their society in the most ample manner. They received similar mandates from the same king, to enfranchise John and Thomas Errington, of Beau∣front, Gentlemen. They were all disfranchised after the King's abdication.—Books of the hostmen..

May 6th, 1689, a petition was presented to the House of Commons by the owners of ships, and traders in coals to and from Newcastle, Sunderland, &c. against a farther imposition on coals. It was referred to a committee of the whole houseJournals of the House of Commons, vol. x..

April 23d, 1690, a petition was presented to parliament from the hostmen of Newcastle, for leave to bring in a bill for setting reasonable prices on staith-rooms, and way-leaves, which was granted themIbid. This appears to have been attempted again February 24th, 1695, but it should seem with no better effect than before..

December 2d, 1690, great complaints were made in the House of Commons concerning the high prices of coals, setting forth that the poor were in danger of perishing for want of firing; on which a petition was presented by some persons, for leave to make a bank of coals within London and Westminster, and to ensure the traders to New∣castle against pirates, and the dangers of the seasJournals of Commons, vol. x..

December 20th, 1690, mention of his majesty's royal assent occurs to an act for reviving a former act for regulating the measures and prices of coals
Ibid.
In the year 1690 the hostmen of Newcastle made an order, that the custom of git coals at London should be wholly laid aside..

A. D. 1693, the coal-trade of Newcastle suffered great interruption, the keelmen there being afraid to work on account of an impress for seamen, concerning which the hostmen complained to the members of parliament for that town
Books of the hostmen.
A. D. 1694, for the increase of the fund for the orphans of freemen of the city of London (among other things), four-pence per chaldron for metage on coals imported; and six-pence more per chaldron or ton, for fifty years from Michaelmas, 170 was granted, to be collected in the same manner as by the act of the 19th of Charles II. rebuilding London.—See Index to Statutes, "Coals," 23.
A D. 1695, the hostmen of Newcastle sent up a congratulatory address to the King, on the prevention of an horrid conspiracy against his royal person.
A. D. 1697, the mayor of Newcastle granted a warrant to four persons to seize on coals, grind-stones, and sub-stones, sold by foreigners, i. e. those not free of the town and hostmen's company..

February 5th, 1694, a bill was brought into parliament for mea∣suring the keels and boats at Newcastle by a dead weight, which was
opposed by a petition of several owners and masters of ships in the coal-trade.

March 6th, 1695, leave was granted to bring a bill into parliament for the better measurement of keels and keel-boats at Newcastle; it was ordered to be engrossed March 21st following.—See Index of Statutes, "Coals."

March 12th, 1695, five shillings per chaldron were ordered by par∣liament to be laid on coals, thirty-six bushels to the chaldron, Win∣chester measure; and also five shillings per ton on all coals exported from Scotland, over and above the then duties. See Index to Statutes, "Coals." Also allowance of seamen to coal-ships free from impres∣sing. Ibid.

January 9th, 1696, a petition of owners of ships was brought into parliament against the above bill, wherein they set forth, that, by a storm in September last, they lost near two hundred sail of ships, worth upwards of two hundred thousand pounds.
February 19th, 1696, leave was granted to bring a bill into par∣liament, to settle the rents of way-leaves and coal-wharfs; which, however, was not presented till December 11th, 1696.
An engrossed bill for taking off the duties of tonnage upon ships and coals, was read the third time before the House of Commons, April 24th, 1696.

February 6th, 1697, the hostmen of Newcastle petitioned parlia∣ment against an intended duty upon coals, &c. imported from New∣castle, for the reparation of Whitby Piers; which they alledged was injurious to the coal-trade, and a discouragement to navigation.—Jour∣nals of the House of Commons.

In the year 1699, one thousand four hundred ships are said to have been employed in the coal-trade, exporting yearly from Newcastle
Grey's MSS. No. I. quarto. From a book printed 1699, intitled, "The Mischief of Five Shillings Tax on Coals."
Dr. Ellison's MSS. say that, in 1698, there was a quarto published, intitled, "The Mischiefs of the Fifth Tax upon Coal, by Robert Bel."
two hundred thousand chaldron of coals, Newcastle measure, in time of peace. Newcastle had at that time two-thirds of the coal-trade; three hundred thousand chaldrons in all coming annually to London. The over-sea trade in this article at the same time is said to have employed nine hundred thousand tons of shipping; so that the coal-trade made, at that period, the greatest body of English shipping.

March 2d, and 15th, 1699, petitions were presented in the House of Commons against the late imposition of live shillings per chaldron on coals, from Scarborough, Sunderland, Ipswich, and King's Lynn in Norfolk
Journals of the Commons, vol. xii. and xiii.
December 8th, 1699, accounts of the monies accruing from the new duty on coals from Michaelmas, 1698, to the same time in 1699, occur as follow in the Journals of the House of Commons.
Account of customs from Michaelmas 1697 to 1698.
£. s. d.
New duty on coals to the 15th of May, 1698 37,887 0 3 London
16,058 1 5 Out-ports
From 15th of May, 1698 85,123 1 1 London
30,184 6 4¼ Out-ports."
.

It appears from an account of the coal-trade, printed in 1701, that at that time the best coals in the pool of London sold for eighteen shillings, or eighteen shillings and three-pence per chaldron; out of which, seven shillings and two-pence were to be deducted, i. e. five shillings to the King, one shilling and sixpence to St Paul's, and one shilling and sixpence metage; and that at Newcastle good coals sold at four pounds, or four guineas the keel, which keel made fifteen chaldron in the pool of London
Povey's Unhappiness of England as to Trade.
November 13th, 1700, the hostmen of Newcastle made an order, that fitters in future should have only six-pence per chalder on coal..

February 27th, 1702, a petition from the coal-owners in the north of England concerning the decay of the salt trade, by which, to their great detriment, they lost the means of disposing of their small coals,
was presented to parliament. This was backed by another of similar import from the salt-makersJournals of the House of Commons, vol. xiii..

November 7th, 1702, on an inquiry in the House of Commons concerning the excessive price of coals within the bills of mortality, it appeared to have been occasioned by the high wages paid to sailorsIbid. vol. xiv..

A. D. 1703, upon an inquiry of a committee of the House of Com∣mons appointed to receive proposals, and prepare heads of a bill for the increase of seamen, and the speedy manning of the royal navy, sent to the masters of the Trinity-House of Newcastle, concerning the number of ships, &c. necessary for the coal-trade: they were answered by that fraternity, that six hundred ships, one with another, each of eighty Newcastle chaldron, with four thousand five hundred men, were re∣quisite for the carrying on of that great branch of commerce. "A num∣ber," they added, "both of ships and men, that had been engaged therein for three years last past." Coals occur at this time as sold at eleven shillings per chaldron at Newcastle
Trinity-House books.
In the MS. Life of Barnes, written about the beginning of the eighteenth century, oc∣curs the following passage: "Trade of sea-coals, wherein there are sometimes three, four, or five hundred sail in one fleet employed to London, which city, at six and thirty bushels a chaldron, takes off from Newcastle 600,000 chaldrons a year.".

February 24th, 1704, mention occurs in the Journals of the House of Commons, of the Lords having given their assent to an act for the increase of seamen, and security of the coal-tradeJournals of the Commons..
There appear to have been employed this year four hundred keels in the river Tyne, and between fifteen and sixteen hundred keelmenDr. Ellison's MSS..

From Christmas 1704, to the year 1710, there appear to have been exported from Newcastle, communibus annis, 178,143 chaldrons of
coals; and from the port of Sunderland in the same time, 65,760 chaldrons and a halfDr. Ellison's MSS..

By a resolution of the House of Commons, made January 18th, 1706, the duties appointed by an act of the first year of Queen Ann's reign, to continue till the 15th of May, 1708, were ordered to be farther continued from that term, till the 30th of September, 1710Journals of the Commons, vol. xv..

February 4th, 1706, a fruitless attempt was made to rid the hostmen of Newcastle of the duty of twelve-pence per chaldron, which had been granted by that society to Queen Elizabeth, and her succes∣sors, kings and queens of England, for everHostmen's books..
A. D. 1707, an over-sea duty of three shillings per chaldron was laid on coals by 6 Ann. c. 22.
A. D. 1709, an additional duty was laid upon coals, 8 Ann. c. 4.
— On coals exported in British ships taken off, 8 Ann. c. 13, sect. 15.
A. D. 1710, an additional duty upon coals, 9 Ann. c. 6, sect. 8.
— Coals carried from Stirling to Dunbar exempted, 8 Ann. c. 4. sect. 39—9 Ann. c. 6, sect. 10.—Index to Statutes, "Coals."
In the spring of the year 1710, the coal-trade at Newcastle was for some time put a stop to by a mutiny of the keelmen of that portDr. Ellison's MSS..
A. D. 1710, a duty was laid on coals for building fifty churches, 9 Ann. c. 22.
— Coals exported from the west of Scotland to Ireland, &c. were charged with the same duties as coals from the west of England to Ireland, 9 Ann. c. 22, sect. 90.
Combinations of coal-owners, &c. prohibited, 9 Ann. c. 28.
— Regulations of the several branches of the coal-trade, 9 Ann. c. 28.

1 Geo. I. c. 26, sect. 1, a duty imposed upon exported coals, 9 Ann.
c. 6, sect. 5—12 Ann. stat. 2, c. 9, sect. 9—30 Geo. II. c. 19, sect. 28, made perpetual by 1 Geo. III. c. 7, and part of general fund.—Index to Statutes, "Coals."
March 6th, 1711, a bill received the royal assent for reviving, con∣tinuing, and appropriating certain duties upon coals, &c. to be water borne, and carried coastways.

A. D. 1711, 9 Ann. cap. 28, an act passed to dissolve the present, and prevent future combinations of coal-owners and others, to advance the price of coalsLords' Journals, vol. xix.—June 12th, received the royal assent..
A. D. 1713, coals exported to Ireland, Isle of Man, or plantations excepted, 12 Ann. stat. 2, c. 9, sect. 9.
The contents of the coal bushel were ascertained 12 Ann. stat. 2, c. 17, sect. 11.—Index to Statutes, "Coals."

August 27th, 1715, by a resolution of the House of Commons, the duty of three shillings for every chalder or tun of coals and culm (by an act 9 Ann. to have continued till 28th September, 1724) was to be farther continued till 28th September, 1725Journals of Commons, vol. xviii..
March 27th, 1716, great complaints occur in the House of Com∣mons concerning the heavy duties on coalsIbid..

April 17th, 1716, a petition was presented to parliament from the mayor and common-council of Newcastle, against the oppressions of the coal-trade
Ibid.
A curious and particular account of the monies collected by duties on coal, for the building of St. Paul's church in London, from October 1st, 1668, to May 15th, 1716, is preserved in the Antiquarian Repertory, vol. ii. p. 40, &c..

By an act of the 5th of George the First, c. 9, sect. 13, A. D. 1719, lottery annuities were granted upon the coal-duties, and, by section 42 of the same, the surplus was to be disposed of by parliament.

Also by the same c. 19, the duties imposed on coals by 8 of Ann, c. 4, were made perpetual, and part of South Sea fund
Index to Statutes, "Coals."
There still remains a remarkably large arch standing over Causey-Burn, near Tanfield, in the county of Durham, which appears to have been finished, after having once fallen in for want of weight A. D. 1727. It was built by a country mason for a waggon-way to a colliery of the late Lord Ravensworth, which was set on fire, and has been long un∣wrought. It is said to have cost 1200l.
The architect involved himself in many difficulties concerning it, and is reported to have destroyed himself at last from the dread of its falling a second time. The height of the arch is 21 yards—according to Randall's MSS. "the arch of the coal-bridge near Beamish is 103 feet, or 34 yards and one foot."
I copied the subsequent inscription from a sun-dial on this stupendous arch.
"Ra. Wood, mason, 1727.".
A. D. 1722, 8 Geo. I. c. 14, sect. 14, there was, by authority of parliament, an exemption of coals carried from Ellen-Foot to Bank-EndIndex to Statutes, "Coals.".
A. D. 1727, 13 Geo. I. c. 21, application was made by the same of the surplus of the coal-dutyIndex to Statutes, "Coals.".

A. D. 1730, 3 Geo. II. c. 26, it was enacted, that dealers in coals should not use their own lighters on the Thames—that dealers should not act as crimps—that there should be a penalty on receiving premium for contracts for coals—that forms should be prescribed for contracts and notes for coals—that there should be a penalty on masters of ships refusing to account—and on lightermen, &c. delivering coals without the ingram: as also that sacks and other coal-measures should be marked3 Geo. II. c. 26, sect. 3, 4, 6, &c. 9, 10, 11..

A. D. 1731, by an act 4 Geo. II. c. 30, a penalty was laid on masters of coal-ships keeping turn; and by the same, sect. 2, it was en∣acted that masters of colliers should deliver their cockets in four daysStatutes at Large..

February 28th, 1738, a petition was presented to the House of Commons by the glass-makers, brewers, &c. of London and West∣minster, against the excessive prices of coals, the consideration of which was referred to a committee of the whole house: and on the 14th and 15th of March following, petitions of the like purport were presented from Southwark, and from the town of Cambridge: the
above were answered by counter-petitions from the coal-owners of Durham, Sunderland and Newcastle, and the fitters of these placesFrom a MS. intitled "A Complaint about Coals.".

By an act of parliament made A. D. 1738, 11 Geo. II. c. 15, sect. 6, all coal-contracts at Billingsgate were directed to be signed and pro∣duced; and, by the 8th section of the same, it was enacted that wag∣gons at Newcastle, &c. should be measured and markedStatutes at Large..
In the month of June, 1740, there appears to have been a great riot among the colliers and keelmen at Newcastle upon TyneSee Historical Events..
A. D. 1740, 13 Geo. II. c. 21, it was enacted by the authority of parliament, that treble damages should be given for damaging col∣lieries by water.
A. D. 1741, 14 Geo. II. c. 41, sect. 3, a drawback was granted of the duty on coals used in fire-engines, for drawing the tin and copper mines in Cornwall.
Sept. 17th, 1741, complaints occur in parliament concerning the coal-tradeHostmen's books..
A. D. 1744, 17 Geo. II. c. 35, justices of peace were allowed to regulate the retail price of coals.
A. D. 1746, 19 Geo. II. c. 35, the land coal-meters' office for Westminster was erected.
By an act of parliament made 1749, 22 Geo. II. c. 37, it was enact∣ed that ships having exported coals, were not to be cleared out till the duty was paid.
By the same 22 Geo. II. c. 37, sect. 3, a penalty was laid on ships exporting coals that were entered coastwise.

A. D. 1750, there was a great riot among the keelmen of Newcastle, which cost the hostmen there a considerable sum of moneyIbid.—November 20th, 1749, this fraternity made an order to repeal a former one, dated July 2d, 1742, resolving thenceforth to admit any person free of the mysteries ac∣cording to the charter of James I. By another order on the same subject, dated May 22d, 1751, it was enacted that each mystery man, coming to be admitted a free hostman, should bring a certificate under the hands of the clerk or stewards of such mystery.—Ibid..
By an act of parliament, 23 Geo. II. c. 26, a penalty was laid on principal land coal-meters neglecting to station labouring coal-meters as directed by 19 Geo. II. c. 35.

Mention occurs June 2d, 1753, of a machine invented by Michael Meinzies, Esq (for which he had obtained an act of parliament to secure the property thereof to himself) by which coals were drawn up, not by the strength of horses or of men, but by the descent of a bucket full of water, of a weight superior to that of the coals drawn up, lifting a corf of above 600lb. weight out of a pit 50 fathoms deep, in two minutesNewcastle Courant.—It is mentioned as then going at Charters Haugh, in the county of Durham, a colliery belonging to William Peaneth, Esq—"The same hands who at∣tend a common horse-gin, for drawing up coals, are sufficient to attend this machine, with this difference, that in the place of two boys who drive the horses, one man serves to con¦duct the machine, by the help of which he does the work of three shifts of horses, of two horses each. The water let down for drawing up the coals, is raised and discharged by the fire engine.—But where there is a level, there is no need to raise it again.—The parti∣cular of this machine in this work is, that as the same weight of water is drawn up at far less expence by a fire engine than by horses, so the water which draws up the coals, i raised again by far less expence than the coals would have been by horses.—The machin is extremely simple, and it is not only useful for collieries, but for mines of lead, &c. but is most useful at those collieries and mines, where they can have water at the top of the pits, and have a level at bottom.".
By an act made A. D. 1757, 30 Geo. II. c. 19, sect. 28, an ad∣ditional duty was laid on coals exportedStatutes at Large..
A. D. 1759, 32 Geo. II. c. 27, punishment for delivering coals fraudulently, was appointed by act of parliamentStatutes at Large..

In the year 1764 there were exported from the river Tyne for Lon∣don and coastways, 20,000 chaldrons of coals, London measure, and 40,000 chaldrons, like measure, for foreign parts; more than had been exported before in any one year.

The same year, 3,727 vessels were cleared out of that river for the coast, loaden with coals, and 365 for foreign parts; a greater number than ever was known beforeGyll's interleaved Bourne's History of Newcastle, p. 159..
A. D. 1765, 5 Geo. III. c. 35, sect. 1, an additional duty was laid on exported coalsStatutes at Large..

In the year 1766 there was an act of parliament made to regulate the loading of ships with coals in the ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, to take place after the 1st of June, for seven years
Ibid.
April 30th, 1768, mention occurs of what is called "a stick" in the language of the coal-trade, that is, a combination among the keelmen at Newcastle. This mischief is said to have been occasioned by "the large quantity of coal conveyed by the keelmen above the King's measure, and contrary to the regulations of the dues in this respect.".
The subsequent is an accurate account of the state of the coal-trade about A. D. 1772:
3,585 ships, 689,090 tons, 330,200 chaldrons of coals (with 123,370 hundred weight of lead) for the coast trade.
And 363 ships, 49,124 tons, 21,690 chaldrons of coals (with 30,064 cwt. of lead) to foreign partsPennant's Tour, vol. iii. p. 311, from Hutton's Plan of Newcastle upon Tyne..

An act of parliament passed A.
