D. 1773, to continue an act made in the 6th of George the Third, intitled, An Act to regulate the loading of ships with coals in the ports of Newcastle and Sunderland, for a further term of seven years, and from thence to the end of the next session of parliamentStatutes at Large..

The subsequent account of the coal-trade for six years, on an average, to the Christmas of 1776, was communicated by a respectable officer of the custom-house of Newcastle
Mr. Robert Page, deputy comptroller.
"The weight of these at 53 cwt. per chalder, is one million seven thousand tons. The duty paid to the crown at the ports of discharge on 351,000 chaldrons, at 5s. per chaldron, Winchester measure, is 1670l."
—"A medium of six years revenue to the Duke of Richmond, 17,550l.—One of these years was 9,000l. and upwards."
Hutchinson, in his View of Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 417, says, "the customs for coal (at Newcastle) exported, on an average, amount to 40,000l. or thereabouts annually, exclusive of one shilling a chaldron paid to the Duke of Richmond for coals sent coast∣ways, which brings in a yearly income of 15,000l. or more.".
To London, and other ports of Great Britain, 351,000 chaldrons of coals (of which 260,000 to London); to the British colonies and plantations 2,000 chaldrons; to foreign parts 27,000.

In all 380,000 chaldrons, Newcastle measure, per annum
See the tables communicated to Mr. Hutchinson for his View of Northumberland, vol. ii. (ad finem) by Joseph Fell, Esq surveyor of the customs of Newcastle upon Tyne, where, under A. D. 1776, occur:
"14,000 chaldron of coals exported from Blyth.
18,000 ditto, from Hartley Haven.
350,803 ditto, from Newcastle upon Tyne, coastwise." .

A. D. 1777, the wages for each able-bodied seaman for a voyage in a coal-ship to London, were fixed at 3l. 10s
From a printed hand-bill, dated January 25th, 1777, purporting that "at a meeting of the owners, masters and commanders of ships and vessels belonging to the port of New∣castle upon Tyne, it was unanimously agreed not to give more than 3l. 10s. to each and every able seaman for a coal voyage to London, during the continuance of impressing sea∣men."
A. D. 1778, mention occurs of a new-constructed machine for drawing coals by water, set up at Willington colliery, near Newcastle upon Tyne, drawing up from the depth of one hundred and one fathoms, thirty corves, containing each 20 pecks, in one hour. Newcastle Courant, November 14th, 1778..

In the beginning of the year 1780, it was proposed to lay an ad∣ditional duty of four shillings per chaldron on exported coals
When among the new taxes in the House of Commons, March 15th, 1780, an ad∣ditional duty of four shillings was proposed to be laid on exported coals, Sir Thomas Clavering, one of the members for the county of Durham, complained much of it, and said it would drive away the trade of Newcastle and Sunderland, to Scotland.
Lord North, in his apology for this intended tax, alleged that it was not fit that our enemies should burn our coals cheaper than we do ourselves; and added, that the duty arising from thence would produce annually the sum of 12,899l.
March 20th, 1780, a petition from the coal-owners in Newcastle, &c. against the above clause in Lord North's budget, was sent up by express to London, in order to be presented to the House of Commons.
April, 25th, 1780, his lordship informed the committee, that he had dropped the above design, finding it would not be so productive a tax as he had expected..

This year died at Gateshead, Baron van Haake, a native of Silesia, who had come thither for the purpose of extracting tar from coalNewcastle Courant, January 22d, 1780. The following advertisement occurs, ibid. Sept. 22d, 1782: "To be sold by auction, by order of the assignees of Messrs. William and John Chapman, bankrupts—(inter alia) Also the two fifth shares of the benefit of certain letters patent, granted to the Earl of Dundonald, for the exclusive exercise in the kingdoms of Great-Britain and Ireland, of his invention for extracting pitch, tar, essen∣tial oils, mineral acids, volatile alkalies, and cinders from pit-coal; with two fifth shares of certain tar-kilns now erected.".
July 7th, 1781, mention occurs of a machine to draw coals, as newly invented by Mr. Jos. OxleyNewcastle Courant.—Set up at Hartley colliery in the vicinity of Newcastle..

May 17, 1782, the royal assent was given by commission to an act to revive and continue an act passed in the 6th of Geo. III. intitled, "An Act to regulate the loading of ships with coals, in the ports of Newcastle and Sunderland
London papers.
In one quarter of the year 1782, five hundred and eighty-four keelmen took out pro∣tections to avoid being impressed to go on board of his majesty's ships of war, at the town-clerk's office at Newcastle; as did, the next quarter, seven hundred and ninety-eight of the same body:—many infirm keelmen, and those above and under age to be pressed, took out no protections.—Communicated by Mr. Robinson, of the town-clerk's office.."

For a collection of notices concerning the art of, and curious machines and contrivances used in working coal-mines, see Appendix—where there is also a translation of the charter of the hostmen's company, with a list of the governors of that fraternity.

DIV2.HEAD: TWELVE COMPANIES, CALLED MISTERIESA copper-plate print of the several coats of arms belonging to the different companies of Newcastle upon Tyne, was published there A. D. 1776, by William Whitehead and Thomas Jameson, dedicated to the mayor, aldermen, sheriff and common-council of that town.—They are copies, but not exact ones, of those of the societies of London in Stowe's Survey of that city.. MISTERIES.
DIV2.P:
THE word mistery is plainly derived from "mestiere," in modern French "metier," a trade. "In England," says Madox, in his Firma
Burgi, p. 32, "men have been told that in regard there is some mys∣tery in every trade, therefore a trade is called a mystery; but it must be remembered, that there is no affinity either in the nature of the thing, or in proper language, between , a mystery and trade. Nor is the word misterie, as applied to signify a trade or employment, of Greek or Roman extraction, but of French, or, if you please, Ro∣manick. , and the Latin mysterium, were words always used with some relation to things that were esteemed sacred, religious, or ceremonious, never concerning crafts, trades, or ordinary business, for which I refer to Lexicographers." This learned writer has sub∣joined a great variety of instances from records and otherwise, shewing that the words mestiere, mistera, and misterea, are words of Romanick original.

DIV3.HEAD: 1. Merchants of woollen cloth, alias drapers.
DIV3.P: Mention first occurs of the drapers, or merchants of woollen cloth, as one of the twelve misteries, in the ordinances for the government of Newcastle upon Tyne, which was confirmed by King Edward III. October 20th, 1342.

The oldest ordinary of this society, the original of which having affixed to it many seals and skin-marks, with names of the brethren, dated June 1st, 1512, is still preserved in their archives. It enacts that two should be chosen annually by most voices of the society, for the election of the mayor and officers of the town, at the Spital, i. e. St. Mary's hospital; that no apprentice should be taken under the term of seven years; that, on the Wednesday after the election of the mayor, they should meet at the Maison-Dieu on the sand-hill, to choose their stewards, two auditors, and for the election of the mayor for the ensuing year; and that whosoever of the fellowship should be chosen mayor, sheriff, chamberlain, or clerk of the cham∣ber, should be exempted that year from the office of auditor.

About the year 1650, a violent dissension took place between some of the merchants-adventurersBooks of the merchant-adventurers, June 21st, 1650. The drapers were one of the three members that composed the society of merchant-adventurers. of Newcastle and this fraternity; the former claiming the sole privilege of being styled merchant-drapers, and of sending two members to the election of the mayor and other officers. This seems to have ended in the exclusion of the true society, or at least of that part of them, by whom the unquestionable records of the fraternity have been transmitted
I was favoured with the perusal of them by Mr. Rutter, attorney at law, who told me that he was almost the sole representative left of the real company, who are very im∣properly called cappers, a nick-name by which they are styled in some printed poll-book although there certainly was never any such fraternity in Newcastle upon Tyne.
The following is from an original paper preserved among their records, intitled, The Drapers' Case: "The drapers have of late, as they formerly used to do, presented two for the audit, and two for the election; but they have refused to admit them, upon pretence that they are not the true company of drapers, and the mayor will not swear them to audit or elect. They who principally oppose the company of drapers, are certain tradesmen in Newcastle, who style themselves merchants-drapers, and they would have the company of drapers to be noe company, but a sort of people who traded in making up capps, and soe they call them by a nick-name, cappers.—These have of late been admitted to the auditt and election instead of the drapers, and the drapers are now thrust out as if they had never bene a company.".

Sept. 29th, 1652, an ordinary was granted to this society by the mayor, aldermen and sheriff of Newcastle upon Tyne, under the seal of the corporation, prescribing them an oath on admission: that they should meet at their ancient meeting-house, called the Maison de Dieu, every Wednesday before Michaelmas, at nine o'clock in the forenoon, to choose new wardens and pass their accounts: as also every year on the Monday after St. Bartholomew-day, at the same hour, in St. George's porch in St. Nicholas' church, to choose two auditors; that whosoever of the fraternity should be chosen to the first election, or standing elec∣tion of the mayor, &c. should preserve the dignity and priority of the company, as being first named in the charter, claiming their meet∣ing place for the company in the south corner, at the east end of the
election-house, and their chairs for the former election, next to the mayor's chair on the right-hand; as also their place in St. Nicholas' church, which was the north side in St. George's porch, under a penalty of forty shillings. That those of the company who were al∣dermen, should have priority of place at their meetings, and be re∣ceived as justices of the peace: that apprentices should serve eight years, and that no second one should be taken till the first had served four years; and that none should be taken whose father was not a freeholder, to the value of forty shillings a yearFrom the drapers' records.—They appear to have met no longer at the Maison-Dieu on the Sand-Hill, than the year 1725..

DIV3.HEAD: 2. Mercers.
DIV3.P: No ordinary or other record of this society is now to be found: a copy of their oath on admission, dated 1517, is preserved in the books of the merchants-adventurers"This here ye maister of this feloship and wardens of the craft of mercers that I shall ly and trewly observe and kepe all good rewles and acts made or shal be made by the said maister and wardens and of the moost part of the felowship of mercers &c. So help me God and holy dom and by the contents of this booke.", of which this is one of the three mem∣bers. It appears, from a copy of a warrant by the mayor of Newcastle, dated Sept. 19th, 1648, and entered in the said books, that the com∣panies of mercers and boothmen were at that time united.

In the reign of King James II. the mercers, drapers and boothmen, though distinct companies, appear to have had their meetings and assemblies as if they had been but one fraternityRecords of the butchers' company.—"Whereas the merchants consisting of mercer drapers and boothmen, though these be distinct companies in themselves, and yet have usually had their assemblies and meetings as if they were but one companie, therefore is desired that hereafter they meet severally, dividedly and apart, &c." On the proposd to alter the charter of the town in that reign..

DIV3.HEAD: 3. Skinners.
DIV3.P: The ancient ordinary of this company is dated January 20th, 1437. The names of Richard Hall, mayor, Thomas Wardell, sheriff, Roger Thornton, Robert Whelpington, Laurence Acton, Simon Weldon and William Ellerby, aldermen, occur in it.

The society were to meet on the Tuesday after Michaelmas every year, unless that festival should fall on a Monday, and then on the Tuesday seven-night following, to choose their stewards and pass their accounts. The different orders it contained, together with others of a subsequent date, were transcribed into their present order book, 1735. One of these forbade the use of tobacco at their meetings, under a penalty of 3d. for every offenceRecords of the skiners' company.—Their meeting-house is in the Black-Friars.. The skinners appear to have in∣corporated themselves with the fraternity of glovers, about the year 1703. They still keep separate books, though they have but one meet∣ing-house.

DIV3.HEAD: 4. Taylors.
DIV3.P: The oldest ordinary of this society is dated October 8th, 1536, and enjoined, that every brother at his setting up shop should pay a pot of oil to the fellowship; as also thirteen pence a year to the stewards for "our Lady light;" and that each apprentice, or person hired by the week, should pay four-pence per annum, and each hireling three-pence a year to their play when it should be performed: also that any person born a subject of the King, and free of Newcastle, might set up shop on pay ment of 40l. with a pound of wax and a pot of oil at his admit∣tance; as also 13d. to our Lady light, and 8d. to the play. That no taylor should work on Saturdays after eight o'clock in the evening, and should keep holy the Sundays, vigils and festival days, on pain of six pounds of wax for every default. That the society should pass their accounts on St. John's day in every May, and having chosen twelve electors, the said twelve should choose the tour stewards, the searchers and auditors. It further ordered, that every brother should be at the procession on Corpus Christi-day, before it passed the New-Gate, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax; and that each brother should attend in his livery. And that the common light of the fraternity should go before the corpse of every brother when it was carried to church for interment, and continue there lighted during mass time, and till it was interredArchives of the society..
I found another ordinary of this society, dated August 12th, 1624 confirmed March 2d, 1679; also September 15th, 1707—January 17th, 1731, and October 17th, 1737Archives of the society..

DIV3.HEAD: 5. Sadlers.
DIV3.P: The oldest ordinary of this society, dated March 6th, 1459, is still in their possession. It enjoins them to go together in procession in a livery, at the feast of Corpus Christi, and play their play at their own costs: and that each brother should be at the procession when his hour was assigned, under pain of 40d. That no Scotsman born should be taken apprentice, or suffered to work within the town under a penalty of 20s. It farther ordered, that no apprentice should be taken under the term of seven years, on pain of 6s. 8d.—ordering civil behaviour to each other at meetings, the observance of holidays, &c. Another ordinary of the society is dated February 4th, 1532.

DIV3.HEAD: 6. Merchants of corn, alias boothmen.
DIV3.P: No ordinary or other record of this society, considered as a separate mystery, has been transmitted, if we except a few scattered memorials preserved in the books of the merchants-adventurersThe oath of a boothman is preserved there. Nov. 7, 1566, "the scyens of boothmen" occurs..

DIV3.HEAD: 7. Bakers and Brewers.
DIV3.P: Among the articles agreed upon in full guild of the town of New∣castle upon Tyne, held at St. Mary's hospital on the Friday before Valentine-day, 1342, and confirmed by the King, October 20th that year, the following occurs: "13. The assizes of bread and beer to be held according to law.—The master bakers, and not their servants, to suffer the penalties ordained by statute. Measures, ells, and weights to be proved twice a year, or at least onceSee charters under that year in the History of Newcastle as a corporate town.."
By an inquisition taken at Newcastle upon Tyne, January 4th, 1446, it appeared that common baking and brewing for sale were restricted to that town, and no where else within the port of TyneIbid..
An old ordinary of this society, now lost, appears to have been in their possession A. D. 1583, and long afterwards, as several entries in their old books testify.

There is an ordinary of this society, dated Nov. 4th, 1661, enrol∣led in the books of the corporation, setting forth that their ancient or∣dinary was lost, and enjoining them to meet yearly on the 23d of November, unless it should fall on a Sunday, and then the day after, to elect the twelve of the society and four wardens, who were im∣powered, by the name of the wardens of the art and mystery of bakers and brewers, to prosecute, sue and implead, and be prosecuted, sued, &c. only within the courts of Newcastle upon Tyne; to make laws for the government of the society, impose fines, &c. forbidding any brother to strike another at any meeting with fist, hand, elbow, dagger, staff, stick, rod, or otherwise, on pain of twenty shillings; and ordering that no apprentice should be taken under seven years, nor a second till the first had served six years. As also that the society should attend the burials of their brethren, on pain of a penalty of three shillings and four-pence for every omissionRecords of the society..

DIV3.HEAD: 8. Tanners.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of the tanners, called anciently barkers, dated Novem∣ber 8th, 1532Ibid., enjoined the society to come yearly in their best array and apparel, at the feast of Corpus Christi, and go in procession, set forth their pageants, &c. on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax.—Not to take any Scot by birth for apprentice, under a penalty of twenty shil∣lings.—That each brother should have but one butcher to buy slaughter of, on pain of 10l. and not to buy above eight fothers of bark, or forty trees, on pain of 6s. 8d. As also to supply each other with bark, &c.

DIV3.HEAD: 9. Gordwainers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, an agreement signed by 31 brethren, is dated December 17th, 1566, mentions their meeting-house in the lately dissolved monastery of Black-Friars, and enjoins that every ap∣prentice
should serve ten years, five of which to be expired before a second could be taken; and that foreigners might be admitted into the company on payment of 5l. one half whereof to go to the fellowship, and the other to the reparation of Tyne-Bridge
From the original with the seals, in the possession of the company.
This society in 1690 met on the head-meeting-day on Firth-Hill.—This custom ceased on their repairing their present hall at the foot of the Flesh-Market. They ob∣tained the first lease of this building, then called "The House of Charitie," of the corpo∣ration of Newcastle, A. D. 1668.—See account of Black-Friars..

DIV3.HEAD: 10. Butchers.
DIV3.P: There is an inrolment of an ordinary of this society in the book of inrolments, in the archives of the Corporation of Newcastle, dated July 20th, 1621.—This enjoins them to meet every year on Ash-Wednes∣day to choose their two wardens; that apprentices should serve at least eight years, five of which to expire before a second could be taken— that no brother should be partner with any foreigners called crockers, on pain of forfeiting 5l.—that none should kill after nine o'clock on Saturday night, nor keep open shop after eight o'clock on Sunday morning; that no brother should buy, or seek any licence to kill flesh in Newcastle during Lent, without the general consent of the fel∣lowship, on pain of forfeiting 5l.—that none should kill either at Lent or any other time, within the liberties ol the High-Castle, "being in the county of Northumberland," on the like pain for each offence. But that any butcher, though not a brother, might expose good meat to sale in the market, from the hours of eight in the morning till four in the afternoonFebruary 9th, 1713, they made an order to change the day of their head-meeting from Ash Wednesday to the preceding Wednesday in every year. There is an order that no free brother should blow a calf's pluck, or any part of a calf, except calf's close-ear, nor any other goods but a cow's udder, under a penalty of 6s. 8d. unforgiven. Nov. 14th, 1726, their work-house in the Gale-Grupe occurs—called also, Nov. 1727, "the Tal∣low-House in the Gavel-Groop," for the use of the butchers' company..

DIV3.HEAD: 11. Smiths.
DIV3.P:
The oldest ordinary of this society, dated January 14th, 1436
From a copy inrolled in the book of inrolments in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle, and the originals remaining in the strong box of the society.
The following curious entries occur in their old books:
"February 10th, 1668, John Bolam for not carrying Clem. Browne to church, but giving the stang to another—fined 13s. 4d.
"1682, paid for making the seat in the Firth, 1s. 4d.
"1685, spent in the Forth-House with the twelve, the raine causeing them in, 2s.
"— (spent at the Hill-Side in wine, 2."
June 23d, 1709, order to meet no more at the "Forth-Hill" on the head-meeting-day, but at their own meeting-house.
Inscriptions on their meeting-house, the ground floor of which, once that of chapel of Black-Friars, was the scene of a remarkable state transaction, where homage was done by the Scottis King to the King of England for the kingdom of Scotland.—See Histori∣cal Events.
"This hall was repaired at the charge of the company of smiths anno 1751. Edward Gaire, Jon. Bell. Ed. Gall, Will. Hodge, wardens."
"This hall was repaired by the company of smiths anno 1770. Juo. Jopling, Robinson, Joseph Cooper, wardens.",
enjoined that they should go together in procession on the feast of Corpus Christi, and play their play at their own expence, attending at the hour appointed, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax—that every brother should be at St. Nicholas' church at the setting forth of the procession on St. Loy-day on the like penalty—that no Scotsman born "should be taken apprentice, or suffered to work, on pain of the forfeiture of 40s. half whereof to go to the chamber of the town, and the other half to the fellowship"—that no brother should sell "seyme and roffe" by weight, under 3s. 4d. a hundred, on pain of forfeiting 6s. 8d. for each offence. Another ordinary, dated Sept. 25th, 1664, exhibits the society as consisting of the dif∣ferent branches of black-smiths and farriers,—black-smiths or anchor-smiths, and lock-smiths or white-smiths. Another, dated August 17th, 1677, impowered the fraternity to be a body politic in law, enjoined them to meet yearly on St. Loy-day, to choose four wardens, of which one at least was to be an anchor-smith: that the twelve of the com∣pany should consist of four anchor-smiths, four black-smiths and far∣riers, and four lock-smiths:—to choose four searchers—that appren∣tices should serve seven years, and that no brother should come
meetings, or attend the public guild of the town, with his apron on, but with a decent cloak or coat, on pain of forfeiting 6d. for each de∣fault
"George Whinfield, Esq mayor of Newcastle, gave the sum of 20l. to be put out at interest by the stewards of this society, to two of the company, at the rate of 20s. annual interest for the whole, which interest to be paid to the poor brethren and sisters. —Each brother to keep the 10l. for three years and no longer.—Dec. 22d, 1718, the company purchased a pall for funerals.
"Margaret Stephenson, of Newcastle upon Tyne, widow, by her last will, dated October 26th, 1725, left 20l. to be lent to two young brethren of this society, 10l. each, on their re∣spective bonds, with each two sureties, to be repaid at the end of four years without in∣terest, and then again lent to others on the same conditions successively and perpetually." Books of the society..

DIV3.HEAD: 12. Fullers and DyersIn St. Nicholas' Register, Dec. 1583, mention occurs of "Roger Gray, litster"— litster signifies dyer.—See Lye's Junii Etymologicum in verbo..
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, called anciently walkers, dated May 6th, 1477
From the original in the archives of the society.
Their hall is in the Black-Friars., enacted that no brother should strain cloth upon the tentor to deliver it with the short wand, on pain of forfeiting four pounds of wax, nor tentor cloth on a Sunday, nor "wend to the walk mylne" with any raw cloth on that day, on pain of forfeiting two pounds of wax—that they should take no Scotsman born to appren∣tice, nor set any such to work under a penalty of twenty shillings, half whereof to go to the society, and half to the support of Tyne-Bridge; that no apprentice should be taken under seven years; that no brother should work carsey under 2d. the yard; that they should at∣tend the weddings and burials of the brethren in their livery; that they should meet in their livery in Carlel-Croft, on St. John's day in May, at six o'clock in the morning; and upon St. John's day at Christmas, at one o'clock in the afternoon; that none of the com∣pany should fail being at the setting forth of the procession on Corpus Christi-day, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax; and that each bro∣ther should pay 6d. to the procession and play yearly; to choose twelve
who were to be sworn and elect wardens, auditors, searchers, and the two to attend the mayor and chamber for the year; to meet on the eve of Corpus Christi-day in the morning, at six o'clock, under the penalty of a pound of wax; to walk no broad-cloth of colour under 4d. a yard, nor any wadded blue under 2d. the yard, nor any freeze under a penny halfpenny the yard, under the like penalty; to "dight" (i. e. clean) no gown under 4d. on pain of half a pound of wax; not to sheer a dozen yards of tilted cloth under 3d. on pain of two pounds of wax, or sustian under a penny the yard, or broad cloth under 3d. for the like quantity, under the penalty of forfeiting a pound of wax for each.

DIV2.HEAD: FIFTEEN COMPANIES CALLED BY-TRADES.
DIV2.P: 1. Masters and Mariners: called also the Trinity-House.

IN tracing the origin of a society, to whose good services not only the port of Tyne, but also our national commerce
The mariners of Newcastle upon Tyne are distinguished in our annals for their bravery by sea, and their gallant behaviour in the national service. A. D. 1335, they appear to have been called out on a naval expedition to Scotland, and burnt the town of Dundee.
King Edward III. by writs, dated February 6th, 1341, and February 12th, 1344, com∣manded the mayor and bailiffs of Newcastle upon Tyne, to send up to his council two of their most skilful mariners to consult with on affairs of the greatest importance to the na∣vigation of his kingdom.
A. D. 1380, in company with the mariners of Hull, they took a Scotch pirate with a cargo to the value of seven thousand marks.—Wallis's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 240; and Hollingshead—also Rymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 230 and 405.
There was preserved among the writings of the corporation, A. D. 1565, one entitled, "A commission made by one King Henry unto the mayor, for taking of mariners to serve on the sea." See afterwards under 1636, concerning pressing. in general owes very considerable obligations, we first discover them as an ancient re∣ligious, or secular guild, with the title of the "Guild, or Fraternity of the Blessed Trinity," consisting of both sexes, and founded, it is pro∣bable, by the licence of some of our former kingsMadox, in his Firma Burgi, p. 25, tells us that neither religious nor secular guilds could be set up legally without the King's licence..

January 4th, 1492, this society occurs as a corporate body, purchas∣ing by their feoffees the site of their present house, for which the ac∣knowledgment of a red rose, if demanded, was to be paid yearly at Midsummer for ever
From "a breviat of the evidences belonginge to the Trinitie-House" among their records.
I know not whether ever the representatives of Hebborn claimed this acknowledgment no mention occurs in their books concerning the payment thereof.—Bourne says (on what authority I find not, but certainly by mistake) that it was "a red rose at Christmas, which Bertram Anderson turned into wine." The acknowledgment of a pottle of wine an∣nually, was for some additional property, and continued to be paid for above a century after the grant. See under A. D. 1525..

By a writing still preserved in their archives, and dated January 4th, 1505, they ordered that, on the site of the present Trinity-House, an∣ciently called, from the name probably of a former owner, "Dalton-Place," a hall, chapel, and lodgings, for their poor brethren should be erected at their common expenceFrom records remaining at present in the possession of this house..

An original deed, dated September 9th, 1525, and preserved in the archives of the society
In this writing mention is first made of their altar or chantry, called Triniry Altar, in All-Saints church, which probably they had founded long before, on their having first become a secular guild, or fraternity: in this writing also a government by aldermen and wardens occurs in like manner as after King Henry VIIIth's charter. Their chaplain also is mentioned in it.
Frequent entries are found in their old books, of expences incurred by washing the linen used at this altar.
"1539 Item pd. for a key and washing of th' alter close, and for two towells 24d.
"1541 Item pd. for weshin the alter close in the churche — 12d."
It is very probable, notwithstanding what Bourne has advanced to the contrary, that the porch behind their late gallery in All-Saints church was, in the Popish times, their altar or chantry, which would of consecquence be suppressed at the reformation.
In 1540 their priests' salary was 4l. per annum.
"Item pd.to the prest of his waygis for 3 quarters 3l."
Yet for extraordinary duties they appear to have been at particular expence.
"1542 Item pd. to Wyllm Hette for helping the morne mess 2s."
"1545 Item pd. for fallmes and deryge 6s. 8d.
"1539 Item pd. for a deryge and pawper &c. 8s. 6d.", informs us, that Robert Hebborn, Esq
son of Ralph Hebborn, Esq of whom they had purchased, as above related, the site of their house, made over to them some additional buildings that lay on the north side thereof, and for which they were to pay yearly for ever, on the vigil of the apostles Peter and Paul in June, a pottle of wine
In their old books, 1542—also July 19th, 1630—July 29th, 1650, &c. mention oc∣curs of the payment of this wine-rent to Mr. Henry Anderson, first, and after to Mr. Ber∣tram Anderson, the successive representatives, as it should seem, of the above Hebborn.
"Item 1542, pd. for one pottell of wine for howse farme 4d."
"July 29th, 1650, paid for a pottle of brewed white wine for Bertram Anderson, due at St. Peter ve last past 2s. 7d.", if demanded, to the above Robert Hebborn, his heirs and assigns.

It appears from the entries of expences in the old books of this so∣ciety, that some privileges had eithcr been granted or confirmed to them about the year 1530
"1530 Item awyng to Thomas Bell for my lorde admyrall seyll at London 46s. 8d."
—"Item paid for sygnet and prevye seyll 4l. 6s. 8d.
"Item pd. to Kynge's Grayce for the great seayll 8l. 2s.", both by the King and the Lord Admiral, probably to enforce to them the duty of primage and pilotage, which they certainly received before the charter was granted them in A. D. 1536
In which charter is the following clause: "Provided always that the masters, pilots and governors of ships and mariners aforesaid, of the town aforesaid, may have, and every of them may have all and singular such customs, subsidies, &c. as before tyme they have had, &c."
In the year 1539, mention occurs in their books of their having charge of the buoys and cann buoys in the haven and river of Tyne.
Their poor brethren and sisters occur in their books about this time, by the title of bedefolk.
"1540 Item pd. to the bedfolk this year at serten tymes 5s. 10d.
Item paid for 20 chalder of colls to the bedfolk 17s. 4d."
They had at this time also which is still continued, a meeting on Trinity-Sunday.
"1542 Item pd. for expens. of Trinite-Sownday 8s."
The subsequent entries shew also, that, according to ancient custom, they had their fires and rejoicings on Midsummer and St. Peter's even.
1540 "Item pd. for 1 chald'. of colls to make fyer agaynst Mydfomer 10d.
"Item for expens of the Trinite ewyn, Mydsummer ewyn, and Seynt Peter's ewyn 14s. 9d.
"1552 Item pd. to the menstrells on Sant John and St. Peter's ewyn." 14s. 9d..

October 5th, 1536, King Henry VIII. granted a charter of new incorporation to this guild or fraternity, consisting at that time both of men and women, out of love to the Trinity, and to encourage the art of navigation, which society in future was to be governed by a master and four wardens, and by the name of the master and wardens of the fraternity, or guild, of the holy and indivisible Trinity, to have a com∣mon seal, implead and be impleaded, &c. with licence to build and imbattle two towers, the one at the entrance of the haven of Tyne, and the other on the hill adjoining, in each of which a light was to be maintained every night, for the support of which they were im∣powered to receive four-pence for every foreign ship, and two-pence for every English vessel, arriving at the port of TyneRecords of the society.. King Edward VI. granted them a charter of inspeximus, dated October 20th, 1548, confirming the above, but without the addition of any new privilegesIbid.: A similar charter of inspeximus was granted by Queen Mary, March 21st, 1553
Ibid.—See Appendix.
It appears by their books, that their first seal cost 2s. 8d.—a second seal August 4th, 1645, for the silver, cutting and stalk, 2l. 7s. 9d. There is an order, March 14th, 1609, to continue the use of a seal with this inscription: "This is the seale of the Trenitie-House in Newcastle."
Some apartments appear to have been fitted up in 1583, for that date remains on the ling of what is at present the beadle's room, with an E. and R. between a rose and rown for Elizabetha Regina, and also E. T. and M. below, the initials probably of the then master's name.
The following occurs in a collection of original letters to the Archbishop of York pre∣sident of the council of the north, communicated by Messrs. Egerton, booksellers, Chat∣ing-Cross, p. 273. "The abstracte of the certificate for the musters of the maisters of shippes and maryners certified unto Robert, Archbisshoppe of York, in April 1547, by vir∣tue of letters directed unto him from the Duke of Somerset's Grace, Lorde Protector, and others (of the Privy Council).
"The towne of Newcastell upon Tyne, maisters 32, maryners 145.—Total 177.
"The county of Northumbrelaunde, maisters non, maryners non.—Havinge fishermen whiche fishe alongest the see costs and be in nombre 192, whereof many be Scotts.
"Duresme, maisters 3, maryners 16.—Total 19.
"Cumberlaunde, maisters non, maryners non.
"The county of Westmerlande neither masters nor maryners.
"The county of Yorke (including the city, three ridings, and Hull and Hullshire) 486, whereof maisters 30, maryners 456.".

A. D. 1584, Queen Elizabeth granted to this society a new charter, on their humble suit and complaint of the defects of the former ones, founding them anew by the name of the master, pilots and seamen of the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be a perpetual bro∣therhood, consisting of nineteen elder brethren, who with the rest, styled younger brethren, should yearly on the Sunday next after Candle∣mas, choose a master, two elder wardens, and two younger ones; as also four assistants out of the elder brethren, with as many out of the younger, for the government of the fraternity, and safe custody of the possessions thereof: they were also to plead and be impleaded, &c
From an imperfect and undated translation entered in the old books, the original du∣plicate of which has been lost, but Mr. Punthou, under sheriff of Newcastle, saw the other original in the Rolls chapel in London, 1781, where he made the following memo∣randum:
"In the next year, viz. 25 Eliz. grant to the master, &c. of the Holy Trinity, New∣castle."
A very observable old anchor, almost eaten through with rust, is at present affixed to the outside wall of the Trinity-House of Newcastle, near the entrance from the Broad-Chare, which, if we will believe tradition, belonged to one of the ships font from Spain, in Queen Elizabeth's time, in the fleet well known by the name of the Invincible Armada, which was shipwrecked somewhere within the jurisdiction of this society..

January 18th, 1606, King James I. granted a new charter to this society, constituting them a body politic by the name of master, pilots and seamen of the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the same, and appointing a master, twelve elder brethren, two elder wardens with their two assistants, and two younger wardens, with the like number of assistants. They were to have a common sealSee Seals, Plate. I. Nov. 4.. Their jurisdiction was extended to Blith, Sunderland, Hartle∣pool,
pool, Whitby and Staithes—power is given them to impose sines on their offending brethren, and to appoint pilots for the river Tyne, with its creeks and members, who are to have for conducting every laden vessel 12d. for every foot it shall draw, and for every foot a light ship shall draw 8d. The duty of primage was confirmed to them from vessels from beyond the feas coming into the river, or its creeks and members: 2d. per ton of wine, oil and other things, sold by the ton (fish killed and brought in by Englishmen excepted), and 3d. per last of flax, hemp, pitch, tar, or other things fold by the last. Aliens are to pay this duty before they leave the port, and free merchants and inhabitants of Newcastle, within ten days after their landing: all this to go to the support of twelve poor brethren, or their wives, or shipwrecked mariners.

Lightage was also confirmed to them; of every owner's ship, Eng∣lish born, 4d. each time, and of every owner's ship that is an alien 12d. The buoying, canning, marking, and beaconing of the river Tyne was also confirmed to them, for which they are to receive of each ship, whose owner is English, and burthen above 20 chaldron of coals, 4d. Of the same when under 20 chaldron, 2d. and of every alien, 6d. They were also impowered to hold lands and tenements under 30l. per annum clear value
Records of the house.—In their old books, pilotage is called "loadmannage."—See Lye's Junius' Etymology Angl. in verbo "Lodesman."
A curious account of the ancient wages of seamen is preserved in their old books, of the date of Feb. 14th, 1602..

The Lords of the Privy-Council, by their warrant dated the last of May, 1607, and directed to the customers and other officers of the ports of Newcastle, Yarmouth, Hull, Boston and Lynn, enforced the payment of the duties of buoyage and lightage to this societyRecords of the society.—By an order of Privy-Council, October 9th, 1613, the Trinity-House of Newcastle, on a conference with that of Deptford-trand, having eect∣ed two turets upon the tops of their light-houses, each to contain two candles, two pence additional duty of lightage was imposed on each English ship, making it six-pence in all, with an additional four-pence to that of each foreign vessel, in all one shilling and four∣pence.—Ibid..

Disputes having risen concerning the payment of primage to this society, the Lords of the Privy-Council, by a letter dated Nov. 17th, 1617, ordered, that the merchants of Newcastle should pay only three halfpence for every last of corn brought into that port, or the crecks and members thereofRecords of the society..
In the year 1618 a gallery was ordered to be built in All-Saints church, in Newcastle, at the sole expence of this fraternity, and to be called the Trinity GalleryIbid..
King Charles the First, in the month of June, 1633, was escorted by this society when he went down from Newcastle by water to TinmouthIbid..

October 16th, 1634, this society purchased a parcel of waste ground at Pow-Pans, near North-Shields and their low light-house there, 30 ells in length, and 60 in breadth, that formerly had been parcel of the possessions of Tinmouth monastery, of George Ward, Esq of Upton, in Yorkshire, and Francis his son
Ibid.—"Nov. 10th, 1634. Item for the ground purchased of Mr. Ward, where the lowe light-howse standes 5l. 11s. 2d.
"Sept. 14th, 1635, paid for wherry hire and charges when livery and seisin was made of the sandy ground on which the lowe light-house stands 9s. 6d.".

Probably they used to pay an annual acknowledgment to the owners of the site of their low light-house, before the above additional purchase was made. Entries in their old books shew that they used to pay ground-rent for that of their upper one"Dec. 6th, 1658, paid Mr. Thomas Hockin for one whole yeares rent of the ground whereon the upper light-hous at North-Shecles stands, due 11 Nov. last past 4s. 8d.".

The same year the present chapel of the Trinity-House was sitted up and beautified
Ibid. There is a stone over the chapel door, inscribed "June 7th, 1634."
The same year some new rooms square were ordered to be finished..

January 12th, 1634, this society made an order, that every elder brother should furnish himself with a silver whistle and chain; and every younger brother, with a silver whistle and silk scarf; which naval ensigns of honour were, doubtless, ordered to be worn at meetings, on particular occasionsRecords of the house.—See afterwards, under 1660, "Arms" of this society..

March 28th, 1636, press masters visited, and were entertained at this house. It appears, by orders of a subsequent date, that this frater∣nity were employed in pressing not only seamen, but also boats and vessels for his majesty's serviceIbid.

In 1636 a warrant was procured from the Bishop of Durham, for the preaching of sermons by the vicars of Newcastle for the time being, for ever, in the chapel of this house
Ibid. "April 25th, 1636, pd. about the procureing of my Lord Bysshop of Dur∣ham his warrant for sermons to be preached in the Trinity chapel for ever 1l. 10s.—Given to Mr. Yeldard Alvey, vieker of Newcastle, for a present from the house in wine and wheate in regard he made the first sermon in the chappell 2l. 5s. 10d.
"Paid for a diner for the vicker, the doctor and rest of the clargie that daie the vicker preached in the chap. being the first sermon, 28 March 1636—3l. 1s. 6d.
"March 26th, 1638, paid for wine when the Lord Bushopp of Durham came to see the chappel 2s. 6d. April 23d, 1638, pd. for 4 gallons of sacke and two loves of suger containing 7 lb. 7 oz. weight, sent to Mr. Doctor Jenison after he preached in the chappell 1l. 14s.".

The Scots appear to have had possession of this house, or at least of part of it, when they took Newcastle, in the year 1640; in which year also General Lesley granted a warrant for the safeguard of their lights at the entrance of the harbour of Tyne
Books of the society.—"October 5th, 1640, pd. for carring wood out of the roomes the soldiers came to 1s. 2d—pd. a wright for nailing up dooies and making up pertitions when the Scots came 2s. 8d. &c."
"November 2d, 1640—given to prisoners that were shott in the scremedge at New∣bourne 2s."—""The great sess the Scottish army inflicted upon us" is mentioned Novem∣ber 30th, 1640..

January 21st, 1642, this society paid 100l. which had been taxed
by Sir John Marley, Knight, mayor, for the maintenance of a gar∣rison of soldiers at NewcastleBooks of the society. Also September 22d, 1643, in plate and money 66l. 13s. 4d..

When the Queen, in the year 1642, was expected to have landed at Tinmouth, this fraternity gave proof of their loyalty, by sending down some of their brethren to attend her arrival at that placeIbid..
In 1644, when the town of Newcastle was taken after an obstinate siege, this house was plundered by the ScotsIbid..

January 5th, 1645, the solemn league and covenant was admini∣stered by Dr. Jennison of All-Saints, in the chapel of this house
Books of the society.—"March 17th, 1644, pd. for beare which was bestowed on Mr. Thwing, scolemaster, while he was writing the covenant in parchment 1s. 6d. Paid for a skin of parchment for it 8d.
"February 16th, 1645, given to Doctor Jenison for a gratuitic, when he preached in Trinity-House chappell January 5th, when he administered the covenant 1l. 10s., which, in 1646 and 1648, appears to have been again inhabited by soldiersIbid.; as it was also in 1650, by several of the wretched prisoners sent out of Scotland to Newcastle by Oliver Cromwell, after the famous battle of DunbarIbid. "September 23d, 1650, pd. to two men that watched the presoners and the garde that they did no harme the first night the Scotts presoners came to the Trinity-House 2s.".

January 19th, 1655, this society was desired by the council of trade, under the protector Cromwell, to transmit them a copy of their charter, with an account of their government, and what was want∣ing in their house. In their answer to the council, they suggested the necessity of erecting two light-houses on the Fern Islands, with the owner of which, Sir Francis Liddell, of Bambrough, Knight, they had already been treating concerning such erectionIbid. October 29th, 1656, the articles concerning the agreement with Sir Francis Riddell for this purpose, were sealed and delivered by him as his act and deed, for the use of the Trinity-House, at a guild then and there held; as was also the counter part, with the seal of the said Trinity-House. In the month of August 1785, I paid a visit to the Fern Islands, where there are still two light-houses kept up. One had been lately re¦built, the sea having washed the greatest part of the old one down..

October 31st, 1660, William Gibson, merchant, and master and mariner, died, having bequeathed to the poor of this society twenty shillings yearly for ever, to be paid on the 24th of DecemberFrom an escutcheon remaining in the chapel. This still continues to be paid..

The oldest painting I have met with of the arms of this society, is on an escutcheon, remaining at present in the chapel, of the date of 1660
What is there in the upper part of the field, a boatswain's whistle and chain, by a whimsical metamorphosis has been changed by later painters or heralds into a cannon. In the old painting, the chain of the whistle is disposed like the strings of a purse in heraldry. The anchor is suspended by the chain.—The upper division of the field, in which is the wooden part of the anchor, as also the ring thereof, to which the chain of the whistle is annexed, is azure—the under division argent;—the iron part of the anchor is azure— the wooden part of it, with its ring, as well as the boatswain's whistle and chain, . Another copy of their arms, painted in 1724, gives the mermaid supporter on the right (i. e. facing the left hand of the spectator), holding a quadrant;—the opposite mermaid holds an anchor. The quadrant and anchor, as also the hair and fins of the mermaids, with the ship on the crest, or. I have seen these arms drawn otherwise, i. e. instead of a quadrant, the mermaid holds a plummet, which with its rope is or:—the motto, Deu dabit vela. There is no account of the arms of this society in the Herald's Office, London.
In Collins' Coasting Pilot their present seal is given by way of arms.
Books of the society..
December 2d, 1661, this fraternity subscribed, "for a voluntary present to his majesty, according to an act of parliament in that behalf made, the sum of one hundred poundso."

October 21st, 1664, King Charles II. by a new charter, confirmed the privileges formerly granted to this house, with an exemption to the brethren thereof from serving in the trained bands, juries, and all other like land-services, and as the members of the Trinity-House at Deptford-Strand are exempted; laying also an additional duty of two-pence upon every ship, towards the maintenance of the light-houses, and the like sum in addition to what was formerly paid for buoys; as
also an addition of six-pence, and four-pence to the former duty of pilotage, to be paid by strangers onlyRecords of the house.—March 15th, 1665, there is an order for converting the great court-yard of this house into a place of recreation for the brethren of the society..

It appears that when Clifford's Fort at the entrance of the Tyne was built in 1672, at the expence of government, the low light-house of this society, as well as the ground annexed to it, was railed in with rails and stakes: Government finding a part of this ground most convenient for their purpose, inclosed about five hundred and nine yards of it within the walls of the new fort, leaving, however, a little door for the keeper of the light-house to go out at, and mark the time of the tide, but which afterwards also was built upBooks of the society. Before the erection of Clifford's Fort, which Wallis, in his History of Northumberland, has confounded with one which stood on the south side of the Tyne, to the seaward, at a little distance from this light-house there was anciently a sort of baskets filled with sand and mortar, with a gun placed between each basket..

October 25th, 1675, Justinian Angel, of London, merchant, obtained a grant from the crown of two light-houses, erected at his own charge, upon a piece of ground leading into Humber, in Yorkshire, called the Spurn Island, or Spurn Head, which was his own inheritance, and for the support of which, he had agreed to receive a farthing per tun from all English, and a halfpenny per tun from all foreign vessels: Mr. Angel had been induced to undertake this at the instance of this society, and that of merchants, owners, and masters of ships trading on the north seas, and was opposed in it by the Trinity-Houses of Hull and Deptford-Strand
Books of the society.—By indenture, August 7th, 1677, the above J. Angel agreed to pay forty pounds per annum for one thousand year to the Trinity-House of Newcastle.— N. B. The like sum of forty pounds per annum from Spurn lights is paid to that of Hull, and also to the Trinity-House of Deptford-Strand. A. D. 1703, Mr. Edward Car made an assignment of the Spurn lights to Robert Bailiff, &c. October 1st, 1724, by a deed, this forty pounds per annum from Spurn lights is continued from Mr. Robert Bailiff, and John Welford, to the said Trinity-House.—From deeds in the custody of the house.
June 14th, 1678, the King granted a patent to Justinian Angel, and his heirs and assigns for ever, of the Spurn lights, by which a halfpenny per tun was laid on English, and a penny per tun on all foreign vessels, and reserving a crown rent of five pounds per annum. —Journals of Commons, 15th July, 1689..

March 11th, 1680, the King referred a petition of Sir Edward Vil∣liers, sen. Knight, for an additional toll of one farthing per tun to be laid on English, and three farthings per tun on foreign vessels, for the support of his light-house in Tinmouth-Castle, to the consideration of this society; who certified to his majesty the great use of that light-house, but objected to the proposed imposition, which they were of opinion would run high, and distress the northern navigationBooks and records of the house..
March 3d, 1685, this society addressed King James II. on his ac∣cession to the crownIbid..

July 1st, 1687, the King granted a new charter, on the surrender of their former ones, to this society, with an addition to the pilotage of every foot a vessel when laden should draw, i. e. six-pence to every stranger's loaden, and four-pence for every stranger's light vessel; so that an Englishman's laden vessel should pay twelve-pence, and a stran∣ger's one shilling and sixpence per foot: and for every Englishman's light vessel eight-pence, and for every stranger's ditto one shilling: lightage to be, for every Englishman's vessel eight-pence, and for every stranger's one shilling and four-pence: buoyage, six-pence for every Englishman's vessel above twenty chaldrons burthen, and four-pence for ditto under twenty chaldrons, and eight-pence for every alien's vesselIbid..
March 12th, 1696, this society addressed the King on the discovery of a plot against his lifeIbid..
August 6th, 1706, this house addressed Queen Ann on the success of her armsIbid..

John Bee, master and mariner, died February 19th, 1712, having given at his death, to the master, wardens and assistants of the Trinity-House in Newcastle, and their successors, the sum of one hundred pounds for a legacy, to be put out from time to time for the space of two years, to two younger brethren, and to two others for other two years successively for everEscutcheon in the chapel..
May 9th, 1712, this society ordered a free-school to be erected in the Trinity-House, for the instruction of the children of brethren in writing, arithmetic, and mathematicsBooks of Trinity-House..

January 20th, 1716, an order was made by this society, that prayers should be read every month-day in their chapel, before they entered upon secular business, and that a sermon should be preached in it everv quarter-day in the forenoon
Ibid. I have met with the following names of chaplains.
A. D. 1524, Sir Robert Ellison.
1541, — Gray.
1625, — Barkar.
1637, Joseph Alvey.
1716, — Wilcock.
1724, Joseph Carr.
1726, — Maddison, succeeded by Mr. Alderson and Mr. Stevenson.
Portraits of King William and Queen Mary are preserved in this chapel;—a curious model of a ship, said to have been made by some French prisoners during their confine∣ment, &c.
The chaplain's salary is eight pounds per annum, with two guineas given by the master for a sermon preached before him on the first Monday in the year, vulgarly called in the north, "Handsel Monday.".

The present great hall of the Trinity-House appears to have been built A. D. 1721Inscription on the front: "This Trinity-Hall was built 1721, John Welford then master, Thomas Rowcastle, deputy master; Mr. Nicholas Burdon, Mr. Henry Shad∣forth, Mr. Robert Bailiff, Mr. Joseph Milbourn, Mr. John Binks, Mr. John Hewbank, Mr. James Liddell, elder brethren." On a dial opposite to the above, "John Welford, master, 1721.", and the widows' apartments in 1724
Inscription; "These rooms was erected 1724, Thomas Peighin, master, Mr. Nicholas Burdon, Mr. Henry Shadforth, Mr. Robert Bailiff, Mr. John Welford, Mr. John Binks, Mr. James Cart, Mr. Peregrine Henzell, elder brethren."
It appeals from their papers, that the hall and new buildings cost them, the former 669l. 7s. 6d. the latter 115l. 6s. 7d..
February 1727, this society addressed King George I. against the Emperor and King of SpainTrinity-House books..
June 26th, 1727, this house addressed King George II. on his ac∣cession to the crownTrinity-House books..

February 24th, 1728, the Trinity-House of Newcastle gave publick notice that Tinmouth-Bar, which had of late been much alteredNewcastle Courant, February 24th, 1727-8. "So that the best of the bar was with the high light-house, a sail's breadth open to the southward:"—adding the subsequent direction: "The best and middle of the bar, with the lights over end.", was become so very good again, that ships might pass it with as much or rather more water than ever; and that the high light-house, which they had lately been obliged to rebuild, as well as the other, at a great ex∣pence, would be completed, and lights kept in each by the 25th of the following monthNewcastle Courant, February 24th, 1727-8. "So that the best of the bar was with the high light-house, a sail's breadth open to the southward:"—adding the subsequent direction: "The best and middle of the bar, with the lights over end.".
April 26th, 1734, this society addressed his majesty on the marriage of the Princess RoyalTrinity-House books..

In the rebellion in the year 1745, when the town of Newcastle was fortified, and put in a posture of defence, the elder brethren of this society were commissioned to procure such seamen as were found ne∣cessary to work the guns under their care, that were placed round the walls of that townIbid. It appears that several of the brethren of this house were sent over to Carlisse to sight the guns placed upon the walls of that city..

February 1746, when his royal highness the Duke of Cumberland passed through Newcastle, on his return from Scotland, after the con∣quest of the rebels, he was presented with the freedom of this society in a gold box. This house also addressed his majesty on the glorious victory at Culloden
Ibid.
In the year 1753, the school-house of this society was rebuilt, as appears by the follow∣ing inscription on a stone built up in it: "This School-House rebuilt 1753, Francis Pemberton, Esq master; elder brethren, James Carr, John Welford, Matthias Giles, William Errington, William Harrison, Charles Liddell, Thomas Proctor, Robert Hudson, Francis Heath, George Stephenson, John Cole, Henry Shadforth; Thomas Aubone, secretary."
Mr. Robert Harrison, an eminent mathematician, was master of this school; as was also Mr. Fryer, who published a map of the Tyne..
February 15th, 1765, this society petitioned parliament against adopt∣ing any other methods of disposing of ballast than by laying it on landTrinity-House books..
January 7th, 1769, this society petitioned the Lords of the Admiralty, against a canal intended to be made from Coventry, to the city of OxfordIbid..

December 3d, 1770, this fraternity offered a reward of two guineas over and above the royal bounty, to every able seaman, and one guinea for every ordinary seaman, who should, before the 1st of January, 1771, voluntarily enter into the King's service under the re∣gulating captain in Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

The subsequent letter of thanks was transmitted from this society, and presented by Sir William Stephenson: "To the Right Honour∣able Brass Crosby, Esq Lord Mayor of the city of London, and Richard Oliver, Esq alderman and member of parliament for the same. May it please your lordship, and Richard Oliver, Esq we the master, pilots and seamen of the Trinity-House in Newcastle upon Tyne, beg leave, among others of his majesty's most dutiful and loyal subjects, friends to liberty, the English constitution, and the laws thereof, humbly to return you our warmest thanks for the supporting with a patriotic manly firmness and dignity, the freedom and privi∣leges of your fellow citizens of London, and the natural rights of your fellow subjects in general. Given under the common seal of our cor∣poration the 13th of April, 1771; Jonathan Blagdon, masterNewcastle Courant, May 11th, 1771.."

A. D. 1775, the lower light-house at North-Sheilds, belonging to this society, was raised at their common expenceInscription on the building: "This house was raised, Cuthbert Adamson, Esq. master, Thomas Mande, deputy master, 1775.".

April 14th, 1779, this fraternity sent a congratulatory letter to Admiral Keppel, for what is styled therein "his spirited, gallant and
judicious conduct, on the 27th and 28th of July, 1778;" which was accompanied with a gold box of elegant workmanship, inclosing the freedom of their corporationNewcastle Courant, April, 1779.—On the lid was the following inscription: "The gift of the corporation of the Trinity-House in Newcastle upon Tyne, to the Honourable Augustus Keppel, Admiral of the Blue, &c. in testimony of their high regard for his many faithful and important services to his country, particularly for his gallant conduct on the 27th and 28th of July, 1778.".
June 5th, 1782, this society addressed the King on the late success of his majesty's fleets and armies in all the quarters of the worldNewcastle Courant, June 29th, 1782..

This respectable fraternity, whose revenue, communibus annis, amounts to about eight hundred pounds a year, support at present (1785) within their house, twelve widows, and have upon their list about twenty extra poor
From a calculation communicated by Mr. Thomas Aubone, secretary.—They allow each widow twelve shillings per month, a gown and petticoat every two years, and pro∣vide them with coals, and the advice of a surgeon whenever it is necessary.
Some of the extra poor have five shillings per month allowed them by this house, others twenty shillings a quarter, &c. according to their several necessities.
They keep a fire-engine in their court-yard.
Their rents in Broad-Chare, and Trinity-Lane, amount to about one hundred pounds per annum. An iron box hangs over the table in their great room, wherein the odd pence, &c. that occur in casting up their accounts or donations to their poor, are kept for their use.
The master and deputy master are sworn on admission to their respective offices; as are also the elder and younger brethren on their respective promotions and admissions into the fraternity..

DIV2.HEAD: NAMES OF THE MASTERS OP THE TRINITY-HOUSE OP NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.

LIST.HEAD: COMPILED FROM THE DORMANT BOOK AND OTHER RECORDS OF THIS SOCIETY.
LIST.ITEM: "A. D. 1555 Master Thomas Shaldfourthe, heed of the howis theis yer"

1665 George SwaddellQuere under 1665, for I find that Ralph Fell, master, died, and that Thomas Aubone was elected for the remainder of the year. For account of Sir Chaloner Ogle, 1726, see Nicholson's and Burn's Westmoreland and Cumberland, vol. i. p. 605.

DIV3.HEAD: 2. Weavers.
DIV3.P:
The old ordinary of this society, the original of which is still in their possession, is dated the last day of August, 1527. By the au∣thority of the mayor, sheriff, and aldermen, justices of the peace, with the consent of their own body, it enjoins them to assemble yearly at the feast of Corpus Christi, go together in procession, and play their play and pageant of "The Bearing of the Cross," at their own expence; each brother to be at the procession when his hour is assigned, on pain of forfeiting sixpence. To take no Scotsman born to apprentice, nor set any to work under a penalty of forty shillings for each default, whereof half to go to the fellowship, and half to the work of Tyne-Bridge, with∣out any forgiveness; to admit any person who had served an appren∣ticeship with a brother of the society, a member thereof, on the payment of thirteen shillings and four-pence, and twelve-pence for a pot of ale;
as also any man of that craft, being the King's liege man, and desirous to be of the fellowship, a brother thereof, with power to set up shop on the payment of twenty pounds, and twelve-pence for a pot of ale. The searchers to search four times a year at least. That any brother falling into poverty should be supplied out of the common box, at the discretion of the stewards and twelve; and that any brother misbe∣having at meetings, should forfeit six pounds of wax for every de∣fault; and that any brother lying in wait to beat, slay or murder any of his brethren, should be put out of the society for ever; that any brother calling another "Scot," or "mansworn," in malice, should for∣feit six shillings and eight-pence without any forgiveness: that every apprentice should serve seven years, and pay at his entrance a pound of wax; that they should settle their accounts every year, on the Mon∣day after Corpus Christi day, and choose their stewards in manner fol∣lowing: the whole society first to choose four discreet brethren, who, after being sworn, should choose other four, which eight being all sworn, should choose the stewards and searchers for the year: that every brother should be "at the Sante Augustine's" in the day of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross, and go "the none of the same day to the dirige and sowle masses to be done for the brederes and fusters" of the fellowship, on pain of forfeiting sixpence for each default; that every brother take for the working of a dozen broad cloth four shillings; for a dozen "strates wollene" twenty-pence, to be mea∣sured by the long wand; for a dozen lyn-cloth, yard broad, bleeched, twelve-pence; also "sise and brood-lynn and hardone," ten-pence a dozen; a dozen "san-clothe" twelve-pence; a dozen "karsais" eight∣teen pence; for a dozen lyn-cloth, five quarters broad, eighteen-pence, &c.
This society have a warrant renewed yearly from the mayor of Newcastle, to seize bad yarn, &c. and still continue to receive annual contributions from the pedlars, who keep booths on the Sand-Hill.
Mention occurs of the "craft of challon weavers," in the decree of the Star-Cham∣ber, concerning the government of Newcastle, dated May 2d, 1516.
Mention occurs in St. Nicholas' Register, November 1581, of "David Pentland, webster."
Ibid. Marc. 1599, of "John Carr, silck weaver."
In All-Saints' Register, August 1623, of "Richard Aizley, silk weaver."

Another ordinary, having the sanction of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, in Guild-Hall assembled, dated August 12th, 1608, and inrolled in the books of the corporation, confirmed to them that no foreigner or person not free of the fellowship, living in or about the High-Castle, near the liberties of that town, should take any work in prejudice of this society, on pain of forfeiting five pounds for each de∣fault. And that none should buy any linen or hardone yarn, to carry out of the precincts of the said town, under a penalty of forty shillings.

DIV3.HEAD: 3. Barber-Chirurgeons, with Chandlers.
DIV3.P:
The ancient ordinary of this society, dated October 10th, 1442From the original., enjoined that they should go together in procession on Corpus Christi day in a livery, and afterwards play the "Baptizing of Christ," at their own expence. Every man to be at the procession when his hour is assigned him, at the New-Gate, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax; to go also with their pageant, when it should be played in a livery, on the like pain: that no alien born should be taken apprentice, or al∣lowed to work within the town, or without, under a penalty of twenty shillings; that the society should uphold the light of St. John Baptist, in St. Nicholas' church, as long as they were of ability; that no barber, apprentice, nor servant, should shave on a Sunday, neither within the town nor without, by a mile's space
Extracts from their old books.
"Accounts 1691.—Disburst about the man that was given the company for dissection."
"April 9th, 1711, four statues ordered to be bought, not to exceed fifteen pounds." April 9th, 1711, "a skeleton ordered to be bought in London, not to exceed six guineas."
December 11th, 1711, ordered by a full vote in the company, that "perrywigg-making be from thenceforth accounted as a part and branch of the company." "June 14th, 1742, order that no brother shave John Robson, till he pays what he owes to Robert Shafto.".

There is another ordinary of this society, dated September 25th, 1671,
confirming the former, and making them a body politic by the name of the barber-chirurgeons, and wax and tallow-chandlers, ordering them to meet yearly, and choose two wardens, who were to be sworn; that apprentices should serve seven years; and that when any brother had taken a cure in hand, no other should meddle with it till it was completed, on pain of forfeiting twenty shillings for the first, thirty shillings for the second, and forty shillings for the third default, half of which to go to the brother who first dressed the patient. It fur∣ther enjoined, that none should wash, dress, or trim on a Sunday, on pain of forfeiting two shillings for every offence, giving the company power to make by-laws, and to choose annually two searchers, who were to be swornRecords of this society..

In the year 1648, on a petition from this society for a place in the Manors whereon to build a meeting-house, the corporation of New∣castle ordered a lease of certain ground there to be granted them for that purpose for sixty-one years, at the annual rent of six shillings and eight-pence, with a certain number of yards of land for a garden to be planted with medicinal herbsCommon-council books..
A new lease, dated November 4th, 1771, was ordered them by the same body, for sixty-one years from the expiration of the old oneIbid..

DIV3.HEAD: 4. Cutlers.
DIV3.P: No ordinary, or other record of this company, has been preserved. Mention occurs of them as a society in the ordinary of the armourers, dated 1579"The second day of July, A. D. 1579, A. R. Elizabethe 21o, it is ordered, by Mr. Mark Shafto, mayor, of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, and his brethren, the alder∣man and sheriff of the same, as well by the consent of the fellowship of cutlers of the said towne, as by the assent of the fellowship of armourers of the same, that whatsoever ar∣mourers of the said towne, that shall from henceforth make any daggere sheaths, or knives sheathes, shall yearly paye to the occupation of the cutlers of the said towne, the summe of 8 pence of lawful money of England; and that no armourer of the said towne shall from henceforth take any daggeres to dight or make clean, except the same daggere be made of a sworde blade, and such as hilted daggers. Mark Shafto.". In the year 1688, they appear to have presented to the election of the mayor, as one of the fifteen by-tradesMS. Life of Alderman Barnes, "John Baxter and Garret Starkey.".
Their hall, anciently called "Cutler's Tower," in the Carlel-Croft, is now the meeting-house of the fraternitySee, under "masons," an order of common-council, dated May 19th, 1740. of masons.

DIV3.HEAD: 5. Shipwrights.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated August 8th, 1638, signed the day following by the judges of assize, who certify their having perused and ratified the same, enjoins them to meet yearly on the 27th of December, to choose two wardens, and the like number of overseers; prohibiting them from working on Sundays and holidays observed by the church, giving them power to make by-laws, and restricting apprentices from working tide-work till they had served three years.

Another order of this society, dated August 6th, 1674, was also confirmed by the judges; as was another also, dated July 26th, 1689. Besides the above this fraternity have since made many additional orders by their own authority
Records of the society.
In the old books I found the subsequent curious entries.
"1613, Robart Harrigad for a carvell 1s.
"1622, William Keisley, for working on a ketch on a holiday 7d.
"— of two for working on a "flebote" on a holiday 7d.
"1624, received for a pott "fower heates on a keele 21d."
1651. About this time the company appear to have had ways at the Close-Gate, where large ships were built.
Their meeting-house occurs 1622.
"27 December, 1622, pd. for "bretedging the towre 24s. 2d."
1630, mention occurs of "Skis-Thursday being our Lady-Day in Lent."
1656, mention occurs of new ways about St. Lawrence for building ships.
June 24th, 1673, a brother fined for challenging another to fight, and giving him his glove.
Ten brethren fined for working on January 30th, 1651, "being a thanksgivinge-daye."
December 27th, 1672, a brother fined for telling one of the twelve, "he turned his cloake on the other shoulder.".

DIV3.HEAD: 6. Coopers.
DIV3.P: The ancient ordinary of this society, dated January 20th, 1426From the original in the archiv of the society., enjoined them to go together yearly at the feast of Corpus Christi in procession, as other crafts did, and play their play at their own charge; each brother to attend at the hour assigned him at the procession on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax: that none should take a Scotsman born to apprentice, nor set any such to work, under the penalty of forty shillings, whereof twenty-six shillings and eight-pence to go to the fraternity, and thirteen shillings and four-pence to "Sente Nicholas kyrkwarke." No brother to take any more than one apprentice in seven years. All turners and pulley-makers coming to Newcastle, to be bound by the same ordinary.

An after clause forbade the employing of any Dutchman; and by another after clause, the company of ropers were united with this societyFrom an inrolment in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

Another ordinary of this society, dated September 10th, 1575, con∣stituted them, in deed and name, a body incorporated of themselves, ordering them to meet on the 6th of June yearly, to choose their two wardens, &c. and granted them power to make by-laws, and sue and be sued within the courts of Newcastle; joining them with the pully-makers, turners, and rope-makers, who were to be one company with the coopers for ever; and enjoining that no Scottishman born, or other alien, should set up shop in their trade here, or be employed in it, under a penalty of forty shillings.

January 30th, 1650, the corporation of Newcastle ordered them a lease for seven years of a place in the Manors, to be a meeting-houseFrom the original lease in the archives of the society.. The company of plaisterers appear to have met with this society soon after the restorationEntry in their books: "June 5th, 1667, received of the plaisterers for their part of the plaistering of the new meeting-house 1l. 4s. 6d.".

October 7th, 1699, a warrant was granted to this society by the mayor of Newcastle, to search all herring, &c. a power which is still continued in their handsOriginal in the possession of the society..

A. D. 1725, a legacy of twenty pounds was left by Mrs. Margaret Stephenson to this society, to be divided, and let out to two brethren for a certain number of years without interest
Books of the company.—Will dated October 26th, 1725.
In the old book of this society, 1670, mention occurs of the following measures: "Bushel, kenning, beatment, peck, milner's beatment."—1664, mention occurs ibid. of a kind of wooden vessels called "seas."
In the meeting-house of this society, over the water-gate on the Sand-Hill, there is a table of fir wood, all of one piece, which is twenty-two feet and a half long, and twenty-two inches and a half broad..

DIV3.HEAD: 7. House-Carpenters, anciently called Wrights.
DIV3.P:
An ordinary of this society, dated July 3d, 1579From a copy inrolled in the books of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne., constituted the house-carpenters and joiners a body corporate of themselves, with per∣petual succession and power to sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of Newcastle; ordered that they should meet yearly, and choose three wardens, two of whom were to be house-carpenters, and the third a joiner; and that whenever the general plays of the town, called Corpus Christi plays, should be played, they should play the Burial of Christ, which anciently belonged to their fellowship: that no apprentice should serve less than seven years; no Scotsman to be taken as such under a penalty of forty shillings, nor to be made free on any account. It further enacted, that the joiners should work at the sealing of houses within, the making "dorments and windows," "drawn tables of frame-work, and tables with turnposts," "buffet-stools," "forms," "cup-boards," "almeries," "pressers," "chairs, and sconces of frame-works," "casements," "trellising of windows," "buttries of framed work," "framed chists," and all others pinned with wood, "as also every other kind of joiner's work." That the two trades should occupy in common the making of buttries, or any other kind of work with "seal∣ing
linck," i. e. one board growen in another, and nailed with iron nails; "chists for corpses, and all other chists not pinned with wood;" "removing of beds, cupboards, and draw-tables, together with making of doors and windows mulder work." And that half of their fines should go to the maintenance of the great bridge, and the other half to the fellowship"George Collingwood, house-carpenter, died December 23d, 1698, and devised by his last will, to the stewards and society of house-carpenters, forty shillings, to be paid on the first day of May yearly for ever; and be employed towards the putting out an ap∣prentice to one of the society."—From an escutcheon in their meeting-house at West-Gate.—Arms—Collingwood's impaling those of the company..

DIV3.HEAD: 8. Masons.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated September 1st, 1581Inrolled in the books of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne., consti∣tuted them a body incorporated of themselves with perpetual succes∣sion; enjoined them to meet yearly to choose two wardens, who might sue and be sued in the courts of Newcastle, make by-laws, &c. That whenever the general plays of the town, anciently called Corpus Christi plays, should be played, they should play "the Burial of our Lady St. Mary the Virgin;" every absent brother to forfeit two shillings and sixpence: that no Scotsman should be taken apprentice, under a penalty of forty shillings, nor ever be admitted into the company on any account whatever; each brother to be sworn; that apprentices should serve seven years; that at the marriages and burials of brethren, and their wives, the company should attend to the church such persons to be married or buried; that one half of their fines should go to the maintenance of the great bridge, and the other half to the said fellow∣ship. July 1st, 1674, the society appear to have met in the White-Friar-Tower, with the wallers, or bricklayers and mettersCommon-council books..

George Maxwell, mason, who died September 14th, 1732, be∣queathed the rental of five messuages in Newcastle to this society, for the relief of brethren reduced to poverty by sickness, and of their necessitous
widowsOn a monument in their meeting-house, erected in 1776: "To the memory of Mr. George Maxwell, mason, who died September 14th, 1732, and bequeathed to the company of masons of Newcastle, the rentals of five messuages and their appurtenances, to be applied to the relief of such brethren as are sick, or incapable of working, and to such of their widows as are needful.". May 19th, 1740, this fraternity, on their petition, obtained of the corporation of Newcastle, a grant of the Cutler's Tower in the Carlel-Croft, which they have since repaired in a handsome mannerCommon-council books.—"They agree to deliver up the White-Friar Tower to the corporation.".

DIV3.HEAD: 9. Glovers.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated January 20th, 1436, enjoined them to go together in procession at the feast of Corpus Christi in a livery, and play their play at their own charge; to choose annually three stewards; that apprentices should serve seven years, on pain of forfeiting six shillings and eight-pence "to the light of the said craft;" that no Scotsman born should be taken apprentice, nor allowed to work in the town, under a penalty of forty shillingFrom the original in the possession of the society. The subsequent extracts are from their old books: "April 12th, 1643. At the quarter sessions holden at the Guild-Hall at Newcastle upon Tyne, information was made against William Ramsey, but∣ton-maker, for tagging of points, which was proved to be part of the glover's trade, and tryed by the verdict of a jury.—Ramsey was cast in forty shillings, and the charges of the court.".
A. D. 1648, this society occur as renting part of the skinners' meet∣ing-house in the Black-Friars, at the annual rent of five shillingsBooks of the company..

DIV3.HEAD: 10. Joiners.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated March 28th, 1589
