From a copy inrolled in the book of inrolments in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle.
The following inscription is on an escutcheon in their meeting-house in Pilgrim-Street-Gate: "Mrs. Margaret Stephenson, relict of Mr. John Stephenson, merchant of Newcastle, departed this life August 23d, 1729, and, by her last will and testament, gave to the com∣pany of joiners of Newcastle aforesaid, twenty pounds, to be lent to two such brethren of the said fellowship, as shall want stock to set up with for four years without interest, and so to be transferred to other two such brethren of the said joyners at the end of every four years for ever."
On another ibid. "Barbara Farbridge, relict of Charles Farbridge, brother of the company, died April 13th, 1743, aged 60, bequeathed to the poor widows of deceased bre∣thren twenty pounds, the use of which to be paid by the stewards on St. Peter day yearly for ever.", separated them from the house-carpenters, and constituted them a fellowship of
themselves, with perpetual succession. It enjoined them also to elect two wardens, who might sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of New∣castle, make laws, &c. and that whenever the mayor, aldermen, and sheriff of Newcastle commanded any general play to be set forth, or martial exercise to be performed, they should appear, and perform such parts in them as should be respectively assigned them, on pain of for∣feiting two shillings and sixpence, for every time they were absent; that apprentices should serve seven years, five of which to elapse be∣fore a second could be taken; that no Scot should be taken apprentice, or ever admitted into the fellowship. It enjoined also the appoint∣ment of two triers of work, as expressly and particularly named in the former joint ordinary of the house-carpenters and joiners, dated July 3d, 1579.

DIV3.HEAD: 11. Milners or Millers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated September 20th, 1578From a copy inrolled in the books of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne., citing another of older date, constituted twenty free millers a fellowship, with perpetual succession, and enjoined them to choose two wardens every year, on the Sunday next before St. Andrew's day, who might sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of the town; and that when the general plays should be performed, they should play the ancient one of the society, called "the Deliverance of the Children of Israel out of the Thraldom, Bondage and Servitude of King Pharoh," on pain of forfeiting twenty shillings for absence: that no stranger or alien born should be taken apprentice, or set to work, on pain of six shillings and eight-pence; and that apprentices should serve seven years; that no corn should be ground upon Sundays; that each miller in the counties
of Northumberland, or Durham, who brought corn from Newcastle market, should pay them an acknowledgment of sixpence per annum, and pay two shillings and sixpence every time he should be found in the wheat or malt market before two o'clock in the afternoon on market days, unless to fetch away the corn which his customers had bought there; and that none such foreign millers should buy corn there, under a penalty of two shillings and sixpence for each defaultBooks of the society..
It further enjoined, that the wardens of this society should make oath in the Town-Chamber concerning the fines, half whereof to go to the support of the Newcastle part of Tyne-Bridge.

April 8th, 1672, a singular order occurs in the books of this fra∣ternity, that if any brother should attend the burial of another with a black hat, he should be fined sixpence for every such default.

DIV3.HEAD: 12. Curriers, Feltmakers, and Armourers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated October 1st, 1546, enjoined them to go together in procession at the feast of Corpus Christi, hear the charges of the lights, pageants and play, and be there at the hour assigned them, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax. It further en∣joined that none born out of the King's dominion should work with them, unless he were denizen, or for urgent causes to be admitted by the mayor and justices of peace, on pain of paying forty pounds sterling; that they should not work on holidays, or on Saturdays longer than five o'clock at afternoon, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax; that each brother should be sworn on admission; and that the armourers, cur∣riers, and hatters, should not interfere in each other's occupations
Records of the society.
March 27, 1671, other for the seizure of French hats, except such as were sold by those of the company..

A. D. 1719, this society made a singular order, that no quaker should be taken apprentice, on pain of forfeiting one hundred pounds
Books of the society.
Mention occurs in St Nicholas' Register, May 1578, of "Henry Browne, armorer▪" also, Septemher 1631, of "Christopher Hemson, armorer.".

DIV3.HEAD: 13. Colliers, Paviors, and Carriage-Men.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated July 30th, 1656
I found the original, which is a good deal mutilated, used as a wrapper for the bonds, &c. of the fraternity.
In All-Saints Register, September 1603, mention occurs of "Thomas Deanham, car∣ridgeman."—There are many other names ibid. with the same title.
At the election of the mayor, 1688, Robert Percival and Richard Armstrong were pre∣sented by "the colleirs and carrmen," one of the fifteen by-trades of the town.—MS. Life of Alderman Barnes.
In their old books their officers are styled "a box-master, and two key-keepers." They have at present two stewards.
The tower near St. Andrew's church, where they meet, appears to have been rebuilt about April, 177.
A. D. 1771, it was thoroughly repaired and beautified at the expence of the society, and cost them 18l. 1s. 3d. each of the twelve brethren contributing 1l. 10s. 1¼d., appears to have been a mutual agreement signed and sealed by themselves, to re∣main in force till they should obtain one under the authority of the magistrates of Newcastle. It ordered that no stranger, not having duly served an apprenticeship to their calling, should be set to work, on pain of forfeiting the sum of forty shillings; that any brother working a day's work privately, should forfeit six shillings and eight-pence for each default; and that they should choose a warden yearly, on the feast of St. Mark, who should keep the books of the fraternity, and do all other offices belonging to a steward, as in other companies.

DIV3.HEAD: 14. Slaters.
DIV3.P:
The ancient ordinary of this society, dated March 12th, 1415Records of the society., en∣joined them to go together in a livery, yearly, at the feast of Corpus Christi, and play their play at their own expence; each to be at the procession when his hour was assigned him, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax: that no apprentice should serve less than seven years, nor a second be taken till the first served six; that no brother should take a Scot to ap∣prentice, on pain of forfeiting forty shillings; that if any brother had taken a slate quarry, or any places to cover with dates, none should undermine him, under a penalty of thirteen shillings and four-pence;
that none should work upon St. Catherine's day, on pain of forfeiting a pound of wax. An order was added December 28th, 1460, that no brother should take less than six shillings and eight-pence, for handling a rood of slate covering.

Another ordinary, dated September 28th, 1579, cited an agreement between the slaters and bricklayers, and incorporated the societies with perpetual succession, enjoined them to choose two wardens annually, who might sue and be sued, make by-laws, &c. that at the general Corpus Christi plays, they should play "the Offering of Isaac by Abraham," where every brother was to attend, on pain of forfeiting two shillings and sixpence: that they should make ovens and chimney-tops, or fun∣nels, and all works of tile or brick, which was claimed by the wallers, to whom they were to pay an annual acknowledgment of three shil∣lings and four-pence. It further ordered, that the slaters should work no kind of work with black mortar or clay, on pain of ten shillings for each default, half of which to go to Tyne-Bridge, and half to the wallers. By mutual agreement, the annual acknowledgment of three shillings and four-pence was given up February 23d, 1597Records of the society.

Another ordinary of this society, dated March 16th, 1677, separated them from the company of wallers, bricklayers, and dawbers, alias plaisterers; and made them in deed and name a fellowship, by the name of slaters and tylers; ordered them to meet yearly on St. Catherine's day, and choose two wardens, who might sue and be sued, &c. to pay to the wallers three shillings and four-pence yearly on St. Catherine's day; to work no kind of black mortar or clay, but to make ovens and chimneys, or funnelsRecords of the society..
March 30th, 1619, the joiners appear to have granted the use of their hall to this societyIbid..
November 11th, 1654, this fraternity agreed to meet with the coopers in the MannorsBooks of tho society.; they assemble with them at present on the Sand-Hill.

DIV3.HEAD: 15. Glaziers, with Plumbers, Pewterers and Painters.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, anciently consisting of goldsmithsFrom a copy inrolled in the books of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne., plumbers, glaziers, pewterers, and painters, and dated September 1st, 1536, enjoined them to go together on the feast of Corpus Christi, and maintain
See afterwards "Goldsmiths."
Their hall, anciently called Morden-Tower, was granted to them in the mayoralty of Sir Peter Riddell, A. D. 1619.—Old books of the society.
A. D. 1598, there is an order, that none of the fellowship "shall worke or sell his own glasse under seven-pence one foot," on pain of forfeiting three shillings and four-pence.—Ibid.
June 9th, 1615, no brother to work any "Normandye glasse" under eight-pence the ft, under a penalty of twenty shillings.
September 7th, 173, no brother to lend his diamond, except to a free brother of this company, on pain of forfeiting six shillings and eight-pence.—Ibid. their play of "the three Kings of Coleyn;" to have four wardens, one goldsmith, one plumber, one glazier, and one pewterer or painter; to be sworn on admission; not to interfere with each other's occupation: that no Scotsman born should be taken apprentice, or suffered to work in Newcastle, on pain of forfeiting three shillings and four-pence; one half of which to go to the upholding of Tyne-Bridge, and the other to the society.
The names of some apothecaries are added, I know not on what ac∣count, to this ordinary.

DIV2.HEAD: COMPANIES NOT OF THE FIFTEEN BY-TRADES.

DIV3.HEAD: Goldsmiths.
DIV3.P: THE goldsmiths, as before related, were incorporated, by an ordinary, dated September 1st, 1536, with the glaziers, plumbers, pewterers, and painters.

They separated from them in the year 1717
In Consequence of an opinion taken by the glaziers, &c. of J. Cuthbert Esq recorder of Newcastle upon Tyne, dated October 4th, 1717.—Books of the glaziers.
A. D. 1249, the King commanded the bailiffs and good men of Newcastle upon Tyne, to choose in full court by the oath of four and twenty burgesses, four of the most prudent and trusty of their town for the office of moneyors there, and other four like per∣sons for the keeping of the King's mints in that town; also two fit and prudent goldsmiths to be assayers of the money to be made there, and one fit and trusty clerk for the keeping of the exchange, and send them to the treasurer and barons of the Exchequer, to do there what by ancient custom and assize was to be done in that case."—Memor. 33 Hen. III. Rot. 1. a.—Madox's History of the Exchequer, p. 604.
By an act of parliament, 2 Hen. VI. c. 14, it was ordered how silver should be touched and marked in Bristol, Chester, Exeter, Newcastle upon Tyne, &c.—See also Statutes at Large, 12 and 13 W. III. c. 4..

In the year 1702 this society obtained an assay master
See Journals of the House of Commons, vol. xiii. February 9th, 1702.—See also Statutes, 1 Annae, stat. 1. c. 9. sect. 3, 4.
By a report of the committee for assay offices, printed London, 1773, it appears that, May 3d, 1772, John Langlands and John Kikup were wardens of this society, which at that time consisted but of three members, i. e. the above two, and Joseph Hutchinson.
A. D. 1759, Matthew Prior, assayer at Newcastle upon Tyne, was sworn before Matthew Ridley, Esq mayor of that town..

DIV3.HEAD:
Waits, or Musicians
In All-Saints' Register, March 1606, mention occurs of "John Hobkyrk, minstrell."— Minstrels are mentioned in the old books of the slaters A. D. 1567—in those of the sadlers 1594—those of the tanners 152—also 1592, and even in 1599, two years after the statute had passed which included minstrels in the number of "rogues, vagabonds and sturdy beggars."—See Dr. Percy's Essay on Minstrels, in his Reliques of English Poetry.
In St. Nicholas' Register, August 1581, mention occurs of "Robert Atcheson, harper;" as also ibid. September 1589, of "John Walles, singing-man.".
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, citing an ancient one that had been lost, and dated September 18th, 1677, appointed them a fellowship with per∣petual succession; enjoined them to meet on the feast of St. James the Apostle, and choose two stewards, who might sue and be sued, &c. within the courts of Newcastle; that the admission fee should be ten shillings, but to those who came in by patrimony only six shillings and eight-pence; that none should teach musick without a licence from the mayor; that no stranger should be suffered to play at weddings or feasts, unless allowed by the mayor, under a penalty of six shillings and eight-pence; that no fiddler, piper, dancer upon ropes, or others that
pretended to skill in musick, or that went about with "motions or shewes," should practise in Newcastle without licence from the mayor, on pain of forfeiting ten shillings; that at marriages where musick should be chosen, the waits should be preferred; and if any other mu∣sicians, who had the mayor's licence, were called, their fee should not exceed three shillings and four-pence, under a penalty of ten shil∣lingsFrom the book of inrolments in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle.—In a list of salaries in the time of Queen Elizabeth ibid. the following entry occurs: "ive waites sallary 20l.".
By an order of common-council, November 4th, 1646, the waits were commanded to go about morning and evening, according to an∣cient customCommon-council books..
A. D. 1655, the corporation of Newcastle appears to have provided them with instrumentsIbid. "A sagbutt" occurs among the instruments then in use..

An order from the same authority, A. D. 1675, enjoined their going about the town in the winter seasonIbid. December 11th, 1694, there is an order of common-council, that the wait have cloaks a-piece once in three years, value 3l. a-piece.—Ibid..
They had their meeting-house in a tower in the Carlel-Croft, near Pilgrim-Street-Gate.

DIV3.HEAD: Scriveners.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated September 13th, 1675, appointed eight scriveners a fellowship with perpetual succession, enjoining them to meet every year on the 29th of September, and choose two stewards, who with the fellowship might sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of Newcastle, and make by-laws, &c. that apprentices should serve seven years, and no second be taken till the first had served three. It further enjoined that all scriveners should dwell in the town of NewcastleFrom a copy in the book of inrolments in the archives of Newcastle upon Tyne▪ In St. Nicholas' Register, October 1586, mention occurs of "James Turpin, scribe.".
The meeting-house of this society is in an apartment of the Town-Court.

DIV3.HEAD: Bricklayers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, called "wallers, bricklayers, and dawb∣ers, alias plaisterers," dated January 19th, 1660, cited an ancient one, granted in the time of King Henry VI. and constituted them a fellow∣ship with perpetual succession, who should meet on the 24th of Febru∣ary in every year, and choose two stewards, who might make orders, plead and be impleaded, &c. in the courts of Newcastle; that they should not be molested by the company of masons, or the slaters; that no foreigner should work in the town, under a penalty of six shillings and eight-pence; that none should employ an alien born under the like penalty; that apprentices should serve seven years, and that no second should be taken till the first had served three
From a copy in the above book of inrolments.
It appears that, in A. D. 1614, the meeting-house of this society was in a lower story of the White-Friar-Tower, and under that of the masons. The names of the stewards at that time,
—Armstrong 1614."
—Robson 1614." in raised letters in the plaisterme, were lately discovered..

January 21st, 1691, an order was made by the corporation of New∣castle upon Tyne, that the slaters and tilers should not exercise the trade of bricklaying or plaistering, otherwise than in making and mending chimney-tops above the slates, and plaistering them; but that the annual acknowledgment from them to this society should cease to be paid in futureCommon-council books..

Nevil-Tower appears to have been repaired by this society for a meeting-house, A. D. 1711, and has continued to be their hall ever since
Inscription on the wall: "This hall was repaired by the wallers, bricklayer and plaisterers, anno Domini 1711. Richard Fletcher and William Johnson, wardens."
Inscription over the door: "This hall was repaired at the charge of the company of wallers, bricklayers and plaisterers, 1745. Robert Taylor, Robert Thompson, wardens.".

DIV3.HEAD: Rope-makers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated April 14th, 1648, citing one of
more ancient date, but without the authority of the magistrates of New∣castle, made them a fellowship with perpetual succession, to meet on the 6th of June every year, and choose two wardens, who with the fellowship should make by-laws, sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of Newcastle; ordered that they should not be molested by the company of coopers, pulley-makers, and turners; that no brother should set an alien to work, under a penalty of forty shillings; that they should take apprentices only once in four years, but put their own children to the business at their pleasure; and further enjoined that they should not impose upon the publick by excessive prices
From a copy inrolled in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle.
There is an order in the books of this fraternity between A. D. 1709 and 1713, concerning "Richard Hutchinson's charity of forty shillings a year to be disposed of in the binding of a poor brother's son."
January 30th, 1695, there is an order that every brother should pay a fine of 6s. 8d. for every hundred weight of hemp unfound, "for rope yarn for either shipp, keel, water-gins, cole-pitts, or lead-mines.".

A. D. 1697, the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne granted to this society part of the room at the west end of the Correction-House in the Manors, formerly the hall of the coopers, for a meeting-house.
Their present hall is a tower near the bottom of Carliol-CroftCommon-council books..

DIV3.HEAD: Upholsterers, Tin-plate Workers, and Stationers.
DIV3.P:
The ordinary of this society, dated July 22d, 1675From an inrolment in the archives of the Corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne., constituted six upholsterers, three tin-plate workers, and two stationers, a fellowship, with perpetual succession, and ordered them to meet annually on the 25th day of July, and choose four stewards, two upholsterers, and one of each of the other branches, who with the society should have power to make by-laws, and might sue and be sued in the courts of New∣castle; that apprentices should serve seven years, and no second be taken till the first had served three; that they should not interfere with each other's callings, and that no person not free of the town and
this society should exercise their trade in Newcastle. The meeting-house of this fraternity is an apartment of the Town-Court.

DIV3.HEAD: Sail-makers.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated December 18th, 1663, con∣stituted five persons of the occupation a fellowship, with perpetual suc∣cession, and enjoined them to meet yearly on the 10th of August, and appoint two wardens, who with the fellowship might sue and be sued, &c. in the courts of Newcastle, and have power to make by-laws: that apprentices should serve seven years; that every brother should attend at meetings, under a penalty of sixpence for each default; and that none but those who were free of the town and this fellowship should exercise their trade. This ordinary was confirmed by the judges August 15th, 1664From a copy inrolled ut supra..

September 28th, 1713, the Corporation of Newcastle granted a lease of the meeting-house at the Close-Gate, formerly that of the carpenters, for twenty-one years, to this fraternity, at the rent of two shillings and sixpence per annumCommon-council books.—Ibid. March 19th, 1770, mention occurs of the tower at the south end of the Town's Wall, a having been used as a meeting-house by the house car∣penters, and afterwards by this society..

DIV3.HEAD: Mettors.
DIV3.P: The ordinary of this society, dated August 3d, 1611, enjoined them to meet on the 20th day of September in every year, and choose four wardens, who were to pass accounts, and make an equal division of their money on the day following. There was a card or table of rates and duties of the same dateFrom a copy inrolled ut supra..
October 18th, 1670, upon the alteration of measures, another ordi∣nary was granted to this societyIbid.—Common council books..

June 30th, 1726, a new card or table of rates and duties was ap∣pointed by act of common-council
In the book of oaths in the town clerk's office in Newcastle, occur the ons of "the oath of the mettors," and "the oath of a mettor for keels and boats."
A. D. 1614, this fraternity had their meeting-house in a lower story of the White-Friar-Tower, in the same room with the bricklayers, and under the hall of the masons. The names of
"Ralph Rogerson metters,"
Thomas Forster metters,"
Robert Jackson metters,"
Robert Todd metters," were discovered in raised characters on the plaistering, when the tower was converted into an ice-house by Isaac Cooson, Esq A. D. 1770..

DIV3.HEAD: Porters.
DIV3.P: The oldest ordinary of this society is dated A. D. 1528From a copy in the book of inrolments ut supra..

September 2th, 1648, the common-council of Newcastle made an order to revoke the ordinary of this fraternity for refusing to go down and lend their assistanceCommon-council books. See under Historical Events. January 17th, 1649, th porters petitioned to have their orders restored to them., on the revolt of Tinmouth-Castle.

September 27th, 1667, a second ordinary was granted to this frater∣nity, which constituted them a body politi, sixteen in number (vacan∣cies in which by death or removal were to be filled up by the mayor of Newcastle), and ordered them to meet on Michaelmas-day, and choose two stewards, with power to make by-laws, sue, &c. in the courts of Newcastle; accompanied with a table of wagesFrom a copy inrolled as above..
January 1st, 1670, another ordinary was granted to this societyIbid..
December 14th, 1704, a new table of wages was appointed them by the common-councilCommon-council books..

DIV2.HEAD: COMPANIES EXTINCT.

DIV3.HEAD: Cooks.
DIV3.P: IN the decree of the Star-Chamber, May 2d, 1516, concerning the government of Newcastle upon Tyne, mention occurs of the craft of cooksSee charters..

An ordinary of this society, dated September 10th, 1575, and citing a more ancient one, incorporated a new seven cooks, with perpetual succes∣sion, and enjoined them to meet on the Thursday aster Trinity-Sunday every year, to choose two wardens, who were to be sworn, and might in the name of the society implead and be impleaded, &c. in the courts of Newcastle; that no brother should forestall or regrate in the mar∣kets either flesh or fish, or sell fish or flesh, boiled, baked, roasted, or otherwise, unless duly seasoned, and such as could stand search, on pain of forfeiting three shillings and four-pence; that none but persons of this society should keep shop, or dress abroad any dinners at mar∣riages, burials or churchings; that no stranger should cut fish on the Sand-Hill, without paying them an acknowledgment of thirteen-pence per annum; that the like sum should be paid yearly by those who steeped fish, or sold such steeped fish on the Sand-Hill or elsewhere; that they should receive of all fish that should be cut in the common markets, "purpoise, seal, fresh ling, cod, and other great fish, one penny out of every shilling they sold for;" and of every "purpoise and seal, the head, finns and numbles." It further ordered that every person who should sell either publickly or privately pies or pasties should pay thirteen-pence per annum to this society; that they should keep up the bonefires on the Sand-Hill every year, i. e. one on Mid∣summer-eve, and another on St. Peter's eve, if the magistrates thought fit; and that they should be ready to let forth their play among the other plays at Corpus Christi-day, if requiredFrom the book of inrolments ut supra..
This society appears to have been extinct about the year 1692, when there occurs an order of common-council to appoint a person to cut fish on the Sand-HillCommon-council books..

DIV3.HEAD: Spicers.
DIV3.P: Mention occurs of a society called the craft of spicers in the books of the merchant-adventurers, as existing A. D. 1517, in the town of NewcastleThe oath of the spicer.—"This here ye wardens of the craft of spicers, that I shall lely and trewly observe and kepe all goode rewles and actes made or shal be made by the said wardens, and by the most part of the feloship of spicers, and that I shall no maner of spice or spices occupy that belongs unto the craft of grossers and spicers bot alonly myn own nor knaw no manner of men occupye no manere of spicere perteynyng to the craft of spicers bot ysse he be als free as I to the said crafft of spicers, &c. So helpe me God and holidom and all his ballowes and by this booke."—Books of merchants-adventurers..

DIV3.HEAD: Furbishers.
DIV3.P: Mention occurs of the craft of furbishers in the decree of the Star-Chamber, dated May 2d, 1516, concerning the government of New∣castle upon TyneSee charters.—St. Nicholas' Register mentions, May 2d, 1595, "Henry Gray, furbisher.".

DIV3.HEAD: Sword-Slippers.
DIV3.P: Entries occur concerning persons of this trade in the parish registers of Newcastle, A. D. 1576 and 1586In St. Nicholas' Register, July and October, 1576, mention occurs of "William Browne, sword-slipper"—as also of Robert Peacock, sword-slipper—also, March, 1586, "Robert Heslop, sword slipper.".

DIV3.HEAD: Bowyers.
DIV3.P: The craft of "boieres," i. e. bow-makers, is mentioned in the de∣cree of the Star-Chamber, May 2d, 1516, concerning the govern∣ment of NewcastleMention occurs in St. John's Register, September 1588, of "Roland Hedley, bower.".

DIV3.HEAD: Fletchers.
DIV3.P: Mention occurs in the above decree, also, of the craft of "fletchers," i. e. arrow-makersMention occurs of "Roland Hedle, fletcher," in the books of the merchant-ad∣ventures of Newcastle, anno 32 Elizabethae—allo of "Robert Hedley, fletcher," in St. Nicholas' Register..

DIV3.HEAD: Spurriers.
DIV3.P: Part of the street in Newcastle now called Middle-street had an∣ciently the name of "Spurrier-Gate," from the circumstance of its being inhabited by persons of this trade.

As to an actual exercise of their trade, this society appears to have
been extinct before the year 1655Common-council books. December 7th, 1655, William Bryan, spurrier, petitioned leave to set up a spurrier's shop in this town, "being there is not free companye of spur∣ryers, or any in towne that served apprentice ship to that trade.". Yet in the old poll-books, per∣sons are long afterwards distinguished by this appellation.

There is a reference in Corbridge's Plan of Newcastle to the meet∣ing-house of the spurriers. An attempt was made not long ago to revive the fraternity of spurriersNewcastle Courant, April, 1771,—when Mr. Thomas White, and Mr. Thomas Pat∣tison, occur as wardens; and William Smith as a member of the spurrier's company..

DIV3.HEAD: Girdlers.
DIV3.P:
Mention occurs of the craft of girdlers in the decree of the Star-Chamber concerning the government of the town, dated May 2d, 1516
See charters.
In St. Nicholas' Register, May, 1581, mention occurs of "William Blithman, girdler:" also of "Henry Blithman, girdler," in St. John's Register, November, 1588..

DIV3.HEAD: Vintners.
DIV3.P: Mention occurs of them in the books of the merchant-adventurers, 6 Edw. VI.

DIV3.HEAD: Intended company of Watermen.
DIV3.P: In the beginning of the year 1656, the wherrymen of Newcastle petitioned the corporation of that town to be made an incorporated company. They renewed their request in the years 1675 and 1698, but still without effectCommon-council books, Fubruary 22d, 1656—Octobcr 27th, 1675—January 22d, 1698..

DIV3.HEAD: Keelmen.
DIV3.P:
Mention occurs of the craft of keelmen in the above-mentioned de∣cree of the Star-Chamber concerning the government of Newcastle, dated May 2d, 1516
In St. Nicholas' Register, "November, 1595," mention occurs of "William Malteby, parchemente-maker."
Ibid. January, 1582, of "Helias Partridg' grate-maker."
It should seem that grate-maker signifies basket-maker.—See Lye's Junii Etymologi∣cum Anglic. in verbo.
Ibid. March, 1635, "Mr. Nicholas Raine, pursuiant," occurs.
Ibid. February, 1645, a midwife is styled "grace-wyse;" French, grosse femme.
Ibid. August, 1576, "Henry Lightfoote, ymbrother" (i. e. embroiderer), occurs.
Ibid. July, 1602, "Cornelius Brandling, pictor-maker," occurs.
In All-Saints' Register, June, 1601, "John Scott, jack-maker," occurs.
Ibid. April, 1621, "Christopher Evison, clock-maker," occurs..

DIV2.HEAD: MISCELLANEOUS ACCOUNT OF OFFICERS AND SERVANTS OF THE CORPORATION OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.

DIV3.HEAD: Muster-Masters.
DIV3.P: THE earliest mention of a muster-master appointed in the town occurs in the books of the common-council, September 26th, 1638, when William Bowes, of Gateshead, Gentleman, was appointed "muster-master for the training up of youth and the trained bands within this town."—It appears ibid. that before that time, on the death of Captain Thomas Jackson, the place of muster-master had been ob∣tained by Mr. Ralph Errington from his majesty's lord lieutenants of the north, who had resigned in favour of W. Bowes. Salary 20l. per annum.
September 19th, 1642, Thomas Williamson.—Ibid.

January 18th, 1664, Henry Milborne, who had been appointed on the death of Thomas Williamson by his majesty's lord lieutenants of the north, was re-appointed at his own request by the Corporation of New-castle, with the above salary, "resigning up his commission from the said lord lieutenants, and accepting the place from the mayor and burgesses."

July 12th, 1708, Richard Stanley, ibid. with a salary of ten pounds per annum.—December 12th, 1711, Mr. Richard Stanley ordered in future to have the yearly salary of ten pounds, five pounds as a gratuity, and five pounds for looking to the arms; with a gratuity of ten pounds
three shillings" for attending several times on my Lord Scarborough, on account of the militia."

December 18th, 1729, on the petition of Mr. Thomas Potts, setting forth, that he had been appointed by commission from the Earl of Scarborough, lord lieutenant, to be muster-master of the town and county of Newcastle—ordered, that ten pounds per annum, and no more, be given him.

DIV3.HEAD: Town's Physician.
DIV3.P: Samuel Rand, M. D. was appointed town's physician, on the death of Doctor Robert Henryson, with a salary of forty pounds per annum. —Common-council books.
He was displaced for negligence April 21st, 1643, and afterwards, July 5th, 1652, re-admitted.
August 27th, 1660, Dr. George Tunstall was appointed.—The town had been without one for about six years, and from the time of Dr. Rand's death.
November 4th, 1664, Richard Luck, M. D. on the removal of Dr. Tunstall.
August 17th, 1682, Henry Atherton, M. D. was appointed.

Dr. Atherton was succeeded by Dr. Robert Grey, who must have died before March 31st, 1701, when a motion was made in the com∣mon-council to appoint either Dr. Thomas Davison, or Dr. Richard Huntley, to succeed him; but without effect, for the corporation never appointed another.

DIV3.HEAD: Town's Solicitor.
DIV3.P: The earliest account I find of a town's solicitor, is in an order of common-council, dated March 28th, 1638, when the famous Mr. John Rushworth, "he having been found to be a man verie able, and well experienced in the matters of this towne," was appointed to that office, with a salary of thirty pounds per annum.—Common-coun∣cil books.
March 17th, 1656, Mr. Samuel Hartlib was appointed town's agent at London, on the death of Mr. Maddison.—Ibid.
September 1st, 1668, Mr. Michael Tempest, and Mr. Samuel Hartlib, were appointed joint solicitors.—Ibid.

It appears (ibid.) September 25, 1684, on the removal of Mr. John Rushworth, "agent or solicitor for this towne of Newcastle," that Mr. Edward Ridley was appointed, by an act of common-council, to suc∣ceed him in that office, with a salary of thirty pounds per annum.

DIV3.HEAD: Town's Surveyor.
DIV3.P: The earliest account of the officer termed town's surveyor, that oc∣curs in the common-council books of Newcastle, is in an order, dated March 27th, 1666, when Henry Moore was appointed to that office.

The MS. Life of Alderman Barnes informs us, that one John Pig was some time land-surveyor for the town, well known both to the King (Charles II.) and the Duke of York; "and for his giddy singularities noted not only through the country, but almost through the kingdom. He usually wore a high-crowned hat, a strait coat, and would never ride, but walkt the pace of any horse hundreds of miles on foot with a quarter staff, fenced with an iron fork at one end.
"The King and Duke of York, to whom he was often trotting, made themselves sport with him, as looking upon him to be a brain∣sick enthusiast, and he was no less.

"He was of so peculiar and odd a humour, that he would not only go to prison, when he needed not, but conceitedly chose the vilest part of the prison for his apartment, where he continued a long while, when he might have had his liberty whenever he pleased. This Pig died in a stye, in circumstances not unlike those who lay hands on themselves or die crazy or distracted. Pig's Folly, near Gosforth, was erected by this man." P. 88.
September 24th, 1691, James Quincey appointed.—Common-coun∣cil books.
September 26th, 1716, William Sowerby, on the death of the abovc.—Ibid.
May 3d, 1736, Michael Dawson occurs.—Ibid.
September 26th, 1757, William Errington, on the death of M. Dawson.

April 11th, 1774, John Fenwick, on the removal of John Craister from that office
Among the inferior officers appointed by the Corporation of Newcastle, occurs one with the singular title of "whipper and hougher," who is also the executioner of felons.
He is called "hougher," from the power he is said to have had formerly of cutting the houghs, or sinews of the houghs, of swine, that were found infesting the streets of the town.—See the Glossary to Gawen Douglas's Virgil, where "to hoch," Scotch, from the Anglo-Saxon "hoh," is rendered "suffragines succidere," to hamstring.
To hox is to hamstring.—So in Knolles' History of the Turks, "alighted, and with his sword hoxed his horse."—King James VI. in his eleventh parliament, had an act to punish hochares and slayers of horses, oxen, &c".—Johnson's and Steevens's Shakespeare, vol. iv. p. 307, notes.
In the common-council books, September 24th, 1691, "James Marke" occurs.
Ibid. September 25th, 1705, Alexander Robinson appointed in the room of Thomas Cooper, to be "common executioner in hanging of felons, putting persons in the pillory, clearing the streets of swine, and to doe and perform all other matters belonging to the place and duty of the hougher.".

DIV2.HEAD:
FREE CUSTOMS OF THE CORPORATION OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE
The subsequent were the customs, &c. of this borough in the time of King Henry I. —See History of Newcastle as a corporate town.
"These are the laws and customs which King Henry granted to his burgesses of New∣castle. It is lawful to distrain the goods of rusties, and those that live in the country, within their markets and without, within their houses also and without; and that without licence of the bailiff, unless when they come to the court, or be in the army, or guarding the castle; but it is not lawful for one burgess to distrain the goods of another, without leave of the bailiff Of mayor. If a burgess inherit any thing from a villain, or other per∣son, the pleas that are moved in the borough may be pleaded there, except those that be∣long to the crown. If a burgess be indited, let him not be impleaded without the borough, unless for defect of court, nor ought he to answer concerning an appeal without day or term, unless he has happened to give a foolish answer, or in matters relating to the crown, or belore the justices itinerant.
"If a ship arrive at Tinmouth, and will not go away, by a council of the burgesses, any person may purchase merchandise of that ship.—If a plea be moved between the burgesses and an itinerant merchant, the matter may be determined before three floods of the tide. Merchandises brought to the town by sea, ought to be canied ashore, except salt and herring, which may be sold on board. Whoever shall hold land in the borough a year and a day justly, and without claim, if the claimant be within the kingdom, he is not bound to answer such claimant. If a burgess have a son at his table in his house, let the son have equal liberty with his father.—If a villain come to the borough to stay and hold land in the borough a year and a day, without any prolocution of his lord or himself to any term, let him remain in the borough as a burgess. No foreigner ought to buy cloth to dye, unless he be of the custom of the borough. Any burgess may sell his land, and go where he pleases, unless his land be indited or claimed. If a burgess be impleaded in a plea, whence battle may arise, by any villain, or inhabitant of the country, let him defend himself by the law, which he has in his custom, unless he be impeached of any crime, for which he ought justly to light, nor ought a burgess to fight with a villain, if there be not a prior claim to his burgage. It is not lawful for a foreign merchant to buy wool, skins, or any other things, either in the market or the country. The forfeiture of a burgess towards the bailiff ought to go to the common fund. In the borough there ought neither to be given merchet, heriot, bloodwit, or stengedwit. Every burgess may have a furnace and mill. If any one sell any of his bread or ale, it shall be forfeited to the bailiff, who may act thus: if he incurs the forfeit twice, he must pay it; if three, he must be punished by common-council of the burgesses. No foreigner to be permitted to cut fish to sell. A burgess may carry his corn out of the country whithersoever he pleases without licence.".
DIV2.P:
ALL the sons of a free burgess claim the franchise of their father by patrimony: there is a kind of double franchise; the fellowship with
the general body, called the freedom of the town, and that of some particular company, usually styled the freedom of a trade; and the per∣son who enjoys both is said to be free of town and trade.
If a father, possessed of a right of franchise, die before admission, all his sons forfeit their claim. No natural son can inherit the franchise.

with a right to vote for two representatives in parliament, every bur∣gess, and widow of a burgess, may claim two stints on the common and common-pasture of the town. Every freeman is also exempt from the payment of tolls, quay dues, river dues, &c. Franchise is also obtained by servitude. Anciently this servitude was in some companies for ten years; it cannot at present be for less than seven. A master, being free of the town only, cannot make his apprentice
Kennet, in the Glossary to his Parochial Antiquities, cites a deed, dated 12 Ed. III. in which the word apprentice occurs in its present sense.
A. D. 1389, "bond of apprentise" occurs in the Statutes.
An indenture of apprenticeship in Latin, dated April 6th, 149, from the Augmenta∣tion-Office, is preserved in Madox's Formulare Angulicanum.
There is a statute, 7 Hen. IV. that "none shall put son on daughter to serve as ap∣prentice to any craft in any city or borough, except they have land or rent to the value of twenty shillings per annum. Apprentices are mentioned in the ordinaries of the sadlers and glovers companies of Newcastle, dated 1436. These are the earliest accounts I have met with of this kind of servitude. free; for, in order to this, the franchise of some company is indispensable.

Some privileges are obtained by marriage: if a person who has a right to the franchise of Newcastle, marry a freeman's daughter before his admission, he pays on such admission 6s. 8d. less than those who claim the same freedom either by patrimony or servitude.

The franchise devolves on a freeman's widow; she can enfranchise the apprentices of her husband, if he had been free of any company, and she continues to carry on his bsfiness; she inherits also her hus∣band's exemption from tolls, quay dues, &c. all which are lost if she afterwards marry a non-freeman.
The franchise of Newcastle, it is said, cannot be sold, but may be presented as a gift, when it is usually styled an honorary or personal freedom.
It has been generally supposed, that an honorary freeman can neither transmit his franchise to his sons, nor confer it upon his apprentices.
The determination of this question will, probably, at some time or other, occasion much trouble to the corporation of Newcastle.
The form of the oath, on the admission of a freeman of Newcastle, concludes with an expression that seems to imply that every burgess is bound to a personal defence of the town.
It is usual, on admission, to present the mayor or alderman who ad∣mits, with a silver penny.

By the charter of the 42d of Elizabeth, March 22d, 1600, it was ordered that burgesses should be admitted by the mayor and burgesses, or common-council, whereof the mayor and six aldermen were to be seven.
By the charter of King James I. 1604, all customs, rights and liberties of the town of Newcastle, held by former charter or prescrip∣tion, were confirmed to it.

The following passage occurs in the ordinary of the bakers and brewers, dated September 28th, 1579. Every brother was enjoined to live in the town of Newcastle, and "continue therein as a burgesse of the same towne, to watch and ward, and beare scott and lott as other burgesses of the same towne ought to doe."

No freeholder in Newcastle has a right to vote for a member of parliament for that town, as such, unless he be also a free burgess thereof; neither have they votes for representatives for the county of Northumberland; so that by far the greater number of the inhabitants cannot be said to be represented in parliament.

The odium anciently entertained against the Scottish nation, and which hardly yet has subsided among the vulgar, must be referred to as one of the leading reasons, why so few of the present inhabitants of Newcastle enjoy the franchise of that town. There is a clause in the ordinary of almost every company, that no Scotsman born should be taken apprentice; and it is highly improbable that any of that once hostile people would, at least before the time of King James I. be ad∣mitted to a freedom of the town, either after residing any time in it, or on the payment of a fine: which seem to have been the ancient terms of admission.

There was an Essay on Charters published a few years ago at New∣castle upon Tyne, by Mr. Collier, in which the account of the origin of burgesses, except of the claim by servitude, is entirely chimerical, and evinces in almost every line that the writer was totally unacquaint∣ed with his subject.

DIV3.HEAD: Form of a Freeman's Oath—from an old copy.
DIV3.P:
"Newcastle upon Tyne.—You swear that you shall from henceforth hold with our sovereign Lady the Queen's Majesty that now is, and with her heirs and successors, kings and queens of England, against all persons to live and to dye and maintain the peace and all the fran∣chises of this town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and be obedient to the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and all other the officers of the same. And their counsel keep. And no man's goods avow for yours, unless he be
as free as yourself and of the same franchise: and you shall observe and keep to the best of your power all the lawful ordinances made by common consent on high court days: and all other things shall you do that belong to a freeman of the said town. So help you God.

"13 Nov. 1704. John Wheatley, cordwainer, was this day admitted and sworn a free burgess of this corporation, before the right worship∣ful Thomas Wass, Esq mayor, and stands charged with a musqt. in defence of the same. Douglas."

DIV2.HEAD: PARTICULARS CONCERNING THE CORPUS CIIRISTI PLAYS, OR MIRACLE PLAYS, ANCIENTLY PERFORMED BY THE TRADING COMPANIES OF NEWCASTLE UPON TYNE.
DIV2.P: WHATEVER relates to this subject is extremely interesting, as these miracle plays were the first and earliest of our dramatic exhibitionsWarton's History of Poetry, vol. i. p. 242..

These appear to have been acted in the open air, in what was called in some places the Play-Field, or in some spot calculated to shew the performance to the greatest crowd of spectatorsArnot's History of Edinburgh, p. 76..
They are reported to have been many of them very indelicate and obsceneIbid..

They were not without their use
Warton ut supra, vol. ii. p. 179. "Not only," he tells us, "in teaching the great truths of scripture to men who could not read the bible, but in abolishing the barbarous attachment to military games and the bloody contentions of the tournament, which had so long, pre∣vailed as the sole spicies of popular amusement.—Rude, and even ridiculous, as they were, they softened the manners of the pcople, by diverting the publick attention to spectacles in which the mind was concerned." See also Appendix to Drake's Eboracum, p. 29, 30, 31.
I know not when this kind of entertainment first began. The Chester plays appear to have been written A. D. 1328.
Mr. Warton, who smiles at the idea of their having anciently committed to the black∣smiths the handling of the "Purification," an old play so called, would have had still greater reason, could he have assigned with truth to the company of taylors "the Descent into Hell." however, not only in impressing on the rude minds of an unlettered pcople the chief histories of their
religion, but also in softening their manners, at that time very gross and impure; "creating insensibly," as Mr. Warton observes, "a re∣gard for other arts than those of bodily strength and savage valour."
In the ordinary of the coopers, dated January 20th, 1426, occurs the earliest notice I have found of any of the Corpus Christi exhibitions in Newcastle upon Tyne.

They are mentioned also in those of the smiths and glovers, A. D. 1436; barbersThe barbers to play the "Baptyfyng of Crist."—See also skinners' ordinary, January 20, 1437—also that of the armourers, &c. 38 of Henry VIII., 1442; statersThe following entry occurs in the old book of the slaters:
s. d.
"A. D. 1568. The plaers for thear dennares 3 0
Item for wyne 0 8
Item for the rede clothe 2 0
Item for the care 0 20
Item for four stoopes 0 6
Item for dreanke 0 6
Item for bearers of the care and baneres 0 18
Item in drencke 3d. to theme that bare the care and 1d. to the plaeres in drencke and 2d. the horse mete 0 6
Item for the pyper 0 6
Item for osemare 0 2
Item for detten of the swearde 0 2
Item for charcole 2d — Item for the detten of the croones 0 2
Item Bertram Sadler for plaers whan they came home from the playe in mete and drenk had 0 6."
N. B. Their play was "the Offering of Isaac by Abraham."
, 1451; sadlers 1459; and of the fullers and dyers
The following memorandums occur in the old books of the fullers and dyers:
"1561. The charges of the play this yere.
"The play lettine to Sir Robert Hert, Sir William Hert, George Walles, Robert Murton, 9s.
"First for the rehersall of the play before ye crafft 10s. Item to a mynstrell yt nyght 3d.
"Item for paynting the geyre 10s. Item for a samone trout 15d.
"Item for the mawndy loves and caks 2s. 8d. Item for wyn 3s. 6d. Item for 3 yds and a
The following entry occurs in the first leaf of their old book.
"XPS Jesus salvat nos, March day 5, anno salutis 1558
"An invoic of all the players apperell pertainyng in the oliny th plr, prderrs, glacieres and payntes.
"Bye beards to the kynges three and for the messonger one
"Item three cappes and thre sptrs and thre crownes
"Item one sterre and twey crownes
"Item box with our ordenarie and oure playe book.". lyn cloth for God's coot 3s. 2d. ob. Item ye hoysse and cot makyng 6d. Item for a payr of gloves 3d. Item for the care and banner berryng 20d. Item for the carynge of the trowt and wyn about the towne 12d. Item for the mynstrell 12d. Item for 2 spares for stanges 6d. Item for drynk and thayr suppers that wared of the paient 5s. Item for tentor howks 3d. Summa totalis 50s. ob.
"Item to the clerk this yere because of the play 2s.", 1477.

By the ordinary of the goldsmiths, plumbers, glaziers, pewterers and painters, dated 1536, they were commanded to play at their feast "the three Kynges of Coleyn
The following entry occurs in the first leaf of their old book.
"XPS Jesus salvat nos, March day 5, anno salutis 1598
"An invoic of all the players apperell pertainyng to the goldsmyth planr, pderis, glacieres and paynters.
"Bye beards to the kynges three and for the ssonger one
"Item three cappes and thre spters and thre crownes
"Item one sterre and twey crownes
"Item box with our ordenarie and oure playe book."."

A. D. 1552, mention occurs of the merchant-adventurers, as being concerned in the exhibition of five plays; one of them is assigned to the ostmen, and charged to the account of the corporation. The dra∣pers, mercers and boothmen had probably each one, and the last might belong to the spicers, who appear anciently to have been a branch of the said fellowship of merchant-adventurers
Merchants old books, A. D. 1552.
"Item paide of this reven abvesaid for the five pla the town must pay for the ostmen playe 4l. and so the playes paid for with the and ordynarie char's as aperes by perticulers wrytten in the booke of this yerey 31l. 1. 11d..

"Hogmagog" was the title of one of the plays, but I know not by which branch of the society it was acted
A. D. 1554. Ibid "For the in and aboute log aygowyl. 4l. 2s."
The charges of "Hogmagoge" occur again A. D. 1558, 14 2d.
"A. D. 1561. Corpus Christi plays for the setting orth as apers by the bu 14l. 9s. 6d.
"Anno 6 Edwardi VI. receyved that was gathered of the vntyn for the play 39s. 10d.".

An act was made by the merchants of Newcastle, March 23d, 20
Edward IV. for settling the order of their procession on Corpus Christi dayMerchants old books..

By the ordinary of the millers, dated 1578, we may infer that the Corpus Christi plays were at that time on the decline, and never acted but by a special command of the magistrates of Newcastle. "Whenso∣ever," says that authority, "the generall plaies of the towne shall be commanded by the mayor, &c." they are to play "the an∣tient playe of their fellowship, called "the Deliverance of the Chil∣dren of Isrell out of the Thraldome, Bondage, and Servitude of King Pharo
The title of the weavers' play was the "Beringe of the Crosse."
Weaver, in his Funeral Monuments, p. 405, informs us that about the beginning of the reign of King James, these Corpus Christi plays were finally suppressed in all towns of the kingdom.."

Thus also in that of the house-carpenters, dated July 3d, 1579, it is ordered, that "whensoever the generall plaies of the towne shall be plaied," they shall play "the Burial of Christ," pertaining an∣ciently to the said fellowship.

To this effect also it was ordered by that of the masons A. D. 1581, "that at all times hereafter for ever whensoever the generall plaies of the towne of Newcastle, antiently called the Corpus Christi plays, shall be plaied, they shall cause to be set forth and plaied among other plaies of the said towne the plaie antientlye named "the Buriall of our Lady Saint Mary the Virgin."

And lastly, by the joiners' ordinary, dated 1589, it was provided that "whensoever it shall be thought necessary by the mayor, &c. to comand to be sett forth and plaied or exercised any general playe or martial exercise, they shall attend on the same and do what is assigned them."

Bourne has preserved the following copy of the ancient play belong∣ing to the company of shipwrights, in Newcastle upon Tyne. I sought in vain in all the archives of the several societies of that town for another. After the reformation, they were probably destroyed in∣dustriously as reliques of popish superstition.

DIV2.HEAD: "NOAH'S ARK, OR THE SHIPWRIGHTS' ANCIENT PLAY, OR DIRGE.

SP.SPEAKER: Deus incipitur.
SP.L: Ere was this world that I have wrought
No marvel it is if I do show;
Their folk in earth I made of nought,
Now are they fully my foe.
Vengeance now will I do
Of them that have greived me ill,
Great floods shall over them go,
And run over hoope and hill.
All mankind dead shall be,
With storms both stiff and steer;
All but Noah my darling free,
His children and their wives,
Ever more yet they trow'd in me,
Save therefore I will their lives.
Henceforth my angel free,
Into earth look what thou would
Greet well Noah in this degree,
Sleeping thou shalt him find:
Bid him go make a ship
Of stiff board and great,
Although he be not a wright
Therefore bid him not lett,
He shall have wit at will,
Be that he come thereto;
All things I him fulfill,
Pitch, tar, seam and rowe.
Bid him in any manner of thing,
To ship when he shall walk,
Of all kine kind of beast and fowl,
The male and female with him he take,
Bid him go provey, say so,
In ship that they not die,
Take with him hay, corn and straw,
For his fowl and his fee.
Henceforth my angel free
Tell him this for certain;
My blessing with thee be,
While that thou come again.

SP.SPEAKER: Angelus dicat.
SP.L: Waken Noah, to me take tent.
Noah bid, if thou hear this thing
Ever whilst thou live thou shalt repent.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah respondit.
SP.L: What art thou for Heaven's King
That wakens Noah off his sleeping
Away I would thou went.

SP.SPEAKER: Angelus dicat.
SP.L: It is an angel to thee sent
Noah, to tell thee hard tiding;
For every ilk a wight for warks wild,
And many fowled in sins fair
And in felony fowly filled;
Therefore a ship thou dight to steer,
Of true timber highly railed,
With thirty cubits in defence,
Look that she draw when she is drest,
And in her side a door thou shear,
With senesters full fitly fest,
And make chambers both more and less,
For a flood that up shall burst;
Such a flood in earth shall be,
That every like life that hath lifeward,
Beast and body with bone and blood,
They shall be stormed through stress of storm;
Albeit thou Noah and thy brood,
And their three wives in your hand,
For you are full righteous and good,
You shall be saved by sea and land.
In the ship ere you enter out,
You take with you both ox and cow;
Of ilk a thing that life has lent,
The male and female you take with you,
You fetch in fother for your freight,
And make good purveiance for you prove,
That they perish not in your sight
Do Noah as I have bidden thee now.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah respondit.
SP.L: Lord be then in this stead,
That me and mine will save and shield;
I am a man no worth at need,
For I am six hundred winters old,
Unlusty I am to do such a deed,
Worklooms for to work and weild
For I was never since I was born,
Of kind of craft to burthen a boat;
For I have neither ryff nor ruff,
Spyer, sprund, spront, no sprot.
Christ be the shaper of this ship,
For a ship need make I must.
Even wo worth thou fouled sin,
For all too dear thou must be bought,
God for thanks he made mankind,
Or with his hands that he them wrought;
Therefore or ever you blind,
You mind your wife and turn your thought,
For of my work I will begin,
So well were me were all forth brought.

SP.SPEAKER: Deabolus intrat.
SP.L: Put off Harro, and well away,
That ever I uprose this day;
So may I smile and say,
I went, there has been none alive,
Man, beast, child nor wife,
But my servants were they;
All this I have heard say,
A ship that made should be,
For to save withowten nay,
Noah and his meenye;
Yet trow I they shall lie,
Thereto I make a vow,
If they be never so slee,
To taynt them yet I trow
To Noah's wife will I wynd,
Gare her believe in me;
In faith she is my friend,
She is both whunt and slee,
Rest well, rest well, my own Dereday.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor Noah dicat.
SP.L: Welcome, Fewsthere, what is thy name,
Tyte that thou tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: Deabolus dicat.
SP.L: To tell my name I were full loath,
I come to warn thee of thy skaith,
I tell thee secretly,
And thou do after thy husband read,
Thou and thy children will all be dead,
And that right hastily.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor dicat.
SP.L: Go devil, how say, for shame,

SP.SPEAKER: Deabolus dicat.
SP.L: Yes, hold thee still le dame,
And I shall tell how;
I swear thee by my crooked snout,
All that thy husband goes about
Is little for thy profit;
Yet shall I tell thee how,
Thou shalt weet all his will;
Do as I shall bid thee now,
Thou shalt weet every deal.
Have here a drink full good,
That is made of a mightful main,
Be he hath drunken a drink of this,
No longer shall he learn:
Believe, believe, my own dear dame,
I may no longer bide,
To ship when thou shall fayre
I shall be by thy side.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: This labour is full great
For like an old man as me,
Lo, lo, fast I sweat,
It trickles at our myn ee
Now home will I wende,
My weary bones for to rest,
For such good as God hath sent,
There I get of the best:
Rest well day, what chear with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor dicat.
SP.L: Welcome Noah, as might I thee
Welcome to thine own wayns.
Sit down here beside me,
Thou hast full weary baynes:
Have eaten, Noah, as might I thee,
And soon a drink I shall give thee,
Such drink thou never none afore.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: What the devil what drink is it
By my father's soul I have nere lost my wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor dicat.
SP.L: Noah, bode you tell me where about you wends
I give God a vow, we two shall nere be freinds.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: O yes dame could thou layne
I would thee tell my wit.
How God of heaven an angel sent,
And bad me make a ship,
This world he will foredoe
With storms both stiff and steer fell,
All but thee and me, our children and wifes.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor dicat.
SP.L: Who devil made thee a wright,
God give him evil to fayre
Of hand to have such slight
To make ship less or more perfect,
Men should have heard wide where
When you began to smite.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: Yes dame it is God's will,
Let be so thou not say,
Go make an end I will,
And come again full throng.

SP.SPEAKER: Uxor dicat.
SP.L: By my faith I no rake
Whether thou be friend or foe,
The devil of hell thee speed,
To ship when thou shalt go.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: God send me help in high,
To clink yon nail too,
God send me help in high,
Your hand to hold again,
That all may well be done,
My strokes be not in vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Angelus dicat.
SP.L: God hath thee help hither send,
Thereof be thou right bold,
Thy strokes shall fair be kend,
For thou thy wife has cowld.

SP.SPEAKER: Noah dicat.
SP.L: Now is this ship well made
Within and without thinks me,
Now home then will I wend
To fetch in my money,
Have good day both old and young,
My blessing with you be.

SP.SPEAKER: Deabolus dicat.
SP.L: All that is gathered in this stead,
That will not believe in me,
I pray to Dolphin prince of dead,
Scald you all in his lead
That never a one of you thrive nor thee.

DIV2.HEAD: ANNALS AND HISTORICAL EVENTS.
DIV2.P: THE memory of events, transmitted only by tradition, soon must be either defaced or destroyed. By letters alone the accounts of past actions can be handed down to us with accuracy and fidelity. The periods of time therefore preceding the discovery of the art of writing, are necessarily involved in darkness, nor can the earliest histories of nations just emerging from barbarism and ignorance, afford us a light more copious than those faint glimmerings that rather foretel than ascer∣tain the break of day: vain then would be the attempts of the topogra∣pher to rescue the particular and minute transactions of remote antiquity from the common confusion and obscurity; and we may surely rest satisfied with being unable to discover the first residents on the banks of the Tyne, on reflecting that the more general inquirer into the origin of the first inhabitants of our whole island,The earliest visitants of Britain are said to have been Grecian and Phoenician mer∣chants, about a thousand years before Christ; but our first account of its being inhabited, that can be depended upon, occurs in Caesar's description of his own attempt upon it, near fifty years before the Christian aera: there is every reason to suppose that it was first peopled from Gaul.—See a memoir on this subject by Mr. Milot, shewing that the Greeks never traded here before Julius Caesar's time.—Memoirs de l' Ac. des Inscript. vol. xxix. p. 265, 295, 12mo. cited in Gough's Topog. vol. i. p. 1. See also Richard of Cirencester, p. 50. must encounter at least equal difficulties.

The fitness of the river Tyne for the purposes of navigation would not long escape the notice of a commercial people, which the earliest inhabitants of every island must have been; nor need we doubt but that the most ancient Britons were seated on its fertile banks, and im∣posed on it a nameSee, in the account of the river Tyne, conjectures concerning the etymology of the name of this river. that has faithfully been transmitted to the present time.

Whether any village, town, or fortress, was erected by the Britons
on the site of the present Newcastle upon Tyne, forms one of those questions relating to the darker ages and our more remote antiquities, which cannot be answered by any authority of history or tradition.

Julius Agricola
See Horseley's Britannia Romana, p, 39, 40. Also the Chronological Table at the end of that work, sub anno 79. The design of these stations was evidently to cut off the communication betwixt the conquered and unconquered part of the Britons.
The "Orrea" of Ptolemy has been by some writers very erroneously fixed at Newz∣castle.—See Bale, cent. 2, p. 99, &c. &c. "Orrea" says Horseley, ut supra, p. 373, "is placed by Ptolemy about half way between Tay and Forth, and consequently must be in Fife, in Scotland. We are told in Camden, that near the water of Ore (Fife) they find lead, as also many fine crystals of several colours at the Bin and at Orrock. I think we may settle Orrea here, and Victoria at Abernethy.", governor in Britain under the emperor Titus Ves∣pasian, was probably the first that distinguished it from the common banks of our river, when he established a garrison here about A. D. 80, and made it one of that chain of military stations which extended from the eastern to the western sea, to defend the northern frontier of a Ro∣man province, against the incursions of still more northern and un∣conquered barbarians.

In the year 120, the emperor Hadrian built his vallum, wall, or rampart, nearly from the Irish sea to the German ocean, taking in the former chain of forts made by Agricola, ending it at this part of the river Tyne, over which also he threw a bridge at this place; a circumstance which gave a new appellation, that of Pons Aelius or AeliiSee under the account of Tyne-Bridge. By this time, or more probably at a still earlier period, a Roman way conducted hither from the more southern parts of the pro∣vince: I know not whether the appearance of that road in succeeding times, from the top of the hill now called Bottle-Bank, might not have given its present appellation to Gateshead, of which the simple etymology is "the head of the gate," i. e. way. See under the account of Gateshead., derived from his own family name, to the Roman station, the site of which is at present included within the walls of Newcastle.

The emperor Severus, who was here in person in the year 207, began to erect his famous wall of stone that year, which was extended across the island nearly from sea to sea, finishing it in the year follow∣ing. This stupendous monument of the Roman people passed through
the site of the present Newcastle eastward, ending at the station of Segedunum, near the village of Walls-EndHorseley's Britannia Romana..

About the year 445, Newcastle occurs under the appellation of Pons Aelii, a Roman station, where at that time a cohort of the Cornovii were in garrisonSee the Notitia Imperii, &c. supposed to be dated about A. D. 445, when the bulk of the Roman forces were stationed on the Kentish coast against the Saxon invaders, and on the northern barrier, per lineam valli, a work which appears to have been transcribed from the Latercula, or Registers of State. Gough's British Topography, vol i. p. 8..

After a silence of near two hundred years, mention occurs
In the year 650.
See "account of the churches in Newcastle."—Bede's Eccl. Hist. and Flores Histo∣riarum, by Matthew of Westminster, p. 226, where we read "in vico Regis qui vocatur Ad Murum."
That "Ad Murum" was the then name of Newcastle, seems to be clearly proved by the Itinerary of Richard of Cirencester, discovered since the publication of the Britannia Romana, and edited by a Mr. Bertram, who was so fortunate as to find the MS. in Sweden. It appears not only from the very curious ancient map affixed to this work, but also from the fourth and fifth iters described therein, that the Roman way divided at Vino∣vium, the present Binchester, in the county of Durham, from whence one of the branches conducted to Corbridge, &c. by way of Lanchester and Ebchester, while the other led through Epiacum, the present Chester-le-Street, to the town called "Ad Murum," upon the Roman wall, the present Newcastle upon Tyne, where it seems to have terminated, as no vestiges thereof have ever been traced to the north of that place.
This Richard of Cirencester lived about the end of the fourteenth century, and appears to have been the Leland of his age.—He searched all our monastic libraries, and drew up the geography of Britain from memoirs left by a Roman general, whom Dr. Stukeley persuades himself to have been Agricola. Horseley, p. 387, seems to authorise this sup∣position, observing that most of our military ways were probably laid by Agricola; none certainly were made till after Claudius' conquest, A. D. 44. Richard's is more exact and particular than Antoninus' Itinerary. Of five hundred places which it mentions in Britain and Ireland, one hundred and fifty are new or more correctly fixed.—Gough's Brit. Topog. vol. i. p. 13.
Dr. Stukeley is of opinion that the original itinerary and map which Richard copied, was constructed in Agricola's time, though afterwards additions were made to it.—Such names as ad pontem, ad murum, ad vallum, &c. intimate that the roads were generally made or marked out, but towns, cities, castles not then built. again of
this place under the new appellation of Ad Murum (at wall), and the residence of a Northumbrian king
Bede tells us that Peada, the son of Pendan, King of the Midland Angles, came to Oswin, King of Northumberland, to demand his daughter Alcfleda in marriage. Oswin refused his consent to this match, till Peada should be baptized and embrace Christianity. Either through the love of this fair virgin, or of truth, the condition was accepted, and he was baptized, together with his retinue, adds this writer, by Bishop Finan, at a royal town called Ad Murum, which, in the next chapter he tells us, was close to the Roman wall and at the distance of twelve miles from the eastern sea.—Lib. iii. cap. 21.
Dr. Smith, in his note on the above passage, differs, as he well might, from the common opinion that Ad Murum was the present Walton, a village near the confines of Cumber∣land, and above thirty miles from the sea, and fixes it at Walbottle, an obscure village, about six miles west of Newcastle. A similarity of sound in the name has, it seems, occa∣sioned both these errors, for such have our later discoveries clearly enabled us to call them; Ad Murum being unquestionably the present Newcastle upon Tyne, where there are still both traditionary and printed accounts, that the Saxon kings of Northumberland had their palace. See Grey's Chorographia, p. 12. "After the departure of the Romans, the kings of Northumberland kept their residence and had their house now called Pandon-Hall; it was a safe bulwark, having the Picts wall on the north side, and the river of Tyne on the south." The Roman measures would probably be retained in Bede's time; and if we believe Dr. Gale, who, in his edition of Antoninus' Itinerary, tells us that fifteen English miles answer to twenty Roman, his account of the distance of Newcastle from the sea will be strictly true..

During the heptarchy, which lasted from the year 587 to 826, New∣castle upon Tyne, by the name of Ad Murum, or the later appella∣tion of Monk-Chester, appears to have continued to be one of the chief seats of our Northumbrian kings
"The Saxons (who generally built on Roman foundations) held it in the greatest esteem, and during the heptarchy made it the chief seat of the kings of the Northumbers, who adorned it with so great a number of monasteries that from them it obtained the name of Munk-Chester."—Warburton's MS. Collections, penes h. v. Due. Northumbriae.
In the preface to the History of the Nunnery of Newcastle, are hazarded conjectures why Ad Murum changed its name for Monk-Chester, which cannot appear altogether improbable to those who are inclined to think, with our writers in general, that that ap∣pellation signifies "the fortified residence of monks," an etymology which, however, has been controverted by Charlton, in his History of Whitby, p. 51, where he endeavours to explain it to be a corruption of "Roman Chester.".

From the year 826, when Northumberland ceased to be a distinct and separate kingdom, till the reign of William the Conqueror, the
town of Newcastle, under the title of Monk-Chester, as part of that division of territory, known by the title of the county of Northum∣berland, appears to have remained
"Newcastel, so since, whych before was called Monk-Chester and did alwaies pertaine to the forespoken earles of Northumber."—MS. in Cotton library, Julius, c. 2, recorded in the Exchequer of Durham.
Diligent inquity has been made after coins fabricated at Monk-Chester by the earls, or at Ad Murum during the heptarchy by the Saxon kings of Nothumberland, but with out success, York having been the principal place of their mintage. without interruption in the posses∣sion of the earls of that district, who, it is probable, continued to make it one of their principal places of residence: but no mention thereof occurs in history for more than two hundred years after that period, as the scene of any remarkable transaction.

In the year 1068Warburton's MSS. penes. h. v. Ducem Northumbriae., Northumberland was invaded, and the town now called Newcastle taken by Edgar Etheling, heir to the crown of England, together with Malcolm,"In alio loco reperi scriptum anno Domini 1067, Sancta Margareta copulata suit matrimonialiter Regi Malcolmo anno regni sui decimo quarto.—Hic Angliam usque Cleve∣land vastavit, et rediens per Wetvicam, quae est ostium Weri fluminis, intravit Scotiam, & invenit ante se Fadgarum Etheling et sorores suas Margaretam & Christinam in nave latitentem pro Culros, & Margaretam matrimonio copulavit."—Johannis Forduni Scot▪ Chronicon, lib. v. cap. 18, p. 265. Boweri. King of Scotland, and some Danish pirates, whom William the Conqueror encountered in person, and over∣threw on a heath adjoining to that place, and now called Gateshead-Fell. Having recovered this place, King William is said to have laid it almost level with the ground, to prevent its becoming in future an asylum to his enemies.

In the year 1070, Monk-Chester, now Newcastle, had a second visit from William the Conqueror, who marched through it in his route to Scotland with a very numerous armyWarburton's MSS. ut supra, p. 82..

A. D. 1072, William the Conqueror passed again through New∣castle, in his way to Scotland: on this occasion, according to Matthew of Westminster, his enemy King Malcolm met him at Berwick upon
"Coins struck at Newcastle upon Tyne by Hen. 1d. 2d. and 3d. and by Edmd. 1d. and 2d."
Tradesman's Tokens, Newcastle and Gatesheads.
Coin Hadrian found in pulling up the Foundation of one of the Ps of Tyne Bridge after the Fall thereof in 1771."
To Mr. Thomas Saint of Newcastle, upon Tyne Printer and the Propter▪ this new History of that Town this Plate in Testimony of qoud. is inscribed by his very faithful humble servant. John Prtre
Tweed, and paid him homage. He is said to have built the castle of Durham on his return
Ridpath's Border History, p. 63.—Yet I find the following in Fordun's Scoti Chro∣nicon.
"Anno millesimo septuagesimo secundo Willielmus Bastard Scotiam intravit, cui oc∣currens Rex Malcolmus, in loco qui dicitur Abernethy homo suus devenit pro terris in Anglia. Rex Willielmus in reditu de Scotia temere per suos capellanos de Sancto Cuth∣berto explorare volens, territus a Dunelmo et sub velocitate recessit." Lib. v. cap. 18, p. 266. Boweri..
For an account of the building of a new castle upon the river Tyne at this town, a circumstance from which it derived the name which it now retains, see the History of "the Castle."

King Henry I. appears to have coined at Newcastle upon Tyne
See Wise's Account of the ancient Coins preserved in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, p. 99. But later discoveries have evinced his mistake, and that he attributes to King Henry I. a penny which undoubted belongs to Henry II.
His words are "HENRI REX ANGL. Regis caput barbatum corona ex gemmis et filiis ornatum, ad pectus D. sceptrum. WILLEM ON NEVCAS. Crux quatuor cruciculis intermediis." See plate of coins, A. a representation of this, from an accurate drawing taken from the original, by the Rev. Mr. Ruding
"Per Willielmum filium Willielmi Monetarii," is a passage that occurs in an account of the payment of some rents to the King, out of property in Newcastle upon Tyne, in or near the time of King John. "Arkenwaldus Monetarius" occurs ibid.
Notwithstanding the above, I have the authority of the Rev. Mr. Southgate, of the British Museum, for asserting that the first Henry certainly coined at Newcastle. I saw in that gentleman's very curious collection, a penny of that monarch, weighing 20 grains, probably the first money struck at Newcastle—the inscription round the head is "Henricus Rex;" on the reverse we read "Wulethord on Ne."—a cross fleuri, in each of the divi∣sions of which are three pellets, from the center of which arise two slender leaves. See a representation of this in the plate of coins, No. 1..

Some accounts however assure us, that King Henry the Second was the first person that established a mint at that place
"Civitas Dunelm'—Cunei monete solebant reddere 10 marcas: sed Dominus Rex Henricus secundus per cuneos quos in Novo Castello primum posuit, redditus 10 mar∣carum usque ad 3 marcas diminuit et ad ultimum cuncos a multis retro temporibus habi∣tos abstulit."—Extract from a transcript of the Boldon-Book, in the Collectanea Curiosa, vol. ii. Oxford, 1781, p. 88.
The subsequent instance of commuting an ancient judicial superstition, and relating to this place, will not be thought uninteresting.
A. D. 1140, Gospatric of Newcastle, who was perhaps the son of Gospatric, Earl of Northumberland, who had been deprived of that earldom for disloyalty in 1072, was fined 20 marks of silver for the liberty of purging himself of the judgment of the hot-iron by oath. This was a kind of purgation continued even till the reign of King John and Henry the Third. There were two sorts of it; one by fire, another by water: liber per ferrum candens, rusticus per aquam. See Madox's Exchequer, folio edit. p. 344.
In the fifth year of the reign of King Stephen, William Espec and Eustace Fitz-John were the justices itinerant for the county of Northumberland. These justices were vested with great power and authority: they determined pleas of the crown and common pleas, in like manner as did the justices of the Curia Regis. They assessed tallages and aids, and admitted men to make conventions, fines, and oblata's, in their several iters. It is not easy to discover at what time they were first instituted.— Madox's Exchequer, p. 83, folio..

About the beginning of the reign of King Stephen, the town of Newcastle appears to have been seized into the hands of David, King of Scots
The English historians, says Dalrymple, in his Collections, p. 175, &c. Edinburgh, 8vo. 1705, place in the year 1127 the feilty sworn to Maud, the Empress daughter to King Henry, as heir to the crown of England. King David her uncle gave also oath to her.
Till the year 1135, when King Henry died, it seems the good understanding continued betwixt King David and him, as it had done in the reigns of former kings; but King Stephen being placed on the throne of England, to which the Empress Maud's right was declared and confirmed by oath, King David with reason adhered to her, and made war against King Stephen. King David quickly became master of all the fortresses in Cum∣berland and Northumberland, excepting Bebbanburch, and made the nobility give oath of fealty to his niece, with hostages.
King Stephen being at Durham, invaded Northumberland. There was a peace be∣tween the two Kings in the year 1139, at the intreaty of Matilda, i. e. Maud, King Ste∣phen's Queen, niece to David, by his sisther Mary, and Countses and heiress of Bulloigne.
By this mediation, says Buchaum, it was accorded that David from Newcastle, where he commonly resided, and Stephenn from Durham, should send arbritrators for composing matters to the town of Chester-in-the-Street, situate in the midway equally distant from that place. David sent the Archbishops of St. Andrew's and Glascow—Stephen those of Canterbury and York.—This peace was made A. D. 1139., in whose possession, or rather perhaps in that of Prince Henry his son, it seems to have continued for a longtime afterwards.

This Prince Henry, whose mother was Matilda (Maud), daughter
and heiress of Valdeof, or Waltheosus, Earl of Huntingdon, the son and heir of Siward, Earl of Northumberland, had claimed the earl∣dom of Northumberland
Major, the Scottish historian, tells us, that the conditions of the peace between David and Stephen, were, that Prince Henry, David's son, should do homage to the Eng∣lish King for the free possession of the counties of Huntingdon and Northumberland. Hist. p. 110, lib. iii.
