Lesley says that peace was made between the above princes, on these conditions; that Northumberland and Huntingdon should be ceded, as of just right, by heirship of his mother, to Henry, David's son; and that Cumberland, as of ancient right, should remain in David's possession. P. 211.
Hector Boethius, p. 265, informs us to the same purport: as does also Buchanan. Dal∣rymple adds the following circumstance: that Northumberland was delivered up to Prince Henry at Durham, the 5th of the ides of April, 1139. P. 175. A charter of immunity to the monks of Durham by Earl Henry, son of the King of Scots, is preserved in Ander∣son's Diplomata Scotiae, p. 20. This cannot be of a later date than 1152.
No money appears to have been fabricated by King Stephen at Newcastle upon Tyne. by inheritance. Our historians clash in their account of this transaction: some of them setting forth that Newcastle was restored again to King Stephen
Those writers who tell us that Newcastle was reserved to the crown of England by the treaty made between the kings Stephen and David, 1139, against whose credibility as to this particular sad, the charge of inconsistency can fairly be objected, have neglected to inform us by what means it fell afterwards into t hands of the Scots, although the themselves mention the restoration of it, in the year 117, to the crown of England. So Matthew Paris, Baker, Brompton, Ralph de Diceto, and the annals of Waverley.—Ridpath, on his Border History, in order to reconcile the differences of writers on this head, sup∣poses that, in the course of the troubles that followed the above treats in 1139, David got possessions of Newcastle and Bamburgh, and held them in the name of the Empress. P. 90. It is observable that the burrough laws, in the Scottish statutes, were made by King David, and are dated at the New Castell on the water of Tyne.
Sir William de Vesci, Knt. was sheriff of Northumberland, from the year 1153 to the year 1169.—Fuller's Worthies.; but the truth of this we find controverted by many unquestionable evidences of history.

On the authority of a MS. chronicle preserved in the library of Peter-House, Cambridge, it appears that, some time in the year 1157, the King of Scots was in possession of the earldom of Lancaster, the city
of Carlisle, Bamburgh castle, and Newcastle upon TyneLeland's Collectanea, vol. ii. p. 471, new edit.: and, accord∣ing to the accounts of many of our historians
Ymagines Historiarum, autore Radulpho de Diceto apud decern Scriptores, p. 531.
Annales Waverlenses. Gale's Scriptor. tom. ii. p. 159.
Matthew Paris, Watt's edit. p. 96.
Hollingshead, p. 396, tells us that King Henry "wanne the towne of Newcastel with the castel of Bamburg.", Malcolm, King of Scots, that year surrendered to King Henry II. the above city and towns or castles, with the county of LodonComprising the counties of Northumberland, Cumberland and Westmoreland.—See Intruducto ad Hist. Scot. Boweri Fordun, vol. i. p. 47..

In the year 1173, William, King of Scots, taking advantage of the unnatural rebellion raised against
Sec Littleton's History of Henry II. vol. iii. p. 146.
Gal. Neubrigen. Hearne, vol. i. p. 212.
Mag. Brit. vol. iii. p. 624.
The names of Robert de Stureville, William de Vesci, Bernnrd de Baliol, and Ordinet Umfreville, occur in this very memorable transaction. The Duke of Northumberland has erected on the spot, marked by tradition for the place where the King was taken prisoner, a kind of square column of stone, with an inscription recording the above event.
Henry II. had a mint at Newcastle. The Rev. Mr. Southgate is in possession o a penny of that king, weighing of grains, which was struck at Newcastle. Legend round the head, which is crowned, HENRI REX ANGL. He holds a transverse sceptre— on the reverse, WILLEM ON NIVCA, with a plain cross, having four smaller crosses in the division. That in the Bodleian library has a letter more, WILLEM ON NIVCAS.
For an engraving of Mr. Southgate's, see plate of coins, No. 2. Henry II. in his family and his kingdom, appears to have invaded England. After having committed the most dreadful devastation, as far as the banks of the Tyne, he re∣treated, and sat down before Alnwick castle, in a place adjoining to which "amidst a troop of between sixty and seventy horsemen, apprehend∣ing no danger, and diverting himself with the exercises of chivalry in an open plain," he was taken prisoner by Ranulph de Glanville, sheriff of Yorkshire, with a band of horse, in which were about four hundred knights. This gallant party, who had set out from New∣castle early on the morning of the 12th of July, returned to that town
the same evening, having brought the grand enemy of their royal master along with them.—This William, King of Scots, surnamed the Lion, was afterwards confined in the castle of Richmond, till King Henry removed him, and imprisoned him at Roan in Normandy. The Scottish King was afterwards delivered up at York for the ransom of 4,000l. and a dreadful rencounter
Leland's Collectanea, vol. ii. p. 531, &c. The words are, "King William was afterwards delivered at York for the ransom of 4000l.—Souldiers of the King's going with him again towards Scotland, fought with the commons at the town of Newcastle, at the very bridge, for certain displeasures: and there was Sir John Perith, Knt. slain, and other esquires belonging to the constable and marshal."
In the year 1165, as also in 1166, Earl Geoffrey and Richard de Luci were the justices itinerant for criminal and common pleas in the county of Northumberland.—Madox's Exchequer.
In the year 1169, William Basset and Alan de Nevill, junior, Robert de Stutevill and Hugh de Morvill, were justices itinerant for Northumberland.—Ibid.
The year following Alan de Nevill and William Basset were justices itinerant for that county.—Ibid.
In the year 1175, the justices itinerant for Northumberland were, Randolph de Glan∣vill, Robert de Pikenot and Robert de Vals.—Ibid.
A. D. 1176, the justices itinerant for that county were, Randulph de Glanville, Wil∣liam Fitz-Ralph, William Basset and Michael Belet.—Ibid.
A. D. 1177, the justices itinerant for Northumberland were, Ranulph de Glanvill and his companions, William Basset and his companions.—Ibid.
In the year 1178, the same.—Ibid.
In the year 1179, Ranulph de Glanvill and his companions were the justices itinerant for the county of Northumberland.—Ibid.
When eschaces came to the crown, the justices itinerant took care within their several circuits to have them seized for the crown, and put in charge to sheriffs and other officers for the King's profit. This was done in the 33d year of the reign of Henry II. when the sheriff of Northumberland accounted for 8l. 15s. 10d. of small eschaets within the borough of Newcastle upon Tyne.—Ibid. p. 205, folio edition.
Roger Stutevill was sheriff of Northumberland from the year 1169 to A. D. 1183, as was Roger de Glanvill from 1183 to 1189.
In 119, William de Stuteville and Reginald Basset occur as sheriffs.
From 1194 to 1197, Hugh Bardolph. In 1198, Hugh Bardolph and Ot. son of Wil∣liam. In 1199, Hugh Bardolph. In 1200, William Stuteville and John Laleman. In the year 1201, Robert son of Roger, and Ralph de Furnell.
In 1202, Robert son of Roger, and Ralph de Furnell.—The same in 1203.
In 1204 and 1205, Robert son of Roger. In 1206, Robert son of Roger, and Robert de Kent. In 1207, Robert son of Roger, and Ang. de Corvo. In 1208, Robert son of Roger, and Thomas Haltem. In 1209, Robert son of Roger, and William de Blunvill. The same till 1214.
Dugdale says that Robert Fitz-Roger was sheriff of Northumberland for half the year 1200. took place at the bridge of
Newcastle, on his return to his kingdom, between his own guards and the commons of that town, who, doubtless, were highly exasperated at the redemption of an enemy whom they had so great cause both to hate and to fear.

About the year 1209, there was a conference held at Newcastle be∣tween King John and William King of ScotsBourne's History of Newcastle, p. 185 "King John commanded William, King of Scots, to meet him at Newcastle, and they met each other at Boyelton. Then the King, of Scots, went on, and the King of England came as far as Norham: and in going and returning, bore his own expences at Alnwick. A little after they both came to New∣castle, where they had a conference: but they parted without doing the business they came about." The Scottish King is said to ahve lain ill at Newcastle for a considerable time..

In the year 1213, King John marched through the town of New∣castle, on his route against Scotland with his army: but the Scottish King met him on the borders, and, by the mediation of common friends, the quarrel was made up for some time between the two king∣doms
Warburton's MS. penes h. v. Ducem Northumbriae, p. 82.
Among the fines in the 6th year of the reign of King J, I found a singular concerning the wife of Hugh de Nevill, who gave the King woumhed hens to li night with the said Hugh, at that time probably a state prisoner Cotton libr. Vjs. c. 14. p. 112, Plut. 4. B. sol. 359.
"Uxor Hugonis de Nevill dat Domingo Regi ducentas gallinas eo quod possit j una nocte cum Domino Hugone de Nevill.—Fines de anno 6 Regis Johannis .".

A. D. 1223, the men of Newcastle paid 120l. of a tallage of the manors of Northumberland, assessed by William Mauclere and Simon de HalMadox's Exchequer, p. 506. "De tallagio maneriorum assiso per w. M of Simeon de Hal, homines de Novo Castellom r. c. de 120l. de eodem.—Mag. Rot. 7 Hen. III. Ront. 2. d. Northumb.".

In the year 1233, Hugh de Bedeford, William de Hextild, Roger Williamson, and Henry de Karliol, were the bailiffs of Newcastle upon TyneMadox's Formulare Anglicanum, p. 375. "Hugone de Bedeford, Willielmo de Hextild, Rogero filio Willielmi, Henrico de Karliolo, tunc prepositis.".

A. D. 1234, there was a grievous plague at Newcastle, which con∣tinued for three yearsWarburton's MSS. ut supra. This authority adds, that in 1239 there was a drought at Newcastle for three months space, succeeded by a continual rain for the like time, and that in the following year there was a great dearth and mortality..

In the year 1236, King Henry the Third had a conference with Alexander, King of Scotland, at the town of Newcastle upon Tync
Chronicle of Mailros Abbey.—This conference was on a demand made by the Scot∣tish King for restitution of Northumberland, Westmoreland and Cumberland.
The Queen of Scotland also was present.
In the year 1225, Robert de Lexinton, Roger de Mersey, Roger Bertram, and Jurdan Hayron, were the King's justices itinerant at Newcastle upon Tyne.—Rental of the Earls of Nurthumberland remaining at Northumberland-House, fol. 114.
In the year 1214, Almericus, archdeacon of Durham, and Phil. Ulecott, occur as sheriffs of Northumberland.
In 1215, Phil. de Uleot and Will de Stratton. From 1216 to 1220, Phil. de Ulcot. In 1220, Rob. de Witer, ths Wirceser. The same in 1221.
In 1222, William Briewere, jun. and Roger Langford.
In 1223, William Briewere, jun. as keeper, and Thomas de Tetleburn.
From 1224 to 1227, John son of Robert, and William Coniers.
From 1220 to 123, Brian son of Alan, and Hugh de Magneby.
From 1231 to 1235, Brian son of Alan, and John de Mersley.
From 1236 to 1243, Hugh de Bolebet and Alan de Kirkby.
It appears, however, from a MS. in the Harlean Collction, No 644, p. 173, b. that Richard de Gray had the custody of the castles of Bamburgh and Newcastle upon Tyne, in the 2th of 21st of Henry III.
Dugle says, that, in 1218 and 1219, Hugh Bolebck, who died 1261, was sheriff..

A. D. 1238, mention occurs of silver mines in the county of Dur∣hamHian MSS. 624, p. 175, b. "Meor' seaccar' 23 Hen. III. Dunolm' die ani∣marum liberavit Robertus de Cropping sacriste Westm' ex parte Domini Regis qor platas aregenti de minera Dunolm' ponderis 14 marc' ad faciendas inde ymagines argenteas de quibus debet Domino Regi respondere prout idem Dominus Rex mandavit per eundem Robertum.".

In the year 1244, the sister kingdoms had nearly come to an open rupture, the King of England being at Newcastle upon Tyne with an army, and the King of Scots with another at Pont-Eland: a peace however was agreed upon by the mediation of the Archbishop of York, and some of the nobility, on the eve of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin. Rapin tells us, that Alexander submitted to the same homage that he himself had paid on a former occasion, and which his ancestors had been accustomed to pay. So perfect a rceonciliation took place between the contending parties on this occasion, that, before their de∣parture, a marriage was agreed upon between Alexander, the King of Scots' eldest son, and Margaret, the eldest daughter of the King of Eng∣land
Matthew Paris, p. 647, in anno 1244. He informs us that the army of Henry III. on his departure trom Newcastle, consisted of cavalry elegantly equipped, to about the number of five thousand, besides a very numerous and powerful infantry. The following record occurs in Rymer's Foedera, tom. i. p. 429, concerning this agreement:
"De pactionibus inter Regem & Scotiae Regem confirmandis.
"A. D. 1244, 28 Hen. III.—Rex omnibus &c. salutem. Noverit universitas vestra quod sacramentum quod electus frater & fidelis noster Richardus Comes Pictaviae et Cor∣nubiae fecit apud Novum Castrum super Tinam pro pactionibus inter nos et Regem Scotiae factis, ibidem confirmadis, idem comes praedictum sacramentum fecit per prae∣ceptum nostrum. Et ei firmiter praecipimus quod dictum sacramentum suum inviolabili∣ter observet. Teste Rege apud Novum Castrum super Tinam 13 die Augusti. Er ma∣dat' est Domino R. Scotiae, quod illud castrum ei liberet.".

A mandate occurs of the date of 1249, whereby King Henry the Third commanded the bailiffs and good men of Newcastle upon Tyne, to elect four persons to be moneyors in that town, and four others to have the custody of the royal mints in that place. Two goldsmiths were also to be chosen to assay the money that should be made therein, with a clerk to keep the exchange
Madox's Exchequer, fol. edit. p. 604.
For an account of the coins struck by Henry III. at Newcastle, see Folecs on Coins, edited by the Society of Antiquaries, 1763, Supplement, p. 181.
In the Rev. Mr. Southgate's collection, there is a penny of Henry III. weighing 20 grains struck at this place. The obverse, HENRICVS REX III. The King's head full faced, with a coronet—mint mark a star—reverse, IOH ON NEWECAS—a double cross, in the divisions of which are three pellets. This is of his second coinage. See plate of coins in this work, No. 3.
A penny of this second mintage is engraved in Withy's Coins, Plate V. The head the same as the foregoing, but the reverse is Roger on Newec.
In the time of King Henry III. Northumberland appears to have been infested with wolves, as I find by the following entry in the Harleian MSS. "Duodecima pars sfcaetor temp. R. H. fil. Reg. Johannis.
"Idem Henricus tenuit de Rege in capite in com' Northumbriae manerium de Laxton— per serjentiam ad fugand' lupum cum canibus suis per quatuor com'—Undecima pars ibid.—idem Vitali tenuit manerium de Laxton—de Rege in capite per serjentiam cur∣rendi ad lupum ad mandatum Regis."
Under the year 1245, the chronicle of Mailros relates a marvellous story of a rich burgess of Newcastle upon Tyne, who labouring under an extreme weakness that had almost deprived him of motion, was warned in his sleep to visit the foot of Simon de Montford, a relique in high estimation, and kept at that time at Alnwick Abbey, and which afforded him, as the same authority adds, a miraculous relief.—Credat Judaeus Apella.—This foot, which was said to be supernaturally preserved, was inclosed in a shoe of silver.
In the year 1243, Robert Camhoe, of Camhoe, Knight, was sheriff of Northumbe∣land. In 1244, Hugh de Bolebeck and Robert de Cambo. The same 1245. From 1246 to 1256, William Heetun, Robertus de Nevill was sheriff of Northumberland..

In the year 1251, Peter Scott was appointed the first mayor of New∣castle upon Tyne: Henry de Karle, Stephen de Lindesey, Thomas de Merchingle, and Robert de Galesmith, were bailiffs that yearI have collated Bourne's list of the mayors, bailiffs, and sheriffs of Newcastle upon Tyne, with other MS. accounts, and have ventured to translate the names, which in old writings generally occur in Latin, where I thought I clearly understood them. It must be observed, that the mayor's years are to be reckoned from the Monday after Michael∣mas-day to the same term in the year following..
The year following the town was governed by the same mayor and bailiffs.
In 1253, the same mayor was continued, and the bailiffs were Henry de Karle, Roger le Dyer, Thomas de Karle, and Adam Clerk.
In the year 1254, Henry Carleiol was mayor, and Robert le Valet, Nicholas de Wainford, Thomas de Carleol, and Nicholas Scott, bailiffs.
A. D. 1255, the same mayor was continued, and Richard de la Haye, Thomas de Karle, junior, Bartholomew Clerk, and Walter de Ponte, were bailiffs.
Ring Henry III. visited Newcastle upon Tyne this year—an affec∣tionate desire to see his daughter, the Queen of Scots, was probably the cause of this journey.

He was accompanied by the Queen, and their interview with the King and Queen of Scotland was at Werk castle
Warburton's MS. collections ut supra.
Also Rymer's Foedera, tom. i. p. 561.—The King dates from Newcastle on the 25th and 28th of August; as also on the 25th of September that year.
In the same tome of the Foedera there occurs a letter of King Henry, dated Septem∣ber 2d, 1255, from Alnwick. "De potestate conducendi Regem et Reginam Scotiae in presentiam Regis."
In the year 1250, Walter de Kirkham was made bishop of Durham, instead of Nicho∣las Farnham, who had obtained licence of the Pope to resign his bishoprick the preceding year..
In the year 1256, the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
A. D. 1257, there was the same mayor, and Nicholas Scot, Tho∣mas de Merchingle, Adam Clerk, and John Sant, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
A. D. 1259, the same mayor continued, and Thomas de Karle, Adam de Blagedon, John Witherold, and John Sant, were bailiffs.

The two following years there were the same mayor and bailiffs
Walter de Kirkham, Bishop of Durham, died in August, 1260, and was succeeded by Robert Stichell.
In the year 1257, John de Plesset was sheriff of Northumberland—also 1258.
In 1259 and 1260, Thomas son of Michael. From 1261 to 1266, Adam de Jesmont (alias Cresnor), and John Lidegreynes. In 1267 and 1268, Wischard de Charny. An old deed in the Augmentation-Office is witnessed, inter alios, by "Domino Wiscardo d Charun tunc vicecomite.".
In the year 1262, the same mayor continued, and Adam Clerk, Nicholas Scott, and Adam de Blageden, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs continued.
A. D. 1264, Thomas Carleiol was mayor, and Robert Mitford, Henry le Scott, John le Fleming, and Henry de Burneton, were bailiffs.
The two following years the same mayor and bailiffs continued.
In the year 1267, the same mayor continued, and John Rogerson, Henry Scott, John le Fleming, and Henry de Burneton, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1268, the same mayor and bailiffs continued.

June 30th, 1268, the King appears to have made a grant of New∣castle upon Tyne, among many other places, to his son Edmund and his lawful heirs
Memoranda in scace'. Mich. 9 Ed. I. Sir John Maynard's Reports, p. 10, folio, 1678. It is called Novum Castrum subtus Tynam.
It is asserted that no coin of Richard I. was ever struck. in England..

In the year 1269, Nicholas Scott
Nicholas Scot is styled "capitalis balivus."
In the year 1274, August 4th, Robert Stichell, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Robert de Insula.
In 1269, 1270, and 1271, Richardus de Charny was sheriff of Northumberland.— From 1272 to 1274, Robert de Hampton. From 1275 to 1277, John de Liche greynes.
A. D. 1269, Gilbert de Preston and his companions occur as justices itinerant of Newcastle upon Tyne, on the morrow of the apostles Pete and Paul.—Rental of the Earls of Northumberland remaining at Northumberland-House. was mayor, and Henry de Karle, Thomas de Karle, Adam de Blageden, and Thomas de Karle, junior, bailiffs.
The year following there were the same.
A. D. 1271, Thomas de Karle was mayor, and Hugh de Merchingle, Thomas de Karle, junior, Robert de Lindsay, an —, were bailiffs.
The same were continued the year following.
In the year 1273, the first of Edward I. the same mayor was con∣tinued, and Hugo de Merchingle, Thomas de Karle, junior, Henry de Burneton, and Robert de Lindesey, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor continued, and John le Flem∣ing, Adam de Blageden, John Santmarays, and Richard de la Hay, were bailiffs.
In the year 1275, John Rogerson was mayor, and Robert de Mit∣ford, John de Darton,—, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1276, Thomas de Carleol was mayor, and John Rogerson John Torrand, Henry Scott, and —, were bailiffs.
In the year 1277, Thomas Karle was mayor, and William Fran∣cays, Henry Scot, Thomas de Karle, junior, and —, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1278, John Rogerson was mayor, and Hugh de Merchingle, John le Fleming, Robert de Lindesay, and —, were bailiffs.
In the year 1279, Thomas de Karle was mayor, and Richard de Hay, Hugh de Merchingle, Henry de Burneton, and Richard Roger∣son, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1280, John Rogerson was mayor, and Richard de la Hay, John Fleming, Henry de Burneton, and John Gadrick, were bailiffs.
In the year 1281, John Rogerson, Knight, was mayor, and Robert de Mitforde, Robert de Lindsey, Richard Rogerson, and John le Scot, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1282, Robert Mitford was mayor, and John de Blamarge, Adam de Pampdon, John de Lindesay, and John le Scot, were bailiffs.

In the year 1283
June 13th, 1283, Robert de Insula, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Anthony Bee, whom the Pope made patriarch of Jerusalem.
In 1278 and 1279, Walt. de Cannblion was sheriff of Northumberland.
From 1280 to 1287, Thomas de Dyveleston. I suspect the former name ought to be "Cambhou."
In the year 1279, John de Vallibus appears to have been one of the justices itinerant upon the northern iter.—Tinmouth Chartulary MS. folio 205.
It appears ibid. 206, that the justices itinerant held their courts in the churches at that time. "Anno R. R. E. 8vo.—1280—Coram quibus justic' comparnuerit prior et alii in ecclesia Sancti Nicholai de Novo Castro, et prior allegavit, &c.—Quod quidem br Dominis G. et M. justic' in ecclesia Sancti Andreae Novi Castri fuerat ex parte Domini Regis per predictum priorem traditum, &c.", William de Hawkwell was mayor, with the style of "custos villae," and Thomas de Witham, John de Heyton, William de Ogle, and —, were bailiffs.
The year following the same person was mayor, and John Flanders, Adam de Pampeden, John Scott, and Robert de Lindesey, bailiffs.
In 1285, the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
In the year 1286, Henry le Scot was mayor, and John Fleming, John le Scott, Hugh de Carliol, and Henry de le Hey, were bailiffs.
In the year 1287, the same mayor was continued, with the title of capitalis ballivus, and John de Blageden, Thomas de Tindale, Peter Draper, and John Surreys, perhaps Surtees, were bailiffs.
In the year 1288, the same person was mayor, and John Fleming, John le Scot, Richard Rogerson, and Hugh de Carle, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1289, the same mayor continued, and Thomas de Tindale, Henry de Karle, Peter Draper, and William de Ogle, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs continued.

In the year 1291, Hugh de Carliol was mayor, and Roger Tun∣nock, Henry le Hay, Peter Sampson, and Alexander de Cowgate, were bailiffs. In the April of this year the King appears to have been at Newcastle, having dated two letters from thence, the one on the 23d, the other on the 28th of that monthRymer's Foedera, tom. ii. p. 525..

Edward I. appears also to have had his mints, and to have coined at Newcastle upon Tyne
See Folkes on Coins, edited by the Society of Antiquaries of London, 1763, Sup∣plement, p. 176. Reverse. VIL NOVCASTRI.
There occurs also a halfpenny—reverse, NOVCASTRI.
I have one of the above in fine preservation, which was the kind present of Mr. John White, of Newgate-Street, London.
I have another and similar coin as to the head—the reverse, VILL NOVICASTRI, containing two letters more than the above.
There is in Mr. Southgate's curious collection mentioned before, a penny of Edward I. weighing 20 grains: inscription on the obverse, EDW. R. ANGL. DNS. HYB.—king's head crowned, full faced.—Reverse, VILL NOVICAS RI—a plain of, three pellets between each division—See plate of coins in this work, No. 4.
In Dr. Hunter's collection is a halfpenny of Edward I. coined at Newcastle.
There is another in Mr. Me's collection, which weighs 9 grains.—See plate of coins in this work, No. 5.
From 1288 to 1292, Richard Knoul was sheriff of Northumberland.
In the year 1292, Hugh de Cressingham and his companions were the justices itinerant for the county of Northumberland: they occur at Newcastle on the morrow of St. Hil∣lary that year.—Murray MS..
In the year 1292, Hugh de Carliol was mayor, and John de Sur∣reys, Sampson le Cuttelar, William de Ogle, and Walter de Cowgate, were bailiffs.

A remarkable event distinguished the feast of St. Stephen this year at Newcastle upon Tyne; John BaliolRymer's Foedera, tom. ii. 694, or 594., King of Scotland, having, against the willBoethius' Hist. Scot. p. 293. "Eodem anno in festo Stephani Edwardo ad Novum Castrum in verba ipsius, invitis primoribus, se (Johannes Baliolus) regnumque suum in servtutem, cum antea omnia semper libera fuissent, tradens." of his own nobles, if we may credit Boethius, done homage on that day, for his crown, to the King of England, in the hall of his palace, within the castleThe words of the original record are, "In aula palatii ipsius Domini Regis infra castrum." of that town: the ceremony
The acknowledgment was delivered in the French language, as follows:
"Mon Seignour, mon Sire Edward, Rey d' Engleterre, soverein seignour du reaume de Escoce, Je Johan de Baillol, Rey de Escoce, devien vostre homme lige de tot de reaume de Escoce ove les aportenances e a qont qel y a peut: le quel Je tieng e Dei de dunt, e cleim, por moi e mes heyrs, reys de Escoce tenir heritablement de vous e de vos heyrs, reys d' Engleterre, de vic e de membre e de teriien honeur, contre toute gent qe porunt vivere e morir"—Rymer's Foedera ut supra. was conduct∣ed with much solemnity, and in the presence of a number of great personages of both nations
John, Bishop of Durham, Robert de Typtot, Nicholas de Segrave, William de Lev∣burne, Brian son of Alan, Gilbert de Thornetone, Knights; John de Langetone, Chan∣cellor of England; Hugh of Cressyngham, John Woughan, Master John Lovel and Waltir de Langetone; all of the kingdom of England.—The Bishops of St. Andrew's and Glascow; John, Abbot of Geddeworthe; John, Earl of Boughan; Patrick, Earl of March; Gilbert de Umfranville, Earl of Aneguz; J. Earl of Atheylles, John Comyn, Alexander de Bailliol, Thomas Randulph, Geoffry de Montbray, William de St. Cler, Richard Syward, Yngelram de Umfranville, Andrew de Murray, Thomas Randulf, son of David de Torthorald, Michael de Wymes, Richard Fraser, Andrew Fraser, Alex∣ander de Bonekyl, and John de Strivelyn, of the kingdom of Scotland.
The fees for his vassalage are said to have been fixed at 2l. for want of a precedent, double the sum paid by an carl on the like account.—Acta Regia, vol. 1. p. 72, 73, 8vO..

A quarrel soon arose between Edward and the Scottish King, who was summoned by the former to meet him at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the 1st day of March, 1296. Edward attended at that place at the time appointed, and waited there a great while to no purpose, Baliol having refused to obey his summons
See Rapin—Brady's Continuation Hist. Engl. p. 8.
From the year 1293 to 1295, Hugh Gubium was sheriff of Northumberland.
In the year 1293, Hugh de Cressingham and his compns occur as the justices itinerant at Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of Northumberland.—Ryey's Plead. p. 18..
In 1293, there were the same mayor and bailiffs as the preceding year.

In the year 1294, Hugh de Gubyone was mayor (mention occurs of him with the titles of "knight, sheriff of Northumberland, and custos villae Novi Castri), and Robert de Mitford, William de Ogle, Thomas de Whickham, and John de Heaton, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1295, Hugh de Carleol was mayor, or capitalis balivus, and John de Surties, William de Ogle, Sampson le Cuttelar, and Walter de Cowgate, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
In the year 1297, John Scot was mayor, and Thomas de Tindale, John son of Adam de Blagdene, William de Ogle, and Peter Draper, were bailiffs.
They continued the six following years.

In the year 1297, the Scots renewed their former hostilities, by making an inroad into England, slaying the inhabitants of Northum∣berland, and burning and laying waste the country: the inhabitants, with their wives, children, furniture and cattle, sled to Newcastle upon Tyne, whither also the enemy marched down the northern bank of the river: the townsmen having made every necessary preparation for
resistance, sallied forth in order to fight them, upon which the Scots turned another way
Brady's Continuation, p. 61.
Walter Hemingford, vol. i. p. 136, ed. Hearne. They were insulted on this occa∣sion by the inhabitants of the village of Riton, upon which they crossed the river and burnt the place..
At a parliament held at York A. D. 1298, there was a general sum∣mons to appear in arms at Newcastle upon Tyne, in eight days, to proceed against the Scottish rebelsParliamentary History, vol. i..

In the year 1299, William Wallace, the famous champion of Scot∣land, wasted Northumberland as far as the walls of Newcastle upon Tyne, which he often assailed to no purpose, having been as often repulsed by the valour of the inhabitants
Warburton's Collections, penes h. v. Ducem Northumbriae.
Polydore Virgil, on I know not what authority, says, that the Scots were victorious, and pulled down and burnt the town. P. 240.
The King of England appears to have been at Newcastle on the 23d of November this year.—Warburton's MSS. ut supra.
He took the banner of St. Cuthbert with him into Scotland on this occasion.
One thousand stock-fish, &c. were purchased at Newcastle for the garrison of Stryvelyn castle in Scotland during this war.—Wardrobe Account of Edward I. 28th year, p. 169 and 143.
John de Kirkby was sheriff of Northumberland in 1297, and 1298 Robert de Baliol.
Another account says, in 1297 William de Halton was sheriff. In 1299 and 1300 Roger Mynot was sheriff (alias Mignot).
In 1297, died at Newcastle upon Tyne, William Heron, son of John Heron, who was constituted governor of Bamburgh castle, in the 32d of Henry III. and soon after of the castles of Pickering and Scarborough, in Yorkshire. He held a barony in Northum∣berland, by the service of one knight's fee, as his ancestors had done since the conquest. —See Dugdale's Baronage, tom. i. p. 730..
The King appears to have been at Newcastle upon Tyne in the beginning of the year 1302See Foedera, tom. ii. p. 899..
In the year 1304, Peter le Draper was mayor, and Nicholas de Carliol, Thomas de Frismarisco, Richard de Emeldon, and John Corane, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1305, the same mayor continued, and Nicholas Scot, Nicho∣las de Carleol, Thomas de Frismarisco, and William de Oggle, were bailiffs.

In the year 1306, Richard de Emeldon was mayor, and Nicholas Scot, Adam de Gallowaie, William de Oggle, and Thomas de Fris∣marisco, were bailiffs. This year John de Seyton, one of the esquires of Robert Bruce, having been taken prisoner, was conducted to New∣castle upon Tyne, and there hangedRidpath's Border History, p. 229. Matthew Westminster, Flores Historiar. p. 461. Leland's Collectanea, vol. i. p. 271, new edit..
In the year 1307, the 1st of Edward II. the same mayor continued, and Richard de Acton, Adam de Dunelm', William de Burnton, and Thomas Frismarisco, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1308, Nicholas de Carliol was mayor, and Thomas de Fris∣marisco, Nicholas Scot, Thomas de Tindale, and Adam de Dunelm', were bailiffs.

The year following the same mayor continued, and Thomas de Fris∣marisco, Gilbert le Fleming, Thomas de Tindale, and Adam de Dur∣ham, were bailiffs
July 30th, 1309, Henry de Percy had a precept from the King, signifying to him that the Scots having broken the truce made with them, at the request of Philip IV. King of France, he had ordered his army to be at Newcastle on Michaelmas-day; and there∣fore commands this Lord Percy to meet him there, with horse and arms, to go with him against the Scots.—Collins's Peerage, vol. ii. p. 304, ed. 1779.
In 1301, John de Cambhow was sheriff of Northumberland; and in 1302 and 1303, Lucas Talboys. From 1304 to 1306, John de Creppunge and John de Sheffld.
In 1307, Robert de Faudon. In 138, Guido Charrowin. In 139 and 1310, John de Cannton. From 1311 to 1313, William de Felton and John Cannton..

September 1st, 1310, King Edward II. was at Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. iii. There occurs ibid. July 30th, 13, an order to the Archbishop of York, with many others, to be at Newcastle on the least of St. Michael next, with horse and arms, &c.. This year Nicholas de Carliol was mayor, and Thomas de Carliol, Gilbert Fleming, Thomas de Tindale, and Adam de Durham, were bailiffsI know not how to reconcile the following account of Stow, in his Survey of London, p. 262, where, speaking of the monuments in the parish church of St. James, Garlick Hithe, he tells us, there was one "of Robert Gabeter, maior of Newcastle upon Tyne, 1310.".
In the year 1311, Richard Emeldon was mayor, and Hugh, son of Thomas de Carliol, Thomas de Frismarisco, Adam de Durham, and —, were bailiffs.

About the latter end of the year 1311Rymer's Foedera, tom. iii. p. 334. Brady's Appendix—Rapin's History., a great confederacy was formed by the nobles and others of England, called Contrariants and Ordainers, against Piers Gaveston, the well-known minion of King Edward II. The King retired with him to York, where he kept his Christmas, and received a petition either to deliver him up, or to ex∣pel him the kingdom. Having no inclination to do either, he re∣treated still farther north with him to Newcastle upon TyneJohannis de Trokelowe Annales Ed. II. p. 15, 16., where they continued till Ascension-day, 1312. The incensed barons, headed by the Earl of Lancaster, and accompanied by all the forces they could raise, pursued him thither. The King having received intelligence of their approach, fled with his hated companion to Tinmouth, where his Queen, then pregnant and near her delivery, at that time resided: from thence, having procured a vessel in the river Tyne, notwith∣standing her tears and intreaties not to abandon her in that place, he sailed with Gaveston to Scarborough. The Earl of Lancaster, after he had taken possession of Newcastle, sent down to Tinmouth to con∣dole with the afflicted Queen, whom reasons of state forbade him to visit in person. The said Earl, who with the barons had entered New∣castle the same day it was deserted by the King and his minion, seized the effects which their great haste had prevented them from removing with them. In Gaveston's baggage were found many jewels of great value: of these they took an exact inventory, and, after his death, restored them to the King
Foedera, tom. iii. p. 387, a writ for the safe conducting of the jewels to be restored.
March 28th, 1311, Anthony Bec, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Rich∣ard Kellowe..
In the year 1312, Richard Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas de Carleol, Gilbert Fleming, John Pampden, and Henry de Newton, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor continued, and John, son of Henry Scot, Thomas Frismarisco, William Burneton, and John El∣lickar, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1314, Thomas, son of Hugh de Carliol was mayor, and Gilbert Fleming, John de Pampden, Henry de Newton, and Adam de Durham, were bailiffs.
The King appears to have been at Newcastle upon Tyne in the month of June this yearRymer's Foedera..
A military rendezvous was ordered to be at that place on the feast of the blessed VirginCollins's Peerage, vol. i. p. 36, ed. 1779..
In the year 1315, Richard de Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas Frismarisco, Richard Acton, Adam of Durham, and John de Pampe∣den, were bailiffs.

The whole militia of England were ordered, by advice of the parlia∣ment held at Lincoln, to rendezvous at Newcastle upon Tyne, at the feast of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary this yearFoedera, tom. iii. p. 523. Daniel's History..

In 1316, the same mayor continued, and three of the same bailiffs; William de Burneton was the fourth, instead of John de Pampden. Fifteen days after Midsummer this year, another rendezvous was ordered to be at Newcastle upon Tyne, on another expedition against, Scotland.
It was afterwards prorogued till the feast of St. Laurence, and after∣wards farther postponed till the octaves of St. MichaelFoedera, p. 553, 563, 569. Also Parliamentary History, vol. i..

In 1317, the same mayor and bailiffs were continued. There was a grievous famine and mortality at Newcastle this yearBourne in anno. "Insomuch," says he, "that the quick could hardly bury the dead —and a great corruption of cattle and grass. Some eat the flesh of their own children; and thieves in prison devoured those that were newly brought in, and greedily eat them half alive.".

In 1318, Richard de Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas, son of Ralpi. ThorauldAltered from Bourne's List, on the authority of a deed preserved in All-Saints' vestry, dated 29th of October that year., Robert de Angerton, Gilbert Hankyn, and Adam de Durham, were bailiffs.

Nov. 24th this year, the King charged the receiver of his victuals at Newcastle upon Tyne, with the delivery of forty casks of wine to the inhabitants of Northumberland, as a compensation for their losses by the incursions of the Scots
Foedera, tom. iii. p. 742.
In 1316, Richard Kellow, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Lewis Beau∣mont.
In 1314, May 3d, William de Ridell, of Swinburn castle, Knight, was appointed, dur∣ing pleasure, sheriff of Northumberland (Wallis, p. 65). No other occurs till 1320. Yet another account "e duabus chartis antiquis" makes John de Fenwick sheriff in 1322, and Gilbert Boroughd in 1323. In the Tinmouth Chartulary at Northumberland-House, "Johanne de Fenwyk milite" occurs as sheriff of Northumberland, and as witness to a deed dated on the Sunday next after the feast of St. James the Apostle, 14. Ed. II. A. D. 1320..

In the year 1319, Nicholas de Carliol was mayor, and Thomas de Carliol, Roger Hecham, Thomas de Frismarisco, and Henry de New∣tonA deed remaining in St. Andrew's vestry, makes the bailiffs in 1319, Thomas de Tindale, John de Thornad, Thomas de Frismarisco, and Richard Emeldon., were bailiffs.

A rendezvous of the army was ordered to be at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the Nativity of St. John the Baptist this year, to go against the ScotsFoedera, tom. iii. p. 774, 784. Five hundred quarters of wheat (in flour) were or∣dered to be sent out of Hampshire, by the sheriff of that county, to Newcastle upon Tyne, for the use of the army.—Madox's Exchequer, p. 262..
A. D. 1320, the same mayor continued, and Thomas de Tindale, John de Thornad, Thomas de Frismarisco, and Richard Emeldon, were bailiffs.

In the year 1321, Richard Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas de
Frismarisco, Gilbert Hankin, Richard Acton, and Robert Angreton, were bailiffs.

A meeting of commissioners to treat of a final peace between Eng∣land and Scotland, was ordered to be held at Newcastle upon Tyne, on Candlemas-day, 1321Foedera, tom. iii. p. 862. Border History, p. 266, et seq..

A. D. 1322, Nicholas Scot was mayor, and Gilbert Hanking, Tho∣mas Carlyne, William de Burneton, and Robert de Angerton, were bailiffsAltered from Bourne's List, on the authority of a deed in St. Andrew's vestry, dated 1322..

A. D. 1322, a general rendezvous
A dangerous quarrel happened at Newcastle, on this meeting, between the English and Welsh infantry.—Wardrobe Account, 15th, 16th, and 17th of Ed. II. penes Th. Astle, Armig. p. 36. "Jevanno ap Griffith ap Thuder Eunoni Craghbyn Jorum ap Gadegan Maddoco ap Madok Vaghan Edmetto ap Helta Kenewrek ap Heyhn & Madoco Cragh Wallensibus vulneratis apud Novum Castrum super Tynam in quadam contumelia nuper orta inter pedites Angl' et Wall' in transitu Domini Regis per ibidem versus partes Scotie cum exercitu suo mense Augusti anno 16, et morantibus ibidem sumptibus Domini Regis per preceptum suum ad curand' pro vadus suis pro 36 dies 10 die Augusti primo computato per quos moram fecerunt ibidem in cura. Quolibet eorum percip' per diem 2d. 42s. Et pro stipendio Thome de Lound cirugici intendentis ad curam eorutelem 7 Wallens' Et pro diversis medicinalibus emptis pro eisdem infra tempus predictum 20s. Summa 62s."
July 18th, in the 16th year of his reign, the King appears to have been at Durham, and to have offered at the shrine of St. Cuthbert, in the conventual church there, an ouch of gold, &c. of the King's forces was or∣dered to be held at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the feast of the Holy TrinityFoedera, tom. iii. p. 946, 952.. A rendezvous was also ordered to be at the same place on the eve of St. LukeBorder History, p. 272. that year, which was prevented by another in∣cursion of the Scots into England, who penetrated as far as Yorkshire, and nearly took the King of England, then residing at Byland in that county, a prisoner. They are said to have besieged NewcastleWarburton's MSS. penes h. v. Ducem Northumbriae.—"They beleaguered Newcastle with a numerous army, and being repulsed, proceeded to York." on this occasion, but met with a vigorous repulse.

On the execution of Andrew de Hartela, Earl of Carlisle, who had suffered death for treason, one quarter of his body was ordered to be put up on the keep of the castle of Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. iii. p. 999. Border History, p. 272. His sentence was, "that his sword should be taken from him, and his gilt spurs hacked off from his heels; that he should be drawn and hanged by the neck, his heart and bowels taken out of his body, burnt to ashes and winnowed: his body cut into four quarters, one to be set upon the principal tower of Carlisle castle, another upon the tower of Newcastle upon Tyne, a third upon the bridge at York, and the fourth at Shrewsbury, and his head upon London bridge:" which judgement was executed upon him accordingly on the morrow after St. Chad's day.—Dugdale's Baronage, tom. ii. p. 98..
In the year 1323, Richard de Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas de Frismarisco, William de Burneton, William Hankin, and Hugh de Heckam, were bailiffs.

A rendezvous of the King's forces was ordered to be at Newcastle upon Tyne this year, on the octaves of St. John the Baptist: this was happily prevented, for a peace was concluded at that town about Ascen∣sion-day the same year, by the commissioners of both nations: this was to last for thirteen yearsFoedera, tom, iii. p. 14 and 1012..
A. D. 1324, the same mayor continued, and Thomas de Frisma∣risco, Gilbert de Hankin, William de Burneton, and Robert de Hal∣liwell, were bailiffs.
In the year 1325, the same mayor and bailiffs continued.
In the year 1326, Richard de Emeldon was mayor, and Thomas de Frismarisco, William de Burneton, Gilbert Hankin, and Hugo de Heckam, were bailiffs.

There was an order of the King, dated Sept. 3d, 1326, for provid∣ing ships against the attacks of the French, by which Ralph de Nevill, Thomas de Grey, John de Fenwyk, and John de Lilleburn, were com∣missioned to superintend that business in the ports of Tynemouth, Donstanburgh, Whiteby, Alemuth, Hertilpool, Werkworth, New∣castle upon Tyne, Newbigging, and Holy Island
Foedera, tom. iv. p. 225.
In 1323, John de Fenwick occurs as sheriff of Northumberland.—Wardrobe Account, 16 Ed. II. penes Th. Astle, Armig. By the same authority, p. 281, Gilbert Burghdon succeeded him in that office.
In 1326, John de Insula (Lisle) and John de Fenwick occur as sheriffs of Northumber∣land.
From 1327 to 1332, John de Littlebourne was sheriff.
Edward II. coined at Newcastle upon Tyne. There is a penny of this King struck there, in Dr. Hunter's collection; another in Mr. Miles's, and a third in Mr. Hodsol's. After this time the mint ceased at Newcastle. In Withy's Coins, Plate VII. a penny of this second Edward is by mistake attributed to King Edward the Third. Edward the Second's are known by EDWA, or EDWAR, or EDWARD. Mr. Miles's penny of this King struck at Newcastle, weighs 21½ grams.—See plate of coins in this work, No. 6..

In the year 1327, the 1st of Edward III. Sir Nicholas Scot was mayor, and Thomas Dankin, Gilbert Hankin, William de Burneton, and Hugh de Heckam, were bailiffs. A summons was issued for all the King's military vassals to attend him at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the Monday before Ascension-day this yearFoedera, tom. iv. p. 282.. The King did not at∣tend in person, but deputed his uncle the Earl of Norfolk, marshal of EnglandBarnes' Ed. III. p. 6.. About the middle of the June following, the Scots made an inroad into EnglandRidpath's Border History, p. 983. Yet in a note he tells us, "it is said in Leland's Collections from Scotch Chron. xi 551, that the unskilfulness of the English leaders in war hindered then from going forth against Lord Douglas, although he burnt the coun∣try within three miles of Newcastle.", and passed the Tyne so privately, as not to have been perceived by the garrisons of Newcastle or Carlisle.
December 10th this year, mention occurs of a treaty having been lately held at Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. iv. p. 328..
In the year 1328, Nicholas de Carliol was mayor, and Thomas, son of Hugh de Carliol, Roger Heckham, Thomas de Frismarisco, and Henry de Newton, were bailiffs.
This year articles of peace were propounded between the two king∣doms at Newcastle upon TyneParliamentary History, vol. i..
A. D. 1329, Richard Emeldon was mayor, and William Burneton Hugo de Heckam, John de Denton, and Robert de Halliwell, were bailiffs.
In the year 1330, William de Burnton was mayor, and Hugo de Hankyn, John Denton, Robert de Halliwell, and Walteranus Lumley, were bailiffs.

A. D. 1331, Richard Emeldon was mayor, and John de Denton, Gilbert HawkynSee Bourne's account of the Nunnery.—I find also "Thomam Daulyn" as one of the bailiff in a record of that date., Hugh de Heckam, and Richard Scot, were bailiffs.
In the year 1332, the same mayor, who had been made the King's eschaetor, was continued, with the same bailiffs.
October 26th, 1332, the King deputed John Darcy and William Denum, to treat with the ambassadors from Scotland, at Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. iv. p. 535..
A. D. 1333, Richard Acton was mayor, and Hugh Heckam, Gilbert Hankyn, Waleranus Lumley, and Robert Halliwell, were bailiffs.

Another rendezvous of the military forces was ordered to be by Easter-day this year at Newcastle upon Tyne
Ibid. p. 552, et seq. The King dates from Newcastle upon Tyne, April 23d—also 27th and 29th, and on the 7th of May—also on the 4th of August following.
This year was rendered memorable by the famous battle of Halidown-Hill., upon an expedition against Scotland.
A remarkable incident happened at the city of Durham, about Easter this year, which is highly characteristical of the manners of that super∣stitious age.

The Queen of King Edward III. having followed the King to that city, was conducted to him through the gate of the abbey to the prior's lodgings, where having supped, and gone to bed with her royal lord, she was soon disturbed by one of the monks, who rudely intimated to the King, that St. Cuthbert by no means loved the company of her sex. The Queen upon this got out of bed, and having hastily dressed herself, went to the castle for the remaining part of the night, asking pardon for the
crime she had inadvertently been guilty of against the patron saint of their church
Anglia Sacra, vol. i. p. 760.
In 1333, Lewis Beaumont, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Richard de Bury.
In 1333, Roger Mauduit was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1334, Hugh Heckam was mayor, and Gilbert Hankyn, Richard Scott, John Galloway, and John Frysman, were bailiffs.

King Edward III. kept his WhitsuntideFoedera, tom. iv. p. 614. this yearHollingshead, p. 896.—Barnes says, that Whit-Sunday fell on the 15th of May that year.—Life of Edward III. p. 84. at Newcastle upon Tyne; soon after which Edward Baliol, King of Scotland, did him homage in the church of the Black-Friars in that town, as his superior, and chief lord of the realm of Scotland.

This was performed on the 19th of June in a publick and solemn manner, in the presence of a great number of nobles and gentlemen there assembled, before whom he bound himself by oath, to hold that king∣dom for himself and successors of the then King of England, his heirs and successors for ever. He alienated at the same time by letters patent, to the English King, the five Scottish counties next adjoining to the borders of England, to be annexed to that crown for ever
Foedera, tom. iv. p. 616, 617. Ypodigma Neustriae, p. 511. Walter Hemingford, vol. ii. p. 277, &c. &c.
The King appears to have been at the head of a gallant army at Newcastle upon Tyne, November 5th, 1334, on an expedition against Scotland, in defence of his late acquisition in that kingdom.—Barnes ut supra, p. 88—Ridpath's Border History, p. 314—Foedera, tom. iv..
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.

February 16th, 1335, the King was at Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. iv.—Tinmouth Chartulary, fol. 165. "Pastura de Elstewyk—A. D. 1335,—carius vendebatur eodem anno quod Rex et exercitus Anglicanus apud Novum Castrum tunc temporis jacentes predictam pasturam destruxerint.,— he was there again about Midsummer this year, with his armyRidpath's Border History, p. 316. He dates from thence June 28th, also July 2d., where
he was attended also by Baliol, King of Scots. This year the mariners of Newcastle were employed in the King's service in ScotlandBarnes' Ed. III. p. 96. "The mariners of Newcastle, with part of the King's fleet, made shift to come in at the mouth of the river Tay, where they burnt a great part of the town of Dundee.". The King dates from Newcastle, 16th of November this year.—He ap∣pears to have continued there till the 31st of DecemberRymer's Foedera, tom. iv. A true was prorogued at Newcastle first for a week, and then for a fortnight..
In the year 1336, John Denton was mayor, and Gilbert Hankyn, Robert Shilvington, John Woodman, and William Acton, were bailiffs.

The King was at Newcastle, on his way to Perth, June 20th, 1336
Foedera, tom. iv.
From the year 1334 to 1336, Hob. Dardins was sheriff of Northumberland.. He appears to have returned to Newcastle before the 28th of October followingRidpath's Border Hist. ut supra, p. 324., and occurs dating from that town on the 3d of November followingFoedera, tom. iv..
A. D. 1337, Nicholas Scot was mayor, and Robert de Hampton, Adam de Blakedon, Bartholomew Clerk, and Thomas de Karle, junior, were bailiffs.
This year the King appointed assemblies of his northern barons, to be held at York, and once at Newcastle upon TyneRidpath, p. 327..
In the year 1338, Hugh Heckam was mayor, and Richard Scott, Robert Halliwell, Peter Draper, and Robert Castle, were bailiffs.
March 25th this year, the King appears to have been at Newcastle upon TyneRymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 19..
A. D. 1339, Waleranus de Lumley was mayor, and Thomas Burn∣ton, Gilbert Hankyn, Richard Scott, and Richard Gallaway, were bailiffs.

In the year 1340, Sir William Felton was mayor, with the title of
custos villae, and Robert Musgrave, John Woodman, Hugh Carliol, and John Emeldon, were bailiffs.

A rendezvous was appointed for the English army to be at New∣castle upon Tyne in the middle of Lent this year, to proceed against the Scots, the King himself being absent at Tournay
Rymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 167.
In 1337, William de Felton, of Westmatsen, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland.
In 1338, Robert de Darreys occurs July 8th.—Rymer's Foedera, tom. v. p. 62.
In 1339, William de Felton. In 1340, Gilbert de Burghdown. Knight..
In the year 1341, John Denton was mayor, and Gilbert Hankyn, Thomas Burneton, John Galeway, and Peter Draper, were bailiffs.

November 4th, the King was at Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. v. he dates from thence also the 3d and 4th of December.. A mili∣tary rendezvous had been ordered there on the 24th of January this yearCollins's Pecrage, vol. ii. p. 39, edit. 1779.
A. D. 1342, Robert de Halliwell was mayor, and William Acton, Robert Musgrave, John de Durham, and Thomas Fleming, were bailiffs.

Soon after the return of David, King of Scots, to his own country, where he arrived June 2d this year, he invaded England by the eastern border with an immense army, and coming to Newcastle upon Tyne, lay about it all night. Early the next morning the townsmen sallied forth to reconnoitre the enemy, of whom they slew great numbers by surprise, and brought back with them the Earl of Murray, whom they took a prisoner in his tent: the next morning the Scots assaulted the town, but Sir John Nevil, then captain of the castle, making a most vigorous defence, they were compelled to raise the siege, and marched on towards Durham
See Froistard, cap. 74.—Also Bourne sub anno, from Barnes' l d. III. p. 254.
The Earl is said to have been taken naked in bed.—Frossard' account is as follows. "Davyde—came to the ryver of Tyne, brennynge all the countrey ronde aboute them and at last came to Newcastle upon Tyne, and there he lay and all his people about the town that night; and in the morning a certaine number of gentilmen that were in the towne issued out to the nombre of two hundred speares to make a skry in the Scottysh hooste, they dashed into the Scottyshe host ryght on th' Erle of Morets tentes, who bare in his armour sylver thre oreylles goules, there they took hym in his bed, and slewe many or th' oost was moved, and wan great pyllage. Then they returned into the towne boldly with great joye, and delyvered th' Erle Moret as prisoner to the captayne of the castell, the Lord Johan Nevel. Whan the Scottes were up, they armed them, and rati lyke madde men to the bartyers of the towne, and made a great assaut, the which endu long, but lytell it avayled them, and they lost there many men, for there were many good men of war within who defended themselves so wisely that the Scots were same at last to withdrawe abacke to their losse.".
In the year 1343, Richard Gallaway was mayor, and William Acton, John Durham, Thomas Fleming, and Robert Musgrave de Penrith, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1344, Robert Shilvington was mayor, and Robert Musgrave, Robert Halliwell, John Woodman, and William de Acton, were bailiffs.
In the year 1345, Robert de Foghale was mayor, and William de Acton, Hugh de Carliol, John de Frismarisco, and Robert de Penrith, were bailiffs.

This year there was a pestilence, which lasted two years, at Newcastle
Warburton's MSS.
April 24th, 1345, Richard de Bury, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Thomas Hatfield, secretary to the king. In 1341 and 1342, William de Felton was sheri of Northumberland. In 1343 and 1344, Robert Bertram, and Robert de Fenwicke. In 1345 and 1346, Roberth Raymes of Bolam—sed qu ere?.
A. D. 1346, Robert de Shilvington was mayor, and Hugh de Angre∣ton, John Wake, John de Emelden, and—From a deed in All-Saints' vestry, dated July, 1346., were bailiffs.

A letter in the King's name, dated September 6th this year, appears to have been sent to the mayor and bailiffs of Newcastle upon Tyne, informing them of the victory of Cressy, and that the siege of Calais was begun, ordering proclamation to be made in the town, for merchants and others to forward to that place immediately, flour, bread, corn, wine, beer, flesh, fish, bows, arrows, and strings, &c. for the use of the King's armyFoedera tom. v. p. 525. This year Newcastle upon Tyne furnished 17 ships, and 314 mariner, for the siege of Calais, a force superior to that provided by any northern port in England, except Yarmouth—Hutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii. p. 423..

October 17th, 1346
Ridpath's Border History, p. 338.
Froissard, cap. 28. Grafton's Chronicle, p. 278. Froissard says, "The Quene of England, who desyred to defend her contre, came to Newcastel upon Tyne, and ther taried for her men who came dayly fro all partes: whan the Scottes knewe that the Englishe∣men assemblyd at Newcastell, they drew thytherward, and their currours, came rennynge before the towne, and at their retournyng thet brent certayne small hamelette, therabout, so that the smoke therof came into the towne of Newecastell."—"After the partes had agreed to sight," he continues, "they all yssued out of the towne, and werein non b men of armes, 3000 archers, and 7000 of others, with the Walshmen." After the were drawn up in battle array, he adds, "The Quene went fro batayle to batayle, de∣fyryng them to do their devoyre to defende the honor of her Lorde the kinge of England, and in the name of God every man to be of good hert and courage, promysng th that to her power she wold remembre them as well or better as thoughe her Lord the Kinge were there personally. Than the Quene departed fro' them, recommending them to God and to Saynt George.", was fought the famous battle of Durham, called by Froissard and Grafton, the battle of Newcastle upon Tyne
Ridpath's Border History, p. 338.
Froissard, cap. 28. Grafton's Chronicle, p. 278. Froissard says, "The Quene of England, who desyred to defend her contre, came to Newcastel upon Tyne, and ther taried for her men who came dayly fro all partes: whan the Scottes knewe that the Englishe∣men assemblyd at Newcastell, they drew thytherward, and their currours, came rennynge before the towne, and at their retournyng thet brent certayne small hamelette, therabout, so that the smoke therof came into the towne of Newecastell."—"After the partes had agreed to sight," he continues, "they all yssued out of the towne, and werein non b men of armes, 3000 archers, and 7000 of others, with the Walshmen." After the were drawn up in battle array, he adds, "The Quene went fro batayle to batayle, de∣fyryng them to do their devoyre to defende the honor of her Lorde the kinge of England, and in the name of God every man to be of good hert and courage, promysng th that to her power she wold remembre them as well or better as thoughe her Lord the Kinge were there personally. Than the Quene departed fro' them, recommending them to God and to Saynt George.". The English army marched from that town to the field of battle, and the Queen of England, who had come down to the northern parts in the absence of her royal husband, resided in the same place during the fight.
In the year 1347, Peter Draper was mayor, and William Acton, senior, Hugh de Angreton, John Emelden, and Hugh de Carliol, were bailiffs.
The same mayor and bailiffs continued till 1351.

In the year 1351, Gilbert Duxfield was mayor, and William Acton, senior, John de Chambers, and—, were bailiffs
The British Chronologist says, on I know not what authourity, that in the year 1319 Newcastle was nearly destroyed by a site.
A deed in All-Saints' vestr, dated the Sunday before the feast of St. Peter ad vincula, 1350, makes Gilbert de Duxta id mayor, and William de Acton, senior Robert de Penteth, John Wake, and John de Emeldon, bailiffs..

King Edward's letters of safe conduct to the hostages, and of power to certain commissioners to receive them, and to take an oath of King David, who had been taken prisoner at the battle of Durham, for his return from Scotland, whither he had obtained leave to go, and the
command for his safe custody at Newcastle upon Tyne, till the hos∣tages were all come, are dated September 5th, 1351
Barnes' Edw. III. p. 455.
From 1347 to 1349, John Clifford was sheriff of Northumberland, and from 1350 to 1355, John de Coupeland, of Coupeland, Knight..
In the year 1352, William Strother was mayor, and Richard Scot John Emeldon, John Chamber, and William Acton, junior, were bailiffs.
In the year 1353, Peter Draper was mayor, and John Emeldon, William de Strother, John de Chambre, and William Acton, junior, were bailiffs.

This year DavidBarnes' Edw. III. p. 469., King of Scots, with the leave of the King of England, went as before to Newcastle upon Tyne, where a treaty was held by certain English commissioners
The delegates for England, were the Bishop of Durham; William de Bohun, Earl of Northampton, and constable of England; Gilbert de Umfreville, Earl of Angus; the Lords de Percy and de Nevill; William, Baron of Greystock, and Henry le Scroop. Eor Scotland, the Bishop of St. Andrew's and Brechin; Patrick of Dunhar, Earl of the march of Scotland; the Abbot of Dumfermelin, and Walter de Moffet, Archdeacon of Leonesse. —Brady's Continuation, p. 253.
Collins's Peerage, vol. ii. p. 317, edit. 1779, informs us, that, "October 15th, 27 Ed. III. Henry de Percy (third Lord Percy of Alnwick) was commissioned to treat with David de Bruce, and the nobles of Scotland, at Newcastle upon Tyne, abuut the discharge of the said David de Bruce, and likewise on June 14th following, on the same account at the said place."
In 1356 and 1357, Alan del Strother was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1358 and 1359, Henry de Strother, of Kirknewton, in Glendale, Knight. In 1360, John Heron. In 1361, Roger de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight., with the nobles of Scot∣land, July 13th, concerning his delivery from imprisonment, and the conclusion of a peaceDugdale's Baronage, tom. i. p. 294. Foed. tom. v. p. 812..
This year King Edward III. in his route to Scotland, kept his Christ∣mas at Newcastle upon TyneHutchinson's Northumberland, vol. ii, p. 423.
In the year 1354, the same mayor and bailiffs continued as in 1353.

A. D. 1355, William del Strother was mayor, and William Acton, Richard Scott, John Emeldon, and John Chambre, were bailiffs. Sum∣monses
were issued for the military forces to attend the King at New∣castle upon Tyne, on the 1st of January, 1356Foedera, tom. v. p. 829..
In 1356, the same mayor continued, and Nicholas Barrot, William Acton, —, —, were bailiffs.
A. D. 1357, the same mayor was continued, and John Emeldon, John Chambre, Nicholas Barrot, and Nicholas Acton, were bailiffs.
The year following the same were continued, except William instead of Nicholas Acton. The two following years the same mayor and bailiffs.
In the year 1361, John Chambre was mayor, and John Emeldon, John Stanhope, John de Ruffen, and Elias de Airwhitt, were bailiffs.
In the year 1362, John Chambers was mayor, and John de Emel∣don, John de Stanhope, Elias de Airwhitt, and Robert de Duxfield, were bailiffs.

An order occurs, dated May 20th, 1362, from the King of England to Henry del Strother, late sheriff of Northumberland, to deliver up Thomas de Hay, and John Grey, hostages for David de Bruys, King of Scots, to Roger de Wyderington, then sheriff of that county, who was directed to keep them safe in the castle of Newcastle upon TyneIbid. tom. vi. p. 364.. A similar order occurs the year following, when the above hostages were to be transferred to Richard de Horsley, then sheriff of that county, to be kept as beforeIn 1362, Roger de Wyderyngton, and Richard de Horseley, of Long-Horseley, was sheriff of Northumberland. From 1663 to 1366, Henry de Strother. From 1367 to 1371, no other name occurs but Richard de Horseley of Long-Horseley..
In the year 1363, Robert Angreton was mayor, and John Emeldon, William Acton, John Stanhope, and John Byker, were bailiffs.
In the year 1364, the same mayor was continued, and William de Acton, John de Stanhope, John Russan, and —, were bailiffs.
In the year 1365, Richard de Stanhope was mayor, and William de Acton, John Stanhope, John de Emeldon, and John de Russan, were bailiffs.
The year following, William de Acton was mayor, and John de Stanhope, John de Ruffan, Thomas Draper, and John de Byker, were bailiffs.
In 1367, the same mayor was continued, and John de Emeldon John de Byker, John de Preston, and John Houghhell, were bailiffs.
The year following the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
In the year 1369, Robert Angreton was mayor, and John Draper, John Ruffan, John Bulkham, and Stephen Whitgrave, were bailiffs.

The next year, as also the four following, the same mayor and bailiffs were continuedYet a deed occurs, remaining in All-Saints' vestry, dated 47 Ed. III. wherein Wil∣liam de Acton is mentioned as mayor, and John Bulkham, John Howden, Thomas Wod∣man, and Robert Plummer, as bailiffs..

This year war breaking out between England and France, King Edward reinforced the garrison of Newcastle upon Tyne, and other fortresses near the bordersRidpath's Border History. In the Foedera, tom. vi. there occurs and order concerning the arresting, i. e. pressing, of ships, dated February 7th, 1372, wherein James Lyons, a King's serjeant at arms, and William de Acton, of Newcastle upon Tyne, are appointed to that business in the counties of Durham and Northumberland..
A. D. 1375, William Scot was mayor, and John Stanhope, John de Ruffan, Thomas Draper, and John de Byker, were bailiffs.
The year following, John Bulgham was mayor, and Laurence Acton, Robert Plumber, Thomas de Horton, and William Durham, were bailiffs.
In the year 1377, the 1st of Richard II. as also the year following, the same mayor and bailiffs were continued.
A. D. 1379, Richard Stanhope was mayor, and Adam de York, William Bishopdale, Thomas de Morden, and Robert Oliver, were bailiffs.
The two following years the same mayor and bailiffs continued.
In the year 1382, William Bishopdale was mayor, and Laurence Acton, William Johnson, John Heworth, and John Thornton, were bailiffs.
The three following years the same mayor and bailiffs were con∣tinued.

In the year 1385, the Scots made an inroad into England, and laid waste the county of Northumberland as far as Newcastle upon TyneRidpath's Border History, p. 355. at which place a rendezvous of the army was ordered on the 14th of July that year, to proceed against them
Foedera, tom. vii. p. 473.
In the beginning of May, 1381, Thomas Hatfield, Bishop of Durham, died. He was succeeded by John Fordham.
In 1372, Thomas Surtees, of North-Goforth, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1373 and 1374, William Delavall, of Delaval C. or Saton Delaval, Knight.
From 1375 to 1377, no other name occurs but Thomas Ilderton, of Ilderton, Knight.
From 1384 to 1387, Henry de Percy, of Warwick, Earl of Northumberland, was sheriff of that county. In 1388 and 1389, Ralph de sheriff..
A. D. 1386, Adam Bulkham was mayor, and Laurence Acton, Robert de Raynton, Sampson Harding, and John de Horton, were bailiffs.
The three following years the same mayor and bailiffs were con∣tinued.

In the year 1388, Alexander, Archbishop of York, was arrested at Shields, near Tynemouth, for high treason, just as he was taking ship to go over sea. Two searchers in the port of Newcastle, John de Refham and Robert de Rypon, discovered him, and delivered him into the cus∣tody of the mayor and bailiffs of that townFoedera, tom. vii. p. 5. Thirty pound money were found upon him, which by another of the Kin, dated th, 1388, vol. two persons that seized him..
This year, while the English were unhappily occupied by the civil dissensions between the King and his parliament, the Scots invaded England.

All the military persons of the country were ordered to assemble, on this occasion, at Newcastle upon Tyne, which was so full of people, that, as Froissard tells usFroissard's Chronicle. Sir Henry Percy in the Hotsu of Shakespear., "they wyst not where to lodge." The enemy
having, as usual, marked their way by rapine and destruction, as far as Durham, returned and sat down two days before Newcastle, on both of which they had skirmishes with the defendants within that town. Sir Henry and Sir Ralph Percy, the gallant sons of the Earl of Northum∣berland, as the same authority words it, were ever foremost at the barryersThe barryers appear to have been a wooden fortification, or out-work, without the gates of the town.—Major, in his History of Scotland, p. 267, speaking of this rencounter, tells us, "extra urbis portam erat quoddam ligneum munimentum, in quo existentes Anglos Scoti a dextrâ obsederunt."—His whole account is curious. "Ad decem millia Douglas delegit ad Novum Castrum oppugnandum.—Itaque ab ea parte qua Scotiam respicit positis castris, omnia circumspectat qua commodius aggredi possit."—Speaking of the two sons of the Earl of Northumberland within the town, he says, that Sir Henry Percy went out at the gate, and challenged Douglas to single combat: "Nec noster," adds Major, "detrectat pugnam—arma igitur expediens in campum descendit, utrinque infestis hastis concurritur." Douglas unhorses Percy, and threatens to carry the spear with which he unhorsed his adversary into Scotland, the highest honour, he adds, to the conqueror, and disgrace to the person overcome. Percy is pulled into the gates by the spectators. "Convocatis antem centurionibus Douglas qua cuique parte aggredienda sint oppuli maenia edocet. Tum dato signo, projectis in fossam lignis, foeno et quicquid ad implendam eam commodum est, scalas muris admovent; sed egregie defendentibus oppidanis, infecta r, acceptis aliquot vulueribus, suos Douglas revocat: ubi convenissent consolatur milites qui frusta rem tentassent, docens in causa fuisse paucitatem scalarum quae ad summum maenium pertingeret. Desperata expugnatione silentio suos Douglas ad majorem exercitum retro ducit."—The Scots had divided themselves into two armies.—There follows an account of the battle of Otterbourn. of the town to skirmish. In one of these rencounters, Sir Henry Percy, fighting hand in hand with the Earl of Douglas, lost his standard, which he made a vow to recover, and for that purpose pur∣sued the Scots on their return as far as Otterbourn, where a most bloody battle was fought, in which the English army were rather unfortunately than dishonourably defeated.

In the year 1390, William Bishopdale was mayor, and Laurence de Acton, Richard Scot, Thomas de Gryndon, and William Jonson, were bailiffsInquisition in the Tinmouth Chartulary at Northumberland-House, fol. 216..

The year following the same mayor continued, and Laurence Acton,
John de Aukland, William Jonson, and Henry de Carliol, were bailiffs.

The four following yearsYet in a deed belonging to St. Andrew's church, dated the vigil of All-Saints, 1395, Laurence Acton is said to have been mayor, and Thomas de Mordon, John de New∣bigging, Thomas de Grendon, and William de Redmershall, were bailiffs;—and the same mayor and bailiffs occur in a deed in All-Saints' vestry, dated the feast of St. Matthias, 20 Ric. II.—See, for 1394, St Margaret's chantry in St Nicholas' church. the same mayor and bailiffs continued.
In the year 1396, Sampson Harding was mayor, and the last men∣tioned four appear to have continued bailiffs.
The three following years the same mayor and bailiffs continued.

In the year 1400, Roger Thornton was mayor, and William Red∣marshell, the first sheriff of Newcastle, which was this year made a town and county of itself. The following year the same mayor and sheriff continued.

King Henry IV. appears to have been at Newcastle on the 25th of July this yearFoedera, tom. viii. p. 155, &c., and marched from thence on an expedition against Scotland, about the 7th of August following
Ridpath's Border History, p. 368.
In the year 1390, John de Felton was sheriff of Northumberland. From 1391 to 1397, Henry de Percy, of Alnwick, Earl of Northumberland. In 1398, John de Fen∣wick, of Fenwick-Tower. In 1399, Henry de Percy, son of the Earl of Northumberland. In the year 1400, Ger. Heron, and Robert Umfravil. In 1401, John Mitford, of Mol∣leston, Knight.
Another account says, that, in 1391, Robert de Ever, Knight, was sheriff; and in 1392, William de Raymes, of Bolam.. He dates from thence again on the 3d of September that year.

By an order of the King, dated January 11th, 1401, the mayor, sheriff, and community of Newcastle upon Tyne were commanded to provide one barge for the service of the state
Foedera, tom. viii. Many other towns were commanded to contribute the like as∣sistance.
"It is recorded," says Jacob, in his History of Faversham, p. 12, "in the red book of Favesham, that on Wednesday after the feast of St. Alphage, 2 Hen. IV. A. D. 1401, William Clerk, hosier, fled to the church of St. Saviour, of Faversham, for sanctuary, and desired the coroner. On which W. Ledys, mar. and coroner of the Lord the King for that purpose, went to the aforesaid place, and before him, on the day and place abovesaid, he acknowledged himself a felon of the Lord the King, and confessed that, on Sunday, on the feast of St. Stephen in that said year of our Lord the King, he feloniously stole from Agnes Thornton, of Newcastle upon Tyne, one pair of beads, value two shillings, and desired, according to the law and custom of England, he might be delivered from the church; on which being led to the door of the church, he abjured the King of England before the said coroner, who assigned him the port of Dover for his passage out of it.".
In the year 1402, Robert Chirdon was mayor, and John Bywellgne, sheriff.
The six following years the same mayor and sheriff continued.

In the year 1402, hostilities were renewed between the neighbouring
Ridpath's Border History, p. 370, 371. Among the orders issued by the King, June 25th, 1400, preserved in the 8th tom. of the Foedera, for all knights, &c. to hasten to him, one was addressed to the sheriff of Newcastle upon Tyne.
Ibid. November 20th, 1402, mention occurs of several ships belonging to Newcastle upon Tyne, well victualled and armed upon the sea; also nightly watches by an hundred persons on the walls of that town for its defence, and that of the parts adjacent, sustained at the charge of the inhabitants. It appears ibid. p. 283, that the counties of Northum∣berland and Cumberland had suffered so much by the incursions of the Scots, that, at the request of parliament, the King remitted to them all taxes and debts due by them to the crown. kingdoms: an army of Scots, headed by the Earl of Douglas, entered Northumberland, destroyed and plundered the country as far as New∣castle upon Tyne: they were intercepted on their return, and routed at the battle of Homeldon, one of the most fatal to Scotland that ever happened on the borders.

June 10thFoedera, tom. viii. p. 400., 1405, the King issued orders to the sheriff of Yorkshire, to summon the whole military force of that country to attend at New∣castle upon Tyne, to proceed against the Earl of Northumberland, and other traitors, who had raised an insurrection against him. The King dates from Newcastle on the 25th of June
Ridpath's Border History, p. 377.
In 1408, this Henry, Earl of Northumberland, was slain at the battle of Bramham-Moor, on the 18th of February. One quarter of his body was put up at Newcastle upon Tyne; but in the May following, with the other three parts and his head, it was taken down, and delivered to his friends. to be solemnly buried.—Dugdale's Baronage, tom. i. p. 278..

April 6th, 1406, among the orders issued by the King for merchants to have the custody of the sea, and to provide certain men of war, for which they were impowered to exact imposts, one occurs addressed to the mayor of Newcastle upon TyneFoedera, tom. viii..
A. D. 1409, and the four following years, William Aughton was mayor, and William Middleton, sheriff.

In the year 1410, there was a great plague at Newcastle
Pat. 11 Hen. IV. p. 2, m. 17. "Novum Castrum;—magna pestilentia fuit in villa predicta in anno preterito."
March 8th, 1410, Thomas Langley, Bishop of Durham, granted an indulgence of forty days, to continue in force a year, for any one who should contribute to the ranson of Simon Chandy, of Newcastle upon Tyne, who had been taken prisoner by the French, nor could obtain his liberty, but by the payment of a great sum.—Register of Bishop Langley, p. 31.
In 1402, John Clavering, of Cally, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland, and in 143. In 1404, Robert Umfravi, Knight. In 145, Robert Lsle, of olton, Knight. In 1406, Robert Harbottle, of Harbottle. In 1407, Thomas Grey, of Heton, Knight. In 1408, Robert Tempest. In 1409, John de Widdrington, of Widdrington Castle, Knight. From 1410 to 1412, no name occurs but John Bertram. In 1412, John de Maners, of Etal. In 1413, Edward Hastings, Knight..
In the year 1414, Robert Hebborn was mayor, and William Mid∣dleton, sheriff.
The year following the same mayor and sheriff continued.

January 28th, 1414, an order was directed to the sheriff of New∣castle upon Tyne, to proclaim the truce between France and England, which was to continue a year, and in which the King of Scotland was comprehendedFoedera, tom. ix. p. 101..

A. D. 1415, while King Henry was preparing to lead his forces into France, a conspiracy was discovered against his life, at the insti∣gation of the French, by Richard, Earl of Cambridge, brother of the Duke of York, the Lord Scroop, Lord Treasurer, and Sir Thomas
Grey, of Werk, in Northumberland, privy counsellors The head of Sir Thomas Grey was sent to Newcastle upon Tyne, and placed upon one of the gates of that townComplete History of England, vol. i. p. 316..
In the year 1416, Roger Thornton was mayor, and John del Strother, sheriff.

The four following yearsYet in a deed in All-Saints' vestry, dated on the feast of St. Michael, 8 Hen. V. we find John Strother, mayor, and William Ellerby, sheriff. the same mayor and sheriff continued.

September 18th, 1417, an order was sent by the bishop's official, to the parochial chaplains of St. Nicholas' and All-Saints' in Newcastle upon Tyne, to inflict certain penances, which had been enjoined Ma∣tilda Burgh and Margaret Usher, servants of Peter Baxter, of that town, for having put on the habits of men, and impiously, as it was con∣sidered at that time, approached the shrine of St. Cuthbert at DurhamBourne sub anno 1417..
In the year 1421, William Essington was mayor, and Laurence Acton, sheriff.
Another account says, John de Bywell was sheriff.
A. D. 1422, the same mayor continued, and John Chirdon was sheriff.
In the year 1423, William Ellerby was mayor, and the same sheriff was continued.

The year following
In a grant of King Henry VI. to Roger Thornton, dated July 6th, 1424, mention occurs of "John Wall, late mayor of Newcastle, and eschaetor there."—See account of the Maison de Dieû, or Thornton's Hospital, on Sand-Hill.
In the year 1417, a dispensation was granted by Thomas Langley, Bishop of Durham, to Thomas Hibburne, son of Robert Hibburne, merchant, of Newcastle upon Tyne, to marry Isabel Strother, relict of William Strother, the parties being too nearly related to go together lawfully without such a licence.—Register of Bishop Langley, p. 951.
In 1414, Robert Lisle, of Felton, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1415, John Bertram. In 1416, Robert Ogle. In 1417, Edward Hastings, Knight. In 1418, William Elmeden. In 1419, 1420, and 1421, Thomas Surtees, of North-Gosforth. In 1422, John Bertram, Knight. In 1423, John Middleton. there were the same mayor and sheriff.

In the beginning of April, 1424, the King of Scotland passed through Newcastle upon Tyne in his way to his own country, attended by a
