numerous train, as well of his own subjects, as of the gentlemen of Northumberland, who had orders to accompany him as far as Scotland, in the most honourable manner they were ableRidpath's Border History, p. 391..
In the year 1425, William Ellerby was mayor, and John Jay, sheriff.

April 7th this year, a sentence was fulminated by Thomas Langley, Bishop of Durham, against certain persons unknown, who had robbed the house of Robert Clytherow, Esq of Newcastle upon Tyne, of plate and jewels of considerable value. Such a proceeding against housebreakers in this age would, I fear, do but little towards the recovery of stolen goodsRegister of Bishop Langley, p. 124..
In the year 1426, Roger Thornton was mayor, and the same sheriff continued.
The year following the same mayor and sheriff continued.
In the year 1428, John Rhodes was mayor, and the same sheriff was continued.

December 1st this year, King Henry VI. issued an order for the safe conduct of the King of Scots, to be escorted as far as Newcastle upon Tyne or Durham, by 1000 of his own horse, to a personal conference with Henry Beaufort, Bishop of Winchester, in order to prevent hos∣tilities between the two kingdomsFoedera, tom. x. p. 408..
In the year 1429, the same mayor continued, and John Clark was sheriff.
The year following there were the same mayor and sheriff.
In the year 1431, the same mayor continued, and Edward Bertram was sheriff.
The year following, Laurence Acton was mayor, and Thomas Chirdon, sheriff.

In the yearIn a deed in St. Andrew's vestry, 12. Hen. VI. 1434, Laurence Acton occurs as mayor, and Edward Berton sheriff. In 1424, John Bertram, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1425, John de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1426, William Lambton. In 1427, Henry Fenwick, Esq In 1428, William Carnaby, of Halton-Tower, Esq In 1429, John de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1430, John Bertram. In 1431, Roger de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1432, John Middleton. In 1433, Matthew Whitfield, of Whitfield-Hall, Knight. In 1434, John Bertram, Knight. 1433, the same mayor continued, and Thomas Penrith was sheriff.
A. D. 1434, Richard Hall was mayor, and Richard Brown, sheriff.
In the year 1435, Robert Whelpington was mayor, and Thomas Wardel, sheriff.
The year following, Richard Hall was mayor, and John Chambers, sheriff.

In the year 1437In a deed remaining in St. Andrew's vestry, dated St. Matthew's day, 1437, Robert de Whelpington occurs as mayor, and Robert de Buthe, sheriff., Laurence Acton was mayor, and Thomas Pen∣dreth, sheriff.

A. D. 1438
Stephen Brown, Knight, lord mayor of London, in 1438, was the son of John Brown, and born at Newcastle upon Tyne—Fuller's Worthies—Northumberland.
In the 36th of Henry VI. Henry, Earl of Northumberland; the prior of Tinmouth, Ralph Percy, Knight; Ralph Grey, Knight; Robert Ogle, Knight; William Bertram, Roger Thornton, John Hauboth, senior, Robert Mitford, John Cartington, and Robert Rodes, were appointed conmissioners to raise archers in the county of Northumberland. —1. Pars Paten. 30 Hen. VI. dorso 60. Sagittar. Harleian MSS. 1448.
In 1435, Roger Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight, was sheriff of Northum∣berland. In 1436, William ue, Knight, of Kirkley. In 1437, Robert Ogle, Knight, of Ogle-Castle. In 1438, John Bertram. In 1439, Robert Harbottle, Knight. In 1440 and 1441, John Heron, of Ford-Castle, Knight. In 1442, Roger de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1443, John Heron, of Ford-Castle, Knight. In 1444, Robert Claxton. In 1445, William Haringe. In 1446, Thomas Wellden. In 1447, Bertram Hrbottel. In 1448, Thomas Nevill, Knight. In 1449, Roger de Widdring∣ton, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1450, Roger Thornton, of Nether-Witton-Castle, Esq, Robert Whelpington was mayor, and John Castle, sheriff.
In the year 1439, John Clark was mayor, and William Harding, sheriff.
A. D. 1440, John Chambers was mayor, and John Musgrave, sheriff.
In the year 1441, William Harding was mayor, and Simon Weldon, sheriff.
A. D. 1442, Thomas Wardell was mayor, and William Jay, sheriff.
In the year 1443, John Musgrave was mayor, and Thomas Head∣lam, sheriff.
A. D. 1444, William Harding was mayor, and Thomas Bee, sheriff.
In the year 1445, William Jay was mayor, and John Ward, sheriff.
A. D. 1446, William Harding was mayor, and John Winton, alias Ovington, sheriff.
In the year 1447, the same mayor continued, and Robert Baxter was sheriff.
A. D. 1448, John Ward was mayor, and John Richardson, sheriff.
The King appears to have been at Durham on the 6th of the kalends of October this year.
In 1449, William Harding was mayor, and Alan Bird, sheriff.
In the year 1450, John Ward was mayor, and George Carr, sheriff.
A. D. 1451, Robert Baxter was mayor, and John Baxter, sheriff.

August 14th this year, a treaty was sealed in the vestry of St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle, at a meeting of plenipotentiaries of the kings of England and ScotlandFoedera, tom. ii. p. 302. 31 Hen. VI. Sir Henry Percy, Knight, son of the Earl of Northumberland, was one of the conservators of the truce concluded at Newcastle, to last till May 21st, 1457.—Collins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 371, edit. 1779..
A. D. 1452, William Harding was mayor, and John Penreth, sheriffIn a deed in All-Saints' vestry, dated last of May, 1452, Robert Baxter occurs as mayor, and Alan Carr, sheriff..
In the year 1453, John Carliel was mayor, and Nicholas Wetwang, sheriff.
A. D. 1454, John Richardson was mayor, and William Roddam, sheriff.
In the year 1455, the same mayor continued, and Thomas Cuthbert was sheriff.
A. D. 1456, the same mayor continued, and John Nixon was sheriff.
In the year 1457, the same mayor continued, and Richard Stevenson was sheriff.
A. D. 1458, John Penrith was mayor, and Henry Fowler, sheriff.
In the year 1459In a deed dated September 3d, 1459, John Pemith occurs as mayor, and Richard Stevynson as sheriff., John Richardson was mayor, and Richard Stevenson, sheriff.
In the year 1460, the 1st of Edward IV. John Baxter was mayor, and Nicholas Hayning, sheriff.
In the year 1461, John Richardson was mayor, and Nichlas Wet∣wang sheriff.

After the battle of Towton, March 29th this year, which proved so fatal to the house of Lancaster, King Henry VI. with his Queen and the Prince, the Duke of Somerset; Henry, Duke of Exeter; Lord Roos; Sir John Fortescue, chief justice of England; and Tailboys, Earl of Kyme, who were then at York, fled on hearing the news, first to New∣castle upon Tyne, and afterwards to Berwick upon TweedLeland's Collectanea, vol. ii. p. 499, new edit..

King Edward IV. after this great victory, marched northward as far as Newcastle upon Tyne, but soon afterwards returned to the south
Ridpath's Border History, p. 425. James Boteler, Earl of Wiltshire and Ormond, being taken after the loss of the day at Towton-Field, by Richard Salkeld, Esq was be∣headed at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the 1st of May following.—Dugdale's Baronage, tom. iii. p. 235.
In 1451, John Heron, of Ford-Castle, Knight, was Northumberlander. 1452, Robert Mitford. In 1453, John Burcester. In 1454, Robert de Maners, of Etal, Esq In 1455, Ralph Grey, of Heton, Knight. In 1456, John Heron, of Ford Castle, Knight. In 1457, Roger Thornton, of Nther-Witton-Castle, Esq In 1458, William Bertram. In 1459, Ralph Grey, of Heton, Knight.—No name occurs 1560. In 156 John de Middleton, of Belsay-Castle, Knight..
In the year 1462, Alan Bird was mayor, and Henry Forster, sheriff.

This year the Queen of King Henry VI. having passed over into France for assistance, returned with 500 men:—she landed at Tin∣mouth, with an intention of going to Newcastle upon Tyne; but pro∣bably being denied admission there, she soon reimbarked, and reached Berwick upon Tweed
Hall's Chronicle, 2 Ed. IV. fol. 2.
Ridpath, in his Border History, p. 426, refers part of the above particulars to a from a second expedition of the Queen into France, A. D. 1463. King Edward IV. ap∣pears to have set out from London, November 30th, 1463, on his way to Northumberland, where Bamborough-Castle surrendered to him on Christmas-eve, as did that of Dun∣stanburgh three days after, and that of Alnwick was taken on the 6th of January following. (Yet see the subsequent letter.) The cause of Henry VI. seems to have been abandoned by Scotland in consequence of a truce which had been concluded in the preceding Decem∣ber with Edward IV.
Newcastle, 10th of December, 1463, 3 Ed. IV. Fenn's Letters, vol. i. p. 272.
"To my ryth worchepfull brodyr John Paston the elder sone of John Paston, Esquyer, be thys delyv'yd in hast. Ryth worchepful brodedyr I recomaunde me to you. Plesyt yow to wet yt as thys day we had tydyngs her that the Scottys wyll come in to Ingland within 8 days after the wrytyng of thys lettyr for to rescue these 3 castellys, Alnwyk, Don∣samborowe, and Bameborowe, whych castellys wer besegyd as on yesterdaye and at the sege of Allnewyk lythe my Lord of Kene and ye Lord Scalys and at Donsam∣borowe castyll lythe the Lord Montague and Lord Ogyll and other dyvers lords and gentle∣men that I knowe not and ther is to hem owt of Newe Castyll ordynans I nowe bothe for the segys and for the feld in cas that ther be ony feld takyn as I trow ther' shall none be not yet for the Scottys kepe no promes My Lord of Warwyk lythe at ye castyll of War∣corthe but 3 myle owt of Alnewyk and he rydyth dayly to all thes cast for to overse the segys and if they want vatayles or any other thyng he is redy for to pervey it for them to hys power The Kyng comandyd my Lord of Norfolk for to tayl and the ordynans owt of Newcastell on to Wacorthe castyh to my Lord of Warwyk and so my Lord of Norfolk comandyd Sir John Howard Syr Willm Peche Syr Rob Chamberleyn Rase Ascheton and me Calthorp and George and othyr for to go with the vitayles and ordyr his on to my Lord of Warwyk and so we wer with my Lord of Warwyk with the ordyna and vitayles yesterdaye The Ky lythe at Duthm and my Lord of Norfolk at Newcastell We have pepyll I or—&c. New∣castyll on Sat. next aftyr y• of owyr Lady. Yor. John Paston the yongest."
The three above castles had been taken by Queen Magaret, and were in the pos∣session of the adherents and friends of Hen. VI. The Earl of Warwick commanded the forces of King Edward. These sieges were undertaken, our historian say, the battle of Hexham, which was sought and won May 13th, 1, he Edward, but according to this account, they were not undertaken month after. The castles of Bamborough and Dunstanborough were soon taken, but that of Alnwick, being relieved by the Scots, the garison▪ out probably, by treaty. herself in a small vessel; but her followers,
having been driven ashore at Bamborough by a storm, burnt their ships, and fled to Holy Island, where near four hundred of them were afterwards taken prisoners by the partizansBastard Ogle, an esquire called Jhon Munton, with others. of King Edward IV.
In the year 1463, the same mayor continued, and William Blaxton was sheriff.
A. D. 1464, John Nixon was mayor, and Nicholas Hayning, sheriff.

In the spring this year, Queen Margaret entered Northumberland again, at the head of a very numerous army, which, on the 15th of May following, suffered a total defeat on a plain called Livells
The seene of this decisive battle, by some fixed to the level ground below Hexham, is said by others to have been a place still called the Lennolds, south-west of Hexham, where the lines of intrenchment are still to be seen.—See Gentleman's Mag. Novem∣ber, 1778, p. 507.
In 1462, George Lumley, of Lumley-Castle, com. Dunelm. Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1463, the same. In 1464, Robert de Manners, of Etal, Knight., near Hexham in that countyHall's Chronicle, fol. 2. edit. 2. In the slight and chace that succeeded this last at∣tempt of the house of Lancaster, Henry Duke of Somerset, Lord Roos, Lord Molyns, Lord Hungerford, Sir Thomas Wentworth, Sir Thomas Huse, Sir John Finderne, and many others, were taken. The Duke of Somerset was beheaded at Hexham; the other lords and knights were taken to Newcastle upon Tyne, and after a little respite were executed, Henry VI. escaped from this battle with Sir Humphrey Nevell; William Taylbois, Earl of Kent; Sir Ralph Grey, Richard Tunstal, and others, who, being in fear of being taken, hid themselves in dens and caves. The Earl of Kent was taken in a close called Riddel∣dale, and was brought to Newcastle, and there beheaded. King Edward went from this battle to the city of Durham. Ridpath, in his Border History, p. 427, says, that, after this fight, "the Queen and her son, with the utmost difficulty, and, as it is related, by the aid of a generous obber, having gained the sea-coast, passed over to Sluys in flanders, while the poor King, having lurked more than a year in Lancashire, was discovered, and caried prisoner to the tower of London.".
In the year 1465, Alan Bird was mayor, and William Thompson, sheriff.

December 12th this year, the prorogation of a truce with Scotland was conchided at Newcastle upon Tyne, in a congress held at that town between plenipotentiaries from both kingdomsRymer's Foedera, tom. ii. p. 557..
A. D. 1466, John Nixon was mayor, and Robert Chambers, sheriff.

December 5th this year, there was a meeting of commissioners at
Newcastle upon Tyne, concerning attempts against the truce of the pre∣ceding yearRymer's Foedera, tom. ii. p. 573..
In the year 1467, William Blaxton was mayor, and John Esington, sheriff.
The year following, John Nixon was mayor, and John Cook, sheriff.
In the year 1469, Richard Stephenson was mayor, and John Fisher, sheriff.
A. D. 1470, William Blaxton was mayor, and Thomas Lokwood, sheriff.
In the year 1471, John Nixon was mayor, and John Carr, sheriff.
A. D. 1472, William Blaxton was mayor, and Thomas Snow, sheriff.

April 25th this year, a great congress of plenipotentiaries was held at Newcastle upon Tyne, who agreed that, notwithstanding the com∣plaints and infractions on both sides, the long truce between the neigh∣bouring nations should continue in force
"Ridpath's Border History. Foedera, tom. ii. p. 733.
Henry Perrcy (fourth Earl of Northumberland) was commissioned February 6th, 1472, to meet on April 25th following at Newcastle upon Tyne, to treat with commissioners sent by the King of Scotland, about a peace, cessation of arms, or confederacy. He was also comimissioned to meet persons deputed by James III. King of Scotland, on June 16th, 1473, at Newcastle upon Tyne, or Alnwick, or such other place as he should think proper, to settle with them all matters transacted contrary to the urce.—collin's Pra, vol. ii. p. 375, ed. 1779.
In 1465, Gerard de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1466, William Bowes, of Suetham-Castle, Knight. In 1467, John Nevil, Knight. In 1468, George Lumley, of Lumley, Knight, till 1471. In 1472, 1473, and 1474, John de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. From 1475 till 1485, no name occurs but that Henry, Earl of Northumberland..
In the year 1473, the same mayor continued, and Robert Harding was sheriff.
The next year Nicholas Haynyng was mayor, and William Hodshon, sheriff.
A. D. 1475, John Carliel was mayor, and John Semple, sheriff.
In the year 1476, the same mayor was continued, and Peter Bewick was sheriff.
In the year 1477, John Cook was mayor, and John Heaton, sheriff.
A. D. 1478, Robert Chambers was mayor, and John Ridsdale, sheriff.
Great numbers are reported to have died this year of a plague at Newcastle upon TyneWarhurton's MSS. penes h. v. Durem Northumbriae..
In the year 1479, John Semple was mayor, and William Scot, sheriff.
A. D. 1480, John Carlisle was mayor, and William Bewick, sheriff.
A. D. 1481, George Carr was mayor, and William Cunningham sheriff.
In the year 1482, John Cook was mayor, and Robert Harding, sheriff.

This year a grant of King Edward IV. to Richard, Duke of Glou∣cester, of the wardenship of the north marches, together with the castles, towns, lordships, customs, and fee-farms, of Carlisle and Newcastle upon Tyne, &c. to be held of the King by knight service, was confirmed by parliamentParliamentary History, vol. ii. p. 376.—Parliament at West minder, January 20—The Duke of Gloucester, afterwards King Richard III. appears to have been sent down a lieutenant-general against Scots.—Foedera, tom. xii. p. 157. His appointment dated June 12th, 1482. There is an order ibid. 3th of that month, to assign "¦dred pundes for the beying of 120 draught housez ofr the carriege of our order oure towne of Newcastlell northwardes into Scotland, and 200 marks for the byng mill-sheves of arrowes to be bought and spente in the said parties for the subuying an of our rebelles an enemyes.".
In the year 1483, the 1st of Richard III. John Carlisle was mayor, and Robert Stockett, sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: John Sherwood, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: A. D. 1484, George Carr was mayor, and George Bird, sheriff.

A convention for a marriage' between James, then Duke of Rosy, heir apparent of the King of Scotland, and Ann, daughter of the Duke of Suffolk, and niece of the English King, as soon within three years as the parties came of sit age, was agreed upon to be ratified December 6th this year, in the church of St. Nicholas in Newcastle upon Tyne;
Foedera, tom. xii. p. 245. Ripath's Border History, p. 450. This conventia was signed at Nottingham, September 21st, 1485, by a congress of plenipotent for composing the dissensions between the Kingdomes, This appears that the union was first projected in the reign of King Richard III an yet then had been intermarriages be∣fore this period.
In 1485, 1486, Robert Manners, of Etal, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland.
but it was a felicity not destined to this Ann, but reserved for Margaret, daughter of Henry VII. by a marriage with the King of Scotland, to lay the foundation of a real, and we trust everlasting, coalition between. kingdoms united by nature, but which for a series of ages were unna∣turally, and very unhappily disjoined.
In the year 1485, Robert Chambers was mayor, and Thomas Har∣bourn, sheriff.
A. D. 1486, George Carr was mayor, and Robert Brigham, sheriff.
In the year 1487, George Carr was mayor, and John Penreth, sheriff.

About the middle of August this year, King Henry VII. arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne, on a progress through the northern counties, and carrying on a severe inquisition against the persons who had been concerned in the late rebellion: he continued to reside in that town during the remainder of the summerHall's Chronicle, Hen. VII. fol. 11. Rlpa' Border History, p. 455..
A. D. 1488, Thomas Lockwood was mayor, and William Richard∣son, sheriff.
In the year 1489, George Carr was mayor, and William Cham∣bers, sheriff.
A. D. 1490, Peter Bewick was mayor, and Thomas Morpeth, sheriff.
In the year 1491, George Carr was mayor, and Robert Harding, sheriff.
A. D. 1492, the same mayor continued, and Bartholomew Young, alias Younghusband, was sheriff.
In the year 1493, George Bird was mayor, and Thomas Hard∣bread, sheriff.

June 25th this year, a truce was concluded at Edinburgh between the two kingdoms, to last for seven years from the last of April, 1494
Foedera, tom. xii. p. 534. Ridpath ut
In 1487 and 1488, Henry, Earl of Northumberland, was sheriff of that county. From 1489 to 1494, no name occurs. In 1494, Roger Fenwick. No name till 1497, when Robert Grey de Horton occurs. In 1498, George Taylboys, Knight. No name occurs till 1502, when Edward Radcliff, of Cartington, Knight, was sheriff. No name in 1503..
A. D. 1494, the same mayor continued, and Thomas Green was sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: Richard Fox, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: In the year 1495, the same mayor continued, and Christopher Brig∣ham was sheriff.
A. D. 1496, the same mayor continued, and William Hayning was sheriff.
In the year 1497, Robert Harding was mayor, and William Davel was sheriff.
A. D. 1498, George Carr was mayor, and John Penrith, sheriff.
In the year 1499, Robert Brigham was mayor, and John Snow, sheriff.
A. D. 1500, George Carr was mayor, and William Riddell, sheriff.
In the year 1501, Bartholomew Young was mayor, and William Selby, sheriff.
A. D. 1502, George Carr was mayor, and Thomas Hall, or Hill, sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: William Sewer, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: In the year 1503, John Snow was mayor, and Robert Baxter, sheriff.

July 24th this year, Margaret, eldest daughter of Henry the Seventh, then affianced to James IV. King of Scotland, arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne, on her way to that kingdom, where she was entertained
Leland's Collectanea, vol. iv. p. 277, new edition.
"The 24th of the said monthe the Queene departed from Durham accompanyed of hyr noble company, as she had beene in the dayes past, in fayr manere and good ordre for to com to the towne of the Newcastell. Thre mylle fore then; came to her the prior of Tynemouth, well apoynted, and in hys company 30 horsys. Hys folks in his lyveray, and ther was in lykwys Syr Rawff Harbotell, Knyght, richly apoynted, well mounted, and his folks in hys lyveray to the nombre of 40 horsys.
"At the intrynge of the said towne of Newecastell the Quene apoynted hyr and intred in noble astat. Ich lord and others tuke newe horsys rychely apoynted, in special th' Erle of Northumberland, as in the manere of the entryng of York, and hys folks in lyke wyse.
"Upon the bryge cam in processyon rychely revested the college of the said towne, and with them the Freres Carmelets and Jacobins with the crossys the wich was gyffen to the sayd Quene to kysse as before by the archbyschop; after them was the mayr of the said towne, accompanyed of the scheryffe and aldermen well apoynted on foot, the wich receyved the said Quene honorably; and after the receyvynge the said mayr monted on horsback, beryng his masse before hyr.
"At the bryge end upon the gatt war many children, revelled of surpeliz synggyng mellodiously hympnes, and playyng on instrumentes of many sortes.
"Within the said towne by ordre the bourges and habitaunts war honnestly apoynted, the streytts were hanged and the wyndow loupps, toppes and schippes was so full of people, gentylmen and gentylwomen in so grett nombre that it was a playsur for to se, but they maid non found of artyllery and ordinaunce.
"In such statt and fayr aray was the said Quene brought and conveyed to the Freres Austyns wher she was lodged, and honnestly received by thos revested with the crosse, in the manner as it is rehersyd befor. And when she was brought to hyr lodgyng every man drew to his awn. The next day after being the 25th St. Jamys day she abode all the day in the said towne, and was at the churche messe varey nobly accompanyd.
"That sam day at even th' Erle of Northumbreland made to many lords, knights, and others a goodely baunket, which lasted to mydnyght for cause of the games, daunces, sports and songs, with force of ypocres, succres and other metts of many delicyouses maners.
"On the 26th the mayr conveyed her out of town and then took leave of her; half a mile out town she was met by Sir Humphrey Lisle and the prior of Brinkbourne, and a mile from thence by the sheriff of Northumberland."
She lay that night at Newminster, near Morpeth.
(From a MS. late in the possession of John Anstis, Esq garter king at arms, intitled, "The Fyancels of Margaret," &c. written by John Young, who was then Somerset herald, and attended princess, on her journey into Scotland.)
In 1504, Ralph de Eure, of Kirkley, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. No name occurs in 1505. In 1506, Thomas Ilderton, of Ilderton, Knight. No name oc∣curs in 1507.
In 1508, Nicholas Ridley, of Willimoteswick, Knights also in 1509, 1510, and 1511, No name occurs till 1515. with great state, and left the town on the 26th following.
A. D. 1504, Christopher Brigham was mayor, and John Blaxton, sheriff.
In the year 1505, the same mayor continued, and John Brandling was sheriff.
A. D. 1506, George Bird was mayor, and Thomas Sanderson, sheriff.
In the year 1507, Bartholomew Younghusband was mayor, and William Harbred, sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: Christopher Bainbridge, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: A. D. 1508, Robert Baxter was mayor, and Thomas Leighton, sheriff.
In the year 1509, the first of Henry VIII. John Brandling was mayor, and Edward Baxter, sheriff.
A. D. 1510, Thomas Riddel was mayor, and Roger (or Robert) Dent, sheriff.
In the year 1511, George Bird was mayor, but died in his office, and was succeeded by Christopher Brigham, and John Paslopp, or Palstay, was sheriff.
A. D. 1512, John Brandling was mayor, and Thomas Horsley, sheriff.
In the year 1513, John Blaxton was mayor, and William Harding, sheriff.

The Earl of Surrey, in the absence of King Henry VIII. ordered a rendezvous of military forces at Newcastle upon Tyne, September 1st this year. He arrived at that town 30th of August, on an expedi∣tion againlt Scotland, hostilities having been renewed between the two kingdoms.
He had procured the banner of St. Cuthbert from the church of Durham.

He was joined at Alnwick, on the 4th of September, by his son Thomas, lord admiral, accompanied with a great number of forces, both soldiers and mariners, which he had brought by sea to Newcastle. On the 9th of that month was fought the battle of Flodden-Field, where the King of Scotland was slain, and from whence his body first taken to Berwick, was afterwards sent to Newcastle upon Tyne, and from thence removed to the monastery of Shene, or Richmond, in SurreyRidpath's Border History, p. 486, 494..
A. D. 1514, Thomas Horsley was mayor, and Robert Watson, sheriff.

In the year 1515, Roger Dent was mayor, and Robert Russel, sheriffIn 1515, Ralph Fenwick, of Stanton, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. No name occurs till 1518, when Christopher Thirkell, Esq was sheriff. In 1519, George Skelton, Esq In 1520, Christopher Dacre, Knight. In 1521, William Elleker, Esq In 1522 and 1523, no names occur..
A. D. 1516, John Brandling was mayor, and Peter Chaitor, sheriff.
In the year 1517, Edward Baxter was mayor, and Nicholas Richard∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1518, the same mayor continued, and Thomas Baxter was sheriff.
In the year 1519, Thomas Horsley was mayor, and Gilbert Middle∣ton, sheriff.
A. D. 1520, John Brandling was mayor, and Henry Anderson, sheriff.
In the year 1521, Thomas Riddell was mayor, and George Davell, sheriff.
A. D. 1522, Edward Baxter was mayor, and Robert Bertram, sheriff.
In the year 1523, Edward Baxter was mayor, and James Lawson, sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: Thomas Woolsey, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: A. D. 1524, Thomas Horsley was mayor, and Robert Brandling, sheriff.
In the year 1525, the same mayor continued, and John Watson was sheriff.
A. D. 1526, Thomas Riddell was mayor, and Edward Swinburn, sheriff.
In the year 1527, John Blaxton was mayor, and William Carr, sheriff.
A. D. 1528, Edward Swinburn was mayor, and Andrew Bewick sheriff.
In the year 1529, James Lawson was mayor, and Bartholomew Bee, sheriff.
A. D. 1530, Gilbert Middleton was mayor, and Roger Mitford sheriff.

DIV3.HEAD: Cuthbert Tunstall, Master of the Rolls, Bishop of Durham.
DIV3.P: In the year 1531, Henry Anderson was mayor, and John Ander∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1532, Robert Brandling was mayor, and Ralph Carr, sheriff.
In the year 1533, Thomas Horsley was mayor, and William Dent sheriff.
In October this year, a truce was concluded for a year, by commis∣sioners of England and Scotland, at Newcastle upon TyneHall's Chronicle. Ridpath's Border History, p. 533..
A. D. 1534 Ralph Carr was mayor, and Peter Bewick, sheriff.
In the year 1535, Thomas Baxter was mayor, and Thomas Bewick, sheriff.

This year the King made great exertions to conciliate the friendship of his nephew the King of Scotland, having conferred upon him the order of the garter, and solicited a personal interview to be held at York; but James and his council preferred Newcastle, as a more pro∣per place for that purpose: the meeting however was postponed
Ridpath ut supra, p. 536.
In 1524, William Elleker, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1525, William Heron, Knight. In 1526, William Eure, Knight, of Kirkley. In 1527, Curthbert Rad∣cliff, of Cartington, Knight. No name occurs till 1540..
A. D. 1536, Robert Brandling was mayor, and John Orde or Urde, sheriff.
In the year 1537, John Sanderson was mayor, and John White, sheriff.
A. D. 1538, Andrew Bewick was mayor, and George Selby, sheriff.
In the year 1539, Henry Anderson was mayor, and John Hilton, sheriff.
A. D. 1540, James Lawson was mayor, and Robert Brigham, sheriff.
In the year 1541, James Hilton was mayor, and Robert Lewin, sheriff.

This year, while King Henry VIII. was at York, expecting an in∣terview with the King of Scotland, which had been agreed upon, and would have taken place if James had not broken the appointment, the mayor of Newcastle waited upon him with a present of 100l. He was complimented in the like manner by the chief magistrate of York, and that of Kingdom upon Hull. The year following hostilities re-com∣menced between the two kingdomsRidpath's Border History, p. 538. Oldmixon's History, p. 125..
In the year 1542, Henry Anderson was mayor, and Mark Shaftoe, sheriff.

This year Earl Fitzwilliams, who led the van of the army against the Scots, of which the Duke of Norfolk
In the Harleian MSS. No. 6989, 51, occurs a letter of the council, dated September 10th, 1542, to the Duke of Norfolk, signifying that the Duke of Suffolk, with 6000 men, was to abide at Newcastle upon Tyne, while he invaded Scotland.
In a letter from the Earl of Hertford, and Sir Rafe Sadler, to the lords of the council, dated from Newcastle 13th of March, 1543, occurs the following passage: "There have been seen on this cost thes ten or twelve days seven saile, suspected to be Frenchmen, being tall shippes of two or three toppes, which kepe aloof in the sea aganst Scath-Rode, and hover alone this cost, by all lyklihood to lye in awayte for such shippes as the merchants of this towne have at this tyme in Flander, and such other as shall com in theyr way." As also the following:
"Ye knowe the King's Majestie hathe appoynted to have a thousand kerne hacbutiers sent hither out of Ireland, which I trust shall , here shortly: there may be now sent hither by see when my lord admiral cometh, one thousand demy hakes for the said kerne; for neyther bring they any with them, nor yet is here any to be gotten." (Burleigh's State Papers, p. 13.) They add, "This towne is utterly disfurnished, and unprovided of all maner of grayn for any such purpose as victualling the Kinge's Majesties army when the same shall arrive."
In 1540, John de Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight, was sheriff of Northum∣berland. In 1541, Reginald Carnaby, of Halton-Tower, Knight. In 1542, John Delaval, of Delaval-Castle, or Scaton-Delaval, Knight. In 1543, Thomas Hilton, Knight. was general, died at New∣castle
upon Tyne; in honour of whose memory, his standard was borne in the foreward throughout that whose expeditionDugdale's Baronage, tom. ii. p. 106..
A. D. 1543, Robert Brandling was mayor, and Bartholomew Ander∣son, sheriff.

This year, on the death of James the Fifth, of Scotland, King Henry projected a marriage between his son Edward, then but five years old, and Mary, the infant queen of that kingdom: certain Scottish nobles, who had been made prisoners at a late defeat near Solway, were deputed into Scotland for this purpose, where they arrived about the middle of January, having first delivered hostages to the Duke of Suffolk, lieu∣tenant of the north, at Newcastle upon Tyne, for their return. Faction, however, prevented also this laudable intention of extinguishing the inveterate hatred of the two nationsRidpath's Border History, p, 542, 543..
In the year 1544, Robert Lewin was mayor, and Cuthbert Ellison,, sheriff.

The last day of March this year, a rendezvous of military forces was ordered at Newcastle upon Tyne: a fleet with 200 ships, and 5000 soldiers and mariners, arrived at Tinmouth-Haven, about March 21st, and sailed with an army of 10,000 men for Scotland, about the end of the April following.
They had been prevented from putting to sea sooner by the want of a fair wind.

They returned from this invasion to Berwick upon Tweed, on the 18th of the May following
Burleigh's State Papers, p. 13.
Ibid p. 41. The army appears to have been mustered at Newcastle, at a place called "the Shellfelde.".
About this time the plague raged at NewcastleTrinity-House books..
In the year 1545, George Davel was mayor, and Oswald Chapman, sheriff.

May 21st this year, there was an array of military forces towards the northern parts
Ridpayh's Border History, p. 554.—"The Earl of Hertford was again trusted this summer with the command in the north of England."
The following occurs in a collection of original letters, &c. to the Archbishop of York, president of the council in the north, of the date of 1546.
" Able men in Newcastel upon Tyne 1714, whereof furnished with harnes and hors
archers 27,
byllmen 53.
"—Com. Northumbr'—
Horsemen 1714.
Fotemen 3800.
"Able men in the byshopryk of Duresme 2402, whereof furnyshed with horse and hernes
archers 260,
speremen 4,
byllmen 494. .
A. D. 1546, Henry Anderson was mayor, and Edward Baxter, sheriff.
In the year 1547, Robert Brandling was mayor, and Thomas Scott, sheriff.

This year the Earl of Hertford, now Duke of Somerset, and pro∣tector of the kingdom during the minority of Edward VI. assembled a great army against Scotland at Newcastle upon Tync
The story and proces of the journey.
"Saterday the 27 of August. My lorde protectours grace, whom neyther y lenght werines of the way did any whit let spedely to further that he had deliberately taken my hande, riding all the way from London his own person in post, accompanied with my lorde marshall and Syr Frauncis Bryan, was met a 6 mile on thys syde Newecastell, by my lorde lieuetenaunt and master treasurer (who for the more spedie dispatch of thinges were cummon to toune there 3 or 4 days before), and all the nobles, knightes and capitaynes of the armye on hors backe, attending upon them. And commyng thus to toune, my lordes grace was honorably (for the dignitie of the place) with gonthot and presence of the mayor, alderman and commoners there, aboute 3 of the clocke in the afternone, recyved and welcommed and lay at the house of Peeter Ryell.
"Sundaye the 28th of August. Thys daye mornyng, in the ld of the neithe the towne, monster was made of suche dimie launces and horse mn a were wherat my lordes grace was hymself, my lorde lieutenaunt, and other of the of the army.
"In the afternone came the Lord of Mangierton with a 40 Scottish gentelmen of the east borders, and presented themselfes to my lorde at hys lodgynge, whome hys grace did gentlye accept.
"It would not be forgotten and it were but for ensamples sake, how a newe paire of gallowes were set up in the market place, and a souldior hanged for quarellyng and fightyng.
"Mondaye the 29 of August. All capitaynes with theyr bandes that had ben monstred, were commaunded forwarde. My lordes grace himself dyd early also part the toune, dyned at Morpeth 12 mile on the waye, and lay that night in Anwyke-Castell with Syr Robert Bowes, Knight, lord warden of the middle marches, being 12 mile further. Where there neyther lact anye store of geastes or of good chere to wel∣cumme them with. In the provision wherof a man myght note great cost and diligence, and in the spending a liberal hart."
(From an extremely rare book, entitled "The Expedicion into Scotlande of the most woorthely fortunate Prince Edward, Duke of Soomertset, uncle unto our most noble sovereign Lord the Kinges Majestie Edward the 6. goovernour of hys hyghnes persone and protectour of hys graces realmes, dominions and subjectes, made in the first yere of his Majesties most prosperous reign, and set out by way of diarie by W. Patten, Londoner. Vivat victor."—The peroration concludes thus: "Out of the parsonage of S. Mary-Hill in London, this 28 of January, 1548."—London, printed by Richard Grafton, last day of June, 1548, 2 Ed. VI.): they were
mustered at that town by John Dudley, then Earl of Warwick; and waiting three days until the royal fleet arrived, reached Berwick upon Tweed at the end of August
"The King's fleet consisted of 65 bottoms, whoreof one open galley and 34 tall ships were well appointed for fight; the rest served for carriage of ammunition and vic∣tuals: of the fleet, Edward Lord Clinton was admiral, and Sir William Wood-house his vice-admiral."—Sir John Haywood.
"The whole army consisted of between 1200 and 1300 foot, and 1300 men at arms, 2000 light-horse, being such men for their goodly personages, their ready horses, their brave apparel, their armour and weapons, as never before was an army set forth in all points better appointed."—Ibid.. After this expedition, the protector re∣turned to Newcastle, where he conferred the honour of knighthood on Robert Brandling, the above mayor
Ridpath's Border History, p. 563.—Oldmixon, p. 162.
In 1544, John Collingwood, of Eslington, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1545, Thomas Hilton, Knight. In 1546, John Horseley, Esq In 1547, John Delaval, of Seaton-Delaval, Knight. In 1548, Thomas Hilton, Knight. In 1549, John Forster, Knight. In 1550, John Gray, Knight. In 1551, Robert Collingwood, of Eslington, Knight..
In the year 1548, Mark Shaftoe was mayor, and Cuthbert Blunt, sheriff.
A. D. 1549, Cuthbert Ellison was mayor, and Richard Hodshon, sheriff.
In the year 1550, Robert Brigham was mayor, and Cuthbert Mus∣grave, sheriff.
A. D. 1551, Bartholomew Anderson was mayor, and Cuthbert Mitford, sheriff.
In the year 1552, Robert Lewin was mayor, and John Raw, sheriff.

In the months of July and August this year, the Duke of Northum∣berland (late Earl of Warwick), as lord warden general of all the marches, diligently surveyed them in person.—He was at Newcastle upon Tyne the 12th of August, where he appointed Lord Wharton his deputy. Several articles of discipline relating to the defence of the borders were established or revived on this occasion: watches by day and night were stationed in each of the marches. These were under the superintendance of the principal gentlemen in the neighbourhood of each, or of the officers and tenants of the King, who were intitled overseers, to set and search themRidpath's Border History, p. 574, 575. See Nicholson's Border Laws, p. 195..
In 1553, Cuthbert Blunt was mayor, and Robert Ellison, sheriff.

This year Gateshead was annexed by act of parliament to New∣castle upon Tyne
See account of "Gateshead." By an act of parliament passed 1553, it was enacted, that in Newcastle upon Tyne there should be no greater number than four taverns or wine-sellers, to sell or utter wine by retail.—See Anderson's Dictionary of Commerce.
King Edwards VI. on the dissolution of the bishoprick of durham, granted to New∣castle, the town and liberties of Gateshead: he also proposed to have erected a bishoprick at Newcastle, out of part of the revenues of the dissolved fee: but these purposes were defeated by the death of the King, and, on the accession of Queen Mary, the bishoprick of Durham was restored. The bishoprick of Newcastle was to have 1000 marks a year, with a cathedral church, and a deanary and chapter, with a proviso, that the rights of the manery, chapter, chatedral of Durham should s̄uffer nothing by this act.
Ridley, being a native of that county, was named to be the Newcastle bishop, and (the Duke of) Northumberland had the bishoprick given him, which was turned into a princ∣cipality for that purpose. This county palatine was the bait, which drew the Duke of Northumberland to seek the destruction of that prelate (Tunstal), and the dissolution of the bishoprick.—Parliamentary History, vol. iii. p. 269, 270..
In the year 1554, Cuthbert Ellison was mayor, and William Dixon, sheriff.
A. D. 1555, Richard Hodgson was mayor, and John Wilkinson, sheriff.
In the year 1556, Christopher Mitford was mayor, and William Dent, sheriff.
A. D. 1557, Bartholomew (or Bertram) Anderson was mayor, and William Carr, sheriff.
In the year 1558, Oswald Chapman was mayor, and Andrew Surtees, sheriff.

This year Newcastle upon Tyne was in great danger of having been surprised by the French, who intended by that way to have invaded England. A rendezvous of military forces was appointed to be at that town on the 25th of January following, in order to repel them
Strype's Annals, vol. — p. 17, 18.
In 1552, Thomas Grey, of Horton-Castle, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. Another account says, John Widdrington. In 1553, John Delaval, of S. D. Knight. No names occur till 1557, when Robert Ellerker, Knight, was sheriff. In 1558, George Ratcliff, of Cartington, Knight..
In the year 1559, the first of Queen Elizabeth, Robert Ellison was mayor, and Robert Anderson, sheriff; and the year following Cuthbert Musgrave was mayor, and Francis Anderson, sheriff.

About the end of the year 1559, the Duke of Norfolk came to Newcastle upon Tyne as lord lieutenant-general of the north, to muster an army, which, in conjunction with a fleet of ships of war, were intended to support the protestant party in Scotland, against the great forces that had been transported thither by the FrenchRidpath's Border History, p. 597..

Queen Elizabeth, in a letter to the Duke, dated December 30th that year, desired him to borrow seven or eight hundred pounds of some
of the Newcastle merchants, till her own money should arrive, the car∣riage of which was troublesome and tedious during winter
Burleigh's State Papers, vol. i. p. 247, 217.
By a letter from Lord John Grey, (ibid.) p. 295, to Secretary Cecil, dated from Pyrgo, April 20th, 1560, it appears that the former advised the undermining of Leith, and pointed it out as a very practicable measure, adding; "The coal-myners of New∣castell wyll serve to doo this well inoch: therefore I pray you set yt at work."
In a letter from the Duke of Norfolk to Secretary Cecil, from Berwick, dated May 24th, 1560, mention occurs of "dischargyng of Newcastel schyps and Hull."—Ibid..

By letters from his grace at Newcastle, to the privy-council, dated February 16th and 20th, 1560, it appears that six ships of that town were to be well furnished, and set to sea within ten days, carrying four hundred soldiers, besides a sufficient quantity of mariners, for the reinforcement of the royal fleet then lying in Edinburgh Frith.

In the instructions given by Quecn Elizabeth to Sir William Cecil, Knight, her principal secretary, and Doctor Wooton, Dean of Canter∣bury and York, her commissioners appointed to meet and treat with those of the French King, dated May 26th, 1560; they are ordered to be at Newcastle upon Tyne by the 5th of June following
Forbes' State Papers, vol. i. p. 49.
In 1559, John Delaval, of Delaval-Castle, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. Another account says, John Widdrington. In 1560, Albany Fetherstonhaugh, of Fether∣stone-Castle, Knight..
In the year 1561, John Wilkinson was mayor, and Stephen Sou∣theren, sheriff.

This year Queen Elizabeth appointed Lord Hunsdon, governor of Berwick upon Tweed, to take the charge and government of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and county of Northumberland, under the Earl of Essex
Burleigh's State Papers, vol. i. p. 374.
There occurs an order, ibid. p. 554, from the Queen, dated October 16th, 1569, to the Lord Hunsdon, for him to repair to Newcastle upon Tyne, on account of the rebellion of the Earls of Northumberland and Westmoreland that year..
A. D. 1562, William Dent was mayor, and George Selby, sheriff.
In the year 1563, Bertram Anderson was mayor, and Thomas Liddle sheriff.

A. D. 1564In 1564, a person of the name of Partrage was executed at Newcastle upon Tyne, for coining false money at that town. "This year, 1564, Partrage was put downe for coyn∣ing false money in the Great Innes, in Pilgrim-street."—Carr MS., Robert Brandling was mayor, and William Selby, sheriff.
In the year 1565, William Carr was mayor, and Anthony Swin∣burn, sheriff.

A. D. 1566
"When Rizzio was slain in the prefence of the Quene of Scots, March 9th, 1566, Murray, and the other exiled lords who were lurking at Newcastle, and were in concert with the King and his associates in this enterprize, returned in the evening of the follow∣ing day to Edinburgh."—Ridpath's Border History, p. 620.
"The Earl of Morton, the Lords Ruthven and Lindsay, and Secretary Maitland, fled to Newcastle.—Old Ruthven died there in June following; and the Earl of Morton and his son continued lurking near Alnwick, and other places on the borders, till they obtained their pardon, and were restored."—Ibid. p. 621.
In 1561, Robert Lawson, of Rock, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1562, Henry Percy, Knight. In 1563, Ralph Grey, of Heton, Knight. In 1564, Thomas Forster, of Etherston, Esq. In 1565, Thomas Delaval, Esq In 1566, George Heron, Esq In 1567, Cuthbert Carnaby, of Halton-Tower, Knight. In 1568 Cuthbert Col∣lingwood, of Essington, Knight., Richard Hodgshon was mayor, and Henry Brandling, sheriff.
In the year 1567, Robert Anderson was mayor, and John Watson, sheriff.
A. D. 1568, Henry Brandling was mayor, and William Jennison, sheriff.
In the year 1569, Christopher Mitford was mayor, and George Simpson, sheriff.

This year the Earls of Northumberland and Westmoreland raised a rebellion against Queen Elizabeth, which was soon crushed by the spirited exertions of the Earl of Sussex, at that time her lieutenant in the north
Hollingshead, vol. i. p. 511, edit. London, 1577.
"Sir John Forster, warden of the middle matches, took the castles of Alnwick and Warkworth from the tenants and dependants of the Earl of Northumberland.—He after∣wards mustered for the Queen 1100 horsemen, and waylaid the passes by which that Earl's friends in Northumberland could go to join him." "After this," adds Hollingshead, "having in his company the Lord Ogle, and Thomas Forster, his brother, and other gen∣tlemen, he went to Newcastell, where, with Thomas Gower, Esq that had the principal rule thereof at that present, he took order for the desense of that town agaynst the rebells. Hither came to him Sir Henry Percy, offeryng his service agaynst his brother, and other the rebells to the uttermost of his power. Hereupon, divers excursions were made forth of Newcastell into Bishoprick, where the two Earls were encamped, and sundry skirmishes chanced betwixt the parties, though no great hurte followed thereof. The Earles yet one day came from Durham, and with their army marched towards Newcastell. Sir John Forster, and Sir Henry Percy, having intelligence thereof, issued forth of Newcastell with all their forces, and certain pieces of great ordnance.—At Chester-Dean, midway betwixt Durham and Newcastell, the armies approched the one near to the other, a small brooke renning in a hollow devided them in sunder, so that there was no passage for them to convey their ordinaunce over, the bankes on either side beying so steepe and cum∣bersome. Whereupon the Earles perceivyng that they were disappointed of their purpose, after some skirmishes betwixt the horsemen, they returned into Durham." Soon after∣wards they fled in utter despair into Scotland, whence the Earl of Westmoreland escaped out of the island, but the Earl of Northumberland was taken prisonerQueen Elizabeth damned a mine clonglog to the Earl of Northumberland, a was the cause of . It was at that tunc supposed to be of that valu, but afterwards came again possession of the family, and was attempted to be wrought, it for nothing..
In 1569, Robert Raymes, of Bolam, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. In 157, Nicholas Ridley, of Willimoteswick, Knight. In 1571, John Delaval, of Delaval-Castle, Knight, and George Heron, of Chipchace, Knight. In 1572, Thomas Forster, of Ether∣ston, Esq In 1573, Cuthbert Carnaby, of Halton-Tower, Knight. In 1574, Thomas Grey, of Heton, Knight. In 1575, Robert Delaval, Knight. In 1576, Robert Muddle∣ton, Esq In 1577, Francis Russell, Knight, killed June 27th, 1585. In 1578, Wilham de Fenwick, of Wallington, Knight. In 1579, Henry Widdington, of Widdrington. Castle, Knight..
A. D. 1570, Rubert Ellison was mayor, and George Briggs, sheriff.
In the year 1571, William Jennison was mayor, and Henry Ander∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1572, Thomas Liddell was mayor, and Robert Barker, sheriff.
In the year 1573, William Selby was mayor, and Mark Shaftoe, sheriff.
A. D. 1574, John Watson was mayor, and Roger Rawe, sheriff.
In the year 1575, Henry Brandling was mayor, and William Ridle, sheriff.
This year it was in agitation to unite Gateshead a second time, by an act of parliament, to Newcastle upon TyneJournals of Commons, 13th of March, 1575..
In the year 1576, the same mayor continued, and Christopher Lewin was sheriff.
In November this year, Mr. Thomas Sutton, the founder of the Charter-House in London, occurs as master of the Queen's ordnance at Newcastle upon TyneSt. Nicholas' Register. Baptisms—as a surety.
A. D. 1577, Robert Barker was mayor, and Edward Lewin, sheriff.
In the year 1578, Mark Shaftoe was mayor, and Henry Leonard, sheriff.
A. D. 1579, Roger Rawe was mayor, and James Carr, sheriff.

This year the mayor, aldermen, and sheriff of Newcastle wrote to the bailiffs of Yarmouth, on account of a grievous plague which had carried off, between May and Michaelmas, about 2,000 persons, to for∣bid their ships to come to that place as usual for coalsHistory of Great Yarmouth, p. 393..

In the year 1580, Richard Hodgshon was mayor, and Robert Atkin∣son, sheriffIn the 23d of Queen Elizabeth, there were on the northern circuit "Robertus Shut, secundus baro de scaccario Domine Regine, Edmundus Anderson serviens Domine Regine ad legem."—Villa Novi Castri super Tinam.—Year Book, by Rastell, A. D. 1580..
A. D. 1581, William Jennison was mayor, and Henry Chapman, sheriff.
In the year 1582, William Riddel was mayor, and Henry Mitford, sheriff.
A. D. 1583, Henry Anderson was mayor, and Roger Nicholson, sheriff.

In the year 1584, Henry Mitford was mayor, and Lionel Maddison, sheriff
It appears that, in the year 1583, packets were carried by the post between London and Berwick upon Tweed in forty-two hour in summer, and in sixty hours in winter.
"lrsy s yne and allowed by the lords of his Majesty's previe counsell, and ap∣pointed tyo be put in printe, for the po between London and the borders of Scotland. At Westem. the 14th of Janu, 18."—"The packet m be carried in somer be¦tween London and Pa 4. in in ."—MS. Ctton Library. fol. 467. V . p. 1 ..

This year the ejected nobles of Scotland, who had been ordered by proclamation to leave that kingdom, and on their arrival at Berwick became suppliants to Queen Elizabeth for her protection and inter∣cession on their behalf with their sovereign, were removed, after a short stay at Berwick, and the Queen had resolved to entertain them, to Newcastle upon TyneRidpath' p. , 1..
A. D. 1585, Robert Barker was mayor, and George Whitfield, sheriff.
In the year 1586, Henry Chapman was mayor, and Robert Dudley, sheriff.
June 9th this year, mention occurs of Sir Simon Musgrave, Knight, as master of the Queen's ordnance in the Mannor-House in Newcastle upon Tynex St. .
A. D. 1587, Edward Lewin was mayor, and Robert Eden, sheriff.
In the year 1588, Roger Nicholson was mayor, and George Farnaby, sheriff.
The next year, William Selby was mayor, and John Gibson, sheriff.

A. D. 1588 and 1589, a grievous plague raged at Newcastle upon Tyne, of which there died in all 1727 persons before the 1st of January, 1590
of the John 3, of which 103 i the me In the nm the Earl of Huntingdon's car was reoud before him at Newcastle upon Tyne, up on the expectation of the that time, on 2 Chron. .20.—ninth Sunday after Trinity, when the Spaniards were expected to invade us."—Dr. Ellison's MS. copy o Bishop Matthew's Diary.
The corporation of Newcastle occur about this time as keeping their fool.—The fol∣lowing entry is in St. John's Register: "August, 1589, Edward Errington, the towne's fooll, buried the 23d of August, died in the peste."
In the year 1580, Cuthbert Collingwood, of Eslington, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland. In 1581, John Heron, Esq In 1582, Ralph Grey, Esq In 1583, Robert Delaval, Esq In 1584, James Ogle, Esq In 1585, Richard Ridley, of Willemoteswicke, Esq In 1586, Robert Clavering, of Calleley, Esq In 1587, Henry Anderson, Esq In 1588, the same. In 1589, William de Fenwick, of Wallington, Knight. In 1590, Alexander Fetherstonhaugh, of Fetherston-Castle, Esq.
In the year 1590, William Riddell was mayor, and Ralph Jenni∣son, sheriff.
In the year 1591, George Farnaby was mayor, and William Green∣well, sheriff.
A. D. 1592, Roger Rawe was mayor, and Thomas Liddell, sheriff.

In the year 1593, Lionel Maddison was mayor, and William Jenni∣son, sheriff"1593. This yeare came two of the states of the Low Country into Scotland to christen the young prince, and from thence came to this towne (Newcastell), and staied at the mayors, and lodged there."—Carr MS..
A. D. 1594, Henry Anderson was mayor, and George Selby, sheriff.

This year Thomas Boast, a Roman catholic priest, was executed at Newcastle upon Tyne
Wilford's Memorials, p. 546.
In a letter of Sir Henry Wotton to Lord Zouch, written at Vienna, in the year 1595, he gives the following most remarkable account of a native of Newcastle upon Tyne.
"There is a certain English northern man in this town, born at Newcastle, who hath served the King of Denmark, Succia, and Poland; travelled the seventeen provinces, Muscovia, Liefland, France; been taken prisoner in Spain, cousened by another English∣man in Italy of all his money and apparel; lives now by sweet'ning of gloves; shall marry with a concubine of the Jesuits, as some say, but as I hear more probably with a com∣mon courtesan, upon condition if he can be made burge of Vienna. He hath lately given up a supplication to the Archduke to be entertained in service, and received as a round answer that touches our whole nation, that the Dutch can get no service in England, and the English are like to find the like here; but if he want money to bring him home, or buy him some honest apparel, for the honour of his queen, he shall have so much given him. This answer was sent him yesterday by one of the Duke's servants.—His name is Andrew Miller, of a very low stature, a great drunkard, full of words and lies, not able to keep his own dishonesties close, which he tells with a pride—red faced. If he comes unto your honour, you may know him by this description."—Life of Sir Henry Wotton, 649, 650.
"1596. This yeare, 25th of February, the eclipse of the sun at ten o'clock in the forenoon, fearful to all people's sight to behold, and was called the dark Saturday before Shrove∣tide."—Carr MS.
In 1591, Ralph Grey, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1592, Robert Delaval, Esq In 1593, Ralph Grey, Esq In 1594, and 1595, Thomas Bradford, Esq In 1596, George Muschampe..
In the year 1595, William Riddell was mayor, and Francis Ander∣son, sheriff.
In 1596, Ralph Jennison was mayor, but died in his mayoralty, 1597, and Henry Chapman succeeded for the remainder of the year; Adrian Hedworth was sheriff.
In the year 1597, Thomas LiddellGreat great great grand-father of the late Lord Ravensworth. was mayor, and William Hunt∣ley, sheriff.

Mention occurs, July 6th this year, of the plague being at Newcastle upon Tyne
Strype's Annals, vol. i. p. 306, No. 223. The justices of assize appear to have ad∣journed the assizes and jail delivery in the counties of Durham and Northumberland, in regard of the great infection of the plague, especially in and about Durham and Newcastle.
March 7th, 1599, a rumour prevailed that the town of Newcastle upon Tyne was to be besieged.—Bishop Matthew's (then Dean Matthew's) Diary.—Dr. Ellison's MSS..
A. D. 1598, George Farnaby was mayor, and William Warmouth, sheriff.
In the year 1599, William Jennison was mayor, and James Clavering, sheriff.

In a special commission for the suppression of schism, dated Novem∣ber 24th this year, the mayors of Hull, Chester, and Newcastle upon Tyne, for the time being; Henry Anderson, and Henry Chapman, aldermen of Newcastle; John Hutton, parson of Gateshead; and Wil∣liam Morton, preacher of Newcastle, were appointed commissioners
Foedera, tom. xvi. p. 386.
The subsequent is an entry in the Register of St. John's church in Newcastle upon Tyne: "Puled Clement Roderforthe gentleman was executed in the castle the 22 day of August, 139."
In 1597, Edward Grey, Esq In 1598, the same was sheriff of Northumberlabd. In 1599, Thomas Middleton, Esq In 1600, George Muschamp, of Barmore, Esq In 161, Edward Talbot, Esq In 1602, Nicholas Forster, of Bambrough-Abbey, Knight.
In the year 1600, George Selby was mayor, and Robert Anderson, sheriff.
In the year 1601, Francis Anderson was mayor, and Thomas Riddel, sheriff.
In the year 1602, Robert Dudley was mayor, and Francis Burrell, sheriff.
In the year 1603, the first of James I. William Warmouth was mayor, and Matthew Chapman, sheriff.

Saturday, April 9th this year, King James I. on his way from Scot∣land to take possession of the crown of England, arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne: on the Sunday, Toby Matthew, Bishop of Durham, preached before him at St. Nicholas' church in that town, on the 2 Chron. xv. 1, 2. On the Wednesday following the king set forward for DurhamStowe tells us, fol. 819, that "on the 9th of April, the King set forward from Wid∣drington-Castle towards Newcastle, where his highnesse was met by the maior, aldermen, councell, and beste comoners of the same in joyful manner, the maior presenting him with the sword and keyes with humble submission, giving to his majesty also in token of love and loyalty a purse full of gold. His highnesse returned to the maior the sword and keyes, ratifying all their customs and priveleges that they were possessed of, and so was conducted to a knight's house, where he was richely entertained, and remained there three daies. Sunday the 10th of Aprill, his majestie went to church, before whom preached the Bishop of Durham. Monday he bestowed in viewing the towne. The manner and beauty, the bridge and keye, being one of the fayreste in all the north parts. Beside h released all the prisoners except for treason, murther and papistrie, giving sums of moneys for the release of many that lay for debt. So joyful were the townsmen of Newcastle his majestie being there, that they thankfully bare all the charge of his household g the time of his abode with theme, and on the 13th of April his majesty set forward for Durham." The King was entertained at the house of Sir George Selby, who was pro∣bably knighted on that occasion. Nicholas Tuften, afterwards Earl of Thane, was knighted at Newcastle upon Tyne, April 1 163.—See Dugdale's Baronag, tom. iii. p. 454. The King, soon after his arrival in London, appointed George , Cumberland, wan of the middle and west marches toward Scotland, with the ms ∣tensive powers; and also lieutenant-general of the counties of Cumberland, Northum∣berland, and of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne.—Ridpath's Border His∣tory, p. 705..
A. D. 1604, Thomas Riddell was mayor, and Peter Riddell, sheriff.
In the year 1605, Lionel Maddison was mayor, and Henry Mad∣dison, sheriff.
A. D. 1606, Sir George Selby was mayor, and Hugh Selby, sheriff.
In the year 1607, James Clavering was mayor, and Robert Shaftoe, sheriff.
A. D. 1608, Henry Chapman was mayor, and William Hall, sheriff.
In the year 1609, Thomas Liddell was mayor, and Thomas Liddell, sheriff.

This and the year following, the plague was at Newcastle
St. Nicholas' Register of burials.
In 1603, William Selby, junior, of Betlesdon, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1604, Ralph Delaval, Esq In 1605, Henry Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight. In 1606, William Selby, Knight. In 1607, George Selby, knight. In 1608, Ralph Delaval, Knight. In 1609, Edward Talbot, Esq In 1610, John Delaval, Esq In 1611, Ralph Grey, Knight. In 1612, Claudius Forster, of Bambrough-Abbey, Esq In 1613, Ralph Selby, Knight. In 1614, John Clavering, Knight. In 1615, Henry Anderson, Knight. In 1616. William Selby, Knight..
A. D. 1610, William Jennison was mayor, and Timothy Draper, sheriff.
In the year 1611, Sir George Selby was mayor, and Alexander Davison, sheriff.
A. D. 1612, Francis Anderson was mayor, and Roger Anderson, sheriff.
In the year 1613, Sir Henry Anderson was mayor, and Henry Chap∣man, sheriff.
A. D. 1614, William Warmouth was mayor, and John Cook, sheriff.
In the year 1615, Francis Burrell was mayor, and Robert Bewick, sheriff.
A. D. 1616, Sir Thomas Riddell was mayor, and Nicholas Milburn, sheriff.
In the year 1617, Lionel Maddison was mayor, and William Bonner, sheriff.

April 23d this year, King James, on his way towards Scotland, came to Newcastle upon Tyne, where he was met upon the Sand-Hill by the mayor, aldermen and sheriff; and after an oration made by the town-clerk, was presented by the mayor in the name of the whole corpora∣tion, with a great standing bowl, to the value of an hundred jacobuses, and an hundred marks in gold; the mayor carrying the sword before him, accompanied by his brethren on their foot-cloths.

On Sunday, May 4th following, his majesty, with all his nobles, dined with the mayor, when it pleased the King to be served by the mayor and aldermen. The King left the town on Monday the 5th of MayFrom an account remaining in the archives of the Corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne..

A. D. 1617, the lord president and council of the north kept their sitting in the Guild-Hall of Newcastle upon Tyne, and Lord Sheffield being then president and knight of the garter, celebrated the feast of St. George at that town
Dr. Ellison's MSS.
In 1617, Robert randling, of North-Gosforth, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland in 1618, Thomas Middleton, Esq In 1619, John Kenwick, of Wallington, Knight. I 1620, Matthew Forster, of Etherston, Esq. In 1621, Robert Delavall, of Delavall-Castle, Knight. In 1622, William Muschampe, of Barmore. In 1623, John Clavering Knight..
A. D. 1618, James Clavering was mayor, and John Clavering, sheriff.
In the year 1619, Sir Peter Riddell was mayor, and Robert Ander∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1620, Henry Chapman was mayor, and Nicholas Tempest, sheriff.
In the year 1621, William Jennison was mayor, and Henry Liddell, sheriff.

A. D. 1622, Sir George Selby was mayor, and Richard Ledger was
sheriff; but the latter died April 26th, 1623, and was succeeded by William Jackson.
In the year 1623, Henry Maddison was mayor, and Henry Bowes, sheriff. The latter was buried June 4th, 1624, and was succeeded for the remainder of the year by William Jackson.
In the year 1624, William Hall was mayor, and Lionel Maddison, sheriff.

May 17th this year, Lodowick, son of Esme Stuart, Duke of Lenox, in Scotland, was created Earl of Newcastle upon Tyne, and Duke of Richmond. He died without issue, and the title became extinct at his deathDugdale's Baronnge, tom. iii. p. 426—citing Pat. 21 Jac. p. 10..
A. D. 1625, Sir Thomas Liddell was mayor, and Ralph Cole, sheriff.
This year the plague appears to have raged at Newcastle upon TyneDr. Jennison's Newcastle's Call to her Neighbours, p. 23..
In the year 1626, Alexander Davison, was mayor, and Ralph Cock, sheriff.
A. D. 1627, Henry Chapman was mayor, and Henry Cock, sheriff.
March 7th this year, the title of Earl of Newcastle upon Tyne was revived in the person of William Cavendish, Viscount Mansfield and Baron OgleMagna Britannia..
In the year 1628, Robert Bewick was mayor, and Ralph Grey, sheriff.
A. D. 1629, John Clavering was mayor, and Robert Shaftoe, sheriff.
In the year 1630, Robert Anderson was mayor, and James Carr. sheriff.

This year a most extraordinary, and yet a seemingly well-attested account occurs of the fruitfulness of a Scotch woman, wife to a weaver▪ who bore him, as is therein asserted, sixty-two children, all of whom
lived till they were baptized: three or four of these children are repre∣sented as living this year at Newcastle upon Tyne
Harleian MSS. No. 980.—87. "Of the Scots weaver, who had 62 children by one woman, all living till they were baptized, &c."—"A weaver in Scotland had by one woman 62 children, all living till they wer baptized, of which ther wer but fower daugh∣ters onely, who lived till they wer women, and 46 sonns, all attaining to man's estate. During the time of this fruitfulness in the woman, her husband at her importunity absented himself from her for the space of 5 years together, serving as a soldier under the command of Captain Selby, in the Low Countries. After his return home, his wife was againe delivered of three children at a birth, and so in her due time continued in such births till through bearing she became impotent. The certainty of this relation I had from Joh. Delavall, of Northumb' Esq r. who, anno 1630, rid about 30 miles beyond Edinburrough to see this fruitful couple, who wer both then living. Her stature and features he described to me then more fully. Ther was not any of the children then abiding with ther parents, Sir John Bowes and three other men of qualitie having taken at severall times ten of ther children a peece from them and brought them up. The rest wer disposed of by other English and Scottish gent. amongst which 3 or four of them are now alive, and abiding at New∣castle, 1630."
N. B. The compiler of the catalogue of Harleian MSS. says, speaking of this No. 98, "By the similitude of hands, I find the collector was Thomas Gybbons, Esq"
In 1624, John Delaval, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1625, Cuthbert Heron, of Chipchace-Castle, Esq In 1626, Francis Brandling, Esq In 1627, none occurs. 1628, Thomas Swinburn, of Cap-Heaton, Knight. In 1629, none occurs. In 1630, Robert Brandling, Esq Another account says, Francis Brandling, of North-Gos∣forth, Knight. In 1631, Nicholas Towneley, Esq In 1632, Nicholas Tempest, Knight..
A. D. 1631, William Warmouth was mayor, and Henry War-mouth, sheriff.
In the year 1632, Sir Lionel Maddison was mayor, and Francis Bowes, sheriff.

This year at Shrove-tide, there was a riot of the apprentices of New∣castle, on account of a new lime-kiln and ballast-heap having been made without the gate of the town called Sand-GateGrey's MSS. No. 3. quarto..

In the year 1632, Ralph Cole was mayorIn the 3d volume of Walpole's Anecdotes of Painting in England, p. 134, is an en∣graved portrait of Sir Ralph Cole, Baronet, with the following account. "Sir Ralph Cole appears as the painter of a preture of Thomas Windlham, Esq from which there is a mezzotinto." When Brane peth-Castle was in the possession of the Bellasis family, there was a portrait of Sir Ralph Cole there. Quarte, whether still remaining at that place, or in the possession of Lord Edconide?, and Nicholas Cole, sheriff.

Tune 3d this year, King Charles I. on his way to ScotlandCarr. MS. By mistake under 1632. Echard's History. to be crowned, came to Newcastle upon Tyne, attendcd by the Earls of Northumberland, Arundel, Pembroke, Southampton, Holland, the Marquis of Hamilton, Dr. Laud, Bishop of London, and many other personages of distinction, who were all entertained by the magistrates and corporation of that town: the day following they dined with the mayor, who received the honour of knighthood on that occasion. On the 5th of June, the King visited Tinmouth-CastleSee "Tinmouth.". His majesty on his return from Scotland came also by the way of Newcastle upon TyneChurch-wndens' account, All-Saints,—where there are entires for the expence of ringing bells on his majesty's containg to that to an; and also "at his majestis return.".
A. D, 1634, Ralph Cock was mayor, and John Marley, sheriff.
In the year 1635, Sir Peter Riddell was mayor, and Leonard Carr, sherifi.
In the year 1636, Thomas Liddell was mayor, and Henry Lawson, sheriff.

The plague, which raged so dreadfully this year at Newcastlle upon Tyne, is said to have cume over from Holland, and other parts be∣yond the seasSee "Newcastle's Call to her Neighbom and Sister Townes and Cities throughtout the Land, &c. by R. Jenmson, DS. of D. London, 1637, 12o," page 2..

It began at North-Shields in October 1635, and after an intermission of some months broke out again at Newcastle May 6th, 1636, with such fury, that 14 persons died of it the first fortnightIbid. page 4.. It would pro∣bably have been accompanied with a great samine (the usual con∣comitant
comitant of a pestilence), had not the magistrates of the town exerted their utmost endeavours to prevent itNewcastle's Call, &c. p. 169..

There died in all, of this tremendous visitation, between the 7th of May and 31st of December this year, no less than 5037 persons at Newcastle upon Tyne; and at Gateshead, between 30th of May and October 17th the same year, 515 personsIbid. ad finem..

Fumigations of pitch, rosm and frankincense, appear to have been used as antidotes on this melancholy occasion, and to cleanse the apart∣ments of those who had died of it, to prevent the spreading of the in∣fectionBooks of the Trinity-House..

All trade was at a stand at Newcastle, and there is a tradition that the streets of that town were covered with grass
Merchant's Books.
In 1633, Thomas Middleton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1634, none occurs. In 1635, William Carnaby, of Halton-Tower, Knight. In 1636, William Widdrington, of Widdrington-Castle, Knight.: "The high-ways were unoccupied."
In the year 1637, John Marley was mayor, and Peter Maddison, sheriff.
A. D. 1638, Alexander Davison was mayor, and Mark Milbank, sheriff.

In the beginning of this year the magistrates of Newcastle occur as preparing military stores for the defence and safety of that townCommon-council books, January 23d, 1638. About 600l. to be raised by a cess..
In the year 1639, Robert Bewick was mayor, and John Emmerson, sheriff.

This year King Charles I. at the head of a gallant army, came to Newcastle upon Tyne, on his mareh against the Scotch covenantersNalson's Collections, vol. i. p. 218.. He came about the 5th of May, and continued in the town till the 17th of that monthIbid.. On this occasion he was received with great testimonies of duty and affection, and was magnificently entertained.
Alexander Davison, mayor, was knighted, as was Thomas Riddell, town-clerk, son of Sir Thomas Riddell the recorder, on whom the King had before conferred that honour.
This year the Town-Clerk's Office and part of the Exchange were burnt, and several of the deeds and writings of the corporation de∣stroyedDr. Ellison's MSS..
In the year 1640, Sir Nicholas Cole, Knight and Baronet, was mayor, and Francis Liddell, sheriff.

This year, August 21st, the Scottish army commanded by Lesley, Montross, and others, invaded England; and having without molesta∣tion marehed through Northumberland, came to Newburn, a village four miles above Newcastle, where there is a ford over the river Tyne
Nalson's Collections, vol. i. p. 412.
The Scottish army consisted of 20,000 foot, and 2,500 horse; and was commanded by General Lesley in chief; the Earl of Calendar, lieutenant-general; Alexander Hamilton, major-general of the artillery, &c. &c.
August 27th this year, the Scots pitched their tents upon Heddon-Law, above Newburn, from whence there is a continued descent to the river Tyne.—In the night they made great fires in and round about their camp, on an open moorish ground (having coals plenty thereabouts), so that the camp seemed to bc of large compass and extent. That night, and the next morning, they suffered any Englishmen to come into their camp, and made them welcome with expressions of great love, and protestations of doing harm to none but those who should oppose them in demanding justice of the King against incendi∣aries.—Rushworth, part. ii. vol. ii. p. 1234, et seq.
Nalson tells us, vol. i. p. 500, that his majesty's great care was for the security of New∣castle, in whieh place there was a considerable magazine of all sorts of provisions for his army..

Lord Conway, with the Earl of Strafford, general of the King's army, then at York, with 3,000 foot, and 1,500 horse, were posted op∣posite to them on the south side of that river, to guard the pass, and prevent their coming over
The same night, August 27th, 1640, part of the King's army, consisting of 3,000 foot, and 1,500 horse, were drawn forth into a plain meadow ground, near a mile in length, close on the fouth side of the Tyne, called Newburn, or Stell-Haugh, to hinder the Scots from passing the river in the night-time, where were two several sconces, or breast-works, raised by the English against the two fords, only passable at low-water, and into each sconce were put 400 musketeers, and four pieces of ordnance.—Rushworth ut supra.
The horse were drawn into squadroas in the said haugh at some distance from the foot; in this posture the horse and foot guarded the river all that night and the next day, till the engagement.—Ibid.
In the year 1637, Robert Bewick, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland; with his name Puller's list ot sheriffs of that county ends. No name occurs till 1645.
The following is extracted from the Register of St. Andrew's in Newcastle upon Tyne: "May, 1640, two sogers for denying the Kings pay, was by a counsel-of war appoynted to be shot att, and a pare of gallos set up before Tho' Malaber's dore in the Byg-Market. They cust lotes which should dy, and the lotes did fall of one Mr. Anthone Viccars; and he was set against a wall, and shott at by 6 lyght horsemen, and was buried in our churchyarde the sam day, May 16 day.".

A messenger deputed from the Scots to desire leave to come over the Tyne, and present a petition to his majestyBourne, from Echard's History., was answered, that a few might be allowed to pass, but not the whole army: upon this, Lesley commanded some of his horse to ford the riverRushworth ut supra., in which at∣tempt they were repulsed at first with discredit by the gallant opposi∣tion of the King's forces, according to some writersBishop Guthrie, p. 71. Echard, lib. i. c. 3., but were suc∣cessful in a second attempt, and caused the English to suffer, what Lord Clarendon has well called, "an infamous and irreparable routRushworth ut supra.."
At a council held by Lord Conway at midnight, after the defeat, it was resolved that the whole army, horse, foot, and artillery, should quit Newcastle upon Tyne, and retreat to Durham.
That town was accordingly deserted of all the military forces by five o'clock in the morning of Saturday the 29th of AugustIbid..

On that day also Douglas, sheriff of Tiviot-Dale, with a trumpet, and some troops of horse, entered the naked and almost defenceless town, but not till after the gates had been shut upon them by Sir
Peter Riddell, and great assurances given on their part of the sincerity and peaceableness of their intentions
Nalson's Collections, vol. ii. p. 19.
Echard says, "the next day the Scots were attended by commissioners from Newcastle. Sir Jacob Ashley, their governor, judging the town not tenable, and sinking his ordnance in the river, thought fit to desert it, to treat for the surrender of that important town.".
Thus fell Newcastle upon Tyne, as the first victim in the grand rebellion.

Sunday, August 30th, the Scots took possession of the town of New∣castle upon Tyne; and, after Henderson, the celebrated presbyterian divine, had preached before them at St. Nicholas' church, the chiefs were entertained by the mayor at dinner.

The day following, General Lesley pitched his camp on Gateshead-Hill, half a mile to the south of NewcastleRushworth ut supra.—He says also, that "fifteen lords and Douglas came and dined with the mayor, drank a health to the King, and had three sermons that day by their own divines." Sir Thomas Riddell, senior, Knight, of Gateshead, suffered particularly by their encampment.—See Nalson's Collections, vol. i. p. 441..

On Tuesday, September 1st, General Lesley demanded of the mayor of Newcastle to bake certain quantities of bread, and brew so many tuns of beer a day; upon the mayor's refusal, the Scots em∣ployed men to do it themselves, who were paid with money in part, and promissory notes for the remainder.

On Thursday following, September 3d, the sheriff of Durham, with Sir William Lampton, Knight, were summoned to appear before General Lesley, at his leaguer at Newcastle, the 5th of that month, by eight o'clock, to require the county to bring in provision to the Scots army, on payment of money in part, and security for the rest, or otherwise they would be compelled to take it without securityRushworth ut supra..

An entire stop was put to the coal-trade on this occasion; the shops in the town were shut up for many days; several families having fled, and left their houses and goods to the mercy of the enemyIbid..
The Scots appointed the Earl of Lothian governor of Newcastle, with a garrison of 2,000 menEchard's History, lib. i. cap. 3..

In the year 1641, Sir Nicholas Cole, Knight and Baronet, was mayor, and Francis Anderson, sheriff. In the month of August this year, the Scottish army, having received 60,000l.Bourne's Newcastle. for disbanding, quitted Newcastle upon TyneJournals of Commons. They were to pass over the Tweed before the 25th of August., through which town the King passed on the 10th of that month, on his way post to ScotlandArchbishop Laud's Diary, p. 62. Churchwardens' accounts—All-Saints.. Mention occurs of his majesty's return by the fame route on the 19th of November following.
Divers of the burgesses of that town petitioned the House of Com∣mons before December 1st that yearJournals of Commons, 1st of December, 1641..
A. D. 1642, Sir John Marley, Knight, was mayor, and Henry Maddison, sheriff.
March 19th this year, an order passed in the House of Commons for the speedy securing of Newcastle upon TyneIbid..
June 11th, there occurs an order of the same house, to desire the lord admiral to send some ships of war to guard the coasts about New∣castle upon Tyne, to prevent the importation of armsIbid..

And on the 29th of that month the King appointed William, Earl of Newcastle, to be governor of that townFoedera, tom. xx. p. 531. In the Journals of the Commons, last of June, 1642, vol. ii. mention occurs of the Earl's having sent out his warrants from that town into the county of Durham, commanding 600 foot, and 100 horse of the train-band of Durham, to come into Newcastle; and as having deputed 300 men to South-Shields, to make fortifi∣cations and trenches, who had carried thither six pieces of ordnance. The house resolved, that two of the King's ships should be appointed to lie at the river's mouth, "to prevent the inconveniencies that may happen by the fort there in building.".
About the 19th of August this year, the mayor and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne sent the King a most loyal address, accom∣panied with the loan of 700l.Common-council books..

September 7th this year, William, Earl of Newcastle, was made an honorary burgess of that town
Ibid.
Sir Robert Heath appears to have been down upon the northern circuit, A. D. 1642..

September 21st this year, it was resolved upon the question by the House of Commons, that Sir Nicholas Cole, mayor of Newcastle upon Tyne, Sir Thomas Riddell the younger, Sir Alexander Davison, Sir John Marley, and Mr. Thomas Lydell, of that town, should be forth∣with sent for as delinquents by the serjeant at armsJournals of Commons, vol. ii..
October 13th, a small vessel arrived at Newcastle with arms for a thousand men, and 10,000l. in moneyJournals of Commons, vol. ii..
October 20th, Sir John Marley was chosen mayor by a mandamus from the KingIbid..
November 19th, there was an order in the House of Commons, to prevent the carriage of all provisions of victual and ammunition to Newcastle upon TyneIbid..
