About December this year, the Queen was at Rotterdam, and in∣tended shortly to sail for Newcastle upon Tyne: she had been exerting all her interest in procuring and sending off before her, men, money, horses and ammunition, for the service of her royal consortLord's Journals, vol. v. p. 405..

About the latter end of January, 1643, the Queen was expected to land at Newcastle upon Tyne, for which place she embarked at Schivel∣ing, two miles from the Hague, on Thursday, January 19th; but after having been exposed to great danger in a storm, she was compelled to return to Holland
"True Relation of the Queen Majesty's Return out of Holland, &c. York, 143. By special command." 4to.
It appears by the Trinity-House books, that that fraternity had deputed several of the brethren to attend the Queen upon her landing at Shields.. On Thursday, February 16th following, she em∣barked
barked a second time for Newcastle, and by the Monday following had proceeded as far as Scarborough, but being detained by contrary winds was obliged to land at Burlington-Key on the Wednesday following, where her majesty was gladly welcomed by the Lord General, the Earl of Newcastle, and the army
True Relation, &c. ut supra.
I copied the following passage from an original letter of the Queen of Charles I. to the Marquis of Newcastle, dated at Oxford, March 15th, 1643, remaining in the British Museum:
"Mon cousin jay reseu vre lettre par persons: avec la relation de tout ce qui cest passe a Newcastell: et suis bien ayse que vous naves pas encore mange des rats: pourveu que les Escossois ne mange point des Yorkshire oate cakes tout yra fort bien.".

In the beginning of June this year, propositions for the reducticn, as it was termed, i. e. the taking, of Newcastle upon Tyne out of the hands of the crown, were agitated in both houses of parliament
Lords' Journals, vol. vi. June 1st and 5th. Commons' Journals, June 5th, 1643.
In the ordinances for raising money for the army by a weekly assessment, ibid. p. 163, 25l. to be raised weekly in the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne.
The royalist party appear to have been no less active to secure that town for the King.— See common-council books. September 8th, 1643, three-pence per chalder was land upon coals..
October 27th, William Cavendish, then Earl, was advanced to the dignity of Marquis of Newcastle upon TyneDugdale's Baronage, tom. iii. p. 421..
In the year 1644, Sir John Marley was mayor, and James Cole, sheriff, till the town was taken; after which Henry Warmouth was mayor, and Robert Ellison, sheriff.

January 15th, 1644, in a snowy season the Scottish army, consisting of 1,800 foot, and 3,500 horse and dragoons, crossed the Tweed at Berwick. Sir Thomas Glenham, with the loyalists, retreated before them, with his forces and artillery, from Alnwick to Newcastle upon Tyne; the Scots following them by difficult and slow marches, sum∣moned that town to surrender, on the 3d of February: after three
weeks fruitless stay, and some skirmishes, they passed the river Tyne on the 28th of that month, and entered Sunderland by the sea on the 4th of March following
Whitelock's Memorials, p. 76, &c. "The Scots," says he, "besieged Newcastle, and took a main out-work, and beat back the enemy fallying out upon them. The Marquis of Newcastle being in the town, burnt an hundred houses in the suburbs, for which the in∣habitants raised a clamour against him. The marquis ordered the firing of the coal-mines, but was prevented by General Lesley's surprising all the boats and vessels; seven of the parliament's frigates lay in the mouth of the haven, to stop their passage by sea." He adds, "15,000 of the Scots passed the river Tyne, and blocked up Newcastle on the south side." "They took also," he continues, "a great fort over against Tinmouth, which com∣mands all ships coming in or going out of Newcastle, and five pieces of ordnance, arm∣powder, and some prisoners, and lost but nine men."
Wallis, in his History of Northumberland, has confounded the capture of this sort of the south-side, with that of Clifford's Fort on the north side of the river Tyne.
"In the mean time," says Rushworth, "a smart dispute happened: the town had raised a sort at the entrance into the Shield-Field, to gain which, the Scots sent out two parties; one to attack the sort on the east side, the other on the west; in which service, divers of them were cut off by the cannon, and particularly Patrick English, the Earl of Lindsay's captain-lieutenant, slain. That evening the marquis, for the better guard of the town, se the Sand-Gate, a street without the walls, and the other suburbs, on fire, which continued burning all Sunday and Monday." — "Henceforwards the Scots continued their quarters near Newcastle, but no great action passed for divers dayes; at last they resolved not to waste their time before this town, but to pass the river Tyne, leaving behind on the north side of the town six regiment, of foot, and some troops, of horse, under the command of Sir James Lumsdail, major-general; and accordingly, on Thursday, the 22d of February, the gross of their army marched from quarters near Newcastle to Hadden on the Wall."—Collections, part iii. vol. 11. p. 612..
In May this year, the Earls of Montross and Crafurd fled to New∣castle upon TyneWhitelock..
In the month of June, Colonel Charles Fairfax, having been sent to assist the Scots party at Sunderland, beat back the Earl of Montross, Musgrave, and others, into Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

The Earl of Calendar, who had entered England with a reserved army of 10,000 Scots, to assist the parliament against the King, joined with
General Leven in the siege of Newcastle, which commenced very closely on the 13th of August, 1644
Whitelock. He adds, that the Earl of Calendar took Gateside, and blocked up Newcastle on that side, beating back a party of that garrison that fallied out upon him. General Leven came also before Newcastle; he and Calendar got possession of the bridge, and most of the inhabitants of the lower town sled to the higher for shelter. Leven summoned 3,000 countrymen to come in with spades and mattocks, &c. The lord general's quarters were at Elswick. They appointed a new stage from Morpeth to Kenton, and so to Elswick.—See Thurloe's State Papers, vol. i. p. 42.
They write very pressingly into Scotland, for "considerable quantities of meal to be sent to Sunderland."
During this siege, Bourne tells us, on the authority of the Milbank MS. "the round tower under the Moot-Hall towards the Sand-Hill, called the Half-Moon, was by Sir John Marley made use of to secure the river and key-side against the Scots; and the other castle he put into good repair, which was very ruinous: on the former he laid great guns, and on the latter placed great ordnance, to beat off those guns which the Scots had laid upon the banks of Gateshead against the town; and this he managed bravely for a long time.".

No particular mention occurs of the transactions, either of the assail∣ants or the besieged, for some time after it was begun: General Leven, with the forces under him, appears to have been quartered at Elswick, a village about a mile to the west of Newcastle; while the Earl of Calendar, with the division of the army under him, was stationed at Gateshead, on the bridge, and at the glass-houses; below which he had thrown a bridge of boats across the riverThurloe's State Papers..

September 7th, a letter was sent from the general's quarters at Elswick, signed in the name, and by the warrant of the committee of both kingdoms, to the mayor, aldermen, common-council, and bur∣gesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, entreating them to surrender the town, and stop the farther effusion of christian blood. The besieged, however, paid no regard to these entreaties, hut proceeded to still more hazardous demonstrations of their loyalty to King CharlesRushworth's Collections, part iii. vol. ii. p. 645, et seq.. In the beginning of the month of October, Henry Warmouth, Esq was appointed de∣puty
lieutenant for Newcastle upon Tyne, by both houses of par∣liamentLords' Journals, 9th October, 1644—also of the Commons of that date..

October 14th, General Leven sent a peremptory summons to the mayor, aldermen, and common-council of the town, to surrender it im∣mediately, on peril of the extremities of warRushworth's Collection, part iii. vol. ii..

October 15th, the mayor, aldermen, and common-council, answered the general's letter of the preceding day, desiring to know the terms on which he expected a surrender, and promising after that to give him a farther and satisfactory answerIbid..
A reply of General Leven the same day signified his desire, that hostages might be sent from either side, and some appointed to treat concerning terms and conditionsIbid..

October 16th, Sir John Marley, with the aldermen, and common-council, in reply to the general's last, informed him, "that as to send∣ing hostages, they do not hold they have power, as mayor, aldermen, and common-council; but solely to be in Mr. Maior, as he is governor of the military affairs."
Upon this, the general the same day addressed a letter to Sir John Marley, and desired of him the names of hostages and commis∣sioners.

Sir John Marley, by a letter of the day following, desired the general to name his commissioners first, "that he might suit them as to their qualities, having no noblemen in the town, but two of the Earl's countrymen."

After some other letters had passed, the following commissioners were lixcd upon:
For the town.
Sir John Marley, knight, and governor.
Sir Nicholas Cole, knight and baronet.
Sir George Baker, knight: and a secretary.
For the besiegers.
Sir Adam Hepburn.
Sir David Hume.
John Rutherford: and a secretary.
These met in the town, and after three or four hours debate "finding the governor very high," they separated, though they had concluded on nothingRushworth ut supra..

October 18th, the above-named commissioners for the town sent a letter to General Leven, and desired him to rest satisfied till the Mon∣day following, when they hoped to transmit him inch propositions as should give content The Scottish general answered them that same night with great anger.

On the morning of the 19th, instead of the hostages that were ex∣pected, the Scottish general received a letter from the governor, &c. of Newcastle, containing their resolution not to give a final answer till the Monday following. Sir John Marley wrote the same morning to Lord Sinclair, desiring that his drummer might have leave to deliver a letter to General Leven himself, as it was strongly reported in New∣castle that he was deadIbid..

The Scots interpreted this last letter of Sir John Marley as an insult, and began, almost instantly after the receipt thereof, a most violent firing from their several batteries upon the town-wall, and the several regiments were drawn up, standing to their arms while the breaches were in readiness, and the mines sprung. About three o'clock in the afternoon, tlie town garrison by their counter-mines had very nearly approached some chambers, where the gun-powder was lodged for blowing up the walls; which being signified to General Leven, he or∣dered immediately that fire should be given to those two mines endan∣gered, and afterwards to maintain the breaches carefully, whilst a general assault should be made from all quarters: a little after, the day failing and the breaches being made, though not so large and passable as was
needful, the rest of the mines were fired, and the regiments advanced all at once towards the breaches, and those places of the wall which were opened by the mines. In this attempt, however, they were ex∣cellently entertained by the besieged, who left nothing unessayed to repel the fury of the assault. They played incessantly from the castle upon the breaches and the flanking towers of the walls, with scattered shot; and the Scots received a considerable loss of soldiers and officers of quality: yet still tliey pressed on, and, after two hours desperate dis∣pute upon the breaches, forced their first entry at the mine sprung on the west side of the town, near to Close-Gate. Tlien the horse in the town gave them three brave charges, which they stoutly sustained, and kept their ground till the reserve of that post came to assist them. Then they marched for the relief of the rest of the breaches: and the soldiers of the garrison seeing farther resistance in vain, forsook the walls, and the whole body almost of the army entering, they soon became mas∣ters of the town. The Scots extolled their own clemency and kindness on this occasion
Rushworth ut supra. The Milbank MS. cited by Bourne, says: "Newcastle was entered by the White-Fryer Tower and Sand-Gate, where the colliers of Elswick and Benwell were employed under one John Osbourn, a false rebellious Scot, to undermine the walls: which they did and blew them up, and so got and plundered the town. And no marvel, for they were accounted 30,000 men, and the townsmen were but in all 1500 men, wearied with continual watch and duty, though men of great courage, and sought it gallantly to the last: for the Newgate-Ward, which was under Captain Cuthbert Carr, was taken by the enemy, who entered at the aforesaid places, and encompassed them be∣fore and behind: and Pilgrim-Street-Gate was maintained by Captain George Errington, Lieutenant William Robson, and Ensign Thomas Swan, who sought and killed very many: they themselves not having one hurt, until they were encompassed by the enemy before and behind; and even then they would not parley with the Scots, who sougth against them without, but did capitulate with Lieutenant Colonel Smelair who loved and ho∣noured them, and kept his agreement well with them, that not one of them was sobbed of his clothes or money, not were any of his men suffered to give any evil word; and it was the great blessing of God that in all that time there was not one man slain nor hurt, although that company consisted of nine score men, all tradesmen: and there were divers fallies made out at that gate, for it was the longest of all the gates of the town, being barrocaded and shut up. And after they had surrendered, and the my was called over at that breach, they durst not approach, but shot at their friends that called them and would not believe that the town was taken."
"Thus," adds Bourne, "was the town taken from the King, after an obstinate and gallant defence, and may well assume the motto bestowed upon it, 'Fortiter defendendo triumphans.' The Scots are said to have risled the town's hutch, and destroyed most of the evidences and deeds belonging to the Corporation, after they had captured Newcastle.", affirming, that never was town gained by storm,
wherein less cruelty and insolency, and more mercy and moderation in respect of plunder, was shewn. Upon their first entry, the gover∣nor, Lodowick Lindesey, Earl Crawford, the Lord Maxwell, Doctor Wishart and others, that had been most resolute for holding out the town, betook themselves to the castle.
Sunday, October 20th, General Leven entered the town, where he went to church with his chief officers, to return thanks to God for their success.
The next day Sir John Marley, mayor, wrote a spirited letter to General Leven from the castle, to which he had retreated, and which he owned could not hold out long.

In this he hinted at the particular motives of his loyalty, and begged for liberty to withdraw to some neighbouring garrison of the King; but the incensed general would allow no terms, and insisted upon a general surrender.
October 22d, Sir John Marley, with his brave associates, came forth of the castle, and surrendered themselves prisoners to the Scottish army.

The gallant mayor and governor was almost torn in pieces by the mob on this occasion, and appears to have been persecuted afterwards with a spirit rather of revengeful than becoming generous conquerors
Journals of Commons, December 5th, 1644—ibid. January 8th, 1645—also May 27th following.
Lords' Journals, vol. vii. p. 43..

Friday, October 25th, a thanksgiving was agreed upon by both houses of parliament, to be on the Sunday following, in all the parishes of London and Westminster, and within the line of communi∣cation, for the great success of the Scottish army, by the capture of Newcastle upon TyneLords' Journals, October 25, 1644..
In the year 1645, John Blackston was mayor, and Christopher Nicholson, sheriff.

Newcastle was assessed at 36l. 10s. 0¾d. per month, by an ordinance for raising the sum of 20,000l. monthly, for four months, for the Scottish army, February 10th, 1645Lord's Journals, vol. vii. p. 224..

April 14th this year, the Hon. Sir William Armyn, Knight and Baronet, Richard Barwics, and Robert Fenwick, Esqrs commissioners from the parliament, and then resident at Newcastle, were compli∣mented each with the personal freedom of that corporationCommon-council books..

July 3d, there was an order of the House of Commons, that a true state of the garrisons of Newcastle upon Tyne, &c. should be laid before them, and another on the 26th following, that a commission should be granted under the great seal, for the adjusting of the accounts (amongst others) of the county of Newcastle upon Tyne, between the Scottish army and the said county, arising either by assessments, free quarter, billeting, or any other wayJournals of Commons, vol. iv..

Sept. 4th this year, there was an order of the House of Commons, that 500 musquets, with their furniture, and 20 barrels of gunpowder, should be furnished immediately out of the publick stores, for the ser∣vice of the town of Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

Sept. 27th, the common-council of Newcastle made an order to dis∣franchise the Earl of Newcastle, who was charged with possessing him∣self thereof by force of arms, and altering its ancient and lawful govern∣ment
Common-council books.—He is charged also with "imprisoning divers of his majes∣ties good subjects, and plundering and taking away their estates." He had been before this time declared a traitor by the Lords and Commons. The cause assigned for his dis∣franchisement is a curious one: "As a meanes to expiate and appease the great wrath of God, which yet hanges over this pooi and miserable towne."
In 1645, John John Fenwick, of Wallington, who had been created a baronet in the year 1628, was sheriff of Northumberland.—No mme occurs till 1653..
About the beginning of October, 1645, the plague appears to have been at Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books, October 3d, 1645..

October 13th, a resolution passed the House of Commons, to desire that satisfaction should be given to the kingdom, that such forces of the Scottish nation as had been put into the several garrisons of New∣castle upon Tyne, Tynmouth-castle, &c. without the consent of both houses of parliament, should be forthwith removed and disposed of at the pleasure of those assembliesJournals of Commons, vol. iv..
In the year 1646, Henry Dawson was deputy mayor, and Henry Rawling, sheriff.
The 5th of January this year, mention occurs of Sir James Lumsden, Knight, as commander of the garrison of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council book..

April 7th, by an order of the Lords and Commons, the above Henry Dawson was approved and established deputy mayor of Newcastle dur∣ing the absence of Mr. Blakiston, a member of the House of Commons, and then mayor of that townLords' Journals, vol. viii. p. 257..

The unfortunate King Charles, having fled from Oxford, which was then besieged by the parliament's forces, threw himself into the protection of the Scottish army at Newark upon Trent: they conducted the royal fugitive from thence to Newcastle upon Tyne, into which he made a private entry on the 6th of May this year
Rushworth ut supra. He says, "On Wednesday, May 13, the Scottish army came into Newcastle, a lane of musquets and pikes being by order of Sir James Lumsdale, the governor, made from Gateshead, the place where his majesty entered the town, all along the streets to the general's quarters, where his majesty took up his lodgin."
Bourne says, "that upon his majesty's entry into Newcastle, he wa ested with bon¦fires and ringing of bells, drums and trumpets, and peals of ordnan; but guarded by 300 of the Scottish house, those near him bare headed. He lodd at General Leven's quartes, who proclaimed that papists or delinquens should come near his person; and that although his majesty was present, yet all men woever should yield obedience to the ordinance of the parliament.
The MS. Life of Alderman Barnes, p. 16, says, "King Charles was no where treated with more honour than at Newcastle, as himself confessed; both he and his train having liberty every day to go abroad and play at goff in the Shield-Field without the walls, till a design for his escape was discovered, which occasioned stricter orders to be sent down concerning his person."
"A little after the King's coming to Newcastle," says Whitelock, in his Memoirs, p. 234, "a Scotch minister preached boldly before him, and when his sermon was done, called for the 52d psalm, which begins:
"Why dost thou, tyrant, boast thyself
Thy wicked works to praise?
"Whereupon his majesty stood up and called for the 56th psalm, which begins:
"Have mercy, Lord, on me I pray,
For men would me devour."
The people waved the minister's psalm, and sung that which the King called for..

About the middle of July this year, the Lords and Commons sent certain propositions for a safe and well-grounded peace, by members of both houses, to be presented to his majesty at Newcastle upon Tyne; but to which the King could by no means be prevailed upon to give his assentJournals of the Commons, vol. iv. 7th of July, 1646..

Soon after this, mention occurs of the King's having been prevailed upon to think of an escape from Newcastle: false friends are said to have been in the secret, so that the plot was divulgedHis majesty is said to have lodged at the house of the late Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, a room in which still, or very lately retained the name of the King's bed-chamber. In this stood a bed of a very antique fashion, said to be the identical one upon which the un∣fortunate monarch passed in all probability many a restless night. While the King was here, his coachman died, and was buried, as the register testifies, in St. Andrew's church. There is a popular tradition, that the King attempted his escape from this house by the passage of Lortburn, and that he had got down as far as where the grate is at present in the middle of the Side, where he was apprehended. A ship was said to have been in rea∣diness to transport his majesty beyond sea.—The King had disguised himself when he was taken. William Murray, of his bed-chamber, is said to have projected this plot.—See Desiderata Curiosa, vol. ii. lib. ix. p. 31. before the ap∣pointed time: on which a guard of soldiers was placed at the door of his majesty's chamber, both within and without, that not only de∣prived
him of his former liberty, but destroyed also his future quiet and reposeBourne says, "The King having an antipathy against tobacco, was much disturbed by their bold and continual smoaking in his presence. A military presage of the same heathenish barbarity at going to the block before Whitehall.".
December 11th this year, Major-General Philip Skippon was ap∣pointed governor of Newcastle upon Tyne, Gateshead, and Tinmouth-castle, by an order of the House of CommonsJournals of Commons, vol. v..

December 21st, mention occurs of the expences which the corpo∣ration of Newcastle had been at, both with regard to the garrison, and also of the court since his majesty's arrival at that town, an account whereof was ordered to be drawn up and presented to their represent∣ative in parliament
Common-council books. The corporation appear to have been at half the expence of finding his majesty, the general, and the governor, with coals.
A rare instance of the King's temper appeared during his residence at Newcastle: When the news reached him of the fatal turn of matters in Scotland against him, he took no no∣tice of it to those about him, but continued in a game of chess, and was as cheerful as before.—Burnet's Memoirs of the Dukes of Hamilton, p. 305..
In the year 1647, Thomas Ledger was mayor, and Robert Young, sheriff.

An agreement having been made between the parliament of Eng∣land and the Scottish army, that the former should have possession of the King's person, and that the latter, on the receipt of 200,000l. should quit the kingdom of England; commissioners were deputed from London to receive the King, and convey him from Newcastle upon Tyne, from whence he set out on the 3d of February this year to Holmby-house in NorthamptonshireThe King sent a letter to the Queen on the morning of the day on which he was de∣livered into the hands of the English commissioners, at Newcastle upon Tyne, which was on Thursday, January 28th, 1647, at nine o'clock, and immediately after the Scottish army marched out of that town for Scotland.—Guthrie's Memoirs, p. 195..

On the calling up of Major-General Skippon to the army this year, Colonel Robert Lilburne was appointed governor of Newcastle
Journals of Commons, vol. v. March 29th, 1647.
March 15th, 1648, the common-council presented him with two silver flaggons, of the value of twenty pounds, for his many services while governor.—Common-council books.
This Colonel Robert Lilburn was eldest brother to the famous John Lilburn, and was, after the King's death, major-general of the north of England: he was one of the King's judges, and signed the warrant for his execution; for which he was tried and condemned with the other regicides; but favourable circumstances appearing in his behalf, his life was spared, being banished to the island of St. Nicholas, near Plymouth, in which confine∣ment he died in 1665. His father being alive at the time of his attainder, the family estate of Thickly Puncharden, in the county of Durham, descended to his issue..

Soon after October 5th this year, mention occurs of a "petition of the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle to the House of Commons, against the oppression of the soldiery under the command of his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, now resident hereCommon-council books..
Before December 30th this year, Sir Arthur Haslerigg was appoint∣ed governor of Newcastle upon TyneRushworth's Collections, part iv. vol. ii. p. 949..
In the year 1648, Thomas Bonner was mayor, and Ralph Jennison, sheriff.

January 1st this year, an order was made by the House of Com∣mons, for granting the sequestrations of the county of Newcastle upon Tyne, for the relief of that county
Journals of Commons, vol. v.
Februarty 17th this year, Newcastle was rated to pay the monthly sum of 9l. 19s. in the ordinance to raise 20,000l. a month for Ireland, by a general assessment throughout England and Wales.
March 15th following, Newcastle was sessed in the monthly sum 29l. 17s. in the ordinance to raise 60,000l. a month for the army.—Ibid..

April 25th this year, there was an order of the Commons for the sum of 5,000l. to be forthwith raised and advanced to be employed in repairing and fortifying the town of Newcastle and Tinmouth-castleIbid..

May 15th this year, the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne made an order to put the town into a posture of defenceCommon-council books.: they had before undertaken the work of Shield-Field fort, an outwork, as a
testimony of their love and due respect to the parliament for the great favours that had been shewn them
May 2d. Common-council books. "Ordered that all the earth-work and sodd-work how∣soever called be done by the burgesses and inhabitants of this town in their several wardes att the costs and charges of the burgesses and inhabitants of this town respectively.—In case any refuse to come, they are to pay 8d. per diem. Every one to come at six o'clock in the morning—a drum to call them, and goe to the work."
May 19th there occurs ibid. a petition to parliament from the mayor, aldermen, com∣mon-council, and other inhabitants of Newcastle well affected..

May 23d this year, mention occurs of an ordinance to settle the militia in the northern counties, when the committee appointed for the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, were, Algernon, Earl of Northumberland; Thomas Ledgard, Esq Sir Arthur Haslerigg, Bart. George Fenwick, Esq Mr. Mark Shaftoe, recorder; Mr. Henry Warmouth, Mr. Henry Dawson, Mr. Thomas Bonner, Mr. George Dawson, Mr. William Dawson, alderman; Mr. Robert Young, sheriff; Mr. Christopher Nicholson, alderman; and Mr. Edward Man
Lords' Journals, vol. x.
June 8th this year, the common-council of Newcastle wrote to their representatives in parliament, earnestly to solicit the House of Commons for present supply of money for the garrison in that town.—Common-council books.
June 29th, there occurs in the Journals of the Commons, vol. v. a petition from the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne to parliament, requesting 4,000l. a month for the pay of three regiments of foot in that town.
In June this year, there was a fort built in Sand-Gate, as an outwork to defend the town, —Common-council books..
About the beginning of September this year, Lieutenant-General Cromwell passed through Newcastle upon Tyne, in pursuit of the royalistsRushworth, part iv. vol. ii. p. 1259..

September 25th this year, the common-council of Newcastle made an order, that every free burgess of that town should serve the parlia∣ment, and defend that place with such arms as the mayor should ap∣point themCommon-council books..

October 2d, a violent affray happened at Newcastle, at the annual election of the officers of the corporation of that townIbid. June 4, 1649. "Whereas on the 2d of October last, Thomas Bonner, Esq mayor elected, coming from the Spittle to go to his dwelling-house upon the Sand-Hill, the serjeants carrying torches lighted in their hands—one Edmund Marshall threw a long stick at the said lighted torches, and struck divers of them out; and it being dark, stones, &c. were slung, &c. &c.".

October 10th, there was a petition of the mayor, aldermen, and common-council, and others of Newcastle upon Tyne, presented to the House of Commons, requiring speedy and impartial justice to be done upon the greatest offenders and incendiaries of the kingdom, the fomentors of and actors in the first and second war, otherwise they could expect no blessing upon the treaty then on foot between the King and parliament, &c.Parliamentary History, vol. xviii. p. 30, 31.

October 16th this year, Lieutenant-Colonel Paul Hobson occurs as deputy-governor of Newcastle upon Tyne
Rushworth, part iv. vol. ii. p. 1295.
January 30th, 1650, he was made a free burgess of Newcastle upon Tyne, by an act of common-council.—Common-Council books..

About the middle of October this year, Cromwell, and the army under him, returned to Newcastle, after the taking of Berwick upon Tweed: they stayed three days at the town, partly to give the army a little rest, and also to give time for the train to get up to them. They are said to "have been received there with very great acknowledgments of love." On the 19th, they were sumptuously feasted by the new mayor, and the next day reached Durham, but not till late in the eveningRushworth, vol. vii. p. 1310..

November 24th this year, there was presented to his Excellency Lord Fairfax, lord general at Windsor, a most remarkable petition and representation of the officers and soldiers of the garrisons of Newcastle, Hartlepool, Holy-Island, and of several officers of Berwick upon Tweed, wherein they charged the King with being "the occasion of a seven years unnatural bloody war, by deserting his parliament, and the principal author, contriver, abettor and manager of all the blood∣shed, massacres, devastations, and whatever ruins have befallen, not only this kingdom, but also that of Ireland;" declaring, "that all
other endeavours are to little purpose while the grand delinquent is untouched, as being not an acceptable sacrifice to the justice of God to offer him ought else, while the Agag is sparedFrom the original printed tract in quarto, London, printed by John Partridge, 1648. The following will not be thought uninteresting. "A copie of two letters sent from divers officers of thearmy in the north, to his Excellency Thomas Lord Fairfax, concerning the late large petition, presented to the parliament upon the eleventh of Sept. 1648, &c.—A copie of a letter to his Excellency the Lord Fairfax, from the garrison of Newcastle and Tin∣mouth. May it please your Excellency, we make bold, being prest in spirit, to represent to you, as the ground of our fears, so the matter of our desires. It hath pleased God, after much plottings and endeavours of the old and new malignants, to crown the army under your conduct with great successe; and although God by that calls for justice, little or none is done, to the great grief as to the kingdom in general, so unto us in particular; and lesse is like to be done, unlesse your excellency presently appear to do something, and the army with you, to be a leading cause to us: we wait for it. Instead of justice, be∣hold a treaty with them for peace, that God speaks no peace to; and instead of owning just petitions, they are laid aside, and not countenanced: some employed in the treaty not long since voted the army rebels; what that prognosticates in the future, when they have power, we leave to your excellency to judge. We can hardly forbear but petition the parliament (rememberinge our engagement at Newmarket-Health), but we are very un∣willing to do any thing without your excellencies pleasure, being desirous in all good things to be led by you: and being confident (as formerly, so still) you will stand by the kingdom and the army in their just rights. So hoping you will so far honours us, a to make a favourable construction of our expressions, and give an answer to encourage us to joyn with the well-affected, in their petitions, for their just rights and privileges, we sub∣scribe ourselves in the behalf of the officers and souldiers of this garrison and Tinmouth▪ your excellencies humble servants, Lieut. Col. Paul Hobson, Major Cobbet, Cap Clark, Cap. Hutton, &c. Newcastle, 22 Sept. 1648."—From a collection of printed sheet the British Museum (gift of George III.) dorso, "A. 1648-9, Aug. 18 to March 2d !"

In the year 1649, William Dawson was mayor, and Samuel Rawling, sheriffIt appears by the Journals of the Commons, vol. vi. Sepember 18th, 1649, that t House especially recommended it to the committee of the army, to take care that the assign∣ment to the garrison of Newcastle, &c. should be constantly and duly paid..
September 14th this year, Sir Arthur Haslerigg, governor of the garrison of Newcastle upon Tyne, was admitted and sworn a free bur∣gess of that CorporationCommon-council books..
December 24th this year, mention occurs of several pirates lurking up and down in the northern seas, and committing great depredations in the vicinity of NewcastleWhitelock's Memorials..
In the year 1650, George Dawson was mayor, and John Lodge, sheriff.
March 8th this year, Colonel Fenwick was admitted and sworn a free burgess of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books..

When the whole nation laboured under a fascination, like the fan∣cied one attributed to the power of witches, it is no wonder that the popular superstition concerning these ideal criminals should have raged at this time at Newcastle. Mention occurs of a petition in the com∣mon-council books of that townIbid. "March, 26th, 1649—Witches.—The petition concerning witches was read, and ordered that thankes be returned to the petitioners, and the common-council will contribute their best assistance therein." The following corroborating testimony is from Whitelock's Memorials, p. 418. "13 Dec. 1649. Letters from Newcastle—that many witches were apprehended thereabouts of late; that the witch-tryer taking a pin and thrusting it into the skin in parts of their bodies, they were insensible of it, which is one circumstance of proof against them." Gardiner, who has given a print of this horrid ex∣ecution, in his England's Grievance of the Coal Trade, p. 17, blames the magistrates of Newcastle on this occasion, but very unfairly, as they appear to have done what they did at the instance of the public, who were prejudiced by th then raging superstition., dated March 26th, 1649, and signed, no doubt, by the inhabitants, concerning witches, the purport of which appears, from what followed, to have been to cause all such per∣sons as were suspected of that crime, to be apprehended and brought to trial. In consequence of this a person was sent for from Scotland, who pretended to be possessed of the knowledge of distinguishing those wretches, who, for the sake of being able to hurt their neighbours, had sold themselves to the devil. His method of examining those pre∣tended witches, which was publickly performed in the town-hall, was shockingly indecentThirty women were brought into the town-hall and stripped, and then openly had pins thrust into their bodies, and most of them were found guilty; near twenty-seven of them by him (i. e. the witch-finder) and set aside. "The magistrates sent their bellman through the town, ringing his bell and crying, all people that would bring in any complaint against any woman for a witch, they should be sent for and tried by the person appoint∣ed."—Gardiner ut supra. The Scotchman, it is said, had twenty shillings a-piece for all he could condemn!. There is no account how many were committed
to take their trials at the assizes; but it is certain, (horresco referens!) that one wizard and fourteen reputed witches belonging to Newcastle, in company with nine thieves and a witch of the county of Northum∣berland, were executed upon the Town-Moor, near Newcastle upon Tyne, August 21st this yearThe following is an extract from the register of the parochial chapelry of St. Andrew in Newcastle upon Tyne. "1650, 21 August. Thes partes her under named wer execut∣ed in the Town Mor for wiches. Mathew Boumer Isabell Brown Margrit Maddeson Ann Watson Ellenor Henderson Ellener Rogers Ellsabeth Dobson Mrs. Ellsabeth An∣derson Jane Hunter Jane Koupling Margrit Brown Margrit Mossit Kattren Welsh Aylles Hume and Marie Pootes." Then follow the names of the persons executed for steal∣ing, who were a gang of moss troopers, at the close of which occurs "Jane Martin for a wich, the myllers wis of Chattim.".

June 29th this year, Oliver Cromwell having three days before been appointed captain-general of the army, set out from London upon an expedition into Scotland: at Durham he was met by Sir Arthur Iasel∣rigg, governor of Newcastle, with Colonel Pride and other officers, who attended him to that town on the 15th of July following. He was sumptuously entertained at that place by the governor; and during his stay there was a fast kept to implore God's blessing upon the army's undertaking, and a declaration was agreed upon to be dispersed in their marchWhitelock, p. 464. Parliamentary History, vol. xix. p. 298.. Five companies, as a reinforcement, were drawn out of the garrison of that town on this occasionJournals of the Commons, vol. vi. 13 August, 1650..

September 2d following, which was the day preceding that of the battle of Dunbar, Cromwell wrote a remarkable letter all with his own hand, and sent it from Scotland to Sir Arthur Haslerigg, at Newcastle upon Tyne
"Deere Sr. wee are upon an engagement very difficult, the enimie hath blocked up our way att the passe at Copperspeth, thorough which wee canott gett without almost a miracle. Hee lyeth soe upon the hills that wee knowe not how to come that way without great difficulty and our lying heere dayly consumeth our men whoe fall sicke beyond ima∣gination. I perceave your forces are not in a capacitye for present releife wherefore (whatever becomes of us) itt will be well for you to gett what forces you can together and the south to helpe what they can, the businesse neerely concerneth all good people. If your forces had beene in a readinesse to have fallen upon the back of Copperspith itt might have occasioned supplies to have come to us, but the only wise God knowes what is best, all shall worke for good, our spirits are comfortable (praised bee the Lord) though our present condition bee as it is and indeed wee have much hope in the Lord of whose mercy we have had large experience. Indeed doe you gett together what forces you can against them. Send to frendes in the south to help with more. Lett H. Vane know what I write. I would not make it publick least danger should accrue therby. You know what use to make hereoff Let me heere from you. I rest your servaunt, "O. CROMWELL.
"Its difficult for me to send to you lett me heare from (you) after.
"Septr. 2d, 1650.
"For the Honble. Sir Ar. Haselridge att Newcastle or elsewhere thease hast hast."
(From the original letter in the possession of the representatives of Sir Arthur Hasilrigg, by favour of Mr. Ormston, agent for their estates in Northumberland.)
This remarkable letter is inscribed on the back as follows, in another hand:
"Gen. Cromwell he of the armys condicon neer Copperspith Scotland 1650, 2 Sept. which was the day before the memorable battle of Dunbarr in Scotland where Gent Cromwell routed all the Scotch forces totally and instead of returninge to Englande he turned to Edinburrough and conquered Scotland. This letter is every word writ with his owne hand, the superscription also." The seal, which is of red wax, is nearly broken off. —The letter has been folded up so hastily that the ink has come off on the opposite paper.
.

September 4th following, General Cromwell wrote an account of the victory which he had just obtained at the sight of Dunbar, to Sir Arthur Hasilrigg, governor of Newcastle
"For the Honoble. Sir Arthur Hefilge att Newcastle or else where these hast hast.
"Sir you will see by my inclosed of the 2d of this month which was the evening before the fight, the condicōn we were in att that time which I thought fitt on purpose to send you, that you might see how great and how seasonable our deliverance and mercie is by such aggravacōn Having said my thoughts thereupon to the parliamt. I shall only give you the narrative of this exceeding mercie, beleeving the Lord will enlarge your heart to a thankful consideracōn thereupon. The least of this mercie lyes not in the advantageous consequences which I hope it may produce of glory to God and good to his people in the prosecution of that which remaynes unto which this great worke hath opened so faire a way.
We have no cause to doubt but if it shall please the Lord to prosper our endeavours we may find opportunities both upon Edenburgh and Leith, Starling-Bridge and other such places as the Lord shall lead unto even far above our thoughts as this late and other expe∣riences gives good encouragements. Wherefore that we may not be wanting I desire you with such forces as you have immediately to march to mee to Dunbarr leaving behind you such of your new levies as will prevent lesser incursions for surely their rout and ruine is to totall that they will not be provided for anie thinge that is verie considerable, or rather which I more encline unto, that you would send Thomlinson with the forces you have ready and that with all possible expedicōn and that you will go on with the remainder of the reserve which upon better thoughts I do not thinke can well be done without you. Sr. let no time nor opportunitie be lost, surely its probable the kirke has done their doo I believe their king will sett upp upon his owne score now, wherein he will find many friends, taking oportunitie ofred, 'tis our great advantage through God. I need say no more to you on this behalfe but rest your humble servant "O. CROMWELL.
"My service to your good ladie. I think it will be very fitt that you should bake hard bread agen considering you encrease our numbers. I pray you do so. Sir I desire you to procure about three or four score masons and shipp them to us with all speed for we expect that God will suddenly put some places into our hands which we shall have occasion to for∣tifie. Dunbarr Septemb. 4, 1650."—From the original letter, sealed with black wax, in the possession of the representatives of Sir Arthur Hafilrigg, ut supra—written by Oliver Cromwell's secretary, but signed by the general himself.
.

After the fight at Dunbar, General Cromwell sent a great number of the prisoners
Echard says, "They were driven like turkeys to Newcastle, whereof Sir Arthur Hafilrigg was governor, where about 1600 of them were starved, having nothing to eat but green cabbage-leaves and oats in a small proportion: the stronger persons that subsisted with this diet were condemned to the sugar-mills, and by the English planters were trans∣ported to the West-Indies."
It appears from Whitelock's account, that the breaking into the gardens, and eating greedily of the cabbages, was a voluntary act of the Scottish prisoners. taken on that very memorable occasion, to Newcastle upon Tyne, recommending them to be treated with humanity
Cromwell, in a letter to Sir Arthur Hasilrigg, dated Edinburgh, Sept. 9, 165, speak∣ing of those prisoners, says, "I hope your northerne guests are come to you by this time. I pray you lett humanitie be exressed towards them, I am persuaded it wil be comely, lett the offices be kept at Newcastle, some sent to Lynn, some to Chester."—From e original preserved ut supra.
It appears from the Trinity-House books, that some of these prisoners were kept in the Trinity-House at Newcastle.
In a former letter to Sir Arthur, dated Dunbar, Sept. 5th, 1650, and preserved ut supra, Cromwell says, "After much deliberacōn we can find no way how to dispose of these prisoners that wil be consisting with those two ends (to witt the not loosing them and the not starving them, neither of which would we willingly incurr) but by sending them into England."
The following passages occur concerning these prisoners, in a letter from Sir Arthur Haselrigge to the council of state, dated at Newcastle, October 31st, 1650. "When they came to Morpeth, the prisoners being put into a large walled garden, they eat up raw cabbages, leaves and roots, so many as the very seed and labour at 4d. a day, was valued at 9l. which cabbage (they having fasted as they themselves said near eight days) poisoned their bodies, for as they were coming from thence to Newcastle some died by the way-side: when they came to Newcastle I put them into the greatest church in the town, and the next morning when I sent them to Durham, about 140 were sick and not able to march— three died that night, and some fell down in their march from Newcastle to Durham and died.—On being told into the great cathedral church, they were counted to be no more than 3,000, although Col. Fenwick wrote me that there were about 3, 500.", not∣with∣standing
that a contrary account of this matter is given by Echard the historian.
November 18th this year, a petition was ordered to be sent to par∣liament, to alter the market days at Newcastle upon Tyne, from Mon∣days and Saturdays, to Tuesdays and Fridays.

A bill passed in the House of Commons, June 8th, 1651, to change the market-day in that town, from Monday to Tuesday in every week, but to continue on Saturdays as beforeJournals of Commons—Common-council books. "In respect Saterdays and Mondays were days that caused the Lord's day to be much prophaned by travellers goinge and tra∣vellinge upon the said Lord's day.".
A. D. 1651, Thomas Bonner was mayor, and Peter Sanderson, sheriff.

September 11th this year, the garrison of Newcastle upon Tyne con∣sisted of ten "companies, the governor, a store-keeper, two mates, one master gunner, three gunners, six mates, fourteen matrosses, a judge-advocate, and for the guards of the town, one of the regiments of foot of the army, 1200Journals of Commons, vol. vii.."
October 2d following, it was propounded to reduce the monthly expence of this garrison, from 92l. 12s. to 21l. 9s. 4dJournals of Commons, vol. vii..
In the year 1652, Henry Dawson was mayor, as was afterwards George Dawson, and John Butler, sheriff.
March 14th this year, Mr. John Rushworth, the celebrated author of the Collections, &c. was admitted to his freedom of the corpora∣tion of NewcastleCommon-council books..

About the end of November this year, General Blake detached twenty of his ships to bring up a fleet of colliers from Newcastle upon Tyne
Biographia Britannica, vol. i. p. 325.
Bourne tells us from the perfect Diurnal, No. 78, p. 1083, that at Durham fair, in 1651, happened the following sad accident: "Captain Blet, an officer of the garrison of New∣castle, going to buy some sheep there, some words passed between a countryman of 60 years of age and him, whom the captain struck with his cane, and the countryman having a btt or staff in his hand, therewith gave him a stroke on his head that he presently after died.".
In the year 1653, William Johnson was mayor, and Robert John∣son, sheriff.

February 25th this year, the mayor and rest of the common-council of Newcastle sent up an address to the Lord Protector Cromwell
"For his Highness the Lord Protector of the commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland, and the dominions thereto belonging. May it please your Highness, many of the precious servants of God in these nations, over which the Lord hath set your high∣ness, have gotten upon their watch-tower, to see if they can discover what hath been the eminent design of the Lord in these latter days; for the allwise God hath of late visibly been out of the common road of providence: his paths have been in tempests and thick darknesse, plucking up by the roots the greatest of men and the highest of powers, like cedars in Lebanon, that he might make way for the glorious bringing forth of truth and righteousness; and we question not but the Lord is fulfilling that great prophecy, Isaiah l. 17. I will make thy officers peace and thy exactors righteousness. For when we consider how the Lord hath eminently made your highness instrumental for the breaking of the iron yoke from off the neck of these three nations, and likewise hath invested you with the supream power of this commonwealth, whereby you may be exceedingly instrumental to the Lord Jesus in the advancing of his kingdom in righteousness and peace: wee having the sence of these things with wight upon our spirit have judged it our duty to pro out great resentment of this signal mercy from the hands of our God, and do solemnly bless the Lord for setting up your highness over this great people, and shall endeavour, through the strength of Christ, to live in all humble obedience to your highness, as becometh those who are under your government and protection.—Signed in the name and by order of the common-councell of Newcastle upon Tyne, "WILLIAM JOHNSON, Mayor." "Feb. 25, 1653.
In the year 1653, Robert Middleton, of Belsay-castle, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
No name occurs till 1666. There were no assizes on the northern circuit in 1653.— Grey's MSS..
The town of Newcastle was first visited this year by George Fox, the well-known founder of the religious sect called QuakersSee his Journal..

July 30th this year, the convention of parliament began, in which the remarkable act passed for marrying by justices of peace
See registers of the different parishes in Newcastle, where persons occur about this time, as having been married by justices of peace.
In 1654, Richard Newdigate and Hugh Windham came down on the northern circuit. —Grey's MSS.
November 15th this year, a resolution was made in the House of Commons, that 5l. of the monthly assessment, charged on Haverford-West, should be taken off and charged on the town of Newcastle upon Tyne..
In the year 1654, William Johnson was mayor, and John Rumney, sheriff.

This year it appears to have been intended by the royalists, to make an attempt for the recovery of Newcastle upon TyneThurloe's State Papers, vol. ii. p. 512. "Newcastle was to have been possessed by landing some men there in some of the colliers ships, who were treated with to that pur∣pose, whoe they say doe now pass Timnouth-castle, without either examination or searche, if they are known to be colliers belonging to the towne: soe that the men being stowed under deckes, they might remaine privately there, till in the night-time they might have landed and possessed the magazine and castle, where the King was informed there were store of armes and ammunition.".

November 22d this year, the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle are mentioned as having been sued for near 3,000l. in which debt the
former magistrates had left that body at the reduction of the townBooks of the drapers company.—The common-council resolved on this emergency to lease out some of the town's lands, to raise the money for payments..
In the yearr 1655, Robert Shaftoe was mayor, and Henry Thompson, sheriff.

In the month of April this year, the town of Newcastle upon Tyne was again put into a posture of defence
Common-council books.—April 6th, 1655, order impowering Mr. John Butler, Mr. Robert Johnson, Mr. James Briggs, and Mr. Thomas Errington, to be captains of the ram-bands.
"Order 13th of April—Serjeants in the train bands to have quarterly 25s.
Drummers 20
Corporals 20
Lance presadoes 8 4d."
"Order occurs ibid. 14 May, as having come down from his highness the lord protector, to form companies of our best-affected townsmen, for the securitie and safety of the towne."
The following occurs ibid. and curious mark of the superstition of the times:
"February 4th, 1655, the ministers of the town were defited to come before the mayor and aldermen, and give their opinion concerning the legality of ringing bells at funrals, as had hitherto been the custom."
In 1655, William Steel, chief baron, and John Parker, were the judges on the northern, circuit.—Grey's MSS.
In 1656, John Parker, and Erasmus Earl.—Ibid..

July 20th, 1655, a petition was ordered by the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be sent up to the Lord Protector Cromwell, concerning the prohibition of a market at North-ShieldsCommon-council books..
In the year 1656, Henry Rawling was mayor, and George Blakiston, sheriff.

January 18th this year, there was an order of the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to enfranchise Colonel Charles Howard, then resident in that town: he was one of the members of Cromwell's council, and major-general of the four northern countiesIbid. Sept. 24th, 1655, Major Tolhurst had been made a free burgess of the same town..

November 20th this year, it appears to have been in agitation to erect a court of law and a court of equity (among other places) at the town of Newcastle upon Tyne
Journals of Commons, vol. vii.
In 1657, Parker and Uniton Crook were judges on the northern circuit.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1657, George Dawson was mayor, and George Thoresby, sheriff.

February 26th this year, Newcastle is mentioned as having no gar∣rison, and containing many disaffected inhabitants, and likely to be surprised by the royalists
Thurloe's State Papers, vol. vi. p. 79. General Monk to the protector, from Dal∣keith, 26th February, 1656-7. "I thought fitt likewise to acquaint your highnesse that I doe more feare Newcastle than any town you have that may be surprized: it he hath a designe to any towne in England I doubt that towne more than any towne in the north∣ern parts, being there is no garrison in it, and many people disassed."
The following occurs in the Journals of the Commons, vol. vii. "Thursday, 11th of June, 1657, Sir Robert Collingwood, of Branton, on the information of Robert Ogle, of Eslington, com. Northumb. gent. was charged with saying, "We must have a king, and will have a king, and my lord protector dares, not refuse it nd Dnl Collingwood, son of the above, in company with some cavalier gentlemen, who were murmuring that they were debarred from horse race, was accused of saying, "that their non now in power but the rascality, who envied that gentlemen short tions." Both ther and son were sent for as delinquents..

May 15th this year, a writ of privy seal for founding an university at Durham, was signed by Oliver Cromwell, lord protector. This university, rather intended to be founded, than actually settled, was soon suppressed. It is a singular fact, that George Fox, the founder of the quakers, who visited Newcastle a second time this yearGeorge Fox's Journal, p. 281., has assumed to himself the consequence, and what he thought the merit, of having been the means of suppressing this laudable institution
The original writ i preserved in the hives of the dean and chapter of Durham; it appears to haved supprssed on acnt of pons against it from the universities of Oxford and It had been obtained by petition of the city and county of Dur∣ham, con d, and town and count of Newcastle upon Tyne.
Fox's account of this matter is too curious to be omitted: "We came to Durham, where was a man came down from London to set up a college there, to make ministers of Christ as they said: I went with some others to reason with the man, and to let him see that to teach men Hebrew, Greek and Latin, and the seven arts, which was all but the teachings of the natural man, was not the way to make them ministers of Christ, for the languages began at Babel: and to the Greeks, that spake Greek as their mother tongue, the cross of Christ was foolishness; and to the Jews that spake Hebrew as their mother tongue, Christ was a stumbling block: and as for the Romans, who had the Latin and Italian, they persecuted the Christians; and Pilate, one of the Roman governors, set He∣brew, Greek and Latin atop of Christ, when he crucified him; so he might see the many languages began at Babel, and they set them atop of Christ the word when they crucified him. And John the divine, who preached the word that was in the beginning, said that the beast and the whore had power over tongues and languages, and they are as waters. Thus I told him he might see the whore and beast have power over the tongues and the many languages which are in mystery Babylon.—Now said I to the man, dost thou think to make ministers of Christ by these natural confused languages which sprang from Babel, are admired in Babel, and set atop of Christ by a persecutor? Oh no.—So the man con∣fest to many of these things.—When we had thus discoursed with the man, he became very loving and tender, and after he had considered further of it, he never set up his college.".

August 29th this year (1657), Lieutenant-Colonel John Lilburn died at Eltham, and two days after was brought to London, and bu∣ried in the Quakers Yard: he was the son of Mr. Richard Lilburn, and was born at Bishop-Weremouth, in the county of DurhamSee State Trials, vol. vii. p. 283..

September 7th this year, the Honourable Sir Thomas Widdrington, speaker of the House of Commons, and his son, were complimented with the franchise of the corporation of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books..
September 25th, Robert Trollop, builder of the new town-court, was presented with the same franchiseIbid. "For his ingenuity, skill and abilities.".

December 28th this year, a letter, received from the Lord Pro∣tector and his Privy-Council, to remove Mr. Leonard Carr from his office of alderman of Newcastle upon Tyne, on a charge preferred against him by the standing committee of the north, for abetting, &c.
against the parliament, was confirmed by the mayor and common-council of that townCommon-council books..
In the year 1658, Mark Milbank was mayor, and John Watson, sheriff.

June 7th this year, Sir John Marley, the loyal partizan of Charles the First and Second, occurs as offering himself, with a view it should seem to serve the interests of his prince, to the then prevailing powers to betray them. He obtained leave, and had the means granted him of coming into England, where no doubt he acted as a spy, and con∣tributed every thing in his power to the restoration
Thurloe's State Papers, vol. vii. p. 149—also p. 313, 526, 549, 346.
The following occurs in a new catalogue of the lords, baronets and knights, made by his highness the lord protector since the 2d of November, 1657, printed in 1658, pre∣served in Morgan's Phoenix Britannicus, p. 161.
32. Walter Strickland, Esq
40. Sir William Strickland, Knight and Baronet.
38. Sr Arthur Haslerigg, Baronet.
58. Sir John Hewson, Knight.
Walter Strickland, Esq was one of his highness's privy-council.
These to take place as lords, and have that dignity in all commissions..

In the month of September this year, on the death of Oliver Crom∣well, his son Richard Cromwell was proclaimed protector
Thurloe's State Papers, vol. vii. p. 388.
"Mr. Thomas Errington to Secretary Thurloe.
"Right Honourable. My humble service presented to your lordship, the trust your honour has reposed in me, crave leave to acquaint your honour with the passages in these parts since the death of his highness the late lord protector. On Tuesday last upon receipt of the mail, I immediately delivered Mr. Shaftoe, our deputy mayor, my lord president of your councell's letter, with order for proclaiming his now highness my Lord Richard protector; and presently the deputy mayor sent for Mr. Recorder, the aldermen and seve∣ral of the common-councell, myself being one, and did communicate the councell's plea∣sure, and forthwith his highness was proclaimed in state and in a very solemn manner lord protector, and watches set at every gate in town. Mr. Mayor and others went the rounds that night, and every alderman goes the round a night; and sees the gates be well locked in, and the watchmen, six at every gate. All these parts are in quietness, and I hear not one person as yet speak against his highness nor your lordship's proclamation. If any thing fall out in these parts or news, I crave leave to acquaint your lordship, and shall alwavs be ready to serve his highness or your lordship what is in my power, and rests my lord "Newcastle, 9 September, 1658. "Your most humble servant, "THO. ERRINGTON." at New∣castle,
from which town also he was complimented on his accession to a dignity which proved of short duration, by the mayor, aldermen sheriff, and the rest of the common-council
Diurnal, Thursday, September 25th, Newcastle upon Tyne.
"The mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and the rest of the common-council of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne—address to Richard Cromwell; wherein, after several flattering expressions as to his father, they say, that he being settled in the government of this commonwealth as supream magistrate, to the great satisfaction of his people, accord∣ing to the declaration and appointmemt of his late highnesse, they do therefore acquiess therein and promise to yield all due honour, love and obedience to him, &c." P. 47..
In the year 1659, Thomas Bonner was mayor, and James Briggs, alias Bigg, sheriff.

June 6th this year, a petition of the well-affected, as they are called, in the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, was read before the House of Commons; and Sir Arthur Hasilrigg was ordered to return the thanks of the House to the petitioners, for their good affectionsJournals of the Commons, vol. vii..

June 8th, there was voted in the common-council of Newcastle, an address to the supreme authority of the parliament of the common∣wealth of EnglandCommon-council books.—It was signed by the mayor only..

July 15th this year, the names of the commissioners and commission officers of the militia of Newcastle upon Tyne, were read and agreed to by the House of Commons
Journals of the Commons, vol. vii.
Price, in his History of the Restauration, p. 32, says: "There appears to have been a number of quakers in Lambert's army, in Newcastle, 165, where they bargained for and sold horses, to be paid when such or such a steeple-house (i. e. church) was pulled down.".

September 5th this year, a counter petition was agreed upon by the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and the rest of the common-council of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, to one at that time about
to be presented to the supreme authority of the nation, the parliament of the commonwealth of England, by those who styled themselves well-affected persons of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be sent up also to the said parliamentJournals of Commons, vol. vii. The first was read September 14th, 1659; as was the second also, with a bill for the better government of that town and county for one year, the first time.—September 17th, it was read a second time, and committed to a committee..

In November this year, General Lambert arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne, with a force of about 12,000 men, comprehending, as was re∣ported, 7,000 of the chief of the cavalryPrice's History of the Restauration.—Two letters, the one dated Nov. 30th, and the other December 1st, 1659, appear by the Journals, vol. vii. to have been received by the House of Commons, January 14th, 1660, from the Lord Lambert, at Newcastle upon Tyne..
In the year 1660, John Emmerson was mayor, and William Blackett, sheriff.
Algernon, Earl of Northumberland, was constituted lord lieutenant of the county of Northumberland, Sept. 7th, 1660Collins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 464, edit. 1779..

Sunday, January 1st this year, General Monk, with Lord Fairfax, and other English friends, passed the Tweed, with six regiments of foot, and were followed the next day by four regiments of horse, in order to advance towards Lambert, who commanded superior forces in and about Newcastle, to oppose them
Price's History of the Restauration, p. 75. "'Twas now the first of January, 1660, (it was the Lord's day, and it was his doing) when our general ordered his infantry from Coldstream over the Tweed; and the next day marched his house likewise, having sent Colonel Knight before, with some troops towards Newcastle."
The same writer, p. 55, says "The general (Monk) sent Major Knight, with four troops of horse, and Captain Miller, with six companies of foot, to enter Newcastle: but Colonel Lilburne had prevented them, and put in force too great for them to attack; so they retreated to Anwick, and stayed there till they were remanded.".

January 6th, General Monk arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne, on the road to which place he was met by great multitudes of the com∣mon people, and welcomed by loud acclamations: General Lambert
appears to have quitted Newcastle about the time that General Monk began his march from Coldstream
Price's Hist. of the Restauration, p. 77. The MS. Life of Alderman Barnes, p. 42, tells us, "That on Monk's marching into England, Mr. Barnes was ordered by the com∣mon-council and magistrates of Newcastle, to meet Major Dorny at Chester-in-the-Street, who, with a party of Colonel Zanchy's regiment, was advancing to oppose him, to desire him to halt a little, lest the country should be involved in blood."
Bourne relates that, "in the spring of 1660, an unknown gentleman came to reside at Winlaton, living very privately, and daily more and more inquisitive after news, and every circumstance of the restoration. Upon understanding the passing of the act of in∣demnity, together with the exception of the murderers of the late King, he went into an adjoining wood and hanged himself.".

Sir Arthur Haslerigg, soon after the meeting of that parliament which restored King Charles the Second, came to General Monk and delivered up his two regiments, as also the governments of Berwick, Newcastle upon Tyne, and Tinmouth, which had been conferred upon him by the late powers, on condition of having his life and estate pre∣served, which were generously assured to himEchard's History. Also Lord's Journals, vol.ii. p. 293..

May 31st this year, the effects of Mrs. Blakiston, relict of John Blakiston, Esq a magistrate and member of parliament for the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and who was one of the regicides, were seized upon by the sheriff of DurhamJournals of the Commons, vol. viii..

July 28th this year, King Charles II. by his writ, restored William Robson to the office of parish-clerk of All-Saints' church in Newcastle, from which he had been ejected for his loyalty, October 20th, 1644
Bourne's History of Newcastle.
It appears by the common-council books of Newcastle, August 8th, 1660, that the Earl of Newcastle; Sir John Marley, Knight, sometime mayor; Sir George Baker, some∣time recorder; Sir Nicholas Cole, Knight and Baronet; Francis Bowes, Knight, some∣time alderman; James Cole, Esq sometime sheriff; Henry Marley, merchant, sometime clerk of the chamber; Henry Brabant, merchant; Jonas Cudworth, draper; Thomas Carnes, slater; and Anthony Errington, sometime one of the serjeants at mace, were re∣stored to their former freedoms of that corporation.
The following anecdote concerning King Charles's restoration, is extracted from the MS. Life of Barnes so often cited:
"Levingston, a Scots minister, being inticed into the ship wherein the King was embarked to come for England, standing off some leagues at sea upon the deck, amongst sundry lords and gentlemen, in a most solemn manner, with uplifted hands and eyes said: 'Lord, if it be thy blessed will, let us all this moment sink down to the bottom of the ocean, for we are carrying over thy heavy wrath to Britain.'—But God's wrath ceased not, and therefore," says my author, "they did not sink!!!"
"The restored King," adds this writer, "soon discovered what his manners were like to be, in a horrid debauch in the mulberry-garden, drinking to filthy excess till 3 o'clock in the morning.—Mr. Barnes, on his return home (from London), presaged, from the saturnine aspect of the King, that as his majesty resembled Tiberius Caesar, so should his reign, i. e. our Lord should be crucified in it!".
In the year 1661, Sir John Marley, Knight, was mayor, and Thomas Jennison, sheriff.
In the year 1662, Sir Francis Anderson was mayor, and Henry Brabant, sheriff.
September 5th, 1662, Colonel Edward Villiers, governor of Tin∣mouth-castle, was presented with a personal freedom of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books..

August 12th, 1663, Oswald Rogers, master and mariner, who landed the Lord Marquis of Newcastle upon Tyne safe in England, was, at the request of the said lord marquis, admitted to a personal freedom of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne
Ibid.
In 1664, Thomas Twisden of the King's Bench, and Charles Turner, of the Exche∣quer, were judges on the northern circuit.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1663, Sir James Clavering was mayor, and Robert Shaftoe, sheriff.
A. D. 1664, Sir Francis Liddell was mayor, and Francis Liddell, sheriff.
In the year 1665, Henry Maddison was mayor, and William Carr, sheriff.

June 28th this year, mention occurs of an order of the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to prevent the spreading of the plague,
by forbidding masters of ships to bring passengers or goods into this harbour, upon pain of being stayed, or detained for forty days, and sailors to come on shore, on pain of imprisonmentCommon-council books..

September 29th this year, Sir William Forster was admitted to a personal freedom of the corporation of Newcastle
Ibid.
In 1606, William Middleton, of Belsay-castle, Bart. was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1666, William Blackett was mayor, and Timothy Davison, sheriff.
In the year 1667, Henry Brabant was mayor, and Ralph Grey, sheriff.

June 27th this year, the Right Honourable Henry, Earl of Ogle, who had received his majesty's commission to be governor of New∣castle upon Tyne, and was resident there, was admitted to his personal freedom of the corporation of that town
Common-council books.
The following extract is from Dr. Ellison's MSS.
"April 2d, 1667, John, son to Mr. Thomas Harrison, merchant, was baptized: sure∣ties Mr. William Huntley, Mr. Henry Bland, and Mrs. Alice Proctor. This child was born the 27th of March, about 3 in the morning."—St. Nicholas' Register.
It is said, that this is that Captain Harrison, who was executed for the murder of Dr. Clinch, and was afterwards found wrongfully executed, the murder being confessed by another person.
Wednesday, July 29th, 1668, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Chris∣topher Turner and Richard Rainsford, Knights, and barons of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1668, Ralph Jennison was mayor, and Robert Jennison, sheriff.

November 9th, 1668, Josceline, Earl of Northumberland, was con∣stituted lord lieutenant of the county of Northumberland
Collins's Peerage, vol. ii. p. 467, ed. 1779.
August 10th, 1669, the assizes began at Newcastle before Christopher Turner, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, and — Walker, serjeant at law.—Ibid.
Tuesday, August 2d, 1670, the assizes began ibid. before Christopher Turner and Timothy Littleton, Knights, and barons of the Exchequer.—Ibid.
Tuesday, August 22d, 1671, they began ibid. before William Wylde, Baronet, and Timothy Littleton, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Ibid..
In the year 1669, Thomas Davison was mayor, and John Rogers, sheriff.
A. D. 1670, William Carr was mayor, and Richard Wright, and afterward Robert Roddam, sheriff.
In the year 1671, Ralph Grey was mayor, and Matthew Jefferson, sheriff.
In the year 1672, Mark Milbank was mayor, and Robert Mallebar, sheriff.

October 7th this year, his Grace John, Duke of Lauderdale, &c. lord president of his majesty's most honourable privy-council of Scot∣land, and sole secretary of state for those kingdoms, &c. was admitted to the freedom of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne
Common-council books.
In the year 1672, on Tuesday, August 20th, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before William Wylde, Bart. and Timothy Littleton, Knight, baron of the Ex∣chequer.—Grey's MSS..

December 17th this year, the King wrote a letter to the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, to elect James Aire, pilot of his majesty's good ship the Saint Michael, a free burgess of that townCommon-council books..
In the year 1673, Timothy Davison was mayor, and George Mor∣ton, sheriff.

July 10th this year, an address was ordered by the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be presented to the King, on the discovery of a plot against his majesty's life, and that of James, Duke of York
Ibid.
In 1673, John Forster was sheriff of Northumberland. In 1674, Martin Fenwick, Esq
Tuesday, July 29th, 1673, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before William Wylde, Bart. and William Ellis, Knight.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1674, Thomas Jennison was mayor, and Henry Jenni∣son, sheriff.

July 1st this year, William Lilburn, Esq was admitted to a per∣sonal freedom of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne
Common-council books.
In the reign of Charles II. says the writer of Nummi Britann. Hist. p. 117, private persons had the liberty of coining pennies, halfpence and farthings, with their own device upon them, for the convenience of trade. This began in 1653.—See Thoresby's Museum, p. 397.
Yet Jacob, in his History of Faversham, gives engravings of some dated 1649.—See also Cottoni Posthuma, p. 199, under the year 1609, where mention occurs of "re∣tailers of victual and small wares using their own tokens." These are generally called trader's pennies.
For specimens of those belonging to Newcastle and Gateshead, see "Tradesmen's tokens in the plate of coins in this work," No. 1, 2, 3, 4.
August 18th, 1674, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Richard Rains∣ford and Timothy Littleton, Knights.
About 1673, Henry, Earl of Ogle, occurs as lord lieutenant of the county of Northum∣berland, and of the town and county of Newcastle, and governor of town and port of Newcastle.—Dedication of Hollar's Views of Tinmouth-castle of that date..
In the year 1675, Sir Francis Anderson was mayor, and William Christian, sheriff.

This year a dreadful pestilential disease, called "the jolly rant" ap∣pears to have raged in Newcastle upon Tyne, and the neighbourhood of that town
There died of it 924 persons. Thoresby, in his Ducatus Leodensis, p. 527, mentions a MS. on this subject, communicated by the ingenious Jabez Cay, of Newcastle upon Tyne, M. D. on two of the four parishes in that town.
Tuesday, August 10th, 1675, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Richard Rainsford and Timothy Littleton, Knights.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1676, Sir Ralph Carr was mayor, and Michael Blackett, sheriff.

June 21st this year, the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, on the petition of John Stobbs, an ingenious artisan, granted him a personal freedom of that corporationCommon-council books.—He is represented as particularly skilful in the making and tempering of steel—making water-engines against the accidents of fire and the like—mak∣ing wind guns, speaking trumpets, glaziers' vices, and several mathematical instruments.,

This year Henry Cavendish succeeded his father William, in the title of Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne
Magna Britannia—Northumberland.
In 1676, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, on Tuesday, August 1st, before Francis North, Knight, chief justice of the Common Pleas, and Vere Bertie, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
September 26th this year, the following order of common-council was made concern∣ing gloves, presented by the sheriff at the assizes, when no prisoners receive sentence of death: "To prevent abuses formerly committed, ordered for the time to come, that the sheriff give gloves only to the following persons:
"Two judges of assize, one paire jessamy and one paire keide; the clerk of assize the like—two marshals—two cryers—four associates, serjeants at law, a paire of jessamy a piece, of 2s. 6d. a paire."
A curious and interesting account of the coal-works, curiosities, manners and custom of the north, and of Newcastle upon Tyne and its vicinity, is preserved in North's Life of Lord-Keeper Guildford.—His lordship, then Sir Francis North, Knight, chief justice of the Common Pleas, came to that town on the northern circuit, August 1st, 1676, with Vere Bertie, baron of the Exchequer.
Tuesday, August 21st, 1677, the assizes were held at Newcastle upon Tyne, before William Mountague, Esq lord chief baron, and Timothy Littleton, baron of the Exche∣quer.—Grey's MSS.
On Thursday, August 1st, 1678, ibid. before William Wylde, Bart. and Vere Bertie. —Ibid.
June 20th, 1678, mention occurs of the magistrates of Newcastle upon Tyne, as in∣teresting themselves in preventing the profanation of the Sabbath, by the rowing of keels on that day.—Common-council books.
On Saturday, August 9th, 1679, the assizes were held at Newcastle upon Tyne, before William Dolben, Knight, justice of the King's Bench, and Thomas Raymond, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
In 1679, Mark Milbank was sheriff of Northumberland.—No name occurs till 1682.
On Saturday, August 7th, 168 ot he assizes began at Newcastle, before William Dolben, Knight, justice of the King's Bench, and Edward Atkins, Knight, baron of the Exche∣quer.—Ibid.
On Tuesday, July 26th, 1681, they began ibid. belore the above Sir William Dolben, and William Gregory, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Ibid.
On Wednesday, August 9th, 1682, ibid. before Thomas Jones, Knight, and Thomas Street, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Ibid.
In 1682, and in 1683, Edmund Crayster, of Crayster, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
Tuesday, August 7th, 1683, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Tho∣mas Jones, Knight, justice of the King's Bench, and Thomas Street, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
