The learned Mrs. Elizabeth Elstob was daughter of Ralph Elstob, merchant at New∣castle, and was born 1683. See Nichols's Anecdotes of Bowyer, p. 10, and Archaco∣logia, vol. 1. p. 26.
Ralph Elstob was sheriff of that town in 1685.
Tuesday, July 29th, 1684, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before George Jeffries, Bart. chief justice of the King's Bench, and Richard Holloway, Knight, of the same court.
In 1684, James Howard, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. No name occurs till 1686.
The MS. Life of Alderman Barnes, so often cited, tells us, that when Sir George Jef∣fries was on the northern circuit, at Newcastle, "he indulged himself in his usual drunken excesses.—A certain gentleman invited him to a plentiful entertainment at his house, with which he was so taken, that he gained his guest's wondrous opinion. They tell me, says he, such a man is a whigg, but I find it is no such thing, he is an honest drunken fellow. They told him Mr. Barnes's house stood in the close. I even thought so, says he, some close or field, for that rebel to train and muster his men in. There had lately been a meet∣ing conventicle broken up at Mr. Barnes's—a fine was levied upon the house; several were taken and bound over to the assizes—Barnes himself escaped—Jeffries was huge witty upon all the prisoners, but it fretted him sadly he could not catch this Barnes."
A marvellous escape from destruction, by the blowing up of gunpowder, is related in the MS. Life of Barnes, which must have happened in Newcastle about this time.
"One of his brother-in-law's (Alderman Hutchinson's) apprentices, stepping up into the back-lofts to fetch somewhat he wanted, in his heedlessess and haste, stops his candle into a barrell of gunpowder, whose head was struck off, to serve instead of a candlestick. But the man reflecting upon what he had done, was struck with affrightment, his heart failed him, nor durst he slay any longer, but running down stairs, leaves the candle burn∣ing in the gunpowder cask, and with horror, trembling and despair, tells the family what indiscretion he had committed: they were all immediately at their wits end, and well they might, for the lofts were three stories high, very large, and stowed full with whatever is combustible, as brandy, oil, pitch, tar, rosin, flax, alum, hops, and many barrels of gun∣powder. Had the candle fallen to a side, or had th least spark fallen from the snuff into the cask, the whole town had been shaken, and the lower part of it had been immediately blown up and in a blaze: but one of the labourers, a stout fellow, run forthwith into the loft, and joining both his hands together, drew the candle softly up between his middle most finger, so that if any snuff had dropped, it must have fallen into the hollow of the man's hand, and by this means was Newcastle saved from being laid ni ashes."
Friday, August 14th, 1685, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Edward Atkins, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, and Thomas Wallcot, Knight, justice of the King Bench..
In the year 1677, Robert Roddam was mayor, and Timothy Rob∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1678, Matthew Jefferson was mayor, and Nicholas Fenwick, sheriff.
In the year 1679, George Morton was mayor, and Willlam Au∣bone, sheriff.
A. D. 1680, Sir Nathanael Johnson was mayor, and Joseph Bonner, sheriff.
In the year 1681, Timothy Robson was mayor, and John Squire, sheriff.
A. D. 1682, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and Nicholas Ridley, sheriff.
In the year 1683, William Blackett was mayor, and John Rumney, sheriff.
In the year 1684, William Aubone was mayor, and William Proc∣tor, sheriff.
A. D. 1685, Sir Henry Brabant was mayor, and Ralph Elstob, sheriff.

On the death of the King, which happened in the beginning of this year, addresses were sent up to James II. his successor, both by the corporation and Trinity-House of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books, February 16th, 1685..

The rebellion this year, by the Earl of Argyle in Scotland, and the Duke of Monmouth in England, did no way incommode the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, both having been speedily deserted, taken prisoners and executedBourne..
In the year 1686, Nicholas Cole was mayor, and Thomas Paise, sheriff.

August 6th this year, mention occurs of the town-chamber of New∣castle as having been lately robbed: the corporation of that town offered 100l. reward for the discovery of the offenders
Common-council books.
In 1686, Mark Milbank, Knight, was sheriff of Northumherland.
Monday, August 2d, 1686, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Robert Wright, Knight, justice of the King's Bench, and John Powell, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..

In the year 1687, John Squire was elected mayor, but removed by mandamus from the King, December 24th, and Sir William Creagh placed in his stead: William Ramsay was elected sheriff at the same time, but removed also by the said mandamus, and Samuel Gill ap∣pointed in his room
Grey's MSS. No. 3, dorso, in quarto, p. 19.
Monday, July 25th, 1687, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Richard Allibon, Knight, of the King's Bench, and Thomas Powell, Knight, baron of the Ex∣chequer.—Grey's MSS..

September 20th this year, mention occurs of an address from the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle, to King James the Second
Common-council books.
In 1687, Richard Neile, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..

In the year 1688, William Hutchinson
The MS. Life of Alderman Barnes, speaking of this period of tyranny and confusion, p. 70, tells us, that "on the accession of James II. the magistracy was composed of papists and protestants, conformists and non-conformists; the cap, the mace, and the sword, were one day carried to the church, another day to the mass-house, and on a third to the dissenting meeting-house.—When it fell to the dissenters to have a mayor chosen out of their party, Alderman Barnes declared himself, and exerted himself in favour of his brother-in-law, Mr. Hutchinson."
In 1688, Richard Neile, Knight, was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 13th, 1688, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Robert Wright, Knight, chief justice of the King's Bench, and Thomas Jenner, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas. was mayor, but was turned out, and succeeded by Nicholas Ridley; and Matthias Partis first, and afterwards Matthew White was sheriff.

A remarkably fulsome address, dated January 16th this year, was signed, not only by Sir William Creagh, then mayor of Newcastle, and by other aldermen of that town that were papists, but by some others of the magistracy who were dissenters; but it was not presented to the King, having been over-ruled by a majority of the common-councilDr. Ellison's MSS..

August 13th, 1688, an address to the King, "for the inestimable blessing of a Prince of Wales," appears to have been agreed upon, and
signed at the assizes held at the castle of Newcastle upon Tyne, by the high sheriff, deputy lieutenants, justices of peace, and grand jury of the county of NorthumberlandEchard..

In November this year, the town of Newcastle received the Lord Lumley, and declared for the Prince of Orange, and a free parliament. Upon this occasion, a beautiful statue of King James the Second on horseback, erected upon a white marble basis, before the Exchange in the midst of the Sand-Hill, was demolished by the mob, who dragged the statue and its horse upon the key, and turned them over into the riverBourne's History..
In the year 1689, William Carr was mayor, and William Feather-stonhaugh, sheriff.

This year the town of Newcastle upon Tyne was put into a posture of defence
Common-council books—April 8th, 1689. William Harrison, marshal, on his peti∣tion there is granted him 5l. for his care and pains about the gates during the late watch.
Ibid. July 15th, 1689. Ten guineas ordered to be paid to Mrs. Squire, for the trouble of her house in entertaining the lords commissioners.
Ibid. "December 19th, 1689. Powder, ball and arms. It's ordered that the same be pro∣vided at the town's charge in such manner as the mayor and aldermen shall think meet."
May 26th this year, King William granted to John White, of York, father of the late John White, printer of the Courant in Newcastle upon Tyne, who had printed his mani∣festo, his royal licence to be the King's sole printer in the city of York.—From the origi∣nal, communicated by Mr. Thomas Saint.
In the year 1689, William Blackett, of Newcastle upon Tyne, Baronet, was sheriff of Northumberland. No name occurs till 1692.
Monday, August 5th, 1689, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before John Powell, Knight, and Penton Ventris, Knight, justices of the Common Pleas.— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1690, William Ramsey was mayor, and Thomas Wasse, sheriff.

In July this year the militia of the town of Newcastle were em∣bodied
Common-council books. "July 15th, 1690. Townes armes—militia. Ordered, that all the armes belonging to the towne in the hands and custody of the several inhabitants, or delivered out to the several companyes (of militia) be taken an account of by some person appointed by the captain of every company, who shall have each 20s. for preserving the said armes from being embezzled, &c."
Ibid. October 13th this year. "Thanksgiving-day for his majesty's safe return from Ireland, being on Sunday next, ordered, that Mr. Mayor have a feast dinner at the town's charge, and after evening service, that they come to the court and take a glass of wine, and have bonfires, as is usual, &c."
Thursday, September 4th, 1690, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before William Dolben, Knight, justice of the King's, Bench, and John Powell, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1691, Matthew White was mayor, and Joseph Atkin∣son, sheriff.

July 26th this year, Henry Cavendish, Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, died, and having left no male issue, that honour became extinct in the male line of the family; but John Hollis, Earl of Clare, who had married Margaret Cavendish, his third daughter, having appeared with the most early in asserting the liberties of the nation against popery and tyranny, and advanced the revolution with great zeal, was pro∣moted, in consequence of these his great services, to the dignity of the Marquis of Clare, and Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne
Magna Britannia, in Northumberland.
August 10th, 1691, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before John Holt, Knight, chief justice of the King's Bench, and John Turton, Knight, baron of the Ex∣chequer.—Grey's MSS.
September 24th this year, mention occurs in the common-council books, of a linen manufactory and spinning trade being established at Newcastle, for the managing and carrying on of which, the mayor and aldermen for the time being were to be a standing committed.
Tuesday, July 26th, 1692, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Robert Atkins, Knight, chief baron, and John Powell, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas.— Grey's MSS.
In 1692, John Backett, of Wylam-Hall, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, August, 15th, 1693, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Edward Nevill, Knight, and John Powell, Knight, justices of the Common Pleas.
In 1693, John Bacon, of Staward, Esq was sheriff of Northumbeland..
In the year 1692, Thomas Wasse was mayor, and Benjamin Davi∣son, sheriff.
A. D. 1693, Sir Ralph Carr, Knight, was mayor, and George Whinfield, sheriff.

In the year 1694, Joseph Atkinson was mayor, and Robert Eden, sheriff
In the common-council books, July 23d, 1694, mention occurs of Crowley's factory (at Swalwell, in the vicinity of Newcastle', which must have begun at least three years before. Mr. Ambrose Crowley agreed to pay the corporation of Newcastle 6l. 13s. 4d. per annum, for his exemption from toll, and other privileges concerning the manage∣ment of that factory.
In 1694, no name of any gentlemen occurs as sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 6th, 1694, the assizes began at Newcastle, before George Treby, Knight, chief justice of the Common Pleas, and John Turton, baron of the Exchequer.— Ibid.
In 1695, Robert Bewick, of Close-House, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 22d, 1695, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Edward Neville, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas, and John Turton, Knight, baron of the Exechequer. —Grey's MSS.
The following is extracted from the Register of St. Andrew's in Newcastle: "April 24th, 1695, were buried James Archer and his son Stephen, who in the month of May, 1658, were drowned in a coal-pitt in the Galla-Flat, by the breaking in of water from an old waste. The bodys were sound intire after they had lyen in the water 36 years and 11 months.".
A. D. 1695, Timothy Robson was mayor, and George Henderson, sheriff.

January 14th this year, an address of condolence on the death of the Queen, was ordered by the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be drawn up and remitted to the burgesses in parliament for that town, to be presented to the King
Common-council books.
Saturday, August 8th, 1696, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Edward Ward, Knight, chief baron, and John Turton, Knight, justice of the King's Bench.— Grey's MSS.
In 1696, Robert Shaftoe, of Benwell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1696, George Whinfield was mayor, and William Ram∣sey, junior, sheriff.

In the beginning of this year there appeared to have been a scheme
in agitation between the King of France, and the late abdicated King James, to make a descent upon Great Britain, in the vicinity of New∣castle upon Tyne
Macpherson's Original Papers, vol. i. anno 1696.
"A memorial the 8th of January, 1696. In Nairne's hand.—Translation.
Nairne's Papers, D. N. vol. i. 4to, No. 5. "The town of Newcastle, one of the most considerable in England, is situated at the distance of a league from the sea, on the river Tyne, which separates the county of Northumberland from the bishoprick of Durham. At the mouth of this river stands a large village called Tinmouth, with a fort, which com∣mands the entry; but is in bad repair towards the land—vessels of 500 tons can enter the harbour. The town is surrounded only by an old ruinous wall, without ramparts or ditches; and is commanded by heights on all sides. It is in this neighbourhood they dig the coals, which are so well known throughout all the kingdom, as coals are shipped only from thence and from Sunderland, a small town at three leagues distance, which is scarcely known but by the nobleman who takes his title from it. From London to New∣castle, there are seventy leagues of as fine a country as is in the world; fifteen from New∣castle to Scotland, and twenty to Lancaster. In the counties of York, Westmoreland, Cum∣berland, Northumberland, and in the bishoprick of Durham, are all the excellent studs; consequently the cavalry and dragoons might be easily mounted. Besides 20,000 car∣riages and cart horses, which carry coals from the mines to Newcastle and Sunderland, will be found in that country, and may be useful for carrying the baggage of the army; but a more important consideration is, that the greatest part of the inhabitants of these districts are well affected towards his majesty, and may join him without any hindrance. The length of the navigation is the only objection that can be foreseen; to which it may be answered, that the difficulty consists in sailing from Dunkirk, and leaving the coast; but that ships when they are once at sea have nothing to fear; and it is immaterial whe∣ther the descent is made on the second or on the fourth day. It is proper to remark, that the favourable wind for this passage is the S. and S. E. which will hinder the ships in the Downs from putting to sea."
"A mistake in a conversation between Lewis XIV. and the late King, defeated the in∣vasion intended for this year. Mr. Powel, who had been sent by the adherents of the latter prince, from England, through the vehemence of his zeal, produced this mistake. He seemed to insinuate, that the Jacobites in Britain were first to take arms, and then expected to be supported by France. On this state of the case, his most Christian Majesty pro∣ceeded to make preparations for transporting a force into England. His order gives, were so well obeyed, that things were in great forwardness in the beginning of the year. James, therefore, and his servants, employed themselves in forming plans for invasion; the above is a scheme for a descent in the neighbourhood of Newcastle.".

In March this year the Trinity-House of Newcastle addressed the
King on the defeating of a plot which had been discovered against his majesty's life.

This address glows with a spirit of loyalty, and contains many per∣tinent allusions to the particular profession of this fraternity
Papers of the Trinity-House.
Monday, August 9th, 1697, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Edward Neville, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas, and John Turton, Knight, justice of the King's Bench.—Grey's MSS.
In 1697, Robert Mitford, of Mitford, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
A very honourable account of the gallant behaviour of Charles Newton, master of a col∣lier of Newcastle upon Tyne, loaden with merchant goods, and aided by a merchant-man of that port, on an attack April 10th, 1697, by a French privateer of very superior force, and in company with another privateer of that nation, occurs in Campbell's Lives of the English Admirals, vol. iii. p. 218, in a note..
In the year 1697, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and George Cuth∣bertson, sheriff.

November 27th this year, an address of congratulation from the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to King William on his return to England, was signed, and directed to be forwarded to the Earl of Scarborough, in order to be presented to his majesty
Common-council books.
Monday, August 22d, 1698, the assizes began at Newcastle, before John Powell, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas, and Samuel Eyre, Knight, justice of the King's Bench.—Ibid.
No name of a sheriff of Northumberland occurs in 1698..
In the year 1698, Sir William Blackett, Baronet, was mayor, and Edward Harrison, sheriff.
A. D. 1699, Robert Eden was mayor, and Jonathan Hargrave, sheriff.

In September this year, a fire happened in Sand-Gate in the suburbs of Newcastle
Common-council books.
Monday, August 7th, 1699, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Edward Ward, Knight, chief baron, and John Powell, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas.—Ibid.
In 1699, Edward Collingwood, of Byker, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1700, George Anderson was mayor, and John Bowes sheriff.

June 24th this year, the Lord Bishop of Durham was entertained at dinner by the mayor of Newcastle
Common-council books. No name of a sheriff of Northumberland occurs in 1700.
Monday, August 5th, 1700, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before John Turton, Knight justice of the King's Bench, and John Blencowe, Knight, justice of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..

In December this year, mention occurs of a society established in Sand-Gate in the suburbs of Newcastle, for the reformation of manners, consisting of twenty keelmen, who had entered into an agreement to exert themselves in "preventing tiplers upon the Lord's day, and keeping Sand-Gate free of inmates
Common-coucil books.
In 1701, John Grey, of Howick, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, August 19th, 1701, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Edward Ward, Knight, lord chief baron, and John Turton, Knight, justice of the King's Bench. —Grey's MSS.."
In the year 1701, William Ramsay was mayor, and William Bout-flower, sheriff.

August 22d this year, Mr. John Fenwick, of Rock, in the county of Northumberland, stabbed Ferdinando Forster, Esq one of the repre∣sentatives in parliament for that county, between the White-Cross and a thorn tree which stood at that time in Newgate-Street in Newcastle upon Tyne, upon which spot he was also executed for that crime on the 25th of September following
Fenwick was hanged at the White-Cross, and all be gates of the town were shut during the execution, for fear of a rescue from the people of the north, with whom the name of Fenwick was held in great veneration.
The quarrel arose about some family matters at dinner, at the Black-Horse inn, near the White Cross, which was then the best inn in Newcastle. Fenwick challenged the other to fight, and as they went out, being behind Forster, he stabbed him in that situa∣tion. This happened during the assizes. There is an entry concerning this in St. Andrew's Register. There is an order of common-council, 1701, to pay 40 shillings to the officers that apprehended Fenwick on this occasion..

October 23d this year, an address to King William, on the King of
France's declaration in proclaiming the pretended Prince of Wales, was signed by the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, common-council, and principal inhabitants of Newcastle upon Tyne
Common-council books.
In 1702, William Brown, of Bolton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. Monday, August 3d, 1702, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Thomas Trevor, Knight, chief justice of the Common Pleas, and Littleton Powis, Knight, of the Queen's Bench..
In the year 1702, William Carr was mayor, and John Bell, sheriff.

March 25th this year, an address to Queen Ann, on the death of her predecessor King William the Third, was signed by the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, common-council, and other the principal inhabitants of Newcastle upon TyneCommon-council books..
May 20th this year, a petition was agreed upon by the mayor, aldermen, and common-council, of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be sent to the Queen concerning the fortification of the port of that townIbid..

July 7th this year, mention occurs of a petition from the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, to Prince George of Denmark, lord high admiral of England, concerning the coal-trade, which suffered much at that time for want of convoys and cruisers to annoy the enemy
Ibid. In 1703, Thomas Forster, of Ftherston, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. None occurs till 1707.
Monday, August 2d, 1703, the assizes ben at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Thomas Trevor, Knight, chief justice of the Common Pleas, and John Blencowe, justice of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1703, Matthew White was mayor, and Allan Bateman, sheriff.

A most remarkable suicide, the consequence, it should seem, of melancholy, occasioned by too serious reflections on an unfortunate amour that had happened many years before, was committed by Eliza∣beth Sharper in Sid-Gate, in the suburbs of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the beginning of August this year
In the register of burials, belonging to St. Andrew's in that town, there is the following most horrid entry: "Aug. 8, 1703, Elizabeth Sharper, who lived in Sidgatt, rip opin her owin belle with a pare of sesers. The wound was six inches long, and her pudens cam out and lay on each side of her, and was buried August 8th, 1703."
The MS. Life of Barnes, p. 354, gives the following particulars. "Elizabeth Sharper was well respected by all her neighbours, and lived with her sister to a great age un∣married, only it was whispered she bore a child to another woman's husband in her younger years. When she had reached her 80th year of age, she fell at once into a deep despair: there was no outward cause by losses or other calamities, that could be assigned as the occasion of it:—most, if not all the parish clergy of Newcastle visited her, but no comfort they could offer ever staid with her. She confessed her bearing a bastard, which was taken from her body, and she believed was murdered. She ript up her belly with a pair of scissars, and pulled her bowels out with her hand. A surgeon put them in their place again, and sewed up her belly. She had her reason and senses perfectly, and lived and died in a house that belonged to Mr. Barnes."
I was myself an eye witness of the deplorable effects of a similar paroxysm of despair in Susannah Nicholson, an inoffensive old laundress, who lived in the Back-Row in New∣castle upon Tyne, and who on Sunday evening, October 23d, 1763, maimed herself deli∣berately in the most dreadful manner, by cutting off her breasts, her lips, ears, and nose, and yet lived for some days afterwards.—An account of this suicide (as a gentleman with whom I then corresponded at Paris, informed me) had found us way into the Paris Alamain, soon after it happened, and excited the horror and commiseration of all Europe.
Monday, August 14th, 1704, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Edward Ward, Knight, chief baron, and Littleton Powis, Knight, justice of the Queen's Bench. —Grey's MSS..
In the year 1704, Thomas Wasse was mayor, and Matthew Matsin, sheriff.
Matsin died July 24th, 1705, and was succeeded by Jonathan Roddam.

September 20th this year, the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne addressed Queen Ann on the late great and glorious victories of her fleet and armyCommon-council books.—Ibid. April 4th, 1704, the common-council of Newcastle gave 60l. towards the building of a church in Rotterdam, wherein divine service was to be celebrated according to the Liturgy of the church of England..

December 21st this year, there was an order made, that the whole House of Commons should attend Queen Ann with an address to re∣quest her majesty to give speedy and effectual orders for putting the
town of Newcastle upon Tyne into a posture of defence, and securing the port of Tinmouth
Lord's Journals, vol. xvii. p. 602.
Monday, August 6th, 1705, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before John Powell, Knight, of the Queen's Bench, and John Blencowe, Knight, of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1705, Sir Ralph Carr was mayor, and William Ellison, sheriff.

This year it appears to have been in agitation in the House of Com∣mons to enlarge the river Wear, and the port and haven of Sunder∣land. This was opposed by a petition from the master, pilots, and seamen of the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne
Records of the Trinity-House.
Monday, July 29th, 1706, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Edward Ward, Knight, chief baron, and Robert Tracy, Esq of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS. August 11th, 1707, before John Blencowe, Knight, and Thomas Bury, Knight; and August 2d, 1708, before Robert Tracy, Esq and Thomas Bury, Knight..
In the year 1706, Nicholas Ridley was mayor, and Matthew Fea∣therstonehaugh, sheriff.

July 17th this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and com∣mon-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed the Queen on the glorious victories of her majesty and her allies in the battle of Ramilies, and the success of her fleets and armies in SpainCommon-council books. "Then your majesty arose like another Deborah," oc∣curs in it..
August 6th, her majesty was addressed on the same subject by the Trinity-House of that townBooks of the Trinity-House..
In the year 1707, Joseph Atkinson was mayor, and Henry Reay, sheriff.

April 21st this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and com∣mon-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed the Queen on the happy union of the two kingdoms of England and ScotlandCommon-council books..
In the year 1708, Robert Fenwick was mayor, and Edward John∣son, sheriff.
March 27th this year, on the rumour of an intended invasion, se∣veral ships of war and transports with land forces, under the command of Lieutenant-General Withers, arrived at the port of Newcastle.

A loyal address was sent to the Queen on this occasion by the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of that town
Common-council books.
Henry Ogle, of Eglingham, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland in 1707. In 1708, Robert Lawson, of Cramlington, Esq was sheriff. None occurs in 1709.
In 1709, Littleton Powis, Knight, of the Queen's Bench, and Thomas Bury, baron of the Exchequer, were down on the northern circuit.—Grey's MSS.
In 1710, George Fletcher, of Rothbury, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
This year, John Powell, Knight, of the Queen's Bench, and Robert Price, baron of the Exchequer, were down on the northern circuit.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1709, George Whinfield was mayor till June 28th, 1710, when Jonathan Roddam was appointed, and Henry Dalston was sheriff.

In the beginning of March this year, the keelmen mutinied at New∣castle; they held out for some months, and prevented the keels from working upon the river for that time, to the great annoyance of the coal-tradeGrey's MSS. No. 3, quarto..
In the year 1710, William Ellison was mayor, and Ralph Reed, sheriff.

January 16th this year, there was an order of the common-council of Newcastle, to apply to the lords of the admiralty for two small cruisers, to secure the commerce at sea between that port and North-Britain from French privateersCommon-coucil books..

April 24th this year, it appears to have been in agitation in the common-council of Newcastle, to buy up the fee-farm of that town of the crown at the price of 2,200l. An address was ordered at the same
time to be sent to the Queen on the success of her majesty's armies, and those of her alliesCommon-council books. This has been done by the corporation of the city of Bristol, as the historiographer of that city, Mr. Barrett, informed me in November, 1785..
June 10th this year, a petition was ordered to be forwarded to the Queen concerning a riot of the keelmen in the port of TyneIbid..

December 18th this year, on the circulation of a malicious report that the plague raged at that time at Newcastle upon Tyne, it was ordered by the common-council of that town, to transmit to the lord mayor of London a certificate to the contrary, and to cause the same to be published in the Gazette, and other publick papers
Ibid.
In 1711, John Hollis, Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, died, and left the greatest part of the land estate (he had no male issue) to the eldest son of his youngest sister, Grace Hollis, who had married Thomas Pelham, Baron of Laughton, by whom she had Thomas Hollis Pelham, Baron Laughton, created Duke of Newcastle after his uncle's decease. —Magna Britannia—Northumberland. See under 1715.
In 1711, John Middleton, of Belsay-Castle, Baronet, was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 30th, 1711, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Thomas Parker, Knight, chief justice of the Queen's Bench, and Thomas Bury, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1711, Matthew Featherstonhaugh was mayor, and Francis Rudston, sheriff.

A. D. 1712, Henry Reay
Mr. Alderman Reay married Bridget, daughter of Henry Blencowe, Esq of Little Blencowe in Cumberland.—Nicholson's and Burn's Cumberland, &c. vol. ii. p. 377.
In 1712, Henry Rawling, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 18th, 1712, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Littleton Powis, Knight, of the Queen's Bench, and Thomas Bury, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.— Grey's MSS. was mayor, and Joseph Green, sheriff.

June 28th this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and com∣mon-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed the Queen upon her majesty's communicating to the two houses of parliament, the terms upon which a general peace might be madeCommon-council books..
In the year 1292, Richard Ridley was mayor, and Nicholas Feu∣wick, sheriff.

April 27th this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and rest of the common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed Queen Ann on the conclusion and signing of the treaty for a general peace
Common-council books.
In 1713, William Fenwick, of Bywell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 3d, 1713, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, bcfore Thomas Bury, Knight, and Robert Dormer, Esq of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1714, Edward Johnson was mayor, and Roger Matsen, sheriff.

September 29th this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed King George the First, on his accession to the throne of Great Britain
Common-council books.
In 1714, Mark Strother, of Kirk-Newton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 2d, 1714, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Robert Tracy, Esq of the Common Pleas, and Thomas Powis, Knight, of the Queen's Bench. —Grey's MSS.
In 1715, John Johnson, of Bebside, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 22d, 1715, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Robert Price, Esq baron of the Exchequer, and James Mountague, Knight, baron of the Ex∣chequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1715, Henry Dalston was mayor, and Nathanael Clayton, sheriff.

August 2d this year, Thomas Hollis Pelham, nephew of John Hollis, Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, was created Marquis and Duke of that town, for his great services to governmentMagna Britannia—Northumberland. Thomas Hollis Pedham was also Duke of New∣castle under Lyne in Staffordshire: by his death the title of Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne became extinct, and that of Newcastle under Lyne descended to Henry Clinton, Earl of Lincoln.—Camden's Britannia, last edit. vol. ii. p. 210..

In the beginning of October this year, on the bursting out of the rebellion in the county of Northumberland, the corporation of New∣castle upon Tyne equally discovered their loyalty, and evinced their
spirit on this trying occasion; and, before the arrival of any rcgular forces, put that important town into a posture of defence
It appears to have cost the town of Newcastle above 850l. in raising their own militia, and accommodating the soldiers sent down against the rebels, from Michaelmas that year to the Michaelmas following.—Grey's MSS. No. 3, in quarto.
Bishop Crewe addressed a circular letter to the dean and clergy of the diocese of Dur∣ham on this occasion, dated Steane, November 9th, 1715. His lordship compliments the town of Newcastle for its Ioyalty on this occasion. "I hear Newcastle and Berwick, places of great consequence, and both in my diocese, have been very active for our pre∣sent constitution."
"On Monday, October 10th, 1715, the rebels marched to Morpeth, about 300 strong, all horse; they had expectation of surprizing Newcastle; preparing to march to New∣castle, which they expected should open its gates to them, a party having seized the post at Felton-Bridge, and one Thomas Gibson, a blacksmith of Newcastle, whom they ap∣prehended, and detained as a spy, which he is thought to have been from Alderman White, of Newcastle, a zealous gentleman for the govemment; and finding some delay in it, they promised themselves to have it in a few days, and in the mcan time marched to Hex∣ham. But even before any regular forces entered Newcastle, the magistrates and deputy lieutenants, having first suspicion, and soon after positive intelligence of the designs of the rebels to surprise it, had effectually prevented it, and had taken all imaginable precaution for their security, raising immediately what men they could, securing and imprisoning all papists and suspected persons; arming and encouraging the inhabitants for their own de∣fence. Indeed, the magistrates shewed a very commendable zeal in the interest of the King, and the service of the town; and no less courage in their application to the defence of the place. They got the militia and train bands, who about that time were ordered to muster at Killingworth-Moor, near the town, to be taken into it for its better defence. At the same time the Earl of Scarborough, lord lieutenant of the county of Northumberland, repaired with his friends to Newcastle; and the gentry of those parts, after his lordship's example, mounted their neighbours and tenants on horsebakc, so that the town was full of horses and men, both townsmen and countrymen unanimously declaring for King George. A body of 700 volunteers were armed by the town for their immediate guard. The keel∣men offered a body of 700 men more to be always ready at half an hour's warning; an association having been signed by the whole body of loyal inhabitants. In the middle of this hurry, a battalion of foot, and part of a regiment of dragoons, came to Newcastle, and than all their fears vanished. On the 18th of October, Lieutenant-General Carpenter, with Hotham's regiment of foot, and Cobham's, Molesworth's, and Churchill's draggons, arrived at Newcastle, the gates of which were walled up with stone and lime very strong. These left Newcastle, and lay at Woo 27th of Octobr, intending to face Kelso the next day. This brave general, after long, some, and dismal marches after the re∣bels, who, he was informed, had gone over the mountains to join Mar, which was im∣practicable for his heavy horse, returned to Newcastle, where having scarce refreshed him∣self, he set out against the rebels towards Preston."▪Patten's History of the Rebellion, 1715, p. 22, 24, 25, 51, 89.
In 1716, John Rogers, of East-Denton, Esq was sheruff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 20th, 1716, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before James Mountague, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, and — Hanbury, serjeant at law.— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1716, Ralph Reed was mayor, and Francis Johnson sheriff.

On Tuesday night, March 6th this year, a remarkable aurora borealis was seen in the sky, which is said to have been interpreted by the jacobite party as an omen of God's displeasure against the ruling powers for beheading the rebel lords: a pleasant countryman, by an equally justifiable interpretation, is said to have declared, that it was "an illumination, and publiek rejoicing in the heavens for the defeat of King George's enemies
The comment of the latter seemed most consonant both to the letter and spirit of the phe∣nomenon. Some melancholy fanatics fancied, however, that they saw in thos novel appear∣ance, men without their heads. A popular notion prevailed at that time, and is scarcely now eradicated among the peasants in the neighbourhood, that on the beheading of Earl of Derwentwater, who had a most amiable private character, Dilston Brook, that passes by the place where his seat stood, near Hexham in Northumberland, ran with blood.
In 1717, Ralph Jennison, of Wolsington, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 26th, 1717, the assizes begun at Newcastle, before Robert Doer, Esq of the Common Pleas, and John Fort Eland, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.."
In the year 1717, Francis Rudston was mayor, and John Kelly, sheriff.

January 14th this year, it was in agitation by the common-council of Newcastle, to regulate the watch of that town, and erect lamps in the several streets by an act of parliamentCommon-council books..

In the month of March this year, a bill for the improvement and preservation of the river Wear, and port and harbour of Sunderland, having been again brought before the House of Commons, it was a
second time petitioned against by the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and rest of the common-council of Newcastle upon TyncCommon-council books. March 22d, 1717; also April 3d..

In the year 1718, Sir William Blackett, BaronetHe was chosen mayor this year on producing two letters from the secretaries of state, testifying that he was well affected to government. He had been rejectd the year before., was mayor, and Thomas Stephenson, sheriff.
A. D. 1719, Joseph Green was mayor, and Cuthbert Fenwick, sheriff.

April 6th this year, an address to the King was agreed upon by the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and the rest of the common-council of New∣castle upon Tyne, on the supposed intention of an invasion from Spain
Common-council books.
In 1718, Robert Shaftoe, of Benwell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 3d, 1718, the assizes began at Newcastle, upon Tyne, before Sir James Mountague, and Sir Francis Page, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
In 1719, William Coatsworth, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 3d, 1719, the assizes began at Newcastle, before the same judges as in 1718.
In 1720, Matthew white, of Blagdon, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 15th, 1720, the assizes began at Newcastle, before the same judges as in 1718.
In 1721, Edward Delaval, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 7th, 1721, the assizes at Newcastle, before Mr. Justice T and Mr. Baron Price.—Grey's MS..
In the year 1720, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and Jacob Rutter, sheriff.
A. D. 1721, Francis Johnson was mayor, and Stephen Coulson, sheriff.

June 8th, being Thursday in Whitsun week this year, the first gold cup given by the Corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be run for upon the Town-Moor, was won by Mr. R. Raikes
Grey's MSS. No. 3, in quarto.
"Mark Akensale born the 9 November 1721; baptized h of the same month by the Revd. Mr. Benjo. Bennet." The above was communicated by Mr. Addison, glazer, at Newcastle upon Tyne, who married Dr. Akenside's sister, and is in possession of some drawings, which were the works of that ingenious poet in an early period of his life. Mr. Bennet was a dissenting minister at the new meeting-house in Hanover-Square, New∣castle upon Tyne.—See Life of Mark Akenside in Dr. Johnson's Lives of the Poets..
July 20th this year, the corporation of Newcastle gave 10l. towards the building of a church for those of the episcopal persuasion at Aber∣deen in Scotland.

They voted also, at the same time, the like sum towards the build∣ing of a church at Hartlepool, in the county of Durham, and a farther sum of 10l. for the same pious purpose at Penrith in Cumberland
Common-council books.
In 1722, William Mitford, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 24th, 1722, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Lent Chief Justice King, and Mr. Baron Gilbert.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1722, William Ellison was mayor, and Robert Sorsbie, sheriff.

This year, the attorney-general reported the affair concerning the forfeiture of Walker estate, in favour of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, which report also the lords justices agreed to, and con∣firmedGrey's MSS. No. 3, in quarto..
September 24th this year, the common-council of Newcastle gave 30l. towards the building of a new church at Leeds in YorkshireCommon-council books..

In the year 1723, M. Featherstonhaugh
At the election this year, Thomas Twizel, baker and brewer, an election man, re∣fused to elect, so that the election was on Tuesday, October 1st, by the election men for the last year. The reason he gave for his refusal was, that he himself was an auditor, and that the last year's account was not passed.—Grey's MSS.
October 7th following, Twizel was disfranchised by an order of the common-council. —Common-council books.
In 1723, Robert Mitford, of Mitford, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
In 1724, John Coatesworth, of the Hermitage, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 23d, 1724, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Francis Page, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, and Sir Alexander Denton, Knight, of the Common Bench.—Grey's MSS. was mayor, and Richard Swinburne, sheriff.

At the assizes this year, which began at Newcastle before Mr. Justice Tracy, and Mr. Baron Price, Monday, August 12th, Mr. Edward Riddle, attorney, was tried for killing Captain Lilburn in a duel, in the Nun's Garden in that town, and acquitted, no proof having been made that Mr. Riddle killed him.
In the year 1724, William Carr was mayor, and James Moncaster, sheriff.

October 21st this year, a great fire began in the house of Mr. Joseph Partis, merchant, near St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle, where, by the explosion of a barrel of gunpowder, a great many persons that stood near it, unfortunately lost their lives.

There had been a very wet summer this year in the vicinity of that town, and for the most part the crops of hay and corn were spoiled
Newcastle Courant, October 24th, 1724.
Between March 25th, 1724, and March 25th, 1725, there were baptized in Newcastle upon Tyne, 275 males, and 279 females; in all 554. That year there were buried ibid. 340 males, and 314 female.—Newcastle Courant.
In 1725, Alexander Collingwood, of Little-Ryle, Esq was sheriff of Northumber∣land.
Monday, August 2d, 1725, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Robert Price, Esq baron of the Exchequer, and James Reynold, Esq of the King's Bench.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1725, Nathanael Clayton was mayor, and Thomas Wasse, sheriff.

August 24th this year, the Bishop of Durham held his visitation at Newcastle, where also his lordship preached on the day followingl
Newcastle Courant.
In 1726, Robert Hewick, of Close-House, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 8th, 1726, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Francis Page, baron of the Exchequer, and Bernard Hall, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1726, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and Joseph Lid∣dell, sheriff.
A. D. 1727, Cuthbert Fenwick was mayor, and Robert Johnson, sheriff.

In February this year, the Trinity-House of Newcastle addressed the King on hearing of the wicked designs formed against him and his kingdoms by the Emperor of Germany, and the King of Spain
Trinity-House books.
In 1727, Luke Clennell, of Clennell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
At the assizes, which began at Newcastle, August 7th, 1727, before Edmund Probin, Knight, of the King's Bench, and Laurence Carter, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, one Hackson was tried and condemned for kiliing Mr. Salkeild, by giving him a blow on his breast, of which he died above six months after, but was pardoned at the intercession of Alderman Carr..
June 26th this year, the same body addressed King George the Second on the death of his father, and his accession to the crown of Great BritainTrinity-House books..

October 10th this year, the coronation of King George II. and Queen Caroline was celebrated with great solemnity at Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant, October 13th, 1727. "On Wednesday last, the King and Queen's coronation was celebrated here with the greatest solemnity the day was ushered in with ringing of bells; the magistrates in their scarlet gowns, accompanied by the common-council, clergy and gentry, went from the Guild-Hall to church, with musick playing, and cannons firing, and from thence proceeded to the mayor's house, where a splendid en∣tertainment was prepared for them; and after dinner they repaired to the market-place, where a fountain was erected which ran wine; where the magistrates, common-council, clergy, and gentry, drank the healths of the King, Queen, and royal issue, with many other loyal healths, in presence of many thousand spectators; thence they went to Guild-Hall, where the said healths were repeated with the like ceremony as above, and the con∣duit running wine all the time for the populace, whilst a great bonefire, erected in the Market-place, was burning, the cannons firing at each health: they afterwards returned to the mayor's house, where there was a hall lor all the ladies; and the evening was concluded with rejoycings, bonefires, illuminations, ringing of bells, and all other de∣monstrations of joy."
In 1728, John Fenwick, of Bywill, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 19th, 1728, the assizes began at Newcastle, before John Cummyns, Knight, baron of the Exchequer, and Spencer Cowper, Esq of the Common Bench.— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1728, Stephen Coulson was mayor, and John Stephen∣son, sheriff.

October 7th this year, the corpse of Sir William Blackett, Baronet,
after lying in state for several days, was interred with great funeral pomp, in the church of St. Nicholas in Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant.
In 1729, John Blackett, of Wylam-Hall, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 4th, 1729, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Francis Page, Knight, of the King's Bench, and Bernard Hall, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.— Grey's MSS..
The winter of this year having proved remarkably severe, a collec∣tion was made by the magistrates of Newcastle, &c. for the relief of poor house-keepers, which amounted to the sum of 362l. 18s.
In the year 1729, Henry Reay was mayor, and Cuthbert Smith, sheriff.

October 13th this year, Walter Blackett, Esq afterwards Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, was, on his petition, admitted a free burgess of New∣castle upon Tyne
Common-council books.
"In 1729, the town had a trial at the assizes with Sir Henry Liddel about paying of tolls, wherein a verdict was given in favour of Sir Henry. It was then customary for the judges to go in the town's barge, attended by the mayor, and others of the corporation, to Tinmouth; and in their return, Mr. Justice Page, who tried the cause, had some hot words with Mr. Reay relating to the trial, and thereupon the judge threatened to com∣mit the mayor; and the mayor told the judge he would commit him, being then upon the water, and in his jurisdiction. This squabble was the occasion of discontinuing the custom of going to Tinmouth."—Gyll's interleaved Bourne, p. 245.
In 1730, Francis Blake Delaval, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 20th, 1730, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Francis Page, Knight, and John Fortescue, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
In 1731, Thomas Wilson, junior, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 16th, 1731, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Alexander Denton, of the Common Pleas, and Edmund Probyn, Knight, of the King's Bench.—Grey's MSS.
In 1732, Walter Calverley Blackett, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 31st, 1732, the assizecs began at Newcastle, before Francis Page, Knight, of the King's Bench, and Sir William Thompson, Knight, baron of the Exchequer.— Grey's MSS.
In 1733, John Reed, of Chipchace, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 6th, 1733, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Robert lord chief justice of the Common Pleas, and Thomas Reeve, Esq justice of the Common Pleas.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1730, Francis Rudston was mayor, and William Har-bottle, sheriff.
A. D. 1731, Robert Sorsbie was mayor, and Challoner Cooper, sheriff.
In the year 1732, Richard Ridley was mayor, and William Fen∣wick, sheriff.
A. D. 1732 Matthew Ridley was mayor, and John Simpson, sheriff.

This year four persons received sentence of death at the assizes at Newcastle upon Tyne, and two men were executed upon a gallows erected on purpose on the Town-Moor, where none had been hanged for thirty years before
Grey's MSS.
In 1734, John Ogle, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 5th, 1734, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Francis Page, and Thomas Reeve, Esq—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1734, William Ellison was mayor, and Robert Ellison, his son, sheriff.

April 24th this year, the Trinity-House of Newcastle addressed King George II. on the marriage of the Princess Royal
Books of the Trinity-House.
In 1735, Henry Ellison, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 28th, 1735, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Alexander Denton, and Mr. Justice Lee.—Grey's MSS.
In 1736, Henry Grey, of Howick, Baronet, was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 16th, 1736, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Mr. Justice Lee, and Mr. Baron Fortescue.—Grey's MSS.
In 1737, Henry Ogle, of Causey-Park, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 8th, 1737, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Mr. Baron For∣tescue, and Sir William Chapple.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1735, Walter Blackett was mayor, and John Wilkinson, sheriff.
A. D. 1736, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and Matthew Bell, sheriff.
In the year 1737, William Carr was mayor, and Jonathan Sorsbie, sheriff.
December 17th this year, the day of the funeral of Queen Caroline was observed with great solemnity at Newcastle upon Tynez.
In the year 1738, Nathanael Clayton was mayor, and William Greenwell, sheriff.
A. D. 1739, Cuthbert Fenwick was mayor, and Cuthbert Colling∣wood, sheriff.

This year Michael Curry and John Wilson, having heen condemned each for murder at the assizes at Newcastle upon Tyne, were both exe∣cuted September 4th, about eight o'clock in the morning: Curry's body was immediately carried from the place of execution to Hartley, and there hung in chains
Grey's MSS. October 17th this year, the common-council of Newcastle gave fifty guineas towards the establishment of the Royal Infirmary at Edinburgh.—Common-council books..

October 27th this year, war was declared against Spain in the usual manner, and at the accustomed places in Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant.
In 174, George Shaftoe Delaval, of Little-Bavington, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
August 4th, 1740, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Thomas Parker. Esq of the Common Bench, and James Reynolds, Esq. of the Exchequer..
In the year 1740, Edward Collingwood was mayor, and Ralph Sowerby, sheriff.

January 26th this year, mention occurs of liberal contributions having been made by the Corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, and by Walter Blackett and Matthew Ridley, Esqrs. members of Newcastle Courant.
In 1738, James Hargrave, of Shawdon, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 31st, 1739, the assizes began at Newcastle, before William Fortescue, Esq and Sir William Chapple—Grey's MSS.
In 1739, William Errington, of Walwick-Grange, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.

Monday, August 20th, 1739, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir William Chapple, and Mr. Baron Parker.—Grey's MSS.
parliament, to the poor of that town during the extreme severity of the winterNewcastle Courant, January 26th, 1739 4. "The corporation gave 50l. to the four parishes of the town, by reason of the bad weather for some time past, the coals are in this place as scarce as money. Had it not been for the heaps of small coals belonging to Alderman Ridloy, which the said gentleman gave from the beginning of the frost to all poor people that would fetch them, and which is still continued, great numbers of poor families in Sand-Gate, and other places, must have starved with the excessive cold.— Newcastle, February 2d, 1739-40. Walter Blackett, Esq gave 200 guineas to the four parishes of Newcastle; 50l. to Gateshead; 50l. to Hattburn; and 50l. to Hexham."— Ibid..
This year the Earl of Tankerville was appointed lord lieutenant of the county of Northumberland, and of the town and county of New∣castle upon TrueGentleman's Magazine..

June 9th this year, a great riot began at Newcastle upon Tyne, on account, as it was pretended, of the dearness and scarcity of corn.— The militia of the town was instantly raised, and upon promise given to the rioters, that they should have grain at a much lower rate, the mob was pacified for that dayIbid..

June 10th, Mr. Alderman Ridley, at the head of the militia, gave notice to the multitude, that the corn-factors had set a price on their grain, and had declared, that every one that applied should have it at the fixed rate: they received this information with satisfaction and applause.

On the 21st following, the several pitmen, keelmen, and poor of the town, having made application for corn at the price that had been promised them, found, to their disappointment, that the factors kept their shops shut up, and that most of them had absconded through fear; upon which the mob proceeded to plunder the granaries.
On the 22d, 23d, and 24th of June, nothing material happened, but the discovery of a vessel going off with rye, which was stopped, and some of the grain sold to the poor at the stipulated price.
On the 25th, the militia very imprudently were disbanded; a mea∣sure which seems to have had no inconsiderable hand in tempting the outrageous multitude to the horrid mischiefs of the ensuing day.

July 26th, the rioters assembled in immense numbers on the Sand-Hill, the market-place of Newcastle, where also the mayor and the above alderman, and some other gentlemen, met at the Guild-Hall, to consult what was best to be done on so pressing an extremity. The mob, unawed by the presence of any military force, and intent upon mischief, grew more and more intruly; and a gentleman venturing out to inform them that it had been agreed upon to defend the ship till the poor should be supplied with the rye in it, was knocked down, and much wounded. Upon this the rioters, with more justice than prudence, were fired upon; and one of them having been killed, and several dan∣gerously wounded by the shot, the rabble instantly fell upon the gen∣tlemen assembled in the hall, and having wounded mostGentleman's Magazine, July. of them, pro∣ceeded to outrages that threatened the destruction of the whole town.

They ransacked the town-court and chamber, and having de∣stroyed many of the publick writings
The following occurs in the Newcastle Courant, October 4th, 1740: "Whereas the guild books of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne, from Christmas 1721, to Michaelmas 1738, were destroyed in the late riot there; and as several persons, entered in the said books, are not yet made free of the said corporation, and cannot now have the benefit of such entry: this is to give notice, that such persons as were entered in the said books, and not yet made free, must be entered again, and called in guild as usual, before they be admitted to their freedom; and that the next guild be held on Monday the 13th of October instant."
As also the week following, with the subsequent addition. "And notice is hereby given to all persons who have any causes depending in the several courts of record, held before the mayor and sheriff of this town respectively, that jury days for trial thereof will be held before the mayor on Monday, 10th of November next; and before the sheriff on Wednesday, 12th of November next."
The following occurs, ibid. Saturday, July 19th, 1740, et seq. "Newcastle upon Tyne. Whereas several books, parchments, paper writings, and other things belonging to this corporation and other persons, were taken away during the late tumult; this is desire all persons to whose hands or custody any such things as above, came, immedi∣ately to deliver or give an account thereof at the mayor's house; and notice is hereby given, that all or any person or persons having any such things as before-mentioned, and neglecting to deliver the same, or give such account as before-mentioned, in or before the first day of August next, will be prosecuted as the law directs; and all persons who know or can give information of any such books, parchments, paper writings, or other things, being in the hands or custody of any other person, are desired forthwith to attend the right worshipful the mayor for that purpose, and they shall receive a generous gratuity for so doing." and accounts, carried off a
very large sum of the money belonging to the CorporationSome accounts say, 12 or 1300l. others near 1800l.—They did great damage to the wood-work in the Town-Court; they spoiled and tore every part except the faces of two good whole length pictures of Charles II. and James II. and broke all the windows towards the Sand-Hill. The spirited and great services of Mr. Alderman Ridley, during this tumult, cost him a malicious and false report, that he was the first that gave fire on the unhappy occasion. The following occurs in the Newcastle Courant. "Friday, June 27th, 1740. As it hath been maliciously reported, that I was the first person that fired in the unhappy tumult yesterday, I think myself obliged to declare in this publick manner, that I had neither gun or pistol in my hand, nor did I give order to any person to fire; but when the gentlemen were attacked in so violent a manner, and several of them knocked down, they defended their lives in the best manner they could. Our in∣tention at that time was to guard the delivery of the ship lying at the Key, laden with rye, at the low price; and so to protect the poor upon the terms promised last Saturday. "M. RIDLEY.". After∣wards they patrolled the streets, where finding all the shops shut up, they threatened with horrid execrations to burn and destroy the whole place. In the evening, three companies of Howard's regiment, under the command of Captain SowleIt appears by the common-council books, December 2d, 1740, that Captain Marina∣duke Sowle, on his applying for preferment, had a letter given him in the name of the Corporation of Newcastle, to his Grace the Duke of Richmond., who had marched that day from. Alnwick, entered the town, and soon dispersed the rioters, forty of whom were seized upon, and committed to prison; of which number, six were afterwards convicted at the following assizes, and transported each for seven years
Their names were William Keed, alias Kid, alias Keedy; William Sopit; Robert Hatherick, alias Hatherwick; Thomas Grcy; James Harriot; and Thomas Wilson.— Newcastle Courant, August 16th, 1740.
In 1741, John Strother Ker, of Fowbery, Esq. was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, July 28th, 1741, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Thomas Parker, Esq. of the Common Bench, and Martin Wright, Esq of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
This dreadful affray is reported to have cost the Corporation of New∣castle upon Tyne upwards of 4000l.
In the year 1741, Robert Sorsbie was mayor, and John Ord, sheriff.

March 19th this year, Thomas Gibson, smith, was disfranchised for an audacious attack upon Edward Collingwood, Esq mayor, at the publick guild at Newcastle, by seizing his rod, attempting to wrest it from him, and breaking that badge of publick authority in his handCommon-council books..

October 1st this year, mention occurs of the Corporation of New∣castle persisting in a refusal of the franchise of that town to George Bowes, Esq of Gibside, who had most earnestly requested and peti∣tioned for the sameIbid. Mention occurs, November 6th, 1741, of writs of mandamus for making George Bowes, Esq free, &c. but the Corporation defended themselves against them..
In the year 1742, John Simpson was mayor, and William Peareth, sheriff.

July 12th this year, the mayor and common-council of Newcastle gave 50l. towards the propagation of the Gospel in foreign parts; the Trinity-House of that town having contributed 10l. towards the same pious design, and large collections having also been made for the same purpose in the different parishes of the said town
Common-council books. Mention occurs ibid. July 12th, 1742, of the inn-keepers of Newcastle, who had dragoons quartered upon them, that remained at that town on account of the late riot, as claiming of the corporation six-pence a day for each man and horse, to the amount of 213l. 10s. 6d. and which a committee of that body were appointed to settle.
In 1742, Anthony Isaac son, of senton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, August 17th, 1742, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Thomas Burnit, Esq of the Common Bench, and Samuel Urlin, Esq serjeant at law.
In 1743, Charles Lorain, of Stanton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, August 2d, 1743, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Thomas Dennison, Esq of the King's Bench, and John Birch, serjeant at law.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1743, Ralph Sowerby was mayor, and George Coll∣pitts, sheriff.

Monday, August 8th this year, one William Brown, a bold and des∣perate man, who was at the head of a great number of thieves or moss troopers, and had been convicted at the assizes at Newcastle upon Tyne,
was hanged without the west gate of that town, for returning from transportation. His execution had been hastened for fear of a rescue
Grey's MSS.
In 1743, two old men, the father and son, were subpoena'd to an assize held at New∣castle upon Tyne, as witnestes from a neighbouring village; the father was 135 years of age, and his son 95; both of them hearty, and retaining their fight and hearing. And the next year, one Adam Turnbull died in Newcastle, aged 112, who had married four wives, and the last when he was near 100 years of age.—England Displayed, London, 1769, folio, vol. ii. p. 187.
In 1744, James Carr, of Black-Heddon, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 23d, 1744, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Thomas Burnitt, Esq of the Common Bench, and Charles Clark, Esq of the Exchequer—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1744, John OrdMember of parliament for St. Michael's in Cornwall. was mayor, and Aubone Surtees, sheriff.
Mr. Ord died about July 1st, 1745, and was succeeded in his office by Matthew Ridley.

April 7th this year, war was proclaimed against France in the usual places in Newcastle, the mayor and aldermen attending, clothed in their scarlet gowns, and accompanied by their proper officersNewcastle Courant, April 14th, 1744..
August 11th this year, two men were executed at Newcastle, the one for coining, and the other for horse-stealing.
In the year 1745, Cuthbert Smith was mayor, and Henry Partis, sheriff.

January 10th this year, the coast between London and Newcastle
is mentioned as being much infested with privateers, which had been so daring as to pursue the shipping close to Tinmouth-Bar
Grey's MSS. Newcastle Courant.
In 1745, William Bacon, of Staward-Peele, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 12th, 1745, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Edward Clive, Esq of the Exchequer, and John Bird, serjeant at law.—Grey's MSS..

On the bursting out of the rebellion this year in Scotland, Newcastle upon Tyne, under the direction of a magistrate distinguished for his spirit and prudence, gave indubitable proofs of its loyalty to the house of Brunswick.

An agreement, dated September 10th this year, and signed by eight hundred and thirteen persons of Newcastle upon Tyne, by which they voluntarily obliged themselves either to appear in person, or to provide each an able man, to act in concert with his majesty's forces in that place for the defence thereof against all the King's enemies, is still preserved as the testimony of their loyalty in the archives of that townThe town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne. Whereas an actual rebellion is begun in Scotland, and the city of Edinburgh is now possessed by a popish pretender and his adherents; we whose names are hereunto sub∣scribed, being duly sensible of the many blessings we enjoy under his majesty's happy ad∣ministration, and that the continuance thereof can in no wise be expected, but by support∣ing his majesty King George on the throne of these realms, and his royal family; and as it is to be apprehended that the rebels may proceed to make an attempt upon this town, do voluntarily oblige ourselves to appear in person, or to provide daily, or when we shall be required, an able man to act in concert with his majesty's forces in this town for the defence thereof, against all his majesties enemies. Dated this 15th day of September, 1745. M. Ridley, Nath. Chiyton, Ed. Collingwood, Ralph Sowerby, Cuthbert Smith, Aubone Surtees, Geo. Cuthbertson" (and 806 others)..

On Friday, 20th of September, the militia of Newcastle mounted guard there for the first time after the breaking out of the rebellionNewcastle Courant. On Tuesday 17th preceding, a fleet passed by Tinmouth-Bar, under convoy of some men of war, having on board 3000 Dutch forces for Scot∣land.—Ibid..

On Sunday morning, September 22d, the alarming news of General
Cope's defeat by the rebels arrived at Newcastle, and threw that place into the utmost consternation. Many of the most opulent inhabitants fled immediately, and removed their most valuable effects into the country with the greatest precipitationNewcastle Courant, Saturday, September 28th, 1745.—The following notice occurs, ibid. "We have lately got several more cannon, and are assured that ten thousand troops will soon arrive here from the south, so that we hope to give a good account of the rebels, if they come to pay us a visit. Lord Mark Ker and Colonel Frazier are arrived here. On Wednesday last, part of the militia from the county of Northumberland came to town, viz. about four hundred horse, and above two hundred foot, well armed, and headed by many fine gentlemen, who are determined to defend his majesty, this government, and the religion and liberty of this kingdom, against all invaders.".

In the beginning of October
Newcastle Courant for October 12th, 1745. "Last Saturday 600 Dutch of General de la Rocque's regiment, lately arrived at Berwick, came here from thence."— "Every day this week some part of the gentlemen volunteers, who are determined to de∣fend his majesty's person, &c. and this town in particular, have been employed in learn∣ing the military exercise; the principal parts of which they are now expert in, particularly the gentlemen that compose the company with red and pink cockades."—"Last Wed∣nesday and Thursday, a great number of cannon, nine and eighteen pounders, were car∣ried from the Sand-Hill on their carriages, and placed on the proper parts of the town wall."—"Newcastle upon Tyne.—All persons whatsoever residing without the walls of the said town, that have any ladder or ladders, are desired immediately to bring the same into the town's yard behind the hospital in the Manors; and it is ordered, that no person whatsoever (except the proper gunners) shall come near the great guns within the said town after six o'clock at night. And that no person whatsoever fire a gun, or other fire arms, in or near the said town in the evening, or at night when it is dark, upon pain of imprisonment. And all persons living without the walls, but within the liberties of the said town, who have in their custody any fire-arms, are desired immediately to bring and deliver them at the mayor's house. And all persons living within the said town, who have in their custody any pick-axes or shovels, are also desired forthwith to deliver them at the same place. And notice is hereby given, that the fair, customarily held on the 18th day of October yearly, will not be held on the 18th instant, but some time after, of which publick notice will given. CUTHBERTSON."
"Newcastle, October 19th, 1745. Last Monday our volunteers and militia, also the Dutch and English soldiers, were reviewed by the Hon. General Huske; after which, they were all stationed at their proper places on the town wall (where we have about 200 cannon planted), there to answer at a minute's warning."—Ibid. this year, great exertions were made
for the defence of Newcastle upon Tyne against the rebel army; the news of which preparations having been industriously conveyed to them, is supposed to have diverted their intended course; for they took their route into England by way of the city of CarlisleNewcastle Courant.—Ibid. "A great quantity of cannon, and other warlike im∣plements, are arrived here this week, some of which are nine and eighteen pounds; several of the water-gates on the Keyside are built up with gun holes in them. The town walls are all repairing, and we expect a reinforcement of his majstry's forces every day. Last Sunday the Hon. General Huske arrived here, as is also Colonel Walsh.".

Great guns were placed on this occasion at "the Close-Gate, White-Friar-Tower, Postern-Gate, Heslop's House, Old Roper's Tower, Dobi∣son's Tower, West-Gate, Hatter's Tower, Glazier's Tower, Paviour's Tower, St. Andrew's Tower, New-Gate, Pilgrim-street-Gate, Weaver's Tower, Cutler's Tower, Roper's Tower, Pandon-Gate, Carpenter's Tower, Sand-Gate, on the wall above the Pant, Broad-Chare, Sand-Hill-Corner, Bridge-End, Mayor's and Close-Gate
Paper communicated by Mr. T. Aubone.
October 14th, 1745, the lieutenant-colonel of La Rocque's regiment being disap∣pointed of money to pay his soldiers, the Corporation of Newcastle advanced him 600l. of their money on this occasion, on his receipt for that sum, and bill for it payable at London.—Common-council books.."

October 28th, Field-marshal Wade, commander in chief of the army intended for the north, having left Doncaster on the 21st, with the British and Dutch infantry, and sent his cavalry to York some days before, arrived at Newcastle, being about 1400 strong, and resolving to wait there, not only to defend the coal-mines, which are the support of London, but also to be ready against any eventHistory of the Rebellion, by an impartial Hand, 8vo. p. 165..

November 9th
Newcastle Courant. Ibid. November 2d. On Saturday last arrived in town the follow∣ing regiments of foot, viz. Barrell's, Wolfe's, Fleming's, and Monroe's. On Monday, the Right Hon. Field-marshal Wade arrived here. On Tuesday came to town (who marched quite along, and all encamped on the Moor) Pulteney's, Cholmondley's, and Blakeney's regiments of English foot; Holstein's, Gottorp's, Parot's, and three regiments of Hizzell's, all Dutch; in all about 9000, who made a good appearance, and in high spirits.—Prince Maurice, of Nassau, who is to command the Dutch, came along with them."
On Thursday the grand train of artillery came to the Town-Moor, with a great number of baggage-waggons, ammunition, &c. escorted by Batteroy's regiment, who also en∣camped there; and yesterday night the Royal Scots, commanded by General Sinclair, came to town from the south, and soon after marched to the Town-Moor, and pitched their tents. We hear there is fifty thousand weight of biscuit ordered for the army, which consists of about 15,000 effective men in high spirits, and who, we also hear, will all decamp to-morrow, or Monday next, longing for nothing more ardently than to attack the rebels."
"Newcastle, Nov. 9th. The army still continues encamped here under the command of his Excellency Field-marshal Wade. We hear the army detaches several hundred men some miles distant from the camp, to prevent being surprized on any account.", his Excellency Field-marshal Wade appears to have been encamped on the Town-Moor at NewcastleA printed sheet lies before me—"Fortis cadere, cedere non potest"—Advice to the Gentlemen of the Army under his Excellency, &c.".
Sunday, November 10th, the remainder of General Barrell's and Brigadier Fleming's regiments arrived at the camp above-mentionedNewcastle Courant..

Tuesday, November 12th, the grand train of artillery was removed about two miles to the south of Newcastle, and the main army was expected to have marched the next day, when the train returned to them again on the Town-MoorIbid. "On Monday the 11th, James Brand, Esq lieutenant and quarter-master in Lord Kilmarnock's regiment of horse, in the rebel army, was brought a prisoner from Carlisle to Newcastle. He had been taken near Carlisle, on the 9th, in fight of the rebel army. He behaved with great resolution. He was afterwards hanged, drawn and quartered at Carlisle."—Ibid..
Thursday 14th, the camp on the Town-Moor was augmented by General St. George's dragoons, and Montague's and Marshal Wade's horseNewcastle Courant..

On Sarurday 16th, General Wade put his troops in motion for the relief of Carlisle, but was too late to prevent its falling into the hands of the enemyHistory of the Rebellion, p. 174. Having at Hexham learnt the fate of Carlisle, he resolved to return..

On Wednesday 20th, Marshal Wade, and General Montague's
horse, with General St. George's dragoons, returned to Newcastle from the army under General WadeNewcastle Courant, November 23d., and on the 21st and 22d they marched for DurhamIbid..

Friday 22d, General Wade, with the infantry, British and Dutch, re∣turned to Newcastle upon Tyne, in which place, and the neighbouring villages, they were quarteredIbid. and History of the Rebellion. "The magistrates and town's people received them with a tenderness adapted to the circumstances wherein they were. The malt-houses, publick halls, and other empty buildings, were warmed and sitted up; while such as appeared most shattered, were quartered in private houses, and kindly entertained at the proprietor's charge..
On Tuesday 26th, Marshal Wade marched with his army from Newcastle upon Tyne for the south, in pursuit of the rebelsNewcastle Courant, November 30th..

December 18th this year, General Huske, with about 1100 men from Marshal Wade's army, arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant for December 21st, 1745. Adding, that, on the 20th of that month, General Wade himself, with his aids de camp, &c. arrived; as did the same after∣noon the train of artillery, belonging to the general's army, at Gateshead.
An order of the common-council of Newcastle, dated December 19th this year, assigned 350l. extraordinary to the then mayor, for entertaining General Wade and his retinue for three months past.—Common-council books..

December 22d, the regiment of Scots Royal, General Wolfe's, Colonel Battereau's, and Brigadier Fleming's, arrived at Newcastle, and on the day following, the Old Buffs, commanded by General Handasyd, and Fleming's.—And on the 24th, Barrell's, Pulteney's, Blakeney's, and Cholmondeley's regimentsNewcastle Courant, December 28th..
On Christmas-day several hundred horses were pressed at Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

Early on Thursday morning the 26th, several captains of ships be∣longing to the port of Tyne, and others well skilled in gunnery, set out
from Newcastle, with those of the train of artillery of Marshal Wade's army, for the city of CarlisleNewcastle Courant, December 28th..

The same day there marched from Newcastle for Scotland, the Scots Royal, and Cholmondeley's regiments.—They were followed on the 27th by Wolfe's and Battereau's; and on the 28th, by Howard's and Fleming's regiments.
Barrell's and Pulteney's regiments, with several additional companies, remained at Newcastle upon TyneIbid..

On Tuesday night, December 31st, on the arrival of the news that Carlisle had surrendered to the Duke of Cumberland, there were great rejoicings at Newcastle
Newcastle Courant, January 4th, 1746. "Our bells were ordered to ring, which continued all night and next morning; so that we concluded the old and began the new year with pleasant and chearful countenances; and church was observed to be thronger on Wednesday morning than is usual on a New-Year's day."
In 1746, Lancelot Allgood, of Hexham, Esq (afterwards of Nunwich, and knighted), was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 4th, 1746, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Thomas Parker, chief baron, and Thomas Burnitt, of the Common Bench. They went away Monday, August 11th, to meet Judge Dennison, and another judge, to open a special commission for trying the rebels at Carlisle..
In the year 1746, Nicholas Fenwick was mayor, and Henry Eden, sheriff.

On Tuesday morning, January 28th
Newcastle Courant.
Ibid. On the 15th, there had been a great press for horses at Newcastle. On the 26th of January, the Duke of Rutland's regiment arrived at that town: on the 21st, the Duke of Bedford's; and on the 23d, the Duke of Montague's horse. January 26th, six∣teen pieces of brass cannon with stores, forty gunners and matrosses, that had been sent by order of the King for the army, arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne.—History of the Rebellion, impartial, p. 281. this year, about one o'clock, his Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland arrived at Newcastle on his way to Scotland, to check the progress of the Pretender and the rebel army. He was welcomed at Gateshead by a kind of illumina∣tion,
which gave his Royal Highness great uneasiness to see, the mob having set a popish chapel on fire at that place on the occasion: the Prince, after some hours refreshment, set out again about seven the same morning, and arrived at Edinburgh on the 30th of that month
Newcastle Courant, February 1st. Great preparations had been made there for his reception. There were very great illummations and other rejoicings. That morning early some disorderly persons broke and entered into a house called The Nuns, in New∣castle (where was another popish chapel), and took away and destroyed several goods, &c. belonging to it. The Corporation liberally offered 50l. reward for the discovery of the offenders.—Ibid.
