January 30th, the remainder of St. George's dragoons marched from Newcastle for Edinburgh, to join the army. January 31st, there arrived at Newcastle on their way to Edinburgh, two troops of Mark Kerr's dragoons.—Ibid..
February 4th, the common-council of Newcastle voted the personal freedom of that town to his Royal Highness William, Duke of CumberlandCommon-council books..

April 21st, there were the greatest rejoicings ever known at New∣castle, on the arrival of the news of the great and decisive victory at Culloden, on the 16th of that mouth
Newcastle Courant. April 26th, 1746. "Last Monday afternoon, and till next morning, we had the greatest rejoicings of all sorts in this town, known in the memory of man, on receiving the great and good news of his Royal Highness the Duke of Cumber∣land's obtaining a compleat victory over the rebels the 16th instant, near Inverness."— "On hearing the agreeable news of his Royal Highness William Duke of Cumberland's having defeated the rebels, the young gentlemen of the Head-School in this town ex∣pressed an uncommon joy on such an happy issue; who, at their own expence, and with the greatest freedom and alacrity, ordered the school to be illuminated, tar-barrels to be burnt, and, in short, such a spirit appeared amongst them as made the inhabitants much admire."
Newcastle, May 31st, 1746. Last Monday afternonn arrived here his Serene High∣ness the Prince of Hesse, from Scotland, where he received the compliments of the mayor, recorder, aldermen, and sheriff, with repeated peals of bells. His highness set out for London early on Tuesday morning.—Ibid..

July 23d, about one o'clock in the morning, his Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland arrived
Newcastle, July 26th, 176. "About one o'clock last Wednesday morning ar∣rived here his Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland from Scotland: his Royal High∣ness was attended hither by Lancelot Allgood, Esq high sheriff for the county, and Sir William Middleton, Baronet, in a coach and six, and was welcomed to town by Cuth∣bert Smith, Esq mayor, William Cuthbert, Esq recorder, and several other persons of distinction at the New Gate, after a polite and genteel manner. His Royal Highness was im∣mediately presented with the freedom of the town in a gold box by the mayor: and was also presented with the freedom of the company of masters, mariners, &c. of the Trinity-House, by Francis Heath, Esq master, in another gold box, both of curious workman∣ship, both which his Royal Highness accepted very graciously. The expedition of his Royal Highness' journey to London not permitting him to stay long at one place, he set out about three o'clock the same morning with a great deal of company: we had great illuminations, bonfires, and other rejoicings on the occasion, and mock-pretenders were burnt in different places."—Newcastle Courant., on his happy return from Scotland, at
Newcastle, where he was immediately presented with the freedom of that corporation, as a token of their high esteem for his many princely virtues, and the grateful sense they entertained of his dis∣tinguished services in defence of the laws and liberties of Great Britain.

The Trinity-House of that town complimented his Royal Highness with the freedom of that fraternityThe tickets of grants of the said freedoms were severally written upon fine vellum, and inclosed in two curious and large gold boxes.; and both the townNewcastle Courant, May 24th, 1746. Thompson's Newcastle paper, May 31st, 1746. and Trinity-HouseNewcastle Courant, May 24th, 1746. Thompson's Newcastle paper, May 31st, 1746. addressed the King on the above-mentioned ever memorable victory.

October 3d this year, the Bishop of Gloucester, for the Bishop of Durham, held a confirmation at St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant, October 4th, 1746.
In 1747, William Ord, of Fenham, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 17th, 1747, the assizes began at Newcastle, before John Birch, of the Common Bench, and Sir Heneage Legge, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1747, Nicholas Fenwick continued mayor, and William Watson was sheriff.
February 6th this year, peace was proclaimed, with the usual solem∣nities, in the two public markets at NewcastleNewcastle Courant..

April 25th this year, on the day appointed for a general thanksgiving for the peace of Aix la Chapelle, there were great rejoicings at New∣castle
Ibid.
In 1748, Nicholas Brown, of Bolton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 6th, 1748, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Edward Clive, of the Exchequer, and Sir Heneage Legge.—Grey's MSS.
In 1749, Gawen Aynsley, junior, of Little-Harle, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 27th, 1749, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Thomas Abney, of the Common Bench, and Thomas Dentn, Esq of the King's Bench.—Grey's MSS.
The following note is taken from Gyll's interleaved copy of Bourne's History of New∣castle, under the year 1749. "Francis Armori, of Newcastle, a coal ater, has now living three brothers and one sister; all whole ages put together amount to 3 years, or thereabouts, and are healthy persons."
In 175, William Car, of tall, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 13th, 1750, the assizes bean at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Ed∣ward live, Esq of the Exchequer, and Sydney Stafford Smyth, Esq of the same.— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1748, Walter Blackett was mayor, and John Vonholte, sheriff.
In the year 1749, Robert Sorsbie was mayor, and Robert Herron, sheriff.
In the year 1750, Ralph Sowerby was mayor, and William Clayton, sheriff.
Dr. Edward Chandler, Bishop of Durham, died, and was succeeded by Dr. John Butler from Bristol.

April 27th this year, several unknown persons assembled in the fields near Newcastle, and from a stile proclaimed Prince Charles King of England, France, and Ireland, &c. The corporation of that town offered next day a reward of 100l. for the discovery of the offendersNewcastle Courant, May 5th, 1750..

In the night between the 24th and 25th of July this year, about
eleven o'clock, a fire broke out in the east end of a street called the Close in Newcastle upon Tyne, near the end of the bridge, which burnt down some houses and ware-houses between the street and the river
Gyll's interleaved Bourne's History, p. 127.
In 1751, William Bigge, of Little-Benton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 5th, 1751, the assizes began at Newcastle, before John Birch, of the Common Bench, and Heneage Legge, of the Exchequer.. A charitable collection was made for the poor sufferers on this occasion, which amounted to 806l.
In the year 1751, Matthew Ridley was mayor, and Matthew Scarfe, sheriff.

July 17th this year, the Bishop of Durham held his primary visita∣tion at Newcastle
Newcastle Courant, July 20th, 1751.
In 1752, William Fenwick, of Bywell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 27th, 1752, the assizes began at Newcastle, before John Birch, of the Common Bench, and Heneage Legge, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
At the assizes this year, Richard Brown, keelman, was condemned and executed for the murder of his own daughter.
In the year 1752, Henry Partis was mayor, and Francis Rudston, sheriff.
At the assizes this year, a soldier was condemned for murder, and hanged on the 28th of September following.

September 27th this year, an order of the common-council of New∣castle was made on the alteration of the stile, by an act of the 24 George II. that at the next quarterly payment at Christmas, eleven days should be deducted out of the salaries of all persons employed un∣der them, who had 10l. per annum or upwards; as also out of the several annuities, in order to make the same in all succeeding years payable on the nominal quarterly days directed by the new calendar
Common-council books.
In 1753, Robert Fenwick, of Lemington, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Tuesday, August 21st, 1753, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Heneage Legge, of the Exchequer, and — Eyre, serjeant at law.—Grey's MSS..
Dr. Butler, Bishop of Durham, died this year, and was succeeded by Dr. Richard Trevor, Bishop of St. David's.
In the year 1753, Henry Eden was mayor, and John Harrison, sheriff.

May 25th this year, Hugh, Earl of Northumberland, Baron Wark∣worth, of Warkworth-Castle, lord lieutenant of the county of Northum∣berland, and of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, was ad∣mitted to a personal freedom of that corporation
Common-council books. His lordship was constituted lord lieutenant of Northum∣berland and Newcastle; as also vice-admiral of Northumberland and Newcastle upon Tyne in March 1753, on the death of Lord Tankerville.—Collins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 484, says March 20th.
In 1754, Robert Shaftoe, of Benwell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 12th, 1754, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Heneage Legge, of the Exchequer, and Sydney Stafford Smyth, of the same.—Grey's MSS..

At the assizes this year at Newcastle, Dorothy Catenby was con∣demned and executed for the murder of her bastard child. Three per∣sons were tried also for a rape and condemned, but afterwards par∣doned.
In the year 1754, Cuthbert Smith was mayor, and William Rowell, sheriff.

July 17th this year, the Bishop of Durham held his primary visita∣tion at Newcastle, and confirmed near 2400 persons
Newcastle Courant.
In 1755, John Swinburn, of Westgate in Newcastle, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
Tuesday, July 29th, 1755, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Richard Adams, of the Exchequer, and Henry Bathurst.—Grey's MSS.
In 1756, Matthew White, of Blagdon, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Wednesday, August 25th, 1756, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, of the Common Bench, and Sir John Eardley Wilmot, of the King's Bch— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1755, William Clayton was mayor, and William Har∣bottle, sheriff.
In the year 1756, Sir Waiter Blackett, Baronet, was mayor, and John Erasmus Blackett, sheriff.

His Grace Thomas Pelham, Duke of Newcastle upon Tyne, having been by patent, dated November 13th, 1756, created Duke of New∣castle under Lyne, with remainder, on default of his issue male, to Henry Earl of Lincoln, and his heirs male by Catharine, his then wife; was at his death, November 17th, 1768, succeeded in the said title of Duke of Newcastle under Lyne in com. Stafford, by the said Henry Earl of LincolnCollins' Peerage, vol. ii. p. 278, ed. 1779..

April 6th this year, the corporation of Newcastle addressed the KingCommon-council books. on the impending war with France; as on the 9th following, did the Trinity-House of that townTrinity-House books..

May 22d this year, war was proclaimed against France at New∣castle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant, May 22d. The same day the high sheriff of Northumberland declared war as above without the west gate of Newcastle, which is in the liberties of the county of Northumberland.
In 1757, Edward Blackett, of West-Matsen, Baronet, was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
Monday, August 8th, 1757, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, of the Common Bench, and William Noel, of the same—Grey's MSS..

The mayor and aldermen in their scarlet gowns, attended by their proper officers, were present on this occasion. Soon afterwards the coast about Newcastle, &c. was much infested with privateers, and several trading ships were taken.

At the assizes this year, Richard Curtise was condemned for the mur∣der of one of the serjeants of Newcastle, who came to arrest Charles Cowling by an escape warrant; but he was reprieved, because the war∣rant was void. He was afterwards pardoned—See Forster's Reports, folio, Oxford, 1762, p. 135.
In the year 1757, Matthew Bell was mayor, and John Scurfield, sheriff.

February 5th this year, on account of the rigorous season, a collec∣tion was made for the poor of NewcastleNewcastle Courant. The whole amounted to upwards of 900l. of which the cor∣poration gave 200l. and Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, 100l..

Some time before June 16th this year, the Right Honourable Wil∣liam Pitt, and the Right Honourable Henry Bilson Legge, Esq were presented with the freedom of the corporation of NewcastleCommon-council books..

October 8th this year, mention occurs of an intended military associ∣ation of gentlemen at Newcastle upon Tyne
Newcastle Courant. February, 1758, the association was signed, a uniform fixed upon, &c.
In 1758, William Wilkinson, of Clennel, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 24th, 1758, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Lord Chief Justice Mansfield, and Sydney Stafford Smyth, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1758, Ralph Sowerby was mayor, and Edward Moseley, sheriff.

In April this year, a register-office, upon the same principles with the offices of Sir John Fielding in London, was opened by Edward Humble and Co. in Newcastle upon Tyne. This useful institution did not meet with the success it deserved, and was soon set aside
"A Plan of the original Register or Intelligence-office, Newcastle upon Tyne, opened at the head of the Side, &c. Newcastle, printed for the proprietors," 8vo. 12 pages, lies before me.
In 1759, Abraham Dixon, of Belford-Hall, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 13th, 1759, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, and William Noel, of the Common Bench.—Grey's MSS..
At the assizes this year at Newcastle, Ann Williamson was con∣demned for burglary, and executed August 6th following.
In the year 1759, Matthew Ridley was mayor, and Matthew Ste∣phenson, sheriff.

August 28th this year, on the opening of a publick subscription to encourage recruits to enlist in the 36th regiment of foot, or in Craw∣ford's
Royal Volunteers, by an additional bounty of two guineas a man, the corporation of Newcastle contributed the sum of 315l.
Common-council books. Ibid. April 24th this year, the corporation of Newcastle gave 20l. towards the erection of a publick stable near the church of Long-Benton, in the county of Northumberland.
September 29th this year, mention occurs of Mr. Cuthbert Lambert, son of a physician of Newcastle, who had a most narrow and providential escape, in surviving a fall of thirty-six feet perpendicular; his mare having taken fright with him, and leapt over the eastern bat∣tlement of the bridge at Sandy-Ford-Stone: "Lambert's Leap" is cut upon the coping-stone of the battlement.—Newcastle Courant.
A print of this was engraved by Pollard, and published in London.
November 2d this year, the corporation of Newcastle addressed the King on the suc∣cess of his arms, by the conquest of Quebeck, &c.—Newcastle Courant, November 10th, 1759.
In 1760, Robert Bewick, of Close-House, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 4th, 1760, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, of the Common Bench, and Sir Richard Lloyd, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS.
In the year 1760, Henry Partis was mayor, and John Baker, sheriff.

November 1st this year, the mayor and magistrates of Newcastle, with the usual solemnities, proclaimed his present majesty King George the Third
Newcastle Courant, November 8th. Ibid. June 7th. Account of the opening of a publick garden, with a concert of musick, and other entertainments for the season, near Newcastle upon Tyne. It was called New Ranelagh-Gardens.
In 1761, Alexander Collingwood, of Unthank, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 28th, 1761, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, of the Common Bench, and Sir Richard Lloyd, of the Exchequer. They went away July 31st, but returned in August to try the rioters.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1761, Aubone Surtees was mayor, and Fletcher Partis, sheriff.

At the assizes this year at Newcastle, the rioters in Northumberland, who had opposed the justices of peace in the execution of the militia act, were tried for high treason, and Peter Paterson and William Elder were convicted, and the former was executed at Morpeth on the 5th of October following.

September 22d this year, the coronation of King George the III. and Queen Charlotte, was solemnized at Newcastle upon Tyne, with every demonstration of publick festivity
Newcastle Courant. A fountain ran with wine on the Sand-Hill, &c.
June 20th this year, Ralph Bigland, Esq then Somerset herald, and at Newcastle, pub∣lished in the Courant there, an address to the nobility and gentry of the northern coun∣ties concerning coats of arms.
In 1762, Ralph Bates, of Halliwell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 7th, 1762, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst, Esq of the Common Bench, and Sir Henry Gould, of the Exchequer.—Grey's MSS..
In the year 1762, Cuthbert Smith was mayor, and Hugh Hornby, sheriff.
January 9th this year, the mayor and magistrates of Newcastle pub∣lished at the usual places in that town, his majesty's declaration of war against SpainNewcastle Courant, January 16th, 1762..
August 18th this year, the Bishop of Durham confirmed upwards of 1400 persons at St. Nicholas' church in NewcastleIbid. August 21st, 1762..

October 11th this year, the corporation of Newcastle addressed his majesty on the reduction of the Havannah
Ibid. September 27th this year, the corporation of Newcastle gave 30l. to the sufferers by a sire at Wareham. December 20th following, twenty guineas towards carrying on the colleges of Philadelphia and New York.
In 1763, John William Forster Bacon, of Etherston, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
Monday, August 1st, 1763, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Sir Henry Gould, of the Common Bench, and George Parrot, Esq of the Exchequer.— Grey's MSS..
In the year 1763, William Clayton was mayor, and Francis Forster, sheriff.
April 11th this year, the mayor, recorder, aldermen, sheriff, and common-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, addressed the King on the peaceNewcastle Courant..

July 9th this year, mention occurs of a design in agitation to estab∣lish an hospital in Newcastle for the reception of penitent prostitutes
Newcastle Courant.
In 1764, Christopher Soulsby Reed, of Chipchace, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Henry Bathurst and Sir Joseph Yates were on the northern circuit, 1764.—Grey's MSS..
August 27th this year, George Stewart was hanged on the Town-Moor for killing one Lindsey, a keelman; and September 2d, James Edgar at the West-Gate, for a burglary.
In the year 1764, Sir Walter Blackett, Bart. was mayor, and Tho∣mas Blackett, sheriff.

Sunday, April 1st this year, divine service did not begin at New∣castle till near twelve o'clock, on account of a great eclipse of the sun, which commenced at fourteen minutes past nine in the morning, and ended three minutes fifty seconds past twelve: the air was remarkably cold about the time of the greatest obscurationNewcastle Courant, April 7th, and March 31st..

July 2d this year, his Grace the Archbishop of York was at New∣castle, and dined with the mayor
Ibid.—This year "as the mayor and magistrates were coming out of the election-house, a person, as usual, fired some patteraroes, the wadding of one of which unfortunately wounded Mr. Alderman Eden in the groin, but he is now in a fair way of recovery."— Ibid. October 6th, 1764.
In 1765, Matthew Forster, of Bolton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 5th, 1765, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould and Sir Joseph Yates..
In the year 1765, John Erasmus Blackett was mayor, and Charles Atkinson, sheriff.

February 15th this year, a petition was signed and sent to parliament, by the master and brethren of the Trinity-House of Newcastle, against the introduction of any other method of disposing of ballast, than by laying it on land which is not covered by the tide
Trinity-house books.
In 1766, Henry Collingwood, of Cornhill, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, July 26th, 1766, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Henry Bathurst and George Parrot, Esq—Jean Gray stood in the pillory on the Sandhill, August 2d, for per∣jury..
In the year 1766, Matthew Scaife was mayor, and John Hedley, sheriff.
This year Hugh, Earl of Northumberland, was created Duke of Northumberland.

February 15th this year, Mr. Hillcoat, ironmonger, in Newcastle upon Tyne, is mentioned as just having obtained his majesty's patent for the invention of an easy method to disengage horses instantly from a carriage, and prevent accidents, which are frequently occasioned by their taking frightNewcastle Courant..

August 5th this year, the Bishop of Durham held a confirmation at St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle
Ibid.
In 1767, Hylton Lawson, of Cramlington, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 17th, 1767, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould and George Parrot, Esq.
In the year 1767, Edward Mosley was mayor, and Richard Lacy, sheriff.

January 9th this year, the corporation of Newcastle gave fifty guineas to a committee appointed to collect and distribute contributions set on foot for the relief of poor house-keepers of that town, on account of the severity of the season
Common-council books.
In 1768, Bryan Burrell of Broome Park, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Sir Henry Gould and Sir Joseph Yates were down on the northern circuit in 1768..
In the year 1768, John Baker was mayor, and William Coulson, sheriff.

October 6th this year, the celebrated astronomer James Ferguson, F. R. S. began a course of lectures at Newcastle, on natural and ex∣perimental philosophy
Newcastle Courant, October 8th, 1768.
In 1769, Michael Pearson, of West-Matfen, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, July 24th, 1769, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould, Knight, and George Parrot, Esq.
In the year 1769, Francis Forster was mayor, and William Reed, sheriff.
January 7th this year, the Trinity-House of Newcastle petitioned the lords of the admiralty against the canal intended to be made from Coventry to the city of OxfordTrinity-house books..

August 28th this year, between two and three o'clock in the morn∣ing, a comet was discovered at Newcastle, in the constellation Taurus; that evening it was about ten degrees north latitude, six degrees from Aldebaran, and about thirteen from the PleiadesNewcastle Courant, September 2d, 1769..
In the year 1770, Aubone Surtees was mayor, and James Liddell, sheriff.

January 5th this year, Sir Francis Blake Delaval, Knight of the Bath, accompanied by Thomas Delaval, Esq presented to the King at St. James's, a petition of some of the free burgesses of Newcastle upon Tyne, "on a late unprecedented seating of a candidate in the House of Commons, who was not chosen by the peopleNewcastle Courant, January, 13th. It appears by the common-council books, Ja∣nuary 15th this year, that the corporation of Newcastle gave fifty guineas to the sufferers by fire at St. John's, in the island of Antiqua.."

May 16th following, an humble address, remonstrance and petition of the said free burgesses, was presented to his majesty at St. James's, by Sir Francis Blake Delaval, Knight of the Bath
Newcastle Cournat.
In 1770, John Simpson, of Long Horseley, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Monday, August 20th, 1770, the assizes began at Newcastle, before the Hon. George Parrot, Esq of the Exchequer, and Sir Richard Aston, Knight, of the King's Bench..
July 24th this year, the Bishop of Durham, assisted by the Bishop of Sodor and Man, confirmed upwards of 1200 persons in St. Nicho∣las' church in NewcastleNewcastle Courant..

September 18th this year, Robert Hazlet was executed at Durham, for robbing the mail, and was afterwards hung in chains in a dreary
spot, opposite to the Lough, on Gateshead-Fell, near Newcastle, where many robberies had been committed
Newcastle Courant.
December 31st, 1770, died at his house in Gateshead, Mr. William Sedgewick, a gen∣tleman well known in the chemical world, for his many valuable inventions, and particu∣larly for that of dissolving the stone in the bladder, which it is feared has died with him.— Newcastle Courant.
In 1771, Thomas Charles Bigge, of Little Benton, Esq was sheriff of Northum∣berland.
Saturday, July 27th, 1771, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould, Knight, and the Hon. Edward Willes, Esq.
In the year 1771, Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, was mayor, and Christopher Wilkinson, sheriff.
Dr. Richard Trevor, Bishop of Durham, died in June this year, and was succeeded by Dr. John Egerton, translated from Litchfield and Coventry.
August 21st this year, his Royal Highness the Duke of Cumberland arrived at Newcastle, on his way to Seaton-Delaval, in the county of NorthumberlandNewcastle Courant, August 24th, 1771..

August 24th, the common-council of Newcastle made an order, that the Duke of Cumberland should be requested to accept a personal freedom of that town, to be presented to him by the mayor in a gold boxCommon-council books..

August 30th following, his Royal Highness partook of a most sump∣tuous entertainment, provided for himHis Royal Highness was accompanied in this occasion by his Grace the Duke of Northumberland, Earl Percy, Lord Algernon Percy, Sir Edward Blackett, and Sir John Hussey Delaval, Baronets. He was saluted at his entrance into the town by twenty-one pieces of cannon.—There was a grand assembly in the evening.—His Royal Highness pre∣sented the prisoners in Newgate with ten guineas.—Newcastle Courant. at the mansion-house in New∣castle
Newcastle Courant, August 31st, and September 7th, 1771.
Thursday, February 28th, 1771, died in the 78th year of his age, at Hinton in Nor∣thamptonshire, the learned, ingenious, and Rev. Richard Grey, D. D. one of his ma∣jesty's justices of the peace for that county, archdeacon of Bedford, commissary of Lei∣cester, prebendary of St. Paul's rector of Hinton and of Kimcoat, in Leicestershire, chap∣lain to the late Lord Crew, Bishop of Durham, by whom he was presented to the living of Hinton, A. D. 1718.—Newcastle Courant, March 9th, 1771.
Dr. Grey was born at Newcastle upon Tyne—the son of a Mr. Grey, barber; his mother's name was Lambert, the sister of Fenwick Lambert, who kept and inn in that town. He had one sister, who married Thomas Burdus, Esq counsellor at law, and another who married Mr. John White, an eminent printer at Newcastle.—See Nicholas's Anecdotes of Bowyer, p. 210. Note..

There lies before me a medal of gold, most elegantly executed, weighing about four ounces; on one side, the head of George III. in∣scribed: "Georgius 3. D. G. Mag. Brit. Fr. & Hib. Rex. T. Pingo, f." Reverse, Minerva directing a youth to the Temple of Fame. "Haud facilem esse viam volvit." Underneath, "R. Ac. instituted 1768." En∣graved on the edge: "To Mr. William Bell, for the best historical pic∣ture, 1771Mr. Bell is a native of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the son of an ingenious book-bind∣er of that town—he was patronized by Sir John, now Lord Delaval, in whose possession the picture that gained the said medal is at present. He studied in the royal academy, where he made great proficiency, and became particularly remarkable for the fineness of his draperies.."

In the night between Saturday the 16th and Sunday 17th of No∣vember this year, the river Tyne, swoln to an amazing height by a land flood, which had been occasioned by an unremitted fall of heavy rains in the west, swept away the bridge at Newcastle upon Tyne, with the loss of many lives, and immense damages of the inhabitants of that place, and its vicinity
About eleven o'clock it began, and continued to rise till about seven o'clock next morning, when it was about seven feet four inches above the common flow of a good spring tide, in Bewick's entry, in the street called the Close. It continued at a stand between seven and eight o'clock next morning, and then gradually decreased. About two o'clock that morning, several ships and keels were driven from their moorings, and a very great quantity of tar, timber, deals, &c. was swept off the key, upon which also four ships were left stranded, when the flood subsided. About an hour afterwards, the arches of Tyne bridge began to fill up, and between three and four o'clock, part of it to∣wards Gateshead fell in, and seven of the inhabitants were drowned. The stoppage of water at the bridge occasioned a violent current in the Close and Sandhill, to the north corner of which a boat was rowed. About five o'clock, the north arch adjoining to the toll shop on the bridge fell in: providentially the wind blew from the north-east; had it blown from the west, it might have occasioned a greater rapidity, and been attended with still more fatal consequences. The water fell between eight and nine o'clock five inches; from nine to ten, sixteen inches; from ten to eleven, twenty-five inches; from eleven to twelve, thirty-two inches; from twelve to one, it fell four feet; from one to two, five feet four inches; and was off the key at four o'clock that afternoon, when it had subsided in all about eight feet.—Paper communicated by Mr. Thomas Aubone.
The utility of Jarrow Slake appeared in this disaster, as it took in so immense a body of water, that at Shields the flood was no higher than a spring tide: great damage, how∣ever, was done in that place to the shipping. A vessel took up at sea near that place, a wooden cradle, with a child in it, which was alive and well. Friday morning, Novem∣ber 29th, 1771, two more of the houses on the west side of the south end of Tyne bridge fell down, as did also next morning the remaining part of the south end of the bridge. The week following, the workmen began to remove the ruins of the bridge, and take down the houses on the north end thereof, in order to erect a temporary one with all possible ex∣pedition. November 27th, 1771, the corporation of Newcastle advertised, that a com∣modious and safe ferry for conveying carriages, horses, &c. across the river Tyne, was completed, to attend every day, from six in the morning to eight o'clock at night, and for∣ward dispatches from the post-office at any hour.—Newcastle Courant..

The charity of this opulent town and neighbourhood evinced itself in a remarkable manner on this melancholy occasion, and very large sums of money were collected with an haste, almost equal to the rapi∣dity of the inundation, to alleviate the distresses of the poor sufferers
The corporation of Newcastle gave 250l. Lord Ravensworth, 100l. and Henry Ellison, of Park-home, Esq 50l. to their relief.—Newcastle Cournt, November 30th, 1771.
In 1772, Francis Blake, senior, of Crawley, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 15th, 1772, Christopher Wilkinson, Esq sheriff of Newcastle, in the mayor's barge, attended by several gentlemen in the river jury barge, went and re∣ceived Sir Henry Gould, and the Hon. Edward Willes, Esq the judges, on the south shore, and landed them on the key opposite the Exchange, which they walked through, and were received at the foot of the Court Stairs by Sir Walter Blackett, mayor, &c. and were pre∣ceded as usual by the regalia into court, where they opened their commission.—Newcastle Courant..
In the year 1772, John Erasmus Blackett was mayor, and James Rudman, sheriff.

September 6th this year, Henry Lord Borthwick, premier baron of Scotland, died suddenly at an inn in Newcastle, on his way to Lon∣don,
and was privately interred in St. Nicholas' church in that townNewcastle Courant, September 12th, 1772.—Created A. D. 1424. His lordship succeeded to the title in 1734 and in 1769 married Miss Drummond, by whom having no issue, the title is extinct..
Thursday, October 1st this year, the boundaries of Newcastle were perambulated by the mayor and burgesses of that town and countyIbid..

November 23d this year, the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and com∣mon-council of Newcastle upon Tyne, petitioned the House of Com∣mons on the scarcity and dearness of all sorts of grain, occasioned chiefly by a general failure of the last harvest
Common-council books.
In 1773, William Lowers, of Ridley Hall, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 7th, 1773, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould, Knight, and Sir William Blackstone, Knight..

In the year 1773, Matthew ScaifeMr. Scaife died on Sunday, and on the Monday morning after, the regalia were sur∣rendered to Mathew Ridley, Esq as senior alderman, who held the guild that day, and the session on Wednesday, agreeable to the charter: a new mayor was elected on Thursday, when also Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, was chosen alderman in Mr. Scaife's stead. —Newcastle Courant. was mayor, till on his death, January 16th, 1774, he was succeeded by Edward Mosley: and Wil∣liam Yeilder was sheriff.

May 29th this year, Charles Hutton, a celebrated self-taught mathe∣matician of Newcastle, was appointed, by the Board of Ordnance, pro∣fessor of mathematics in the Royal Military Academy at Woolwich, near London
Newcastle Courant.
In 1774, William Lorrain, of Kirk-Harle, Baronet, was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, July 30th, 1774, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir William Black∣stone, Knight, and Sir Henry Gould, Knight..
In the year 1774, Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, was mayor, and Francis Johnson, sheriff.

July 18th this year, the Bishop of Durham held his primary visita∣tion
at Newcastle, and on the 21st confirmed upwards of 1800 per∣sons at St. Nicholas' church in that townNewcastle Courant..

November 19th this year, was held the first meeting of the associa∣tion of school-masters in the north of England, at Newcastle upon Tyne: the object of the society in this institution, was the relief of their dis∣tressed and aged brethren, and their widows and orphans
See a pamphlt intitled, "An Address to the Publick in behalf of the Association among Protestant Schoolmasters, &c. Newcastle, printed by T. Saint, 1774," 8vo. 47 pages.
In 1775, Walter Trevilian, of Netherwitton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 12th, 1775, the assizes began at Newcastle upon Tyne, before Sir Henry Gould, Knight, and Sir William Henry Ashurst, Knight..
In the year 1775, Charles Atkinson was mayor, and William Cram∣lington, sheriff.

November 8th this year, an humble petition and memorial of many of the free burgesses, traders, and inhabitants of Newcastle upon Tyne, against the prosecution of the American war, was presented by Sir George Saville, Baronet, to his MajestyNewcastle Courant, November 18th, 1775..

December 2d this year, there was an address to the King, signed by the recorder, eight aldermen, the sheriff, fourteen of the common-council, and many other merchants, gentlemen, traders, and inhabi∣tants of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, lamenting the defection and revolt of many of his subjects in America, and assuring him of their abhorrence and detestation of so unjustisiable a spirit of re∣sistance
Ibid. December 2d.
December 20th this year, the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne subscribed 50l. "for such occasional acts of benevolence as should be useful to the soldiers employed in his majesty's service in America."—Common-coucil books.
Saturday, August 3d, 1776, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould, and Sir William Henry Ashurst, Knights.
In 1776, John Askew, of Palinsburn, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1776, John Baker was mayor, and James Thomas Lor∣raine, sheriff.
August 21st, Robert Knowles was executed upon the Town-Moor in Newcastle upon Tyne, for stealing a letter out of the post-office in that town.

September 23d this year, the foundation stone of a new hall, for the society of free-masons of St. John's lodge, in Newcastle upon Tyne, was laid in the street called Low-Friar-Chare in that town
"The ancient and honourable society of free and accepted masons of St. John's lodge, in this town, are now building a new hall in the Low-Fryar-Chare: and on Monday last, Mr. Francis Peacock, their present worshipful master, laid the foundation stone, under∣neath which was placed a copper-plate, with the following inscription: "Edificii hujus, In mutuam amicitiam stabiliendam Pro summi naturae Numinis Architecti Regnatoris veneratione Morum, scientiae, artiumque bonarum Ingenuo cultu Humani generis beneficio Solatium tempestivum praebendo, Conventui fraterno sacri Franciscus Peacock praefect' honorand' Fundamenta posuit In calend. Octobris Anno salutis hamanae 1776, anno consort' 5776."—Newcastle Courant.
In the year 1777, John Hedley was mayor, and Robert Clayton, sheriff.

February 14th this year, Sir Walter Blackett, Baronet, died in London
He was the son of Sir Walter Calverley, Bart. of Calverley, in Yorkshire—August 27th, 1729, he married Miss Blackett, daughter of Sir William Blackett, Bart. There was a private act, 7 George II. to enable Walter Calverley, Esq now called Walter Black∣ett, Esq and his issue male, to take and use the surname of Blackett only, pursuant to the will of Sir William Blackett, Bart. deceased. This Sir William Blackett died September 25th, 1728.
July 7th, 1735, the lady of Walter Blackett, Esq was delivered of a daughter, who died young.
September 27th, 1759, the remains of Lady Blackett were interred in St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle, with great funeral pomp. Sir Walter Blackett, Bart. died without issue, and the title became extinct; his name is however immortal in the annals of charity and humanity..

October 16th, the elegant new hall for the society of free-masons of St. John's lodge, in Newcastle upon Tyne, was dedicated with the usual solemnities by deputation from the grand lodge in London
Newcastle Courant, October, 18th, 1777.
Saturday, July 26th, 1777, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir Henry Gould, and Sir George Nares, Knights.
In 1777, William Ord, of Fenham, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 15th, 1778, the assizes began at Newcastle, before the Hon. Edward Willes, and Sir Beaumont Hotham, Knights..
In the year 1778, Hugh Hornby was mayor, and James Wilkinson, sheriff.

February 20th this year, the common-council of Newcastle ordered an additional bounty of two guineas, to be given to every able sea∣man that should enter on board his Majesty's ship the Content, com∣manded by Captain Prescott, for the protection of the trade of that port, to be continued till the 30th of April followingCommon-council books..

May 16th this year, a subscription for the defence of Newcastle upon Tyne, its port and neighbourhood, occurs to the amount of 1784l. 15s. to which sum the corporation of that town contributed 1000lNewcastle Courant..
May 25th this year, Lord Percy arrived at Newcastle upon Tyne, to take the command of the King's forces in the north of EnglandIbid. for May 30th, 1778..

July 22d this year, the Bishop of Durham confirmed 1800 persons; at St. Nicholas' church in Newcastle upon Tyne
Ibid. There dined at the mansion-house the day after, the Bishop of Durham, the Duke of Northumberland, the Earls Percy, Darlington, Seat borough and Fauconberg; and Lords Ravensworth, Algernon Percy and Fielding.
In 1778, Thomas Carr, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, July 31st, 1779, the assizes began at Newcastle, before the Hon. Edward Willes, Esq and Sir Francis Buller, Knight.
In 1779, Daniel Craster, of Cratster, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1779, Francis Forster was mayor, and Isaac Cookson, sheriff.

March 22d this year, the thanks of the mayor, aldermen, sheriff,
and common-council of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne, were ordered to be transmitted to Admiral Keppel, on his honourable acquittal, for his long and eminent services to his king and country
Newcastle Courant.
"April 6th, 1778, died at Heaton, in the sixty-seventh year of his age, Matthew Ridley, Esq senior alderman, and lately one of the representatives of this town in parliament. He was a gentleman of excellent natural parts, improved by a very liberal education. He had a quick and clear conception of business, and a peculiar address in the execution of it. These talents he early and successfully employed in discharging the first offices of honour and trust in this corporation, where he since continued in discharging the first offices of honour and magistrate. By a diligent attention to his duty in the senate, he had acquired a con∣summate skill in the forms and business of parliament: to this he united a more general knowledge of the constitution, applying both with a manly and disinterested spirit to the general welfare of his country. These eminent qualities of the mind were adorned with a graceful address and polished manners; and, I may add, endeared to his family and friends by an hospitable, generous and affectionate temper. Such are the outlines of this distin∣guished character, saintly indeed, but faithfully sketched out by one who offers a tribute of honour and esteem to his departed friend, by this publick acknowledgment of his vir∣tues."—Newcastle Courant.
Saturday, August 12th, 1780, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Lord Loughborough, lord chief justice of Common Pleas, and Sir Beaumont Hotham, Knight..
In the year 1780, John Erasmus Blackett was mayor, and William Surtees, sheriff.

June 2d this year, the petition of the protestant association in New∣castle upon Tyne, was presented to the House of Commons, by Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, and seconded by Sir William Mid∣dleton, Baronet, one of the members for the county of Northumber∣land, in the absence of Sir John Trevelyan, Baronet, the other repre∣sentative for Newcastle, having been signed by 7661 perlonsNewcastle Courant, June 10th, 1780. There had been a great meeting, February 3d preceding, at the Guild-Hall of that town, when the company assembled adopted the Cumberland petition..
In the year 1781, Edward Mosley was mayor, and John Wallis, sheriff; but the latter resigned, and was succeeded March 14th, 1782, by George Collpitts, the senior sheriff peer.

In the summer of this year, a small camp was formed at Ayton, on the south-east side of Gateshead-Fell, in the county of Durham, and
vicinity of Newcastle upon Tyne, consisting of that division of the Yorkshire militia, commonly called the Beverley Buffs, and the South Lincoln militiaNewcastle Courant.. This camp broke up on the 29th of October fol∣lowing
Ibid.
In 1780, Andrew Robinson Bowes, of Benwell, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, August 11th, 1781, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir George Nares, Knight, and the Honourable John Heath.
In 1781, Charles Brandling, of Gosforth, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
Saturday, July 27th, 1782, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Lord Chief Baron Skinner and Baron Eyre.
In 1782, Calverley Bewicke, of Close-House, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1782, Sir Matthew White Ridley, Baronet, was mayor, and Richard Bell, sheriff.

June 25th this year, the East Yorkshire militia went into camp at Ayton, as in the preceding summer, and were followed soon after by the North York militiaNewcastle Courant.. This camp broke up on the 11th of November following
Ibid.
Saturday, August 16th, 1783, the assizes began at Newcastle, before Sir James Eyre, Knight, and the Honourable Francis Buller.
In 1783, William Hargrave, of Shawdon, was sheriff of Northumberland..
In the year 1783, Charles Atkinson was mayor, and Christopher Soulsby, sheriff.

July 28th this year, died Mr. Thomas Umfreville, parish clerk of St. John's in Newcastle upon Tyne. He had formerly been a mer∣chant in that town. By several indubitable evidences in his possession, he appeared to be the true and sole representative of one of the greatest names, and most illustrious families in the north
Newcastle Courant.
He had in his possession a sword which belonged to Sir Robert Umfieville, vice-admiral of England, about the time of Richard II.—This, with a pedigree, &c. &c. is now in the possession of his son William Umfreville, tallow chandler.—Quid stemmata faciunt?
In 1786, James Allgood, of Nunwick, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
The subsequent appeared in the Universal Register, Monday, March 18th, 1786.
"On Friday morning last, was found dead in his bed, at an obscure lodging near Chis∣well-street, Mr. Swan. He was the only surviving male heir of the late Thomas Swan, Esq alderman and mayor of Hull, in Yorkshire, who left estates to the amount of 20,000l. per annum, which he had been trying (in vain) for above twenty-five years to recover. The history of this unfortunate man is no less remarkable than that of his father, who, when nine years of age, in 1705 (to disinherit him), was trepanned from his father's house, Richard Swan, Esq of Benwall-Hall, near Newcastle, and put on board the new Britannia brig, was wrecked on the rocks of Scilly with Sir Cloudesley Shovel's fleet, and was afterwards taken by an Algerine vessel, sold for a slave, and after four years im∣prisonment, was set at liberty by the Redeeming Friars.
"After this he was again taken prisoner, carried and sold for a slave to a planter at South Carolina, where he suffered almost every human woe. He returned again to England, after a banishment of twenty years, in 1726, and was identified at Newcastle by his muse and father's footman. He directly laid claim to the estate alluded to; but having neither money, nor friends living to assist him, all his efforts proved abortive. After this he set∣tled at North Dalton near Hull, where he married one Jane Cole, by which mara left the above unfortunate William Swan: he afterwards died of a broken heart at the above village in 1735."
"There was an address given under the common seal, 18th of August, 1786, entitled "The humble address of the mayor, aldermen, sheriff, and common council of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the same, in common-council assembled," on the attempt upon the King's life by Margaret Nicholson, which was afterwards presented to his Majesty by the Duke of Northumerland.. The pedigree, now in the custody of his son, traces back the family to Robert Umfreville, lord of Tours and Vian, in the time of William the Conqueror.

At the assizes at Newcastle this year, William Alexander was con∣victed of forgery, but not executed till the 17th of November follow∣ing: he was respited for the opinion of the twelve judges, one of the jury who tried him not having been returned on the sheriff's panel, though summoned instead of his father, by mistake.
In the year 1784, James Rudman was mayor, and Edward Dale, sheriff.
In 1784, Sir Francis Blake, Bart. was sheriff of Northumberland.
In the year 1785, William Yeilder was mayor, and Aubone Surtees, junior, sheriff.
In 1785, Sir Henry George Liddell, of Eslington, Bart. was sheriff of Northumberland.
In the year 1786, Francis Johnson was mayor, and Richard Cham∣bers, sheriff.

September, 1786, the Duke of Northumberland was appointed lord lieutenant and custos rotulorum of the county of Northumberland, and of the town and county of Newcastle upon Tyne
Gazette, Whitehall, September 2d.—The late Duke, the former lord lieutenant, died June 6th, 1786.
Wednesday, August 30th, 1786, Henry Jennings was executed on the Town-Moor, for horse stealing. Francis Buller, Esq &c. and Mr. Justice Heath, went the northern circuit this year.
Tuesday, September, 19th, 1786, Mr. Lunardi, the famous aeronaut, made an attempt to ascend in an air-balloon, from the Spital in Newcastle upon Tyne: in filling it, Mr. Lunardi having introduced the remaining part of the acid, and the effervescence being at that time remarkably strong, forced a quantity of inflammable air through the hole, which was only four inches in diameter, before the plug could be replaced: this gave such an alarm to some of the gentlemen on that side of the balloon, who thought it was on fire, that they immediately quitted their hold of the net, and flew from it to the other side, alarm∣ing those stationed there also. The balloon, being liberated on one side, made a rapid stretch upwards, whereby a considerable rent was made in the neck of it: this occasioned a loud noise, and a considerable discharge of inflammable air: the consternation now be∣came general, in spite of Mr. Lunardi's remonstrances, and the balloon being set at liberty, ascended with great rapidity, and dragged up with it Mr. Ralph Heron, junior, son of the under sheriff of Northumberland, who had twisted a rope, fastened to its top, round his hand and arm, to the height, it is supposed, of five hundred feet, when the rope and netting being disengaged from the balloon, he sell into a garden adjoining, and expired soon after. —In an advertisement which Mr. Lunardi inserted on the occasion in the Newcastle pa∣pers, he says, "It remains for him to yield his own wish to fulfil the expectation of the town to the feelings of a parent wounded by the loss of a most amiable son, and to forbear a repetition in this place of an attempt, which, without fault on his part, has been fatal to the peace of a respectable family."
In 1787, Edward Collingwood, of Chirton, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland.
The following occurs in the Newcastle Courant, June 9th, 1787: "A more curious incident that the crows building their nest upon the spire of the Exchange in this town, has happened last week; two sparrows having built their nest upon the topmast of a ship lying at our qy and deposited therein six eggs.".

In 1787, William Cramlington was mayor, and Joseph Forster, sheriff
This year a bill received the royal assent to enable his majesty to licence a play-house in the town and cou of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne.
Lord Loughborough and Judge Wilson were on the northern circuit this year..

A. D. 1788, John Hedley was mayor, and Robert Newton Lynn, sheriffIn 1788, Davidson chard Grieve, of Swarland, Esq was sheriff of Northumberland. Mr. Justice Grose and Baron Thomson were on the northern circuit this year..

DIV1.P: APPENDIX TO THE SECOND VOLUME.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 8, Note (t.) (Murray MS. P. 176, or 178.) Inter recorda in thesaurario curiae receptae scaccarii adservata (viz.) In rotul' coram Rege Hiliar' 20 Ed. I. continet' ut sequit'.
DIV2.P: HENRICUS Dei grat' Rex Anglie et Franc' & Dominus Hibernie omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Inspeximus recordum & processum loquele que fuit coram Domino Edwardo quondam Rege Anglie fil' Regis Henrici progenitor' nostri anno regni ipsius Domini Edwardi vicesimo inter ipsum Dominum Edwardum et tunc burgenses suos Novi Castri super Tynam et tunc priorem de Tyne∣mouth super quibusdam gravaminibus et injuriis tam dicto Domino Edwardo quam burgensibus praedict' per ipsum priorem illatis in hec verba Placita coram Domino Rege apud Westmonaster' termino Sancti Hillarii anno regni Regis Edwardi filii Regis Henrici vicesimo recordu' missum de concilio. Prec' fuit vic' Northumbrie quod scire faceret priori de Tynemuth quod esset coram Domino Rege in parliamento suo a die Pasche in tres septimanas ad respondend' eidem Domino Regi et burgensibus suis Novi Castri super Tynam super quibusdam gravaminibus et injuriis tam prefato Domino Regi quam burgensibus predict' per ipsum priorem illat' ut dicitur et ulterius inde faciend' quod Dominus Rex de consilio suo duxerit ordinand' et quod haberet ibi &c.

Pretextu cujus mandati venerunt predictus prior et predict' burgenses personaliter modo hic et pred' burgenses pro Domino Rege dicunt quod cum ipse Dominus Rex habeat et habere debeat totum portum in aqua de Tyne a mari usque ad locum qui dicitur Hydewine-Streames ita libere quod non liceat alicui carcare seu discarcare mer∣candizas aliquas seu denaratas nec forstallum facere de hujusmodi mercandizis seu denar' emend' vel vendend' eadem nisi infra villam Novi Castri predict' Ita quod Dominus Rex tolneta sua prisas et custumas et alia ad dominium suum ibidem spectant' percipere possit. Predictus prior qui habet dominicas terras suas predict' aque adjacent' inter mare & villam pred' carcare & discarcare facit ibidem mercandisas & denar' quascunque ibidem applicant' emend' et vendend' in terris fuis pred' pro voluntate sua faciendo ibi portum ubi nullus, portus prius fuit ei etiam forstalla mercandisarum in prejudicium Domini Regis & ville sue predict' manifestum. Dicunt etiam quod cum
Dominus Rex habeat et habere debeat sua furna communia apud Novum Cas∣trum ita libere quod panis venalis ibidem et non alibi in partibus illis furnari debeat Ac idem Dominus Rex percepit et percipere debeat de quolibet quarterio ibidem furnato quatuor denarios de consuetudine hactenus usitat' Predictus prior levavit novam villam apud Sheeles inter mare predict' et Novum Castrum et haber ibidem piscatores pistores & brasiator' suos residentes de quibus idem prior percepit per annum triginta et sex marcas et amplius Et Dominus Rex proinde amittet per annum de exitibus furnagii sui predict' ad valenc' decem librarum et etiam per forstallum pre∣dict' apud Sheeles ad valenc' viginti librarum. Dicunt etiam quod predict' prior capit ibidem wreccum maris cum accideret quod specialiter spectat ad Dominum Regem Dicunt etiam quod cum Dominus Rex capiat et capere debeat per vic' suu' predict' prisas suas & custum' debitas ad portum Novi Castri pred' videlicet de qualibet nave vini duo dolia ante et retro electa quodlibet dolium pro viginti solidor' De quali∣bet nave allecis centum allecia quiete De nave de haddock unuxn centum haddock pro sex denari' De qualibet batella milnelli vel regard' meliorem piscem pro denar' et hujusmodi pred' prior empciones et discarcaciones navium & batellorum facit apud Sheeles et alibi per quod Dominus Rex hujusmodi prisas et custumas debitas non per∣cepit eo quod mercandise predict' ad portum debitum Novi Castri integre non per∣venerint Dicunt etiam quod predict' prior levavit quatuor furna apud Tynemuth que Willielmus Savage Willielmus Barbitonsor Robertus de Bruerne et Adam le Taylur comunes pistores tenent reddendo inde per annum predicto priori octo mercas Et dicunt quod panis ibidem furnatus venditur apud Sheeles nautis et aliis ibidem appli∣cantibus et qui applicare debuere apud Novum Castrum et ibidem victualia sua emere in emendacionem ejusdem ville. Dicunt etiam quod predict' prior habet mercatum per diem Dominicam apud Tynemuth similiter que non distat a Novo Castro nisi per sex leucas et habet ibidem tumbrellum et shamellas conductivas ad carnifices et alios et capit ibidem emend' panis & servicie sine warranto. Et ubi dicunt quod tota patria et etiam et naute applicati apud Sheeles cum rebus suis et mercandisis venalibus veniunt et eas ibi vendicioni exponunt in prejudicium Domini Regis qui nullum inde percepit tolnetum nee aliud &c. Dicunt etiam quod praefat' prior habet comonachos suos mercatores corriorum recentium per patriam qui cum ea comparaverint apud Preston tannari faciunt et inde naves vel batella apud Sheeles onerant et vendunt ad magnam deterioracionem et depauperacionem burgensium Domini Regis de Novo Castro qui hujusmodi officium exercent et exercere consueverunt. Dicunt etiam quod cum Dominus Rex habeat & habere debeat towagium navium & batellorum majorum et minorum in aqua de Tyne ascendentium versus Novum Castrum et discendent' versus mare libere per terr' dominorum quorumcunque pred' prior non permittet hujusmodi transitum facere volent' terras suas ingredi et cum forte terras suas ingressi fuerint com∣pellit eos reverti et in aquam profundam gradari unde vix cum vita sepius evadunt ac nonnulli mercatores cum bonis & mercandisis suis et similiter alii qui briscam et car∣bonem & hujusmodi apud Novum Castrum ad melioracionem ejusdem ville ducere voluerunt predict' impedimento se retrahunt in prejudicium Domini Regis non modi∣cum qui in portu suo ibidem de quolibet batello cum remigio quatuor denar' et de minori batello sine remigio unum denarium percipere debuit ubi modo vix aliquid percepit Et unde dicunt quod preter dampna que Dominus Rex sustinuit et sustinet in premissis predicia villa ipsius Regis inde deteriorata est et dampnum habet inestimabile Et pre∣dictus prior dicit quod ista promissa sibi imposita contingunt solum liberum tenementum et libertatem. Et breve directum vic' predict' per quod premonitus est essendi modo hic explanat quod respondeat de quibusdam gravaminibus et injuriis tantum nulla facta mencione liberi tenementi vel de spectantibus ad liberum tenementum unde non intendit quod de aliquo libero tenemento suo vel ad liberum tenementum suum seu libertat'
spectan' sola premunicione respondere debeat sine sum' et sine brevi Domini Regis in casu speciali et maxime contra statut' suum quod vult quod nullus de libero tenemento seu respondent sine brevi nisi velit &c. Et postea respondit idem prior & quoad wrecum maris et forstallum mercandisa' dicit quod ipse prior et predecessores sui wreccum maris habuerunt et perceperunt hactenus cum accederit Et forstallum mer∣candisarum videlicet victualium et aliarum sustentati' domus sue predicte nec iufra terram suam predict' emendo fecerunt sicut ei bene licuit per cartam Domini Ricardi avi Domini Regis nunc quam profert in hec verba.

Richardus Dei gratia Rex Anglie Dux Nomannie Aquitannie Comes Andegavie archiepiscopis episcopis abbatibus comitibus baronibus justic' vic' ministris et omnibus suis fidelibus Francis et Anglis omnibus com' in quibus Sanctus Albanus Martir terras habet amicabiliter salutem' Notum facimus vobis nos concessisse et presenti carta con∣firmasse Deo et Sancto Albano et ecclesie suae Sancti Oswini de Tynmuth celle Sancti Albani et monachis ibidem Deo servientibus omnes terras suas et omnes homines suos cum sacha, socha overstronde et streme in wode & felde tol et tem et gridbruh hamsock murdrum et forstallum danegild infangenethere et utsngenethese flemmenesslemeth bludwyte warec' et habet super omnes terras suas et super omnes homines suos ubicun∣que fuerint intra burgum et extra in tantum et tam plene sicut proprii ministri nostri exquirere deberent ad opus nostrum Et nolumus ut aliquis hominu' nec Francus nec Anglicus de terris eorum neque de hominibus eorum ullo modo se intermittat nisi ipsi et ministri sui quibus ipsi committere voluerint. Pretereaque nos concessimus Deo & Sancto Albano et ecclesie Sancti Oswini de Tynmuth celle Sancti Albani pro redemp∣cione anime nostre & parentum nostror' omnes libertates et omnes liberas consuetudines quas regia potestas liberiores alicui ecclesie conferre potest Et prohibemus super foris∣facturam nostram ne quis eas aliquo modo infringere presumat Prohibemus etiam ne in ipsor' terris vel domibus minister dapiser' vilet vel pincerna camerarius vel dispensator janitor vel proposit' contra ipsor' voluntat' et assensum tempore nostro aut successorum nostror' per manus alicujus principis vel justic' quocumque tempore ponatur Teste B. Cantuar' archiepiscopo et T. Ebor' electo &c. Datum per manum Willielmi de Longo Campo cancell' nostri Eliens' elect' quarto die Decembris anno primo regni nostri apud Cantuar'.

Et quoad fundacionem nove ville apud Sheeles dicit quod nullam villam ibi levavit de novo dicit enim quod temporibus predecessor' suorum prioium domus pred' fuerunt ibi manciones super solum suum proprium ubi Dominus Rex nullum habet solum neque liberum tenementum eo quod solum dicte domus et liberum tenementum se ex∣tendit usque ad silum aque de Tyne ultra terram suam scitam ibidem Et inter quod quidem filum aque & terram predict' domus predict' habet piscariar' suam liberam in longitudinem terre ejusdem in eadem aqua Et dicit quod ipsi et predecessores sut domus & manciones ibidem successive construxerunt et pro voluntate sua collocaverunt piscatoribus & aliis qui panem serviciam et piscem vendiderunt ibidem applicantibus sine aliquibus emend' Domino Regi faciend' sed tantummodo ipsis prioribus Dicit etiam quod nullum mercatum neque surnam habet nec habere clamat apud Sheles Ti quod ad piscatores et piscium emptiones ibidem dicit quod' predecessors sei predict' temporibus suis habuerunt piscatores suos proprios pro voluntate sua in aq ut predict, piscantes ad sustentacionem domus sue predict' absque tolneto vel aliquo inde Regi prestando non obstante eo quod protus aque de Tyne specialiter & ad Dominum Regem pertinet Dicit etiam quod iidem habuerunt tenentes sun quosdam de Sheles cum batellis suis liberos infra terras suas dominicas Et dicit quod ipsi pre∣decessores sui predict, ad sustencionem domus & familie fire praedict' piscem sic et alia sustentacioni domus & familie suae necessaria per terram et aquam ibidem emerunt libere & quiete Quia dicit quod quanquam hujusmodi emptiones seu discarcationes piscium
ibidem fecerunt a quibusdam piscatoribus Preterque a dictis piscatoribus suis, iidem pis∣catores quum ad portum de Novo Castro vel alibi applicuerint solverint et solvere de∣buerint ibidem tolnetam et custumam debitam tam pro pisee sic vendito quam pro pisce in nave sive in batello remisso et ad portum illum applicato. Et quoad mercatum de Tynemth et cetera ibidem dicit quod nullum ibi clamat mercatum sed bene recogn' quod est ibi tumbrellum et quod sint ibi pistor' & brasiator' et furna ipsius prioris con∣ductiva & shamella ad supponendas res venales et panem earnes et pisces que in villa illa venduntur sicut in alus villis campestr' pertin' illarum sicut fuerunt temporibus, pro∣decessorum ipsius et quod ipsi hactenus ceperunt emendas Dicit et quod nullus halv: monachos mercatore corior' prout sibi imponitur sicit tamen quod corea lardariot' suorum licite vendunt vel aliter inde comodum suum faciunt sed quod corea numquam emerunt per patriam neque apud Sheles inde naves seu batella inde oneravertum nec vendiderunt paratus est verisicare &c Dient etiam quod quoad towagium in aqua de Tyne quod nunquam hoc ossicium exercentes in terram suam adjacentem impedima preterquam in pratum suum de Astwike quod super hujusmodi est et suit liberum hacre∣mis et exemptum et hoc paratus est verificare Similiter dicit insuper quod ante con∣festionem dicte carte et a tempore confectionis ejusdem que prior est unaquaque liber∣tate burgo Domim Regis de Novo Castro et burgensibus ibidem per Dominum Regem Johannem concess' predecessores sui priores domus predict' omnia premissa acceperunt & habuerunt modo quo ea recogn' libere et quiete sinc temporis interrupeione virtute consuetudinum libertatum per cartam predict' sibi concessar' in terra et aqua et de quibus invenit ecclesiam suam seisitam Et unde hactenus libere et quiete usus est illis prout predecessor' sui predicti eisdem utebantur consimili modo et in eisdem locis quod paratus est verificare &c. Et petit judicium sicut prius si de alieno facto et de hus de quibus invenit ecclesiam suam seisitam ratione soli et consuccudinum et libertau' ex∣pressar' que tam libere limitantur que regia potestas eis alicui ecclesie liberiores con∣ferre potest Si absque brevi speciali et sunt contra legem communem debeat respon∣dere &c.

Et Willielmus Juge & Johannes de Insula et alii qui sequuntur pro Rege dicunt quod predicta carta in hoc casu presato priori valere non debet dicunt enim quod wreccum matis quod cum naves extra magmum mare infra portum predict' in aqua de Tyne applicuerint et ibidem fregerint casu fortuito predictus prior cum hominibus suis et batellis bona (har') navium direptarum in aqua illa natantuim infra portum illum et etiam cetera bona in hujusmodi navibus commorantia capit & ad terram suam ducit et similiter naves hujusmodi appropriat Et unde dicit quod isle prior quo modo est instante tempore, ed seisitus de sexdecom doliis vim nomine wrecci de quadam nave Petrye de Appleby burgens' Eborum in aqua predict' nuper naufragata. Et ubi hoc verbum wree non debet intelligi nisi tantum cum in terram predict' prior ceciderit Et quoad sostallum dit quod cum lil errates diverse predict' Domini concesse fuerint ut ham so ham overstronde et streme &c. Et forstallum hoc totum intelligend' est in tercis suis ina tatem suam de Tynempth et non in portu de Tyne Et frailiter hoc verbum sotall intperrati debet et intelling ad impediend' aliquem vel regia strata modo sicut predict' prior lud intelligit Et quoad ea et quoad car navium emtiones merchandisarum & dirator' victualium et aliarum, dicunt quod cum predicti' portus de Tyne solium modo est Do∣mino Regi et non predicto prior alini alteri prout idem prior recog∣novit quotions idem prior his canes vel discationes navum vel lttell∣rum aut emtione as rit ibidem ipsi Domino Regi manifeste in riatur cum Dominys Rex est in et semper extitit de portu illo nec predict prior ali∣qas otest nec debet extra dominium suum et suas pre∣dictas Et quoad villum de Sheeles quod qualescunque fuerint ibi mansium∣cule si que temporibus predecestorum istius prioris Idem prior qui
est tempore suo fieri fecit ibidem viginti & sex domus supra solum quod Domino Regi esse debet Et quoad fluxum & inundaciones maris comprehenditur et petunt recordum justic' quod prefatus prior jam alligavit quod Dominus Rex inibi nullum habet solum nec liberum tenementum sed quod mere pertinet ad predict' priorem & domum suam usque ad silum aque de Tyne Dicunt etiam quod in domibus illis apud Sheles sunt manentes piscatores et brasiatores auxionarii & auxionatrices panis & servicie et aliarum rerum tam divites quod omnes naves & batella per centum vel ducentum ad plus vel minus cum rebus & mercandisis suis ad partes illas transfretantes ibidem applicant ad sufficientiam hospiciorum et victualium quam ibi inveniunt et qui apud Novum Castrum applicare debuerint et victualia sua ibi emere prout consueverunt ad melioracionem ejusdem ville Et unde dicunt quod idem prior solus est occupator soli Domini Regis ibidem et solus ablator commodorum ville ipsius Domini Regis predict' Dicunt etiam quod idem prior habet in Sheeles sexdecem piscatores vel plures cum batellis magnis piscantes in mare per annum causa negocionis non causa sustentacionis domus sue pre∣dict' et de quibus Dominus Rex nullum tolnetum neque custumam suam debitam per∣cipit Dicunt etiam quod cum naves vel batella majora vel minora cum piscibus vel aliis mercandisis quibuscunque ibidem applicuerint venit idem prior et homines sui et alie patrie cum equis et sumagiis et inde sibi necessaria comparant Ita videlicet quod ali∣quando navis vel batella illa vacua vel semicarcata ad portus alios quam ad Novum Castrum predictum revertuntur vel saltem ibidem cum relictis hujusmodi piscium de pluribus batellis in upo batello vel duobus translatis Et unde Dominus Rex qui prisas suas et custumas debitas per vic' suum percipit apud Novum Castrum percipere non potest nisi quatuor denarios tantum de batello cum remigio et unum denarium de illo quod sine remigio invenitur ubi de quolibet batello hujusmodi quorquot fuerint tum perciperet cum accesserint et plura alia de quibus hic non fit mentio quia discarcata nave vel attaminata seu batello de venalibus perciperet Dominus Rex custumam suam de qualibet mercandisa in nave illa vel batello existente Et unde idem Dominus vix percipit ex premissis vicesimam partem vel tricesimam custume sue Et prior' pred' dicunt etiam quod furna de Tynmuth quod sunt Domino Regi & burgo suo pred' nimis injuriosa quia dicunt quod predict' prior firmariis suis eorundem bladum suum librari facit abundantur ad pecuniam inde ad opus suum faciend' per— quod ipsi firmarii panem furniant comuniter et vendam apud Sheeles Et unde iidem applicantes sustentantur qui apud Novum Castrum emere deberent et consueverunt sua victualia Et unde dicunt quod pistores & brasiatores Novi Castri dicta occasione—a villa illa recedunt et manent apud Tynemuth et Sheeles in dampnum Domini Regis et burgensium predict' de Novo Castro et de sicut pred' prior recognovit quod ipse & pre∣decessores sui emendales panis & servicie apud Tynemuth & Sheeles hactenus perci∣piunt ubi Dominus Rex in his percipit neque tolneta neque alia de rebus & mercandizis ibidem venditis Nec dedi potest quum Dominus Rex prisas suas & custumas debitas amittit manifeste per empciones victualium & discarcationes navium de mercandizis et rebus predictis per presatum priorem factis ubi prise et costume Domini Regis de meli∣oribus et integris mercandisis et rebus venalibus elegie & capi debeant ac ista et alia premissa sunt facta istius prioris personalia licet predecessores sui hujusmodi utebantur o quod unumquodque eorundem factorum est personale et injuriosum in se totiens quotiens factum suerit et que dedici non possunt nee est ibi inquisitio necessaria Et unde dicunt quod alieno facio propria facta sua injuriosa non potest nec debet coopereri Petunt inde judicium pro Domino Rege & burgo suo predict'. Et postea dicunt quod in itinere Johannis de Vall' et sociorum suoium in comitatu Northumbrie anno regni Regis Edwardi nunc septimo presentatum suit per jur' quod prior de Tynmuth levavit unam villam super ripam aque de Tyne apud Sheeles ex una parte aque et prior Dunelm' levavit alia' ex altera parte aque ubi nulla villa deberet este nisi tantummodo Joges in quibus piscatores possent hospitari et quod piscatores ibi piseem vendiderunt qui
vendi deberent apud Novum Castrum ad magnum nocumentum totius burgi et ad de∣trimentum prisarum Domini Regis ad castrum suum Quia piscis et alia mercimonia de quibus Dominus Rex solebat habere prisas suas et que ibidem modo venduntur de∣berent vendi apud burgum de Novo Castro ubi Dominus Rex habet prisas suas Et quod idem prior similiter fecit brasiare apud Sheeles & habuit magnas naves piscatores ubi nul' deberet habere nisi batellos tantum unde Dominus Rex perdit prisas suas & burgus Novi Castri custumam suam ad grave damnum Domini Regis & burgi predicti & similiter quod prior Dunelm' ex altera parte aque de Tyne fecit brasiare et naves habuit ubi nisi batellos habere deberet Et quod predict' prior de Tynemuth fecit furnire in furno suo proprio panem alienum qui furnire debuit apud burgum de Novo Castro per quod burgus predictus furnagium suum videlicet de quolibet quaiterio quatuor denar' et unde voc'—ad warrantum rotulus purprestrur' super Dominum Regem factar' secundum veredictum et presentacionem proborum et legalium virorum ad hoc elector' de itinere predicto Et dicunt quod nunquam fuerunt ille presentationes hactenus determinate sive discusse neque in judicium deducte nee super hiis alique facte emende Et quod hec Domino Regi & concilio suo manifestentur &c. Et predictus prior dicit quod ista presentacio si qua fuerit que est quedam accusatio sibi obesse non debet eoquod tempore illo quo presentacio illa facta fuit, non fuit ipse prior quod paratus est verificare Nec de alieno fact' sive brevi specialitenetur respondere et petit inde judicium sicut prius &c. Postea coram ipso Domino Rege et ejus consilio in presentia Domini Regis venerunt partes pre∣dict' et pred' burgen' petierunt judicium suum super record' et process' pred' Et predictus prior petiit quod si Domino Regi placeret et ejus concilio quod de libertatibus suis de quibus ipse prior invenit ecclesiam suam seisitam tempore quo fastus suit prior non re∣sponderet fine brevi Domini Regis & super hoc similiter petit judicium &c. Et quia idem prior per breve Domini Regis predict' coram Domino Rege in curia sua venit et coram ipso Domino Rege personaliter comparuit ad respondend' tam ipsi Domino Regi quam burgensibus suis pred' super quibuscunque gravaminibus et injuriis ipsi Domino Regi & burgen' suis pred' illatis ad certum diem coram cert' justic' ad hoc in presentia sua nomina & assigna' per os ipsius Domini Regis ad quecunque gravamina seu injurias ipsi Domino Regi seu burgensibus suis pred' illata audiend' placitand' ac coram ipso Domino Rege referend' Prout tam per ipsum Dominum Regem quam justic' ad hoc assignat' plenarie est recordatum recepit et coram eisdem justic.' spente & de mero jure suo in articulis sibi superius impositis precise respondet Et etiam cartam Domini Regis Ricardi et alias responsiones pro jure suo defendendo & sustinend' grat et non coactus proposuit Nec etiam se precise tenuit ad illam responsionem quod ecclesiam suam invenit seisitam licet in quibusdam articulis sic se excusaverit prout patet per recordum predict' Dictum est ei quod aliud pro se oftendat vel dicat si qiud habeat vel sciat quod ei proddesse debeat &c.

Et idem prior nihil dicit nisi ut prius sed petit quod Dominus Rex intellecta carta Domini Regis Ricardi progenitoris sui predicti saciat quod sibi placuerit faciend' Et quia Dominus Rex cerciorari vult si predict' prior & predecessores sui a tempore con∣fectionis predicte carte per cartam illam continue et absque aliqua interruptione liber∣tatibus pred' plenarie usi sint neene vel etiam si pred' prior tempore suo aut predeces∣sores sui post consectionem carte illius temporibus suis super ibidem Dominum Regem aut progenitores suos libertat' supradict' seu earum aliquas usurpaverunt vel purpresta∣runt Et ubi et a quibus et per quos et a quo tempore & quo modo idem Dominum Rex assignavit Willielmum de Visey Thomam de Normanville Johannem de le Che∣greyns et Ricardum Knout vic' Northumbriae ad inquirend' veritat' omnium & singu∣lorum articulorum premissorum in recordo islo contentor' Ita quod inde certificent Dominum Regem ad proximum parliamentum suum post festum Sancti Michaelis et est dies partibus ad eundum terminum Preterea quia pred' prior nullum cla∣mat habere mercatum vel portum apud Tynemuth nec etiam apud Sheeles prout patet
in recordo pred' et prout presentia deind' Regis cognovit inhibitum est ei ne merca∣tum vel portum in locis pred' de cetero tencat seu tenere faciat Immo quod omnia signa quecunque fuerint tam portus quam mercati in locis pred' prosternere faciat er diruere Et preceptum est per ipsum Dominum Regem quod inquiratur per justic' suos pred' si mercatus vel portus in locis pred' temporibus retro actis fuerint et a quo tempore & per quem & que dampna Dominus Rex ea occasione sustinuerit &c. Postea die Sancte Trinitatis in quindecem dies anno regni Regis nunc vicesimo venit predictus prior et similiter Richardus de Bretinle qui sequitur pro Rege & Dominus Rogerus de Brabason Dominus Willielmus de Bereford et Gilbertus de Rowbery justic' ipsius Regis alias miserunt inquisitionem super pred' articulis factam que quidem inquisitio in∣veniri potest inter recorda de termino Sancti Michaelis anno decimo nono finiente cujus inquisitionis tenor est, ss. Inquisitio capta est apud Novum Castrum super Tynam die Jovis in crastino Assumptionis beate Marie anno regni Regis Edwardi decimo nono coram Rogero de Brabazon Willielmo de Bereford & Gilberto de Roubiry justic' ejus∣dem Domini Regis ad hoc assignat' de diversis gravaminibus et injuriis ipsi Domino Regi & burgensibus suis ville predicte per priorem de Tynemuth apud Tynmuth & Sheeles illatis et de quibusdam libertatibus quas idem prior clamat habere per cartam Domini Ricardi Regis predecessor' Domini Regis nunc juxta articulis in recordo et processu inde inter ipsum Dominum Regem & burgenses suos pred' et predict' prior coram ipso Do∣mino Rege et consilio suo habitis contentos per sacramentum Johannis de Hatweyton Johannis de Islington Willielmi de Framlington Ricardi Bennet Roberti de Throck∣law Rogero de Creswell Hugonis Gabion Hugonis de Eure Michaelis de Punchadon Nicholai Vigrens Alde de Cambhowse et Ricardi de Stotton clerici qui dicunt super sacramentum suum quod portus in aqua de Tyne a mari usque ad locum qui dicitur Hedwyne Streames est Domini Regis liber et quod nullus in portu illo carcare aut discarcare potest aut debet nec predictus prior nec alii antequam captores prisarum Do∣mini Regis aut ejus ballivi per mercator' premuniantur et prisas Domini Regis ceperint & licentiam eis discarcand' dederint et nisi licentiam habuerint aut oportebit ipsos mer∣cator' ad villam Novi Castri ulterius transire aut in mare redire. Et dicunt quod pre∣dictus prior qui nunc est & predecessores sui a tempore confectionis carte Domini Regis Ricardi usi sunt mercandisas et bona apud Sheeles applicantia discarcare et ca que volu∣erunt ad usus proprios emere abducere et asportare et hoc aliquando per licentiam cap∣tor' et ballivorum prisarum Domini Regis et aliquando line licentia Sed dicunt expresse quod omni tempore quo premissa sine licentia fecerunt injuste fecerunt et injur' Domino Reg' Requis' quis prectecessor' predict' prioris sine licentia premissa facere incepit et quo tempore dicunt quod quidam Willielmus de Horton quondam prior de Tynemuth pre∣decessor pred' prioris primo et tempore Regis Henrici patris Regis nunc cito post hel∣lum Evesham jam viginti annis clapsis premissa sacere incipit. Quesiti de dampnis que Dominus Rex habuit occasione pred' decunt quod prior qui nunc est jam extitit prior per undecim annos et quod dampna predict' de tempore suo se extendunt ad quatuor libras & de temporibus predecessorum suorum ad sexaginta solid' Dicunt etiam quod homines et tenentes predict' prioris de Tynemuth et de Sheeles per ipsum priorem apud Sheeles receptati caream & discarcam mercandizas & denarratas ac si essent mercatores secundum quantitatem bonorum suorum a ita portum et forstallum ibidem faciunt ubi nullus portus de jure fieri deberet et hoc a tempore quo apud Sheeles edificare domos adunare et inhabitare ceperunt et secundum quod facultates se obtulerunt et bona sua multiplicaverunt ad dampnum Regis decem librarum Et a tempore quo homines pred' prioris apud Sheeles inhabitare ceperum clapsi sunt tam ut eredunt sexaginta & sex anni ante quod tempus non fuerunt ibi nisi tres sciales tantum ad opus piscatorum ad mare cuntium et rediuntium Item quoad piscatores pistores brasiatores et surna dicunt quod apud Sheeles sum piscatores brasiatores qui accrescunt de die in diem ratione mercado∣rum
ibidem venientium qui pisces et cervisiam emunt Et quod non sunt ibi immo apud Tynemuth sunt quatuor furna in quibus panis venalis furnitur et venditus tam apud Tynemuth quam apud Sheeles nautis et aliis venientibus in prejudicium Domini Regis et forstallum ville sue Novi Castri requisiti de tempore levacionis predic∣torum furnorum et cujus seu quorum sunt dicunt quod levata sunt post ultimum iter Johannis de Vallibus et sociorum suorum justicior' ultimo itinerantium in comitatu islo quod suit anno regni Regis nunc septimo Et quod predicta furna sunt quatuor homi∣nibus qui nominantur in querela in recordo pred' qui pro furnis illis capiunt furnag'. Et prior eis capit emendas assise fracte cum inde convicti fuerunt qui nullas emendas assise panis fracte capere potest eo quod assisam non habet ad dampnum Recus decem librarum Item quoad wreccum maris dicunt quod pred' prior et predecessor' sui cepe∣runt wrecum in terris suis cum bona navium fractarum in mari & infra portum pred' natantia cum batell' et alio modo attingere potuerunt ca ad terram traxerunt & asporta∣verunt et in hoc Domino Regi injuriatur eo quod hujusmodi wreccum ad alium non per∣tinet nisi solummodo Domino Regi infra portum pred' Quesiti de tempore quo wrec∣cum et bona talia ceperunt infra portum predictum et ad quorum manus devenerunt dicunt quod viginti annis clapsis tempore pred' Willielmi quondam prioris quedam navis lana carcata disrupta suit et de cujus bonis devenerunt ad predictum prioratum ad valenc' decem librarum ad dampnum Regis &c. Item quoad prisas ad custumas Regis de vinis et allecis piscibus dicunt quod nullum vinum ibidem discarcatum sui' nisi pro necessariis ipsius prioris et eo modo quo supradicitur de allec' haddocke & alio pisce dicunt quod tot piscatores sunt ibi et alii homines manentes quod naute ibidem applicantes et piscatores tantam deliberacionem mercandizarum suarum invenient quod naves suas discarcant & pisces vendunt per quod Dominus Rex prisas et custumas sur∣amittit et amisit et tempore quo homines ibidem inhabitare ceperunt ad dampnum Regi sexaginta solidorum.
