Item quoad mercatum dicunt quod per diem Dominicam et alios dies festivos conveniunt apud Tynemuth plures homines propter Sanctum Oswinum et ecclesiam et ibi emunt victualia et alia mercimonia que ibidem inveniunt Sed dicunt quod non est ibi aliquis certus dies mercati nec prior aut predecessores sui aliquod mer∣catum ibidem tenuerunt aut commodum aliquod ut tolneta aut aliud quod ad mercatum pertinet perceperunt. Item quoad corea empta et vendita dicunt quod predictus prior per commonachos suos aliqua corea non emerit nec vendiderit nec naves inde oneravi∣sicut ei imponitur Item quoad towagium dicunt quod Dominus Rex habere debet towagium navium in aqua de Tyne ascendendo versus Novum Castrum et discendenda versus mare per terras quorumcunque dominorum. Ita quod trahentes transcunt ad minus dampnum et gravamen per que poterunt. Et dicunt quod prior non impedivit hujusmodi transeuntes nisi in dampno suo et ubi plus infra terram suam transierunt et viam secerunt quam necesse fuit Item quoad fundacionem ville de Sheeles dicunt quod sunt ibi quinquies viginti messuagia cum domibus necessariis eisdem messuagiis spectan tibus et in quibus messuagiis homines inhabitant de quibus messuagiis tempore illius prioris levata sunt sexdecim et una placea parata ad edificand' Et dicunt quod omnia messuagia illa sunt extra le slodmarke in solo ipsius prior' edificata preter unum cornerum unius domus et unumquodque predict' messuag' habet kayam suam levatam insia le slud marke in solo Domini Regis. Et tempore Willielmi Bernard imediate predecessor' prioris nunc levata suerum octo messuagia. Et tempore Ade de Meperdeshalle prede∣cessoris ipsius Willielmi et tempore cujusdam Radulphi predecessoris predict' Ade, vide∣licet infra viginti quatuor annos proximo preterito levata fuerunt quindecim messuagia. Et sic dicunt quod omnia messuagia edificata inter le bourne versus orientem et mare levata sunt a tempore predict' preter tria que fuerunt ibidem a tempore quo non extat memoria et vocali solebant le Sheeles de quibus mentio sit supra. Et ex alia paite del bourne versus occidentem usque quoddam siketium scita sunt septem messuagia que
edisicabantur tempore Regis Henrici infra sexaginta annos proxim' preteritos et que omnia sunt sita in solo ipsius prioris preter medietatem unius domus que sita est ultra le sludmarke in solo Regis. Ex alia parte siketti versus occidentem sita sunt viginti messua∣gia in solo ipsius prioris et est medietas trium domorum predictorum messuag' sita ultra le sludmarke et super kayas et suerunt edificata infra sexaginta & sex annos proxim' preteritos Et omnia messuagia predict' kayas habent & quedam duas. Et omnia alia messuagia que supersunt de predicto numero infra idem tempus fuerunt edisicata et sunt in solo ipsius prioris sed non habent kayas Et dicunt quod omnes kaye predict' purprestate sunt super Dominum Regem et infra le sludmarke in solo ipsius Domini Regis videlicet in aliquo loco per sexdecem pedes et in aliquo loco per decem et in aliquo per octo & in aliquo per sex et in aliquo plus & in aliquo minus prout ibi patet. Et dicunt quod ante predict' tempus viz. sexaginta & sex annos ut credunt non fuerunt ibi nisi pred' tres shales tum ubi modo sunt predict' quinquies viginti messuagia edifi∣cata et inhabitata. In cujus rei testimon' pred' jur' sigilla sua presenti inquisicioni appo∣suerunt data anno die loco predictis &c. Et sciend' quod predicta inquisitio capta suit per pred' justic' antequam pred' loquela missa suit de consilio reg' justic'de Banco Regis Postea a die Sancti Johannis Baptiste tres septimanas anno R. R. nunc vicesimo apud Novum Castrum super Tyham venit Richardus de Bretevill qui sequitur pro Rege et similiter prior in propria persona. Et etiam jur' veniunt Et quia compertum est per veredictum jur' sicut in recordo patet superius quod portus in aqua de Tyne a mari usque ad locum qui dicitur Hidewyne Streames est liber portus Regis et quod nullus in portu illo carcare aut discarcare potest sine licent' Regis aut ballivorum suorum Ideo quoad hoc com'—est quod pred' portus rem' Domino Regi & heredibus suis libere cum prisis suis towagiis et omnibus libertatibus ad portum spectantibus Ita quod apud Tyne∣muth neque apud Sheeles naves carcantur sive discarcantur bona vel mercimonia ibi∣dem de cetero vendantur infra coopertum nec extra &c. Et recuperet Dominus Rex dampna sua que taxantur per jur' ad quatuor libras racione carcacionis et discarcaci∣onis navium ibidem per predict' priorem.

Item quia compertum est per veredictum jur' quod apud Tynemuth sunt quatuor furna comunia in quibus panis venalis furnitur & venditur et unde predictus prior emendas cepit assise panis fract' et ten' surna capiunt furnagium Ideo quoad hoc com —est quod Dominus Rex recuperet damna sua quinque mar' secundum declaracionem vered' jur' predictor' versus pred' priorem Et dictum est Ricardo de Bretevill qui sequi∣tur pro Rege quod sequitur versus eos qui capiunt furnagium de furnis pred' &c. Et similiter versus homines et tenentes predict' prioris de Tynemuth & Sheeles qui for∣stallum fecerunt et faciunt Domino Regi et burgensibus suis de villa Novi Castri carca∣ciones et discarcationes empciones &—venditiones &c. Item quoad wreccum maris concessum est quod Dominus Rex et hered' sui habeant de cetero wreccum in pred' portu et quod recuperet catalla sua ad coronam suam spectantia de wrecco quoad pervenit ad prioratum pred' que taxanum per jur' ad decein libras Item quoad mer∣catum & seriam cons' est quod non sit apud Tynemuth sive apud Sheles mercatus nec seria Et quod apud Tynemuth neque apud Sheeles non fiat communiter exposisio verum venalium ut in cibis potibus nec aliis rebus quibuscunque venalibus. Nec ali∣quod forstallum apud Tynemuth sive apud Sheles quod Dominus Rex hered' sui sive burgenses sui Novi Castri in aliquo deteriorentur. Et preceptum est Hugoni Gobyon vic' Northumbrie quod non permittat sore apud TYnemuth neque apud Sheles aliquod mercatum seriam sive signa mercati serie vel portus de cetero &c. Et quod kayas et alia pred' prior infra le sludmarke in solo Domini Regis levata cons' est quod amoveantur ad custus pred' prioris et per visum jur' Et hoc pred' Hugoni vic' et cus∣todi pred' burgi Novi Castri presenti precep' suit et pred' prior in Et precep∣tum est vic' Northumbrie qui presens est quod venite sac' coram Rege a die Sancti Mi∣chaelis
in 15 dies ubicunque &c. omnes lib' tenentes de Sheles ad respondend' Domino Regi &c. Nos autem recordum et processum loquele predictum ad instantiam & re∣quisitionem burgensium predictor' duximus exemplificand' per presentes.
In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westmonasterium tertio decimo die Julii anno regni nostri primo.

DIV3.HEAD: Asplion.
DIV3.P: (In a modern hand) Ex' with a copy from the record by P. Gibson & W. A. D. 20 April, 1772, W. D.

Q.P: "Judgment in Parliament 34 Ed. I. where the Prior of Tinmouth having lands adjoining to the said river of Tyne at North Shields, and having built a shoar there, within the flood∣mark; it was adjudged that it should be removed at the cost of the prior. It may not be amiss to give some account of this trial.
"The contents mentioned in a plea at Westminster, in the 20th year of Edward I.
"Between the King, and the Burgesses of Newcastle, and the Prior of Tinmouth.

DIV3.P: 1st, THE whole port in the water of Tyne; 2d, His ovens at Newcastle; 3d, For every quarter of corn there baked; 4th, Of Custom; 5th, The King loseth at North-Shields for the issues of baking per annum 10l. and by the forestalling of the market there 20l. The said prior also taketh the wreck of the sea, which specially belongs to the King.

"The King could also take two tun of wine to be chosen behind and before, and every tun of wine for 20s. of every ship of herrings 100, herrings, &c. all which the said prior takes at Shields and elsewhere, by which means the King lost his prises and customs due to him; because the same merchandises came not entirely to his due port of Newcastle.

"The prior also built four ovens at Tinmouth, which were rented at 5l. 6s. 8d. per annum, and kept a market on the Lord's day at Tinmouth. It was also objected to him, that the whole country and the mariners applied themselves, and sold their goods and merchandize at Shields, to the King's great detriment, he receiving no toll nor other profits for the same.

"The King ought to have the towage of ships and boats, greater and smaller, in the river of Tyne, in going up to Newcastle, and down to the sea, freely over any lord's land, &c. The King ought to have in his port 4d. for every boat that has an oar, and 1d. for every lesser one that has none.

DIV4.HEAD: "IN ANSWER,
DIV4.P: "The prior said, the premises did only touch his free tenement, and he answered, that as for the wreck of the sea, the forestalling of merchandises, &c. be and his predece∣sors had them by charter of King John, grandfather of King Edward I. and so he pro∣ceeds to his new town of Shields.

"He said also, that he had 110 market or oven at Shields. But as to the fishers and buying of fish, he saith, that his predecessors in their times have always had their own fishers fishing in the same water, for the maintenance of their house, toll free, &c. be∣cause the port of the water of Tyne doth especially and entirely belong to the King, and that they (meaning the prior and convent of Tinmouth) have had certain their tenants of Shields, wish their boats within their dcmclncs. " And
"And as for the market at Tinmouth, he said he claimed none there; but he had a rumbrel, and had hired fishers, brewers and bakers, and also shambles there.
"As to the charge of towage, he said, that he never hindered those that exercised any such office in the water of Tyne, adjacent to his land, save only at Elstwick or Ast∣wick.

"He said moreover, that before and at the time of making King Richard's charter, which was before any liberties granted to Newcastle by King John, the priors of this house took and had all the premises freely and quietly, &c. by virtue of custom of liberties granted to them by their said charter by land and water, whereof he found his church seized, &c.

"Those who prosecuted for the King, said, that the charter was worth nothing. As to the wreck of the sea, they said, no sooner had the ships applied themselves out of the great sea into the said port, and there had the misfortune to break, then the said prior taketh the goods of such broken ships, both swimming and therein abiding, and converts them to his own use; and that the then prior was seized of ten tuns of wine, out of a certain ship of Peter of Appleby, burgess of York, wrecked in the said water.

"And as to the charging or discharging of ships, and of merchandises, &c. they said, that whereas the said port of Tyne is only the King's, as often as the prior should do so, the King was manifestly injured, being then, and always before, in seizin and possession of the said port.

"As to the town of Shields, they said, that whatsoever small dwelling houses there had been there, &c. the said prior (that then was caused there to be made twenty-six houses upon the King's soil; because they are comprehended within the flowing and inundation of the sea, and they demanded the record of justice, that the said then prior alleged that the King therein hath no soil, &c. but that it merely belonged to him, even to the fill of the water.

"They also said, that in those houses at Shields, there were fishers and brewers, and victuallers, &c. so rich that they were able to give loading and victuals for 100 or 200 ships, which ought to apply themselves at Newcastle upon Tyne, and there buy their victuals for the bettering the said town. Whereupon they said, that the said prior is the only occupier of the King's soil, and the only taker away of the said King's town of Newcastle, and that he the said prior had sixteen fishers or more, with great boats, fishing in the sea yearly for traffick's sake only, and not for maintenance of his house; whereof the King received neither toll nor custom.

They said also, that the said prior and his men come out with their horses and car∣riages, and out of such ships as came thither, got necessaries for themselves, so that most times ships and boats return empty and half laden to other ports than to New∣castle aforesaid, whereby the King cannot receive his due prises and customs.

"And after they said that John of the Vale, I suppose De le Val, being judge itine∣rant, 7 Edw. I. It was then reported by the jury, that the prior of Tinmouth built a upon the bank on the water of Tyne on one side, and the prior of Durham levied, or built another on the other side, where no towns ought to be, unless lodges only for fishermen; and that the fishermen have there sold their fishes, which ought to have been sold at Newcastle, to the great hurt of the said town, and loss of the King's prises: and that both the said priors of Tinmouth and Durham have caused to be made brewers, and fishers, having great ships, whereas they ought to have but boats, and have caused bread to be baked there, which ought to have been baked at New∣castle.

"It is inhibited and forbidden the said prior of Tinmouth, that from thenceforth he should not hold, or cause to be held a market or fair, in the aforesaid places, and was
determined that the port within the water of Tyne, from the sea to Heddon Streams, is the free port of the King and his heirs, with its prises, customs, towages, tonages, with all other profits and commodities incident and belonging to the same &c. and that neither at Tinmouth, nor at Shields, ships are to be laden or unladen.

"It was also ordered, that four ovens at Tinmouth should pay damages five marks, and those that took tonnage and make forestal, &c. and as to the wrecks of the sea, &c. that the King and his heirs should have them for ever hereafter; as to the markets and fairs, that there be not at Tinmouth or Shields any market or fair, and that neither at Tinmouth or Shields there be any sale of things saleable, as in meats, drinks, or any other things whatsoever, whereby the King, his heirs and successors may be made the worse.

"It was also ordered, that the keys and other things levied and raised by the said prior within the flood-mark on the King's soil, should be removed at the costs of the said prior."—Bourne's Newcastle, p. 161.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 12. Harleian Charter, (18 Ed. III.) 43 D. 41. (Sine sgillo.)
DIV2.P:
EDWARDUS Dei gratia Rex Anglie & Francie & Dominus Hibernie dilectis & fide∣libus suis Gilberto de Umframvyll comiti Danegos Johanni de Fennewyk Ricardo de Galewaye majori ville Novi Castri super Tynam et Ade de Corbrigg salutem. Quia datum est nobis intelligi quod plures gurgites et kidelli ex transverso aque de Tyne ex utraque parte ejusdem ultra numerum ordinatum et longiores quam fieri debent et solent de novo facte existunt Et quod transitus navium et batellorum versus eandem villam Novi Castri per hoc multum artatur per quod hujusmodi naves & batelli cum mercandisis ad dictam villam prout hactenus solebant venire non possint. Et nos de proficuo piscarie ad nos in fil' aque predicte pertinentis percipiend' sumus impedit. in nostrum grave dampnum er dicte ville nostre detrimentum & destructionem ac hominum in eadem villa manencium dampnum non modicum et depauperacionem manifestam Nos nolentes talia nobis et dicte ville dampnosa aliqualiter tolerare assignavimus vos tres et duos vestrum ad superintend' gurgites et kidellos predictos et ad informand' vos per inquisitionem per sacramentum proborum et leg' hominum de com' Northumbriae tam infra libertates quam extra per quos rei veritas melius sciri poterit faciend' de numero gurgitum & kidellorum quos in aqua predicta ex antiqua ordinacione five consucru∣dine fieri debent et de longitudine latitudine et altitudine eorundem et de nominar illorum qui hujusmodi gurgites et kidellos ultra numerum ordinatum et consuetum seu dictos gurgites & kidellos longiores alciores vel latiores quam esse debent fecerunt et ad omnes gurgites et kidellos quos in dicta aqua ultra numerum debitum vel sint longiores laciores seu alciores factos inveneritis amovend' et ad statum debitum reducend' necnon ad omnes illos quos hujusmodi gurgites et kidellos contra antiquam ordinacionem inde factam inveneritis facientes per amerciamenta & alios modos quibus expedire vide∣ritis debite juxta quantitatem delicti sui secundum legem et consuetudinem regni nostri
Anglie castigand' et puntend' Ita quod navibus vel batellis versus villam predictam venire volentibus impedimentum aliquod aut nobis de proficuo quod de piscaria aque predicte percipere debemus dampnum providend' fraus vel injuria nullatenus fiat Et ideo vobis mandamus quod ad certos dies et loca quos vos tres vel duo vestrum ad hoc provideritis diligentes informaciones et inquisitiones super premissis et omnia alia pre∣dicta fac' in forma predicta salvis nobis amerciamentis inde provenientibus mandavimus enim vic' nostr' com' pred' quod ad certos dies et loca quos vos tres vel duo vestrum ei scire fac' venire fac' coram vob' tribus vel duobus vestrum tot et tales probos et leg' homines de balliva sua tam infra libertat' quam extra per quos rei veritas in premissis sciri poterit et inquiri. It cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westm' 10 die Julii anno regni nostri Anglie decimo octavo regni vero nostri Franc' quinto.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 16.(Wednesday 4th January, 25o Henrici 6ti.)
DIV2.P:
INQUISICIO capt' apud villam Novi Castri super Tynam coram Thoma Ful∣thorp, milite, Willielmo Hardyng majore ville pred' Rogero Thornton, Roberto Rodes, Rolando Tempest, Johanne Musgrave, Thoma Wardale et Johanne Chaumber, virtute commissionis Domini Regis, eisdem direct' ad inquirend' per sacramentum pro∣borum & legalium hominum, tam de villa predicta et libertate ejusdem, quam de com' Northumbriae, tam infra libertates quam extra per quos rei veritas melius sciri poterit, de omnimodis mercandizis, victualibus et aliis rebus venalibus, alibi infra aquam de Tyne, quam apud portum dicte ville, prout retroactis temporibus fieri debuit & con∣suevit carratis, discarratis, emptis sive venditis: ac de omnimodis wreccis maris et deodandis, que in aqua predicta, ante hec tempora, aliqualiter contigerunt, per quoscun∣que alios quam per officiarios nostros, ad hoc assignat' capt' sive seisitis Nec non de omnimodis forstallariis, regratariis, purpresturis, accrochis, amentis, usurpationibus, aut aliis nocumentis, novitatibus, injurus et gravaminibus in aliquibus viilis burgis hamelettis, sive locis, ville et portui predictis propinquioribus; per quoscunque & qualitercunque, tam per terram quam per aquam factis, habitis, sive perpetrat' quo casu, quando, qualiter & quomodo: ac de omnibus articulis & circumstantiis premissa qualitercunque concernentibus plenius veritatem assign', die Mercurii, 4o die Januarii anno regni Regis Henrici Sexti post conquestum vicesimo quinto per sacram' Willielmi y, Will' Myddylton, Will' Pray, Johannis Usher, Will' Rotham, Johan' Forester, Joh' Leynton, Roberti Elthom, Will' Faucus, Joh' Hilton Gener' Joh' Nicholson, Will' Hoton, John' Wellys, & Rob' Bulmer, jur' Qui dicunt super sacramentum suum quod major & burgenses ville Novi Castri super Tynam habent s tenent de Domino Rege nunc ipsique et omnes predecessores sui, quondam burgenses ville illuis, quando major ville illius ibidem non suit, ac majores & burgenses ejusdem ville quando major ibidem suit, a tempore quo non extat memoria successive habuerunt & tenuerunt de eodem Rege & omnibus progenitoribus et predecessoribus suis quondam regibus Anglie villam illam; unde aqua de Tyne, et solum aque a toto eodem tempore coopertum, a loco vocat.' Sperhaul in mari usque lotum vocat' Hedwynstremes, sunt perrcell, cum
pertinen' libertatibus et liberis consuetudinibus ejusdem ville, ad feodi firmam, salvis redditibus, prisis et assisis regiis in portu ejusdem ville: Dominusque Johannes nuper Rex Anglie progenitor Domini Regis per quandam cartam suam coram jur' predict' ostens' villam predictam cum pertinentiis, libertatibus et liberis consuetudinibus predictis (ex∣ceptis preexceptis) tunc burgensibus ville predict' predecessoribus eorundem nunc major' & burgensium, habend' sibi et successoribus suis ad feodi firmam in perpetuum confirmavit Et quod villa predicta est omnibus partibus regni Anglie in Estmerchia, versus Scociam et populo Regis in eisdem moranti quasi clipeus, sane defencionis et refugium tutele contra invasiones et frequentes insultus Scottorum Et ulterius dicunt quod inter dictas liber∣tates et liberas consuetudines prefati nunc major et burgenses et omnes predecessores sui predicti a toto tempore supradicto, habuerunt & seisiti fuerunt ut de percella firme sue predict' tam de portu integre ville predict' quam de quodam mercato in eadem villa quolibet die tenend'. Ac de omnimodis seldis shopis macellis & shamellis conductivis universorum victualium mercandizarum et rerum venalium de tabernis omnium vinorum, servigie et bere, de hospiciis communibus quorumcumque hominum et * * * * quorum, et de herynghowsys et fichhowsis, factur' et exiccation' unius cujus allecis et piscis venal' ubicunque capt' infra dictam aquam applican' qualitercunque & quandocun∣que infra aliquam partem parcium eidem aque, inter loca predict' vocat' le Sperhauke & Hedwynstremes adjacen' vendi hospitari fieri, exiccari vel reponi deben' sive contingen' infra eandem villam et libertat' ejusdem et non alibi exigend' faciend' tenend' habend' locand' & exercend', una cum carratione discarratione et recarratione omnimodorum navium batellarum et vasorum in eandem aquam cum bonis mercan∣disis aut aliis rebus venalibus quibuscunque venientibus seu extra eandem aquam trans∣cuntibus apud eandem villam videticet inter pontem et le Walfoote ville illius, et non alibi absque eorum licentia fiend'. Ac de communibus furnagio et brasiatura omnimod' panis servicie & bere venal' vel locabilis pro lucro ubicunque et quibuscunque residentibus in partibus supradictis & venientibus ibidem apud eandem villam et non alibi tenend' & fiend'. Nec non de assaia et forisfactura hujusmodi panis vini servicie et aliorum victu∣alium quorumcunque ut predicitur venal' vel locabil' pro lucro de correctionibus & puni∣tionibus pro eisdem ibidem faciend' et tenend' et non alibi * * * * etiam de quadam custuma videlicet de quolibet quarterio frumenti ibidem furnato iiiid. Et similiter de tali libertate eidem ville pertinen', quod a toto tempore supradict', aliquis non de∣beret alibi extra villam predictam et libertat' ejusdem in aliquibus partibus inter eandem villam et altum mare adjacentibus aque predict' cum navibus batellis vel aliis vasis qui∣buscunque applicare vel exire, vel ea carrare seu discarrare absque licentia dictorum nunc major' & burgens' & predecessorum suorum predictor' pro tempore existen' nec extra eandem villam mercatum aliquod sacere seu exercere, seldas, macellas vel shamci∣las pro mercibus seu victualibus vendend' conductivas exigere vel locare panem vena∣lem vel alienum pro lucro habendo, furnare. Nec servisia vel beram brasiate ad ven∣dend': neque assaiam, assisam correctionem vel sorisfacturam panis vini servisie aut aliquorum aliorum victualium vel rerum venalium habere seu hospicia communia tabernas herynghowses aut sichhowsis, pro allece albo, rubeo, saltfish: doggedrase, vel Northesesishe in eisdem conficiend', vel exiccandis erigere, tenere nec habere. Sed quod eadem premissa apud dictam villam Novi Castri fierent, tenerentur et haberentur per totum tempus antedictum. Necnon habuerunt et seisiti fuerunt a toto eodem tempore vel de pertinen' sive libertate & consuetudine ville predicte ac percella firme predicte de quodam theolonio sive custum' de omnibus bonis, mercandisis et rebus venalibus ibidem pro sustentatione ville & firme predict' capiend' viz. de qualibet navi extranea mercandis' carrat' et ibidem applicant' 12d. De qualibet navi mercandisis custumalibus carratis ibidem exeunt' 16d. De qualibet celdra carbonum marimorum 2d. De qualibet face' lane 6d. De quolibet dolio sive pipa vini 6d. De qualibet lasta corio∣rum
picis terre vel cinerum, et fraiell cepar' vel 60 barell pro le fraiell 20d. De qualibet centena pellium lanitar' 6d. De qualibet lasta allec' rubei vel barrellat' 20d. De qualibet centena panni linei, alluminis, madicis, * * * * * cere poreti petrar' lini petrar' ferri bundell allii, dogdranes, cultell, bowstafs, vitri sparrs waynscot rygolt masts vel arer' librar' zinziber' galyngal racemor' corane, vel petrar' plum' et bala amigdalor' 6d. De qualibet pensa cepi 8d. De qualibet battell' vel horetac' cum mercandisis ibidem applican' 8d. De quolibet barell allec' quando minus fuerit lasta 6d. De qualibet cado allec' quando minus fuit lasta 1d. ob. De qualibet centena poreti, garba carbonum barell sturgionis, grampeys vel porpas, quolibet panno laneo colorat' vel de ray, quolibet centena de cawdrons vel paiell de meles, stokfishe, sale, vel hoppes & quolibet batteil habent thosts applicant' vel exeunt' 4d. De quolibet duodena de gryndstones 3s. Celdra salis terre vocat Rouchester erth, carbonum vel bladi, quolibet fees de bastes, quolibet cabell empt' vel vendit', qualibet centena petri, walde furrere, et bogge vel de bateria 2d. Et sic de ceteris mercandisis quibucunque & qualibus∣cunque ibidem applicantibus exeunt' vel per terram ad venden' veniend' capiend' con∣simile proficuum, juxta ratam valoris ad qualitatem & quantitatem earundem Et ulterius idem Dominus Rex nunc et omnes predecessores sui predicti a tempore supra∣dicto habuerunt et seisiti fuerunt de dictis redditibus assisis & prisis suis in portu predicto viz. de qualibet navi vino carrat' et ibidem applicant' duo dolia vini unum viz. ante, et aliud retro mastam navis illius ad electionem suam, ad precium utriusque eorundem doliorum 20s. De nave allece carrata, unam centenam allec' absque aliquo inde solvend'. De qualibet navi cum haddock carrat' unam centenam de haddocks: ad pre∣cium 6d. tantum. De quolibet batello cum milnell' vel regadis carrat' unam piscem meliorem absque aliquo inde solvend' Item dicunt super sacramentum suum quod quidam locus vocatus North Sheles qui dudum vocat' fuit Sheles, tantum est contiguus et adjacens aque predicte inter altum mare & dictum locum vocat' Hedwynstremes. Quodque in curia Domini Henrici nuper Regis Anglie, fil' Regis Johannis, apud Novum Castrum coram Roberto de Vesey, et sociis suis nuper justic' ipsius Regis, anno regni sui tertio itinerantibus in com' Northumbrie per consyderacionem ejusdem curie prohibitum fuit tunc priori de Tynemouth quod extunc non faceret aedificia in predicto loco vocat' Sheles ad nocumentum ville predicte, per nomen burgi Domini Regis de Novo Castro & quod non permitteret homines suos ibidem scilicet apud Sheles manentes, panem furnare, nec servisiam brasiare ad vendend', vel alias mercandisas facere, per quod burgus predictus deterioraretur Et quod per 60 annos prox' preterit' prior de Tynmouth, qui nunc est & qui pro tempore fuit successor, predicti nuper prioris et ejusdem loci conventus habentes terras dominicales prioratus sui predicti adjacent' aque predict' apud dictum locum vocat' Sheles, qui nunc vocat' North Sheles, acrochiave∣runt sibi ad easdem terras suas quatuor acr' terre infra aquam predict' et fluxum ac refluxum ejusdem, viz. de dicto solo, nuper aqua cooperto, scilicet apud predict' locum vocat' le North Sheles et per se homines servientes tenentes & firmar' suos super easdem quatuor acras ducent' messuagia hospicia communia hominum et equorum tabernas vinorum er servisie seldas shopas macellas & shamellas conductivas pro victuali∣bus mercandis et aliis rebus venalibus, herynghowses et fishehowses de novo erexerunt, locumque illum villam de North Sheles nominaverunt, prohibitione predict' non ob∣stante; et licet ibidem extra aquam, viz. super ripam ejusdem ex antiquo fuerunt nisi tria cotagia vocat' fisher logges; et ibidem quoddam novum mercatum ad nocumentum dicti mercati ville Novi Castri de novo inchroaverunt, tenuerunt & absque licentia regia usuparunt & habuerunt. Necnon ibidem infra aquam predict' & alibi apud villam Novi Castri predict' prout retroactis temporibus sicri debuit et consuevit absque licentia majoris & burgen' dict' vill' Novi Castri pro tempore existent' aut aliquo super∣visu ministrorum seu officiariorum regiorum ejusdem ville Novi Castri forstallaverunt, re∣grataverunt, carraverunt, discarraverunt, emerunt & vendiderunt, forstallant, regratnt,
carrant, discarrant, emunt & vendunt, absque licentia majoris & burg' vill' pred' omni∣mod' mercandisas victualia & alias res venales que ad predictam vill. N. C. venirent & ibidem (ut predictum est) carrari discarrari, emi & vendi debent & consueverunt Et sic quoddam generale forstallum ac quendam quasi novum portum fictitium apud eundem locum, vocat' le North Sheles fecerunt & dissimulaverunt ac faciunt & dissimulant in presenti ubi prefatus Dominus Rex nunc nullos ibidem habet, nec aliquis progenitorum suorum habuit officiarios neque ministros ad redditus prisas & assisas suos predictos in hac parte capiend' et levand' Per quod idem Dominus Rex et predecessores sui eosdem reddit' prisas & assisas, ac maior & burgenses predicte ville N. Castri pro tempore existent' theolonium & custum' sua predicta per eosdem 60 annos amiserunt ac eorum grave dampnum et exheredationem periculum manifestum et predict' vill' Novi Castri ruinam devastacionem, & perdicionem verisimiliter consequuturas Item dicunt super sacrament' quod per quadraginta annos prox' preterit' prior de Tynemouth predict' qui nunc est & qui pro tempore fuit et ejusdem loci conventus, per se, homines servientes & firmar' suos fecerunt quandam purpresturam infra dictum portum Domini Regis pre∣dict' vill' Novi Castri in aqua de Tyne predict' juxta predictum locum de North Sheles, infra le flude mark super dictum solum nuper aqua coopertum, ubi sit communis con∣cursus et recursus ac pertransitus navium ad eandem villam applicantium & ab eadem exeuntium, ac ibidem de novo fecerunt & erexerunt sibi quasdam stathas, de denariis locandis, viz. anno quarto Domini Henrici nuper Regis Anglie avi Domini Regis nunc, unam statham, longitud' 40 pedum et latitudinis 20 ped' jam in tenura Thome Car∣penter Et unam aliam statham longitud' 60 pedum & latitud' 40 ped' et unam tertiam statham vocat' Muscullstath, jam in tenura Roberti Bull Et anno decimo Domini Henrici nuper Regis Anglie, patris Domini Regis nunc unam statham longitudin' 30 pedum & latitu' 20 ped' jam in tennura Herman Duchman Et anno primo Domini Henrici nuper Regis Anglie patris Domini Regis nunc unam statham longitud' 30 pedum & latitud' 20 ped' jam in tenura Johannis Kirke. Et anno decimo ipsius Regis unam statham longitudin' 60 pedum & latitud' 40 pedum ac desuper statham illam unam domum vocat' herynghowse unum stabulum equinum & unam scalp' pro musculis jam in tenura Ricardi Gaddon Et dicto anno quarto predict' nuper Regis avi unam statham, longitud' 40 ped' et latitud' 30 ped' unam domum desuper statham illam edificatam & unam scalp' jam in tenura Johannis Cooke, unam statham longitud' 40 ped' & latitud' 30 ped' et unam scalp' jam in tenura Willielmi Cunyby Et anno 3o ipsius nuper Regis avi unam statham longitud' 40 ped' & latitud' 30 ped' et unam scalp' jam in tenura Roberti Savage Et anno quartodecimo Regis Richardi Secundi unam statham longitud' 40 ped' & latitud' 30 pedum jam in tenura Roberti Spald. Et dicto anno 4o predict' Regis Henrici avi unam statham longitud' 60 ped' et latitud' 40 ped' et scalp' pro muscul' jam in tenura Joh' Barboz Et anno 8vo Domini Regis nunc unam statham longitud' 20 ped' & latitud' 15 ped' jam in tenura Elizabeth Sheffeld. Et anno decimo predicti Regis Ricardi unam statham longitud' 60 ped' & latitud' 40 ped' ac unam scalp' jam in tenura Roberti Forester. Et anno decimo pre∣dict Domini Regis nunc unam statham longitud' 40 ped' & latitud' 40 ped' et unum herynghouse & unum musculscalp' jam in tenura Johannis Galon ad grave nocumen∣tum dicte ville Novi Castri et populi predictorum exheredacionem corundem majoris & burgensium Item dicunt super sacrament' suum quod per 60 annos prox' preteri prior de Tynmouth predictus qui nunc est & qui pro tempore fuit et ejusdem loci con ventus predict' per se, homines servientes, tenentes & firmarios suos apud dictum locum vocat' North Sheles infra dicta messuagia edificat tenuerunt et exercuerunt ac tenent & exercent in presenti communia furna panis venalis in quibus annuatim furnaverunt panem venalem mille quarteriorum bladi, unum viz. furnum jam in tenura Thome Carpenter, aliud in tenura Roberti Bull, tertium furnum jam in tenura Herman Ducheman, quartum furnum jam in tenura Joh. Kirke, quintum furnum jam in
tenura Ric' Gadden, 6tum furnum jam in tenura Andree Dawes, 7um furnum jam in tenura Joh. Cunyby, 8vum furnum jam in tenura Roberti Savage, 9um furnum jam in tenura Johannis Bell, 10um furnum jam in tenura Roberti Spalde, 11mum furnum jam in tenura Joh. Barbow, 12mum furnum jam in tenura Elizabeth Sheffelde, & 13mum furnum jam in tenura Roberti Forster absque licentia dictorum majoris & burgensium & unde ipsi nullum proficuum habuerunt per quod iidem major & burgenses dictam custumam 4d. de quolibet quarterio bladi sic furnati ut predicitur capiend' si bladum illud apud villam Novi Castri fuisset furnatum, per totum idem tempus amiserunt, qui quidem denar' in toto se attingunt ad mille & quingentas marcas. Item dicunt super sacra¦ment' suum quod prior de Tynemouth qui nunc est & qui pro tempore fuit, ac con∣ventus predict' per se homines tenentes & firmar' suos, per eosdem sexagint' annos, ha∣buerunt et tenuerunt apud predictum locum vocat' North Sheles, infra dict' messuag' edificat' communia brasiatoria, in quibus brasiaverunt annuatim per idem tempu, servi¦siam venalem, duorum millium quarteriorum brasii Nee non assisam, assaiam correc∣tionem & punitionem, panis, vini, servisie et aliorum victualium quorumcunque ibidem tenuerunt, habuerunt & absque licentia regia sibi usurparunt. Ac exitus et pro∣ficua inde, ad ipsos majorem & burgenses de jure pertinent' ad decem libras annuatim ad omnes annos per idem tempus attingen' perceperunt et ad eorum usum habuerunt qui quidem denar' in tot' se atting' ad sexcentas marcas ad annuale dampnum majoris & burgensium ejusdem ville Novi Castri et viginti librarum ultra easdem sexcentas marcas Qui quidem denar' eorundem viginti librarum per totum idem tempus in toto se attin∣gunt ad mille & ducentas libras. Item dicunt super sacramentum suum quod iidem prior & conventus per se homines servientes, tenentes & firmarios suos in forma predicta tenuerunt & habuerunt per idem tempus apud dictum locum vocat' North Sheles pre∣dict' mercat' & communia hospicia omni anno ad dampnum corundem majoris & bur∣gensium annuatim viginti librar' unde summa denar' se attingunt ad mille et decem' libras. Item dicunt super sacramentum suum quod predicti prior & conventus per se ac quidam Johannes de Kirke de North Sheles per se ac Johannem Thornton mona∣chum & celerar' ejusdem domus unam navem per quatuordecim annos ultimos pre∣teritos et iidem prior & conventus per se ac eundem Johan' Thornton monach' & celerar' ejusdem domus unam navem per duos anno; prox, preterits Robertus Bull de North Sheles, unam navem per duodecim annos ultim' preterit' Will' Canyby de North Sheles, tres navem per 40 annos prox' preterit' et Robertus Forstler de North Sheles duas naves per duodecim annos prox' preterit' apud eundem locum vocat' North Sheles infra aquam predictam alibi quam apud villam Novi Castri predict' pro retroactis temporibus debuit et consuevit, tenuerunt & cum et applicaveri exierunt et eas ibidem carraverunt ac discaravernt cum et de metand et bus venalibus omnimodis piscibus. Ac domos vocat' heryng houses ibidem tenue reut ac Allec' album et rubium, salti the dogdrasss et Northfetishe ibidem feo unt et ldt absque supervisu officiator' predicti Domini Regis unde tam idem Dominus Re pre∣dict' pris' & assis' suos quoliet anno ad valorem viint' librarum, quam iidem mao & burgenses & predecessores sui theolomian et al' custom' suas quolibet anno ad valenciam viginti librar' Eo quod per hujusmodi cacionem & distionem conclat' fuerint, amiserunt Item dicunt super sacramentum fuum quod entes predicta priotis & conventus de North Sheles predict' viz. Thomas Tryngg unam per decn annos ultimos clapsos, Hermanus man unam per vi ultimos elapsos, Thomas Carpenter unam eandem per viginti annos ultim' claps Roberto Bull-duas cimbas per novem annos ult' elapson, Johannes Kirke du imbas per viginti annos ultimos elapsos Ric. Gadden unam cimbam per 20 annos ult' eq ss et aliquam unam navim per idem eus, Andreas Deux duas cimbas per 16 annos
uit' elaps' Johannes Conyby unam cimbam per quatuordecim annos ult' elaps' Johanne-Cook duas cimbas per viginti annos ultimos elapsos, Robertus Spalde duas cimbas per 30 annos ultim' elaps' Johannes Barbour unam cimbam per 20 annos ultim' elaps' Eli∣zabeth Sheffeld duas cimbas per 30 annos ult' elaps' et Robertus Forster duas cimbas per 12 annos ult' elaps' apud dictum locum vocatum North Sheles infra aquam pre∣dictam, alibi quam apud villam Novi Castri predicti, prout retroactis temporibus fieri debuit & consuevit de novo retinuerunt et cum eis applicaverunt exierunt easque carraverunt ac discarraverunt cum piscibus et aliis rebus venalibus ad grave nocu∣mentum dictorum portus & ville Novi Castri necnon eorundem majoris & burgen∣sium dampnum annuatim ad valenciam viginti librar'. Item dicunt super sacramen∣tum suum quod prefat' prior & conventus per se & servientes suos de novo fecerunt et levaverunt tres fishgarthes, vocat' salmon yares infra dictos fluxum et refluxum aque predicte viz. infra portum predictum ex opposito cujusdam celle abbie de Durham vocat' Yarowe in tantam stricturam sive arctitudinem portus predicti, quod naves et batelle ibidem, pertransire debentes magnum ibidem sepius incurrunt periculum et naufragium ad grave nocumentum eorundem portus et ville Novi Castri ac totius populi Domini Regis ibidem per transeunt' Item dicunt super sacramentum suum quod predict' prior et conventus perpredict' sexagint' annos prox' elapsos de novo erexerunt, & fecerunt in predictis terris suis apud le North Sheles, mercatum, forum, et vendicionem communia panis vini servilie et vidualium quoruncumque tam nautis & marinariis quam aliis venientibus & residentibus quibuscunque, ad grave nocumentum predict' ville Novi Castri sup' Tynam & totius populi Domini Regis ibidem & ad dampnum eorundem majoris & burgensium annuatim sex librar' unde summa denarior' atting' ad CCC & XL libras. Item dicunt super sacramentum suum quod predict' prior & conventus per se, homines servientes tenentes & firmarios suos, per dictos 60 annos usurparunt sibi & habucrunt ac perceperunt omnimod' wrecca maris et deodanda in∣fra aquam predict' invent' accidentia seu contingen' in partibus supradict' et que ipsi Domino Regi de jure pertinerent, per officiarios et ministros suos viz. majorem te ballivos ejusdem ville Novi Castri seisiend', ad grave nocumentum totius populi Domini Regis tam predicte ville Novi Castri quam omnium partium adjacentium ac vasta∣cionem et finalem diftructionem earundem et precipue dictarum partium Estmarchie versus Scotiam, veresimiliter infra breve consequutur'. In cujus rei testimonium jur' predicti huic inquisicioni sigilla sua apposuerunt. Dat' die anno et loco supradictis.
In the Murry MS. p. 192, is a similar inquisition, dated the day following, i. e. Thursday, 5th January, 25 Hen. VI.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 17. Rotulus Parliamenti de anno regni Regis Henrici Octavi vicesimo primo.
DIV2.P: PARLIAMENTUM inchoatum & tentum apud Fratres Predicatores in civitate London tercio die mensis Novembris anno regni metuendissimi ac potentissimi Domini nostri Henrici Octavi Dei gratia Anglic et Francie Regis Fidei Defensoris et Domini Hibernie vicesimo primo.

Ad laudem et gloriam Dei omnipotentis honorem derorem parem quietem tranqui∣litatem securitatem et reformacionem tocius regni reipublice et dominationis Anglicane
in nomine sancte et individue Trinitatis Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti post missar'— Solempnia decenter et devote celebrata divinoque auxilio humilime implorato et invo∣cato die videlicet Mercurii tercio die mensis Novembris anno regni prepotentissimi Domini Regis Henrici Octavi post conquestum Anglie vicesimo primo existente primo die hujus parliamenti ipso Domino Rege in camera magna infra domum Fratrum Pre∣dicatorum in civitate sua London regali solio sic residente presentibus tune tocius regni Anglie proceribus ac dominis tam spiritualibus quam temporalibus ac etiam commu∣nibus tunc ad parliamentum summonitis ac regio mandato convocatis Thomas More miles cancellarius Anglie causam summonicionis parliamenti prēdicti ex ipsius Domini Regis mandato non minus elegant' et egregie quam graviter sapienter et docte et cum omnium presentium summa laude pronunciavit declaravit et publicavit asserens presens hoc parliamentum summonit' congregatum et inchoatum esse ut que aut hominis incuria vel temporis varietate preteriti bonum publicum antehac in hoc regno Anglie utata et errore permissa fuerant debita nunc correccionis emendacione sagacique providentia et circumspectione reformarentur et castigarentur novaque ubi expediens visum fuerit statuta ac leges nove prioribus adderentur de quibusquidem erroribus et abusibus longa et elegante deseruit oratione qua dictorum abusuum et errorem summam causasque et occasiones eorundem et quid pro eorum reformacione sit faciendum singulari quadam eloquentia et facundia declaravit cui tam excellenti orationi finem tandem imposito idem cancellarius prefatis communibus nomine Regis dedit in mandatis quod in domo sua communi et consueta in crastino convenirent ibidemque unum prolocutorem suum eligerent et sic electum prefato Domino Regi presentarent ceterum ut querelae petitiones et alia in presenti parliamento tractanda commodius intelligantur examinentur et scrutinentur assignati sunt more solito et consueto qui hujusmodi peticiones recipient et qui receptas deliberate invisant et examinent quorumquidem sic ad has seperales provincias assignorum nomina per clericum parliamentorium Gallica lingua prout ex antiquo usitatum est publice lecta fuerunt et declarata ut sequitur.

Hiis tandem folemniter peractis dictus dominus cancellarius jussu et mandato regio propter aeris infeccionem et pestem in locis presenti huic parliamento vicinis sementem et invalescentem presens hoc parliamentum usque in diem sequentem videlicet diem Jovis quartum diem mensis Novembris tunc tenendum apud Westmonasterium in loco consueto continuavit et prorogavit mandans universis proceribus tam spiritualibus quam temporalibus et eciam comunitati ad parliamentum summonitis ac regio mandato con∣vocatis quod dicto die sequente apud Westmonasterium conveniant ibidem super negociis regni colloquium habituris et tracttur'.

Posteaque videlicet die Sabbati quarto die presentis hujus parliamenti ipsi de domo communi coram Domino Rege in presente parliamento tune infra palacium apud Westmonasterium tento comparentes presentaverunt eidem Domino Regi Thomam Audley prolocutorem suum quem prefatus Dominus Rex gratante & benevole accep∣tavit Qui quidem Thomas post excusacionem suam coram dicto Domino Rege factam pro eo quod ipsa sua excufacio ex parte ejusdem Domini Regis admitti non potuies Domino Regi humilime supplicavit quatenus omnia et singula per ipsum in parliamento predicto nomine predicte communitatis proteclatione proferenda et decra∣randa sub tali poffit protestatione proferie er declarare quod si ipse aliqua sibi per prefatos focios suos—ali' quam ipsi concordati fuerint aut ad lendo vel omittendo dec laraven it ea fic declarata per predictos socios suos corrigere et emendae posseti et quod pro∣testacio hujusmodi in otulo parliamenti predicti mactitanetur cui per dominum can∣cellanium de mandata regio extitit responsum quod idem prolocutor tali protestatione fueretur et ganderet quali alii prolocutores tempore nobilium progenitorum ipsius Domini Regis Regiam Anglie in hunodi parliamentis uti et gandere contueverunt.

DIV2.HEAD: An Acte for the Towne of Newe Castell upon Tyne concerning the Shippinge of Merchandize and Unshippinge thereof within the Liberties of the said Towne.
Item quedam alia billa formam cujusdam actus in se continens exhibita est prefato Domino Regi imparliamento predicti cujus quidem bille tenor sequitur in hec verba.
DIV2.P:
HUMBLY SHEWEN to your Highnes your true and faythfull subjectes the where burgeyses and commynaltie of your towne of Newcastel upon Tyne That where your Grace and your moost noble progenytours Kynges of England tyme out of mynde have ben seased of the said towne and of the portes and haven of the ryver of Tyne thereunto belogyng and of all grownde with water covered within the said ryver of Tyne from one place in the mouth of the said ryver called the Sparhawke to one other place in the same ryver called Hedwynstremes in their demeane as of see in right of their crowne of England and as parcell of the same and duryng all the said tyme all maner of person or persons as well freemen as staungers and denyzens applyeing or comyng into the said porte haven and ryver from any parties of beyonde the sea or of this realme of England with shippes or her vessells charged or loden with any maner of wares or merchandyses or shippyng chargyng or lodyng any shippes or vessells with any kynde of merchandyses to be conveyed out of this said porte and haven to any partes of this realme of England or discharge lode of this said realme have alway during all the said tyme used to charge and discharge lode and unlode their said goodes wares and merchandises at the said towne of Newcastell and no where els within the said porte and haven and there have always paid to your said Highnes and your said mooste noble progenitours all customes subsedyes tolles and other thynges due for the same amountyng yerely to the somme of fyve hundred poundes and above whereof your noble progenitours your Highnes and your assigns have ben hytherto duely and truely answeryd and payed as in your Escheken more ample and large doth appere The which your towne of Newcastell is as well in tyme of warres as of peas the chese key relyef and defence of all the parties of this our realme theirunto adjoynyng and by reason of the said liberties and fraunchesses your said towne hath beene to this tyme well replenysshed and mayntened: In so moche as the inhabytauntes of your said towne of late dayes have ben able to serve your Highnes in your wartes with foure hundred maryners or mo apte and able persons for that purpose tyll nowe of late that dyvers gre personages as well spirituall as temporall havyng landes adjoynyng to the porte river betwene the said towne of Newcastell and the see apte and easy for chargyng and dyschargyng of shippes and merchaundises have charged and dyscharged lo dyvers shippes and marchaundyses within the said porte and haven at the said places not paycing therfore any or other dutyes to your Highes by meane whereof your said towne is lykely to to
the country's thereunto adjoynyng and to the great damage of this your realme specyally to all persons nedyng see coles, which be only conveyed from the said porte of Newcastell and in no where els had or to be shypped within thys your realme. In con∣sideracyon therof yt may please your Highnes of your moost habundaunt grace with the assent of your lordes spirituall and the commons of this present parliament assem∣bled and by the auctorite of the same to enacte ordeyne & establyshe that from bensforth any merchaunt or merchauntes or any other person or persons shall not ship lode or unlode charge or discharge any manner of goodes wares or mer∣chaundyses to be solde here within this your realme or elleswhere into or from any shipp or shippes or other vessells in or at any place or places within the said porte ryver and haven betwene the said place called the Sparhawke and the said place called Hedwyn∣emes but onely at the said towne of Newcastell and no where els upon payne of forfeynare of all such goods wares and marchandyses to the Kyng our said soveraigne lorde and to his heirs Kyngs of England and that yt shall be lefull unto the mayre burgeyses and comynaltie of the said towne of Newcastell and their successours and all other the Kynges officers there for tyme beynge for to take and fease all the said such forfeyt goodes wares and merchandyses to the use of our soveraigne lorde the Kynge and of his heyres and the value thereof to be answered in his Eschequer Be yt also enacted and establysshed by the auctorite aforsaid that every owner fermer or occypyer of the said weyres gores and engynes and every of the same do abate put downe and put away the same weyres gores and engynes on thys syde the fest of Ester next comyng and that no maner person or persons from hensforth araise levey or make any maner wayre gore or engeyn in the said haven betweene the said places called Sparhawke and Hedwynstremes upon payne of C. pounds of lawfull Englysshe money for every tyme they do the contrary wherof the one halfe shal be unto owr soveraigne lord the Kinge and the other half to hym or them that wyll sue therfore by action of de byll playnt or informacyon in any of the Kynges courtes wherein the parties defendaunt shall not wage his lawe nor in the accion any essoin lycence ne protectcion be alowed And further yt shal be lawfull at all tymes after the feast of Whytfontide nex comyng to the mayre burgeyses and comynaltie of the said towne of Newcastell and their suc∣cessors to abate plucke downe and take away all and every of the said wayres gores and engynes that shall be than founde standyng in any place wythin the sayd porte and haven betwene the sayd place of Sparhawke and Hedwynstremes, and that hereafter shall be newly made levyed and arrered any where within the same without troble lytte or vexacion of any maner person or persons by sute in the lawe or otherwyse Provyded alwaye that this act be not prejudye yall or hurtfull to any person or persons beyin the Kynges subjectes for beyng shyppyng lodyng or unlodynge of any salte or sye within the said syver and porte or to any of them or any other person or persons repayryng to the said porte with shippes and marchandyses for felling or buying of any wares or marchaundyses nedefull for the vytelling and amendyng of their said shippes at the same of their there beinge within the said porte this acte or any thyng comprysed in the same notwythstanding. Cui quidam bille perecte et ad plenum intellecte per therum Dominum Regem ex assensu et auctoritate parliamenti predicti taliter est respuntiun
This is a true copy of the original record remaining in the Chapple of the Rolls having been examined by me
DIV2.BIBL: HEN. ROOKE, clerk of the Rolls.
DIV2.P: Dorso—Newcastle upon Tyne. Copy of an act of parliament relateing to the ship∣ping and unshipping merchandize within the liberty of the said town 21 Hen. VIII. DENTON, 3 March, 173.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 17.
DIV2.P: OMNIBUS Christi fidelibus ad quos presentes literae pervenerint et quos infra scripta tangunt seu tangere poterunt quomodolibet in futurum Arthurus Plan∣taginer vicecomes Rusley ordinis garterii miles prepotentissimi principis Domini Domini Henrici Ducis Richmondie Somers & Comitis Nottingam magni admiralli Anglie Wallie Hibernie Gascon' Norman' & Acquietan' locum tenens atque vice admirallus salutem in auctore salutis Cum dilectus nobis in Christo magister Johannes Woodhall admiralitatis Anglie commissarius noster generalis privelegia & concession' regum & libertates ab antiquo concess' majori & burgensibus ville Novi Castri super Tinam & successoribus suis imperpetuum vidit inspexit & perlegit et auctoritate nostra examinavit dictos major' & burgenses ville Novi Castri super Tinam usum fuisse et esse a tempore et per tempus immemoratum prout coram dicto nostro commissario plenè liquebat et apparebat et prout in processu coram eo habito et facto liquet et apparet manifeste Cujus quidem processus tenor sequitur et est talis—Sciant presentes & futuri quod ego Johannes Woodhall commissarius generalis et specialis Domini Arthuri Plantaginet vicecomitis Rusley ordinis garterii militis prepotentissimi principis & Domini Domini Henrici Ducis Richemondie Somers & Comitis Notingham magni admiralli Anglie Wallie Hibernie Gascon' Norman' et Acquietan' locum-tenentis arque vice admiralli vidi inspexi & perlegi omnia & singula previlegia concessiones ac donaciones concess' per prepotentissimum principem Johannem Regem Anglie majori & burgensibus ville Novi Castri super Tinam & successoribus suis imperpetuum Necnon et omnes conrirma∣tiones omnium Regum a tempore predicti Regis Johannis una cum confirmatione illus∣trissimi & metuendissimi principis ac fidei defensoris Regis moderni Henrici ejus nomi∣nis Octavi. Quorum quidem privilegior' vigores terre possessiones ac portus omnes et singuli infra dominia et libertates majoris & burgens' ville Novi Castri super Tinam ante∣dict' tam per terras quam per aquas et mare necnon tcnentes firmar' et ceteri ho∣mines omnesque & singuli infra ejusdem libertates ab omnimoda jurisdictione et potes∣tate admiralli Anglie et ossicialium ejus quorumcunque plenarie fuerunt et sunt e∣empti. In tantum cjuod omnes puniciones correcciones deodand' waveson stotteson jetteson lagason et wracks ac alia omnia casualia contingencia quecunque quando∣cunque & qualitercunque per terras aquas et mare cum omnibus et singulis suis per∣tinentibus infra libertates antedict' prefatis majori & burgensibus ville Novi Castri supet Tinam necnon ex consuetudine prescripta a tempore & per tempus immemoratum usitatum pertinet dinoseuntur. Acta suerunt hec omnia pront supra scribuntur et re∣ctantur anno regni Regis Henrici Octavi 19o. vicesimo primo die menfis Junii coram me Johanne Woodhall commissario sive deputato antedicto. Qum quidem processum ac omnia et singula in codem contenta rata & grata, liabentes auctoritate nobis concessa approbanus ratificanius & confirmanus.

In euqus rei testimonium sigillum magnum officii nostri admiralitatis Anglie paedict presentibus apponi mandavmus Dei' London' quoad sigillactionem hujusmodi penul∣presentibus apponi mandavintus De' London' quoad sigillactonem hujusmodi penal∣timo die mensis Julii anno dicti Domini nostri Regis Henrici Octavi 19o.
Dorso " Admiralty NC."
(Grey's MSS. perantiqua manu.)

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 20. An Assignement of the Admirall Jurisdicion.
DIV2.P:
CHARLES Earle of Notingham lord high admirall of England to all officers of the admiraltie and others to whom this present shall come greeting. Knowe ye that for divers consideracions me moving I do by these presents give and grant unto the maior and burgesses of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne in the countie of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne and to their successors full powre and lawfull authoritie to have hould use enjoy and exercise from henceforth during the tyme that I shall have con∣tynaunce tynuance in the office of admiraltie all such admirall jurisdiccion, powre and authoritie as I the said lord admirall, my vice admirall or any my deputies or officers, have, might or ought to have, hould use enjoy or exercise within the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne or the liberties theirof within the haven there, or in any other place or places streames or courses of water extending from a place called Hedwine Streames to a place in the sea called the Sparhawke or in any place or places upon all or any the sands, or within the precincts, limitts or bounds aforesaid. And also all wreck of sea slotzon, jetzon lagon deodands royal fishes and other profitts and commodities apper∣taining or incident to the office or courte of admiraltie, which during the tyme afore∣said shall happen or come upon any of the said sands or within any the said precincts limitts or bounds. And I do further give and grant by these presents unto the sayd maior and burgesses and their successors full powre and lawfull authoritie to hear trie and determine within the said towne or the liberties thereof before the maior and recorder of the same towne for the tyme being or either of them according to the order and cus∣tome of the admiraltie all and all maner of contraversies trespasses contracts debts deteines offences causes and matters whatsoever which shall hereafter during the said tyme arise growe or be done upon the high seas or in any the parts beyond the seas where one partie to the said contraversies trespasses contracts debts deteines offences causes or matters is or shall be dwelling in the said towne of Newcastle or the liberties thereof And for the better executing and performing of all the said jurisdiction powre and authoritie I do by these presents grant unto the said maior and burgesses and their successors that it shall and may be lawfull from tyme to tyme during the tyme aforesaid to and for the maior and the rest of the common counsel of the said towne for they tyme being or the greater part of them whereof the maior and six of the aldermen of the said towne to be seven to nominate appointe ordeine and substitute all such officers and minis∣ters in that behalf as to them shall seem meete and necessarie Prohibiting expresslye and forbiddinge by these presents all other officers and ministers of the admitaltie to inter∣meddle or deale in or about the premisses or any of them on by any means, to molest or trouble the said maior and burgesses on their successors or any other person or per∣sons inhabiting within the said towne or liberties for any cause or matters appertem∣ting or incident to the jurisdiction of the admiraltie (exept for such causes or matters a in or by the proviso hereafter next following are mentioned to be reserved or excepted Provided alwayes that these present or any thing herein encined shall not to any guilt or grant of pirats goods on to the triall of aine pirate or matter of pia or to the tryal of life or member or any cause or matter apperteaning to the jurisdiction of the admiraltie or to tlie debarring or hindering of any the departies officers of any the said lord admirall for ympressing of shipps, manners or others of the
Kings majestie his heirs or successors any thing before mentioned to the contrary not∣withstanding Geven under the hand and seale of me the said lord admirall the 27 Feb. Anno Domini 1605 and in the year of our Sovereign Lord James by the grace of God King of England, Scotland France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith &c. viz. of England France and Ireland the 3 and of Scotland the 39th.
(From a copy in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tyne.)

July 9th, 1739, Jacob Spraggon of South Sheilds having in his custody an anchor which was found in the river of Tyne and is a wreck, and the said J. Spraggon having neglected to deliver the same to or for the use of the mayor and burgesses—It is or∣dered that a regular demand be made of the said anchor, and that if he do not, then to prosecute &c.—Common-councd Book.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 21. (COPY)
DIV2.P:
TO all to whom these presents shall come I Hugh Duke and Earl of Northumber∣land Earl Percy Baron Warkworth of Warkworth Castle lord lieutenant and cof∣tos rotulorum of the counties of Middlesex and Northumberland of the city and liberty of Westminster and of the town and county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, e admiral commissary and deputy in the office of vice admiralty in the county of Nor∣thumberland and town of Newcastle and maritime parts thereof and to the same ad∣joining whatsoever vice admiral of all America, and knight of the most noble order of the garter, send greeting Whereas by letters patent under the great seal of his Ma∣jesty's high court of admiralty of England bearing date the sixth day of May in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and sixty one and of his majesty's reign the first his majesty has been graciously pleased to ordain constitute and depute me the said Duke of Northumberland (during his pleasure only) his majesty's vice admiral com∣missary and deputy in the office of vice admiralty in the county of Northumberland and town of Newcastle and maritime parts thereof, and to the same adjoiningg whatso∣ever with power of taking and receiving all and every the sees profits advantages emo∣ment commodities and appurtenances whatsoever due and belonging to the said office of vice admiral commissary and deputy in the said county of Northumberland and town of Newcastle and maritime parts thereof and to the same adjoining according to the ordinances and statutes of the high court of his majesty's admiralty in England thereby committing and granting to and improwring me the said Duke of Northumberland to do exercise expedite and execute all and every such powers authorities and jurisdictions, acts, matters and things to the said office incident or appertaining within such places and in such manner and form and under and subject to such provisoes restrictions and savings as in the said letters patent are particularly specified mentioned and contained And thereby also impowring me to depute and surrogate in my place for the prettles one or more deputy or deputies as often as I shall think sitt; as by the said letters patent relation being thereunto had may more fully and at large appear Now know ye that
for the special trust and confidence which I have and do repose in Thomas Davidson of the town and county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne Esquire and for divers other good causes and considerations me thereunto moving and by virtue of the power and authoriry to me given in that behalf in and by his majesty's said letters parent; I the said Duke of Northumberland have constituted, deputed, surrogated, and ap∣pointed; and by these presents do constitute, depute, surrogate and appoint the said Thomas Davidson during my pleasure only my true and lawful deputy in the said office of vice admiral commissary and deputy in the office of vice admiralty in the said county of Northumberland, and town of Newcastle and maritime parts thereof, and to the same adjoining whatsoever; hereby authorising and impowring him the said Thomas Da∣vidson for me and in my name and place and during my pleasure to do, exercise, ex∣pedite and execute, all and every such powers, authorities and jurisdictions, acts mat∣ters and things, to the said office incident and appertaining, within all such places, in such manner and form, and under and subject to such provisoes, restrictions and sav∣ings, as in the said letters patent to me granted as aforesaid are specified mentioned and contained and to me thereby committed and granted in as full and ample manner as I myself could might or ought to do, exercise, expedite or execute the same or any of them by virtue of the same letters patent. And further I the said Duke of Northum∣berland do hereby authorize and impower him the said Thomas Davidson during my pleasure only, for me and in my name but to my own and proper use to take and re∣ceive all and every such fees profits advantages emolument commodities and apurte∣nances whatsoever as shall from time to time grow or become due unto me the said Duke of Northumberland as belonging to or by reason of my said office of vice admi∣ral commissary and deputy in the county town and places aforesaid according to the ordinances and statutes of the high court of his majesty's admiralty in England, and by virtue of his majesty's said letters patent from any person or persons whatsoever He the said Thomas Davidson from time to time duly and truly accounting for and paying to me or to such person or persons as shall in that behalf by me be named and appointed by writing under my hand all and every such fees profits advantages emolument com∣modities and appurtenances to the said office belonging as he the said Thomas Davidson shall so from time to time take and receive to my use as aforesaid when and so often and at all and every such time and times as he shall by me be required so to do I the said Duke of Northumberland hereby ratifying and confirming all and whatsoever my said deputy shall lawfully do or use to be done in the premisses by virtue of these presents Given under my hand and seal this eleventh day of November in the seven∣teenth year of the reign of our Sovereign Lord George the Third by the grace of God of Great Britain France and Ireland King Defender of the Faith &c. and in the year of our Lord one thousand seven hundred and seventy-six

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 23. (From a Paper communicated by Mr. Thomas Aubone—Dorso, "Conservator∣ship of the River Tyne 1616.)
DIV2.P: "THE original claim of the mayor and burgesses to the jurisdiction of the river Tyne, was from King Henry the Sixth.

"Queen Elizabeth being humbly intreated by the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle that her majesty would be graciously pleased to grant them a charter of liberties concern∣ing sea-jurisdiction and of admiralty in that port, (to wit) between Sparhawk in the Sea and Hadwyn Streams, being fourteen miles in length, for the advance of the estate of that town, which also was granted as follows:

"The Queen, by her letters patent, dated the 30th day of August, in the 31st year of her reign, touching the office of the high admiralty of the river of Tine and port of Newcastle, grants the reversion to the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, by reason it, was granted under the great seal of England, bearing date the fifth of February, 1522, unto Charles Lord Howard of Effingham, amongst other things, in his said patent in the office of lord high admiral of England, &c. for life, who outlived the Queen, and died 26th January in the sixteenth year of King James.

"King James, in the second year of his reign, being humbly supplicated by the mayor and burgesses of Newcastle, that he would be graciously pleased to confirm all their antient grants and charters, and to give them further powers, especially of the river Tyne, the King confirms these charters, but grants nothing new, only alters the election of their officers, and prescribes them new oaths to be administred to the said officers in their elections, which charter is in the Chapel of Rolls.

"Also, the King and his Council grants them the conservancy of the river of Tyne, by giving nine articles upon the 29th of January, 1613, and joined in the said order the Bishop of Durham and other justices of peace of the county of Durham and Northum∣berland, with the six aldermen of the said town of Newcastle. But three years after the mayor, aldermen and jury of the burgesses, exhibited a great complaint to the king and Council at Whitehall, of the great decay of the river, occasioned by the said commissioners, through their neglect and breach of trust. Which complaint begat this following re∣ference from the council table, and further power to add to the former:

"Whereas, upon complaint of the decay of the river Tyne, and of the daily abuses done and committcd to the prejudice of the same, certain articles were granted on the 29th of January, 1613, and commandcd to be put in execution for the remedy of such abuses: And forasmuch as a jury of Newcastle men have, by their petition to this board, grievously complained those abuses were wholly neglected by the mayor and six aldermen of the same town, and the Bishop of Durham and justices of peace, all which were joint commissioners for the preservation of that river, the river decaying so fall, that in short time it would be dord and wrecked up with sand, &c. if not order soon taken therein: The council ordered Sir Ralph Winwood, Sir Julius Cesar, and Sn Daniel Dun one of the judges of the admiralty, with the assistance of the Trinity Mas∣ters of London, to draw up thirteen articles more, to be joined with the former nine.
And by special order of his majesty's council at Whitehall was given and commanded, that all the said twenty-two articles be put in execution for the conservation and preservation of the river Tyne, by the commissioners hereafter named. Or else to forfeit all the town's liberties into the King's hands. And though the commissioners formerly appointed for the execution of the former articles, are persons of place and quality, and otherwise well deserving of the publick: Yet forasmuch as contrary to the trust reposed in them they have altogether neglected their duty therein, whereof further notice may be taken as occasion shall require: It is thought expedient, that these persons following be named and authorised commissioners for the due performance and execution as well of the said former articles, bearing date the 29th of January, 1613, as of those now de∣vised and published, with the joint consent and good liking of the aldermen of the town of Newcastle, and others attending their lordships in that behalf, for the safety and con∣servancy of that river.

LIST.HEAD: The Names of the Commissioners at Newcastle for the River Tyne.

ITEM.HI: The mayor of Newcastle for time being.

DIV2.HEAD: 29 January, 1613.
DIV2.P: "I. That the owners of every salt-work on either side of the said river of Tyne, built and to be built, do within six months build up their wharfs and keys sufficiently above a full sea mark in height of the water, to be appointed by the mayor and six aldermen, to the end neither coals nor rubbish do fall into the said river.
"II. That all wharfs and keys in all parts of the river of Tyne be dammed and backed with earth, and not with ballast.
"III. That no ballast be cast at Sheilds by any vessel which loadeth either with coals or salt, or other commodities, nor any ballast wharfs to be built there, or used for that pur∣pose.
"IV. That all salt pan owners shall carry away their pan rubbish from off their keys or wharfs every forty days, that none fall into the river.
"V. That no ballast be cast but upon suffcient ballast wharfs, built and to be built above a high water mark, and to be allowed by the major and six aldermen, in any part of the river.

"VI. That the surveyors, unladers and casters of ballast, according to their offices and duties, shall every week cause all the ballast which falls off the ballast shores into the river, to be taken up again and cast upon the ballast wharfs. And to take care that the ships have a good sail to lye between the ship and shore, that none of the ballast fall be∣tween into the river.
"VII. That no coals nor stones be digged within sixty yards on a straight line from a full sea mark in any part of the river, to the end none fall in.

"VIII. That some strt and severe punishment be inflicted by the mayor and six alder∣men upon any such master of ship or keels, as shall presume to cast any ballast upon any in∣sufficient shores, or into the river.

"IX. That there shall be no wyers, dams, or other stoppage, or casting of ballast in or near the said river, or creeks running into the said river of Tyne, or within eight miles of the town of Newcastle, but such as shall be allowed by the mayor and six aldermen of the said town, such shores being sufficiently wharfed."

DIV2.HEAD: Thirteen Articles more granted Feb. 14, 1616.
DIV2.P: "X. That no lighters, beats or keels with ballast be suffered to go up end down the river of Tyne in any night tide, to prevent the keelmen's casting ballast into the river, they often using so to do, being more easy and less labour to cast it into the river, than upon the top of the ballast shores, which spoils the river: the commissioners are to take care herein to see the putting hereof in execution, and punish offenders.
"XI. That strangers shall be appointed every week to cleanse the streets in Newcastle of their ashes and other rubbish, to prevent the rain from washing the same into the river through Load-Burn.

"XII. That all the gates on the Town-Key be locked up every night, except one or two to stand open for the masters and seamen to go to and fro to their ships; which will prevent servants casting ashes and other rubbish into the river. And that those two gates be constantly watched all night long.

"XIII. That all servants dwelling with any the inhabitants residing or inhabiting in the town of Gateshead and Sand-Gate, and the Close in Newcastle, be sworn every year, not to cast any rubbish into the river.

"XIV. Whereas there hath been an antient custom in Newcastle that every mar of any ship, who is known to cast any ballast at sea, between Souter and Hartley, or with∣in fourteen fathom water of the Haven, to the hurt of the said river, was brought into the town chamber, and there in the presence of the people had a knife put into his hand, and was constrained to cut a purse with monies in it, as who should say, in offended in as high a degree as if he cut a purse from the person of a man, whereby he might be so ashamed that he should never offend again therein, and others by his example were terrified from trespassing in the like kind; that now in the time of so ge∣neral wrongs done to the river, and the great number of ships which comes into that haven, this antient custom be revived and put in execution.

"XV. That whereas much ballast falls off into the river of Tyne, between the ships and the ballast shores, in casting it out of the ship, to the great hurt of the same: The commissioners are to set every winter season the poor keelmen and shewel-men on work, to cast into keels such ballast and sand fallen into the river, and then to cast it on the shores or wharf again.

"XVI. That some trusty truly substantial men, burgesses of Newcastle, be appointed to view the river every week, and to make oath for the abuses and wrongs done unto the same, two to be masters of the Trinity-House of that town: they to have no coals, nor mines, nor ballast shores, and to be appointed by the commissioners.

"XVII. That every owner of ground adjoining on that river be ordered to fence the same grounds, to prevent the banks from falling and washing into the river with the great stood slashes nd rains, to the great annoyance thereof.

"XVIII. That the commissioners, namely the mayor and others named before, do give unto the masters and skippers of keels a commission to be a company for the ordering such their brotherhood, and for them to punish such as do cast ballast into the river, or doth other wrong, out of their keels, they having been a company formerly, consisting of one hundred and sixty, which was for the good of the river. That the two great pools of water lying on the back of a ballast shore, be forthwith filled up, to prevent undermining of the shore, to the hazard of the river, if the wall and ballast fall down.
"XIX. That all the ballast-shores in the river of Tyne be constantly kept in good repair, otherwise a hundred thousand tuns of ballast will fall into the river, to the destruc∣tion thereof.

"XX. That no ship or vessel be suffered to load at Shields, or any road-stead in the river, but as near the town of Newcastle as can be, for when they load in remote places, the wrongs cannot be so soon seen.

"XXI. That the commissioners do take good bonds from the owners of such shores as shall be built to lay coals on for ships, and shall take view of such places as shall not do hurt to the said river, either by casting ballast on them indirectly, or to suffer them to go to decay, after there is no use made of them, and to keep the ballast from washing into the river.

LIST.HEAD: "There were present in council that granted these articles.

DIV2.P: "XXII. The council table ordered that Leonard Car and Cuthbert Bewick, two of the com∣missioners which attend this business, be allowed their charges for their pains and attendance, and likewise, that this board might be the better assured with what care and diligence these directions are pursued, that the commissioners do every quarter certifie of the pro∣ceedings herein, that further order might be taken upon any defect that might happen and as shall be found expedient."

DIV2.HEAD: May, 1617.
DIV2.P: "It was further ordered, that the commissioners shall have power for ordering the wharfs and new shoars in every place in that river, after they are once erected, as well for the strengthening, as backing of them with ballast, as with other earth.

"That the commissioners, three at least, shall subscribe every ticket, and the mayor, for the carrying up of every keel of ballast from the ships at Shields to Newcastle ballast shoars for the more faithful execution of that service.

"Ordered, that the commissioners shall have power to order and determine of such re∣wards as shall be given to every wherry-man, or fisher-man, or other that shall truly pre∣sent any offence, or offenders, against any of the articles prescribed, to be taken out of such fines, mulcts and amerciaments, as shall be imposed upon any the delinquents against the said articles.

"Ordered, that the commissioners shall have power to cause the ballast already be∣come noysome, or in any part of the river, or like to do hurt from the land, to be removed to a new wharf or fit place."

LIST.HEAD: Masters fined for casting ballast into the river.

DIV2.P: Captain Gregory Butler, captain of a man of war, took in ballast from a Yarmouth ship at Shields, 1650, the master whereof was fined 5l. and paid 8d. per tun for 48 tun of ballast cast into the man of war.
Richard Nesling, 1652.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 32. (No. 1.) (Copied from the Trinity-House Books.)

LETTER.P: HAVING this day viewed the harbour of Tinmouth, and particularly that part of the entry thereof lying between the Low-Lights and the Black-Middens; I am of opinion that it will be a great addition to the security of vessels entering and going our of the said harbour; if the loose stones that lie scattered upon the North shore, between the Muscle-Scalp and the Prior-Stones, were removed: these stones in some places ex∣tend themselves into the channel, so that ships which happen by accident to take the ground, often receive damage that would be prevented by their removal; and also by affording a greater width and capacity, would greatly add to the convenience of ves∣sels working to windward, either into or out of the harbour.
The rocks called the Prior-Stones, I am of opinion, for the same reason, should be re∣moved and made level; together with such others as obstruct the channel, as far as they can be got at.

The stones that lie near the Black-Middens, may be stowed away in the hollows of this ledge of rocks, so as to strengthen and increase the utility thereof, as a break∣water, and which, if carefully deposited in the method of a pile of cannon-shot, I am of opinion, will lie, where they shall be placed. Those at a greater distance may be laid in the same method, on a ridge extending over the highest part of the ground be∣tween the Black-Middens and the shore; which will also add to the break-water, and in some measure prevent the current from dividing near high-water into two chan∣nels; and as to those stones that lie up still nearer to the Muscle-Scalp, they may be deposited under the high cliffs, which will tend to the defence and security th. Those stones may be removed in different ways; each of which according to ∣stances may have its advantage; and indeed, I would advise them all to be tried, from whence it may be with certainty determined which way is excable at the least charge.
1st. The smaller kind of stones may be moved by hand-barrows.
2d. The larger kind may be split with gun-powder and mauls, and then removed by hand-barrows.
