est alibi inde et super omnibus et singulis causis brevibus querelis actionibus sectis et demandis quibuscunque et super omnibus aliis rebus materiis et causis quibuscunque ac quod dicti gubernator assisten' gardiani et societas mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et rom' ville Novi Castri super Tinam pre∣dictam et sucecssores sui de cetero imperpetuum habeant et habebunt commune sigillum ad omnia et singula cartas evidentias et cetera scripta vel facra ipsos guber∣natorum assisten' gardianos et societatem aut successores suos aut terras tenementa hereditamenta bona seu catalla sua quecunque realia personalia seu mixta aliquo modo tangentia seu concernentia sigilland' Et insuper de uberiori gratia nostra ac ex certa scientia et mero motu nostris ex assensu predicto pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris volumus et concedimus prefatis gubernatori assisten' gardianis et societat' et successoribus suis imperpetuum quod ipsi et eorum successores sint persone habiles et in lege capaces per dictum nomen Gubernatoris Assisten' Gardianor' Societat' Mer∣cator' Venturarior' habitan' infra villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam maneria dominia messuagia terras tenementa et cetera quecunque hereditanienta bona et catalia tam reaa personalia quam mixta capere recipere et perquirere eis et successoribus suis imperpetuum seu aliter tam de nobis heredibus vel successoribus nostris quam de aliis personis quibuscunque seu de alia persona quacunque que illa eis dare concedere lgare vel assignare voluerint vel voluerit Et quod predicti gubernat' assisten' gardiani et societas et successores sui licite et impune possint perquirere capere et recipere omnia et singula tot et talia maneria dominia messuagia terras tenementa et alia heredita∣menta ac bona et catalla quecunque que aliqua alia persona sive alique alie persone eis dare concedere alienare legare seu assignare voluerint seu voluerit habendum tenendum et gudendum eis et successoribus suis imperpetuum vel aliter licet de nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris tent' fuerint vel fuerit in socagio et non in capite statuto de terris et tenementis ad manum mortam non ponend' seu aliquo alio statuto actu pro∣clamacione ordinatione seu lege ante hec tempora fact' vel fiend' in aliquo non obsta dumudo dicta maneria dominia messuagia terre tenementa et hereditamenta sic per eos aut successores suos perquirend' capiend' et recipiend' non excedant clarum annuum valorem quadraginta librarum legalis monete Anglie Ac quod dicti gubernator assisten∣tes gardiani et societas mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam et successores sui per dictum nomen Gubernat' Assisten' Gardianor' et Societat' Mercator' Venturarior' habitan' infra dictam vill' et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam possint omnia et singula predicta maneria dominia messuagia terras tenementa et hereditamenta bona et catalla quecunque per ipsos seu per suc∣cessores suos perquire nel' capiend' vel recipiend' dare alienare dimittere concedere et assignare cuicunque et quibuscunque voluerint Concessimus insuper ac ex assensu predict' per presentes coneedimus prefatis gubernatori assisten' gardianis et societati mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam predict' et suc∣cessor' suis quod gubernator predictus et successores sui gubernatores pro tempore existen' habeat et habeant plenam authoritatem et potestatem capiend' coram se omnimod' recogniciones de quacunque persona de societate predicta, que modo est aut imposte∣rum erit de quacunque pecunie summa et quod eadem recognitio sic coram hujusmodi gubernatore capt' et recognit' tante erit validitatis et efficacie quante alique recog∣niciones que capt' fuerint coram aliquo justic' nostro de com' banco judicialiter ibidem sedente Et insuper de uberiori gratia nostra ac ex certa scientia et mero motu nostris ex assensu predict' volumus concedimus et ordinamus pro nobis heredibus et succes∣soribus nostris quod omnia et singula debita detenciones actiones personal' discordic personales et demand' personalia ac recogniciones concernen' mercandis de cetero con∣tingen' vel emergen' aut capien' infra dictam villam sive com' ville Novi Castri super
Tinam predict' vel extra, inter aliquos tantum de predict' societate mercator' ven∣turarior' habitan' infra dictam villam vel com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam ac placita et execuciones eorundem sint et erunt de cetero determinabilia determinand' judica∣bilia et judicand' per prefatos gubernatorem assisten' et successores suos pro tempore existen' et coram eis et successoribus suis imperpetuum vel per majorem parterm predictor' gubernatoris et assissten' pro tempore existen' qui tune erunt infra dictam viliam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam ac eisdem modo et forma prout aliqua placita infra stapula ville Calisie sive Westm' virtute actus in parliamento Domini Edwardi quondam Regis Anglie tertii progenitoris nostri anno regni sui vicesimo septimo tent' et edit' ordinare et determinare deberent Preterea de ubenori gratia nostra ac ex certa scietia et mero motu nostris ex assensu predict' volumus concedimus er ordinamus pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris per presentes presatis gubernatori assisten, gardianis et societati mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam predict' quod gubernator societatis pro tempore existen' ac assulentes et societas predict' vel eor' major pars pro tempore existen' qui tune ejunt infra dictam villam et com' ville predicte habeant et habebunt auctoritatem et potestatem de tempore in tempus imperpetuum edendi faciendi et condendi pro bono publico ejusdem societatis ac pro salubri gubernacione ejusdem viile et com' ville predicte leges statuta et ordinaciones tantummodo concernen' illos qui sunt vel erunt de eadem societate ac illa leges slatura et ordinacionts licite et impune in predicta villa et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam de tempore in tempus prout res postu∣labit seu aliter exequi et uti ac etiam ea et eorum quodlibet prout eis melius videbitur juxta eorum discretiones alterare et mutare possint et valeant de tempore in tempus imperpetuum ac eos qui hujusmodi leges et ordinaciones sic dandas infregerint et violaverint per fines et amerciamenta punire et mulctare et eadem fines et amerciamenta per debitum processum levare et capere ad usum dicte societatis Et ulterius de uberiori gratia nostra speciali ac ex certa scientia et mero motu nostris ex assensu pre∣dict' concedimus et damus pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris per presentes presat' gubernatori assisten' gardianis et societati mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam predict' et cuilibet de eadem societate qui modo est aut impoilrum erit et successoribus suis imperpetuum quod iidem gubernator assisten' gardiani et societas et successores sui et quilibit de eadem societate qui modo est aut impoilerum erit de eadem societate de tempore in tempus durante beneplacito nostro qualcunque lanas et pellas lamtas de crescen' com' nostror' Northum' Cumbr' et Westmor' et episcopatus Dunclm' nee non dominior' libertatum de Allerton et Richmond seu eor' aliquo (lanis illis et pellibus lanitis de partibus com' Northum' ad villam nostram Berwici assign' tanmodo except') emere et pros idore lanas et pellas lanitas illas (except is preexceptis) et in portu dicte ville Novi Castri super Tinam in quibuscunque navibus sive vasis omnibus temponbus anni quibus comodius et convenientius fieri potent eskippari facere durante beneplacito nostro lanasque et pellas lamtas predictas ad qualcunque partes extes ad libm suum de tempore in tempus durante beneplacito nostro traducere carcare traduci et camari facere possim et quilibet cor' facere possit licite et unpune et absque impericione impedimento seu perturbacione nostri herecum vl successor' nostri aut ossiciarior' ministror' aut hered' seu successor' nostror' quorumcunque aut alterius persone cujuscunque solven' nobis heredibus et successor' nostris pro quolibet sacco dictar' lanar' pro customi, et subssides et alris denariis nobis, inde debu' decem solidos tantum et non ultra et pro quibuslibet ducentis et quadiginta pellibus lamtis decem solidos tantum et non ultra pro custumis et subsid' nobis inde debit' nec non pro pellibus voc' shorling el mor∣lyng, nec non pro pellibus agnelimis custumas sund' et alios denarios nobis ante hec
tempora debit' et consuet' dict' custum' subsid' et alios denarios pro dictis lanis et pel∣libus lanitis per predictos mercator' venturarior' de predicta societate mercator' ven∣turarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam vel per eor' aliquem debit' custum' sive collectoribus custum' et subsid' nostror' predict' in portu predicto Et ulterius volumus et concedimus ex assensu predict' pro nobis here∣dibus et successoribus nostris prefatis gubernatori assisten' gardianis et sociecati mer∣cator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam et cuilibet ejusdem societatis durante dicto beneplacito nostro tam eadem societas et quilibet de eadem societate et cujuslibet eor' factores et attorn' custum' et collectores custum' et subsid' nostror' in portu predicto pro tempore existen' de omnibus et omnimod' pecuniar' summis seu aliquibus aliis custum' subsid' denar' ex accionibus et demandis que ab antiquo ab ipsis seu eor' aliquo ad opus nostror' seu heredum aut successor' nostror' pro premissis seu eor' aliquo beneplacito nostro predicto duran' exigi poterint seu unde ipsi aut eor' aliquis erga nos heredes et successores nostros impeti aut onerari poterint erga nos hered' et successor' nostros exonerentur acquietantur et eor' quilibet exoneretur et acquietetur preterquam de custumis et subsid' nostis per ipsos de dicta societate et per eor' quemlibet' aut ejus vel eorum factores ordinat' et con∣stitut' per fact' eor' sigillat' communi sigillo predicto societatis modo et in forma predict' solvend' Denique volumus et ex certa scientia et mero motu nostris ex assensu predict' per presentes concedimus prefatis gubernatori assisten' gardian' et societat' mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam quod habeant et habebunt has literas nostras patentes sub magno sigillo nostro Anglie debito modo factas et sigillatas absque fine seu feodo magno vel parvo nobis in Hanaperio nostro seu alibi ad usum nostrorum quoquomodo reddend' solvend' vel faciend' eo quod expressa mentio de vero valore annuo aut de certitudine premissor' sive eor'alicujus aut de aliis donis sive concessonibus per nos vel per aliquem progenitor' nostror' pre∣fatis gubernatori assisten' gardian' et societati mercator' venturarior' habitan' infra pre∣dictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam ante hec tempora fact' in pre∣sentibus minime fact' existit aut aliquo statuto actu ordinatione promisione sive restriccione inde in contrarium fact edit' ordinat' seu provis' aut aliqua alia re causa vel materia quacunque in aliquo non obstan' In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri facimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westm' primo die Septembris anno regni nostri primo.

POSTSCRIPT.P: There is an act for encouraging of merchant adventurers for discovering new trades, 8 Eliz. Vid. Hackluit's Voy. 394, a proviso about Newcastle, 397.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 227. (No. 2.) Queen Mary's Confirmation of the Charter, dated 1st September, 1 Ed. VI. to the Merchant-Adventurers. N. B. This original, by whatever means, is now in the archives of the corporation of Newcastle upon Tynt.

LETTER.P: MARIA Dei gratia Angiie Francie et Hibernie Regina Fidei Defensor et in terra ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernice supremum caput omnibus ad quos presentes pervenerint salutem Inspeximus cartam Domini Edwardi nuper Regis Anglie sexti fratris nostri precharissimi in hec verba. "Edwardus Dei gratia, &c. &c. &c."
N. B. This of Edward VI. is dated "primo die Septembris anno regni nostri primo."

NOS autem (scilicet Maria) cartam predictam ac omnia et singula in eadem con∣tenta rata habentes et grata ea pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris quantum in nobis est accepramus et approbamus ac dilectis nobis nunc gubernatori assistentibus gardianis et societati mercatorum venturariorum habitantium infra predictam villam et comitat' vilie Novi Castri super Tynam et eorum successoribus imperpetuum tenore presencium ratificamus et confirmamus prout carta predicta rationabiliter inde testatur. In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipsa apud Westmonasterium quinto decimo die Novembris anno regni nostri. (Unfortunately there is a hole worn in the place where the last word has been. It ought to be "primo." It appears so by the confirmation charters.)

CLOSER.SIGNED: LE HARE. Taxatur finis ad viginti solidos Ste' Winton cancell'. Exa' per nos Ricardwn Redect et Willielmum Gunsted Clericos.

POSTSCRIPT.P: The seal is sewed up in a leathtrn cover.

DIV3.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 231. Extract of the confirmation part from the original Confirmation Caharter of 2 James I. to the Merchants Company of Newcastle upon Tyne, in their possession.
DIV3.P:
JACOBUS Dei gratia Anglie Scotie Francie et Hibernie Rex Fidei Desensor &c. omnibus ad quos presntes litere pervenerint salutem. Inspeximus literas patentes Domine Elizabethe nuper Regine Anglie sorotis nostri precharissime de consirmatione factas in hec verba: Elizabeth Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Regina Fideri
Defensor omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Inspeximus literas patentes Domine Marie nuper Regine Anglie sororis nostre precharissime de confirma∣tione factas in hec verba: Maria Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Regina Fidei Defensor et in terra ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernice supremum caput omnibus ad quos presentes littere pervenerint salutem Inspeximus cartam Domini Edwardi nuper Regis Anglie sexti fratris nostri precharissimi in hec verba: Edwardus sextus Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Rex Fidei Denfensor et in terra ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernice supremum caput omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem Sciatis quod nos ob amorem et favorem quos erga villam nostram Novi Castri super Tinam ac com' ejusdem ville et erga illos dilectos et fideles nostros mercatores, &c, &c.— See Edward's Charter at full length.

DIV3.HEAD: (The confirmation part of James begins thus.)
DIV3.P: NOS autem cartam et literas predict ac omnia et singula in eisdem contenta rata habentes et grara ea pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nortris quantum in nobis est acceptamus et approbamus ac dilect is nobis nunc gubernatori assistentibus gardianis et societati mercatorum venturariorum habitantium infra predictam villam et com' ville Novi Castri super Tinam et eorum successoribus in perpetuum tenore presentium ratisicamus et confirmamus prout carta et litere predicte in se rationabiliter testantur. In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westmonasterium quarto decimo die Aprilis anno regni nostri Anglie Francie et Hi∣bernie secundo et Scotie tricesimo septimo.

CLOSER.SIGNED: Pro quatuor libris solut' in Hanaperio. LUKYN. Taxatur finis ad iiii. lib. J. Ellesmere, canc'. Exam' per nos Mattheum Carew et Johannem TyndaleJ Clericos.

POSTSCRIPT.P: Fine impression of the great seal on green wax, in good preservation.—See plate of the great seal of this reign in Speed.

DIV3.HEAD: Extract of the confirmation part from the original Confirmation Charter of 1 of Eliz. to the Merchants Company in Newcastle upon Tyne, in their possession.
DIV3.P: ELIZABETHA Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Regina, Fidei Desensor, &c. omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem. Inspeximus litteras patentes; Domine Marie nuper Regine Anglie sororis nostre precharissime de confirmatione factas in hec verba: Maria Dei gratia Anglie, Francie et Hibernie Regina Fidei Defensor et in terra eccelesie Anglican' er Hibern' supremum caput omnibus ad quos presentes litere pervenerint salutem. Inspeximus cartam Domini Edwardi nuper Regis Anglie sexti fratris nostri precharissimi in hec verba: Edwardus, &c. &c.—See Edward's Charter at full length.

DIV3.HEAD: (The confirmation part of Elizabeth begins thus.)
DIV3.P:
NOS autem cartam et literas predictas ac omnia et singula in eisdem contenta rata habentes et grata ea pro nobis heredibus et successribus nostris quantum in nobis est. acceptamus et approbamus ac dilectis nobis nunc gubernatori assistentibus gardianis et societati mercatorum venturariorum habitantium infra predictam villam et comuinitat' ville Novi Castri super Tinam et eorum successoribus in perpetuum tenore presentium
ratificamus et confirmamus prout carta et litere predicte in se rationabiliter testantur. In cujus rei testimonium has literas nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipsa apud Westmonasterium decimo die Maii anno regni nostri primo.

CLOSER.SIGNED:
H. CORDETT, Pro quinquaginta tribus solidis et quatuor denariis solutis in Hanaperio. Taxatur finis ad 53s. 4d. Exam' per nos
Ricardum Rede
et Kuthbert Huse
Clericos

POSTSCRIPT.P: The seal or remains of it, is sewed up in a leathern bag.—See plate of the great seal of this reign in Speed.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 271. (No. 1.)
DIV2.P:
TO all Christian people to whome this present wrytynge shall come, the Governor and Stewards and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hostmen of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the countye of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, send greeting in our Lord God everlastinge: Whereas yt hath alwaycs pleased the Queenes most excellent majesty, of her gratious and pryncely inclynation from tyme to tyme most gratiously to affect and tender the good estait of the said towne of Newcastle and the inhabytants therof, and of late of her further grace for the generall profytt and como∣ditye of the same towne, by her highnes letters pattent bearinge date at Westmynster the two and twentieth day of March, in this present two and fortieth year of her Majesties reign, it hath pleased her Highness gratiously to confirme and grant as well unto us the said Governor and Stewards and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hostmen of Newcastle aforesaid, and our successors, as also to the Mayor and Burgesses of the same towne and their successors, divers and sundry immunityes and privileges, with con∣firmation of the antient libertyes of the said towne, and with dispensation of sundry statutes, and release of the forfeitures specifyed in the said statutes, principally for and concerning the loading and unloading of sea cole and stone within the ryver of Tyne, as in and by the said letters pattents more fully yt doth and may appeare. Nowe knowe yee therefore, that wee the said Governor and Stewardes and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hostmen aforesaid, with the consent, good lyking and approbation of the Mayor and Burgesses of the same towne for the tyme being, in regard of these gracious and most princely favours and benignityes, being desirous to our uttermost powers to shew ourselves thankfull for the same, and not being ignorante of the greate, unsupportable and excessive charge which her Highness hath of late susteyned, and likelye to be at in and for the defence of this realme, and her Highness' pore subjects, against the malice and force of the enemyes of this realme, have given and granted, and by these presents for us and our successors do in all humylyty give and grant unto her most excellent Majesty, her heirs and successors, to the use of her Majesty, her heirs and successors for ever, for each and every and for such and so many chaldron and chaldrons of sea cole, stone cole, or pyt cole of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid, as at any tyme or tymes hereafter shall be sold, shipped, carryed
or vented by any person or persons whatsoever, forth or out of the haven or ryver of Tyne, belonging to the foresaid towne of Newcastle, to be spente within this realme, and not transported beyond the seas, the several some of 12d. of lawful money of Eng∣land, to be paid by us and our successors unto our said soveraigne Lady, her heirs and successors, before any ship or other vessel Wherein any such coles shall be laden, shall at any tyme or tymes hereafter be cleared or discharged forth of her Majesty's custom-house in the said towne of Newcastle (coles sold and carryed from the said porte of Newcastle to Hartlepool to be ymployed and spent in and about such salt-pans as now be within Hartlepool aforesaid, and appertaining to the right honourable the Lord Lumley, his heirs or assigns, or any of the burgesses of the said towne of Newcastle only excepted). And further, wee the said Governor and Stewards and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hostmen aforesaid, do by these presents for us and our successors covenante, promise and grante to and with our said soveraigne Lady the Quenes Majesty, her heirs and successors, from tyme to tyme well and truely to yeild and pay unto our said soveraigne Lady the Quenes Majesty, her heirs and successors, or to such of the officers, farmers or assignes of our said soveraigne Lady, her heirs and successors, as by the grante, commandment or direction of her Highness, her heirs and successors, shall from tyme to tyme be authoryzed or appoynted to take, collect or receive the same, the said sum of 12d. of lawful English money for each and every and for such and so many chaldron and chaldrons of the said sea coales, stone coles, and pytt coles, as so at any tyme or tymes hereafter shall be soulde, shipped, caryed or vented forth as is aforesaid, to be spente within this realme of England, and not transported beyond the seas (except only as before in these presents is excepted), without any concealment, dyminution, or other indyrect meanes or practice whatsoever. In wytness wherof, as well wee the said Governor and Stewards and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hostmen of the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the countie of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, as also the Mayor and Burgesses of the said towne of Newcastle, have to this present wryting set our several common seales. Yeoven at the aforesaid towne of Newcastle, the 8th daie of April, in the 42d year of the reign of our said soveraigne Ladye Elizabeth, by the grace of God Quene of Eng∣land, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
N. B. The above copy is taken from one which was examined with a copy of the record taken 22d February 1711.—Exam. per Edw. Coke.
And was collated Dcc. 16th, 1778, with a copy in the archives of the fraternity. J. B.
The following note occurs under a copy of the above grant in the Murray MS. p. 174.

"For the better testimony that this is a true coppie as the same was and yet standeth recorded out and by the principall grante of the premisses into a booke of inrolments in such cases used, remayneing here in Newcastle, wee the abovenamed Mayor and Burgesses have hereunto caused our said common seale to be affixed at Newcastle aforesaid, the 10th day of April, Anno Domini 1610."

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 271. (No. 2.) Hoastmen's Charter from Queen Elizabeth. (Old Translation from the original Latin.)
DIV2.P:
ELIZABETH, by the grace of God of England, France, and Ireland, Queen, Defender of the Faith, &c. to all to whom these our letters shall come, greeting: Whereas the town of Newcastle upon Tyne is an ancient towne, &c. and whereas the maior and burgesses of the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, deeply weighing and pondering the effect of divers charters and letters-pattents made theretofore into them by us and our progenitors, kings of England, containing divers privileges, immunities, and jurisdictions given and granted unto them by the same; and whereas the aforesaid town of Newcastle upon Tyne is an ancient town, and the maior and burgesses of the said town have, and from the time whereof the memory of man is not to the contrary, have had within the said town a certain guild or fraternity commonly called Hoastmen, for the loading and better disposing of sea coales and pitt coales, and stones called grind-stones, rub-stones, and whet-stones, in, upon, and within our river or port of Tyne, which said guild or fraternity is granted or established by none of the said charters or letters-pattents: whereupon the mayor and burgesses of the said town have been humble supplicants unto us, that we would graciously and bountifully shew and extend munificial and royal favour in supplying the aforesaid wants, and that we for the better government of the said fraternity of the hoastmen, would vouchsafe to make, reduce, and create the same into a body corporate and politick; we, therefore, in that behalf agreeing and inclining to their request, that from henceforth a certain, sure, and un∣doubted manner be had for the better loading and disposing of sea coales and stones in, upon, and within the aforesaid river or port of Tyne, and for the more easie maintain∣ing of the charges and payments which dayly do press the same fraternity, out of our cer∣tain knowledge and mere motion, have willed, ordained and constituted, and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, will, ordain, constitute and grant, that our trusty subjects William Jenison the elder, William Selby, Henry Anderson, William Riddle, Henry Chapman, George Farnaby, Lionel Maddison, Thomas Liddle, Hobert Dudley, George Selby, Francis Anderson, George Briggs, Adrian Hedworth, William Huntley, Nicholas Tempest, William Hodgshon, George Dent, Robert Anderson, Francis Liddle, Edward Bartram, Christopher Eylmer, John Watson, John Barker, Rowland Tempest, Anthony Morpith, Nicholas Ponder, Robert Shaftoe, Christopher Midford, Matthew Chapman, Henry Maddison, Robert Dent, William Simpson, Bartram An∣derson the elder, Isaac Anderson, Robert Gibson, Thomas Bowmer, Parcivall Ayre, Edward Hall, John Greenwell, Thomas Hall, William Jennison the younger, Henry aw, Edward Crome, Timothy Draper, William Bonner, John Rand, John Stranguish, and William Jackson, commonly called the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and being brethren of the said fraternity, and all others which now are, or here∣after shall be elected, admitted and taken into the aforesaid guild or fraternity of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, from henceforth for ever, shall and may be one body corporate and politic, in matter, deed, and name, by the name of Gover∣nor and Stewards and Brethren of the Fraternity of Hostmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne; and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, we do establish, make, ordain, and appoint them by the name of Governour, Stewards and Brethren of the Fraternity of the Hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, one body corporate and politic really and fully, and that they may have perpetual succession
by the same name, and they may be for ever hereafrer able and capable persons in law to have, obtain, receive and possess lands, tenements, liberties, jurisdictions, franchises and hereditaments whatsoever, of whatsoever kind, nature, or quality they be, to them and their successors for ever, or assign the same lands, tenements, and hereditaments, and to do and execute all and singular other things and causes by the aforesaid name, and that by the same name they may and can plead and be impleaded, answer and be answered, defend and be defended, in whatsoever courts and places within this our realm of Eng∣land, and before whatsoever our judges and justices and other persons and officers what∣soever of us, our heirs and successors, in all and singular actions, suits, pleas, com∣plaints, causes, matters and demands whatsoever, in the same manner and form as other our liege people of this our realm of England, being able and capable persons in law, may and can plead and be impleaded, answer and be answered, defend and be defended, have, obtain, receive, possess, give, grant, and demise; and that the aforesaid governor and stewards and brethren of the fraternity of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, may have for ever a common seal; and that it is and shall be lawful for the said governor and stewards and fraternity of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, at their pleasure from time to time to break, alter, and make anew the said seal, as shall seem most expedient to them. And further our pleasure is, and we have ordained and constituted, and for us, our heirs and successors do ordain and constitute, that there may and shall be for ever hereafter one discreet and honest man amongst the aforesaid number of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, who yearly upon the fourth of January shall be chosen, named, and appointed by the said brethren of that fraternity, or the greater part of them, to be governor of the aforesaid fraternity; and then they shall take a corporal oath for the due executing of the said office of governor, to remain in that office for one whole year then next following (if he so long live); and that in like manner there may and shall be for ever hereafter two honest and discreet men of the said number of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, who yearly on the said fourth day of January shall be thereof named and appointed by the said governor and stewards and brethren of the aforesaid fraternity, or the greater part of them, to be stewards of the said fraternity; and that either of them in like manner shall take a corporal oath for executing of the said office of steward, and either of them to remain in his office for one whole year then next following (if he shall then so long live). And for the better execution of these presents, and that our will in the premises may have and take better effect, we have assigned, named, and constituted and established, and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, do assigne, name, constitute and establish our well beloved subject, William Jenison the elder, to be the first and present governor of the aforesaid fraternity, willing that the said William Jenison shall remain in the office of governor, and that he shall and may remain in the said office from the date of these presents unto the said fourth day of January next coming, and from the said fourth day of January until some other of that fraternity be duly elected, appointed, and sworn to the said office of governor of the fraternity aforesaid (if the said William Jenison shall happen so long to live). Moreover we have assigned, named, constituted and appointed, and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, do assign, nominate, constitute and appoint our trustie subjects, Francis Anderson and John Barker, to be the first and present stewards of that fraternity, willing that the aforesaid stewards remain in the said office of a steward, and there either of them be and remain in the said office from the date of these presents until the said fourth day of January next coming, and from the said fourth day of January until some others of that fraternity shall and may be duly elected, appointed, and sworne to the said office of steward of the fraternity aforesaid (if the said Francis
Anderson and Jno. Barker, or either of them, shall happen so long to live). Also we will, and by these presents grant for us, our heirs and successors, that if it shall happen that if the governor of the fraternity, for the time being within appointed to the office of governor, die, depart, or for some other reasonable cause be removed or displaced from this office of governor aforesaid, that then, and from time to time, and so often as it shall happen, the said stewards and brethren of the fraternity for the time being, or greater number of them, may and shall have by these presents full power and authority to choose, name, and appoint one other honest and discreet man, of themselves, to be governor of the said fraternity; who being so chosen, named, and appointed to the office aforesaid, may have and exercise that office for the residue of that year then to come, having first taken his corporal oath for the due executing of that office; and if it shall happen that the said stewards of that frater∣nity, or any of them for the time being, die, depart, or for reasonable cause be dis∣placed or removed from his office, that then also from time to time, and so often as it shall so fall forth, the said governor and brethren of the fraternity for the time being, or the greater part of them, likewise may and shall have by these presents full power and authority to chuse, name, and appoint one other, or others, honest and discreet men amongst themselves to be steward or stewards of the said fraternity, in the place or places of such dying, departing, displaced, or removed, who may exercise that office for the residue of the year henceforth to come, having first taken his or their corporal oath or oaths for the due executing of that office. Moreover we will, and for us, our heirs and successors, give and grant by these presents to the said governor, stewards, and brethren of the fraternity of hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, that the said governour, stewards and brethren of the said fraternityof the hostmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, whereof we will that the said governor of the fraternity and the said stewards be three, or the said governor or one of the said stewards be two, may and shall have at all fit times for ever hereafter full power and authority to assemble and meet together in their Guildhall, or in any other convenient place within the aforesaid town, and there appoint, make, ordain, and establish, from time to time, such laws, orders, acts, ordinances and decrees as shall seem to be good, wholesome, profitable, honest and necessary to the said governor, stewards and brethren of the fraternity aforesaid, or the more part of them, whereof we will that the said governor and stewards be three, or the said governor or one of the said stewards be two, according to their good direction, for the better ordering and government of the governor, stewards and brethren of the fraternity afore∣said, and for the declaring in what manner and order the said govenor, stewards, and their factors, servants and apprentices shall behave, carry, and use themselves in their offices and business concerning the said fraternity, and otherwise for the further public good of the said governor, stewards and brethren of that fraternity, whereof we will th the said governor and stewards be three, or the said governor and one of the said stewards be two, so often as they shall appoint, make, ordain, or establish such law, orders, acts and decrees in manner aforesaid, they shall and may impose, make, ordain, limit and provide such pains and punishments, penalties, and imprisonment of body, or by fines or amerciaments, or both of them, against and upon all offenders against such laws, orders, acts, ordinances and decrs, or any of them, as shall seem better for the said governor, steward, and brethren of the said fraternity, or the greater part of them; whereof we will that the said governor and stewards be three, or the said governor and one of the said stewards be two, to be necessty and requisite ob∣serving of the said laws, ordinances and decres, and they shall and have and retain the same lines and amerciaments by their directions, means, to them and their successors, to the use of the governor, stewards and brethren
of the fraternity aforesaid, without vexation or impediment of us, our heirs or successors, or any other, or any of our officers, ministers, or of our heirs or successors, all and singular what law, ordinance and decrees, acts and orders, so as aforesaid to be made, we will shall be observed upon the pains in the same contained, yet so as such laws, orders, ordinances and decrees be not repugnant or contrary to the laws and statutes of this our realm of England. Moreover we will, and for us, our heirs and successors, give and grant to the said governor and stewards and brethren of the fraternity of the hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, that from henceforth for ever the said governor, stewards and brethren of the said fraternity, and their successors, or the greater part of them, whereof we will that the said governor and stewards aforesaid be three, or the said governor and one of the said stewards be two, may and shall have full authority and power from time to time, at their pleasure, to chuse, name and ordain others, being in∣habitants of the said town, and burgesses of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, to be brethren of the said fraternity, every one so elected and named having first taken a cor∣poral oath to observe the ordinances and statutes of the said fraternity, who being so chosen, named and sworne, shall be called and be brethren of that fraternity. Moreover, of our special grace, certain knowledge, and mere motion, we have given and granted, and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, do give and grant liberty, power, and authority, by these presents, to the said governor and stewards and brethren of the fraternity of the hoastmen in the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, and their successors, that the governor, stewards and brethren of the said fraternity for the time being, and their successors, and every of them for ever hereafter, shall and may quietly and peaceably have, hold, use and enjoy all and singular such liberties, privileges, immunities, jurisdictions, uses and customes, and every of them, for and concerning the loading and unloading, charging and dis∣charging of sea coals, stone coals, and pit coals, and stones called grindstones, rubstones, and whetstones; and that they, and every of them, shall and may for ever hereafter load and unload, charge and discharge, in or out of any ships, barks, or vessels, coals and stones aforesaid, in any place or places within our said river and port of Tyne, as shall seem more expedient unto them, in any place or places between the said town of Newcastle and the aforesaid places, being in the said river, called the Sparhawke, so near the said town of Newcastle upon Tyne as conveniently may be, according to our true meaning expressed before in these presents, as the men and brethren of the said fraternity at any time have used or accustomed; notwithstanding the statute holden in the parliament of our most dear father King Henry the VIIIth, begun at London the 3d day of November, in the 21st year of his reign, and from thence adjourned to West∣minster, in the county of Middlesex, published and intitled "an act concerning New∣castle upon Tyne, and the port and haven thereunto belonging," or any other acts, ordinance, or proclamation, or restraint, to the contrary notwithstanding. Also we will, and by these presents grant to the said maior and burgesses that they may and shall have these our letters patent, in due manner made and sealed under our great seal of England, without fine or fee, great or small, to be yielded, paid, or made therefore to us in our Hanaper, or elsewhere, in any manner to our use, for that the express mention of the true yearly value or of the certainty of the premises, or any of them, or of any other gifts or grants heretofore made by us, or any of our progenitors, to the aforesaid maior and burgesses of the said town is not made in these presents, or any other statute, act, ordinance, promise, or restraint thereof, heretofore had, made, published, ordained, or provided, or any other cause, thing, or matter whatsoever in any wise notwithstanding. In testimony whereof we have caused these our letters to be made patent. Witness myself at Westminster, the 22d day of March, in the two and fortieth year of our reign.

LIST.HEAD: Governors of the Hostmen's Company, Chosen annually January 4th.
LIST.ITEM: 1617. Mr. James Clavering No entry in the old book of any governor till
1627. Mr. Peter Riddell None afterwards till

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 298. (No. 1.) Grant of One Shilling per Chaldron to the Duke of Richmond by King Charles II.

Q.P: (From an authenticated or office copy on stamped paper in the possession of the Hoastmen's Com∣pany, communicated by Alex. Adams, Esq Steward.
Copy of Grant of 1s. per Ch. on Coals shipped in the River Tyne to the Duke of Richmond.

A private Act for varying and pestponing certain Limitations in a Grant made by King Charles the 2d of a Duty on Coals shipped on the River Tyne, to Charles late Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and for enabling the pr Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny to make a Jointure on his intended Marriage with Lady Mary Bruce.

DIV2.P: (See this at full length afterwards.)
Decima Pars Paten' de Anno Regni Regis Caroli Secundi vicesimo nono.

D Con' Duke of Richmond's Grant (3)CHARLES the Second &c. to all whom these presents shall come greeting Whereas the governors stewards and brethren of the fellowship of the hoastmen of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne by their writing sealed as well with their common seale as that of the mayor and burgesses of the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne bearing date the eighth day of Aprill in the two and fortieth yeare of the reigne of the late Queen Elizabeth did for them and theire successors give and grant unto the saide late Queene her heires and successors for ever for each and every and for such and so many chaldrons of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid as att any time or times then after should be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever forth or out of the haven or river of Tyne belonging to the aforesaid towne of New∣castle to be spent within the realme and not transported beyond the seas the severall sums of twelve pence of lawfull money of England to be paid by the said governors stewards and brethren and their successors unto the said late Queene her heires and successors be∣fore any shipp or other vessells wherein any such coales should be laden should att any any time or times then after be cleared or discharged forth of the custome house of the said late Queene in the said town of Newcastle Coales sold and carryed from the said of Newcastle to Hartlepoole to be employed and spent in and about such salt∣panns as then were in Hartlepoole aforesaid apperteyning to the Lord Lumley his heires and assignees or any of the burgesses of the said towne of Newcastle only excepted And whereas in and by one indenture beareing date the nine and twentieth day of March in the twelfth yeare of our reigne made or mentioned to be made betweene us of the one part and John late Viscount Mordaunt Sir Thomas Peyton Barronett and Sir Jere∣miah Whichcott Barronett then Esquire of the other part (reciting as therein is recited) and for the considerations therein expressed Wee have demised and to farme letten unto the said Sir Thomas Peyton and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott the several summes of twelve pence due or payable to us our heires or successors for or in respect of the said recited
grant made to the said late Queene for each and every and for such and soe many chaldron of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne afore∣said as att any time or times from and after the commencement of the said indenture dure∣ing the terme of yeares therein mencioned should be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever forth or out of the river or haven of Tyne belonging to the aforesaid towne of Newcastle to bee spent within the realme and not transported beyond the seas the said severall summes of twelve pence of lawfull money of England to bee paid by the said governors stewards and brethren of the fellowshipp of the hoastmen of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne and theire successors before any shipp or other ves∣sell wherein any such coales should be laden should att any time or times hereafter dure∣ing the terme of yeares thereby granted bee cleared or discharged forth of the custome house of us our heires or successors in the saide towne of Newcastle except as in and by the said recited grant made to the saide Queene Elizabeth is excepted to have hold leavy receive and enjoy the said severall sumes of twelve pence unto the said late Viscount Mordaunt Sir Thomas Peyton and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott their executors administrators and assignes for the terme of one and thirty yeares to bee accounted from the feast of the birth of our Lord God which was in the year of our Lord one thousand six hundred and sixty fully to be compleat and ended att and under the yearely rent or sume of one thousand eight hundred thirty eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence of lawfull money of England payable as by the said indenture (amongst other things) may appeare And whereas wee by letters patents under the great seale of England beareing date att Westminster the six and twentieth day of November in the thirteenth yeare of our reigne for the considerations therein mencioned did give and grant unto our trusty and welbe∣loved servant Sir Thomas Clarges Knight his heires and successors for ever one annuity or yearely pencion of five hundred pounds of lawfull money of England to commence and be accounted and paid from the feast of St. Michaell the Archangell which was in the twelfth yeare of our reigne and from thenceforth yearely and every yeare to bee had re∣ceived perceived and taken by the said Sir Thomas Clarges his heires and assignes for ever out of the rents issues profitts summes of money perquisitts emoluments halfe yearely and other payments reserved ariseing or accrewing or comeing or that thereafter should or might be reserved or arise accrewe or become due or payable to us our heires or succes∣sors out of or for or in respect of the aforesaid duty or composition of twelve pence by the chaldron for sea coales stone coales and pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid att the two usuall feasts in the yeare (that is to say) at the feasts of the birth of our Lord God and St. John the Baptist by even and equal porcions And wee did by the said letters patents authorise and require the farmers receivers and collectors for the time being of the duty or composicion of twelve pence the chaldron for sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid that out of the rents issues and profitts reserved or to be reserved or payable or to become due of payable to us our heires or successors for or in respect of the aforesaid duty or composicion of twelve pence the chaldron for sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne they and every of them should from time to time and att all times for ever then after well and truly pay or cause to be paid the said annuity or yearly pencion of five hundred pounds unto the said Sir Thomas Clarges his heires and assignes for ever att the feasts and days of payment aforesaid and the arreares thereof without any other warrant to be sued for had or obteyned in that behalfe And whereas wee by indenture beareing date the day of in the seaven and twentieth yeare of our reigne for the consideracions therein expressed did de∣mise grant and to farme lett unto Elizabeth Viscountesse Mordaunt the summe of foure pence being one third part of the said severall summes of twelve pence due or payable
or to be due or payable to us our heires or successors for and in respect of the said re∣cited grant made unto the said late Queene for each and every and for such and soe many chaldrons of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid as att any time or times from and after the commencement of the last recited indenture dureinge the terme of yeares therein after mencioned should be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever forth or out of the river or haven of Tyne belonging to the aforesaid towne of Newcastle to be spent within the realme and not transported beyond the seas the said summe of foure pence part of the said severall sums of twelve pence of lawfull money of England to be paid by the said go∣vernors stewards and brethren of the fellowship of the hoastmen of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne and theire successors before any shipp or other vessell wherein any such coales should be laden att any time or times then after duringe the terme of yeares thereby granted be cleared or discharged forth of the custom house of us our heires or successors in the said town of Newcastle (except as in and by the before recited grant made to the said late Queene Elizabeth is excepted) to have hold take leavy receive and enjoy the said sume of foure pence part of the said severall sume of twelve pence due or payable or to be due and payable to us our heires and successors for each and every and for such and so many chaldron of sea coales stone coales and pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid which should be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever forth or out of the haven or river of Tyne belonging to the aforesaid towne of Newcastle to be spent within the realme and not transported be∣yond the seas (except before excepted) unto the said Elizabeth Viscountess Mordaunt her executors administrators and assignes from the end expiracion or other sooner determi∣nation of the said terme and estate made and granted to the said Viscount Mordaunt Sir Thomas Peyton and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott in and by the said first recited indenture as aforesaid for and dureing the terme of one and thirty yeares from thence next ensueing fully to be compleat and ended att and under the yearly rent or sume of six hundred and twelve pounds seaventeene shillings and six pence of lawfull money of England payable as by the said indenture relacion being thereunto had may more fully appeare Now know yee that wee for the increase of the revenue and better support of the honour and dignity of our right trusty and right entirely beloved son Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox and the heires of his body to bee begotten and for want of such issue for the support of the honour and dignity of our right trusty and right entirely beloved cousin Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouth and the heires of her body and for divers other good causes and considerations us hereunto especiallye moveing of our especiall grace certeine knowledge and meere mocion have given and granted and by these presents for us and our heires and successors doe give and grant unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox all those the severall summes of twelve pence of lawfull money of England for each and every and for such and soe many chaldron of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne which att any time hereafter shall be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever forth or out of the river or haven of Tyne belonging to the aforesaid towne of Newcastle to be spent in this our kingdome of England, and not transported beyond the seas (except before ex∣cepted) And alsoe the said rent or yearely summe of one thousand eight hundred thirty eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence due and payable unto us our heires and successors upon the said demise made of the said duty unto the said John Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremy Whichcott As alsoe the said yearely rent or sume of six hundred and twelve pounds seaventeene shillings and six pence which will be due and payable to us our heires and successoures upon or by virtue of the said demise made unto the said Elizabeth Viscountess Mordaunt And the rever∣cion and revercions remainder and remainders of the said duty of twelve pence per
chaldron and all other rents sumes of money yearely and other profitts reserved or pay∣able upon any other demise and grant made of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron or any part thereof to any person or persons whatsoever or otherwise arising or payable for or in respect of the said duty or any part or parts thereof To have hold and enjoy the said duty or sume of twelve pence due and payable for each and every such and soe many chaldron of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales aforesaid as shall be sould shipped carryed or vended from or out of the port or river of Tyne as aforesaid And the revercions and revercion thereof And the said severall yearely rents or summes of one thousand eight hundred thirty eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence and six hundred and twelve pounds seaventeene shillings and six pence and all other the premises herein before mencioned and intended to be hereby granted with their appur∣tenances unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox and the heires of his body begotten or to be begotten To the proper use and behoofe of him the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox and the heires of his body lawfully begotten or to be begotten Subject nevertheless and lyable unto and charged and chargeable with the payment of the said yearely summe of five hundred pounds to the said Sir Thomas Clarges his heires or assignes according to the purport and intent of the said letters patents or grant to him thereof made as aforesaid Yielding and paying therefore yearely to us our heires and successors the yearely rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence of lawful money of England att the feast of Saint Michael the Archangel onely

And know yee further that wee for the consideracion aforesaid of our more abundant grace certeine knowledge and meere mocion have given and granted and by these presents for us our heires and successors do give and grant to our said right trusty and right entirely beloved cousin Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouth mother of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox the said severall summes of twelve pence due and payable for each and every and soe many chaldron of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales of water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid as att any time or times after the death of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox without heires of his body lawfully begotten or to bee begotten shall be sold shipped carryed or vended by any person or persons whatsoever from orout of the river or port of Tyne and belonging to the said towne of Newcastle to bee spent in this our kingdome of England and not transported beyond the seas (except before excepted) And alsoe the said rent or yearely sume of one thousand eight hundred thirty eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence due and payable unto us our heires and successors upon the said demise made of the said duty unto the said John Viscount Mordaunt Sir Thomas Peyton & Sir Jeremy Whichcott As alsoe the said yearely rent or summe of six hundred and twelve pounds seaventeene shillings & six pence which will be due and payable unto us our heires and successors upon or by virtue of the said demise made unto the said Elizabeth Viscountesse Mordaunt and the revercion and revercions remainder and remainders of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron and all other rents summes of money yearely and other profitts reserved or payable upon any other demise and grant made of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron or any part thereof to any person or persons whatsoever or otherwise ariseing or payable for or in respect of the said duty or any part or parts thereof To have hold and enjoy the said duty or sume of twelve pence due and payable for each and every and such and soe many chaldron of sea coales stone coales or pitt coales aforesaid as shall be sould shipped carryed or vended from or out of the port or river of Tyne as aforesaid And the revercion and revercions thereof and the said severall yearely rents or sumes of one thousand eight hundred thirty eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence and six hundred and twelve pounds seaventeene shillings and six pence and all other the pre∣misses herein beforemencioned and intended to be hereby granted with their appur∣tenaunces unto the said Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouth and the heires of her body
lawfully begotten or to be begotten to the onely proper use and behoofe of the said Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouth and the heires of her body lawfully begotten or to be begotten from and after the death of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox without heires of his body begotten and to be begotten as aforesaid And also subject and lyable unto and charged and chargeable with the payment of the said yearely sume of five hundred pounds to the said Sir Thomas Clarges his heires or assignes according to the purport and intent of the said letters patents or grant to him thereof made as aforesaid Yeilding and paying therefore yearely to us our heires and successors from the commencement and dureing the continuance of the said estate granted to the said dutchesse and the heires of her body the yearely rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence of lawfull money of England att the feast of St. Michael the Archangell onely And moreover wee doe hereby charge and command that none of the officers ministers or servants whatsoever they bee or shall be of us our heires or successors doe make or deliver any warrant or warrants to any person or persons for the unloading or landing of any of the said coales in any of the ports in this realme of England or do∣minion of Wales or towne or porte of Berwicke or any the members thereof unlesse such of the said officers ministers or servants who shall make give or deliver any such warrant shall first receive a cocquett or certificate thereof from the port or place where the same were laden and that none of the said officers ministers or servants shall wittingly or willingly conceal withdraw deny withhold or diminish any part of the said duty or sume of twelve pence by these presents mencioned to be granted or make any certificate that any coales have been landed att any port or place where the same were not landed or omitt the makeing of just and true entries or that any more or greater quantitys of coales have been landed and delivered att any port or place then in truth were delivered there or consent unto or willingly suffer to be done committed or omitted any other act or thing in or appertaininge to their severall and respective offices and places which shall or may tend or bee to the hinderance losse or damage of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox or the heires of his body or to the said Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouth and the heires of her body in or concerning the said granted premisses We doe for us our heires and successors of our especial grace certaine know∣ledge and mere mocion give and grant unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox and the heires of his body and for want of such issue to the said Louise Dutchesse of Portsmouthe and the heires of her body and to all and every person and persons which by them or any of them shall be deputed or assigned full power liberty and authority to bee present and attendant and to have place in the custome house within the said port of Newcastle and the creeks and members thereof where any ladeing or carrying of any sea coales stone coales or pitt coales shall happen to bee and to have free accesse unto the said custome house and to all books registers bonds and other things whatsoever concerning any of the said coales made kept or preserved or to be made kept or preserved by any customer comptroller surveyor or any other officer of the said ports creeks or members or any of them or by the coale meeters of London or any of them or by the clearke of the towne chamber or Newcastle or by the surveyor war∣dens assistants and fellows of the society of coale merchants tradeing to Newcastle or by any other person or persons whatsoever in the presence of such person or persons to whom the charge and custody of such bookes registers bonds or writeings of any thing touching the premisses or any of them and to be present with all and every the customers collectors comptrollers tearchers waiters or other officers and ministers haveing a charge within the said ports of London and Newcastle and the creeks and members of the same for and concerning the said duty of twelve pence and to see provide and take order for or concerning the better enjoying of the benefits profitts and comoditys of the premisses before by these presents mencioned to be granted att all times and places
where the said officers or ministers or any of them shall by reason of any of their said severall places and offices have occasion or authority to view search or bee and alsoe in every such place to see provide and use such reasonable ways orders and meanes whereby the said duty may bee justly and truely answered and paid without any fraude, con∣cealment or diminucion thereof And also to make entries composicions and agree∣ments for the same and all other acts and things that to the office of any customer col∣lector comptroller searcher surveyor or any other officer and every or any of them within the said port and all and every the creeks and members belonging to the same doth or shall appertaine to bee done for or concerning the said duty before by these presents mencioned to be granted And to take and collect the aforesaid duty as well att and by the hands of all and every owner and owners of the same coales and every of their factors deputys or servants or any other person or persons shipping carrying or con∣veying of the said coales out of the said port of Newcastle or from or out of any of the said creeks or members within the limitts or jurisdiccions of the said port of Newcastle or from or out of any of the said creeks or members within the limitts or jurisdiccions of the said port of Newcastle to be spent within the realme of England or the towne of Berwicke and not transported beyond the seas And alsoe att and by the hands of the customers collectors fitters and other officer and officers of and in the said port places and creeks for the time being without the lett or interrupcion of any customer comptroller collector searcher wayter or other officers or ministers of us our heires or successors or any of them of or in any of the said port places or creeks or of any other whatsoever.

And further for the more surety of the said duty or summe of twelve pence in and by these presents granted wee for us our heires and successors doe by these presents charge prohibite and forbid all and every person and persons as well aliens or strangers as denizens or Englishmen That neither they nor any of them doe shipp lade or attempt presume or adventure to ship lade freight convey or carry out of the said port of Newcastle or any the creeks or members belonging to the same any of the said kinds or sorts of coales to be spent within the realme and not transported beyond the leas before or untill such time as the said duty or sume of twelve pence before by these presents mencioned to be granted as aforesaid be fully and wholly satisfied and paid upon such forfeitures paines penalties and punishments as by any laws statuntes or ordinaunces of this realme can or may be inflictcd upon such offenders and that noe customer col∣lector comptroller or other officer make any entry or deliver any cocquet of for or con∣cerning the ladeing or shipping of any of the said coales without the consent of the person or persons that ought to receive the said duty or some of their deputys agents or factors thereunto first had and obtained upon the paines and penalties aforesaid And wee do give and grant unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox and the heires of his body and for want of such issue to the said Louise Dutchesse of Ports∣mouth and to the heires of her body and every of them respectively full power liberty and authority in the name of us our heires and successors or in theire owne name or names att anye of theire pleasures to implead sue and prosecute all and every such person or persons their heires executors administrators and assigns and every or any of them as att any time or times shall or may by any meanes be found to be indebted chargeable or answerable to the said grantees or any of them for or by reason of the said duty or any part or parcell of the same in the court of exchequer or any other court of record whatsoever And further to doe make take and prosecute concerning the same in the name of us our heires or successors in such and the like manner and forme as wee our heires or successors should or might have done if the same had not by these presents been granted And to the end that the said duty hereby graunted may be well and truely answered and paid Our will and pleasure is and wee doe for us our heires and successors grant by these presents that the deputies servants and factors of the said
grantees respectively shall and may from time to time as well by night as by day by themselves or any of them takeing with them or any of them for his or their assistant in that behalfe our searcher there or any other our officers lawfully authorized in that be∣halfe if any such bee then abideing in the same port and in lawful convenient and reasonable manner to goe on board view search and survey any shipp vessell or bottome rideing or being within the same port of Newcastle or any member thereof to see if there be any such coales whereof the duty shall not have been well and truly answered and paid and all such quantity or quantitys of the said kind or sorts of coales or any of them as shall be found whereof the said duty or sume or sumes of money shall not before that time be answered or paid in lawful manner to seize and take the one halfe to be to the use of us our heires or successors and the other halfe thereof to be to the use and behoofe of the person or persons to whom the said duty shall for the time being belong And wee doe for us our heires and successors will and grant by these presents that the high treasurer of England commissioners of the treasury chancellor under treasurer and barons of the said exchequer for the time being or the more part of them by force of these presents or the inrollment thereof att all and every time and times upon request in that behalfe shall and may make and direct as much as by the law they may under the seale of the saide exchequer one or more sufficient writt or writts close or patent unto every or any such of the customers collectors or comptrollers of us our heires or successors in the aforesaid port of Newcastle for the time being or shall be directed com∣manding and streightly chargeing them the said customers collectors comptrollers and every of them that they nor any of them shall make any entry of any the said kinds or sorts of coales or take any custome or subsidy or make any discharge or agreement for the same other then of those quantity or quantitys of the said sorts or kinds of coales aforesaid whereof the said duty sume or sumes of money before by these presents men∣cioned to be demised and granted shall be then truly answered and paid according to the true intent and meaneing of these presents And furthermore to the end that all and every such person or persons as shall be from time to time assigned deputed and appointed to the exercise and execution of these presents or any part thereof shall and may the better and more quietly attend and supply the same without any lett trouble or hinderance in that behalfe wee doe for us our heires and successors will and grant and alsoe streightlie charge and command that all and every person and persons what∣soever which from time to time shall be assigned deputed or appointed in about to or for the exercise or execution of the premises or any of them shall be clearely and freely exonerated and discharged of and from all and all manner of offices and services what∣soever to be done or executed within the said towne or port of Newcastle or any the creeks or members of the same where such person or persons shall be soe assigned deputed or appointed to serve or attend in any other place whatsoever dureing such and soe long time as they and every of them shall personally attend and be necessarily with∣out fraud or covin employed in or about the exercise or execution of these presents and that during all the said time of their personall and necessary attendance as is aforesaid they nor any of them shall in any wile be inforced constreyned or charged to beare execute or doe any other office or service whatsoever within the said towne or port of Newcastle or any within any the creeks or members of the same either for us our heires or successors or in any other place or places whatsoever soe as there be not above two persons at any one time And wee doe for us our heires and successors of our especiall grace certaine knowledge and meere mocion declare and grant that iff at any time any doubt shall be conceived concerning the validity or strength of this our grant of the premises or of any part thereof that then upon peticion in that behalfe and upon certi∣ficate of the attorney generall for the time being concerning any defects and imper∣feccions we our heires or successors will make and give such further assurance and perfect
grant of all and singular the said premises before in and by these presents mencioned or intended to be granted according to the tenor purport and true meaning of these presents as by the attorney generall of us oure heires and successors for the time being shall be in that behalfe reasonably advised And wee doe alsoe declare direct and appoint that as well all and every the officers and ministers which shall have any office or authority from or under the jurisdiccion of the lord high admirall of England for the time being And alsoe all and every the customers collectors waiters surveyors searchers water-bayliffes and other officers of us our heires and successors within the said port of Newcastle or any the creeks and members of the same and every of them shall from time to time be ayding and assisting to the said deputys factors and servants in all and singular the premisses for the just and best benefitt and advanrage of the said grantees according to the true intent and meaneing of these presents and in as beneficiall manner as they and every of them should or ought to have bin or done to us our heires or successors if these presents had not bin had or made And our will and pleasure is that the said high treasurer lords commissioners of our treasury chancellor or under treasurer and barons of the exchequer for the time being or any three or more of them shall have full power and authority to make forth and award under the seale of the exchequer such and soe many writts of assistance as shall be thought meet And these presents or the inrollment thereof shall be a sufficient warrant and discharge in that behalfe And of our more especiall grace certaine knowledge and meere mocion wee doe for us our heires and successors grant that these presents and every clause article and sentence therein contained shall bee good avaylable and effectuall and shall be expounded deemed adjudged and taken to be good avaylable and effectuall to all intents and purposes according to the tenor effect and true meaneing hereof any law statute usage prohibition restraint proclamacion or other thing whatsoever to the con∣trary in any wise notwithstanding And notwithstanding the misnameing misreciteing or not reciteing of any the premisses hereby granted or mencioned to be granted or of any part or parcell of them or any of them And notwithstanding the not recitall misrecitall misnameing or not nameing of any demise or grant of the premisses or any parcell thereof made being of record or not of record And notwithstanding the not reciteing or misreciteing of the aforesaid grants of the premisses yett in being or of any other grants or demises thereof And notwithstanding the not finding any office or offices inquisicion or inquisicions of or concerning the premisses whereby our title of and in the premisses or any part thereof ought to have bin found before the makeing thereof And notwithstanding any defect in the certainty or computacion or declara∣cion of the true yearely value of the premisses or of any parcell thereof And notwith∣standing any other defect in not nameing misnameing or not right nameing of the tennants farmers or occupyers of the premisses or any parcell thereof And notwithstand∣ing any misrecitall or not true mencioning in these presents of our estate of or in the premisses or any part thereof or any other misrecitall or misnameing not recitall or not nameing whatsoever And notwithstanding the statute made in the parliament of Henry the Sixih late King of England and published in the eighteenth yeare of his reigne or any other acts or statutes whatsoever And notwithstanding any other defects in not nameing or specifying or not rightly nameing or specifying of the natures kinds qua∣lities or quantities of the premisses or any parcell thereof Provided alwaies and our will and pleasure is we doe hereby for us our heires and successors direct and appoint that the said yearely summe of five hundred pounds shall continue and bee payable and paid to the said Sir Thomas Clarge has heires and assignes in whole hands soever the said duity or the rents and profits thereof shall from time to time remaine or bw according to the purport of his said grant and the direccions and authoritys thereby
given Any thing herein before contained to the contrary notwithstanding Although express mencion &c In witnesse &c Witnesse ourselfe at Westminster the eighteenth day of December
(By writt of privy seale.)
This is a true copy from the original record remaineing in the Chappel of the Rolls, having been examined

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 298. (No. 2.) An Act for varying and postponing certain Limitations in a Grant made by King Charles the Second, of a Duty on Coals shipped in the River Tyne, to Charles late Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and for enabling the present Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, to make a Jointure on his intended Marriage with Lady Mary Bruce.
DIV2.P:
WHEREAS by letters patent under the Great Seal of England, bearing date the eighteenth day of December, in the twenty-ninth year of the reign of his late Majesty King Charles the Second, after reciting therein, that the Governors, Stew∣ards, and Brethren of the Fellowship of the Hoastmen of the town of Newcastle upon Tyne, by their writing sealed as well with their common seal as with the common seal of the Mayor and Burgesses of the said town of Newcastle upon Tyne, bearing date the eighth day of April, in the two-and-fortieth year of the reign of the late Queen Eliza∣beth, did, for them and their successors, give and grant unto the said late Queen, her heirs and successors, to the use of the said late Queen, her heirs and successors, for ever, for each and every, and for such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, or pit coals, of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid, as at any time or times thereafter should be sold, shipped, carried, or vendcd, by any person or persons what∣soever forth or out of the haven or river of Tyne, belonging to the aforesaid town of Newcastle, to be spent within the realm, and not transported beyond the seas, the several sums of twelve pence of lawful money of England, to be paid by the said Governors, Stewards, and Brethren, and their successors, unto the said late Queen, her heirs and successors, before any ship or other vessels wherein any such coals should be laden, should, at any time or times then after, be cleared or discharged forth of the custom-house of the said late Queen in the said town of Newcastle (coals sold and carried from the said port of Newcastle to Hartlepoule, to be employed anti spent in and about such salt pans as then were in Hartlepoole aforesaid, and appertaining to the Lord Lumley, his heirs, and assigns, or any of the burgesses of the said town of Newcastle, only excepted). And also reciting an indenture dated the nine-and-twentieth day of March, in the twelfth year of his said Majesty's reign, made, or mentioned to be made, between his said late Majesty of the one part, and John then late Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, Bart. and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott, Bart. then Esquire of the other part; whereby, for the considerations therein expressed, his said late Majesty
demised to the said late Viscount, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott, the said several sums of twelve pence; to hold to them, their executors, administrators, and assigns, for the term of thirty-one years, to be accounted from the feast of the birth of our Lord God which was in the year of our Lord one thousand six hundred and sixty, at the yearly rent of one thousand eight hundred and thirty-eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence. And also reciting that his said late Majesty, by letters patent under the great seal of England, bearing date at Westminster, the twenty-sixth day of November, in the thirteenth year of his reign, for the considerations therein mentioned, did give and grant unto his trusty and well-beloved servant Sir Thomas Clarges, Knt. his heirs and assigns, for ever, one annuity or yearly pension of five hundred pounds of lawful money of England, to commence and be accounted and paid from the feast of St. Michael the Archangel which was in the twelfth year of his reign, and from thenceforth yearly and every year to be had, received, perceived and taken by the said Sir Thomas Clarges, his heirs and assigns for ever, out of the rents, issues, profits, sums of money, perquisites, emoluments, half-yearly and other payments reserved arising or accruing or coming, or that thereafter should or might be reserved or arise, accrue or become due or payable to his said late Majesty, his heirs or successors, out of, or for or in respect of the aforesaid duty or composition of twelve pence by the chaldron for sea coals, stone coal, and pit coal, of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid, at two usual feasts in the year (that is to say) at the feast of the birth of our Lord God and St. John the Baptist, by even and equal portions. And also re∣citing that his said late Majesty, by indenture bearing date the day of in the twenty-seventh year of his reign, for the considerations therein mentioned, demised unto Elizabeth Viscountess Mordaunt the sum of four pence, being one third part of the said several sums of twelve pence; to hold unto the said Elizabeth Viscountess Mordaunt, her executors, administrators, and assigns, from the end, expi∣ration, or other sooner determination of the said term of thirty-one years, granted to the said Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott, at the yearly rent of six hundred and twelve pounds seventeen shillings and six pence: his said late Majesty King Charles the Second, for the increase of the revenue, and the better support of the honour and dignity of his right trusty and right entirely beloved son Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and the heirs of his body to be begotten;
