and for want of such issue, for the better support of the honour and dignity of his right trusty and right entirely beloved cousin, Louise Dutchess of Portsmouth, and the heirs of her body, and for divers other good causes and considerations him thereunto especially moving, of his especial grace, certain knowlcdge, and mere motion, did give and grant unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, all those the several sums of twelve pence of lawful money of England, for each and every, and for such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, or pit coals, of the water measure of Newcastle upon Tyne, which at any time thereafter should be sold, shipped, carried, or vended, by any person or persons whatsoever, forth or out of the river or haven of Tyne belong∣ing to the aforesaid town of Newcastle, to be spent in the kingdom of England, and not transported beyond the seas (except before excepted); and also the said rent or yearly sum of one thousand eight hundred and thirty eight puunds twelve shillings and six pence, due and payable unto his said Majesty, his heirs and successors, upon the said demise made of the said duty unto the said John Viscount Mordaunt, Sir Thomas Peyton, and Sir Jeremiah Whichcott; as also the said yearly rent or sum of six hundred and twelve pounds seventeen shillings and six pence, which would be due and payable unto his said Majesty, his heirs and successors, upon or by virtue of the said demise unto the said Elizabeth Viscountess Mordaunt, and the reversion and reversions, remainder and remainders, of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron; and all other rents, sums of money, yearly and other profits reserved or payable upon any other demise and grant
made of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron, or any part thereof, to any person or persons whatsoever, or otherwise arising or payable, for or in respect of the said duty, or any part or parts thereof; to have, hold, and enjoy, the said duty or sum of twelve pence, due and payable for each and every such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, or pit coals aforesaid, as should be sold, shipped, carried, or vended, from or out of the port or river of Tyne aforesaid; and the reversion and reversions thereof, and the said several yearly rents or sums of one thousand eight hundred and thirty-eight pounds twelve shillings and six pence, and six hundred and twelve pounds seventeen shillings and six pence, and all other the premises therein before-mentioned, and in∣tended to be thereby granted, with their appurtenances, unto the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and the heirs of his body begotten, or to be begotten, to the proper use and behoof of him the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and the heirs of his body lawfully begotten, or to be begotten: subject nevertheless, and liable unto, and charged and chargeable with the payment of the said yearly sum of five hundred pounds, to the said Sir Thomas Clarges, his heirs or assigns, according to the purport and intent of the said letters patents or grant to him thereof, made as afore∣said; yielding and paying therefore yearly to his said late Majesty, his heirs and suc∣cessors, the yearly rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence, of lawful money of England, at the feast of St. Michael the Archangel only; with a remainder to Louise Dutchess of Portsmouth, and the heirs of her body.

And whereas the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox died in the year one thousand seven hundred and twenty-three, leaving issue only one son, Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny; and two daughters:

And whereas the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny died in the year one thousand seven hundred and fifty, leaving issue two sons; that is to say, the Most Noble Charles, now Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny; and the Right Honourable George Henry Lenox, commonly called Lord George Henry Lenox; and five daughters: and upon the death of the said Charles late Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, the said Charles now Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny became seised to him, and the heirs of the body of the first Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, in tail-general of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron; so that in case the said Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny should marry, and leave only issue female, the said duty and premises will go and descend to such issue female, by virtue of the said grant to his said grandfather Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox:

And whereas the said Charles, now Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, is desirous that the honour and dignity of the title may be supported according to what seems to have been the intent of the crown, by the recital in the said letters patent; and that the said coal duty should, for the end and purpose aforesaid, in default of issue male of his own body, go to and vest in his brother the said Lord George Henry Lenox, and the heirs male of his body, in preference to the general heirs of his own body:

And whereas a treaty of marriage has been had, and lately concluded, between th said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, and the Right Honourable Lady Mary Bruce, daughter of the Right Honourable Charles late Earl of Ailesbury, deceased; and the said Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny hath proposed, in consideration of the said intended marriage, and of the portion of the said Lady Mary Bruce, to grant three thousand pounds a year, to issue and be payable out of the sl coal duty, to her the said Lady Mary Bruce, and her assigns, to hold the same during her life as a jointure, in case she shall survive him the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny; and the said Lady Mary Bruce, and her trustees and guardians, are willing to accept of such rent charge in lieu and bar of the dower and thirds of the estate of the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, to which the said
Lady Mary Bruce might otherwise be intitled; but the limitations in the said grant cannot be varied, nor by reason of the minority of the said Lady Mary Bruce can the said proposal be carried into execution, without the aid and authority of Parliament:

Therefore, at the humble suit of your Majesty's most dutiful and loyal subject the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, by and with the consent of the said Lady Mary Bruce, and of Edward Popham of Littlecot, in the county of Wilts; John Talbot of Laycock, in the same county; and Robert Harley, of Lincoln's-inn, Esquires; her trustees and guardians:

By the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from henceforth the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny shall have, hold, and enjoy, and be seised of the said duty or sum of twelve pence, due and payable for each and every such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, or pit coals, aforesaid, as shall be sold, shipped, carried, or vended, from or out of the port or river of Tyne; as aforesaid, so granted by the said first re∣cited letters patents to the said Charles first Duke of Richmond, and the heirs of his body, unto him the said Charles now Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, and the heirs male of his body, to the proper use and behoof of him the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, and the heirs male of his body lawfully to be be∣gotten; subject nevertheless, and liable unto, and charged, and chargeable with the payment of the said yearly sum of five hundred pounds to the heirs or assigns of the said Sir Thomas Clarges, according to the purport and intent of the said letters patents to him the said Sir Thomas Clarges thereof made as aforesaid; yielding and paying therefore yearly to his Majesty, his heirs and successors, the said yearly rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence, of lawful money of Great Britain, at the feast of Saint Michael the Archangel only; any thing in the said letters patents, bearing date the said eighteenth day of December, in the twenty-ninth year of the reign of King Charles the Second, to the contrary thereof notwithstanding.

And be it further enacted, by the authority aforesaid, That in default of heirs male of the body of the said Charles now Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, the said duty or sum of twelve pence, due and payable for each and every such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, or pit coals aforesaid, as shall be sold, shipped, car∣ried, or vended, from or out of the port or river of Tyne, as aforesaid, shall go, and remain to, and vest in, the said Lord George Henry Lenox, and the heirs male of his body; to the proper use and behoof of him the said Lord George Henry Lenox, and the heirs male of his body lawfully to be begotten; subject nevertheles, and liable unto, and charged, and chargeable with the payment of the said yearly sum of five hundred pounds, to the heirs and assigns of the said Sir Thomas Clarges, according to the pur∣port and intent of the said letters patents, or grant to him the said Sir Thomas Clarges, thereof made as aforesaid, yielding and paying therefore yearly to his laid Majesty, his heirs and successors, from the commencement and during the continuance of the said estate hereby limited to the said Lord George Henry Lenox, and the heirs male of his body, the yearly rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence, of lawful money of Great Britain, at the feast of Saint Michael the Archangel only; any thing in the said letters patent, bearing date the said eighteenth day of December, in the twenty-ninth year of the reign of King Charles the Second, to the contrary thereof notwithstanding.

And be it further enacted, by the authority aforesaid, that in default heirs male of the body of the said Lord George Henry Lenox, the said duty or sum of twelve pence, due and payable for each and every such and so many chaldron of sea coals, stone coals, and pit coals, aforesaid, as shall be sold, shipped, carried, or vended, from or out
of the port or river of Tyne, as aforesaid, shall go and remain to and vest in the heirs of the body of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, lawfully begotten or to be begotten, to the only proper use and behoof of the heirs of the body of the said Charles Duke of Richmond and Lenox, lawfully begotten and to be begotten; subject never∣theless, and liable unto, and charged, and chargeable, with the said payment of the said yearly sum of five hundred pounds, to the heirs or assigns of the said Sir Thomas Clarges, according to the purport and intent of the said letters patents, or grant to him the said Sir Thomas Clarges, thereof made as aforesaid: and subject to the said yearly rent of one pound six shillings and eight pence, payable to his said Majesty, his heirs and successors, as they would have done if the same had been limited to the said Charles Duke of Richmond, and the heirs male of his body, prior to the limitation in the said letters patents, to the said Charles Duke of Richmond, and the heirs of his body; and that all and every person or persons, who shall take, hold, or enjoy the said premises, or any part thereof, under or by virtue of any of the limitations herein, or in the letters patents contained, shall take, hold, and enjoy the same, in such manner and quality, to all intents and purposes whatsoever, as he, she, or they would have done, if the said limitations in this act contained had been originally inserted in the said letters patent; and subject to the same privileges, advantages, protections, and restrictions, as if this act of parliament had never been made.

And be it further enacted, by the authority aforesaid, that it shall and may be lawful, to and for the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, by any deed or writing, to be by him sealed and delivered in the presence of two or more witnesses, to grant, limit, appoint, or assure, one annuity or yearly sum of of lawful money of Great Britain, clear of all taxes, charges, and deductions whatsoever, unto, upon, or to the use of the said Lady Mary Bruce, to have, hold, and enjoy the same, for and during her natural life, immediately after the decease of the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, in case the said intended marriage between him and the said Lady Mary Bruce shall take effect, and be solemnized, and she shall happen to survive him, and to be issuing and payable out of the aforesaid duty of twelve pence per chaldron to the said Lady Mary Bruce, and her assigns, during the term of her natural life.

And it is hereby further enacted and declared, that the said annuity or yearly sum of so to be granted, as aforesaid, to the said Lady Mary Bruce, is and shall be taken to be in full for her jointure, and in recompence, satisfaction, and bar, of all dower, title of dower, and thirds, which she the said Lady Mary Bruce may at any time hereafter claim, demand, or be entitled to, of, in, to, or out of the said duty of twelve pence per chaldron, or of, in, to, or out of, any manors, lands, tenements, or hereditaments, whereof the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny now is, or at any time hereafter may be seised; any thing in the said grant of the eighteenth day of December, in the twenty∣ninth year of the reign of his late Majesty King Charles the Second, to the contrary thereof in any wise notwithstanding.

Saving always, to all and every person and persons, bodies politic or corporate, his, her, and their heirs, successors, executors, administrators, and assigns (other than the King's most excellent Majesty his heirs and successors; and other than the said Charles Duke of Richmond, Lenox, and Aubigny, and the heirs of his body, and the heirs of the body of the said Charles the first Duke of Richmond and Lenox, and all other person and persons that do, or hereafter may claim, under the said letters patents; and also the said Lady Mary Bruce), all such right, title, claim, and demand whatso∣ever, as they, every, or any of them might, could, or ought to have, had, claimed, held, or enjoyed, in case this act had never been made.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 303. Alphabetical Table of Shipps useing the Coale Trade at Newcastle in the Yeares 1702, 1703, and 1704.
DIV2.P:
From a MS. quarto, intitled, "An Abstract of Ships using the Coal Trade to Newcastle, anno 1705," in the archives of the Trinity House of Newcastle
A MEMORANDUM on the second page.—Presented this book to the following persons, viz. one to the “”Hon. Charles Montague, Esq One to Sir William Blackett, Batt.
Then follows a dedication to the Hon. Charles Montaguer, signed with the initials E. G. (for Edward Grey)..
N. B. The reason why Sunderland ships load at this port, is, that it is dangerous in winter both for the ships to lye in the roads there, and for the keels to go out to them.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 311. (No. 1.) Notices concerning the Art of and curious Machines and Contrivances used in winning and working Coal Mines.

Q.L: BORING AND SINKING.
"When likely signs th' advent'rous search invite,
A cunning artist tries the latent soil;
And if his subtle engine in return
A nitrous mass contains, brittle and adust;
Strait he prepares th' obstructive earth to clear,
And raise the sable rook."

DIV2.P: THE tools of borers are of the simplest kind, and consist of iron rods, each between three and four feet long, and about an inch and a half square, with a screw (a bed and what fits into it) at each end, by which they are united, and lengthened out as the hole increases in its depth. The chisel is about eighteen inches long, and two and a half broad at the end, and is fixed to the lowest of the rods. The uppermost rod is furnished with an eye, wherein to insert a piece of timber for an handle for two or more workmen to take hold of at once. Their mode of operation is to lift up the rods a little, and then let them fall again, turning them at the same time gently round: by a continuance of this motion a round hole is fretted and worn by degrees through the hardest strata.

When the chisel is quite blunted, or has cut down four or six inches, the rods are lifted up
The borers can put on handles for two, three, or four persons to work, as they find it necessary. After they get down to a certain depth, the rods are wrought by a bracke: a box of wood is inserted first into the ground, to keep the rods in a straight direction. A triangle is erected over the spot where the boring is made, for the sake of drawing up the rods: they have one key to unscrew, and another to secure the rods from falling back again. They use a close wimble to bring up sludge and soft matter.
The established prices of boring are said to be 5 shillings per fathom for the first five fathoms—10 shil∣lings for the next five—15 shillings per fathom for the subsequent five—and so continually increasing, shil∣lings per fathom at the end of every five fathoms. The borer usually finds all his own implements; but when a whinstone occurs above a foot in thickness, he is paid by the day. Three inches diameter for a bore-hole, or boring, is sufficient. The whinstone sometimes resists the hardest-tempered steel, and can scarce be wrought upon., either altogether, if there be convenience, or by pieces, when a key is used to keep the rods from dropping down into the hole, and being either lost, or re∣coverable only with great labour. The chisel is screwed off, and the wimple or scoop put on. This being put down brings up afterwards the dust or pulverised matter of the stratum, through which the chisel has cut, and shews as well what kind of matter they are boring in as the exact depth thereof.

The skilful workmen, however, feel easily, and distinguish the sorts of strata they are upon by the difficulty or facility with which they advance downwards. The prin∣cipal part of the borer's art depends on keeping the hole clean, and observing every variation of the strata with care and attention.

By the wetness of the rods they know when any feeder of water is pricked, and by their falling down as it were without any labour, when they are upon an old waste or colliery that has been wrought before.

This is an art of the utmost use and importance in collieries; for by boring previously to the sinking of a pit, the owner procures most essential data whereon to proceed, being informed before hand of the nature of the earth, minerals and waters through which he has to pass, and knowing to an inch or so how deep his coal lies, as well as its quality, and the thickness of the stratum or bedVide Encyclopaedia, Edinburgh, quarto, in voce "Coalieries;" also The Complete Collier.. The boring notesWallis's History of Northumberland, vol. i. p. 129. of collieries are the grand arcana of the coal trade, and secrets which the owners by no means chuse to discover to the prying eyes of the curious philosopher.

No lease is taken of any ground which has not previously been explored by boring. The boring being completed, in order to win the coals, they afterwards sink what is called the shaftsceaft Sagitta. Cuspis, Lignum, teres. Benson's Anglo-Saxon Vocabulary. of the pit, i. e. the narrow, round, perpendicular passage into the mine

DIV3.HEAD: DIP AND RISE OF THE STRATA OF COAL.
DIV3.P:
BY the sinking of the shaft is opened out a communication with the bed of the coal. The strata of this fossil are seldom or never found to lie in a true horizontal situation, but generally have an inclination or descent, called the dip
In all places where the strata lie regular, they are divided and subdivided, &c. Though it is often otherwise; for their regularity is frequently interrupted, and the strata broken and disordered by sundry chasms, breaches or fissures, which are differently denominated according to their various dimensions, and the matters with which they are filled, viz. dikes, hitches, and troubles.
Dikes are the largest kind of fissures; they seem to be nothing but a crk or breach of the solid strata, occasioned by one part of them being broken away and fallen from the other. They generally run in straight line tor a considerable length, and penetrate from the surface to the greatest depth ever yet tried, in a direction sometimes perpendicular to the horizon, and sometimes obliquely. The same kinds of strata are found lying upon each other in the same order, but the whole of them greatly elevated or depressed, on the one side of the dike as on the other. These fissures are sometimes two or three feet wide, and sometimes many fathoms. If the fissure or dike be of any considerable width, it is gnerally filled with heterogeneous matter, different from that of the solid strata on each side of it. It is sometimes found filled up with , gravel or sand; sometimes with a confused mass of different kinds of stone ing edgeways, and at other times with a solid body of freestone, or even whinstone. When the of no great width, as suppose two or three feet only, it is then usually found filled up with a confused mixture of the different matters which compose the adjoining strata, consolidated into one mass. If a dike of strtches north and south, and the same kinds of strata are found on the east side of the dike, in a with respect to the horizon to or twenty fathoms lower than on the other side, it is then sid to be a dip-dike or down-east dike of ten or twenty fathoms to the eastward. Or counting from the east side, it is said to be a -dik, or of so many fathoms westward. If the strata on one side are not much higher or lower, respe to the horizontal line, than those on the other, but only broken and certain then said to be dike of so many fathoms thic; and from the two side the fissure or dike, it d nominated a clay-dike, stone-dike, &c. — gge of the keelmen, called dikes▪
A hitch is only a dike or fissure of a smaller , by which the strata are not separated from those on the other side above one fathom.
These hitches are denominated in the same manner as they o depress the strata. These are dikes (though not often nt with flled with spa, the oe of iron, lead vitriol, or other known that all metallic veins are nothing else than what in the ▪
The strata are generally found lying upon each other in the same order on one side of the dike as on the other, as mentioned above, and nearly of the same thicknesses, appearing to have been originally a continua∣tion of the same regular strata, and the dike only a breach by some later accident, perpendicularly or ob∣liquely down through them, by which one part is removed to a small distance, and depressed to a lower situa∣tion than the other.
But this is not the only alteration made in the strata by dikes; for generally, to a considerable distance on each side of the dike, all the strata are in a kind of shattered condition, very tender, easily pervious to water, and debased greatly in their quality, and their inclination to the horizon often altered.
Troubles may be denominated dikes or the smallest degree; for they are not a real breach, but only an approach towards it which has not taken a full effect. The strata are generally altered by a trouble, from their regular site to a different position. When the regular course of the strata is nearly level, a trouble will cause a sudden and considerable ascent or descent: where they have in their regular situation a certain de∣gree of ascent or descent, a trouble either increaseth it, or alters it to a contrary position; and a trouble has these effects upon the strata in common with dikes, that it greatly debaseth them from their original quality; the partings are separated, the backs and cutters disjoined, and their regularity disordered. The original cubic and prismatic figures of which the strata were composed, are broken, and the dislocation filled with heterogeneous matter; and the whole strata are reduced to a foster and more friable state. ENCYCLOPAEDIA, ut supra., to some particular part of the horizon. If this inclination be to the eastward, it is called an east dip, and a west rise; and according to the point of the compass to which the dip inclines it is denominated, and the ascent or rise is to the contrary point.

This inclination or dip of the strata is found to hold every where. In some places it varies very little from the level; in others very considerably; and in some so much as to be nearly in a perpendicular direction: but whatever degree of inclination the strata have to the horizon, if not interrupted by dikes, hitches, or troubles, they are always found to lie in the first regular manner mentioned. They generally continue upon one uniform dip until they are broken or disordered by a dike, hitch, or trouble, by which the dip is often altered, sometimes to a different part of the horizon, and often to an opposite point; so that on one side of a dike, hitch, or trouble, if the strata have an east dip
Wallis, in his History of Northumberland, tells us, that "by the best observations of the miners, the coal seams generally rise to the north-west, and dip to the south-east."
Dr. Stukeley, in his Itin. Curios. 1725, says, that "some of the coal-works here dip full east."—" It is plain," he adds, "south-east is the natural dip in general. Those at Whitehaven, inclining south-west, receive, I suppose, a counter bias, as being in the wslt side of the island."
In the same Itinerary he observes, "that the coal in this country, and which is universally diffused through it, dips many ways, as the falls of vallies or duct of rivers occasionally divert its primary bent; but the main dip of it is to the south-east. Sometimes there are fissures or interruptions of some consider∣able quantities, being coaled strata, stone and other materials, jumbled together: This proves that these has been such a partial disruption of the strata of the earth, as we all along suppose was effected by the De∣luge, but not such a hotch-potch or total mixture and confusion as others would pretend."
Pennant, in his Tour, vol. ii. p. 56, speaking of the mines at Whitehaven, says, "The beds of coal are nine or ten feet thick, and dip to the west one yard in eight. In various parts are great bars of stone, which cut off the coal; if they bend one way, they influence the coal to rise above one's head; if another, to sink beneath the feet—operations of Nature past my skill to unfold.", on the other side they may have an east rise, which is a west dip; and in general any considerable alteration in the dip is never met with, but what is occasioned by the cir∣cumstances last mentioned.
It is very observable, that in some places near Newcastle upon Tyne there are four different strata or seams of coals, one above another, at considerable distances.
The following occurs in the affidavits of viewers 1722, Sir Robert Raymond's Re∣ports, Walker manor, 1723.
"In Benwell, Elswick, and Fenham collieries, there have been before the working thereof certain seams of coals, called the upper main coal, the metal coal, the stone coal, and the lower main coal."

DIV1.HEAD: HEWING COAL IN THE PIT.
DIV1.L: "Meanwhile the subterraneous city spreads
Its covert streets, and echoes with the noise
Of swarthy slaves and instruments of toil.
They, such the force of Custom's pow'rful laws,
Pursue their footy labours, destitute
Of the sun's cheering light and genial warmth.
—A narrow pass
Once made, wide and more wide the gloomy cave
Stretches its vaulted isles, by numerous hands
Hourly extended—Some the pick-ax ply,
Loos'ning the quarry from its native bed;
Some heave it to th' expectant scale, that waits
With never-ceasing motion from above
To waft it to the light."

DIV3.P: IN the progress of hewing the coal from its bed, the hewer first digs as far as he can into the bottom of the stratum; then he nocks or corners off the part measured out, and afterwards the great coals come away by a wedge or mallet.

The wages of hewers 2s. 8d. for hewing every score or twenty corves
Corf, the name of the basket by which the coals are brought up the shaft of the mine, is a word plainly derived from the Dutch—Korf, a basket.—It may he still traced higher to the Latin Corbis, a basket of twigs. The corf is made of pined hazle rods; the corf-bow of young seasoned saplings of oak, ash, or alder, of the thickness of three inches or more▪ and about two yards long. These bows are sometimes made of iron.
Great care must be taken to keep up the corf; for it is liable to be beaten down daily against the sides of the shaft, and in a little time to lose one third of its proper measure. It is the banksman's office to take care that the corves be properly filled: if any stand be discovered, they are set aside, and the hewer is not paid for them.
The corver, or maker of them, is paid in the following singular way: He is allowed 4½d. for every score of corves that are brought up the shaft, for which he is bound to find the pit with as many corves as are wanted, and also to keep them up to their exact measure, and in good repair. Emerson in his Mechanics tells us, that a cost of coals weighs about five hundred weight, and contains near four bushels and a half. of coals. This a good workman can do in one day.

In high seams or strata the coals are drawn by horses from the hewers to the shaft in sledges; in low seams, on trams
Trams are a kind of sledges on which the coals are brought from the places where they are hewn to the shaft. A tram has four wheels, but a sledge properly so called is drawn by a horse without wheels.
Barrow-men or coal-putters are a sort of labourers who fill the corves, that are set empty upon sledges or trams, with the coals wrought by the hewer, and then draw them, one pulling before and another putting, as they call it, i. e. thrusting behind, along the barrow way to the pit-shaft.
The pit-man always ha his fellow-workman by the title of "Marrow," i. e. "Companion." See Ray's North Country Words.
The word tram occurs in the famous old poem of Christ's Kik on the Green: "Beat on with barrow trams.", pulled by two small cords called soams by a boy before, and pushed on at the same time by another boy from behind. The wages of horse drivers a shilling per diem.

The overman's office is to go through the pit to view the places where the men have wrought, to see that the pit is clear of sulphur, &c. His usual wages ten shillings per week, whether the pit works or not.

The deputy overman superintends the pillars of coal that are left to support the roof of the pit, to set up props where it is loose, and threatens a fall. His usual pay nine shillings per week, whether the pit works or not.
It is the onsetter's business to hang on the corves upon the rope to be drawn up the shaft. Wages 1s. 2d. per diem.

DIV1.HEAD: OF BEASTS AND FOUL AIR IN COAL MINES.
DIV1.L: "And oft a chilling damp or unctuous mist
Loos'd from the crumbling caverns, issues forth,
Stopping the springs ot life—
—To cure this ill
A philosophic art is us'd to drain
The foul imprison'd air, and in its place
Purer convey.—
This from the wind its salutary pow'r
Derives, thy charity to sick'ning crowds,
From cheerful haunts and nature's balmy draughts
Confin'd, O friend of man! illustrious HALESDr. Stephen Hales's ventilator.!"

DIV3.P:
OF the soul or adulterated air
Dr. Black, in his Sad lecture, reduces to the class of biumens that substance frequently found mines, and which renders the working of them dangerous. It is only inflammable substance, so volatile that it is always in form of vapour, and is called fire damp. By its obviours qualities it is dis∣guished from another damp, which is much more common, and has the power of extinguishing flame, as∣sisting of fixed air.
The fire damp issues out of crevices, mves itself with the air of the mine, and when thus mined is dangerous—from experiments an inflammable substance. It appears that it does not take fi un mixed with a considerable proportion of a; but all the risk is from its taking five, which it does, from the flame of a candle, flashing like gunpowder, and producing satefaction of the spand and thus has produced very dreadful effects on the mines and mines. Thought it takes five to flame, yet it is not kindle by the sparke of shut and steed; hence the use of steed mill, whe thi about. In other mines where the vapour is much more scanty, the mines preserved themselves by often fi and thus never allow it to accumulate. It is said to form a whtsh cloud, which ho in the appear of the mine, quire distinct from the an. And I have been told it forms itself ito a little ball; but I th this account can only be true in some parts.
Cavendism, in speaking of some kinds of this vapoer, in the Philosophical Transctions, scuh as that obtained from mettis and putrefying substances, says, it has a remarkable degree of rarity, and, when com∣pared with common air, has only 1 of its weight. This inflammable vapour then, when it rush out, will float to the upper part of the ui, and lodge in any little cavity it may meet with, just water does on the surface of the earth, and will not mix with the surrounding, air, except by means of a little agitation. When it appears in this manner in mis where it is not very cop ous, the miners set fire to it by means or a candle and a long string; but it is g rally most convenient to get quit of it by leading a long wide pipe from the vapour to the external air, and there making at terminate in the ash-pit of a frnace. It this be close in all other places, there will be a constant draught of the vapour from the inferior parts of the mine to ed the fire. In this manner several mines in England are preferred from danger; and what is another advantage, it gives fresh air to the mine.
It is vapour of the same kind which produces a remarkable phaenomenon in particular springs that are and to be inflammable in the neighbourhood of Naples, and several other places. Tde spring surprise , because they appear always bil; and they are more surprised, when upon prtting their hand i to th they si them perfectly ol; and stll mo, when upon the approach of a candle they take flame hoing over the, for some ny. The son of ta the of vapours of this kind, which throw the water into the same it on, as by the ption of its vapours when boiling over the fa and as this vapour is of , re, it does not mix with the water, but rises to the , and is ready to take fiat the approach of a flame., so often troublesome in collieries, there are two kinds, the black damp or styth, which is of a suffocating nature; and the inflammable or combustible damp. In whatever part of any colliery a constant supply or circula∣tion of fresh air is wanting, there some of these damps exist, accumulate in a body, and become noxious or fatal; and wherever there is a good circulation of fresh air, they cannot accumulate, being mixed with and carried away by the stream of air as fast as they generate, or exhale from the strata. Upon these principles are founded the several methods of ventilating a colliery. If at any time the circulation of the fresh
air is not brisk enough, then a large lamp of fire may be placed at the bottom of the pit, which, by rarefying the air there, will make a quicker circulationSee Encyclopaedia, Edinburgh—voce "Coaliery.".

The following account of the damps
The French call the blast "seu brison," and say, that are sh vapour, ptty which, issues out with violence from the chinks and revices of the gall. This vapour is very thunders out with the greatest violence when it carel; fir, and th at knocks down pand it a the workmen who are not careful to throw themselves on their bssy, remarkable, that the ad d vapour exercises all its violence towards the top of the gallery, and a t but little, or not at all, what∣ever has below.
The other kind of vapours by the English stiled damps, the French call "mossres" and "pousse." These vapours do not catch fire; on the contrary, thev extinguish the lamps and candles they meet with, and do not fail to suffocate in a few minutes the labourers that brth them.—They often give warning by a kind of mist; sometimes they are absolutely invisible. See History of Royal Academy of Sciences of for .
"August 22d, 1766, a most malancholy accident at Ch4st le-street, in the community of Durham. The workmen, to the work, and three masons, with as many labors, been coal taking fire by the lamp; when the said lamp being of the son to ly the , the latter in an instant took fire with a terrible, was the puts, destroying , horse, and all in its passage. The noise of the three miles round, and the flash wa as visible as it flash of lightnings. The men by the ol up throgh the start or great rube, like balls out of a cannon, and every demand the same .
"The neighbourhood being alarmed, colk in ; but so and only h, arms, legs, thrown out to a great distance from the morning of the pr. The groad for was covered with timber, coals, &c. All the party , paper yond-prop and , wre swept away, together with the engine for drwing up and d all ." Niw Pap.
"The colliers now," says nnant, Tour, vol 11. p. . k may, for the fire damps, for∣merly to dangerous, are almost overcome; at present the yare prd d by oarded partinon, pla a foot distant from the sides, which cuse a fee Enlation of a thi boas but as still thr are four pla not capable of such conveniencies, the coll, who have not candle in spo wa five damps are supposed to urk, have invented munc to s#ve the purpose of light it is wt they call a fleed null, consisting of a small wheel and a handle, that they with vast tapders a a fl, and the vry great quantity of speak committed had only service for a candle, but has been so and of such a not to set fire to the horrid vapour."
sy, that "formerly th damp of they vapour was conred through pipes to the , and oa I rrible illumination dumme niht, like the eruptions and be the mn who worked at it haled inflammable are, al, if they against pid our a very stream." Ibid." is preserved in the Life of Lord Keeper North, and is dated 1676: "Damps or soul air kill insensibly; sinking another pit, that the air may not stagnate, is an infallible remedy. They are most in very hot weather.
An infallible trial is by a dog, and the candles shew it. They seem to be heavy ful∣phureous air, not fit for breath; and I have heard some say, that they would sometimes lie in the midst of a shaft, and the bottom be clear. The flame of a candle will not kindle them so soon as the snuff; but they have been kindled by the striking fire with a tool.
"The blast is mighty violent, but men have been saved by lying flat on their bellies."

DIV3.HEAD: OF GINS.
DIV3.P: GIN is said with great probability to be a corruption of "engine." See Skinner's Etymology. The glossary to G. Douglas's Virgil says, that the Scots use it in that sense. It occurs among the coal machines in Plott's Staffordshire. There is an engraving of a common coal gin in Emerson's Mechanics, and a description thereof at page 267. The roller is immediately over the shaft, and the track of the horses goes quite round the pit.

There is a sort of gins
Above ground there are two banksmen, who take off the corves at top, and empty, or, as the work∣men call it, "teem" them. They receive for wages 2½d. for every score of corves between them—1½d. is farther allowed for every said score for the banksmen's horse. The drivers of the horses that run in the gin have usually 10d. a day.
When the coals are brought to the pit bottom, the corves or baskets are then hooked on to a chain, and drawn up the pit by a rope to the surface, which is best effected by a machine called a gin, wrought by horses. There are other kinds of gins for drawing coals, some wrought by water, others by the vibrating lever ot a fire engine: but either of these last is only convenient in some particular situations, these wrought by horses being in most general use." Encyclopaedia, Edinburgh, in verbo "Coalery."
"At Walker Colliery," says Wallis in his History of Northumberland, vol. i. p. 128. "there are two ventilators workd with a machine by the help of the fire engine. This machine is also applied to turn a wheel for raising coals, bringing up a cort of twenty pcks an hundred thoms in the space of a minute, the horses moving in a walk."—See the description and drawing of such a machine, &c. by Feen Fitz∣gerald, Esq in the Philosophical Transactions, part ii. for the year 1758, p. 727. called "whim gins," and a kind known by the name of "macaroni gins." In a whim gin the ropes run upon two wheel pullies over the shaft. The roller is at some distance, and the circular track of the horses is not round the shaft. At Long Benton Colliery, as also at Willington, Walker, &c. the coals are brought up by a gin wrought by a little steam engineIn the Universal Magazine for February 1782, is given "An account of a new machine or sue engine, invented by Mr. Thomas Hunt of London, for draining mines and coa-works, and at the same time raising the ore or coal from the bottom of the mine to the surface, without the assisance of horses, or of any additional fuel: with an exact representation of the same engraved on copper."—Two engines on this construction have lately been erected; the one at Killingworth\moor Colhery, belonging to John Pitt, Esq the other on the colhery near Walker, belonging to John Chapman, Esq &c of Newcastle. By this useful invention, a considerable number of horses, that were before employed in those captd collieries, are rendered unnecessary. The same quantity of fuel only is consumed as in the common engine; nor is a greater degree of manual labour required. It can be so contrived, moreover, as to work two shaft, at the same time; and at the fir engine is situated at five or fi hundred yards distance from the shafts, it can with a little additional expence be made to work them both, without the least in∣convenience.. The steam engine-post lifts the water out of what is called "the sump," into a reservoir, so as to be above the water-wheel, which, instead of a horse or horses, turns the gin. A little runner or feeder to supply the reservoir with water, is necessary.

DIV1.HEAD: STEAM ENGINE.
DIV1.L: —And of the flood
Diverted from its course in torrents pours,
Drowning the nether world—to cure this ill,
A philosophic aid is us'd—
—with impetuous force
To raise the gath'ring torrent from the deep.
This— its virtue owes
To air, by heat expanded, and anon
Condens'd by cold, agent to vulgar thought
How seeming weak, in act how pow'rful!
So Providence, by instruments despis'd,
All human force and policy confounds."

DIV3.P:
IN the Marquis of Worcester's Century of Inventions
"LXVIII. An admirable and most forcible way to drive up water by fire, not by drawing or sucking it upwards, for that must be, as the philosopher calleth it, "intra sphaeram activitatis," which is but at such a distance. But this way hath no bounder, it the vessels be strong enough: for I have taken a piece of a whole cannon, whereof the end was burst, and filled it three quarters full of water, stopping and screwing up the broken end, as alls the touch-hole; and making a constant fire under it, within twenty-four hours it burst, and made a great crack: so that having a way to make my vessels, so that they are strengthened by the force within them, and the one to fill after the other. I have seen the water run like constant foun∣tain stream forty feet high: one vessel of water, rarefied by fire, driveth up forty of cold water. And a man that tends the work, is but to turn two cocks, that one vessel of water being consumed, another begins to force and refil with cold water; and so successively the fire being tended and kept constant, which the self-fame person may likewise abundantly perform in the interim between the necessity of turning the said cocks." P. 49. edit. Glasgow, 1761, mo.
In the Universal Magazine for September, 1747, is a plate and account of the engine to raise waters by fire. After mentioning the Marquis of Worcester's invention of it about A. D. 1663, the writer says, it by dormant till Captain Savery, Trasurer to the Sic and Wounded Office, having read the Marquis's book, took the him, and pretended to find out this secret of nature by such chance as upon experiment is found could not give him any idea; and to become the credit thereof to himself, he bought up and urn all the Marquis's books he could find. Thus Captain Savory claimed the credit of this machine to himself, and obtained a patient for the sole ting thereof, as I have been told. The Captain de a grt many experiments to bring this machine to perfection and erected several with good success on gentlemen's sats for private use, but he could never bring it to bear for working of coal pi of mine because such a work required a steam too dangerously strong to be attempted in his way. These discouragements this necessary machine into oblivion, had not Mr. Nwmen, a , a Glazi, at Dartmouth, about thirty-five years A. D. the objection by it to present state, or rather by inventing a new ., of the date of 1655, occurs the first idea of this most useful machine, which is called in the index of that curious little book," A Fire-water Work."

Before the year 1722, the steam engine appears to have been in common use on the collieries in the North
John Bune's affidavit, sworn Dec. 21, 17, respecting calculations of the expence of winning Wt Coty. before it the property of the corporation. A. D. 1716, "which came to 5011l. and the che of water to be drawn by horses, whereas now it may be Sir Robert Raymond's Report.
By the above it appears that Hugh Bethall, Esq then owner (A. D. 1711) of Walker Manor, attempted to sink two pits nigh the windmill there, and adoining to the Shields road; that with great difficulty and the help of two horse g, both going night and day, to draw the water, they sunk about thirty ∣thoms. Ibid.—The working now by fire engines is much cheaper than formerly.
Affidavit of William Cersworth, Esq 172, January the 3d, ibid—Eliwick colsiery was attempted to be won about forty years ago.—The undertakers —The said Elswick Colliery had a few years ago been won, and, by the help of fire engine, was them a working colliry..

The first steam engine that was erected in the North is said to have been built upon a moor called Washington Fell, about nine miles south east of Newcastle upon Tyne, for a colliery upon the river Were. I have seen the remains of the shell of this building.

The next, as I was informed by a very old man concerned in coal-mines, was at Norwood, near Ravensworth Catle, in the same neighbourhoodNewcastle Courant, January 7, 174. "This is to ive notice to all Gentlemen and others, who have for the fire engine or engine for drawing of water from the collieries, &c. to apply to John Porter, in Chester-le st, who is impowered by the proprietors of the said fire engines, to tat the same.".

About the year 1713 or 171, the first fire engineI received this information from Mr. Thomas Aubone, Secretary to the Trinity House. on the north side of the river Tyne is said to have been erected at Biker Colliery, the property of Richard Ridley, Esq The engineer was the reputed son of a Swedish Nobleman, who taught mathe∣matics at Newcastle.

I know not what kind of engines the following were, which are dscribed in the Life of Lord Keeper Nrth, of the date of 1676: "The coal-mines in Lumley Park are the greatest in the north, and produce the best coal. These collieries had but one drain of water drawn by two engines, one of three stories, the other of two. All the pits for two or three miles together were drained into these drains. The engines are placed in the lowest places, that there may be the less way for the water to rise; and if there be a running stream to work the engines, it is happy"He said that chain pps were engine, for they drew constant and even; but they but two of them, the tree of seven or thom, and the deepest sty wrought by buskets and a , with the force at the top."."
The fire engine to raise water is described in Emerson's Mechanics, p. 280. et. 1754, with a plate of it annexed.
A. D. 1773, was published a pamphlet intitled, "A Philosophical Investigation of the Principles of the Fire Engine, by Cuthbert Clarke."

Great improvements appear to have been lately made in this machine by placing the fire nearer to the boiler
In the Newcastle Courant for June , occur the following observations on fire enines, "The ingenuity and utlity of the contrivances of Boulton and W, respecting the fire engine in certain literat, confessed."
A new engine is mentioned to have been caed at Long Benton Colliery, under Mr. Smeaton's direc. with improvements of his own.
Ibid. June , 1779 "The advantages Messis. Boulton and Watt's invention, not de∣rived from any peculiar construction of or their boiler, but in a saving and application of st."
"Mr. Smeaton can la to from the different engines on ad."
Ibid. July 3, 1779, Messis, Boultron and say in a letter, that "Mr. Smeaton has added several new and in ."
Ibid. July 10, 1779, Mr. mon say coals (consumed in the engine) in the year 1771, his improvements reduced to two; and the new principals Boulton and Warta: "
His letter is dated from Austhorpe, 6th of July, 1979, .
The measuring of coals is a subject that has often engaged the attention of the Lee. Many cutious particulars on this head are to be found in Hunter's Collector's and Comptroller's .
With respect to the practice at Newcastle and Seland, in adjusting the proportion between the New¦castle and Winchester or London chaldron, it is as to fifteen for every Winchester chalder ma out in the port of London..

DIV3.HEAD: WAGGONS AND WAGGON WAYS.
DIV3.P: MENTION occurs of "waggons and waines" as used at that time in the coal trade, in Grey's Chorographia, which was printed in the year 1649.

Waggons and waggon waysThe first thing to be done in making a waggon way is to level the ground in such a to take off all sudden ascents and descents; to effet which, it is sometimes necessary, to out through raise an embankment, to carry the road through hollows. The rod shold be about twelve wide, and no part should have a greater descent than of one yard of a hoizontall, nor a greater ascent than of one yard in thirty. After the long and six inches diameter, called sleepers. are laid oss it, twenty-four inches from each other. Upon these sleeper-other pieces of timber, called , of four or five inches square, are laid in a lateral direction four feet distant from each other, for the waggon wheels to run upon; which be∣ing firmly pinned to the sleepers, the road may then be filled with gravl and finished The waggons, which are in the form of a common mill hopper, have tour wheel, either made of solid wood or of iron. The body of the carriage is longer and wider at the top than at the bottom; the waggon usually his a kind of trap-door at the bottom, which, being loosed, permits the to ran out without any trouble. The size of a waggon to carry fifty hundred weight of coal is as follow:
Length at the top 7 feet 9 inches
Breadth at the top 5 feet
Length at the bottom 5 feet
Breadth at the bottom 2 feet 6 inches
Perpendicular ala height 4 feet 3 inches.
Encyclopedia, ut supra.
The fillies or rims of the waggon wheel are hollow, so as to run upon spring, of wood aded there, with which the roads are laid.—", this , Viw of Northumberland, vol. ii p. 417) these carriage with that rapidity that a piece of wood, called a filler, is the attendant, who on it, to reta the motion; by the which the , and some∣times the carriage, "
This piece of wood, in the nature of .
Their . the purpose in the viiniy of Newcastle, easy to conjt that the including of workmen.
Many of the supernuated workmen are employed in layin pan.
When the axle of a loaded waggon breaks, it the waggon men "a d (i. e. cold) pe" have plainly been in use the North A. D. 1676. Lord Keeper Guildford, who was upon the northern circuit that year, thus describes them: "The manner of the carriage is by laying rails of timber from the colliery down to the river, exactly straight and parallel; and bulky carts are made with four rowlets, fitting these rails, whereby the carriage is so easy, that one horse will draw down four or five chaldron of coals, and is an immense benefit to the coal merchants."

The first waggons are said to have wanted the conveniencies of letting out at the bottom, having been emptied with shovels, like the present ballalst waggons. It ap∣pears by the old books of the Hostmen's Company, A. D. 1600, that the then coal
waines contained eight bowls of coals, and some scarce seven bowls. The present waggons contain more than twice that quantity.

In the London Magazine for March, 1764, there is a representation and descrip∣tion of a coal waggon, communicated to the Editors by a Gentleman, who dates from Chester-le-street, 21st of December, 1763, and signs himself

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 312. (From the Original, in the possession of the Draper's Company.)
DIV2.P: IN the name of Gode and of oure Lady Amen The fyrst day of Juyn the yere of oure Lorde Gode M CCCCC and 12 The fremen of the felysshyp of the Drappers Craft of the towne of Newcastell upon Tyne acr agreed that this ordenaunce and articles fol∣lowyng in eschewyng of debat and to noryshe peace and lusse among them and for the mendement and well of the saide craft to be kept and observed in tyme commyng to ye wylke well and trewly to be doone ichone of the said shyp of Drappers haithe bodely sworne upon the holy Evangelists and haith sett yt sealls to the une presents or∣denats And that all others apprentiss of the said craft yt hereafter shal be fremen of the said felyshyp shall do it the same yt interes to the said felyshyp Yes aer ye names of the fremen of the said felishyp of the Drappers craft nowe beyng on lyve the day and makyng herof yt is to saye Johan Pmth John Hallne Robt Band John Haynyng Wil∣liam Eston and George Bernet

DIV3.HEAD: (There follow many other names in a modern hand.)
DIV3.P:
In they fyrst it is acorded and ordeyned by the said felishyp of Drappers craft yt byg by yt manyest voyces of the sayd craft and they two so chosen to passe upon yt election accordyng to ye old and
custom of the sayd towne after the words and intent of oure comon chartur and thay two so chosen and sworne they shall help to elect and chese fourre of ye moost worshypfull best can and best may of the holl comminalte as well of themself as of any other of yt holl cominalte to yr best wyttnyg as yay wyll answar to Gode (and in default that anie of the said companie of Drapers be in the towne and do not come to the Westspitle to chese theire men for the election according to this former order he shall pay as in the way of a fine for the use of the said felishyp the sum of 3s. 4d. without any forgiveness.)

DIV3.HEAD: (In another hand.)
DIV3.P: Alsoo the forsaide felishyp of the saide craft of Drappers ar agreed yt none of the said felishyp take none apprentiss under ye terme of 7 yeres and ye lest at at ye dat of his be∣gynnyng his name and his borowes to be entred and enrolled in a register of the forsaid feliship ordeyned yrfore upon payne of 10sh. to be leved and employed to ye ordinary chargs of the aforsaid feliship of Drappers as oft as any defawte shal be raisonnably proved Alsoo that every apprentiss shal by free at the ende of his terme for 13sh. 4d. and a dynnarr.

Alsoo it is agreed and accorded that everye mane of the said felishyp raisonnably warned by the steward or stewards to assemble for the chefyng of the stewards two au∣ditours and two men chosen to waitte upon ye mayre for yt yere after followyng kept ther houre assynned thaym in ye Masondew upon the Saunde Hyll on the Wensday after that the mayre be chosen upon payne of 6d. as oft as any defawte may be raissonably proved in thaym or in any of the said fellishyp.

Alsoo in case be that hereafter it happen any of the said fellishyp to be chosen mayre schreff chaumerlayn or clerk of the chaumer or any other office accomptable to the com∣minalte of this towne of Newcastell it is ordeyned yt for yt yer yt he shal be so chosen yt he shal be none auditor of the comminaltie of the same towne for yt yer.

Alsoo it is ordeyned by the felyshyp of the said Drappers that the two stewards afore∣named so chosen and the two auditors in lyke case so chosen yt the said felishyp be agreed yt all such money as the auditours receyveth in the audyt tyme to the behuffe of the Drappers shall brynge the same money to the Masondew ye forsaid day and lygge it afore his feliship for his discharge And in lyke case it is ordeyned that the two forsaid stewards so do in lyke case such money as they shall receyve to the behuffe of the said feliship of the Drappers.

Alsoo it is ordeyned by the holl felischip of the Drappers that yff ye fornamed stewards and auditours brynge not in such money as they shall receyve to the behuffe of ye said felishyp in thers recepts as it afore rehersed the forsaid stewards and auditours shall forfett to the felishipp of the Drappers for ye owthaldyng of the said money or any parte yrof 26sh. 8d. for every defawte raisonnably founden in thaym or in any of thaym in tyme comyng.

Alsoo it is ordeyned yt no man from hensfurth shal by admytted for to be fre with the said felishyp of the Drappers to be of ye pryvey counsell nor lit nor election withowten he have ben prentis 7 yeres with one of ye said fellishyp within the said towne without th'assent of the holl felishyp of the said crast or of the most perty of thayme or by the manyest voyecs of the said felliship.

Alsoo it is agreed and ordeyned y• yff any of the said fellishyp from hensfurth pay not his dewtes ne performe not y^ ordennaunces after th'assent effect and entente of the same ordennances yt he shall broke nerecese none benefett in the same craft unto ye tyme yt he have fully payed such dewtes as he owthalds of the said felishyp And alsoo re¦consylled and raisonnably fynned accordyng to hys defawtes.

Alsoo that all thes artycles and condicyons afore rehersed well and trewly shal be performed and kept as fare as ye lawe wyll souffer All we aforenamed hath setto thys ordennence our seals Yeven day and yer aforsaid.

DIV3.HEAD: (There is added in a more modern hand)
DIV3.P: Also it is agrecd this 17 of December A'. 1582 by the hole companye of Drapcrs of this towne of Newcastell upon Tyne nowe resident in the same towne that no brother of the same felowshippe nowe or heareafter to be of the same felowshippe shall att anye tyme or tymes hereafter take or receyve for his apprentyce anye more then on apprentyce beffor that his apprentyce nowe present being bounde to hym for the tearm before in this order mentioned have served his maister by the tearme of 6 yeares fullie to be expired ended and runn otherwise the offender being a brother of the companie and soe offendinge shall forfeite and pay to the use of the companie of this said felowshippe for every offence so by him comitted tenn poundes of good and lawfull monaye of Englande without anie further delay.

Also it is agreed and ordained that all such apprentices as is to be or enjoy any fredome amongst the fellowshippe aforesaid shall within one whole yeare after the expiration of his indenture come in to the said companie for his fredome Or els to pay for his offence in not doing the same the somme of 26sh. 8^d. And also if any do challenge theire freedome by patrimonie and not comeing in upon lawfull warning he shall pay for his offence the somme of thirtie three shillings and fower pence.
DIV3.Q: (The margin on both sides, as well as the bottom of this ordinary, is written over with names in a more modern hand—Persons, as they become brothers of the com∣pany, appear to have signed this original ordinary. Great numbers of seals are affixed to it—some coats of arms, some skin marks.)

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 324. (From the original in the Archives of the Trinity House in Newcastle upon Tyne.)

LETTER.P: EDWARDUS sextus Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Rex, Fidei Defensor et terra ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernice supremum caput Omnibus ad quos presentes littere pavenerint salutem Inspeximus litteras patentes Domini II. er Regis Anglie octavi patris nostri precharissimi de confirmatime in hec verba:

Honrious octavus Dei gratia Anglie et Francie Rex Fidel Defensor Dominus Hibernie et in terra supremum caput Anglicane ecclesie Omnibus ad quos pr tes littere perve∣nerint salutem. Sciatis quod nos de gratia nostra spectali et ob m auratem de∣votionem et effectionem quem ad sanctam et individuun Trinitatem et habemus nec non ut magistri, marinarii, gubernatos, et alii effectur' , catulem su n exercittione gubernationi, navium transigentis, malati aut aliquo alio ponsectatem collapsi, aliquod relevamen ad eorum sustentacionem habeant, quo non , ve∣rum etiam alii juventes magis moveantur et instigentur ad eandem atem ratione cujus doctiores et aptiores fiant navibus et aliis vasis nostris et aliorum quo
gubernandis et monutenendis tam pacis quam belli tempore cum opus postulet Dedimus e∣concessimus ac per presentes damus et concedimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris quan∣tum in nobis est dilectis nobis Ricardo Graye Willielmo Elleson Thome Bell Thome Ciercke Rogero Dekeson Edmundo Person Thome Bakster John Wylkynson Roberto Atkynson Roberto Person Roberto Wright Ricardo Hardyng Johanni Deryke Roberto Lile Johanni Watson Johanni Elleson juniori Thome Shewtforth Roberto Thomson Ricardo Temple Johanni Dor∣rant Georgio Hogeson et Georgio Cooper, quod ipsi ad laudem predicte sancte et individue Trinitatis de seipsis nautis marinariis et aliis personis ligeis nostris tam hominibus quam feminis quandam fraternitatem sive gildam perpetuam in honore sancte et individue Trinitatis predicte in villa Novi Castri super Tynam incipere unire et erigere facere fundare ordinare et stabilire ac ejusmodi personas et alias quascumque que de dicta fra∣ternitate sive gilda esse voluerint in fratres et sorores ejusdem fraternitatis sive gilde admittere et acceptare possint Quodque fratres ec sorores fraternitatis sive gilde illius sic erecte facte fundate ordinate et stabilite et eorum successores unum magistrum et quatuor gardianos ad gubernand' et supervidend' dictam fraternitatem sive gildam necnon ad habendum regimen et custodiam omnium terrarum tenementorum reddit' possessionum bonorum et catallorum que eidem fraternitati sive gilde perquiri dari legari concedi vel assignari contigerint quolibet anno quandocunque eis placuerit de seipsis eligere ordinare et successive constituere ac ipsos magistrum et gardianos seu eorum aliquem de tempore in tempus prout indiguerit seu expediens fuerit amovere expellere et exonerare et alios magistrum et gardianos eorum loco quociens et quando sibi placuerit eligere ponere substituere et subrogare ac communitatem inter seipsos et de seipsis facere unire et unum corpus esse necnon quoddam sigillum commune pro negotiis et aliis causis agendis ejusdem fraternitatis sive gilde habere et exercere valeant imperpetuum Et ulterius de uberiori gratia nostra volumus et concedimus pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est quod iidem magister et gardiani et successores sui qui pro tempore fuerint persone ha∣biles et capaces existant ac nomina magistri et gardianorum fraternitatis sive gilde sancte et individue Trinitatis in villa Novi Castii super Tynam habeant et gerant imperpe∣tuum Et qued iidem magister et gardiani et eorum successores pro dicta fraternitate sive gilda ac pro terris tenementis redditibus possessionibus bonis et catallis frater∣nitatis sive gilde illius in quibuscumque accionibus causis demandis querelis et placitis tam realibus et personalibus quam mixtis cujuscunque generis sive nature fuerint per nomina magistri et gardianorum fraternitatis sive guilde predicte coram quibuscumque justic' sive judicibus spiritualibus et secularibus placitare et implacitari ac respondere et responderi valeant eodem modo quo ceteri ligei nostri persone habiles et capaces placitare et implacitari ac respondere et responderi poterint Quod iidem magister et gardiani ac omnes fratres et sorores ejusdem fraternitatis sive gilde et eorum successores ad dies loca et tempora congrua et oportuna quociens et quando eis placuerit ad tractand' concordand' et com nunicand' inter seipsos una cum aliis pro consilio et advisa∣mento boni status et regiminis fraternitatis sive gilde predicte necnon fratrum et sororum ejusdem et successorum suorum convenire possint ac ad stabiliend' ordinand' et inacti∣tand' taba legitima aus leges et ordinaciones qualia sibi maximè necessaria vide∣buntur tam pro manutenentia navigii nostri n portu de Tynmouth quam pro bonis con∣tinuantia et ordine inter magistros pillotos sive navi gubernatores et marinarios ac etiam pro manutenencia et continuantia predicti portus habend' imperpetuum t ulterius de uberiori gratia nostra predicta concessimus et licentiam dedimus ac pet prelentes concedunus et licentiam damus pro nobis heredibus et successoribus nostris predictas quantum in nobis est quod dem magister et gardiani fratres et sorores frater∣nitatis sive gilde predicte ac eorum successores et assignati ad libitum et voluntatem suam duas turtes unom videlicet in boriali parte de le Shelys apud ingressum portûs dicte ville et aliam super montem ibidem apt' et convenient pro signis, metis et bundis pro salva et
secura custodia ville et portus predictorum necnon subditorum nostrorum ac aliorum in amicitia nostra existen' ad villam et portum predictos confluentium, de petris calce et sabulo melioribus modis et viis quibus sciverint aut poterint fundare edificare facere et con∣struere necnon turres illas batellare turrellare ac easdem turres sic batellatas turrellatas fundatas edificatas factas et constructas tenere et habere pro intentione et proposito predictis sibi et successoribus suis imperpetuum Et quod iidem magister et gardiani fratres et sorores fraternitatis sive gilde predicte ac eorum successores et assignati pro manutenentia turrium et portus predictorum cum perpetuo lumine noctantur manutenend' de qualibet nave aliena quatuor denaries ac de qualibet Anglicana duos denarios ad eundem portum confluentium recipere capere et habere possint absque impedimento perturba∣cione molestatione sive gravamine nostri heredum vel successorum nostrorum aut aliorum quarumcumque Proviso semper quod magistri pilloti sive navium guber∣natores et marinarii predicti ville predicte habeant et quilibet eorum habeat omnia et singula talia custumas subsidia decima avantagia et prosicua qualia ante hec tempore habuerunt et habere consueverunt hac concessione non obstante Proviso semper quod presens concessio nostra pro erectione fundatione et stabilimento fraternitatis sive gilde predicte facta nullo pacto sic interpretetur ut inde aliqua nova exactio aut impositio orietur in alienigenas et extraneos que ullo modo tangere aut quovis modo adversari seu in offendere ligas tractatas et federa pacis et amicitie inter nos et alios reges aut principes quoscumque inita et conclusa possit sed quod tractatus lige et federa predicta semper et omnino remaneant integre intacta et inviolata aliqua re clausula sententia seu materia quacumque superius in hac concessione predicta contenta expressa et specificata non obstante aliquo statuto actu ordinacione provisione sive restrictione in contrarium fact' edit' ordinat' provis' sive restricta in aliquo non obstante. In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes. Teste meipso apud West∣monasterium quinto die Octobris anno regni nostri vicesimo octavo.

Nos autem litteras predictas ac omnia et singula in eisdem content' rat' habentes et gratas ea pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est acceptamus ratificamus et approbamus ac dilectis nobis nunc magistro et gardianis fraternitatis sive gilde predicte et eorum successoribus tenore presentium ratificamus et confirmamus prout littere predicte rationabiliter testantur In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipso apud Westmonasterium vicesimo die Octobris anno regni nostri tertio.

CLOSER.SIGNED:
Examinat' per nos
Ricardum Rede
et Ricardum Lyll
Clericos.

POSTSCRIPT.P: (The greatest part of the seal broken off.)

DIV3.HEAD: From the original in the possession of the Society.
DIV3.P: MARIA Dei gratia Anglie Francie et Hibernie Regina Fidei Defensor, et in terra ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernice supren caput Otibs ad quos pre∣sentes littere littere pervenerint salutem hispeximus literas patentes Dni Emper Regis Anglie sexti fratris nostri precharissimi de conm actas in hec verba.

DIV3.HEAD: (Here follow Edward the Sixth's Confirmation, and Henry the Eighth's Charter.)

LETTER.P:
NOS autem littere predicte ac omnia & singula in eisdem contenta rata habentes et grata ea pro nobis et heredibus nostris quantum in nobis est acceptamus ratificamus &
approbamus ac dilectis nobis nunc magistro & gardianis fraternitatis sive gilde predicte & eorum successoribus tenore presencium ratificamus & confirmamus prout littete pre∣dicte rationabiliter testantur. In cujus rei testimonium has litteras nostras fieri fecimus patentes Teste meipsa apud Westmonasterium vicesimo primo die Martii anno regni nostri primo.

CLOSER.SIGNED:
Examinat' per nos
Willm Grinysted
et Tho. Martyn
Clericos.

LETTER.P: Taxatur finis ad viginti sex folid' quatuor denarios

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 325. From the Black Book of the Trinity-House of Newcastle upon Tyne. (Not complete.)
DIV2.P:
ELIZABETH by the grace of God Queene of Englande France and Irelande Defender of the Faith &c. to all to whome theise presentes shall come greatinge Whereas our dearly beloved father King Henry the Eight late King of England of his liberall grant and gift by his lettres patents bearinge date att Westminster the 5th of October in the eight and twentith year of his raigne did incorporate and make a guilde or brotherhoode of mr. pilats governours of shipes seamen and mariners of our porte of Newcastell upon Tyne by the name of Master & Wardens of the Brotherhoode or Guilde of the holye and undivisible Trynetye in the towne of Newcastell upan Tyne by which grant and name they have remayned a captaine (company) but now the said corporation and companie findinge some imperfections in the same grant which have growen by the alteration of tyme they have made therfore humble suite for a new grant to be made from us whearein the said defects may be refourmed & other things necessare to them may be granted Knowe ye therefore that wee of our especiall grace certaine knowledge and meere motion and uppon the goode likinge and desire we have that good orders should be established & used amongst the companie of the said guild or fraternitie have given & graunted and by these presents do give &c graunt for us our heires & successors as much as in us is to our welbeloved leighe men and subjects Edward Tailer John Michaelson Nicholas Potter Richard Harigade Robert Eringtcn Thomas Fife Thomas Graye James Nicholson Robert Sotheren Robert Johnson Thomas Musgrave Thomas Tucker Roger Raw Thomas Nicholson Edward Barde John Skelton John Bates & Henry Michaelson John Storree & to all other our naturall subjects beinge now shipmasters & pilots seamen of our towne & porte of Newcastell uppon Tine & their inhabitinge that they of themselves or the said Edward Tailer John Michaelson Nicholas Potter &c. or any twelve of them btfore named may of a new begine make found ordaine & establish a perpetuall brotherbood or societye of themselves within the towne of Newcastell upon Tine & that the said nineteen persons before named & their successors to the full
of that nomber be called Elder Brothers & all the rest Younger Brothers of the same bro∣therhood or societye out of which nomber of 19 elder brothers shall or may be therefor yearlie everye year on the Sonday next after Candlemas day or in anie other tyme of the year when for the comoditye of the said brotherhood or societie it shal be thought best & convenient by genarall consent or most voices of the said brotherhoode or societie as well of the younger as of the elder brothers one mr. & two wardens by the name of the Master and Elder Wardens & likewise to elect and chuse out of the younger bretheren two other wardens by the name of Younger Wardens & the same mr. & wardens soe elected and chosen to be governors and to oversee the said brotherhoode or societye & to have the rule & custodie of all lands and tenements revenewes pos∣sessions goods & chattells which to the said guilde or brotherhood lately incorporated & made by our said father K. Henry the Eight as aforesaide heartosor belonginge or that heareafter may happen to be purchased given bequeathed granted or assigned to the said brotherhood or societie to be erected as aforesaide and the same mr. and elder wardens or the mr. or one elder warden & likewise the said younger wardens or one younger warden from tyme to tyme everie yeare att their pleasures & as often as it shall seeme to be most expedient from his office or their offices to remove expell & dis∣charge and also another mr. and two elder wardens or a mr. or on elder warden being elder brothers in the name place and steede or in the names places and steedes of him or they foe removed putt out or discharged and likewise two younger wardens being younger brothers or on younger warden in the name place and steede or in the names places and steades of him or them foe removed putt out or discharged to apoint elect & substitute as often and when as itt shall please them And likewise itt shall be lawfull for the said brotherhoode or societie by a generall consent or most voices of the said companie as well the younger as the elder brothers to elect & chuse yearlie & everye year on the said next Sonday after Candlemas day or in anie other tyme of the year for the comoditie of the said brotherhoode or societie as aforsaide out of the said nomber of elder brothers foure for assistants & likewise oute of the younger brothers other four for assistants and the same assistants as well the elder as the younger or soche or soe manye of them as shal be by the said brotherhoode or societye thoughte mete or convenient from time to time att their pleasures and as often as it shall seeme to be expedient from his or their office romith and place or their offices romithes & places to remove expell & discharge & also others assistant or assistants as well of the younger as elder in the name place and stead or in the names places and steads of him or them soe removed putt owt or discharged to apoint elect and substitute as often & when as itt shall please theim which brotherhood or societye beinge soe begonne erected made founded united & established shal be on bodye & perpetuall comynaltie brother∣hoode or societye & be named & called by the name of Mr. Pilots Seamen of the Ternitie Howse of Newcastle upon Tine & the same brotherhoode or societye & their successors shal be of themselves and shall continue for ever by that name able persons capeable to purchase and receave lands tenements rentes services and other possessions & eride∣mentes whatsoever to hold to them & their successor for ever & that the same brother∣hoode or societie for the tyme beinge in whatsoever our court or courtes of us our heires successors & before whatsoever judge & justices spirituall or temporall whatsoever arcions suites quarellls pleas causes & demands as well all & personall as mixte of what kinde or nature soever they shal be of concerning o touchinge the said brother∣hoode or societie by the name of Mr. Pilots & Seamen of the Trynitie Howse of New∣castell upon Tyne may at all tymes hereafter pleade & be impleaded aunsweare & be aunsweared in suche sorte & by all such means as other our people persons able & sufficient maye plead and be impleaded answer & be answered And it shal be
lawfull for the said mr. wardens & assistantes and elder brothers for to the said mr. two....
I have searched in vain for the original in their archives, which I fear is for ever lost.
Here it ends abruptly. I know not whether this be the original or only a translation.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 326. 18 Jan. 3 J. I. MARINERS' CHARTER. (E Libro irrot seu Chart' antiq' penes Maj' & B. V. N. Castri sup. Tyn. fol. 258.)
DIV2.P:
JAMES by the grace of God of England, Scotland, Fraunce and Ireland, King, Defender of the Faith, to all men to whom these presents shall come, greeting Know yee that we at the humble petition of the companie, misterie, brotherhood and societie of Ship Masters, Pilots and Seamen within the towne and porte of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the countie of the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, as well for the better increase and for the maintenance of our navigation, for the benefitt, defence and preservation of our realme, as also for the better government, rule and order of them and every of them, of our special grace, certaine knowledge, and mere motion, have willed, ordeined, constituted and granted, and by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, do will, ordain, constitute, declare and grant, that all and singular the shipmasters, pilotts and seamen of the said towne and porte of New∣castle upon Tyne, and all the men of the said companie, misterie, brotherhood and society, dwelling or inhabiting within the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne, for ever hereafter for the better government, rule and order of them, and for the profitt, comoditie and reliefe of the good and honest men, and to the feare and terror of evill and wicked offenders, be and shall be by virtue of these presents one bodie corporate and politique in deed and in name by the name of Maister Pilotts and Seamen of the Trinitie House of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of Newcastle upon Tyne, and them by the name of Maister, Pilotts and Seamen of the Trinitie House of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of Newcastle upon Tyne, we do by these presents for us, our heirs and successors, reallie and fullie create, make, ordaine, constitute and declare, one bodie corporate and politique in deed and name, and that by the same name they may have perpetual succession, and that they and their successors by the name of Maister, Pilotts and Seamen of the Trinitie House of Newcastle upon Tyne, in the county of Newcastle upon Tyne, shall be for ever hereafter persons able and capable in lawe to purchase, take, receive and enjoye lands, tenements, rents, services, and other possessions and hereditaments whatsoever, to them and their successors for ever in see or perpetuitie, or for tearme of lives, yeares, or otherwise, in what sort soever. And also all manner of goods, chattells or things whatsoever, of what name, nature, or qualitie soever they be: and also to give, grant, lett, aliene, assigne and dispose of
