means be appointed for bearing or finding of armour or taxed to or with any manner of land service other than as is aforesaid or to be contributary to the same or sumoned or put in assizes juries inquests inquisitions or other recognizances other than as is aforesaid taken or sumoned within the said counties jurisdictions or places where they or any of them shall remaine or abide other than as in regard of their said tenures or for our service att or in the admiralty of assizes or sessions as aforesaid that then the same appointment or sumons and also the said taxation to be utterly void and of none effect any order custom law or usage to the contrary before this time had or used in any of the said counties jurisdictions or places notwithstanding Provided always that if the lords and others of the privy councell of us our heirs or successors or any six or more of them (whereof the lord admiral of England for the time being to be always one) signed with the hands of them or any six or more of them whereof the lord admi∣ral of England for the time being to be one shall att any timeor times will and command the said master pylotts and seamen or any of them to perform execute or do any land service or to be contributary to the charge of any armour munition or any other thing appertaining to such land service that then and so often as the said master pylots and seamen and their successors shall upon and after the receipt of any such warrant perform and execute all and every such thing as shall be comanded and en∣joyned unto them or any of them in and by the same any thing before in these presents to the contrary thereof notwithstanding Provided also and we do hereby reserve unto us our heirs and successors full power and authority from time to time and att all times hereafter by order made in our or their privy councel to remove and declare to be removed any master elder brother elder warden elder assistant younger warden and younger assistant of the said company mistery brotherhood and society and then and from thenceforth the place or office of such person or persons so removed or declared to be removed shall be utterly void without any other process in that behalf and thereupon some other fitt person and persons shall in due manner be elected and sworne by the master pylotts and seamen of the Trinity House of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid into the place or places of such person or persons so removed or declared to be removed according to the true meaning of these presents any thing in these our letters patents or in any other charters or grants of our royall progenitors contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding And further of our like certain knowledge special grace and meer motion for us our heirs and successors we do grant and confirm unto the said master pylotts and seamen and their successors the house called the Trinity House with the said appurtenances and all other lands tenements herediraments pre∣viledges perquisites ancient duties and profits which the said company mistery brother∣hood and society have heretofore lawfully had and enjoyed or whereof they or any of them or any other to and for their uses have heretofore been lawfully seized or possessed and which the said company mistery brotherhood and society at the time of this our grant do lawfully perceive have hold and enjoy Provided always and our royall intent and pleasure is that the severall and respective sums of money hereby granted or men∣tioned to be granted or confirmed to and for the severall and respective uses ends intents and purposes aforesaid are and shall be and that they be received and taken in lieu of
all other duties allowances payments and sms of money heretofore granted or received in that behalf and that no further or other duties or sum or sums of money shall be at any time or times demanded paid or received upon account or for or in respect thereof any thing in these presents contained to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding And our will and pleasure is that these our letters parents shall be good and effectual in the law to all intents respects and purposes unto the said master pylotts and seamen and their successors without issuing out of any writt or writts of ad qued dampnum the statute of mortmain or any other statute act ordinance proclamation provision or restraint thereof heretofore had made set forth ordained or provided or any other thing cause or matter whatsoever to the contrary notwithstanding although expresse mencion of the true yearly value of the premisses or of other gifts or grants by our predecessors heretofore made to the master pylotts and seamen aforesaid in these presents is not made or any statute matter or thing to the contrary thereof notwithstanding In witness whereof we have caused these our letters to be made pattents Witness ourself &c. the first day of July in the third year of our raign.
Examined with the charter the 3d of February 1724. G. GREY.
N.B. The charter is in English.—Sir Robert Shaftoe gave his opinion that this was void, and that the new duties could not be collected.

DIV2.HEAD: APPENDTX, P. 353. WAITS' ORDINARY, (E Libro quinto, fol. 26.)
DIV2.P:
TO all Christian people to whom these presents shall come and cheifely to whom the knowledge thereof shall appertaine Wee Sir Ralph Carr knight, maior, the aldermen and sheriffe of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne in the county of the town of Newcastle upon Tine doe send greeting in our Lord God everlasting Whereas the company of waites and musicioners of the said towne are and have been time out of mind an antient company incorporated by the name of the fellowshipp of waites and musicioners and they haveing casually lost their said ordinary by which they were so incorporated (as is asserted to us) Know yee that wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe upon the humble petition of Robert Word John Bell Thomas Moore Edward Herbert and Thomas Sweeting members of the said societie taking the premisses into our serious consideration doe by these presents grant order establish and decree in manner and forme following First that the said Robert Word John Bell Thomas Moore Edward Herbert and Thomas Sweeting shall be one society and fellowshipp called and knowne by the name of the fel∣lowship or company of waites and musicianers in the said towne of Newcastle upon Tyne aforesaid and that they and their successors of the said fellowship or company soe much as in us lyeth according to the antient customes liberties and lawes of the said towne shall be reputed taken and accepted for ever to be a fellowshipp or company and shall have a perpetual succession within the said towne and county and liberties thereof
as other societies and fellowshipps within the same towne have and that the said Thomas Moore and Edward Harbert shall be stewards for one whole yeare next ensueing the date of those presents and act a convenient place by the said fellowship to be agreed on yearely for ever the said fellowship or society upon the feast day of St. James the apostle in every yeare if it fall not to be upon the Lord's day and if it be then the next day aftere two persons of the said fellowship and company shall be elected and chosen by the said brethren or most part of them as in their discretions they shall thinke most meet to be stewards of the said fellowshipp to rule and governe the said fellowship for the then ensueing yeare And further wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe doe by these presents order and appoint oe much as in us lieth for us and our successors that the said fellowship of waites and musicioners shall and may from henceforth for ever by the name of the stewards and fellowshipp of waites and musicioners of the towne and county of Newcastle upon Tine pro∣secute sue and implead and be prosecuted sued and impleded to be answered and to answer in all manner of actions suites and demands whatsoever within the courts of Newcastle upon Tyne and county of the same And that the said stewards and fellow∣ship of waites and musicioners or major part of them and their successors for ever shall have power and authority to make among themselves such lawful orders and lawes as by them shall bethought fitt and convenient for the well quiet and orderly government of themselves and the transgressors and offenders of or against the said orders acts or lawes to punish by reasonable fines or penalties of money as in the discretion of the said stewards and fellowship of waites and musicioners shall be thought fitt and the trans∣gressors and offenders in such case upon refusall to pay the fine or penalty soe sett on him or them to be utterly removed and putt off and from the said fellowship of waites and musicioners to remaine removed untill such time as he or they hath or have willingly submitted and reconciled himselfe to the said societye or fellowship of waites and musi∣cioners and also payed his or their fine or fines so sett and imposed upon him or them as aforesaid And also that every one of the said fellowship of waites and musicioners when∣soever he or they shall be warned by the stewards of the said fellowship or either of them or any other person by their or any of their appointment to come to any meeting or assembly of the said fellowship of waites and musicioners either for the makeing or esta∣blishing good laws and orders amongst themselves for their well and quiett government or for any other businesse concerninge the said fellowship of waites and musicioners or any of them shall accordingly repaire att the time hour and place appointed by the stewards for the time being or either of them upon the paine and penalty of sixpence to be paid by every brother of the said fellowship of waites and musicioners who shall wilfully neglect to come and upon the paine and penalty of threepence to be paid by every brother of the said fellowship of waites and musicioners that shall come to such assemblies after the houre and time appointed as aforesaid The said paines and penalties to be paid to the laid stewards of the said fellowship and society for the time being upon demand to the use of the said of the said fellowship of waites and musicianers for every time soe offending And wee the said maior aldermen and sheriff doe further order and appoint that whatsoever brother of the said fellowship of W. & M. at any time of their assemblies or conven∣tions shall by uncivill words reproach and revile any brother of the said fellowship of W. & M. such person and persons shall forthwith pay to the said stewarts or one of them demanding the same to the use of the said fellowship for every such offence the sume of two shillings sixpence And that every brother of the said fellowship of H. & M. which att any time of the said assemblies and conventions shall strike smie or beate any brother of the said fellowship of W. & M. shall forthwith upon demand made by the said stewards for me time being or either of them pay to the use of the said fellowship for every such offence the sum of 6s. 3d. and tht party beaten to be left to his remedy at law for his damage And further wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe by these
presents soe much as in us lieth doe order that when any person or persons are or shall be admitted free in or amongst the said fellowship of W. & M. shall pay to the stewards for the use of the company upon such admission to be free amongst them the sume of ten shillings if he or they come in by service to any brother of the said fellowship and in case he come in by patrimony as the sonne of any brother of the said fellowship then to pay on his admission 6s. 8d. And in case he come in att the orders comand and direction of the maior and aldermen of the said towne for the time being or any seven of them whereof the mayor to be one then upon his admission in and amongst the said company, which orders and commands the said fellowship are hereby enjoyned to observe and obey then to pay to the stewards for the use of the said fellowship 20s. and none to be admitted to the benefitt advantage and privilege in and amongst the said company but such as have served or come in by patrimony as aforesaid unlesse the consent approbation orders and commands of the said maior and aldermen be first had and obtained in manner and form aforesaid And further wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe by these presents do order and appoint that no stranger or other person comeing to this towne professing the science of a musician shall be suffered to teach use or exercise the aforesaid science for his benefit and advantage untill he be first licensed and allowed by the maior of this towne for the time being upon paine of twenty shillings for every time soe offending to be paid for the use of the said fellowship And that noe stranger or other person professing the said art shall be suffered to play att any wedding or feast or any other meeting within the said towne and county or liberties thereof unlesse such stranger or other person be allowed by the maior for the time being upon paine of every one offending herein for every such offence to pay 6s. 8d. to the use aforesaid And that noe fidler piper dancer upon pes and others that pretends to have skill in musicke nor any such as goe about with motions or shewes shall att any time hereafter be suffered to practise in this towne or liberties thereof without the license of the maior of the said towne for the time being first had and obtained upon paine of every one offending herein to forfeit ten shillings to the use aforesaid And wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe by these presents as much as in us lieth do for the better maintenance and incourage∣ment of the said waites and musicioners and that they may the better continue to be men of skill and knowledge in musicke order and appoint that if att any marriage within this towne and liberties thereof the persons to be married or any of their friends be disposed to have any musicke that they shall have the waites before any other And if any other do serve att such marriages by the licence and consent of the maior for the time being they shall allow and pay to the said waites 3s. 4d. for every such marriage upon the paine and penalty of ten shillings to be paid by every such person so licensed to serve at such marriages for every time they shall offend herein in the non-payment of the said sume to the use aforesaid All such paines and penalties sume and sumes of money are and shall be had obtained recovered and gotten by action of debt in the court or courts to be held in the Guildhall of the said towne or in such other manner and forme as the maior and aldermen shall appoint nominate and direct Provided always that the said waites and musicioners and their successors shall for ever hereafter be ready and attendant on all occasions to doe and performe their duty in all matters and clauses whatsoever belonging and appertaining to the setie and imployment and observant and obedience to all such orders commands and directions as shall or may be given by the said maior and aldermen otherwise this present grant and authoritie and all things therein contained shall utterly ceale determine and be void whensoever it shall seem fitt and expedient to the said maior aldermine or any seven of them whereof the maior to be one see to expresse and declare and publish the same And wee the said maior aldermen and sheriffe doe order anti appoint that if any controversie shall arise twixt any brethen of the said fellowship or any other person whatsoever about any sines or other things re∣lating
to their fellowship science or imployment that upon application or complaint of the parties grieved to the maior and aldermen and the deliberate hearing thereof whatsoever shall be determined by the said maior and aldermen they shall yeild their conformity there∣unto In witnesse whereof wee the said mayor and aldermen and sheriffe have hereunto sett our hands and caused the seale of maioralty of the said towne of Newcastle upon Tine in such cases used to be hereunto affixed the eighteenth day of September in the 29 yeare of the reigne &c. annoque Domini 1677.

DIV1.HEAD: APPENDIX, P. 359. COOKES ORDINARY. (E libro quarto.)
DIV1.P:
TO all and singuler Christian people whom this our present writeing shall come hear see or reade and chiefey whome the knowledge hereof shall apperteigne Wee John Watson maior of the towne of Newcastle upon Tyne Richard Hodshon Christopher Metford Robert Ellison William Dent Robert Anderson Henry Brandling William Jennison Tho∣mas Liddell William Selby and Henry Anderson the younger aldermen of the saide towne and Roger Rawe shirief of the same towne doe sende due greatinge in our Lord God everlasting Whereas upon the viewe and sight of the writeing of the fundacion of the feloship of cookes of this said towne of Newcastle to us the said maior aldermen and sherife by the same feloshipp of cookes exhibited and presented wee have perceived that the same feloshipp by time out of minde hath been one of the most auncient occupa∣cions of this said towne howbeit in so much as the same writeing of fundacion doth seeme unto us not to be not in such a good order as needeth to be by reason the same lacketh authority from the maior aldermen and sherife or this towne and haveing no manner of words of ratification of them to be a feloshipp under seale as other occupa∣cions by ancient usage in this saide towne haVe and that therefore the same feloshipp humbly requireth of us according to our discretions and the auncient usage and custome of this said towne of Newcastle to amend as cause requireth Therefore wee the said maior aldermen and sherife of Newcastle aforesaid so much as in us lyeth do by these presents order and decree in manner and forme following First that John Robinson Luke Heynynge Thomas Capston Thomas Hynde Roger Perett Edward Tyne∣noweth and Thomas Dods cookes and presentlie free of the said fellowshipp of cookes of Newcastle shall remayne and be as the principall fundacion of the fe∣loship of cooks of Newcastle And that they and their successors of the said fellow∣ship of cookes of Newcaftle aforesaid soe much as in us lyeth shall be from hence∣forth reputed and accepted for ever as the felloshipp of cookes of Newcastle afore∣said in matter and name and to be liable and capable and to have soe much as in us the said maior aldermen and shereise lyeth according to the customes and lawes of this saide towne of Newcastle a perpetuall succession of the said felloshipp of
cookes of Newcastle And yearely the Thursday next after Trinity Sounday they and their successors of the said fellowshipp of cookes at some convenient place within the said towne at their discretions to be appointed quietly and discretly to elect and choose two of the most honest and substantiall persons that are or shall be free of the said fellowshipp of cookes to be two wardens of the same fellowshipp of cookes for the yeare following And they the same wardens yearely in such sort as abovesaid chosen shall take a corporall oath before the said fellowshipp of cookes of Newcastle to their best power and knowledge for the yeare following to rule and governe the same whole fellowshipp of cookes of Newcastle in good quiett order and to see every point and article in this ordinarie conteigned to be observed and kept by every one that is and shall bee free of the same fellowshipp of cookes And likewise every one that is and shall be free of the same fellowshipp of cookes that he shall reverence and obey the wardens of the said fellowship soe chosen for the time being as shall apperteigne and of his parte shall doe accomplish and observe all and every pointe and article in this ordi∣nary conteigned that by him ought to be done accomplished and observed And fur¦ther wee the said maior aldermen and shereife of Newcastle abovesaid doe order and decree by these presents that the said wardens and fellowshipp of cookes of Newcastle by the name of Wardens and Felloshipp of the Cookes of Newcastle aforesaid shall implead and be impleaded seue and be seued within any court of this said town of Newcastle according to the auncient custome of the same And alsoe that none of the said fellowship of cookes in time to come shall foirstall or regrate in the marketts of this towne either flesh or fish to the hurt of the burgesses and commonality of the same towne And alsoe that none of the said felloshipp shall sell either fish or flesh boiled baked rosted or otherwise but that the same be well and duely seazoned and hable to abide the search and proof when as the wardens of the said fellowship or any of them for the time being shall repair to any of them to make proofe of the same upon payne of every time soe offending he or they that so shall offend to pay to the use of the said fellowship 3s. 4d. And that no manner of strangers or others dwellinge in this towne that can skill in cookerie and openlie pro∣sessing the craft of cookes shall openlie occupie the same occupacion as to keep open shop or resse abroad any dinners at marriages burials or churchings within this towne of Newcastle except the same person be first free and be one of the company of the said fellowship of cookes And at the time of the admission of every one that will be free with the said fellowship according to the auncient custome of the said fellowship shall paye to the use of the said fellowship the sum of ten shilings and a dinner to be made to the whole fellowship abovsaid at the charge of him that soe shall be made free and to make oath before the wardens and fellowship aforesaid att his entry to the purpose above declared And alsoe that ne manner of person being not free of the said fellowship of cookes shall cutt any manner of fish on the Sand-hill in the saide towne of Newcastle upon either bord or tall then but only the said fellowship of cookes except the same persons or person pay to the said fellowship of cookes 13d. by yeare And alsoe that all and every person or persons being not free of the said fellowship that doe steep any kinde of fishe and openly doe sell the same fish me sleeped either on the Sand-hill or any other place within this towne of Newcastle shall yearely pay to the use of the said fellowship 13d. And alsoe that all manner of fish that shall be cutt in any of the comon markets of the saide towne that is to say purpose all t shillinge codd or other great fish he that soe shall cutt the same fish shall take for his payns of everie 12d. that the same fish is sold for one penny and alsoe of every purpose to have the synnes and the head and the n∣bles and of every seall to have the head skynne and numbles thereof for their fre with alsoe their penny of every 12d. for the same purpose and seall so sould as above and And alsoe that noe manner of stalles for cookes be kepte from henceforth out of the
shopp stalles of the said cookes within any place of the said towne except the same be for cutting of fish upon the Sand-hill And alsoe all such as not being free of the said fellowship and do sell openlie or privelie abrode any pies or pasties shall pay to the use of the said fellowship of cookes by year 13d. And alsoe that the fsid fellowship of cookes shall yearely of theire owne cost and charge mainteigne and keep the bonefires accord∣ing to the auncient of the said towne one the Sand-Iiill there that is to say one bonefire on the even of the feast of the Nativitie of St. John Baptist commonly called Mdomer even and the other on the even of the feast of St. Peter the Apostle if it shall please the maior and aldermen of the said towne for the time being to have the same bonefires And also the said fellowship of cookes to be readie to sett forth their play among the red of the Corpus Christi plaies to be plaied att all such time and times hereafter att the cast and charge of the said fellowship of cookes whensoever the whole plaies of the said towne shall proceed upon payn to be punished at the discression of the maior and aldermen of the said towne of Newcastle for the time being And bycause that it is requisite that the said wardens and fellowship of cookes should have a most certeine way and means how to recover and gett into their hands such fines as to them chaunces to be due by offences as aforesaid wee the said maior aldermen and sherete do by these presents order and decree that if any of the said fellowship offending as aforesaid or otherwise will nt pay such sume of money as by them and every of them ought to be paid that then and immediately the same person of the said fellowship soe refusing to pay their fines by them due as abovesaid shall be put out of the same fellow∣ship and soe to remaine as none of the said company unto such time as willingly he or they soe offending shall paye their dewe fines to the said fellowship as above∣said And for recovery of all such sume or summes of money as shall hereafter be dewe to the said fellowship by such as are none of the said fellowship the fel∣ship aforesaid by the name of the Wardens and Fellowship of Cookes of the said towne of Newcastle shall and may bring their accion against all and every such person and persons before the maior and sheriefe of this towne in their courts before them or any of them to be holden in the same towne according to the auncient custome of the towne of Newcastle aforesaid amongst other occupacions theire used And that all and singuler such sume and summes of money as aforesaid shall arise and grow to the said wardens and fellowship of cookes shall by the comon assent safelie be put up in a box or chest and to be locked fast with sundry lockes whereof sundry keys thereof to be and the same keys to remaine in the custody of such as shall be appointed by the said wardens and fellowship and he that hath the keping of the box or chest shall not have the keeping of any of the said keys And that the moneys soe put into the said comon box or chist shall in noe manner of wise be undiscretely expended or consumed but onelie to be reserved kept and used about such necessary charges of the said whole fellowship as the fame fellowship from time to time shall have due occasions to disburse and expend about urgent affaires of the said fellowship of cookes or otherwise not to touch the same money And if any ambiguitie question or doubte shall happen to arise hereafter between any person or persons and the said fellowship of cookes concerning any article clawse or sentence contained in the said ordinarie it shall be disceded and ordered by the maior and his bretheren for the time being And further wee the sad M. A. & Sh. of Newcastle aforesaid doe by these presents order and decree that if any brother of the said fellowshipp of cookes that presently either is free or hereafter shall be free of the same fellowship of cookes shall at any time after the date hereof de∣parte out of this towne of Newcastle to inhabit or serve any manner person in in the country that then the said brother of the said fellowship of cookes foe dwelling and serving in the country out of the said towne dreng such time as he the sail brother shall soe bide remain or live in the country shall in noe manner of wise have or enjoy
any kinde or profitt or comoditie ariseing or groweing in the said fellowship of cookes and soe to remaine and be sequestered from the profitt and comoditie unto such time as he the said brother shall retorne and remaine again in the said towne of Newcastle and then to enjoy and have againe such comoditie and profitt in the said fellowship as any bro∣ther of the same fellowship.

In witness whereof wee the said maior aldermen and shereife of the towne of Newcastle aforesaid hereunto have caused the seale of the maioraltie of the said town of Newcastle to be affixed Given the 10th day of September in the seavententh yeare of the reign of our sovereigne Ladie Elizabeth by the grace of God Queine of England France and Ireland Defender of the Faith anno Domini 1575.
(January 14, 1673, this inrollment was.)

DIV1.HEAD: ADDENDA.
DIV1.P: IN the plate of "arms of the corporation of Newcastle, &c." Nos. 8, 9, 10, re∣present shields of arms cut in stone on the north front of Newgate.
In the same plate, Nos. 1, 2, 3, represent arms still preserved in the painted glass windows of Sr. George's porch in St. Nicholas' church.
No. 1, Sr. Oswin or Tinmouth monastery—No. 2, Edward the Confessor—No. 3, St. George.
No. 4, ibid. represents the seal of the borough of Gateshead, from a drawing by Mr. Lambert.
No. 5, ibid. is an unknown shield of arms on the north side of the eastern arch, that supports the steeple of St. Nicholas' church.
No. 6, ibid. is in the centre under the belfry of St. Nicholas'—the arms of Robert Rodes.
No. 7, ibid. represents the same arms as cut in stone under the window on the out∣side of the south cross of St. John's church.

N.B. It appears by an account of the pedigree of Baynebrige, of Wheteley Hill, in the county of Durham, accompanied with sketches of the arms, & that Richard Baynebrige married Agnes, daughter and heir of Robert Rodes, whose coat is blazoned azure, three annulets or, and on a chief argent a greyhound current or, collared gules. Harleian MSS. 1171, p. 70.

Page 570, the 4th line from the bottom, translate, "viz. of every foreign ship, laden with merchandise, and there plying, 12d. of every ship, laden with customable merchandise, there being, 16d.—of every chaldron of sea coals 2d.—of every sack of wool 6d.—of every cask or pipe of wine 6d.—of every last of hides, pitch, tar, or ashes, and frail of onions, 60 barrels to the frail, 20d.—of every 100 sheep-skins 6d.—of every last: of herring, red or barrelled, 20d.—of every 100 of linen cloths, allum, mad∣der, ..... wax..... stone of line, stone of iron, bundie of garlick, dogdraves, knives, bowstaves, glass, sparrs, wainscot, Riga masts, or..... pounds of ginder, galyngal raisins, currants, or stones of lead (quaere plumbs) and a bale of almonds 6d.— of every weigh of onions 8d.—of every boat or hurdle there plying with merchandise 8d.—of every barrel of herring when less than a last 6d.—of every cade of herring when less than a last 1½d.—of every hundred (poreti) sheaves of charcoal, barrels of stur∣geon —grampeys, or porposs; of every woollen cloth coloured or plain; every hundred of cawdrons or pails of honey (meles), stockfish, salt or hops, and every boat having (th'osts) plying or going 4d.—of every dozen of grindstones 3d.—chaldron of salt earth called Rochester arth, charcoal or grain—of every fees of bastes—of every cable bought or ibid—of every hundred of stone, walde, skins and boges, or of battery, 2d."

The Latin copy, from whence the above record was printed, has suffered greatly from the ignorance or inattention of some transcriber.—The text is so corrupt in many places that one cannot even gues at what has been meant. I was favoured with the above conjectural translation of the most material passage by a learned friend who is particu∣larly conversant in the study of ancient records.

"Calverley church in Yorkshire.

"A handsome monument nf various sorts of marble, south side of the altar.—Book, seales, pen and ink, and other emblems carved; in chief an urn.—The inscription on a white marble com∣prtment in front of the altar part of the tomb, from which rises a pyramid of grey murble, thereon the arms of Calverley, sable, an escutcheon and orle of owls argent, with the esecutchcon of Ulster.
DIV1.Q: "Near this place lyes the body of Sir Walter Blackett, of Wallington, in the county of Northumberland, Bart. son of Sir Walter Calverley, Bart. who died February 14th, 1777, aged 69 years."
DIV1.P: Vol. i. pge 390, Hugh Moites A. M. now rector of Graystock, Cumberland.
